projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: THE HISTORY Of the TURKS.
DESCRIBING The Ri≈øe and Ruin, of their fir≈øt Empire in Per≈øia; the Original of their Second.
CONTAINING The Lives and Reigns of their ≈øeveral Kings and Emperors, from Ottoman its fir≈øt Founder to this pre≈øent Year, 1683.
BEING A Succinct Series of Hi≈øtory, of all their Wars (Forreign and Dome≈øtick) Policies, Cu≈øtoms, Religion and Manners; with what el≈øe is worthy of Note, in that great Empire.
LONDON, Printed by Ralph Holt, for Toomas Pa≈ø≈øenger upon London-Bridge, William Thackery in Dack-Lane, and Toomas Sawbridge in Little-Brittain, 1683.

div.head: TO THE READER.
div.p:
SInce the late Alarms the Port has given to Chri≈øtendom, I have thought it both Profitable and Convenient, to de≈øcribe the Original of that Great Empire, which now ≈øpreads over near half the World, and to demon≈øtrate by what means it a≈øpired to its Immen≈øity, and by what Policies maintained; as in
the Series of this Hi≈øtory, it is fully and at large di≈øcour≈øed; not ≈øo only, but the Turks various Succe≈ø≈øes in their Wars at Land and Sea; Including their Religious Cu≈øtoms, Manners, and extent of that Empire, as it remains at this day; being deduced from the Original of the fir≈øt and ≈øecond Empire, for the ≈øpace of ≈øix hundred years, attended with Circum≈øtances too tedious here to be recited. So that all may plainly comprehend how ea≈øily tho≈øe Infidels might at fir≈øt
have been hindred from Incroaching, and how often (had not the Divi≈øions of the Christians, upon which they founded their Empire) they might have been brought low; but as God, in who≈øe Eternal Wi≈ødom all Affairs are centered, has not of late permited, and ≈øhould they extend their Arms (as at this time they threaten) yet a hearty Unanimity in the Empire, and the Kings and Princes of Christendom, may through God's ble≈ø≈øing impede the growing Greatne≈øs of this great
Monarch, and hinder the Effu≈øion of Chri≈øtian Blood. Here you have an impartial Account of their Ri≈øe and Ruin in the fir≈øt Empire, and the Continuation of the ≈øecond, to this pre≈øent time; Faithfully Collected, which I hope will prove to the Satisfaction of the Ingenious Reader, which is all de≈øired by,

div.head: CHAP. XXVI.
div.p: A De≈øcription of the Power, Policies, Forces, Revenues, Religion, and Greatne≈øs of the Ottoman Empire, and by what means it ≈øub≈øi≈øts, and maintains its Grandeur, &c. p. 378. part 2.
THE HISTORY OF THE TURKS.
DESCRIBING The Ri≈øe and Ruin of their fir≈øt Empire in Per≈øia; the Original of their Second.
CONTAINING The Lives and Reigns of their ≈øeveral Kings and Emperours, from Ottoman its fir≈øt Founder to this pre≈øent Year, 1683.
BEING A Succinct Series of Hi≈øtory, of all their Wars (Forreign and Dome≈øtick) Policies, Cu≈øtoms, Religion and Manners; with what el≈øe is worthy of Note in that Great Empire.

WITH A Continuation of the Hi≈øtory to this pre≈øent time; Containing the Remarkable Siege of Vienna for Sixty dayes, the rai≈øing of it by the Imperial Forces, and the King of Poland: The Ruine of their Army before it, and a Second Fight in German; with their Succe≈øsful Entrance into the Bowels of Hungaria. Together with a Table to the whole Book.
LONDON, Printed by Ralph Holt and John Richard≈øon, for Thomas Pa≈ø≈øinger upon London Bridge, William, Thackery in Duck-Lane, and Thomas Sawbridge in Little-Britain, 1684.

div.head: CHAP. I. The Original of the Turks according to the Opinion of ≈øundry Learned Authors, with the Means by which they acquired their fir≈øt Monarchy in Per≈øia; Together with the Reign and Death of Tangrolipix their fir≈øt King.
div.p:
IT has, and at this day does cau≈øe ≈øundry Di≈øputes among≈øt the Learned, from what Nation or People the Turks, now ≈øo formidable by extending their Empire o're a third part of the known World, are ≈øprung or derived; ≈øome being of opinion that they are de≈øcended of the Remnant of the Trojans that ≈øcaped the Sword at the De≈øtructiou of the City of Troy, and ≈øtrengthen their Argument with this Rea≈øon, viz. That the Word Turcii ≈øignifying a Trojan, is corruptly called Turci or Turk, and that on
all hands it is affirmed that they originally inhabited the le≈ø≈øer A≈øia, where the City ≈øo much Renowned in Story for its holding out a ten years Siege again≈øt the Power of the then Grecian Empire ≈øtood; others affirm they ≈øprung from the ten Tribes carried away captive by Salmana≈øer the A≈ø≈øyrian King, and that from them likewi≈øe ≈øprung the Tartars inhabiting the Northern Climes, and their Rea≈øons are, for as much as the great Lords of Tartary derive their Pedigree from Tribes, calling them≈øelves Dani≈øts, Zebulonians and Napthali≈øts, and that the Word Turk in the Hebrew ≈øignifies a bani≈øhed man, or one in di≈øgrace; and further, that they ≈øtill retain many Ceremonies of the Jewi≈øh Nation, as Circumci≈øion, and the like, as al≈øo frequently to repeat to them≈øelves Lamentations, though corruptly for the fall of Jeru≈øalem, and Dama≈øcus the chief Cities of Judea and Syria, affirming they know not the meaning of ≈øuch their Lamentations, but that they have been taught of their Ance≈øtors ≈øo to do. Others are of Opinion that they were Scythians, who left their Country by rea≈øon of the Scarcity thereof, and Coldne≈øs of the Clime, and falling on Armenia, gra≈øped it with ≈øo hard a hand, that all the Power of the Roman Empire then flouri≈øhing could not re≈øcue it, but as a Token of their fir≈øt Succe≈øs in their i≈ø≈øuing out of the Ca≈øpian Straits, they named it Turcomania, which name remains to this day. And that there were ≈øuch a People long before their a≈øpiring to Empire in A≈øia, Pomponius Mella, Pliny, and Ptolomy do aver; but about the time of their Eruption, Blondus Platina, and Segonius di≈øagree, the two former declaring it to be in the year of our Lord 755, and the latter in 844. yet conclude upon the rea≈øon of their coming forth as afore≈øaid.

Their Ri≈øe and a≈øpiring to Greatne≈øs, was after this manner; Mahomet the per≈øian Sultan wre≈øting the Government
from the Caliph or Succe≈ø≈øor of Mahomet the Impo≈øtor, or as they fal≈øly called him, their Great Prophet, who≈øe Erroneous Doctrine had infected all A≈øia, Affrick, and part of Europe, to provide again≈øt the wor≈øt ≈øtrengthned him≈øelf, and the better to do it, ≈øent to the Turki≈øh Chief in Armenia to furni≈øh him with a competent number of Men of War, who in compliance to the Sultans Command cau≈øed 3000 to March under the Leading of one of his chief Captains named Tangrolipix, by the help of which he overthrew the Caliph of Babylon, with an incredible Slaughter of his Army; and being further minded to make an Expedition again≈øt the Indians that bordered his Country, and knowing by Experience the great courage of the Turks, and their ≈øingular dexterity in Archery, he re≈øolved to retain them for his further Service; ≈øo that when they de≈øired to be conducted over the River Araxis, he not only refu≈øed to permit it, but al≈øo threatned them, if they offered to make any further mention of their departure, which Indignity cau≈øed them to take the opportunity of withdrawing them≈øelves into the De≈øart of Caranonitis, and there like Out-laws to live upon Spoil; the News of which no ≈øooner reached the Sultan's ear, but he commanded ten of his Captains to March again≈øt Tangrolipix with an Army of 20000 choice Soldiers compo≈øed of divers Nations, which Incamping by the border of a Forre≈øt, wherein the Turki≈øh Captain re≈øided with his Forces, they were in the dead of the night ≈øet upon and put to flight with great Slaughter; ≈øo that the Turks furni≈øhing them≈øelves with the Spoyls of the ≈ølain appeared more boldly in the Field, and were in a ≈øhort time increa≈øed to 50000 fighting men by ≈øuch Outlaws and other Villains, as upon the bruit of their Succe≈øs re≈øorted to 'um, which cau≈øed Mahomet, now jealous of his other Subjects revolt to rai≈øe a great Army and to advance again≈øt Ta ‚Ä¢
grolipix
Fir≈øt, having put out the Eyes of tho≈øe Captains overthrown in the fight, and threatned to di≈øgrace the Souldiers that e≈øcaped the ≈ølaughter by attiring them in Womans Apparel, which afterward redounded to his lo≈øs by cau≈øing them to avoid future puni≈øhment to fly to his Enemy. In fine, both Armies met on the great Plain before the City I≈øpahan in Per≈øia, and began a dreadful Battle, which with great Slaughter la≈øted till Sultan Mahomet fell from his Hor≈øe, and broak his neck, at what time both Armies cea≈øed from fight, and by unanimous con≈øent cho≈øe Tangrolipix Sultan of Per≈øia, and the Dominions appertaining to that large Kingdom, who was no ≈øooner ≈øeated in his Throne, but he cau≈øed the Garri≈øons that kept the Pa≈ø≈øage over Araxis to be removed, and called in the Turks his Country-men then dwelling on the other ≈øide, and by degrees advanced them to all the chief Places of Tru≈øt, depo≈øing the Per≈øians and Sarazens, the Ancient Inhabitants of tho≈øe Dominions; but long he had not wielded his Scepter e'r he made War upon Pi≈øa≈øiris the Caliph of Babylon, and after ≈øundry Battles having ≈ølain him annexed his Kingdom to Per≈øia.

This Succe≈øs firing him with a de≈øire to extend his Dominions wider, he ≈øent Cutlu-Mu≈øes his Nephew to war on the Arabians, but tho≈øe People as dexterous in Archery as the Turks ≈øoon overthrew him with the ≈ølaughter of a great part of his Army, and therefore in his Return reque≈øted of Stephen the Greek Emperours Lievtenant in Media, that he might pa≈øs through tho≈øe Territories into his own Country; but he not only denied him pa≈ø≈øage, but oppo≈øed him with a powerful Army, which was by the Turks defeated, and the Lievtenant taken Pri≈øoner: After which the Sultan in Per≈øon made an Expedition again≈øt the Arabians, thinking to revenge the late di≈øgrace, but procured a greater for him≈øelf, was likewi≈øe overthrown, which
cau≈øed him to bend his Forces to the Conque≈øt of Media, to effect which he ≈øent his Brother A≈øan, but in the mean while his Nephew fearing his di≈øplea≈øure for di≈øobeying his Command fled, and gathering to him a ≈øtrong Power, ≈øeized on Pa≈øar a ≈øtrong City of Chora≈ømians, yet the Expedition was not thereby ob≈øtructed; but his Army had ≈øcarce entred the Confines of Media before the Emperor's new Lievtenant gave Battle, and put the Turks to flight following the Execution for many miles.

This defeat inraged the Sultan, and cau≈øed him to ≈øend an Army double the number of the former under the Conduct of Humbramy-Alim his other Brother, who after ≈øix days Siege took Arzen a Town rich in Merchandize, but the Lievtenant having joyned his Forces with tho≈øe of Liperates Governour of Iberia, who came to his A≈ø≈øi≈øtance, the Battle was joyned, which continued bloody and doubtful for the ≈øpace of four hours, at the end of which the Victory fell to the Chri≈øtians, who followed the Execution till Night put an end to it, yet Liperates fighting valiantly was taken and carried into Per≈øia, for who≈øe Ran≈øom the Emperor ≈øent great Pre≈øents; but the Sultan out of a generous bravery ≈øent him home Ran≈øom-free, only admoni≈øhing never to bear Arms again≈øt him more, and with him ≈øent Seriph a Mahumetan Prie≈øt as his Amba≈ø≈øador, to demand of the Emperor that he would become Tributary to the Sultan, and that thereby an Eternal Peace might i≈ø≈øue, which the Emperor rejected with ju≈øt di≈ødain. Whereupon the Sultan invaded the Roman Provinces with great Forces, but under≈øtanding upon his approaching Cae≈øarea that the Emperor's Army was upon the March, re≈øolving to give him Battle, and that if he ≈øhould be overthrown there was little hopes of retreating by rea≈øon he had left ≈øo many Enemies at his back, he returned into Media and laid Siege to the
≈øtrong City of Mantizichiert, furiou≈øly a≈ø≈øaulting it for thirty days without intermi≈ø≈øion; but after the lo≈øs of Alean his chief Captain, and 20000 Turks and Per≈øians he in great perplexity rai≈øed the Siege, and upon his return being di≈øplea≈øed with his Brother Habraim-Alim, he fled by Night and joyned ≈øuch Forces as he could rai≈øe with Cutlu Mu≈øes, again≈øt whom the Sultan marched, and overthrowing them in plain Battle took Habraim Pri≈øoner, and immediatly commanded his head to be ≈øtruck off, when in the mean while Cutlu Mu≈øes, and his Cou≈øin Melech fled into Armenia with the remainder of the broken Army, and from thence ≈øent Amba≈ø≈øadors to the Greek Emperor to take them into protection, but the Sultan following them clo≈øe with his Army, they removed from thence and fled into Arabia, upon which the Sultan leaving the pur≈øuit, turned his Army upon Iberia and wa≈øted the Country with fire and ≈øword in many places; but upon the approach of Acoluthus the Emperor's Lievtenant he retired to Tauris, leaving behind him one Sannich with 3000 Turks to infe≈øt the Imperial Territories. At which time the Emperor Constantius died, leaving his Empre≈øs and three Children, the former being obliged in an Oath not to marry, though afterwards that Oath was di≈øpen≈øed with by the Patriarch, and ≈øhe married to one Diogines whom ≈øhe pardoned as the Sentence of death was about to pa≈øs upon him for con≈øpiracy to di≈ømember the Empire: So that he being proclaimed Emperor, advanced with an Army again≈øt the Turks pa≈øting over into A≈øia, where they were wa≈øting the Provinces with fire and ≈øword, upon who≈øe approach the Sultan doubting the Event, ≈øent one part of his Army into the South, and the other into the North, the latter ≈øurpri≈øing upon its arrival new Cae≈øarea, and ≈øo laded with rich Booties departed, upon notice of which the Emperor pur≈øued them, and after a ≈øharp Incounter
put them to flight, recovering the Booty and Pri≈øoners, at which time the City of Hierapolis was ≈øurrendred to him, and many other Cities which the Turks had taken; and then dividing his Army, pa≈øt on with one part of it to Syria, and left the other part to defend the new Conque≈øt, which in his ab≈øence was overthrown by the Turks, upon News of which the Governour of Aleppo revolted from him. But whil≈øt the Turks ≈øuppo≈øed they had him in a Toil, he without any noi≈øe fell in with their Army and put them to flight, making great ≈ølaughter of ≈øuch as fled, and then receiving the Homage of the ≈øeveral Countries he pa≈ø≈øed through, he came to Alexandria in Caelicia, and there quartered his Army, and ≈øo returned to Con≈øtantinople.

The Emperor having recruited him≈øelf all Winter, early in the Spring ha≈øted to his Army to oppo≈øe the Turks that were abroad ravaging the Country about new Cae≈øaria, and after having repre≈ø≈øed them pa≈ø≈øed on to the River Euphrates, where leaving part of his Army with his Lievtenant for ≈øecuring the Frontires, he retired into Capadocia; but in his ab≈øence his Lievtenant was routed by the Turki≈øh Army which the Emperor under≈øtanding at Sabestia, he ≈øent the Governour of Antioch with part of his Army to oppo≈øe them at Mop≈øiphestia, but they before were broken by the Armenians, who had took from them the rich Booties they had acquired by the Sacks of many Cities.

And thus this Emperour continued to defend the Roman Provinces with great Succe≈øs again≈øt the powerful Forces of a furious Adver≈øary all the Reign of Tangrolipix the fir≈øt Turki≈øh Sultan of Per≈øia.

div.head: CHAP. II. The Reign and Memorable Atchievements of Axan the ≈øecond Turki≈øh King or Sultan of Per≈øia. The Divi≈øion of the Turki≈øh Monarcby, and the Expedition of the Chri≈øtians unto the Holy Land, in order to regain it from the Turks.
div.p:
TAngrolipix being dead, his Son Axan was cho≈øen by the general Con≈øent of the Souldiery, Sultan in his ≈øtead, who ≈øent his Amba≈ø≈øadors immediately upon his Election to the Emperor Diogenes to conclude a Peace, but ≈øome of his Coun≈øellers per≈øwaded him that thereby the Turk only ≈øought to gain time till he could increa≈øe his Army, in≈øomuch that the Treaty broke off abruptly, though in an ill time, for the Emperor had ≈øent away part of his Army, yet was he ≈øpurred on to ingage the Turks by ≈øuch of his Predece≈ø≈øors Relations as envied his Greatne≈øs, and after Battle joyned, the Turks retiring, the Emperor ≈øuppo≈øed they did it to fetch a Compa≈øs, in order to ≈øurprize his Camp, and thereupon him≈øelf cau≈øed a Retreat to be ≈øounded, which John Ducas his Predece≈ø≈øor's Brother and his Cae≈øar, under who≈øe command a great part of the Army was, perceiving, laid hold of that opportunity to ruin the Emperor by, turned Tail and commanded a Retreat to be ≈øounded, which created ≈øo general a fear in the Army, that they fled in all Parts, the Emperor not being able to ≈øtay their flight, which unexpected advantage the Sultan perceiving, charged with fury upon the Chri≈øtians; ≈øo that the Emperor fighting with a brave re≈øolution among≈øt the thicke≈øt Squadrons, was at la≈øt taken Pri≈øoner, together with ≈øeveral of his
great Commanders after ≈øeveral wounds received, yet comforted by the Sultan, and within a while honourably di≈ømi≈øs'd, when during the time of his Captivity John Ducas his Cae≈øar, P≈øellus one of the Senators, and other of the Faction had thru≈øt the Empre≈øs into a Mona≈øtery, and proclaimed Michael Ducas her Elde≈øt Son Emperor, and when they heard that the Emperor Diogenes was at liberty, they ≈øent out Letters to the Lievtenants of the Provinces to apprehend him which made him gather a great Power, but being di≈øcomfitted by Andronicus the Elde≈øt Son of John Ducas, he was forced to re≈øign his Claim to the Empire; nor were his Enemies content with that, but afterward put out his eyes in ≈øuch ≈øort that he died mi≈øerably. To revenge which by rea≈øon of a perpetual League made at his di≈ømi≈ø≈øion, the Sultan with great Forces invaded the Roman Provinces, whereupon ≈øeveral Battels were fought with various Succe≈øs; in which the Cae≈øar and Ro≈øelius the Emperor's Lievtenant were taken, but both ran≈øomed, the former by the Emperor, the latter by his Wife.

The Affairs between the Empire and Sultan of Per≈øia being at this pa≈øs gave Cuthu Mu≈øes opportunity to ≈øtrengthen him≈øelf, in≈øomuch that re≈øolving to ca≈øt a Hazard for the Per≈øian Dominion, he drew his Army into the Field, near the City of Eres, to encounter which the Sultan likewi≈øe drew forth his; but (fatal to Chri≈øtendom) ju≈øt as they were about to give Battel, the Caliph of Babylon, who as Prie≈øt of Mahomet, was held in great E≈øteem among≈øt the Infidels, came running between either Army, and conjured them not to weaken the Religion of their great Prophet by ≈øhedding each others blood, but rather ≈øtand to his award; the which they having con≈øented to do, he in≈øtantly decreed that the Sultan ≈øhould quietly enjoy what ever he po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed, and that his Couzen aided by him
≈øhould po≈ø≈øe≈øs in him≈øelf and Po≈øterity what≈øoever ≈øhould thenceforward be gained from the Chri≈øtians, upon which the Chri≈øtians were on all ≈øides invaded by the Turks and Sarazens, their own Divi≈øions in many Parts rendring them ea≈øie to be ≈øubdued: So that the Turki≈øh Empire ≈øpreading wide, the Chri≈øtians were grievou≈øly oppre≈ø≈øed, e≈øpecially in the Holy Land, which cau≈øed them to ≈øend a Letter filled with Lamentations, by one Peter a Hermit to Pope ∆≤rban the Second, who taking their ≈øufferings into con≈øideration, called a Council at Charemont in France, at which were pre≈øent upwards of three hundred Bi≈øhops, be≈øides ≈øeveral Princes; when to ≈øtir them up, he cau≈øed the Patriarch of Jeru≈øalem's Letter, and other Letters to be publickly read; as likewi≈øe ordered the Hermit to relate the deplorable ≈øtate of the Chri≈øtians, ≈øuffering under the cruelty of the Infidels, which with ≈øuch Eloquence and feeling commi≈øeration he delivered, that it moved the hearts of all pre≈øent; nor was the Pope him≈øelf wanting to exhort them to ≈øtir up the Chri≈øtian Princes to undertake a War for the deliverance of the Ea≈øtern Chri≈øtians, which was ≈øo effectually ordered, that within a ≈øhort time an Army of 300000 men were rai≈øed, wearing on their brea≈øts red Cro≈ø≈øes, under the Lead of Godfry of Bulloin, Duke of Lorrain, and his two Brothers Eu≈øtace and Baldwin, Hugh the French King's Brother, Raymond and Robert Earls of Flanders, Robert Duke of Normandy, Son to the Conqueror, Stephen Devalois, Earl of Chartiers, Ademar the Pope's Legate, Bi≈øhop of Podie, with many other honourable Princes and expert Warriours, who pa≈ø≈øing through part of the Greek Empire, with a Promi≈øe from Alexus the Emperor, that they ≈øhould be from time to time provided with nece≈ø≈øaries, they pa≈ø≈øed over the Helle≈øpont with their Armies, covering the Shores of A≈øia to the great Terror of the Turks and Sarazens,
who notwith≈øtanding to oppo≈øe the Tempe≈øt of War, which from Europe threatned their overthrow; they gathered huge Forces, and falling upon part of Peter the Hermit's Army, which was too far advanced before the re≈øt of the Princes, and con≈øi≈øted of forty thou≈øand men rai≈øed in the Territories of the Church, they cut them off, and cau≈øed him with the remainder to betake him≈øelf to Civite, a Town before abandoned by the Turks, where he ≈øtayed till the Arrival of Duke Godfry.

This Lo≈øs in≈øpired the Chri≈øtians with rage and de≈øire of revenge, ≈øo far that they made a terrible de≈øtruction in all places, when in their Progre≈øs they had notice that Cutlu Mu≈øes the mo≈øt politick Prince of the Turks was dead, and had left large Dominions to his Son Solyman, of the Proceedings during who≈øe Reign I ≈øhall treat in the following Chapter.

div.head: CHAP. III. The Reign of Solyman Son to Cutlu Mu≈øes, his Wars with the Chri≈øtians, their taking of Jeru≈øalem from the Infidels, their various Succe≈øs in the Holy Land again≈øt the Turks, Sarazens, &c.
div.p:
C∆≤tlu Mu≈øes Nephew to Tangrolipix having as afore≈øaid accorded with the Sultan by the means of the Babyloni≈øh Caliph, he by his Aid won many Provinces from the Chri≈øtians, which were now left in the po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of his Son Solyman. The Chri≈øtian Army re≈øolved to recover them again if po≈ø≈øible, and he as ob≈øtinately to defend what he had in po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion: So that
gathering huge Forces with which he approach'd Nicea where the Chri≈øtian Army lay in Leaguer, Anno 1097. and after on the Fifth of July took it, having ≈øpent fifty days in the Siege, but were well recompen≈øed by the rich Booties they found in it, and among≈øt the re≈øt Solyman's Wife and two Children, which they ≈øent Pri≈øoners to Con≈øtantinople; yet the bad Succe≈øs put not a ≈øtop to the advancement of Solyman with the whole power of the le≈ø≈øer A≈øia, con≈øi≈øting of 60000 Hor≈øe and Foot; So that within a ≈øhort ≈øpace the Battle began with great fury on both ≈øides, the Chri≈øtians eager to revenge their Fellows ≈øo lately ≈ølain, and the Turks to ≈øecure their Country, made horrible ≈ølaughter, but after a long and ob≈øtinate fight, where nothing but blood and ≈ølaughter appeared, nor nothing but cries and dying groans to be heard, the Turks were put to flight; the Chri≈øtians following the Execution, ≈øo that 40000 of them fell in the Battel and pur≈øuit. Though Solyman flying with the remainder of his broken Army, gave out that him≈øelf had Victory on his ≈øide, the le≈øs to di≈ømay his Subjects; yet ≈øo far the Terror of the Chri≈øtians wrought, that the Infidels fled into fenced Cities, leaving the Villages de≈øolate; whereupon they be≈øieged Antioch, which with little difficulty they ≈øubdued, being joyfully received by the Chri≈øtians there dwelling; next Iconium and Heraclea, two Cities of note ≈øurrendred upon Summons. Solyman ≈øtill flying before the Victors, and duly ≈øending Letters to his Couzen Axan the Per≈øian Sultan for Aid; but he not being able to ≈øupply him again≈øt ≈øuch powerful Opponents, the Chri≈øtians recovered all that had been torn from the Greek Empire, the which according to their Contract made with the Emperor they re≈øtored.

The Princes thus Victorious in A≈øia, called a Council, in which it was decreed that an Oath ≈øhould be admini≈øtred as well to the Princes Commanders as to the
common Soldiers, that none ≈øhould return till they had won Jeru≈øalem, which was joyfully embraced.

And now the Turks perceiving they were no ways able to oppo≈øe the Chri≈øtians in open fight, endeavoured to ≈øurpri≈øe and cut off as many as they might by Ambu≈øhment, and therefore ≈øent ≈øeveral ≈øtragling Troops to face Antioch, upon which the Flemins ≈øallied and followed hard till within the danger of the Ambu≈øh, where they had been inevitably lo≈øt, had not the Citizens, who were Chri≈øtians, timely come in to their a≈ø≈øi≈øtance, and put the Turks to flight, and then the Armies drawing forth, marched as far as the River Orontes before they met with any re≈øi≈øtance, but there the Turks had fortified the Bridge and Banks on the other ≈øide, but being overwhelmed with ≈øhowers of Engli≈øh Arrows ≈øent from the Squadron commanded by Robert Duke of Normandy, they ≈øoon gave ground, and left the Pa≈ø≈øage open, and ≈øo the Princes pa≈ø≈øing the River, came to the other Antioch in Syria, of which one Ca≈ø≈øianu was Governour, to the Relief of which the Turks came with an Army of 100000 Hor≈øe and Foot, but were repul≈øed by the Chri≈øtians, and returned with 20000 le≈øs than they brought; ≈øo that the City on the third day of June, 1098. was ≈øecretly and contrary to the knowledge of the Governour delivered by one Phirrus to Prince Bohemund of Tarentum, who furiou≈øly entering a di≈ømal ≈ølaughter en≈øued, in≈øomuch that the Streets run with blood. The Governour upon notice of what had hapned fled, but falling into the hand of the Armenians that were expelled Jeru≈øalem, he was ≈ølain.

The lo≈øs of Antioch being made known to Corbanus the Per≈øian Sultan's Lievetenant, as he lay before Ede≈ø≈øa, he rai≈øed the Sige, and with all his Forces marched towards Antioch, re≈øolving to put all upon the Hazard of a Battle, again≈øt whom the Princes drew out their
Strengths, leaving the Earl of Tholous with a competent number to ≈øecure the City from a revolt, by rea≈øon the Turks ≈øtill held the Ca≈øtle, and after a long and doubtful fight overthrowing with ≈øuch incredible ≈ølaughter of his men, that all the Valleys were filled with blood and bodies of the ≈ølain, 100000 Turks being adjudged to fall in that Battel, and not above 4000 Chri≈øtians, and the next day they took 5000 Cammels with their lading, as al≈øo a new Ca≈øtle built but the year before by the afore≈øaid Lievtenant. And thus conquering they pa≈ø≈øed on taking ≈øeveral Cities of note till they came within the view of Jeru≈øalem, upon ≈øight of which they ≈øhouted ≈øo loud, that all the Country re≈øounded with the joyful Acclamations, and with their hands and eyes extended towards Heaven, they called upon the name of Je≈øus, and many in humility to the place where our Ble≈ø≈øed Lord had ≈øo often preached his Go≈øpel, fell to the Ground and ki≈ø≈øed it with great Affection, making fre≈øh Vows never to leave the City till they had delivered it from the Infidels; but their ≈øtrength was much impaired by rea≈øon of a Pe≈øtilence that had the Autumn before hapned in the Army; yet in a Council of the Princes and chief Commanders, it was re≈øolved that the Siege ≈øhould immediately be begun, and carried on with all the vigour imaginable.

The Governour having notice of the Chri≈øtians approach, and what was intended, delayed not to prepare all things that might conduce to the making a ≈øtrenuous defence, having a little before received a ≈øtrong recruit of able Soldiers, and a ≈øupply of all things nece≈ø≈øary; yet the Chri≈øtians after having got what knowledge they could of the ≈øtate of Affairs within the City, ≈øat down before it on the North, for towards the Ea≈øt and the We≈øt the broken Rocks and ≈øhattered Hills render it very incommodious. Next the Wall
incamped Godfry Duke of Lorrain with his Germans and Lorainers, near unto him on the right pitched their Tents Robert Duke of Normandy, and the Earl of Flanders, before the We≈øt Gate lay incamped Tancreed, and the Earl of Tholous. Bohemund and Baldwin being ab≈øent, the one remaining King at Antioch, and the other Governour of Eda≈ø≈øa.

The Chri≈øtians having refre≈øhed them≈øelves, it was concluded among≈øt the Princes, that the fifth day the A≈ø≈øault ≈øhould be given, which accordingly was done with ≈øuch bravery, that the Turks were beaten from their Defences and mi≈øerably ≈ølaughtered by the ≈øhot of the Archers; but they wanting ≈øcaling Ladders, and the weather being exceeding hot, the retreat was ≈øounded, but being de≈øirous of nothing more than winning the City, five days after they gave it another fierce A≈ø≈øault, which made the Walls to tremble, nothing that Policy or Valour could afford being wanting on the part of the Chri≈øtians, but ≈øcarcity of Water afflicting them with drought, and the exce≈ø≈øive heat of the Weather fru≈øtrated this ≈øecond Attempt; for the Enemy had either ≈øtopped up or poy≈øoned all the Wells about the City, unle≈øs that of Siloe, who≈øe Water had worked out the Poi≈øon, and was become whole≈øome, but that yielded not half enough to ≈øuffice the Army.

During the time that the Chri≈øtians be≈øieged Jeru≈øalem, a Fleet of Genoe≈øes arrived at Joppa, where having notice that a far greater Fleet of the Egyptian Sultans lay at A≈øcalon with an intent to relieve the be≈øieged, they after having taken out all things nece≈ø≈øary, ≈øunk their Gallies, and marched over land to the Camp, where they became very ≈øerviceable in making Engines for A≈ø≈øault, and moving Towers covered with raw Hides to prevent their being fired, one of which they ≈øet to the Walls, and from it greatly annoyed the be≈øieged,
which they perceiving prepared to ≈øet it on fire, but the wind favouring the Chri≈øtians, drove i ‚Ä¢ full in the be≈øiegers face, in≈øomuch that the Duke of Lorrain with his German Foot getting upon the Engine beat the Turks and Sarazens from the Wall with great ≈ølaughter, and leaping thereon fixed his Standard, keeping his Ground, though the Enemies ≈øhot flew as thick as Hail, which venturous Attempt ≈øo encouraged the re≈øt of the Princes, that they pre≈ø≈øed on with great fury, in≈øomuch that a terrible ≈ølaughter en≈øued, the Souldiers in their rage ≈øparing neither Man, Woman, nor Child, which made the mo≈øt couragious of the Turks, Sarazens, and Jews retire to Solomon's Temple; in the Entrance whereof they maintain'd a bloody and ob≈øtinate fight, ≈øpreading all the Pavement with the bodies of the ≈ølain, and bedewing it with ≈øtreams of blood, and ≈øo eager were the Chri≈øtians to charge the Infidels, that they for ha≈øte thru≈øt one another upon the Enemies Weapons; yet after great ≈ølaughter they gave back and betook them to the Vaults on the top of the Temple, from whence they defended them≈øelves till the fury of the Chri≈øtians was over, and a Trumpet ≈øounded to give Quarter, upon which they yielded, and had their Lives ≈øpared.

Thus was the Famous City of Jeru≈øalem retaken by the Chri≈øtians in 30 days, Anno 1099. after it had remained in the hands of the barbarous Infidels for the ≈øpace of 409 years, and ≈øo great was the joy conceived by the Chri≈øtians, who inhabited it, and had ≈øuffered mi≈øerable Per≈øecution under the Turks, that they embraced the Souldiers, weeping for gladne≈øs, and every where ≈øinging prai≈øes for their deliverance.

Things being at this pa≈øs, the Princes con≈øulted among≈øt them≈øelves whom to con≈øtitute King of the Holy City, and after ≈øome deliberation thought none fitter than the valiant Duke of Normandy, but he
hearing of his Brothers death declined it, as de≈øirous to return and take po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of his Kingdom of England, but at his return found it po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed by his younger Brother Henry, who not only deprived him of his Kingdom, but ≈øoon after of his Dutchy of Normandy: And finally of his life, by putting out his eyes, which many held as a Judgment for his refu≈øing the Scepter of Jeru≈øalem.

Upon the Duke's declining, the Princes unanimou≈øly cho≈øe Godfry of Bolloin, Duke of Lorain, who accepted the honourable and glorious Tru≈øt, but at the time of his Inauguration refu≈øed to be crowned with a Crown of Gold, ≈øaying, that it became not a Chri≈øtian to wear a Crown of Gold, where Chri≈øt the Son of God had for the Salvation of mankind ≈øometime worn a Crown of Thorns; but long he had not injoyed his new acquired Dignity e'r News was brought that 100000 Turks, Sarazens, and Jews were upon their march to recover the City, again≈øt whom the Chri≈øtian Army advanced and gave them battle with ≈øo fearful an overthrow that all the Field and Plains for the ≈øpace of ten miles were covered with the bodies of the ≈ølain, and then pa≈ø≈øing on won many famous Cities, every where putting the Infidels to the rout, but not long after a great Mortality happening, the Heroick Godfry King of Jeru≈øalem died, and was interred in the Church of the Sepulcher of our Saviour on Mount Calvery: And Baldwin Count of Eda≈ø≈øa his Brother ≈øucceeded him, who with many Victories and Cities taken, much inlarged the Territories of Jeru≈øalem; but be≈øieging the City of Ptolemais, he was in a Skirmi≈øh with tho≈øe Turks wounded, yet took the City, and lived many years after, but the wound being as was ≈øuppo≈øed given with an impoy≈øoned weapon, and not pertectly cured, he died thereof in the eighteenth year of his Reign, and was mo≈øt favourably buried by his Brother, his Sepulcher remaining yet vi≈øible.

After him ≈øucceeded his Couzen Baldwin Brugen≈øes, again≈øt whom the Caliph of Egypt aided by the King of Dama≈øco, and the Turks came with a great Army, but they returned without effecting any thing; yet not long after Gazi the greate≈øt Prince of the Turks in the le≈ø≈øer A≈øia, aided by the King of Dama≈øco, and Debeis King of Arabia came again≈øt Antioch with a great power, and incamped at Aleppo, again≈øt whom Roger Prince of Antioch advanced without ≈øtaying for King Baldwin, who was on his march with a great Army, and unadvi≈øedly joyning battel, his Army was overthrown, and him≈øelf ≈ølain; but King Baldwin coming upon the Turks grown ≈øecure by rea≈øon of their new acquired Victory, put them to the rout far and near, filling all the Plains with the bodies of the ≈ølain; but within a while after, encountring with Balac General of the Per≈øian Sultan's Army, he was taken pri≈øoner, and his Army overthrown; but after eighteen Months impri≈øonment, for the Ran≈øom of 100000 Ducats ≈øet at liberty, and afterwards obtained many ≈øignal Victories over the Infidels; and in his Reign was ≈øetled the order of the Knights Templers, Hugh Paganus being the fir≈øt great Ma≈øter of that Order; but King Baldwin the Second being tired and di≈øordered with the many battels, and having received many wounds, after he had married Margaret his Elde≈øt Daughter to Foulk Duke of Turin, Anjoy and Mayn, fell ≈øick in the thirteenth year of his Reign, Anno 1131. and con≈øtituting his Son in Law to ≈øucceed him, gave up the Gho≈øt, and was buried in the Temple upon Mount Calvery near his Predece≈ø≈øors.

After the death of Baldwin Foulk was crowned King of Jeru≈øalem, viz. on the Sixth of September, Anno 1131. by William the Patriark; but the Devil envying the ≈øpreading of the Chri≈øtian Religion, endeavoured to ≈øtir up Divi≈øion among≈øt the Chri≈øtians, in the beginning
of this King's Reign; for Pontius Count of Tripolis by force of Arms endeavoured to rend the City and Territories of Antioch from the Kingdom of Jeru≈øalem, and Hugh Count of Joppa being highly concerned in the Trea≈øon for fear of puni≈øhment joyned with the Sarazens that held the ≈øtrong City of A≈øcalon, but God prevented the mi≈øchief that thereby might have en≈øued, by taking the former away by the Sword of the Turks, and the latter being driven out of A≈øcalon, died in Exile, the very Heathens abhorring a Traytor.

The≈øe ≈øtirs were no ≈øooner over, but the Turks invaded Antioch with a powerful Army; but the King coming ≈øuddainly upon them, put them to flight with much ≈ølaughter, and got in the plundring of their Camp great Riches.

After which John the Creek Emperor rai≈øed a great power to ≈øeize upon Antioch, pretending it a part of his Empire; but the Kings of Europe interpo≈øing, he was content it ≈øhould be holden by the pre≈øent Prince the Earl of Poictou, he paying him Homage for his Principality; but being a man of a re≈øtle≈øs Spirit, he ≈øoon after came again with a powerful Army, thinking to have admittance into the City, and ≈øo to ≈øurprize it, but found his expectations fru≈øtrate, for the Citizens would not admit him to enter, unle≈øs with ≈øome few of his Followers, in reveage of which he cau≈øed the Suburbs to be ≈øacked, and ≈øo returned into Cilicia, where hunting a Boar, whil≈øt the furious Bea≈øt pre≈ø≈øed on the Spear the Emperor held again≈øt him, the Emperor's hand pre≈ø≈øed upon the point of a poy≈øono ‚Ä¢ s A ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ o ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ he had in his Quiver, which entring the fle≈øh, the force of the poy≈øon was ≈øuch, that in great pain he ≈øhortly died, upon which Emanuel Elexus his Son was cho≈øen in his ≈øtead.

Jeru≈øalem by this means being ‚Ä¢ t pea ‚Ä¢ e, the King, Queen, and many great Commanders went without the Walls to take the Air, when there ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ nced a Hare to
be ≈øtarted, after which the King and tho≈øe that accompanied him rid, and he forcing his Hor≈øe he fell: ≈øo that the King's head fell under him, of which mortal brui≈øe he in three days dyed in great torment, viz. on the thirteenth of November, Anno 1142. and was bu
‚Ä¢ ied by his Predece≈ø≈øors, greatly lamented of all good Chri≈øtians, and after him ≈øucceeded Baldwin his Son, the third of that name, he being about thirteen years of Age, and in his Reign came Conrade the Third, Emperor of Germany with a powerful Army to the A≈ø≈øi≈øtance of the Chri≈øtians in Syria, who by the way being oppo≈øed by the Turks at the River Meander gave them battel and overthrew them with the ≈ølaughter of 30000 of the Enemy, ≈øo that the River for many miles ran „Äà‚óä„Äâ , and then marching forward, without the lea≈øt Impeachment, came to Iconium, the Chief Seat of the T ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ k ‚Ä¢ ≈øh Kings in the le≈ø≈øer A≈øia, which he be≈øieged; but it being ≈øtrongly fortified and Want increa≈øing, in the Camp a Mortality hap ‚Ä¢ ned which de≈øtroyed ≈øo many of the Souldiers, that the Emperor was forced to rai≈øe his Siege and to return home. The occa≈øion of this „Äà‚óä„Äâ was ≈øaid to be occa≈øioned by eating of Meal, which the
„Äà‚óä„Äâ
Emperor upon their pa≈ø≈øing through his Dominions, had cau≈øed to be mingled with Lime, „Äà‚óä„Äâ no le≈øs envying the ≈øucce≈øs of the Chri≈øtians in Syria
„Äà‚óä„Äâ the Turks, and by ≈øuch like Treacheries he fru≈øtrated „Äà‚óä„Äâ Expedition of Lewis the Eighth King of France, who after a long Siege lay'd to Dama≈øco, without pre
‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢
„Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ it, was forced to return with half his Ar
‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ , „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ half being through want and di≈øea≈øes lo≈øt.

But „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ to Baldwin King of Jeru≈øalem, after he had given the Turks and Sarazens ≈øeveral Overthrows, „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ
Pe ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ d, fortified Gaza, and taken all the „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ held in the Terrirories of Jeru≈øalem
„Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ accorded a Marriage with the Greek Emperor's ‚Ä¢ iece, which Emperor in requital
thereof, de≈øired in Marriage one of the King's near Kin≈øwomen; whereupon he offered him Mathildas, an honorable Lad ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢
‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ter to the Count of Tripolis, but he refu≈øing her, and taking Mary the Daughter of Raymund Earl of A ‚Ä¢ t ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ch, the Count was greatly di≈øplea≈øed, and with certain Ships of War greatly infe≈øted the Emperors Territories, and upon the King's coming to Antioch to ≈øolemnize the Marriage, he was ≈øuppo≈øed to be poy≈øoned by one Barac a Jew, the Counts Phy≈øician, for he taking ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ y≈øick to prevent Winter ≈øickne≈øs, immediately fell into a bloody Flux, and afterwards a Con≈øumption, of which he died at Beritus, Anno 1163. when he had reigned pro≈øperou≈øly 21 years, being generally lamented of his Friends and Enemies, Noridan the Turki≈øh General and King of Dama≈øco declaring that the world afforded not his Peer.

During the≈øe ≈øtirs in Syria, Sultan Solyman, and Mahomet his Succe≈ø≈øor being dead, Man≈øal having upon the overthrow of the Greek Emperor's Army gra≈øped the Scepter of Per≈øia, divided his Dominions at his death between his three Sons, viz. to Clizasthilon his Elde≈øt he gave Per≈øia with the Towns and Provinces thereunto appertaining; to Jagupa≈øan his Second Son he gave Ama≈øa and
„Äà‚óä„Äâ , with the fruitful Country of Cappadocia, and to Da ‚Ä¢ i ‚Ä¢ n and his Third Son gave he the Cities of
„Äà‚óä„Äâ
and S ‚Ä¢ ba≈øtia, which Divi≈øion cau≈øed a greater among≈øt the Brethren; ≈øo that mortal hate in≈ø ‚Ä¢ ed, which „Äà‚óä„Äâ heels brought an Inte≈øtine War; the Elder who bore the name of Sultan ≈øeeking to de≈øtroy and di≈øpo≈ø≈øe≈øs the two younger, which inte≈øtine broyls the Greek Emanuel ≈øought to augment, covertly a≈ø≈øi≈øting them both, that they by rending the Per≈øian Monarchy might give him an ea≈øie means to recover what had been di≈ømembred from his Empire; but finding the Sultan powerful, he ≈øuppo≈øed it be≈øt to ≈øide with him openly, which he doing by that means,
Jagupa≈øan was overthrown in a bloody and doubtful battel, and he flying into Arabia, had all his Dominions ≈øeized, upon which an enterview was had between the Sultan and the Emperor, wherein a Peace was concluded between tho≈øe Potentates, the former promi≈øing at his return to take Cae≈øaria and Sebastia from Dadune, and deliver them to the Emperor; the former part of this promi≈øe he performs, viz. the taking the Cities, but the latter part of re≈øtoring them, as he never intended, ≈øo he never performed, but forgetting all former curte≈øies, invaded the Imperial Provinces with Fire and Sword, doing great mi≈øchief, taking by ≈øtorm Laodicea in Phrygia, upon which the Emperor pa≈ø≈øed the Helle≈øpont with a great Army, and fortified Dorileum and Subleum, with other ≈øtrong Holds, to hinder the Inroads of the Turks; neverthele≈øs they cea≈øed not to infe≈øt his Frontiers, whereupon the Emperor grievou≈øly complained of the Sultan's Ingratitude and breach of Promi≈øe, and he on the other ≈øide of his breach of League, in fortifying the Frontier Towns; whereupon the Emperor rai≈øed the whole power of his Empire, re≈øolving to ra≈øe Iconium marching with his whole Army, Phrygia, Laodicea, Chonas, and other Countries, the Turks keeping aloof, as not daring to give him ‚Ä¢ atr ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ; but the Sultan ≈øent his Amba≈ø≈øadors with offers of Peace, but the Emperor driven head-long on as it were by the De≈øtinies, tru≈øting his power, ≈ølighted all his Propo≈øals, willing the Amba≈ø≈øadors to tell their Ma≈øter, he would give him an≈øwer under the Walls of Iconium; whereupon order was given to the Turks to impoy≈øon the Well, and de≈øtroy all Corn and Forrage by the way the Emperor ≈øhould pa≈øs, which was accordingly put in Execution; ≈øo that by ≈øuch means many of the Soldiers and ≈øome prime Commanders died; and further they fortified the Straights of Zibri ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ , through which the Christians were to pa≈øs
upon their departure from Myria-Cephalon, which are ≈øeven narrow Valleys of five miles long each, over which hang Rocks, craggy Clifts and Mountains, that almo≈øt touch at the top, yet through the≈øe the Emperor would needs pa≈øs, though he had notice that the Turks
‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ d ≈øtrongly po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed them≈øelves of the ≈øaid Valleys, having fir≈øt divided his Army into three Battalia's; but he was no ≈øooner entred, but the Turks appeared upon the Rocks and Mountains on every ≈øide, ≈øending ≈øhowers of poy≈øonous Arrows upon the Imperiali≈øts, them≈øelves remaining as it were ≈øecure under the ≈øhelter of the Rock, in≈øomuch that e'r he had got through, three parts of his Army were de≈øtroyed, filling the Valleys with blood, and the Carca≈ø≈øes of the ≈ølain; but in the middle of his di≈øtre≈øs, it plea≈øed God, to move the Sultan to pity him, and conclude a Peace on condition that the fortified Towns ≈øhould be ra≈øed, and ≈øo di≈ømi≈ø≈øed him with the remainder of his broken Army; but after repenting that he had ≈øuffered his Enemy to e≈øcape his hand, permitted ≈øuch as would to fall upon his Rear, by which means many were ≈ølain, yet at la≈øt he arrived at Chovas in his own Territories, and cau≈øed Subleum to be ra≈øed, but not the other Towns, whereupon the Sultan complained of the non-performance of the Articles, but receiving no ≈øatisfaction to his mind, he ≈øent Atapatch one of his great Captains with an Army of 2400 Hor≈øe and Foot to de≈øtroy the Emperor's Territories, even to the Sea-≈øide, and in token thereof to bring an Oar, ≈øome of the Sea water, and Sea Sand, which the ≈øaid Captain undertook, ≈øpoyling Phrygia, and all the Cities upon the Banks of the River Meander, taking a great Spoyl, but in his return he was met withal by John Bataza, the Emperor's Nephew, and Duca≈øe Con≈øtantine, who ≈øetting upon him about to pa≈øs the Meander, de≈øtroyed him and all his Army, recovering the rich Booty.

And thus the Emperor Emanuel pa≈ø≈øed over in continual Wars, yet by ≈øo doing he gave the Chri≈øtians in Syria re≈øt, who after he had ≈øat Emperor for the ≈øpace of thirty eight years died, leaving Alexius Comnenus his Son, a Child of twelve years of Age to Reign in his ≈øtead under the protection of the Empre≈øs, both of which were barbarou≈øly murdered by Andronicus the decea≈øed Emperor's Couzen, who proved ≈øo inhuman and unmerciful, that one I≈øaac Angelius, whom he de≈øigned to murther, cau≈øed the Citizens to mutiny again≈øt him, and put him to a ≈øhameful death him≈øelf, being afterwards cho≈øen Emperor in his ≈øtead; but he reigned not long, for proving almo≈øt as Tyrannical as the former, he was depo≈øed, and his Brother Alexius cho≈øen to ≈øucceed him, who getting him into his power to make all ≈øafe, put out his eyes, and thru≈øt him into a Mona≈øtery; ≈øo that in the≈øe ≈øuddain alterations the Turks made great ≈øpoyl of the Imperial Provinces, greatly di≈ømembring the Empire, ≈øore ≈øhaken with inre≈øtine broyls: But Cli≈øalth ‚Ä¢ n dying gave ≈øome Re≈øt, by rea≈øon his Sons fell at variance among them≈øelves, as he and his Brothers had done; for he leaving four all grown to Mens e≈øtate, viz. Maful, Coppatine, Ren
‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ine, and C ‚Ä¢ ichofroes, he divided his Dominions among≈øt them; but they thinking each other wronged, unle≈øs every one had all, would not content them≈øelves with what their Father had allotted them, though Dominions large enough to ≈øuffice twenty Kings, rai≈øed impious Broils: But after long contention, Ma≈øut the Elder ≈øei≈øed by force all the Dominions in Per≈øia, making him≈øelf thereby ab≈øolute Sultan, where I ≈øhall leave him ≈øetling his Dominions, and return to Jeru≈øalem.

After the death of Baldwin in, Almericus his younger Brother was crowned King, on the ≈øeventeenth day of February, A ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢
‚Ä¢ 163. who was no ≈øooner ≈øetled in his
Throne, but he warred upon Dargan the Egyptian Sultan for refu≈øing to pay him the accu≈øtomed Tribute, and in a dreadful battel overthrew him, who to ≈øtay the pur≈øuit cut the Banks of Nilus, and lay'd the Country under water: But whil≈øt he was bu≈øie in Egypt, Noridin the King of Dama≈øco making Inrodes upon the Chri≈øtians near Tripolis was fought with by Gilbert Lacy an engli≈øh man, then great Ma≈øter of the Templars, and by him overthrown with the lo≈øs of three parts of his Army; but the next year laying Siege to Arethu≈øa, the Chri≈øtian Princes gathered their Forces to oppo≈øe him, who upon their approach rai≈øed his Siege and departed, and whil≈øt they eagerly pur≈øued, he trained them into certain miry Fens, where turning upon them he overthrew their Army with incredible ≈ølaughter, and the Captivity of all the Princes commanding, after which Victory he again laying Siege to the City had it yielded to him; but Almericus was more ≈øucce≈øsful in Egypt, for he ≈øo prevailed again≈øt the Turks and Sarazens, that they were obliged to purcha≈øe their Peace with the delivery of the City of Alexandria, and mo≈øt of the Pri≈øoners taken by Noradin in the late overthrow; and within a ≈øhort while after the Turks infringing the Articles, he aided by the Knights Templars, and other Chri≈øtians lay'd Siege to Pelu≈øium, which he after three days ≈øetting down before it, won and gave it to the great Ma≈øter, and the Knights of the Order. In this City they took the Sultan of Egypt's Son, and Nephew, for who≈øe ran≈øom the King received 100000 Du ‚Ä¢ ats, and ≈øo he returned to Jeru≈øalem, when ≈øhortly after S ‚Ä¢ ra ‚Ä¢ con the Turki≈øh General in tho≈øe Parts, under pretence of Friend≈øhip, ≈ølew the Sultan of Egypt in his Tent, and was in his ≈øtead proclaimed Sultan, being fir≈øt Turk
„Äà‚óä„Äâ ever governed Egypt; yet he enjoyed not his ill got Dominion above the ≈øpace or a year before death ≈øurprized him, when in his ≈øtead Saladine
his Nephew was crowned Sultan, who de≈øirous to be rid of the Caliph, who as Succe≈ø≈øor to the Impo≈øtor Mahomet ruled in effect the Kingdom, he upon ≈øome di≈øgu≈øt with his hor≈øeman's Mace, beat his brains out at a blow, and then taking the chief Places of Tru≈øt from the Egyptians, and giving them to his Turks, ≈øo well ≈øecured him≈øelf and his Po≈øterity, that for the revolution of many years that fertile Kingdom remained in ≈øubjection to the Turks.

Being by the means afore≈øaid ≈øetled in his Kingdom, he rai≈øed a great power and entered Pale≈øtine, and after a ≈øhort Siege took the City of Daron e're Almericus could come to relieve it, and now the Turks increa≈øing in great numbers, the King of Jeru≈øalem was obliged to ≈øend to the Chri≈øtian Princes of the We≈øt for aid, and in the mean while ≈øtoutly defended his Territory, which the former Kings had extended to the uttermo≈øt borders of Arabia Felix, larger than what ever the I≈øraelites po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed; and Anno 1173. Noridon King of Dama≈øco died, the ≈øore≈øt Enemy the Chri≈øtians had; but as Joy ≈øeldom comes without ≈øome ta≈øte of ≈øorrow to allay it; ≈øo now, for Almericus the Sixth famous King of Jeru≈øalem, returning from the Siege of Peane.
„Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ year fell into a Fever, which after a ≈øhort ≈øick „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ him of life.

Up „Äà‚óä„Äâ the „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ
Americus, his Nephew Baldwi ‚Ä¢
„Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ nightily oppo≈øed the Turks, g ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ing them many „Äà‚óä„Äâ
‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ erthrows, but was in the flower of his youth cut „Äà‚óä„Äâ death the ≈øixteenth of A ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ y, 1185. when as he ha ‚Ä¢
‚Ä¢ ei ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ed twelve Years and ≈øome Months.

In this King's ≈øtead his Son Baldwin the Fifth of that name, and Eighth King of Jeru≈øalem was crowned; but long he had not reigned e'r his perfidious Mother to advance her ≈øecond Husband Guy to the Throne, poy≈øoned him; But Heaven le ‚Ä¢ t not ≈øuch wickedne≈øs unrevenged
not long after Guy the Ninth and La≈øt King of Jeru≈øalem took upon him the Scepter, the Chri≈øtians fell at variance among≈øt them≈øelves, ready to turn their Swords upon each other, of which Saladine the Egyptian Sultan taking the advantage, won many Cities, and finally in a bloody battel the Chri≈øtian Army was overthrown, the King and mo≈øt of his Nobles, together with the great Ma≈øter of the Templers, were taken Pri≈øoners, which altogether broke the ≈øtrength of the Chri≈øtians in Syria; for hightned with this ≈øucce≈øs, the Sultan with an Army of 200000 Hor≈øe and Foot be≈øieged Jeru≈øalem, which being naked of men, and wanting a Head, was after fourteen days Siege, and many fierce A≈ø≈øaults delivered up to the Enemy, Anno 1187. after it had been in the hands of the European Chri≈øtians for the ≈øpace of 100 years, upon condition that ≈øuch Chri≈øtians as would might ≈øtill remain there, with free exerci≈øe of their Religion, and tho≈øe that were minded to depart might be permitted ≈øo to do, with as much of their Goods as they could carry upon their backs.

And thus the Holy City again fell into the hands of the Pagans, who poluted it with their prophane Idolatries and ≈øuper≈øtitious Wor≈øhip, through the Chri≈øtians lukewarmne≈øs and di≈øre≈øpect of God's Divine Wor≈øhip, who living in abundance of plenty, forgat the hand that protected them, tru≈øting in their own arms, as the I≈øraelites to their co≈øt had done before them.

After Jeru≈øalem the Metropolis of the Kingdom was taken, An ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ e ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢
was betrayed by the Patriarck (≈øuch little regard had Chri≈øtians of their Fidelity) into the hands of the Turks, for a certain ≈øum of Gold, „Äà‚óä„Äâ afterward mo≈øt of the other Cities either revolted, or were taken by force.

div.head: Chap. IV. The Second Expedition of the Western Princes for the Recovery of the Holy Land, &c.
div.p:
JEru≈øalem and mo≈øt of the Cities of Pale≈øtine being lo≈øt, as afore≈øaid, the European Potentates were not a little grieved, and to recover the ≈øame rai≈øed a mighty power; and fir≈øt that advanced was Frederick the German Emperor, who ≈øetting forth from Vienna pa≈ø≈øed with a pui≈ø≈øant Army through Hungary, Bulgaria, and Thracia, and ≈øo to Con≈øtantinople, where he pa≈ø≈øed over into A≈øia, and entring Lyconia gave the Turks a great overthrow, after which he be≈øieged and took Iconium giving the Spoyls thereof to his Soldiers; and from thence pa≈ø≈øing into Celicia in the Straights, where the Greek Emperor ≈øome years before received his fatal overthrow, he had a ≈øecond conflict with the Turk, whom he put to flight with great ≈ølaughter, and took the City of Philomela, and put the Inhabitants to the ≈øword, for executing his Me≈ø≈øangers he ≈øent to treat with them about delivering it peaceably; and then entring
‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ enia the le≈øs, he took the City of Melitene, and ≈øubdued all the Territories round about, and there gave the Turks an other fearful overthrow, which Army was no ≈øooner vanqui≈øhed, but another not inferiour to ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ appeared under the heading of Saphadine Saladin the Sultan's Son, which with an undaunted bravery he charged, and put to rout, with incredible ≈ølaughter (but the joy of Victory was ≈øoon turned into Mourning) for the good Emperor zealous for the Chri≈øtian Cau≈øe, following h ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ d upon the flyers, his Hor≈øe floundered in the River
„Äà‚óä„Äâ , and threw him out of the Saddle, with his right foot hanging in the Stirrup, after which
manner, e'r he could be relieved, he was drag'd through the River, and hitting by the way on certain Stumps, ≈øo brui≈øed, that when he was taken up, he was heard to ≈øay no more then, Lord receive my Soul, e'r he gave up the Gho≈øt, in the ≈øeventieth year of his Age, and of his Reign 38. Anno 1190. Whereupon his Body was carried to the City of Tire, and there in the Cathedral with all Solemnity interred.

This Heroick Emperor being dead, his Son Frederick Duke of Suevia, then in the Army was ≈øaluted Emperor and General by the con≈øent of the great Commanders; but now (the Country being purpo≈øely de≈øtroyed before them) pale Famine began to ≈øtare them in the face, yet on they marched, and charging Dodequin Saladius, General, ≈øent to oppo≈øe their Pa≈ø≈øage, gave him a great overthrow, and had all the Cities rendred as they pa≈ø≈øed, till they came to Ptolomais, where the power of the Chri≈øtians in Syria were incamped, headed by Guy late King of Jeru≈øalem, who for a great Sum had obtained his Liberty.

Upon the Arrival of Frederick, the Chri≈øtians gave a fierce A≈ø≈øault to the City on all Parts, and had taken it by Storm, had not Saladine the Egyptian Sultan, who lay hovering aloof with his Army, fallen upon their Camp, and thereby in the hotte≈øt of the A≈ø≈øault obliged them to draw off to defend the ≈øame, and having forced him to retire with the lo≈øs of a few men, they returned again to the Siege, expecting the Arrival of Richard the Fir≈øt, King of England, and Philip the Second, King of France, who were upon their way with great Forces; but they wintering in the I≈øle of Sicilia, the French King out of Envy to the Glory of the Engli≈øh, and an old grudge having been formerly about King Richard's refu≈øing the French King's Si≈øter, and marrying the Daughter of the King or Navar, the French King not long after returned home, and
withdrew his Army to the fru≈øtrating the whole de≈øign of recovering Jeru≈øalem; yet at pre≈øent he di≈ø≈øembled the matter, and loo≈øing fir≈øt from the Port of Me≈øina, arrived at Ptolomais, where the Chri≈øtians lay ≈øtill incomped, after whom King Richard ≈øhortly followed; but ≈øayling by Cyprus, his Fleet was di≈øper≈øed by a Storm, and two of his Ships falling on ground on that Coa≈øt, the I≈ølanders ≈øpoyled them, and when the re≈øt of the Fleet put in there, they rudely with≈øtood their landing, which ≈øo inraged King Richard, that he landing by force, ≈øei≈øed the I≈øland, and took the King thereof Pri≈øoner, and ≈øent him bound in Chains of Silver to Syria.

The King having ≈øecured the I≈øland to his u≈øe, di≈øanchored and ≈øailed to Ptolomais, where he was joyfully received of the Chri≈øtian Princes, upon who≈øe Arrival the City after a hot A≈ø≈øault, and a great breach in the Wall, was ≈øurrendred upon condition the Garri≈øon might depart with ≈øafety, for which they were likewi≈øe to pay a great Ran≈øom to deliver they Holy Cro≈øs they had in po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion, and a certain number of them to remain as Ho≈øtages, that the Saladine ≈øhould deliver ≈øuch Chri≈øtian Pri≈øoners as he had in his power, whereupon the Germans of Au≈øtria entered fir≈øt the „Äà‚óä„Äâ and advanced the Standard of their Duke upon the W ‚Ä¢ ll, as if by their only valour the City had „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ , which ≈øo offended King Richard, that he „Äà‚óä„Äâ the Standard to be thrown down, and trampled on, which indignity the Duke re≈øented ≈øo heinou≈øly, that „Äà‚óä„Äâ great hindrance of the Wars in Syria, he retu ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢
„Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ his Forces into Au≈øtria; as likewi≈øe did the „Äà‚óä„Äâ
France with the greate≈øt part of his Army, under „Äà‚óä„Äâ he did it for want of health in ≈øo hot a Clime, „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ out of ≈øecret Envy to King Richard.

Sal ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢
„Äà‚óä„Äâ of the le≈øsning of the Chri≈øtian Army,
and that there ≈øtill remained among≈øt them di≈øcontent, refu≈øed to pay the money for the Ran≈øom of the Ho≈øtages, or deliver up the Christian Pri≈øoners; but threatned that if any Extremity was u≈øed by the King towards them, he would behead all the Chri≈øtian Pri≈øoners, the which notwith≈øtanding the Ho≈øtages were not hurt, he mo≈øt barbarou≈øly performed; in return whereof the King commanded 2500 of the Ho≈øtages to be executed in the ≈øight of the Infidels Camp, and re≈øolved to give him battel, which he perceiving rai≈øed his Camp, and departed along the Sea Coa≈øt, ruining the ≈øtrong Towns, to prevent their falling into the hands of the Chri≈øtians, who leaving Ptolomais ≈øtrongly fortified, followed clo≈øe at his heels, re≈øolving to be≈øiege Jeru≈øalem, which he perceiving, and taking ≈øuch advantage as the time and place would afford, faced about: So that both Armies meeting about Noon, a dreadful conflict began, which continued with great ≈ølaughter, e≈øpecially on the part of the Turks, till Evening: at what time the Victory fell to the Chri≈øtians, who had the Execution of the Infidels for ≈øeven miles; but Winter coming on, they di≈øpo≈øed of the Army till Spring, in the Towns that Saladine had ruinated, repairing and fortifying them ≈øtronger than before; but when Spring came, upon mu≈øt'ring the Army, they were found greatly decrea≈øed by di≈øea≈øes and ab≈øenting, and at the ≈øame time the King found the Duke of Burgundia, under who≈øe command the French King had left part of his Army, ≈øtill to cro≈øs his purpo≈øe, as de≈øirous to return home, having received ≈øuch Orders privately from the King his Ma≈øter, who was contrary to his Oath taken at his departure warring upon the Normans, then King Richard's Subjects, and that others were of the like mind, found him≈øelf altogether too weak to be≈øiege Jeru≈øalem, and hearing how the French King had incited his younger Brother John to take upon
him the Government of the Kingdom of England, fearing le≈øt while he was warring abroad, he might loo≈øe his Kingdom at home, he re≈øolved to make ≈øuch conditions with the Sultantain, as might be be≈øt for the advantage of the Chri≈øtians in Syria, and ≈øo imbarque for England, which the crafty Infidel under≈øtanding, and finding his power daily to decay, would hearken to no other Propo≈øals, than that the Chri≈øtians ≈øhould ≈øurrender all the Towns they had taken, Ptolomais excepted, and in con≈øideration thereof be ≈øuffered to live in Peace, which being concluded on, the King leaving Count Henry of Champaigne his Lievetenant of Syria, imbarked with his fair Queen, who had accompanied him in his tedious Expedition; but by the way being ≈øeparated from the re≈øt of his Fleet, ≈øuffered wrack upon the Coa≈øt of Hi≈øtria, and attempting with a ≈ømall retinue to walk over land in the Habit of a Templar, he was di≈øcovered, and by the command of the Duke of Au≈øtria (in who≈øe Territories, and whom he had di≈øgraced at the Siege of Ptolomais, by throwing down his Standard) taken Pri≈øoner, and by him ≈øold to the Emperor Henry for 40000 pounds, who kept him pri≈øoner a year and three months, and then received for his Ran≈øom 150000 pounds. But the Ship that the Queen and her Ladies were in, arrived ≈øafe in England.

Soon after the King's delivery, news came that Saladine the great Sultan was dead, which cau≈øed the Princes of Germany, animated by Pope Cele≈øtines, to undertake a third Voyage for the Recovery of Jeru≈øalem. The Dukes of Saxony and Au≈øtria commanding in Chief, and with them went many Bi≈øhops, who upon their Arrival joyned with the Chri≈øtians they found there, and repaired Joppa, the which whil≈øt they were doing, the
‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ i≈øh Army approached, whereupon they ‚Ä¢ hew out, and in pitched battle overthrew them, but
to the Lo≈øs of their two Generals, the former dying within four days after the Victory of a Fever, and the latter of the Wounds he had received. And in fine, news coming that Henry the Emperour was dead, mo≈øt of the chief Captains returned home, in hopes to be elected Emperour. After which the Turks took Joppa and put all they found in it to the Sword, but at the in≈øtance of Pope Innocent the third, Philip the French King ≈øent 5000 Souldiers, under the leading of Simon Count of Mont-ferat to joyn the Chri≈øtians, by who≈øe good conduct things were ≈øo ordered that they procured to live at peace in Tyre and Ptolomais, where I ≈øhall leave them and return to the Le≈ø≈øer A≈øia, and relate by what means the Turks fir≈øt Empire in Per≈øia was brought to nought.

And thus taking my leave of Syria for the pre≈øent, I ≈øhall return into the le≈ø≈øer A≈øia, where I find Me≈øoot and Rei-Cubades, the two Tributary Turki≈øh Princes dead, without doing a any thing worthy of note, of which the latter left a Son named Aladan, who likewi≈øe
paying Tribute, held joyntly the Kingdom, that were before po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed by his Father and Uncle. This Aladine the la≈øt of the Selzuccian Family dying without i≈ø≈øue, one Sahib his chief Councellour and then a man of great Authority, a≈øpired unto the Kingdom, but being ri≈øen from a mean e≈øtate, he was highly envyed by the Nobility, they ca≈øting off all re≈øpect from him, by force divided the Kingdom among≈øt them≈øelves, every one ≈øeizing the Province he could be≈øt light on; ≈øo that Sahib who was fir≈øt in po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion, lo≈øt all, no part remaining as his Lot, ≈øo that they turned it into a perfect Anarchy, of which the greate≈øt ≈øhare fell to Caraman Alu≈øirus, who ≈øtronge≈øt took Iconium, with part of Cilicia, Lycaonia, Pamphilia, Caria, and Phrygia; and of him de≈øcended the Caramanian Kings, who in the ri≈øe of the Othoman Empire, put the Turks ≈øo often to the Foil: The next to him was Saruchan, who po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed him≈øelf of the greate≈øt part of Lydia, and ≈øome other Countries adjoyning; Troas, Phrygia, and part of My≈øia, fell to Calumus and his Son Cara≈øius; the remaining part of My≈øia, and part of Lydia, was ≈øeized by Aidin; part of Pontus, the Cities of Heraclea, Pontica Ca≈øtomonia, Synope, and others near to the Euxine Sea, and Country of Paphlagonia, fell into the hands of the Sons of Omer, or as the Greeks call them Amar, of whom the Country took not their names, as did the former of the≈øe that po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed them, but is commonly called Bolli, ≈øo named of the Metropolis, as al≈øo was Mende≈øia, or as ≈øome will have it Mentetia, a Country in the Le≈ø≈øer A≈øia.

The≈øe and divers others, were the divi≈øions of the Turki≈øh Empire in Per≈øia, and the Le≈ø≈øer A≈øia, which Anarchy cau≈øed their Subjection, and utter ≈øubver≈øion, as in the Succeeding part of this Hi≈øtory, will at large appear.

During this confu≈øion among≈øt the re≈øt of the great
Captains, there happened one Othoman, of the Oguzian Family, who had been rai≈øed from a low e≈øtate, by Sultan Aladine, yet by rea≈øon he was not of the Selzuccian Family, they made little account of him, not permiting him to ≈øhare with them in their divi≈øion, though by what ju≈øtice is uncertain; all of them feared his ri≈øing fortune, and ≈øtrove what in them lay, to hinder, but in vain, for the De≈øtinies ≈øo ordering it, he in a ≈øhort time became the Founder of the Othoman Empire, as in the Peru≈øal of his Life and Actions will appear.

div.head: CHAP. VI. The Ri≈øe of the Powerfull Empire of the Turks, under Othoman its first Founder, with his Life and Actions.
div.p:
THat Empires and Kingdoms have their Limitation from the Soveraign Creator and Di≈øpo≈øer of all things, it is undeniably evident, by the Sundry Mutations that have been in all Ages of the World, for nothing can be a≈ø≈øured of long continuance, though never ≈øo great and powerful. How are the great Monarchies of the Per≈øians, Medians, Babylonians, Chaldeans, Romans, and the like, dwindled away into nothing, no more then a bare Relation, of their Names and Greatne≈øs remaining to te≈øtifie the mighty actions they performed, when at their becks were half three parts of Mankind. And indeed no le≈øs famous was the Turki≈øh Empire in Per≈øia, and the Le≈ø≈øer A≈øia, till broken and di≈ømembred, by the violent intru≈øion of the Tartars, a
Savage People bur≈øting from the Frozen-North, to the Terror and Subver≈øion of the greate≈øt part of A≈øia, and Africa; but now under the Turki≈øh Scepter, as ≈øhall by the ≈øub≈øequent Di≈øcour≈øe appear.

During the time that the Tartars overwhelmed the Turki≈øh Dominions in A≈øia, Solyman, of the Oguzian Family, Reigning in the le≈ø≈øer A≈øia; and ≈øeeing his Country-man the Sultan of Per≈øia, driven from all his Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øions, thought it not ≈øafe for him, of far Inferior force, to abide the Sorm; but flying with ≈øuch People as would follow him, after long wandring, the Tempe≈øt being near over, and he de≈øiring to return home, as he was about to pa≈øs the Danube, was carried away by the Stream, and drowned, leaving behind him four Sons, viz. Sencur, Teken, Jundogdis, and Ertogrul, of ≈øome called Orthobules, who was the Father of Othoman. This Ertogrul after the Death of his Father, having notice that Aladine the Sultan had again ≈øettled him≈øelf in the le≈ø≈øer A≈øia: Sent Me≈ø≈øengers to him, to de≈øire him, that he and the re≈øt of his poor followers, who were Herd≈ømen driving Flocks ≈øtill before them as they travelled, might inhabit in ≈øome Corner of his Country. The Sultan not unmindful of the ≈øtate of poor Exiles, it having ≈øo lately been his own Ca≈øe, appointed them a Village called Suguta, lying between the Ca≈øtle Belezuga, and Mount Tmolus in the greater Phrygia; during who≈øe re≈øidence there with his ≈ømall Train, the Sultan had many Conflicts with the Tartars, who≈øe Power by this time was in its Wain; and being hard put to it in one Battle near the ≈øaid Village, Ertogrul with four hundred of his Herd≈ømen unexpectedly came to his A≈ø≈øi≈øtance, and behaved him≈øelf ≈øo valiantly, that the Tartars were put to flight, for which the Sultan honoured him with a rich Cloak, and began highly to prize his Valour; in≈øomuch that he inlarged his Territories, making him a petty Lord, which
Lord≈øhip with great Repute, he held during the Reign of the Sultan, doing many notable Services, as taking the Ca≈øtle of Cara-Chi≈øar from the Chri≈øtians, who by their many Injuries had exa≈øperated the Sultan; but after the Sultans Death, tho≈øe that ≈øucceeded, being Tributaries to the Tartars, till ≈øuch time as the Kingdom was Anachi≈øed, he lived quietly at home; during which time many conceived great hopes of his younger Son Othoman, called by ≈øome O≈øman Gazi, or O≈øman the Warlike, by rea≈øon of the great delight he had in Arms when he was a Child, and when grown up, to di≈øcour≈øe and Argue with the Commanders and Governours, of whom he had the general E≈øteem of an active Youth, de≈øigned for great Atchievements, as it afterward fell out.

One day Othoman going to vi≈øit the Governour of Eski-Chi≈øar, lately taken from the Chri≈øtians by his Father: He fell in Love by the way with a beautiful Damo≈øel, named Malhatun, and ≈øent to reque≈øt her in Marriage, but ≈øhe ≈øeeming ≈øomething aver≈øe, excu≈øing her ≈øelf that ≈øhe was of too mean a Parentage, and not a fitting Match for him, that was ≈øo nobly de≈øcended; he as ≈øhe conceived, de≈øigning rather to Debauch her, then make her his Wife; but this mode≈øt repul≈øe making him more and more de≈øire her, he in other Di≈øcour≈øes declared his Affections to the afore≈øaid Governour, who ≈øeeming little to take notice thereof, begun to be inflamed with the Love of the Damo≈øel un≈øeen, by the lively De≈øcription Othoman had given of her rare Perfection, which Othoman well perceiving, and fearful that he ≈øhould inforce her to his Lu≈øt, having great Power in that Country; he ≈øent her Parents notice thereof, who tender of their Daughters Honour, ≈øent her away ≈øecretly, the which upon Knowledge it was done by Othomans means, ≈øo inraged the Governour, that he vowed Revenge, and ≈øent after him a ≈øtrong Party
to ≈øeize him at the Ca≈øtle of In-∆≤ngi, whither he knew he was gone, where being demanded of the Captain of that Ca≈øtle, after ≈øome Debate tho≈øe that kept it re≈øolved to defend him; but he not greatly tru≈øting them (as knowing the Governours Power in tho≈øe parts) with ≈øeveral of his tru≈øty Friends, he broke through the Leagures, killing ≈øome, and di≈øper≈øing the re≈øt; yet other Forces coming to their A≈ø≈øi≈øtance, they followed him into his Fathers Territories, where his Danger was no ≈øooner known, but all the Youths Armed, and ≈øetting upon the Governours Soldiers, they ≈ølew many, took ≈øome Pri≈øoners, and put the re≈øt to flight: So that Othoman began to be feared of ≈øuch as hated him.

Ertogrul being ≈øpent with Age and Infirmity, created by lying in the Field, and watching in Camps, dyed in the ninety third year of his Age, Anno 1289. Having ≈øince the Death of Solyman his Father, governed the Og ‚Ä¢
zian Family fifty two years, who now being dead, the Heads of the Family a≈ø≈øembled to chu≈øe another Lord, and thereupon they pitched upon Dunder, Entogrul's Brother, but he by rea≈øon of his great Age refu≈øing the Honour; they with one Con≈øent elected Othoman, ≈øaluting him by the Name of Beg or Lord, he being by this means become Lord of the ≈øame Family. The Herd≈ømen that ≈øed their Flocks upon the Mountains complained to him, of outrages done them in pa≈ø≈øing and repa≈ø≈øing by the Garri≈øon or Soldiers of the Ca≈øtle of Einegiol, they being thereto incited by their Captain, with which he being not a little grieved, ≈øent to the Captain of Bil ‚Ä¢ zuga his Friend, another Ca≈øtle not far di≈øtant from the former, to permit his People to ≈øhelter and refre≈øh them≈øelves therein, during their pa≈ø≈øing and repa≈ø≈øing to the Mountains, to which in Relation to the Turki≈øh Women he Con≈øented, but not to permit the Men for Fear of a ≈øurprize: So that they went another way, avoiding the former Ca≈øtle, but
Othoman ≈øtill ≈øtudying Revenge for the Injuries done to his People; whereupon gathering what Force he could, he pa≈ø≈øed to the Mountains, in hopes to ≈øurprize it; but the Captain having notice thereof came out to meet him, laying an Ambu≈øh in hopes to intrap him, of which he being aware came not into it, but gave the Captain battle upon plain Ground; and after ≈øome ≈ølaughter on both ≈øide put him to ≈ølight, and pa≈ø≈øing on took the Ca≈øtle of Chalce not far from Einegiol by ≈øurprize, putting all he found therein to the Sword, of which outrage great Complaint was made to the Governour of Cara-Chi≈øar, and great Forces rai≈øed to apprehend him, and de≈øtroy the Oguzian Family, who as they ≈øaid coming not long before, poor Herd≈ømen and ≈øheltered out of Pity, began to U≈øurp over the rightful Inhabitants.

Again≈øt the≈øe Preparations Othoman provided the be≈øt he could, and near to Mount Tmolus, gave Battle to Calanus, Brother to the Governour of Cara-Chi≈øar, who overthrown in the Battle lo≈øt his Brother Saragatine, and many other Friends; when ≈øhortly after Sultan Aladine the la≈øt Sultan of Iconium under≈øtanding what had happened, and that Othoman might ≈øtand him in ≈øtead again≈øt the Chri≈øtians, gave him the City of Paleopolis, with all the Territories thereunto belonging: So by this means he became of a poor Herd≈øman, a formidable Governour, when not unmindful upon what Account ≈øuch a Favour was be≈øtowed upon him, he entred into Con≈øultation with his Brother Jundus, how he might be≈øt get away, but he finding him≈øelf too weak, and by that means Con≈øidering he ≈øhould lay him≈øelf open to the Fury of the Tartar, he re≈øolved to make Peace with ≈øuch as would accord thereto, and wait his better Fortune; for there wanted not ≈øome of the Selzuccian Family, that greatly envied his A≈øpiring, yet incouraged by the
Sultan, he took the ≈øtrong Ca≈øtle of Cara-Chi≈øar the re≈øidence of his Enemy, and ≈øo ≈øettled his Affairs, winning upon his People with kind Speeches and bounty, that great numbers of the Turks daily re≈øorted to him.

Now during the pro≈øperous Proceedings of Othoman, there happened a Quarrel between the two Chri≈øtian Captains of Belezuga, and Cupri-Chi≈øar, upon which the former doubting his ≈øtrength, and yet de≈øirous of Revenge ≈øolicited Othoman for aid, who in lieu of ≈øome kindne≈ø≈øes received, came to his A≈ø≈øi≈øtance with 100 Turks; by who≈øe Valour he overthrew his Adver≈øary, took his Ca≈øtle, and put him to the Sword, which ≈øo ≈øwelled the Captain with Pride that he gave Othoman many rich Gifts, as likewi≈øe to his Soldiers; but what vexed them more then the Gifts plea≈øed them, he gave them his Hand to ki≈øs; and above all, Othoman who adviced with his Cozen Dunder his Uncles Son, what Revenge was be≈øt to be taken, to humble the Captains in≈øolence; but ≈øeeming to di≈ø≈øwade him from any ≈øuch Attempt, and to be the Captains Friend, le≈øt he ≈øhould relate his Intentions, and that redound to his prejudice, re≈øolving to make all; he at an advantage ≈øhot his Cozen through with an Arrow, and hid him in the Sand.

Long it was not after this Tran≈øaction, e'r he was invited by one Michael Co≈ø≈øi Captain of Hirmen Caia, to the Marriage of his Daughter, where according to the Cu≈øtom of the Country, making large Pre≈øents; the re≈øt of Captains began to mi≈øtru≈øt his greatne≈øs, ≈øo that the Captain of Belezuga re≈øolved to prevent it with his Death, and therefore the better to have him within his Power, he invited him to his Wedding at a certain day, making Co≈ø≈øi privy to his De≈øign: And a little before the appointed time, ≈øent Co≈ø≈øi to fetch him, who was as ready to accompany him, which Co≈ø≈øi perceiving,
