to prevent his Ruin di≈øcovered the Con≈øpiracy again≈øt his Life: Whereupon he Contracted a ≈øtrict Amity with him, obliging him to ≈øecrecy, and then began to ca≈øt about how he might be revenged of the ≈øaid Captain; and ≈øo ordered it, that ≈øending about forty men in a Carriage in≈øtead of packs of Pre≈øents, they, whil≈øt the Captain and all his People, unle≈øs a few left to ≈øecure the Ca≈øtle, by the help of ≈øome Soldiers, who in the habit of Turki≈øh Women were ≈øent thither by the Captains order, as Othomans Friends, ≈øurprized it, putting the Warders to the Sword: Now Othoman came according the Captains wi≈øh, and ≈øtayed drinking with him in his plea≈øant Bowers, till he ≈øuppo≈øed his men had effected his Commands; and together with Co≈ø≈øi and ≈øome other of his Companions retired, which the Captain perceiving, and loath to let him e≈øcape his Hands, as ≈øuppo≈øing he had him ≈øure; he and all his Soldiers followed him, but being over-charged with Wine, they were by him and his Company lightly ≈ølain.

Things thus pro≈øpering he followed his Advantage, and the next Morning ≈øurprized the Ca≈øtle of Jarchi≈øar, took the Captain Pri≈øoner; as likewi≈øe Lubufer the fair Damo≈øel with all her Attendants, that ≈øhould have the next day been Married to the Captain of Bilezuga, and gave her in Marriage to his Son Orchanes, who had I≈ø≈øue by her Amurath, the third King of the Turks, and Solyman Ba≈ø≈øa; and immediately thereupon be≈øieged the Ca≈øtle of Einegiol, which he took, and put the Garri≈øon to the Sword; and now no longer re≈øolving to play ≈ømall Games, he be≈øieged the City of Nice in Bythinia, not many years before the Seat of the Greek Emperor, to relieve which the Emperor ≈øent ≈øuch Forces as could upon ≈øo ≈øhort a warning be drawn together; which Othoman encountring with overthrew, and afterward by Famine con≈øtrained the Citizens upon promi≈øe of Life, to ≈øurrender the City with ≈øpoils, of
which he greatly inriched him≈øelf, ≈øending part thereof to the Sultan, who in requital ordered prayers to be put up for his pro≈øperous Succe≈øs, promi≈øing that he ≈øhould ≈øucceed him in his Kingdom, of which being di≈øappointed, at the death of the ≈øaid Sultan by tho≈øe that divided it into an Anarchy, he neverthele≈øs took upon him the Dignity of a Sultan, Coining Money, and Cau≈øing publick prayers to be put up in his own name, and ≈øezing upon Neapolis, made it his Regal ≈øeat calling it De≈øpotopolis or the City of the Prince; and thus Anno 1300 begun the great Empire of the Turks. This up≈øtart Turk having ≈øo ≈øoon advanced his fortune, ≈øetled his Government with whole≈øom Laws, the la≈øting Cords of Empire, and then drawing all his forces together lay'd Siege to Pru≈øia, during which the Chri≈øtian Princes that bordered upon him, drew all their forces together, re≈øolving to give him battle, but therein his good fortune prevailing they were overthrown, whereupon ≈øeveral Towns and Ca≈øtles fell into his hands, ≈øome ≈øurrendring voluntarily, and others by force compelled ≈øo to do; but the ≈øtrong City of Pru≈øia, in which was the broken Army of the Chri≈øtians ≈øtood impregnable, whereupon he built two Ca≈øtles to block it up, and returned to Neapolis, ≈øending his Captains out daily with ≈øtrong parties, to fetch booties out of the Chri≈øtian Territories, and to take in ≈øuch Ca≈øtles as by ≈øurprize, or otherwi≈øe might fall into their hands: His Power being now greatly increa≈øed, that he was able to draw into the Field 20 or 30000 Hor≈øe and Foot, at what time Co≈ø≈øi the Chri≈øtian Captain revolting, turned Turk, and ≈øtood Othoman in great ≈øtead during his Wars; nor did the other Turks in the Le≈ø≈øer A≈øia le≈øs indammage the Chri≈øtians, ≈øo that the Greek Empire began to Dwindle into a ≈ømall Circumference, occa≈øioned by the divi≈øions among≈øt them≈øelves about Religion; for young Baldwin the
Latin Emperor, being expelled Con≈øtantinople, as is afore≈øaid in flying into Germany, lay daily at Charles the Emperor to re≈øtore him, which Paleologus the Greek Emperor under≈øtanding, offered unto Pope Gregory the tenth, that if he would divert the Emperors forces by intangling him in Dome≈øtick troubles, he would ≈øo order the matter that the Greek Empire, in matters of Religion ≈øhould acknowledge the See of Rome as Supream, and from thence take all directions as to Eccle≈øia≈øtical affairs, which Innovation cau≈øed divers tumults, and many to leave the Empire, rather cho≈øing to dwell with the Turks, which troubles la≈øted to the Death of Paleologus, nor could he fulfil his promi≈øe to the Pope.

After the Greek Emperors Death, Andronicus ≈øucceeded in the Empire, who was no le≈øs troubled with the Incur≈øions of the Turks, yet he fought with them ≈øeveral Battles with various with Succe≈øs, but then a difference ari≈øing between him and his Brother Constantine, all his hopes of prevailing vani≈øh'd though without cau≈øe, as mo≈øt believe ≈øu≈øpected his Brothers a≈øpiring to Empire, who was one of the chiefe≈øt Bulwarks aagain≈øt the Turks, beyond the River Meander, giving to them many a fatal overthrow, yet was he ca≈øt in Pri≈øon, with many of his followers, and one Alexus Philanthropenus made General of the Army, in his ≈øtead, to whom was joyned Libadarius, an experienced Captain, and grave Councellor, the former of which after having obtained many Victories over the Turks and Tartars, per≈øwaded by the Creten≈øians, Rebelled again≈øt the Emperor, taking upon him≈øelf the title of Emperor, which la≈øted not long, for being overthrown by the latter in a mortal Battle, was delivered bound by his Souldiers to the Conqueror, who depriving him of his Sight, ≈øent him to the Emperor, then re≈øiding at Con≈øtantinople.

The Rebellion created ≈øuch Jealou≈øie in the Emperor, that he cho≈øe rather to tru≈øt ≈øtrangers, then his own Subjects, ≈øo that he having notice of the Ma≈ø≈øagetes, a People dwelling beyond I≈øter, being oppre≈ø≈øed by the Tartars, he upon their Supplication, appointed them part of his Dominions, whereupon they came over to him with about 10000 families, which cau≈øed him to fall into the di≈øplea≈øure of his Subjects; the≈øe new-come gue≈øts, being compleatly Armed, he ≈øent them with many others, again≈øt the Turks, under one leading of his Son, and Partner in the Empire Michael Paleologus, who at the fir≈øt ≈øight of the Turks, without ≈øo much as ≈øtriking a ≈øtroak fled, which gave the Enemy the advantage of conquering the Country as ‚Ä¢ ar as Le≈øtos.

After this as if de≈øtiny had ≈øo willed it, the Emperor called to his aid Ronzerius a Pirate, who came with 2000 Catalonians, and afterwards increa≈øe ‚Ä¢ his number by ≈øending for more, who at fir≈øt did con≈øiderable ≈øervice, but within a while fell to ≈øpoiling and plundering the Emperors Dominions in A≈øia, wor≈øe then the Turks, as likewi≈øe by ≈øetting out certain Gallies, bobbed all the Merchants that pa≈ø≈øed tho≈øe Seas, till at la≈øt their Gallies being de≈øtroyed by a Fleet of the Genoways, and their Captain ≈ølain, by the command of the young Emperor, they called in the Turks, having fir≈øt ≈øeized upon the City of Calipolis; again≈øt the≈øe who with joynt forces hara≈øed the Country, the young Emperor went in per≈øon, but was overthrown and mo≈øt of his Greeks ≈ølain, upon the revolt of the Ma≈ø≈øagets and other treacherous Mercenaries, who were ≈øhortly recompenced according to their de≈øerts; for being about to return home with the ≈øpoil they had gotten, the Catalonians ≈øet upon them, and put 'um all to the Sword, taking from them a rich booty, and then pa≈ø≈øing through many
Countries, they left the Emperor free, till at la≈øt coming to the Territories of the Duke of Thebes, and he refu≈øing to give them pa≈ø≈øage, they in a ≈øet battle overthrew his power and ≈øeized on his Country, in which they ≈øettled them≈øelves, where their Po≈øterity to this day remains.

But this freed not the Emperor of the danger, for the Turks coming down in great number, and having overthrown the young Emperor ≈øpoiled all Thracia, to ≈øtay who≈øe fury Philes Paleologus a devout man and Kin≈øman to the Emperor, undertook the defence of his bleeding Country, and meeting them as they were ranging to and fro burning and de≈øtroying all before 'um, he in a ≈øet battle overthrew 'um, and forced 'um into the City of Cher≈øone≈øus, where he ≈øo ≈øtraightly be≈øieged them by Sea and Land, that indeavouring to break through the Leaguer, they were mo≈øt of them ≈ølain, and the re≈øt taken Pri≈øoners.

Things being at this pa≈øs, and by this means peace Recovered to the Empire, inte≈øtine broyles began anew to be fomented by the factious Greeks; for the young Emperor being dead, they ≈øtirred up young Adronicus his Son, to depo≈øe his Grand-father the old Emperor, which after ≈øeveral Stratagems and devices he effected, taking the City of Con≈øtantinople by trea≈øon, and ca≈øting him in Pri≈øon where of grief he ≈øoon after died.

The≈øe Civil di≈ø≈øen≈øions of the Greeks among≈øt them≈øelves, gave Othoman the opportunity to ≈øound his Empire in Phrygia and Bythima, where being ≈øucce≈øsful in all his Attempts he mightily increa≈øed his Dominions, having by this time ≈øubdued 20 Cities with all their Territories, and among≈øt the re≈øt Pru≈øia, which after along Siege worn out with Famine Anno 1327 yielded upon ≈øeveral Articles, few of which were afterward
ob≈øerved, by the Turk, which being the greate≈øt City in tho≈øe parts of A≈øia, became for many years after the ≈øeat of the Turki≈øh Kings. But as all men mu≈øt yield to death, ≈øo in the 28 year of his Reign, and the 69 year of his Age Othoman the Founder of the Turki≈øh Empire, ≈øtill called from him the Othoman Empire, died, and was buried in Pru≈øia, where to this day his Tomb is to be ≈øeen, and in his new acquired Kingdom, Orchanes his Second Son ≈øucceeded him, his elde≈øt dying during his Regency.

div.head: CHAP. VII. The Life and Actions of Orchanes, otherwi≈øe Urchan, Second King of the Turks in A≈øia.
div.p:
THE Funeral rights of this great Conqueror being performed by his Sons, viz. Orchanes, alias ∆≤rchan, his Second Son, and Aladin his third and younge≈øt Son, and he having left great ≈øtore of wealth, Orchanes his Succe≈ø≈øor took upon him the rule of the Kingdom, allotting to his Brother Aladin, at his reque≈øt the Lord≈øhip of Fodore in the Teckences Country, where he lived a private Life, without doing any thing worthy of memory, but Orchanes now ≈øettled in his Kingdom, following his fathers foot≈øteps, who≈øe Armies of late he had altogether commanded as his General, he forgat not to proceed where he had left off, and therefore prepare to War upon the Chri≈øtians, but at fir≈øt with no great Succe≈øs, for the Chri≈øtians upon the death of
Othoman, drawing their forces together out of all parts, recovered the City of Nice, with divers Ca≈øtles and Towns, and among≈øt the re≈øt the Ca≈øtle Tzuprichi≈øer, which greatly hindered the Turks excur≈øions, who dwelt in Bithynia; whereupon Orchanes upon notice that it was ≈ølenderly Guarded, went with ≈øeveral of his followers, in the attire of Merchants, and by that means deceiving the warders got admittance, but were no ≈øooner entered e're they proved fatal ones; for drawing their Swords they put all ≈øuch as they found therein to death, and ≈øeized the Ca≈øtle, and having Garri≈øoned it, pa≈ø≈øed on to the City of Nice, to which they lay'd ≈øiege, when to re≈øcue it the young Emperor Andronicus came with ≈øuch power as he could rai≈øe, but being for the mo≈øt part unexperienced Soldiers, the Turks from the Mountains, as they were pa≈ø≈øing through the hot Country, ≈øetting upon them a cruel battel begun, but night coming on they parted by con≈øent, yet in this fight the Emperor lo≈øt near half his People, and was him≈øelf wounded with an Arrow, ≈øo that de≈øpairing of effecting what he came for, leaving his Tents and great ≈øtore of Furniture therein, every man ≈øhifted for him≈øelf in the dead of Night, ≈øo that next Morning what they left became a prey to the Infidels, who hightened by this Succe≈øs, took in ≈øeveral Sea Towns, and within a while recovered the City of Nice, by Stratagem; As thus the Emperor in his flight thither from his Camp, had promi≈øed to ≈øend them 1000 Hor≈øe-men of which Orchanes having notice di≈øgui≈øed 800 of his men in Grecian habit, and ≈øent them with full in≈øtructions, who being come within ≈øight of the City, he ≈øent out 300 other in Turki≈øh habit as foragers, whom the other e≈øpying, as if they had been ignorant of the Matter, turned upon them, and after a feigned ≈økirmi≈øh put them to flight, then taking their way to the City, the Citizens who from their walls had
beheld what had pa≈ø≈øed joyfully opened their Gates, ≈øuppo≈øing them to be the Emperors promi≈øed Aid; but they no ≈øooner entered but the other 300 Hor≈øe, and ≈øeveral Companies of Foot who lay in Ambu≈øh, were at their Heels; by which means that great City was a ≈øecond time taken by the Turks, who≈øe Riches became a prey to the Soldiers, and who≈øe Inhabitants became of free Per≈øons mi≈øerable Captives.

The Fate of this great City followed many others in the ≈øame Tract, the Turks wa≈øting all before them as they went, mi≈øerably burning up what they could not carry away; ≈øo that the Countries before them were di≈øpeopled, all the Inhabitants flying from them, as a ten-fold Contagion: So that no con≈øiderable Forces being ≈øent from the Emperor, the Cities fell into his Hands in great abundance, and above all being de≈øirous to po≈ø≈øe≈øs the two fair Ca≈øtles of Abydos and Se≈øtus, he ≈øent Accecozza, one of his great Captains to win them if po≈ø≈øible, who by the way having Intelligence that the Captains Son of the Ca≈øtle of Seamandra being dead, his Funeral was ≈øuch a day to be Solemnized without the Walls; whereupon laying an Ambu≈øhment, they upon the Mourners approach, ≈øuddenly i≈ø≈øued from their Coverts, and ≈ølew ≈øeveral of them, taking the remainder Pri≈øoners, and among≈øt them the Captain, whom they carried to the Ca≈øtle; telling tho≈øe that kept the Walls, that if they did not deliver it, he ≈øhould be put to a Cruel Death before their Eyes; at which nothing di≈ømayed they returned An≈øwer, that they might Kill him, Boyl him, and Eat him if they plea≈øed, but as for the Ca≈øtle they would not deliver it; whereupon he finding it a work of great Difficulty to take by force, departed to Se≈øtus which he with little Difficulty took, and had his Pri≈øoners Ran≈øomed for a great Ma≈øs of Mony, and among≈øt the re≈øt, the Captain of Scamandra; and
now Abydos ≈øtanding in Europe on the other ≈øide the Hell ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ , was the only place Aimed at, when, as Fate would have the Night before the Turks came before it the Captain of the Ca≈øtles Daughter dreamt that ≈øhe falling „Äà‚óä„Äâ miry made her Clean; the which as ≈øoon as „Äà‚óä„Äâ the viewed Abdurachman one of the Turki≈øh Captains, the fancied him to be the ≈øame Per≈øon ≈øhe had „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ Vi≈øion, and ≈øo ≈øtrongly her fancy wrong „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ he lead up his Forces again≈øt the Wall, „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ Power from whence ≈øhe beheld what was „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ a Letter tyed to a ≈øtone at his Fee ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢
„Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ pre≈øed her Pa≈ø≈øion, Prote≈øting that „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ of her Love, ≈øhe would on ≈øuch a „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ Ca≈øtle into his Hands. This Letter „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ
Ac ‚Ä¢ ecozza, he much doubted the „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ ≈øearing it was a de≈øign to draw them „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ upon Abdurachman's Reque≈øt, that he might „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ the Enterprize, he Con≈øented; it being agreed, that to give the be≈øieged the le≈øs Su≈øpicion, the Army ≈øhould give a general a≈ø≈øault, and then draw off, the which being done, the Garri≈øon buried in Sleep and Wine for joy of the Turks departure, neglecting their Watches; the Captain being Conducted by his Mi≈øtre≈øs a private way, entered with about fifty Followers, and putting the Warders to the Sword, opened the Gates and let in the Army, who the next Morning took the Garri≈øon. The Turks departed with their Pri≈øoners and ≈øuch Booty as they found: The Tratyre≈øs being given to Abdurachman as a reward of his Adventurous undertaking, not long after Accecozza dying, Orchanes made his Sons, Amurath and Solyman Lords of the Provinces he had taken from the Chri≈øtians, who lay'd Siege to the City of Ni ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ media, which de≈øpairing of ≈øuccour, ≈øurrender'd upon Condition, that ≈øo many as would depart might, and tho≈øe
that would ≈øtay there might, without any hurt: Either Body, or Goods, of which City Solyman was made Governour, and thereupon he removed his Court from Pru≈øa to Nice, that he might be near his new Conque≈øts at all times, to give ≈øuch nece≈ø≈øary Orders as were Convenient; and ≈øo pro≈øpered that he ≈øoon after got Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of Taraxa, Govinucia, and Mndurne; and rai≈øing a pui≈ø≈øant Army, he invaded the Country of Cara≈øiana (the Brothers of the decea≈øed King being at odds about the Succe≈ø≈øion) and ≈øoon over-run it, forcing one of the Brothers to fly into Pergamum, and the other as his Va≈ø≈øal to hold the Kingdom in Fee of him, at the ≈øame time made his younger Son Amurath Lord of Pru≈øa.

The Turki≈øh Kingdom being thus ≈øettled in A≈øia, Archanes con≈øulted with his Son Solyman about getting footing in Europe, which he promi≈øed to effect; and upon his return to his Government, ≈øent over Ezes-Bey his chief Captain, and ≈øome others to di≈øcover the Country; who taking a Greek Pri≈øoner returned and pre≈øented him to Solyman, who having given him Mony and Rayment, inquired of the Nature of the Country, who informed them at large: Whereupon repa≈ø≈øing with a ≈ømall Force, they ≈øeized upon the Ca≈øtle of Zembenick, without doing any harm to the Garri≈øon, which was indeed but ≈ømall; mo≈øt of them being gone out to fetch in their Harve≈øt.

The News of the Turks landing in Europe, ≈øoon flew to Con≈øtantinople, but ≈øuch was their Cowardi≈øe and Sloath together with inte≈øtine Divi≈øions, that no Care was taken to expul≈øe them: So that they daily increa≈øing their Power, by ≈øuch as were ≈øent over in Boats, ≈øeized al≈øo upon the Ca≈øtle of Maditas, and afterward ≈øpoiled the Country of Cher≈øone≈øus, as far as Callipolis; which City they took after having overthrown the Governour in a pitched Battle; yet ≈øo infatuated
were the greater part of the Greeks, that they made a je≈øt of the proceedings of the Turks, who were by this time advanced 200 from the Ca≈øtle of Zembenick, where they fir≈øt Landed. Whereupon Solyman ≈øent to his Father, to acquaint him with what had pa≈ø≈øed, as likewi≈øe to de≈øire him, to ≈øend him fre≈øh ≈øupplies of Men, not only to ≈øecure what he had won, but to pro≈øecute his ≈øucce≈øsful beginning; upon the receipe of which news Orchanes greatly rejoyced, and immediately Commanded 1000 Sarazens and Turks, to pa≈øs the Helle≈øpont in Boats prepared for that purpo≈øe, upon who≈øe Arrival Solyman intercepted the Goveronour of Conger Ca≈øtle, who had greatly annoyed the Turks, and ≈øtriking off his Head before the Ca≈øtle-Gate ≈øo terrified tho≈øe that were within, that they ≈øoon ≈øurrendred the Place, from whence the Turks frequently ≈øallying fetched in great Booties, venturing even to the Walls of Didymotichum.

And thus in the ≈øpace of one year, the Turks got ≈øtrong footing in Europe, po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øing them≈øelves of divers Ca≈øtles and Towns, with the Countries about them; which Solyman as a reward of their Service, gave to his Captains and Soldiers, as appeareth by the Monuments of Ezes-Beg, and Fazel-Beg the fir≈øt, Two Turki≈øh Captains that ≈øet Footing in Europe, but for a while a ≈øtop was put to the Turks Progre≈øs, occa≈øioned by the Death of Solyman; who hawking in the Fields of Bolyre, and following too furious in taking a Ditch, his Hor≈øe threw him where he received ≈øuch a mortal brui≈øe, that he within a few days after died, which News coming to his Father Orchanes, he for grief fell ≈øick, and within two Months gave up the Gho≈øt, Anno 1359. and of his Age 80 years, having Reigned 31 years.
This Orchanes was both warlike and Politick; Courteous he was to his Friends, and ≈øtern to his Enemies, much devoted to the Mahometan ≈øuper≈øtition; and a great Enemy to the Chri≈øtians.

div.head: CHAP. VIII. The Life and Actions of Amurath the fir≈øt of that Name, and third King of the Turks.
div.p:
OChanes and Solyman his elde≈øt Son being dead, Amurath ≈øucceeded in the Kingdom, as the younger Son to the decea≈øed King; who at his fir≈øt Entrance upon his Government, had great Conte≈øts with the Turki≈øh Princes of the le≈ø≈øer A≈øia, who Envying his a≈øpiring, as ≈øuppo≈øing in the Currant of his Victories, he might as well overthrow them, as the Chri≈øtians; but having Vanqui≈øhed their Forces, and brought them Terms of Agreement, he turned his Arms upon Europe with a great ho≈øt; pa≈ø≈øing the Helle≈øpont he ≈øeized upon the Ca≈øtle of Benutum, when pa≈ø≈øing on the Greeks now rou≈øed out of their ≈øecurity, oppo≈øed him with ≈øuch Forces as they could draw together, but were ≈øoon overthrown: After which he won the Town of Trurulus, taking likewi≈øe all the Ca≈øtles and ≈ømall Towns adjoyning, as Me≈øine, Burgos, Hebrus, and ≈øoon after Didimotichum; and ≈øtaying there ≈øent one of his Captains named Lala-Schakin, to be≈øiege Hadrianople, now called Adrianople with whom the Chri≈øtians fought a great and mortal Battle, but ≈øuch was their ill ≈øteered Fate that Victory declared for the Infidels. So that that great City being out of all hopes of Relief, opened her Gates to the Enemy, Anno 1362. The City of Hadrianople being taken, or, as their own Hi≈øtories relate, taken by Treachery in time of Peace; Amuratis made it the chief Seat of the Turki≈øh Kings
in Europe, as a place from whence he might be≈øt annoy Christendom, and then ≈øending for his Captains, he Commanded to invade the Countries of Philipopolis, Zogora, and Ip≈øala; the which in a ≈ønort time they brought under Subjection.

The Turki≈øh Kingdom in a ≈ømall time being ≈øpread wide, Cura Ru≈øtemes the Doctor of the Mahometan Law, and Zinderlu Chelil the Chief Ju≈øtice devi≈øed the Order or Con≈øtitution of the Janizaries (which have ever ≈øince been available to Turks in all their Wars) after this manner, that ≈øeeing there were great multitudes of Chri≈øtian Captives frequently taken, the Youths above fifteen years of Age ≈øhould every fifth be the Kings, and if there wanted of five, then he who had them ≈øhoud pay twenty five A≈øpers a Head, and that tho≈øe which appertained to the Kind ≈øhould for three of four years be put to hard Labour, the better to inure 'um to Hard≈øhip; and then being brought to Court to ≈øerve in the Wars, as the Kings Life-Guard being alway near his Per≈øon. Which advice was ≈øo well approved of, that it has continued acceptable to the Othoman Kings and Emperors ever ≈øince.

Amurath having ≈øettled his Conque≈øts in Europe, leaving a ≈øufficient Power with his great Captains: The Winter coming on, the pa≈ø≈øed over into A≈øia; but early in the Spring, upon view tha the Chri≈øtians were in Arms he returned, and by the way took the Town of Boge, putting the chief Inhabitants to the Sword, and carrying away the re≈øt Captives, but held it not long e'r it was recovered and ra≈øed by the Chri≈øtians, who ≈øerved the Turks in like manner.

In the mean time the Chri≈øtian Army in Servia and Bulgaria con≈øi≈øting of 50000 Hor≈øe and Foot, advanced in Order to their be≈øieging Adrianople, which obliged him for his better ≈øecurity, to ha≈øte over the Helle≈øpont, giving Order for a great number of A≈øians
to follow him, but by rea≈øon of the Christians di≈øcord among≈øt them≈øelves, and refu≈øing to joyn their Forces, they were ≈øet upon at advantage, and overthrown with the lo≈øs of half the Army, e'r the Forces arrived from A≈øia. The News of which fatal overthrow ≈øpreading wide, Anairath's Fame ≈øpread wider; In≈øomuch that German-Ogly Reigning in the le≈ø≈øer A≈øia, and being chief of the Zelzuccian Family, ≈øent his Amba≈ø≈øadors to intreat a Marriage between his Daughter Hatun, and young Bajazet, in lieu of which he promi≈øed a great part of his Territory, and that his Son-in-Law at his Death ≈øhould ≈øucceed him in his Kingdom, by that means joyning both Families into one, the which in ≈øhort time was accorded; at the Celebration of which Nuptials, the Amba≈ø≈øadors of almo≈øt all the Princes of the Ea≈øt were pre≈øent, who in the Names of their Lords pre≈øented the Bridegroom and Bride with exceeding rich Gifts; but Amurath to outdo them all, cau≈øed Eurono≈øes to bring out of Europe 100 beautiful Boys, with as many Virgins; all Chri≈øtian Captives clad in rich Garments, imbroidered with Gold and Pearl, each of them holding a Cup of Gold in the one hand, and a Cup of Silver in the other, filled with Jewels, Pearls, Amber, and the like; which he cau≈øed in requital of their Kindne≈øs given to the Amba≈ø≈øador to be.
At this Marriage Chu≈øun-Beg Prince of Ami≈øum in Galatia, ≈øold by his Amba≈ø≈øador his Territories of Ami≈øum to Amurath, as doubting to keep them; the Turks Power being now ≈øo near him.

The Nuptials Celebrated, Amurath making his Son Bajazer Governour of his Countries in Anatolia, gathered what Forces he could for the Inva≈øion of Servia, taking by the way the ≈øtrong City of Pherae; and entering Servia the De≈øpot no ways able to oppo≈øe him, he took Ni≈ø≈øa the Metropolis of that Province; and ≈øoon
after Apolonia with many other places of ≈øtrength, ≈øo in fourteen days over-run nigh all the Provinces, but receiving News out of A≈øia, that Aladine King of Caramania, who a little before had Married his Daughter, wa≈øted his Countries in A≈øia with Fire and Sword, which ≈øo inraged Amurath, that making Peace with the De≈øpot of Servia, he pa≈ø≈øed over with an Army of 70000 Hor≈øe and Foot, to whom in number Aladine was not inferior, as having Confederated hm≈øelf with all the Petty Princes of A≈øia, when after ≈øeveral overtures of Peace propo≈øed and none accepted; both Armies joyned on the great Plains of Carramania, where after a dreadful Battle Aladin's Army was overthrown, he was forced to fly into Iconium his chief City, and was there ≈øtraightly be≈øieged, but at the humble Supplication of his Queen, who would have no denyal at her Fathers hands; he upon his Submi≈ø≈øion was re≈øtored again to his Dignity and Kingdom, as likewi≈øe were all the Princes, his Confederates upon Condition of acknowledging him their ≈øupream Lord.

Whil≈øt the≈øe things pa≈ø≈øed, the De≈øpot of Servia grieving that he had made ≈øuch a di≈øhonourable League with the Turks, and being told by his General, ≈øent with Forces to a≈ø≈øi≈øt Amurath again≈øt the Caramanian King, how de≈øpightfully he had u≈øed him and his Soldiers, therewithal ≈øtirring him up to break the League, and ca≈øt off the ≈øervile Yoak, he ≈øent ≈øecretly to the King of Bozan, to reque≈øt him to joyn with him again≈øt the Turki≈øh Tyrant, who willingly accorded; and at an interview between the ≈øaid King, and the De≈øpot all things were agreed, upon Notice of which Amurath was not a little perplexed, but yet re≈øolving to take revenge, he gathered great Forces to invade both Princes; the which whil≈øt he was doing, the Captain of Alexandria took a Ca≈øtle in the Confines
of Bo≈øan, came privately to his Tent and offered to deliver to him mo≈øt part of the Country, if he would follow his directions, ≈øtrengthening his Promi≈øe with many ≈øpecious Arguments; in≈øomuch that the Greedy Turk giving Credit to what he had ≈øaid, ≈øent twenty thou≈øand Men under the leading of his great Captain and Tutor Lala-Schalin, who plundering part of the Country, and at la≈øt by the ≈øaid Captains device, who had by Amurath been highly honoured, e≈øpecially with a rich Cloak, which ≈øignifies the Per≈øon ≈øo inve≈øted to be highly in the Favour of the Turki≈øh King; but having drawn them within the Danger of the Ambu≈øh, he ≈øent to the King of Bo≈øan, who coming upon them with 30000 Greeks, as they were ≈øtragling cut of 50000 of them, the other 5000 with Schakin hardly e≈øcaping to tell the News.

With this overthrow of his Men, Amurath was greatly inraged, and gathering all his Power marched into Servia (which before he had Relinqui≈øhed upon the De≈øpots becoming his Tributary) where he found the Chri≈øtians with a formidable Army ready to receive him; when after ≈øome Towns and Ca≈øtles taken, on either ≈øide, both Armies met upon the great Plains of Co≈ø≈øovia, where when the Captains on either ≈øide had put their Men in Order; exhorting them to do their be≈øt for obtaining the Victory, they joyned with ≈øuch Fury that the Earth trembled under their Feet, and ≈øuch was the horrid noi≈øe of Cla≈øhing Arms, ≈øhouts of the Conquerors Cries, of the Vanqui≈øhed and Weeing of Hor≈øes, that wild Bea≈øts in the Mountains trembled; and tho≈øe that beheld the Fight ≈øuppo≈øed that ≈øhowers of Arrows de≈øcended from the Clouds. At fir≈øt the Turks gave back, being a≈ø≈øailed by the Chri≈øtians in great number, and the Right Wing routed, but Bajazet coming in with a fre≈øh Power renewed the Battle, which having continued eight hours with
great ≈ølaughter: In≈øomuch that all the Plains were covered with the Bodies of the ≈ølain, mo≈øt of the Chri≈øtian Captains killed Valiantly fighting, and among≈øt the re≈øt, Lazerus the De≈øpot, the Victory fell to the Turks; tho≈øe that fell in the Battle, not being accounted le≈øs then 50000.

After the Battle was over, Amurath greatly Rejoycing in his huge Conque≈øt, in a Vain-glorious Humour would needs take a view of the heaps of the dead Carca≈ø≈øes, which made the Plain Mountainous, when as a half dead Soldier, named Cobelits faint with lo≈øs of Blood and Wounds, ri≈øing as it were from the Grave, came towards him ≈øtaggering and falling three or four times in twenty paces, when tho≈øe that were about him, would have hindered his approach; but Amurath (De≈øtiny ≈øo ordering) Commanded he ≈øhould have acce≈øs, ≈øuppo≈øing he would have Petitioned for his Life; when on the contrary without a Word ≈øpeaking, Cobelits drawing forth a Dagger, ≈øtabbed him into the Belly, for which he was pre≈øently hewn in pieces; nor did Amurath long ≈øurvive him, but within three days after dyed of his Wound, and was buryed in Pru≈øia, Anno 1390. of his Age 68 years, and of his Reign 31 years. To whom ≈øucceeded Bajazet his elde≈øt Son, who was no ≈øooner Crowned, but he cau≈øed his Brother Jacup to be ≈øtrangled in his Pre≈øence with a Bow-≈øtring, which wicked Precedent has ever ≈øince been put in Practice by the Othoman Kings and Emperors.

div.head: CHAP. X. The Life of Bajazet, the first of that Name and Fourth King of the Turks his Wars and Captivity.
div.p: BAjazet a man of a Proud and haughty temper, having taken upon him the Regency of his Father's Kingdoms, fell heavily upon Servia, not ≈øo much as vouch≈øafing to hear the Emba≈ø≈øadors ≈øent on their behalf, which made the Princes of the We≈øt begin to con≈øider their own e≈øtate, and e≈øpecially Vincelaus the German Emperor, and Sigi≈ømond King of Hungary, and not contented with the ≈øpiols of Servia, he made ≈øeveral inroads into Bo≈øan, ≈øpoiling the Country and carrying away great booties, when in the mean while the King of Caramania hearing of his Fathers death, began anew to wa≈øte his Countries in A≈øia, which cau≈øed Bajazet to ≈øend a great power, who overthrew him and recovered all that was lo≈øt taking from him likewi≈øe his own Country which obliged him in humble wi≈øe to beg their re≈øtauration, which Bajazet upon condition that he ≈øhould from that time forward become his va≈ø≈øal re≈øtored.

About this time Philadelphia, the only City the Chri≈øtians had in A≈øia, was be≈øieged by Bajazets Power, and after a ≈øtraight Siege and no hopes of any ≈øuccours, delivered by the Citizens as a ran≈øom for their Lives and Per≈øons.

Having ≈øubdued Servia, and the greate≈øt part of Bo≈øan, he invaded The≈ø≈øalia wa≈øting it as he pa≈ø≈øed with fire and Sword, even to the Walls of The≈ø≈øalonica,
taking Neopolis in Greece; and Joannia in Aetolia, and afterward returning into A≈øia he there ≈øpent the Winter, but Spring being come, with all his Power he repa≈ø≈øed the Helle≈øpont, and lay'd clo≈øe Siege to Con≈øtantinople, the ≈øeat of the Greek Emperor, Emanuel Paleologus then Reigning, who after he had been brought to great extremity, went to the German Emperors Court to crave aid, who together with many other Chri≈øtian Princes, ≈øent an Army of 250000 under the leading of young Sigi≈ømond King of Hungary, to oppo≈øe whom Bajazet rai≈øed his Siege and found them be≈øieging Neocopolis; from whence they drew into the great Plain and joyned Battle, but by rea≈øon of the confu≈øion that was in the Chri≈øtian Army, their Van being overcharged, the Rear fled without ≈øtriking a ≈øtroak, ≈øo that the Turks getting the Victory with a far le≈øs number pur≈øued ≈øo hard upon the Chri≈øtians that the greater part of the Army was ≈ølain, taken pri≈øoners and drowned in pa≈ø≈øing the River Danubius.

After this great and unexpected Victory over the Chri≈øtians occa≈øioned by the emulation that aro≈øe among≈øt their great Commanders, Bajazet returned to the Siege of Con≈øtantinople, now out of all hope to be relieved, where whil≈øt he lay ca≈øting his eyes upon De≈øpina, the ≈ølain De≈øpot of Servia's fair Daughter, offered by her Mother; his former Wife being dead he Married her, and for her ≈øake re≈øtored to her Brother Stephen all his fathers Principalities.

Aladin the Carramanian King being dead, and his Son of the ≈øame name Reigning in his ≈øtead, de≈øirous to revenge the wrong Bajazet had done his Fathers Subjects, coming to Aucyra ≈øurpri≈øed Temurta≈ø≈øes Bajazet's great Lievtenant, but upon the approach of Bajazet with his Army he richly arraying begged his pardon, and ≈øet him at liberty, ≈øending Emba≈ø≈øadors to
excu≈øe them; but Bajazet would not ≈øuffer them to come into his ≈øight, whereupon the young King gathering all the Power of his Country, fought with him a great Battle, but being far too weak for ≈øuch an Enemy was overthrown & he taken Pri≈øoner, & by the Command of Bajazet delivered to Temurta≈øes his Capital Enemy, who for the di≈øgrace he had put upon him cau≈øed him to be ≈øtrangled, which ra≈øh deed much grieved Bajazet, the young Prince being his Si≈øters Son, yet he ≈øeized upon the greate≈øt part of his Kingdom, though he had ≈øeveral Sons living, and ≈øo inraged was he that he expul≈øed all the Mahometan Princes in Le≈ø≈øer A≈øia, and ≈øeized upon their Territories, whereupon they fled to Tamerlane the Great, who having Married the daughter of the Cham or Emperor of Tartary, and now returned from the Conque≈øt of China, he took them into his protection, and being at the ≈øame time Solicited for aid by Emanuel the Greek Emperor, he ≈øent to Bajazet his Emba≈ø≈øadors, with many rich pre≈øents, reque≈øting him to cea≈øe from mole≈øting his Allies, but he in a proud manner not only rejected his pre≈øents, but with many opprobrious words, ca≈øt foul reproaches on him, telling his Emba≈ø≈øadors that he de≈øired nothing more then to meet him in the field, and with many taunting expre≈ø≈øions di≈ømi≈ø≈øed them. The report of which ≈øo throughly netled the Tartar, that he re≈øolved with a pui≈ø≈øant Army to go again≈øt him, being hightened thereto by Axalla his great favourite, a Genoway by birth, and friend to the Greek Emperor, who≈øe cau≈øe he daily ≈øolicited. And Tamerlane who was a wellwi≈øher to the Chri≈øtians, in his opinion differing little from them ≈øo well approved of all he ≈øaid, and having taken his leave of his Father-in-Law, and his Wife, with a powerful Army he pa≈ø≈øed the Mountains, Marching through many Countries, none daring oppo≈øe his pa≈ø≈øage, till at length coming to Bachichich, he mu≈øtered
his Army, and found it to con≈øi≈øt of 800000 Hor≈øe and Foot of divers Nations, to whom he gave general pay, not having ≈øuffered the lea≈øt wrong to be done in any Country, through which he had pa≈ø≈øed.

Bajazet lying at the Siege of Con≈øtantinople, and hearing the Tartar approached with a Power that covered the Countries as he pa≈ø≈øed, he rai≈øed his Siege, and contrary to Tamerlains Expectation, but even as he wi≈øhed, came over with ≈øuch forces as he could rai≈øe, into A≈øia; where he joyned with his Livetenant, whil≈øt the Tartars ≈øtill came on, having by this time pa≈ø≈øed Euphrates, and taken all the Cities in their way, that appertained to Bajazet, and among≈øt the re≈øt the great City of Saba≈øtia, once the chief Seat of the Turki≈øh Sultan, utterly ra≈øing it, putting all the Citizens to the Sword, or as ≈øome, Buryed them alive in deep Pits he cau≈øed to be digged for that purpo≈øe, unle≈øs the Governour whom he ≈øet at Liberty to carry the News to Bajazet, who was advancing 500000 Strong, who upon the Governours coming into his pre≈øence, demanded which was the greater Army he having ≈øeen both, to which after having craved pardon, he replyed that the Tartars Army mu≈øt needs be the greate≈øt: by Rea≈øon he was Lord of far greater Countries; whereupon Bajazet Laughing, ≈øaid out of doubt the ≈øight of the Tartars hath made this Coward ≈øo affraid, that he thinketh every Enemy two.

The Armies being come near to each other upon the great Plains of Sennas, he thought not good to joyn Battle pre≈øently by Rea≈øon the Evening approached; yet many light Skirmi≈øhes happened between the Parthian Hor≈øemen, and the Forerunners of the Turki≈øh Army; but the next Morning either Hoa≈øt being ≈øet in Array, after ≈øome Pau≈øe the charge
was Sounded, whereupon the Prince of Ciarcan Tamarlin's Kin≈ø-man, with 40000 Hor≈øe charged the Turks in the Front, and Piercing their Battle, put the Jannizaries into di≈øorder; but venturing too far was there Slain, whereupon Axalla Leading the Vaunt-Guard compo≈øed of Sciths and Parthians, bore upon the left Wing of the Turks Army, cutting in pieces and Bearing down all that oppos'd him, at what time his Footmen coming to joyn with him he Faced the Batalion of the Jnnaizaries; who behaved them≈øelves Valiantly for the ≈øafety of their Prince, who in the middle of them Fought on Foot, which Fight continued Bloody, and doubtful for the ≈øpace of an Hour, all the place being heaped with the Bodies of the Slain; till at la≈øt the Tartars being overcharged gave Ground, which Tamerlain from his Stand perceiving ≈øent 10000 Hor≈øe to Reinforce them, and other 10000 to Fight in the Rearward, and at the ≈øame time ≈øent his Foot-men, who fell in with the Turks main Battle that remained yet un≈øhaken with ≈øuch fury, that making them give way, he opened them to the Rear of the Jannizaries; wherein was yet the Per≈øon of Bajazet, who ≈øu≈øtained the greate≈øt Brunt of the Fight, but at la≈øt overpowered with number, they were forced to give Gronnd, at what time Tamerlain coming on with 50000 fre≈øh Hor≈øe, Bore down all before him till he came to the Jannizaries (who always Fight in the Heart of the Army) and they weary, and not able to make ≈øufficient re≈øi≈øtance, were trodden down on all ≈øides, ≈øo that the Battle Swerving, the Turks betook them≈øelves to Flight, and among≈øt the re≈øt Bajazet wounded as he was, who afterwards fell into the Hands of Axalla, together with his Son Mu≈øa. The De≈øpot of Servia and many others of note.

This great Victory fell to the Tartars chiefly, by
the revolt of a great number of Bajazet's men; who were rai≈øed in the Countries of the Mahometan Princes expul≈øed, who in the Heat of the Battle, ≈øeeing their natural Lords under Tamerline's Standard went over to 'um.

This Fight la≈øted Bloody and doubtful from Seven in the Morning till four in the Evening, wherein as many report 200000 on either ≈øide were Slain, and among≈øt the re≈øt Mu≈øtapha Bajazets Son with mo≈øt of his great Commanders.

After this Bajazet being brought before Tamerlain, and demanded why he oppre≈ø≈øed the Chri≈øtians, and made War upon ≈øo Noble a Prince as was the Emperor of Greece; to which he replyed, Even the ≈øame thing that hath moved thee to invade me, even the de≈øire of Glory and Soveraignty; and why, ≈øaid Tamerlain, do you u≈øe ≈øuch Tyranny over tho≈øe you Conquer without Re≈øpect of Sex or Age? That I did, ≈øaid he, to give the greater Terror to my Enemies: Ah what would≈øt thou have done with me, ≈øaid Tamerlain, if it had been thy Fortune to have had me in thy Power? I would, ≈øaid the haughty Turk (not Conquered tho overcome) have put thee in a Cage of Iron, and have carryed thee in Triumph about my Kingdom. Even ≈øo ≈øaid Tamerlain, ≈øhalt thou be ≈øerved, and thereupon commanded him out of his pre≈øence, and as he had determined, ≈øhortly after Cooped him up in a Cage of Iron, and carryed him into the Countries he Conquered, who≈øe Calamity may well ≈øerve as a memento to all a≈øpiring Mortals, by putting them in mind that the Worldly Glory is not perminent.

After this the Greek Emperor ≈øent his Amba≈ø≈øedor to Tamerlain in his Name, to deliver up his City and Empire; but he refu≈øed, ≈øaying he had Dominions ≈øufficient of his own, and after having ≈øeen
the City and wondered at its fair Structures and Riches, he taking leave of the Emperor; he pa≈ø≈øed with his Army into Egypt, to be revenged on the Sultan for a≈ø≈øi≈øtng Bajazet again≈øt him with 30000 Mamalukes, having fir≈øt ≈øubdued all, or the greate≈øt part of all the Turks Dominions in A≈øia; and intirely re≈øtored Europe to its rightful po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øors: and meeting with the Sultan he overthrew his Army, con≈øi≈øting of 174000 Hor≈øe and Foot, and ≈øo wining Dama≈øco, Jeru≈øalem, Damiata, Cairo, and mo≈øt of the Cities in Egypt, Syria, Lybia, and other Ea≈øtern Countries, making all the Kings as he pa≈ø≈øed become his Tributaries, he left Calibes a great Captain with the greate≈øt part of his Army, to pur≈øue the Egyptian Sultan, and ≈øecure what he had won; having news that his Father in Law was ≈øick, and that his Wife was de≈øirous of his Company, he returned into his Country, but 'ere his departure Bajazet as de≈øperate and impatient of his Misfortune, had beaten his Brains out again≈øt the Bars of his Cage, as the mo≈ø Authentick Authors affirm; tho the Turks ≈øay he was ≈øet at Liberty by Tamerlain, who beforehand had cau≈øed to take Poy≈øon, of which within three Days he dyed, tho their ≈øaying is very unlikely to be true; but however he was Buryed in Pru≈øa, by his beloved Wife De≈øpina, Anno 1399. having Reigned ≈øeven years, and kept under re≈øtraint two years.

div.head: CHAP. X. The Life of Mahomet the fir≈øt King of the Turks, and the re≈øtorer of their Kingdom ruined by the Tartars.
div.p: THough Hi≈øtorians ≈øomewhat vary about the Succe≈ø≈øor of Bajazet, yet the mo≈øt Credible do affirm that his Son Mahomet, ≈øeveral of his other Brothers being ≈ølain and carried away Captive, ≈øucceeded him, and that the re≈øt might be mi≈øtaken in the Name.

This Mahomet, when his Father was taken Pri≈øoner, was but fifteen years of Age, having been by him appointed his Succe≈ø≈øor for the great Hope he ≈øaw in him, for the recovery of the broken and much ≈øhattered Kingdom.

When Mahomet entered upon Kingly Authority, the Tartars po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed a great part of the before Turki≈øh Dominion, but the Remains of the ≈øcattered Army and other Aids re≈øorting to his Standard after the departure of Tamerlain, he recovered many Cities, ≈øome by Force, and others by Revolt from the Tartars, and not long after in a great and bloody Battle overthrowing Inal Ogly Tamerlain's Lieutenant, he advanced more boldly and charged Co≈øtor Ogly, and Kinpeck Ogly, two more of Tamerlain's great Captains, whom he likewi≈øe overthrew; and following his good Fortune pa≈ø≈øed into the le≈ø≈øer A≈øia, of which Tamerlain having Notice ≈øent for him with a Promi≈øe, to give him one of his Daughters in Marriage, to whom he intended to go; but by the way being often forced to fight through the Ambu≈øhment
of the Tartars, he fearing it was a De≈øign to take him Pri≈øoner returned to his Government, excu≈øing him≈øelf to Tamerlain's Amba≈ø≈øador, and ≈øending one of his own Amba≈ø≈øadors to give the rea≈øon of his not coming; upon Notice of which, and that the Turks ≈øtill prevailed; Tamerlaine prepared for a ≈øecond Expedition, having recruited his huge Army for that purpo≈øe: But what Man willeth God di≈øpo≈øeth, whil≈øt he was intent upon the matter falling ≈øick of a Feaver, or Ague, after three ≈øits he dyed; Death Conquering him, who in a ≈øhort ≈øpace Conquered fifty intire Kingdoms.

This mighty Tartar being Dead, his great Kingdom divided among≈øt his Sons, by their jarring and di≈øcontent of the Nobility was ≈øoon after rent into pieces, mo≈øt of it falling into the hands of the Turks who at this day po≈ø≈øe≈øs it: And now Mahomet winning all the Dominions his Father held in the greater A≈øia, from the Tartars re≈øolved to recover the re≈øt, which his three Brothers, I≈øa, Solyman and Mn≈øa had ≈øeized on in Europe, and the le≈ø≈øer A≈øia; whereupon a≈ø≈øembling all his Forces, he marched to L ‚Ä¢ pacllum, near to which I≈øa being incamped, he ≈øent to offer him Caramania and ≈øeveral other Kingdoms in the le≈ø≈øer A≈øia; though indeed they were not his to give, being po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed by their rightful Princes, whom Tamerlain had re-po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed them off, which offer refu≈øed from a younger Brother, whereupon a bloody Battle in≈øued; in which I≈øa was overthrown, and for the pre≈øervation of his Life forced to fly to Emanuel the Greek Emperor: In this Battle were blain the two famous Ba≈øas, Eine and Tenurta≈øes, of which overthrow Mahomet ≈øent to certifie his Brother Sol ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ n then in Con≈øtantinople; after which he marched with his Army to Prr≈øa, and received under his Protection all the Countries adjoyning; and now growing ≈øtrong he ‚Ä¢ e≈øelved to brook no Rival in his Fathers Kingdoms, when on the other hand Solyman his
Elder Brother hearing what he had done, and knowing him to be of an a≈øpiring Temper, thought it not Convenient to ≈øuffer him longer ≈øo Triumphantly to proceed; whereupon by the advice of his Grave Coun≈øellors, he ≈øent for his Brother I≈øa then at Con≈øtantinople, and making him general of his Army, gave him Orders to pa≈øs over into A≈øia, and curb the Pride of his a≈øpiring Brother. I≈øa glad of this opportunity to revenge his own Injuries ≈øu≈øtained, in loo≈øing his Dominions, obeying his Brother Solyman's Commands, entered Mahomet's Dominions, and there with Fire and Sword began his Progre≈øs, which Mahomet under≈øtanding came again≈øt him, and having overthrown his Forces put him to a ≈øecond flight into Carramania; where, in ob≈øcurity, of the Wounds he received in Battle, and grief for his foul defeat he dyed.

Solyman hearing of the defeat prepared a great Army to invade A≈øia, which made Mahomet retire into the Country of Ama≈øa, as doubting the affections of his People, by rea≈øon the Kingdoms of Bajazet of Right appertained to Solyman as Flder: This retireing gave Solyman opportunity to advance to the Walls of Pru≈ø ‚Ä¢ s, which City he be≈øieged, and had it pre≈øently yielded, except the Ca≈øtle, which upon the Interceptions of Mahomet's Letters, was likewi≈øe ≈øurrendered, but upon the approach of Mahomet with a great Power, doubtful to keep what he had got, he with all his People retired to the Straights of Neapolis, where he defended him≈øelf right valiantly again≈øt the a≈ø≈øaults of his Brother, who by rea≈øon of the Intemperance of the Weather, and a Letter framed by Alis-Ba≈ø≈øa, that there was a Con≈øpiracy among≈øt his Captains to deliver him up to Solyman, he retired.

Whil≈øt the≈øe things were acting, Mu≈øa being ≈øet at Liberty by the Tartars, came to Mahomet's Camp & was of him joyfully received, when after ≈øome Di≈øcour≈øe it was
greed, that Mu≈øa with an Army ≈øhould pa≈øs over the Euxin Sea, into Europe; and whil≈øt Solyman was bu≈øie in A≈øia, ≈øeize upon his Country, which Expedition he undertaking, and making Isfender Prince of Ca≈øtomonia his Friend, and afterward the Prince of Valachia, by marrying his Daughter, he ≈øoon prevailed with the Governours of the chief Cities, to Revolt from Solyman; when entering Hadrianople he cau≈øed him≈øelf to be inve≈øted with Royal Robes, and as King of the Country ≈øent forth his Decrees, which Solyman hearing of as he lay at Ancira in A≈øia, pa≈ø≈øed the Straights of Bo≈øphorus with all the Forces he could rai≈øe, upon who≈øe Departure Mahomet recovered what ever he had won in A≈øia.

Solyman being come into Europe, Mu≈øa prepared to oppo≈øe him, and both Armies coming in ≈øight of each other, Mu≈øa ≈øo dealt with Solyman's Captains, that they revolted, which he perceiving fled, accompanied only with Caratze-Beg, Cara Muchil and one Country Turk, whom they took with them as their Guide: who≈øe per≈øidiou≈øne≈øs brought them to De≈øtruction, for pretending to lead them through the by-ways all Night, he mi≈ønaming places brought them in the Morning near to Mu≈øa's Camp; when giving Notice to the Ru≈øticks they ≈øet upon them, and having killed the two Captains, took Solyman and delivered him to Mu≈øa, who immediately cau≈øed him to be ≈øtrangled, who≈øe Body by his Command was carried to Pru≈øa, and there buryed by his Ance≈øtors.

Solyman being Dead, Mu≈øa took upon him the Goernment of the Turki≈øh Kingdom in Europe; as had been agreed between him and his Brother Mahomet, but e'r he was ≈øettled he began to Tyrannize beyond mea≈øure over his Subjects, which cau≈øed many of his great Captains to leave him, and among≈øt the re≈øt Eureno≈øie feigning him≈øelf Blind found means to depart to
Con≈øtantinople, from whence he wrote to Mahomet then in A≈øia; giving him an Account of his Brothers proceedings, and ≈øoliciting him to pa≈øs over with his Army, who≈øe Council Mahomet taking, making fir≈øt a League with Emanuel the Greek Emperor, he entered Europe with his Army: But by the over eager pur≈øuit of his Army, after the Vaunt Couriers of Mu≈øa's Army, his Orders being broken, he was put to flight, and forced to repa≈øs the Seas into A≈øia, leaving behind him a great part of his Army, who were ≈øpoiled by the Enemy.

Mahomet thus foiled, and de≈øirous of Revenge re≈øolved once more to try his Fortune, and thereupon drawing to his A≈ø≈øi≈øtance Dulgader Ogly, who ≈øent his Son with great Forces to ≈øerve him in his War, he repa≈ø≈øed the Euxin, and by the Council of Eureno≈øis, having procured the revolt of Jegides-Ba≈ø≈øa, Barack-Beg, and Sinon-Beg, 3 of Mu≈øa's great Captains who came over to him with 3000 valiant Turks he re≈øolved to give his Brother battle, the which being joyned, Mu≈øa by the revolt of other Commanders during the heat of fight was overthrown, taken, and by the Command of Mahomet ≈øtrangled, receiving therein the ≈øame mea≈øure he had dealt to his Brother Solyman.

After this overthrow of Mu≈øa, Mahomet proceeded to take po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of his Kingdom, the which whil≈øt he was doing, news came that the Carramanian King ≈øpoiled his Countries in A≈øia, and had burnt his great City of pru≈øa, which being a frontier City was ≈øtill expo≈øed to the mi≈øeries of War; whereupon Mahomet ≈øetling his Affairs in Europe as nece≈ø≈øity would permit, pa≈ø≈øed into A≈øia, and falling like a tempe≈øt upon the Country of Carramama took A≈øpropolis, De≈øpo ‚Ä¢ opolis, and Hierapolis, laying hard Siege to Iconium, which cau≈øed the Carramanian to ≈øend his Emb ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ dors to treat a Peace, the which by rea≈øon of the great ‚Ä¢ oods of Rain that fell, and the Sickne≈øs in the Army, occa≈øioned by the intemperance
of the Weather, was by Mahomet accorded, but it continued not long e're the Carramanian King in the ab≈øence of Mahomet a ≈øecond time invaded his Countries, with whom Mahomet fighting, routed his Army, taking him and his Son Pri≈øoners, for who≈øe Ran≈øoms he had delivered into his po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion the principal Cities of Carramania, and then returning into Europe ≈øeized upon Valachia obliging the Prince thereof to become his Va≈ø≈øal.

About this time two Per≈øons viz. Buriluzes and Bedredin, pretending them≈øelves to be great Prophets drew great multitudes after them who ≈øpoiled the Country, upon notice of which Mahomet ≈øent forces to apprehend them, who di≈øper≈øing their followers, hewed the former in pieces, and hanged the latter upon a Signpo≈øt, and now Mahomet falling ≈øick without any hopes of recovery, a≈ø≈øembled all his great Captains and charged them to obey his elde≈øt ≈øon Amurath, whom after his decea≈øe he appointed to ≈øucceed him in his Kingdom, and le≈øt in his ab≈øence he being then at his Government of Ama≈øs, any di≈øturbance ≈øhould happen, that they that were about him, if he ≈øhould chance to die ≈øhould conceal his Death: All which, he at that time dying, being accordingly ob≈øerved, for when the Janiziries and Pen≈øioners mi≈øtru≈øting him to be dead, and demanded to ≈øee him, the Ba≈ø≈øas attiring him in his Royal Robes, like as when he was alive brought him forth into a large Gallery, placing a Boy under his Gown, who as he was Commanded, lifted the Kings Arm and moved his head, with which tho≈øe that were below were well contented, and by this Stratagem kept his Death Secret 41 days, even till Amurath came and took the Scepter, the which had they not done the
„Äà‚óä„Äâ
and Pen≈øioners would have ≈øpoiled the rich Citie, wherein they were quartered, as ever ≈øince has been ob≈øerved during an Interregnum.

div.head: CHAP. XI. The Life of Amurath the Second of that name and Sixth King of the Turks, his Wars, Victories and Defeats.
div.p:
A Murath had no ≈øooner taken po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of his Kingdom, and the Death of Mahomet publi≈øhed, but divers Princes revolted from him, and invaded his Territories, as the Prince of Smyrna, Mente≈øia, and others, and among≈øt the re≈øt an ob≈øcure fellow of The≈ø≈øalonica, feigning him≈øelf to be Mu≈øtapha the Elde≈øt Son of Bajazet who was ≈ølain in the battle again≈øt Tamerlane, all the Turki≈øh Cities in Europe fell to him, whereupon Amurath ≈øent Bajazet Ba≈ø≈øa again≈øt him with a great Army, which was no ≈øooner landed but it revolted to Mu≈øtapha, leaving the Ba≈ø≈øa alone to ≈øhift for him≈øelf, whereupon the Ba≈ø≈øa together with his Brother Hamze ≈øubmitted them≈øelves to this counterfeit Son of Bajazet, but being envyed by the re≈øt of the Captains, they rai≈øed ≈øuch Jealou≈øies of his being treacherous in Mu≈øtapha, that he ≈øoon after put him to death, and afterward prepared for the Inva≈øion of Amurath's Territories in A≈øia, of which he having notice, gathered all his forces to oppo≈øe him, and after asking Council of a Mahometan Prie≈øt, who a≈ø≈øured him, he had after two repul≈øes at the hands of the Great Prophet, obtained the favor of making him pro≈øperous in his Wars, and ≈øo coming to the North-≈øide of the River ∆≤libad, he found the Bridge broken down, and Mu≈øtapha's great Army incamped on the other ≈øide, where he ≈øo dealt with the great
Captains of Mu≈øtapha's Army, that many of them revolted, and at length Mu≈øtapha being frighted by forged Letters, importing that his Army intended to deliver him up, fled by night, after which his men ≈øubmitted to Amurath, and he in his flight being taken in Europe was hanged.

The Rebellion being pacified, and Amurath informed that all this had happened, by the contrivance of the Greek Emperor, be≈øieged Con≈øtantinople, which in vain he often attempted to take by ≈øtorm, but whil≈øt he lay at this ≈øiege, news was brought that the King of Caramania had ≈øet up another Mu≈øtapha, viz. his younger Brother Son to Mahomet, to whom many Countries in the le≈ø≈øer A≈øia revolted, which made Amurath rai≈øe his Siege, and with all ha≈øt March to oppo≈øe him, and with large gifts to have the ≈øooner done he ≈øo corrupted Ilias Beg the young Princes Tutor, that he delivered him up together with the City of Nice, where he was by Amurath's command Strangled.

Amurath having appea≈øed the≈øe Rebellious Tumults, Le≈ø≈øened his Council from 5 to 2 Ba≈ø≈øas, viz. Ibrahim, and Eivazes, the latter of which being much envyed by tho≈øe that were outed, they ≈øuppo≈øing it was done by his per≈øwa≈øion, po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed Amurath that he had a de≈øign upon his Life, and after that to ≈øeize his Kingdom, and for that purpo≈øe went privately armed; to prove the truth of which Amurath one day cla≈øping him in his Arms, as in token of Friend≈øhip, found it ≈øo indeed, and therefore growing more ≈øu≈øpitious, notwith≈øtanding his many excu≈øes for his ≈øo doing, cau≈øed his Eyes to be put out, and ≈øoon after had news of the death of the King of Carramania his Mortal Enemy, who having lay'd Siege to the City of Attalia in Pamphilia, as he was viewing it to ≈øee where he might mo≈øt conveniently make an A≈ø≈øault, was ≈øhot
into the Bre≈øt, with an Arrow from a Lope-hole, at which Amurath greatly rejoyced, but his joy was ≈øoon allayed, by other news of a fierce Inva≈øion of his Territories made by Tzunites Prince of Smyrna, but it ≈øoon blew over, for the Prince being Vanqui≈øhed by the Vice-Roy of Anatolia, was together with his Son taken Pri≈øoner; and contrary to Faith plighted Slain; after this Amurath Marryed the Daughter of Prince I≈øflendiar, and then on a ≈øuddain in revenge of the pretended wrongs done him by the Greeks, be≈øieged and took The≈ø≈øalonica and di≈øpoiled it of all its Riches, leading away the Inhabitants into mi≈øerable Captivity.

At this time among≈øt other di≈øtre≈ø≈øed Princes, John Ca≈øtriot Prince of Epirus, perceiving the Turks ready to invade him, and being no ways Capable to with≈øtand ≈øo powerful an Army, re≈øolved to avoid the Mi≈øeries of War by a timely accord with the Turki≈øh Tyrant, promi≈øing to become his Tributary, and for confirmation thereof, as Ho≈øtages delivered his 4 Sons, viz. George, Stani≈øius, Repo≈øuis, and Con≈øtantine; Amurath promi≈øing well and honourably to intreat them, but as ≈øoon as they were within his power, he cau≈øed them to be Circumci≈øed, and brought up in the Super≈øtition of the Mahumetan Religion, and after the Death of their Father, ≈øeized upon his Kingdom, and Poy≈øoned all but George, whom he Named Scanderbeg; who afterwards became the Mawl and terror of the Turks, as will in the Sequel appear.

Amurath being bu≈øie in Europe, the Carramanian King and the other Mahumetan Princes invaded his Dominions in A≈øia, which cau≈øed him to pa≈øs over to repre≈øs that dangerous Enemy, which done he returned into Europe, and with Fire and Sword fell upon Hungary, and turning thence upon the Prince of Servia's refu≈øing to come to his Court ≈øeized Servia, tho he had Sworn to the contrary.

The Hungarians being at Variance among≈øt them≈øelves, and likewi≈øe at Wars with the King of Poland; upon the breaking off of the Match, between their Queen and the King of Poland, Amurath re≈øolved upon the Conque≈øt of that Kingdom, invaded Hungary, laying clo≈øe Siege to Belgrade, often in vain a≈ø≈øaulting it; and now the Queen of Hungary being Dead, leaving Ladi≈ølans a Child in the Cradle to ≈øucceed her, who not able to take any Mea≈øures about oppo≈øing the Turk, and the Kingdom in likely hood to be overrun; the Nobility concluded to Elect ∆≤ldi≈ølaus King of Poland, a man of great Fame and no le≈øs courage their King, which done Amba≈ø≈øadors were ≈øent to Amurath, ≈øtill lying at the Siege of Belgrade, but they were nothing more able to prevail as to his rai≈øing the Siege nor procuring a peace, till ≈øuch time as in divers a≈ø≈øaults half his Army were lo≈øt, overwhelmed with Wild-Fire, and ≈øtrangled in the mines, nor then tho he rai≈øed the Siege, would his haughty mind conde≈øcend to a Peace; in his return, hegreatly troubled the Countries of Servia and Bo≈øan, cau≈øing the Princes in lien of ≈øaving them from the Spoil, to pay a yearly tribute of 25000 Ducats. ∆≤ldi≈ølaus being ≈øetled in his new Kingdom, and having frequently intelligence of the incur≈øions of the Turks into Tran≈øylvania; the better to re≈øi≈øt them on that ≈øide Created John Hunides Vayvod or his Vicegerent in that Country, who putting all things in order, gathered ≈øuch an Army as he might, and upon news that I≈øa the great Ba≈ø≈øa, and one of Amuraths mo≈øt Renowned Captains, was returned with a great power and ≈øpoiled the Country; he went again≈øt him incouraging his Soldiers to Fight Couragiou≈øly for their Lives, Country, Wives and Children; and then ≈øetting upon the proud Ba≈ø≈øa after a hard foughten Battle, put him to Flight with the lo≈øs of 20000 of his men.

This Victory nothing daunted Amurath, but pu≈øhed him forward more eagerly to revenge the di≈øgrace; whereupon early in the Spring he ≈øent Melites Ba≈ø≈øa his Viceroy in A≈øia, with a great Army, who ≈øpoiling the Country, took a great Booty and many Pri≈øoners, but in his return being pur≈øued by Huniades, he overthrew him, & Slew the Ba≈ø≈øa & his Son. By that means recovering all the Pri≈øoners and Riches, together with the Turki≈øh Camp, and many Turki≈øh Pri≈øoners of note, which cau≈øed the Hungarians and Tran≈øilvanians greatly to rejoyce; part of the Spoiles with the Head of the Ba≈ø≈øa and his Son, he ≈øent to King ∆≤ldi≈ølaus, the other part he converted to religious u≈øes, and what remained freely be≈øtowed it among≈øt his Soldiers, not re≈øerving any part to him≈øelf.

Upon Bruit of this Victory, and the Fame of the Valiant Huniades, Moldavia and Valachia, before Tributary to the Turks, revolted, which ≈øo inraged Amurath that he ≈øent yet another great Army to reduce them to their former obedience, which with great pride (under the leading of Schech Abedin, Ba≈ø≈øa, con≈øi≈øting of 80000 Fighting men, among≈øt which were a great number of Janizaries) came on wa≈øting the Country with Fire and Sword as they pa≈ø≈øed, to oppo≈øe which the great Huniades marched with 15000 Hungarians and Tran≈øilvanians, and finding them ≈øtill Plundering near Va≈øcape bid them Battle, where after both Armies were put in order, and both Generals by moving-Oration had incited their Souldiers to Fight to the utmo≈øt Extremity, a dreadful Fight began, where after ≈øix Hours dealing Death on every ≈øide, the Turki≈øh Army broken and di≈øordered by the Chri≈øtians were put to Flight, with the lo≈øs of 30000 Hor≈øe and Foot: And their rich Camp which became an acceptable Prey to the Souldiers.
The many Victories gained by Humiades over the Turks, made Amurath more inclinable to peace then before; yet in his pride he demanded in con≈øideration thereof, the delivery of Bellgrade and many other places in Servia; upon which King Vldi≈ølaus called an A≈ø≈øembly of the E≈øtates of his Kingdom, where after many had given their opinions, it was re≈øolved that the Pious War ≈øhould be carryed on with all Vigor Imgainable, and that the Chri≈øtians following their good Fortune ≈øhould invade the Turki≈øh Countries, whereupon a great Army was rai≈øed, and pa≈ø≈øing the Danubius lead by the King and Humiades, they wa≈øted all the Kingdom of Bulgaria, and having intelligence that the Turks were with a great Army coming down again≈øt them; Humiades drawing out 10000 of the mo≈øt expert Hor≈øemen, having notice where they lay incamped in the Night: Broke in among≈øt them, and put 'um almo≈øt all the Sword; returning the next Day with great Spoil, where the King lay incamped, where he was received with great Joy.

This ea≈øie Victory wherein there fell 30000 Turks, and not pa≈øt 300 of the Chri≈øtians, ≈øo lightned the Souldiers, that they de≈øired nothing more then to be lead forward, but coming to the great Mountain Hemus, and finding all the pa≈ø≈øages ≈øtopped, and being greatly afflicted with Hungar and Cold; their Courages began to abate, and they to conceive a de≈øire of returning home: the which whil≈øt they were about to do, the Turks under the leading of Caramby Ba≈ø≈øa, Amuraths Brother in Law came down from the Mountains, and fell furiou≈øly upon the Rear of the Army commanded by Humiades, and the De≈øpot of Servia, the King with the Van being a Days march before; but after a ≈øharp Incounter were overthrown, and the Great Ba≈ø≈øaw taken by a common Souldier, who
being demanded of Humiades what he would have for his Pri≈øoner, he asked only 10 Ducats; yet Humiades ordered him 400, and the ≈øame Night ≈øold him again to the De≈øpot for 40000 Ducats.

In this Battle, but, as ≈øome ≈øay, in that Fought near Moravia, the famous Scanderbeg found means to fly the Turki≈øh Servitude, and leading Amurath's Secretary with him, commanded him in the Name of Amurath to Write to the Governour of Croia, to deliver him the City, that being the Metropolis of Epirus, the which when he had done, he ≈ølew him and as many Turks as were with him to prevent its coming to the knowledge of Amurath, before he had accompli≈øhed his de≈øign. And thereupon with ≈øeveral of his tru≈øty Friends Po≈øting away, had the City as he wi≈øhed for put into his po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion, whither he ≈øent for Prince Amaza his Kin≈øman, and many other of his acquaintance informing them what he intended, viz. that he re≈øolved to recover his Rightful inheritance, and deliver his Subjects from the Tyranny of the Turks, which made them not a little rejoyce, and greatly incourage him to proceed in ≈øo honourable an undertaking.

Things being at this pa≈øs, and the de≈øign known; great was the re≈øort of the Epirots to their Lawful Prince, who for the delivery of his Country from Servitude had ≈øet up his Standard: Such Cities as conveniently could daily revolting to him, as Petrella, Petra, Alba and Stelu≈øa; other he reduced by force, and having po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of the greate≈øt part of Epirus, he rai≈øed what forces he could, and the more to provoke the Turk, pa≈ø≈øed into Macedonia, ≈øpoiling the Country before him, and putting the Turks to the Sword.

Amurath hearing this unexpected news, ≈øent 40000 ≈øelect Souldiers under the leading of Alis Ba≈ø≈øa, of
who≈øe coming Scanderbeg having notice retired into Epirus, and putting all things in order, rai≈øed what forces he could to oppo≈øe the Turks, comforting his People in the be≈øt wi≈øe; who upon the Ba≈ø≈øa's approach were filled with fear, and then marching again≈øt him, ≈øet upon him as he was wa≈øting his Country of ∆≤pper Dibra, and overthrew him with the Slaughter of 22000 of his men, with the lo≈øs of Scarce 300 of his own, the news of which rai≈øed ≈øuch di≈øpair in Amurath, that he was glad to accord a peace with the Hungarian King, by renouncing his claim to Moldavia, Tran≈øilvania and Bulgaria; and then turning his Arms again≈øt the Carramanian King, his Brother-in Law ≈øeized upon the greate≈øt part of his Country, but upon his Submi≈ø≈øion and giving in Ho≈øtage his Elde≈øt Son, for the performance of paying double tribute he re≈øtored him again to his former dignity, and then as a man weary of the World, ≈øent for his Younge≈øt Son Mahomet, his Elde≈øt Son Aladine being killed at the Siege of Iconium, by a fall from his Hor≈øe, and appointing Caly Ba≈ø≈øa his Tutor, and Cho≈øore a learned Doctor of the Law his Coun≈øellors, he re≈øigned to him the Kingdom being as yet but 15 Years of Age, and retiring into A≈øia entered into a Cloi≈øter of Turki≈øh Monks, there intending to ≈øpend the remainder of his Days. But he had no ≈øooner re≈øigned his Government, 'ere ∆≤ldi≈ølaus King of Hungary per≈øwaded thereto by Julian the Popes Legate who ab≈øolved him of his Oath broke the 10 Years League made with the Turks. But God let not ≈øo heinous an Offence again≈øt his divine Maje≈øty pa≈øs long unrevenged. For Amurath rou≈øed with this unexpected news, leaving his Cloi≈øter, pa≈ø≈øed over into Europe with an Army of 100000 Turks, and advancing with all ≈øpeed again≈øt the Chri≈øtians, who had ‚Ä¢ u ‚Ä¢ dued mo≈øt of his Countries in Europe near the
City of Varna, both Armies meeting a cruel Fight began with an infinite Slaughter of the Turks, whom Huniades and the King charged with ≈øuch fury, that all the Fields lay covered with the Slain, which Amurath perceiving and finding his Battle to Swerve, and his men at the point to Fly; pull'd the Writing containing the League he had made with ∆≤ldi≈ølaus out of his Bo≈øom, and holding it up, with his Eyes lifted towards Heaven with a loud Voice ≈øaid, Behold thou Crucified Chri≈øt, this is the League they Chri≈øtians in thy name made with me, which they have without any cau≈øe Violated, now if thou be a God as they ≈øay thou art, and we deem, revenge the wrong now done unto they name, and ≈øhew thy power upon thy perjured People, who in their deeds deny thee their God.

Upon this Speech of Amurath's, the Chri≈øtians who before were well nigh Conquerers began to give Ground, which the Hungarian King perceiving charging into the Thicke≈øt of the Turki≈øh Army, in hopes to re≈øtore the Battle was there Slain, which ≈øo di≈øcouraged the Hungarians, that Huniades not being able to ≈øtay their Flight giving place to nece≈ø≈øity, and re≈øerving him≈øelf for better fortune fled with them, and left the Turks the Victory, but ≈øo dearly bought, that only thinking the Chri≈øtians had retired to their Camp, they dur≈øt not venture upon it for two Days ≈øpace, till by the profound ≈øilence they perceived it was abandoned. In this Fight, mo≈øt of the Hungarian Nobility were ≈ølain, and among≈øt the re≈øt Julian the Popes Legate, the Author of the perjurous Expedition, who being wounded and ≈ølying out of the Battle fainted for lo≈øs of Blood, & dyed in a Ditch. And thus we may ≈øee how ju≈øt the Almighty is in puni≈øhing tho≈øe that di≈øhonour him, and little Availes the Popes di≈øpen≈øation.

This great and mortal Battle in which peri≈øhed on both ≈øides 60000 men, was Fought Anno 1444, after which Amurath glad of the Victory, tho much di≈ømayed with his great lo≈øs returned to Adrianople, and again re≈øigned his Kingdom to his Son; but ≈øoon after being weary of the Melancholy Life, he again a≈ø≈øumed his kingly Dignity.

At this great Battle of Varna, Scanderbeg ≈øhould have been pre≈øent; being on his way with 30000 Hor≈øe and Foot in order to have joyned King ∆≤ladi≈ølaus. But God prevented his ingaging in ≈øo bad a Quarrel, by permitting both Armies to ingage 'ere he could arrive, of which intention of Scanderbeg's Amurath having notice ≈øent ≈øharply to reprove him of Ingratitude, to which the Valiant Prince as ≈øharply reply'd, upbraiding the Turk with the Poy≈øoning his; Brothers, ≈øeizing upon his Kingdom, and often determining to take his Life whil≈øt he remain'd in his Court, which ≈øo throughly netled the old Turk, that he rai≈øed great forces to invade Epirus, ≈øending of Feri≈øes and Mu≈øtapha his chief Ba≈ø≈øas, with promi≈øe of great reward if they could take Scanderbeg, and ≈øubdue the Country: but on the contrary they were both overthrown by the Invincible Prince, and forced to return with great di≈øhonour, yet the Prince of Peloponne≈øus had not the like good Fortune, but for the pre≈øervation of his Country was obliged to become tributary to the Turk.

∆≤ladi≈ølaus being Slain, as afore≈øaid, Humiades was made Governour by the general cou≈øent of the Hungarian Nobility; during the Minority of the Young King, Son to the decea≈øed Queen, who having ≈øetled the nece≈ø≈øary Affairs of the Kingdom with great di≈øcretion, and finding the Turks ≈øince the late dreaful overthrow at Varna, greatly to have incroached upon the Hungarian Territories, he rai≈øed a great power
and marched again≈øt them, when in the Territories of his Country near the River Schichniza, meeting Amurath with a va≈øt Army, he couragiou≈øly charged upon his formo≈øt Battle, ≈øo that within a while, new Succors being ≈øent the whole Armies were ingaged, which Battle without any other pau≈øing then what Night obliged them to, Fought for the ≈øpace of 3 Days, at the end of which the Chri≈øtians being rather overpowred by number then true valour, having done all that men were capable of doing, Fled di≈øorderly, and were Slain in great abundance: Humiades him≈øelf Flying after, having Incountered and overcome two ≈øturdy Thieves who ≈øet upon him to Rob him, was taken Pri≈øoner by the ungrateful De≈øpot of Servia, who≈øe Country he had a little before re≈øcued out of the Hands of the Turks: And forced to deliver up ≈øeveral ≈øtrong Towns, which the De≈øpot pretended belonged to his Territories for his Ran≈øom. In this Battle were Slain of the Turks 40000, and of the Chri≈øtians 17000.

The Year following Amurath invaded the De≈øpot's, for not delivering into his power Humiades his Capital Enemy; whereupon he was con≈øtrained to ≈øend his humble Supplication to Humiades, whom he not long before had ≈øo evil intreated, for aid; who notwith≈øtanding leavyed a great Army, and pa≈ø≈øing through Servia, where tho fal≈øe De≈øpot to curry Favour with Amurath, taking an account of his Army, ≈øecretly ≈øent the Turk notice what number the Chri≈øtians were, and what they intended; yet this great Captain marched on to the Plains of Ca≈ø≈øova, famous for the many Battles there Fought between the Turks and the Chri≈øtians, where finding Amurath incamped with a huge Army he bid him Battel, which as the former with great Slaughter continued for the ≈øpace of 3 Days, but with better Succe≈øs, for in the end Victory
declared for the Chri≈øtians, all the Plains being covered with the Body of the Slain, mo≈øt of the Turki≈øh Commanders, either Peri≈øhed in the Fight, or fell into the Hands of Huniades, who having recovered many Towns, delivered the Pri≈øoners to the De≈øpot, and returned with Triumph to Buda.

And now a quarrel ari≈øing between Scanderbeg, and the Duke of Venice, about one Lech Zachery, a Nobleman of Epirus; who being ≈øhamefully Murthered by Lech Duchagne his Kin≈øman, and having great Territories on the Frontiers of the Kingdom; the Duke claimed it as belonging to his Signory, ≈øeizing upon the City of Dayna part thereof, of which trouble Mustapha the Great Ba≈ø≈øa, who lay in Macedonia with a great Army, being adverti≈øed by the command of Amurath entered Epirus, of which Scanderbeg having notice gathered all his forces, and finding him Burning the Country in the upper Dibria, where both Armies confronting each other, a Turk named Caragu≈øa ≈øtepping forth, Challenged any in the Chri≈øtian Camp to Fight him Hand to Hand; which bold Challenge being accepted by Mane≈ø≈øi one of Scanderbeg's Captains, he at the fir≈øt Incounter ≈ølew the Challenger, which did not a little di≈ømay the Turks, who highly relyed upon the Strength of their Champion; for the Battle immediately joyning, the Turks were overthrown with great Slaughter, and the Ba≈ø≈øa taken Pri≈øoner, who was afterwards Ran≈øomed by Amurath for 25000 Ducats.

This overthrow ≈øo inraged the Tyrant, that rai≈øing a mighty Power, he came in Per≈øon to invade Epirus; promi≈øing great rewards to tho≈øe that could bring Scanderbeg's Head; of which more then ordinary preparations Scanderbeg having timely notice, furni≈øhed his Cities with all things nece≈ø≈øary, providing them with ≈øtrong Garri≈øons, him≈øelf re≈øolving to keep the
Field with his Army, and by Ambu≈øhes and frequent A≈ø≈øaults, to weaken and cut off the Enemy, which upon the arrival of the Turki≈øh Army he ≈øo effectually performed, that ≈øeldom a Day or Night pa≈øt that he intrapped not ≈øome or other of the Vauntcuriers, or broke into their Camp; in≈øomuch that they were obliged to be continually in Arms; whereupon Amurath de≈øigning to win ≈øome ≈øtrong City, there to leave a Garri≈øon, and ≈øo to depart, be≈øieged Sfetigrade with all his power, continually thundering again≈øt it with his great Ordnance. But one Prelat a Valiant Captain being Governour, right Manfully defended it, in≈øomuch that in the frequent A≈ø≈øaults made he lo≈øt 20000 of his be≈øt men, yet being a≈øhamed to rai≈øe his Siege 'ere he had won the City, ≈øent to offer terms of Peace with great Priviledges and immunities, if they ≈øurrender'd the place, as likewi≈øe by ≈øecret means indeavoured to corrupt the Captains with great promi≈øes; but they dete≈øting his offer regarded more their Loyalty to their Prince then his Gold, yet at the ≈øame time there wanted not one ba≈øe minded Vallain, who for a Sum in Hand and other large offers, when he had performed his promi≈øe, undertook to deliver the City into the Hands of Amurath; which by this means he effected.

This great City ≈øtanding upon a Rock, had in it but one Well, which ≈øerved both the Soldiers and Citizens plentifully with Water, into this Well did the Villain by occupation a Smith ca≈øt the Carkas of a ≈øtinking Dog, which the next Morning found by ≈øome of the Soldiers, and drawn thence the rumour thereof was quickly ≈øpread throughout, whereupon the Soldiers notwith≈øtanding all the intreaties of the Governour and chief Citizens, the Soldiers would not be per≈øwaded to Drink thereof, re≈øolving rather to indure the wor≈øt Extremity; and by this means the
City not being tenable, the Governor to prevent a mutiny among≈øt his Soldiers, and the danger the City was in to be ≈øacked, ≈øent to Amurath to acquaint him, that upon condition the Garri≈øon might pa≈øs with Bag and Baggage to Scanderbeg, and the Citizens live peaceably, he would deliver him the City; who being glad of this offer freely granted their demand, only with this condition, that the Citizens ≈øhould build their Hou≈øes without the City.

The≈øe Articles agreed on, the City was delivered to Amurath, and the Traytor by who≈øe means it was ≈øurrendered, was rewarded with three rich Suits of Apparel, 50000 A≈øpers, and the promi≈øe of a yearly Pen≈øion of 2000 Ducats; but long he had not enjoyed his riches 'ere he received a ju≈øter reward of his Trea≈øon; being, as 'tis ≈øaid, ≈øecretly made away by the command of Amurath, who tho he loved the Trea≈øon, abhorred the Traytor.

The City being thus gained, Amurath having furni≈øhed it with a Garri≈øon of his be≈øt men, departed with the re≈øt of his Army to Hadrianople, upon the Rear of which Scanderbeg ≈øetting with 8000 Hor≈øe and 3000 Foot, cut off a great part of his Army. And having followed quite out of his Territories, returned to Croia, and fortified it, upon notice that Amurath intended to return with his Army in the Spring, in which he was not deceived; for the old Turk de≈øirous to ≈øubdue the Country of Epirus, to obliterate the di≈øgrace he had received by the many overthrows he had there received, he ≈øent Sebahyas one of his Ba≈ø≈øas before with part of his Army; him≈øelf following ≈ølowly with the re≈øt, and upon his arrival ≈øat down before the great City of Croia, where having ca≈øt 10 Pieces of Cannon, he began to batter it, the which with great fury he continued to do for the ≈øpace of 4 Days in two places, beating down part
