of the Wall, upon which he commanded the A≈ø≈øault to be given, thru≈øting his men de≈øperately into the Breach, giving order that ≈øuch as Shrunk ≈øhould be killed by their Fellows, and on the other ≈øide promi≈øing them great reward, if they entered the City, and Mahomet his Son being then in the Camp, and commanding as General promi≈øed 100000 A≈øpers to him that ≈øhould fir≈øt advance his En≈øign upon the Wall; but neither prevailed, for ∆≤ranacontes the Governour, a Valiant man incouraging his Soldiers, gave the Turks ≈øuch a Welcome, that they left 8000 of their dead Bodies in the Breach, Ditches and Plains adjacent; which Amurath perceiving and under≈øtanding the invincible courage of the Epirots, cau≈øed the retreat to be ≈øounded, and after many repul≈øes and no hopes of prevailing, he fell to his old practice, endeavouring to corrupt the Governour, and chief Captains with large Gifts, and to that end ≈øent a Crafty Ba≈ø≈øa, with two Servants Loaded with Trea≈øure; which the Governour with di≈ødain rejected, Vowing that if the like were attempted again, that he would cau≈øe the Hands, No≈øes and Ears of the Me≈ø≈øengers to be cut off, and they ≈øo returned to their Ma≈øter.

During this Siege, Scanderbeg was not Idle but ≈øtill hovered about the Turks Camp, frequently Alaruming 'um, and breaking into one Quarter, or other, killing tho≈øe that Guarded it, and taking great Booties, in≈øomuch that after ≈øeveral Months Siege, and the lo≈øs of 30000 men, Amurath through Grief and de≈øpair Dyed in his Tent Anno 1450, in the 85 Year of his Age, and of his Reign the 28, or as ≈øome ≈øay, the thirtieth, leaving Mahomet his Son to ≈øucceed him in his trouble≈øome Kingdom, charging him to revenge his Death upon Scanderbeg, and ≈øo having his Corps conveyed to Pru≈øa, he was there interred by his Ance≈øtors.

div.head: CHAP. XII. The Life of Mahomet the ≈øecond of that Name, ≈øeventh King, and the fir≈øt that took upon him the Style of Emperor of the Turks, who for his many Victories, was ≈øurnamed Great.
div.p: A Murath being dead Mahomet the ≈øecond began his Reign over the Turki≈øh Kingdom, Anno 1450. Being of a firey Cruel Nature, given to many Debauches, not acknowledging any Deity, but a≈øcribing all things to Fortune and Chance; who, e'r he was well ≈øettled, cau≈øed his two Brethren, the one an Infant, and the other not above twelve years of Age, to be put to Death; after which he fell to altering the Con≈øtitution of the Government, by abrogating the Old Laws, and E≈øtabli≈øhing new ones more ≈øuitable to his Humour: So that he began to be exceedingly hated by his Subjects, when to prevent any di≈øorder that might happen by the Soldiers lying Idle, he hearing that Ibrahim King of Carramania was entered his Territories in the le≈ø≈øer A≈øia, pa≈ø≈øed thither, upon who≈øe Arrival the King unable to oppo≈øe him, fled into the Mountains, and from thence ≈øent his Amba≈ø≈øadors to treat with him, who offered ≈øuch Submi≈ø≈øion in the behalf of their Ma≈øters, as Mahomet was well Content to accept, and ≈øo returned to his City of Pru≈øa, ≈øending I≈øaac Ba≈ø≈øa, again≈øt Elias Prince of Mente≈øia, or Caria, who altogether deprived the ≈øaid Prince of his Country, annexing it to the Turki≈øh Empire, for ≈øo henceforth I mu≈øt call it.

Mahomet being proud of his Petty Conque≈øts, without any Colour or Rea≈øon, only being driven Headlong
by Ambition; he re≈øolved to make War upon the Greek Emperor, and to have the ≈øooner done, marched to the Walls of Constantinople with a great Power, laying Siege to that Imperial City, which had once been Mi≈øtre≈øs of the World, which he reduced to ≈øuch Extremity, that the Citizens for meer Hunger left no filthy thing uneaten, and at la≈øt Eat one another; and perceiving none intended to relieve them, they inforced by invincible nece≈ø≈øity yielded the faire≈øt City of the World, to the Will of the Tyrant, having made all the defence that from true Valour could be expected.

The proud Conqueror entering the City, amid≈øt his Cups cau≈øed all the Grecian Nobility, the chief Citizens and Nobles of other Nations to be ≈ølain in his Pre≈øence. Constantinus Paleologus the Emperor being before ≈ølain and Trampled underfoot in the Pre≈øs, as he was indeavouring to e≈øcape the Imperial City; this taken after a years Siege, Pera a City of the Greeks oppo≈øite to it ≈øurrendred, yet were the Citizens u≈øed with all manner of De≈øpite: And now removing the Imperial Seat from Hadrianople to Constantinople, where it has ever ≈øince remain'd, he repaired the Walls, and ≈øuch Buildings, as had been demoli≈øhed by the Fury of the Cannon.

Among≈øt the Captives taken in the City, one of his Commanders pre≈øented unto him one of the mo≈øt beautiful Ladies that Nature ever formed, named Irene, being nobly de≈øcended; and for Education not to be paralell'd, upon this incomparable Beauty, Mahomet ≈øo doted, that he ≈øpent whole Days and Nights with her, never thinking his time well ≈øpent but in her Company: So that his warlike Affairs were altogether neglected, which cau≈øed his Captains to murmur again≈øt him, though they dur≈øt not freely ≈øpeak their Minds, which Mu≈øtapha Ba≈ø≈øa, one that had been bred up
with him, ob≈øerving, pre≈øuming upon the Intere≈øt he had in him, took upon him boldly to declare his Mind, laying before him the glorious Atchievments of his Ance≈øtors, and the di≈øgrace and obloquie he incurred by devoting him≈øelf to amorous Delights, whil≈øt the Affairs of his Empire were neglected.

At this free Speech of the Ba≈ø≈øas, Mahomet was wonderfully offended, telling him he was worthy of Death for his un≈øea≈øonable Pre≈øumption; but notwith≈øtanding he would pardon him for the good Opinion he had of his Fidelity, Commanding him the next Morning to a≈ø≈øemble all his Captains, and chief Councellors the next Morning to attend his Plea≈øure in his Pallace; which being accordingly done, he came out of his Chamber, leading the fair Greek in mo≈øt ≈øplendid Attire, which adding Lu≈øter to her rare Perfections, made her appear more like an Angel then a Mortal; and ≈øternly demanding of them, Whether if any of them had ≈øuch an ine≈øtimable Trea≈øure, they would not be thrice advi≈øed e'r they parted with it: To which they all an≈øwered, that he had with greater rea≈øon pa≈ø≈øed his time with her, then any man had to find ≈øault therewith. To which the barbarous Tyrant replyed, well, but now I Will make you to under≈øtand how far you have been deceived in me, and that there is no earthly thing that can ≈øo much blind my Sen≈øes, or bereave me of my Rea≈øon, as not to ≈øee or under≈øtand what be≈øeemeth my high Calling; yea, I would you ≈øhould all know that the Honour and Conque≈øt of the Othoman Kings, my noble Progenitors, is ≈øo fixed in my brea≈øt, with ≈øuch a De≈øire in my ≈øelf to exceed the ≈øame, as nothing but Death is able to put out of my Remembrance; and having ≈øo ≈øaid, he pre≈øently with one of his Hands catching the fair Greek by the Hair, and with the other drawing his Scimiter ≈ømote off her Head, ≈øhe vainly Crying out for Mercy, and
then taking the bloody Head in his Hand turning to his Captains; ≈øaid, now by this Judge ye, whether your Emperor is able to Bridle his Affections, or not; and immediately to put this cruel Act out of his Mind, gave order for his Army to march to the Inva≈øion of Peloponne≈øus, which he ≈øoon brought into Subjection, taking mo≈øt of the principal Cities, and putting the Inhabitants to the Sword; but upon the Submi≈ø≈øion of Demetrius the Prince thereof, he re≈øtored him upon Condition of his becoming Tributary to the Turki≈øh Empire; and afterwards being inamoured of his fair Daughter took her to Wife, and ≈øoon after hearing of the Death of George De≈øpot of Servia, he ≈øeized upon his Country; and ≈øo pa≈ø≈øing on with his Army be≈øieged Belgrade, both by Land and Water, as having a great Fleet upon the River Danubius, on who≈øe Bank that City is ≈øeated; which Fleet being incountered by ≈øeveral Ships of War, ≈øent by Humaides for that purpo≈øe were ≈øoon de≈øtroyed; which ≈øo inraged the Turk, that immediately giving order for the a≈ø≈øaulting the City, his men were beaten off with the lo≈øs of 4000 men, and among≈øt the re≈øt Curaizis Ba≈ø≈øa his Lieutenant in Europe, who making his approach was ≈ølain with a great Shot; and ≈øo well did the Valiant Humiades defend that City, that after many un≈øucce≈øsful a≈ø≈øaults, Mahomet was forced to rai≈øe his Siege, and departed with 40000 le≈øs then he brought.

The great Humiades having thus long ≈øtood a Bulwark to Chri≈øtendom, now worn out with the toyls of War fell ≈øick; and although his Di≈øea≈øe was grievous, yet de≈øirous to receive the ble≈ø≈øed Sacrament, he would be carried to the Church, ≈øaying it was not fit, that the Lord ≈øhould come to the Hou≈øe of his Servant: But that rather the Servant ≈øhould go to the Hou≈øe of his Lord, and after his being brought home, his Sickne≈øs Increa≈øing, he gave up the Gho≈øt to the Grief of
all the Chri≈øtian Princes, and was buried in the Church of St. Stephen in Alba Julia.

Mahomet hearing of the Death of this great Captain, who oppo≈øed the Torrent of his Victories greatly rejoyced, and now re≈øolving to extend his Dominions, as well by Sea as Land, Equipped a great many in the Port of Constantinople, with which he invaded the I≈ølands in the Egean Sea, reducing ≈øeveral of them to his obedience, and Landing his Army, ≈øtraightly be≈øieged the famous City of Rhodes; but Calixtus the third then Bi≈øhop of Rome, being greatly di≈øplea≈øed for the lo≈øs of Pera, a City belonging to his See, aided by the Genoways, ≈øent out a great Fleet under the Conduct of Lodonicius, Patriarch of Aquilla, fought with the Turks Gally, ≈øunk and burnt mo≈øt of them. And by that means recovered the I≈ølands they had taken, which ≈øo inraged Mahomet, that he prepared an other Fleet again≈øt the Spring; the which whil≈øt he was doing, Amba≈ø≈øadors came from ∆≤≈øun Ca≈ø≈øanus King of Per≈øia with many rich Pre≈øents, de≈øiring that he would enter into League with the mighty Prince his Ma≈øter, and remit the Tribute payed him by the King of Trepezond; that Kingdom as he ≈øaid, after the Death of the then Reigning King, revolving to his Ma≈øter, in right of his Wife, Daughter to the ≈øaid King; which Peremptory demand ≈øo inraged Mahomet, that he not only refu≈øed his Pre≈øents, but di≈ømi≈ø≈øed his Amba≈ø≈øador with this An≈øwer: That he would him≈øelf e'r long be in A≈øia, to teach ∆≤≈øun Ca≈ø≈øanes what to reque≈øt of one greater then him≈øelf, and thereupon Commanded the Fleet he had prepared for the Inva≈øion of the I≈øles in the Egeum, incontinently to ≈øail to Sinope, the chief City of Paphlagonia, and to expect his coming thither with his Army by Land; which City and Country being under the Per≈øian King, he re≈øolved to be≈øiege it on no other Account, then to rai≈øe a
ground of Quarrel; which City being but ≈ølenderly fortified, and not able to indure the Force of the Ordnance, it was delivered by I≈ømaele the Prince of Paphlagonia into his Hands, who putting a Garri≈øon therein proceeded to the Siege of Trepezond, which he had in like manner yielded to him, who ≈øent the Emperor, together with his Empre≈øs Sons and Daughters Pri≈øoners to Con≈øtantinople, di≈øpeopling the City, and thru≈øting thereinto a Garri≈øon of his Janizaries, by that means bringing the whole Country into Subjection, and for ever ruining that Chri≈øtian Empire: And now hearing that Waldus Dracula Prince of Valachia, his Tributary, went about to joyn with the Hungarians his mortal Enemies, he ≈øought by all means to get him into his Power, to effect which he ≈øent Chamuzes Ba≈ø≈øa, and his Secretary accompanied with ≈øeveral others, to invite him to Court, but the Prince under≈øtanding the De≈øign upon his Life, hanged the Ba≈ø≈øa and Secretary, and impailed the re≈øt alive, and then invaded his Country with Fire and Sword, which ≈øo inraged Mahomet, that he in Per≈øon with a great Army invaded Valachia, ruining all with Fire and Sword, till at length driving the Prince out of his Country, he gave it to his younger Brother, who in lieu thereof became his Tributary, and upon his return invaded the I≈ølands in the Egeum, as he had before purpo≈øed, and Landing on the I≈øle of Mittylene took the ≈øtrong City, from whence the I≈øland take its name, after twenty ≈øeven years Battery with the great Ordnance, and then for non-payment of Tribute, invaded the Kingdom of Ba≈ø≈øan; which ≈øubdued he by that means incompa≈ø≈øed Epirus, he having all this while according to his Directions of the Father, by one or other of his Ba≈ø≈øas, maintained War again≈øt Scanderbeg, but with ≈øuch bad ≈øucce≈øs, that he thought more then Convenient to make Peace with him; but ≈øuch were his Propo≈øals, that Scanderbeg with ≈øcorn rejected 'um, whereupon Mahomet ≈øent Ama≈øa
Ba≈ø≈øa with 12000 Hor≈øemen, to wa≈øt Epirus; but Scanderbeg incountering with 6000 put his Army to flight, and took him Pri≈øoner, and wor≈øe faired Debreus Ba≈ø≈øa, who ≈øoon after was ≈øent with 14000 Hor≈øemen, for ingageing with Scanderbeg's Forces, his Army was overthrown, and him≈øelf ≈ølain.

Mahomet grieved his Affairs pro≈øpered no better, and finding that by force he could not prevail again≈øt Scanderbeg, he dealt underhand by giving great Rewards to his Captains, thinking if he could cau≈øe them to revolt, Scanderbeg would ea≈øily be ≈øubdued, and ≈øo effectually he wroght with Mo≈øes his chief Captain, and a great Soldier, that in hopes of the Kingdom of Epirus promi≈øed by Mahomet; when Scanderbeg ≈øhould be ≈øubdued, and a great ma≈øs of Money, he found means to e≈øcape to Con≈øtantinople, and after him Ama≈øa another of Scanderbeg's Captains, who were ≈øent by Mahomet with great Power to invade Epirus; but being overthrown by the invin≈øible Prince, they received ≈øuch cold Comfort at their return, that fearing their Lives, which indeed the Turk had a de≈øign to bereive them off, Mo≈øes fled and humbling him≈øelf at the Feet of his Compa≈ø≈øionate Prince, he notwith≈øtanding his Treachery received him again into his Service, who afterward ≈øerved him faithfully in his Wars, but Amaze being overthrown in his expedition with I≈øaac Ba≈ø≈øa, with the lo≈øs of 20000 Turks upon his return, was by the Command of Mahomet as mo≈øt Conjectured poi≈øoned, after which Scanderbeg concluded a Peace with the Turks for a year, and was afterwad continued for a longer time, during which great War happened between the Turks, about the ≈øeizing the I≈ølands in the Egeum, and thereby hindering the Traffick in the Mediteranian, to the great impoveri≈øhing their Signiory. Wherefore entering into a Confideracy with the Princes, they Arme both by Sea and Land; into which
League they with many per≈øwa≈øions drew Scanderbeg, notwith≈øtanding his League made with Mahomet was not expired.

The Princes thus Confedrated rai≈øing great Forces, when in the mean time Mahomet ≈øent Scremet Ba≈ø≈øa again≈øt Scanderbeg, to keep him from joyning with the Venetians, who≈øe Duke Chri≈øtopher Maurus was coming to him, with ten Gallies appointed; with which Ba≈ø≈øa Scanderbeg fought, and put him to flight with the lo≈øs of ten Thou≈øand of his Men, taking the Trea≈øurer of the Army, and ≈øix others of Account Pri≈øoners, who were ≈øpeedily Ran≈øomed at 40000 Duccats; and greater things had been done, had not the Duke of Venice dyed of a Fever, upon who≈øe Death his Army returned home Victor Capella; the next year with the Venetian Fleet, ≈øeized Athens, Aulis, Chalchis, Lar≈øum, and the I≈øle of Himber: But attempting to recover Patras was overthrown.

Hungary being de≈øtitute of ≈øuch a King as might defend them again≈øt the Power of the Turks, elected Matthias Corroinus, the younge≈øt Son of John Huniades their great Captain decea≈øed, who not much inferiour to his Father in valour and ≈øucce≈øs in Arms, gave the Infidels many a fatal overthrow, with the Lo≈øs of many of their Armies, and gave great hopes to the Chri≈øtians that he would as indeed he did prove a Bulwark to Chri≈øtendom.

Whil≈øt things thus pa≈ø≈øed, Mahomet de≈øirous to revenge him≈øelf of Scanderbeg, fent Ballabanus with a great Army to invaide his Territories, whom Scanderbeg charging furiou≈øly overthrew him, but Mo≈øes and others of his Captains contrary to the command of their General, in the heat of fight following their Enemies into the ≈øtraights of the Mountains, where fallen into an Ambu≈øh for that purpo≈øe layed, they were taken Pri≈øoners, and carryed
to Con≈øtantinople, by tho≈øe they had before Vanqui≈øhed, wherewith Sanderbeg ≈øent to de≈øire that he might Ran≈øom them, but the crafty Tyrant knowing how much he was weakned by ≈øuch a lo≈øs, cau≈øed them Cruelly to be flain alive, and ≈øoon after ≈øent Jacup Ba≈ø≈øa with a great Army, with whom the renowned Prince ingaging, ≈ølew him hand to hand, and put to the Sword a great part of his Army, upon news of which Mahomet mad with Anger, rai≈øed an Army of 200000 men, thinking to overrun the Country, but in vain, for having a long time layn Siege to Croia, and there by the furious Sallies of the Garri≈øon, and on≈øets of Scanderbeg, lo≈øt near half his men, together with Ballabanus his General, he with great ≈øhame and confu≈øion returned to Con≈øtantinople.

But as all things mu≈øt yield to Fate, ≈øo our invincible Champion, whom no mortal hand could ≈øubdue, wearyed with the Toils of a tedious War, coming to Ly≈ø≈øa a City of the Venetians, fell Sick, and calling the Venetian Emba≈ø≈øador to him, he di≈øcovered to him what a trouble≈øome Life he had lived, and by what means the War was to be maintained, recommending to him the care of his Wife and Children, appointing the Venetians the Guardians of his Son, till ≈øuch time he came of Age, and in the mean while to ≈øecure for him the Kingdom of Epirus, admoni≈øhing him to be faithful and as much as in him lay to maintain peace and unity. Then calling his Wife and Son, told them that he mu≈øt leave the World and exchange this Life for one more durable, and willed her that after his death ≈øhe ≈øhould pa≈øs over into Apulia, and there to live upon the inheritance given him by King Ferdinand, and then after ≈øome devout Prayers, gave up the Gho≈øt, Anno. 1466. in the 63 year of his Age and 24 of his Reign, to the great grief of the Chri≈øtian Princes, and joy of the Turks, who≈øe Armys his very name had
frequently put to flight. After his death he was with great Solemnity buryed in the Cathedral Church at Ly≈ø≈øa, where he re≈øted till about 9 years after, at what time the Turks taking the City dug up his Bones, and happy was he that could get the ≈ømalle≈øt piece, which they wore about them ever after as ine≈øtimable Jewels, ≈øuper≈øtitiou≈øly imagining that whil≈øt they had them about u'm Scanderbeg's fortune would attend u'm, and that they ≈øhould be invincible.

Not long after the Death of this renowned Soldier, the Hungarians under the leading of their young King, ≈øeized upon the Kingdom of Bo≈øna, and ≈øoon rent it from the Turki≈øh Empire, demoli≈øhing the Ca≈øtles and driving away the Garri≈øons placed there by Mahomet, at what time the Venetians being abroad with a great fleet of Gallies, took divers Cities from the Turks, burnt many Villages, and carryed away 2000 Captives into the Country of Euboea, now called Nigroponte, which ≈øo inraged Mahomet, that he prepared a great Army to invade that Country, and recover the ≈øpoil; in order to effect which, he ≈øent Mahomet Ba≈ø≈øa with a fleet of 300 Gallies, whil≈øt him≈øelf with a great Army Marched overland, with which the Venetian Admiral not daring to ingage it, arrived ≈øafe, where the Turks landing took Stora Ba≈øa≈øilicon, and Marching to Chalcis joyned with the Emperors Army, who with ≈ømall Ve≈ø≈øels and other Materials, made a Bridge over the ≈øtraight or narrow Sea, which divides Euboea from Achaia, ≈øtraightly be≈øieging it both by Sea and Land, and with his Cannon for 4 days battered the City ince≈ø≈øantly, being given to under≈øtand by the chief Cannoneer of the „Äà‚óä„Äâ , whom he had bribed, which was the weake≈øt part, in≈øomuch that in the end ≈øeveral large „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ made, yet was the City ≈øo manfully „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ the Turks could not enter, and every day „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ
Turks forced
to make a new Battery, for ≈øuch part of the Wall as was in the Day time beaten down, which the Citizens in the Night repaired, and at length coming to under≈øtand the Tretchery of their Gunner, hanged him up as a reward of his Tretchery; Mahomet perceiving the valor of the defendants, re≈øolved after his having rent the Wall with his Cannon in divers places, and thirty Days be≈øieged the City, to give a general a≈ø≈øault with all his power, at what time the Venetian Admiral came in ≈øight of the City with his Fleet, but would not tho his Captains urged, either Fight with Turki≈øh Gallies, or endeavour to break the Bridge, the which had he done, he had ≈øhut up Mahomet, and all his forces in the I≈øland, where through Famine and other nece≈ø≈øities he might have greatly di≈øtre≈ø≈øed him. This Cowardice of the Admiral, for which he and all his Family was afterwards Bani≈øhed by the Signory of Venice, being perceived by the Turks, they gave a furious a≈ø≈øault on all parts, and were ≈øo ≈øtoutly repul≈øed, that they with their dead filled up the Trenches and Breaches, but their number ≈øtill increa≈øing, and continuing the a≈ø≈øault a whole day and a night without intermi≈ø≈øion, the Citizens at la≈øt being 3 parts of them Slain, and wounded, the remaining part retired to the Market, and there upon the Turks entering Fought it out to the la≈øt man; ≈øelling their Lives at a dear rate, among≈øt whom many Women di≈øgui≈øed in men's apparel Fighting couragiou≈øly were Slain.

The City being thus gained at the price of 40000 Turks Lives the Barbarous Tyrant commanded all that were found therein to be put to the Sword; which Paulus Ericus the Governour under≈øtanding, with his Wi≈øe, Daughter, and tru≈øty Friends, betook him≈øelf to the Ca≈øtle, who capitulated that upon the ≈øurrender of the Ca≈øtle, him≈øelf, and his Friends
≈øhould have their Lives and Liberties Granted them, which the Tyrant ≈øolemnly Swore to, but having gotten them in his power, made at the great lo≈øs, he had ≈øu≈øtained in winning the City, he cau≈øed the Governour and all but his Daughter to be pre≈øently Slain, re≈øerving the young Lady, as the only Mirror of Beauty, to ≈øatiate his lu≈øt; but ≈øhe di≈ødaining the Tyrants promi≈øes, and reviling him for his wicked purpo≈øes, rather de≈øiring Death then to lo≈øe her Cha≈øtity by becoming his pro≈øtitute, he cau≈øed her even in his pre≈øence to be cruelly put to Death, and then proceeded to ≈øubdue the other Cities of the I≈øland; who terrified with the fate of Chalcis, ≈øurrendered without being A≈ø≈øaulted: So that all the Fruitful I≈øland of Euboea fell into the Hands of the Turks, who infinitely inriched them≈øelves in taking the Spoil.

The Turks thus Triumphing over the Ocean I≈ølands, the Chri≈øtians thought it no ways convenient to be lookers on, but in time to oppo≈øe them, whereupon the Venetians aided by Ferdinand King of Naples, Sextus the fourth Bi≈øhop of Rome, and the Great Ma≈øter of Rhodes, ≈øet out a powerful Navy; under the command of Petrus Mocenicus, a Valiant Venetian Gentleman, and the better to Amate him both by Sea and Land, drew Alymbeus ∆≤≈øan Ca≈ø≈øanes, the great King of Per≈øia into a League with them, and ≈øo at once by Sea and Land, invading the Ottoman Empire, took many ≈øtrong places, and Loaded the Fleet with the Spoil, which Fleet con≈øi≈øting of 85 ≈øo terrified Mahomet, that he dur≈øt not ingage them, nor once oppo≈øe their proceedings, but in revenge thereof turned his whole force upon Epirus and Dalmatia; which Countries having lo≈øt their Champion, the renowned Scanderbeg, growing Weak, he mightily wa≈øted with Fire and Sword, till he had made an ab≈øolute
conque≈øt over them, and the ea≈øier by Rea≈øon of the di≈øcords, that aro≈øe among≈øt the great Commanders, during the Minority of the King; but ere Mahomet had well ≈øetled him≈øelf in tho≈øe ≈øo much de≈øired Countries, he had news that the Per≈øians with a great Army invaded his Countries in A≈øia, which made him begin to con≈øider how to defend his own, rather then further to proceed in Conquering what appertained to others, ≈øo that increa≈øing his Army with no le≈øs then 320000 men, he pa≈ø≈øed over the Hele≈øpont, and after ≈øeveral Days marching, came within a League of the Per≈øian Army, lead by ∆≤≈øan Ca≈ø≈øanes their King, who after ≈øome debate, gave the Turks Battle near the Mountains of Armenia, in which one of the great Ba≈ø≈øas together with 40000 Turks were Slain, and the re≈øt put to Flight, which ≈øo di≈øcouraged Mahomet, that had not his great Captains u≈øed many Arguments to per≈øwade him to the contrary, would have returned without attempting any thing further, but being rou≈øed by their reproofs, le≈øt he ≈øhould be ≈øu≈øpected of Cowardi≈øe, he re≈øolved to try the Fortune of another Field; in order to which he drew up his forces in Battalia near to the Straights of the Mountains, and ≈øo fortified his Camp with Waggons, and other cumber≈øome Carriages, that it ≈øeemed a Walled City, when in the mid≈øt of his Army, he placed his great Artillery; the which upon the fir≈øt joyning of Battle, his men opening to the Right and the Left, played ≈øo furiou≈øly upon the Per≈øian Hor≈øe-men, that they ≈øoon began to Di≈ørank, by Rea≈øon their Hor≈øes upon hearing the unwonted Thundering of the Cannon, would know no Ruler but with Head-≈øtrong fury Floundered fir≈øt one way then another, and by that means put all things into confu≈øion, of which Mahomet taking the advantage,
commanded his men furiou≈øly to charge upon the Enemy as flyers. To re≈øi≈øt who≈øe fury and to ≈øtay the Flight of his men Zeinal ∆≤≈øan Ca≈ø≈øanes Elde≈øt Son Labouring, was Slain with a ≈ømall Shot, which more and more di≈øcouraged the Per≈øians, ≈øo that from retreating, they betook them≈øelves to plain Flight, yet ≈øo great was the lo≈øs of Mahomet that he contented him≈øelf only with the Spoil of the Enemies Camp, not thinking it convenient to per≈øue them, for it was generally Rumoured, that in that Battle he lo≈øt 40000 men, and the Per≈øians 1000 only, after which Mahomet returning home, and ∆≤≈øan Ca≈ø≈øanes leaving his ≈øecond Son with his Army, for the defence of Armenia. Amba≈ø≈øadors were ≈øent by the former to Treat of a Peace, the which to the great di≈ølike of the Christians his Confederates, the Per≈øian concluded with the Turks.

After the Expedition into the Per≈øian Territories, Dyed the Couragious Prince Mu≈øtapha, as ≈øome ≈øay of a Surfeit, but others ≈øay that he was ≈øtrangled by the Commandment of his Father, for Ravi≈øhing Ba≈ø≈øa Achmets Wife, a Lady of Incomparable Beauty, and Daughter to I≈øaac Ba≈ø≈øa one of Mahomets chief Favorites.

Mahomet de≈øirous to revenge the wrong done by the Venetians, ≈øent Solyman Ba≈ø≈øa with 80000 Soldiers to be≈øiege Scodra a ≈øtrong City; then in the po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of the Venetians, and an Inlet into Epirus, Dalmatia and Albania, who Anno 1475 ≈øet down before it, and having rai≈øed his Batteries, gave it a furious a≈ø≈øault, but was repul≈øed by Antonius Lauretamus the Valiant Governour with great lo≈øs, when a while after the Venetian Gallies coming up the River Boliana, on who≈øe Banks the City ≈øtandeth, and as the Turks were bu≈øie in laying a Chain acro≈øs, ≈ølew many of them, and forced the re≈øt to retire to their
Camp, out of which ≈øoon after Matthias King of Hungary drove them with the Terror of his approach, the Ba≈ø≈øa being glad after the lo≈øs of 14000 of his men to rai≈øe his Siege.

Anno 1476. Mahomet growing impatient to be thus hindred in his progree≈øs of Victory, by the Chri≈øtians confederates, ≈øet out a great Fleet under the conduct of Geduces Achmetes; who did great harm to the I≈ølands in the Mediterranean, and hoped by Trea≈øon to have ≈øurprized the I≈øland of Creet, but was prevented by the Venetians, who di≈øcovering the Plot Executed the Traitors before his arrival, yet ≈øailing into the Euxine, he Landed his men in Taurica Cher≈øone≈øus, a Friutful Country belonging to the Genoways; in hopes to have ≈øurprized the rich City of Caffa, Scituate near to the Shoar, but was repul≈øed with a great Slaughter of his men, but being reinforced by fre≈øh Troops, he lay'd Siege to it, which by Rea≈øon of the Turki≈øh Garri≈øons all along the ≈øhoars of Bo≈øphorus, and the Helle≈øpont could have no relief by Sea, after a ≈øtout re≈øi≈øtance ≈øurrendered, and ≈øoon after all the Country to it appertaining, mo≈øt of the Merchants contrary to the promi≈øe of the Faithle≈øs Ba≈ø≈øa, being plundered of their Riches.

Mahomet thus conquering on, grew dreadful to the Tartar princes; Namely the Precopen≈øes and De≈øten≈øes, who for fear of being invaded Voluntarily ≈øubmitted them≈øelves, and became Tributaries, having ever ≈øince been greatly ≈øerviceable to the Turks in their Wars, who now impatient that the Venetians held ≈øeveral ≈øtrong Towns in the Heart of the Ottoman: Solyman Ba≈ø≈øa with a great Fleet entering the Gulph of Corinth lay'd Siege to Naupactum now called Lepanto a ≈øtrong City near Locris over again≈øt Pelopenne≈øus, but upon the arrival of Antonius Lauretanus with the Venetian Gallies, after. he had layn 4 Months before
it, and gave many un≈øuccesful a≈ø≈øaults, in a great fury rai≈øed his Siege in order to his returning to Con≈øtantinople, and by the way Landing his men on the I≈øle of Lemnos, in hopes to have ≈øurprized the City of Coccinum, but were Valiantly repul≈øed by ≈øuch Citizens, and Merchants Strangers as were then near the Gate, and among≈øt the re≈øt one Merulla a Maiden of the City ≈øeeing her Father Slain, took up his Weapon, and with it made great Slaughter of the Turks that were entering the Gate, upon which bad Succe≈øs the Ba≈ø≈øa departed for Con≈øtantinople, and ≈øoon after was ≈øent to be≈øiege Croia in Epirus, to the relief of which the Venetians ha≈øt'ned with an Army, under the leading of Contarenus a man of great courage; who at the fir≈øt on≈øet overthrew the Turks with great Slaughter, obliging them to leave their Camp, but not pur≈øuing them by Rea≈øon of the near approach of Night, whil≈øt they were taking the Spoil, the Enemy rallying fell into their di≈øordered Ranks, and ≈øoon turned the Scale of Victory, by ≈øubduing tho≈øe who a little before were Conquerers, in which la≈øt Fight the General, and ≈øeveral of his great Captains were Slain. Heightned with this Succe≈øs, the Year following A≈øa-Beg with a con≈øiderable Army pa≈ø≈øed the River Sontium, where being incountered by the Garri≈øon Soldiers of three ≈øeveral Forts, under the leading of Hieronimus Nowel, the Count of Verona; he trained the Venetians into an Ambu≈øh, by which they being few in number, and be≈øet on every ≈øide were mo≈øtly Slain, after which the proud Conquerers proceeded to ≈øpoil the Country, wa≈øting it with Fire and Sword taking great Spoils, and driving before them a number of the mi≈øerable People into Captivity.

The Year following Anno 1478. about Harve≈øt-time they come again, and with a great power pa≈ø≈øing
the afore≈øaid River, marched further into the Country, wa≈øting all before them, and unoppo≈øed pa≈ø≈øed over a part of the Alps towards Germany: a way both difficult and dangerous, and ≈øo plundering the Mountaniers who little dreamt of ≈øuch trouble≈øome Vi≈øitants, they returned home laden with great Spoil. And now Mahomet remembring the di≈øgrace he received at the Siege of Scodra, of which he allowed one a yearly Pen≈øion, to put him daily in mind, he ≈øent for his Soldiers from all parts of his Dominions, and under the Leading of ≈øeveral of his Ba≈ø≈øa ‚Ä¢ , him≈øelf being there in per≈øon, likewi≈øe he ≈øet down before the City with an Army of 350000 men, and there ca≈øting ≈øeveral pieces of Ordnance of Mettal he had for that purpo≈øe brought thither in Ma≈øs, one of them carrying a Bullet of 1300 pound Weight; he after he had in vain E≈ø≈øayed to have the City delivered by fair means from the Mounts ince≈ø≈øantly battered the Walls, and withal threw into the City huge Balls of Wild-Fire, and Stones of a prodigious Weight, which beat down and fired many Hou≈øes, yet ≈øo far were the be≈øieged from being di≈øcouraged, that they daily animated each other couragiou≈øly to defend the City to the la≈øt man, every Night Countermuring the Breaches the Cannon made, with Earth Timber and Planks, which Mahomet perceiving commanded his men to give a furious a≈ø≈øault, and either by Firing the Planks, or ≈øcaling the Walls to enter the City; the which in hopes of great rewards, promi≈øed them if they happened to be Succe≈øful in the attempt, thru≈øt them≈øelves into the mouth of Slaughter, being cut off in ≈øuch numbers by the ≈øtorm of Shot ≈øent from the Walls, that all the plains were covered with their Bodies, which Mahomet perceiving and under≈øtanding, they could not accompli≈øh his de≈øire cau≈øed the retreat to be ≈øounded, and gave order for
the renewing the Battery, ≈øo that in one day the Engineers ≈øent 194 great Shot into the Breach, and immediately cau≈øed a ≈øecond A≈ø≈øault to be made, tho with as bad Succe≈øs, as had been the former.

About this time the Turks under the leading of Solyman Ba≈ø≈øa, had taken Croia more through Famine then their Valour, which City the Inhabitants nigh peri≈øhed with Hunger, and not being able to expect any Relief, all the Country about the City being in the hands of the Turks, had delivered upon promi≈øe of Life and Liberty; but the Faithle≈øs Ba≈ø≈øa not having Regard to his Promi≈øe, having got Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion put the remaining Skeletons to the Sword, which the Scadrians under≈øtanding by ≈øome Chri≈øtians in the Turks Camp, were the more incouraged, re≈øolving manfully to dye rather then tru≈øt the perfidious Infidels.

Mahomet inraged at the be≈øieged ob≈øtinacy, and the lo≈øs of his men in the two a≈ø≈øaults, after he had with his Artillery beaten down a great part of the Wall, Commanded the mo≈øt Couragious of his Soldiers to give a third A≈ø≈øault, which they did with great Fury, ≈øhouting in the mean while Showers of Arrows and Bullets into the City, and at length as men de≈øperate entering into the Breach came to Hand-≈øtrokes with the Chri≈øtians, and began a cruel and dreadful Fight, in which many were ≈ølain on either ≈øide: The Turks ≈øtill renewing their a≈ø≈øault with fre≈øh Forces, till at length they ≈øo far prevailed, that tho≈øe who defended the Breach were at the point to retire; at what times a fre≈øh Troop brought by the Governour came happily to their Relief, and beat off the A≈ø≈øailants with great ≈ølaughter: Whereupon Mahomet again renewed his Battery, and lodged 173 more of his great Shot in the Breach, and then ≈øending for his chief Commanders into his Tent-Royal, pitched upon a Mount advantagiou≈øly to behold what pa≈ø≈øed, and there by Threats
and Promi≈øes incouraged them to undertake a fourth A≈ø≈øault. In which he lo≈øt 12000 of his be≈øt Men, and was forced at la≈øt to ≈øound a retreat, yet by the ≈øeveral Fights the Chri≈øtians were ≈øorely weakened in all the Streets, lying covered with Turki≈øh Arrows, and the Breaches with the mingled Bodies of the Chri≈øtians rent mo≈øt mi≈øerably by the great Shot, they were forced to Labour both Day and Night to repair the Breaches, every one incouraging his Fellow in ≈øuch ≈øort, that Mahomet began to de≈øpair of Victory, and bla≈øpheming God, for (as he impiou≈øly pretended) hindering his Proceedings, he retired in his Melancholly Mood into his Tent; where Tormenting him≈øelf for the ≈øpace of two days, he would not be ≈øpoken with by any, but the third Day calling a Council, it was concluded another A≈ø≈øault ≈øhould be given, which was according done with great Fury, and much Effu≈øion of Blood on either ≈øide, but the be≈øieged and re≈øolving to fell their Lives dear, ≈øo manfully with≈øtood them, that with Shame and greater Slaughter then ever they were forced to retire; and now all Provi≈øion being cu≈øt off from the be≈øieged, the Tyrant re≈øolved to gain that by Famine, he could not do by Force; and therefore cea≈øing any further A≈ø≈øault, cau≈øed the City to be ≈øo clo≈øely Blocked up, that the Chri≈øtians were forced to Eat all manner of unclean and loath≈øome Things, as Hor≈øes, Dogs, Cats, Rats, Mice, and the like: Which mi≈øerable ≈øtate of theirs made known to the Senate of Venice, under who≈øe Protection that City was, and they being grown weary of their twenty years tedious War with the Turki≈øh Tyrant, ≈øent Benedictus Trivi≈øanus their Emba≈ø≈øador to Con≈øtantinople, whither weary of the Siege, Mahomet was returned leaving one of his Ba≈ø≈øas with the Army, to Block up the City as afore≈øaid; who upon his Arrival being admitted to the Pre≈øence of the Tyrant, he ≈øo ordered the
Matter, that a Peace was concluded upon the≈øe Articles: Fir≈øt, that the Venetians ≈øhould deliver him the City of Scodra, the I≈øle of Lemnos, the ≈øtrong Ca≈øtle of Tenarus in Peloponne≈øus, and pay him yearly 8000 Duccats; that they might have leave to Traffick in the Euxine-Sea, by the Straights of Bo≈øphorus Helle≈øpontus, and Thracius, and that the Citizens of Scodra, and the Garri≈øon contained therein, ≈øhould upon the Delivery of the ≈øaid City, be at their Choice free to Live in the City under the Turki≈øh Government; or depart whither they plea≈øed with their Goods, &c. The≈øe Articles concluded on Notice thereof was ≈øent to the Governour, who a≈ø≈øembling the Citizens related it to u'm, as he had received it from the Amba≈ø≈øador, who then together with the Venetian Admiral, Rode at Anchor in the Mouth of Boliana, when after ≈øome Debate it was agreed, that they would leave the City, and not expo≈øe them≈øelves to the Mercy of the Tyrant at all times; whereupon at a certain time prefixed the City was put into the Hands of the Ba≈ø≈øa, and the Citizens marching out Bag and Baggage, went on Board the Venetian Gallies, who carefully Tran≈øported them into their other Territories of Italy, and thus was this City ≈øurrendered, Anno 1478. after a years Siege, before which 100000 Turks had lo≈øt their Lives.

Mahomet having gotten what he ≈øorely longed for, ≈øent Achmetes Ba≈ø≈øa with his Gally, to take in the I≈ølands of Neritus, Zacynthus, and Cephalenia; upon which he ≈øeized without any Re≈øi≈øtance, Lenord Prince of the ≈øame, upon the Arrival of the Turks, ha≈øting with his Wife and Children into Italy, where he was kindly received of King Ferdinand his near Kin≈øman, after that he ≈øent three of his Ba≈ø≈øas with a great Army to invade Tran≈øilvania: Whereupon Stephanas, Batore the Vayvod, fled to Matthias King of Hungary to
crave Aid, who at the ≈øame time lay ≈øick of the Gout, yet he ordered his two Captains, viz. Stephanus Cherepetnus, and Palus Rivi≈øus, to march with his Army; who incountering the Turks near Alba Julia, in a great and bloody Fight overthrew the Army, with the Slaughter of 30000 of their be≈øt Men, together with I≈øa Ba≈ø≈øa their chief Commander, and of the Chri≈øtians there fell 8000 only.

Mahomet po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øing mo≈øt of the I≈ølands in the Mediterranian Sea, began to be very de≈øirous of the Famous Rhodes, and to further his De≈øign at the ≈øame time, a Fugitive Knight of the Order, named Antonius Meligalus re≈øiding in his Court, gave him a Plat-form of the City; informing him in what place the City was ea≈øie≈øt to be A≈ø≈øaulted, and how the I≈øland might be be≈øt ≈øubdued: Whereupon a great Fleet was fitted out, and this Traytor to his Country put on Board, with a Command that his Directions ≈øhould be followed, but he by the way falling ≈øick of a loath≈øome Di≈øea≈øe, ≈øo infected the Ship with his noi≈øome Smell, that the Marriners in a great rage threw him Over-Board, whil≈øt he vainly Cryed to them for Mercy, and thus he received the reward due to his Traiterous Intention.

The great Ma≈øter of Rhodes, having notice that Mahomet intended to invade his Territories, was like an experienced Captain wanting nothing that might conduce to a re≈øolute Defence, and having certain Notice that Mi≈øi≈øtes Ba≈ø≈øa had Landed his Power, and was marching towards the City, he a≈ø≈øembled his Captains, and with many Chri≈øtian and Soldier-like per≈øwa≈øions admoni≈øhed them to fight the Battle of the Lord Je≈øus again≈øt his Enemies, which ≈øo wrought upon them that they all re≈øolved to Live and Dye in his defence.

By this time the Ba≈ø≈øa had ≈øet down his Camp, and
began to rai≈øe his Batteries, according to the Directions of one Demetrius another Fugitive Knight, who in the fir≈øt Skirmi≈øh according to the Merits of his Trea≈øon, having his Hor≈øe ≈ølain under him, was mi≈øerably trampled to Death; mo≈øt of the Ordnance now bent again≈øt the Wall, the Ba≈ø≈øa ≈øent out a part of his Army to ≈øeize upon an Orchard, po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed and intrenched by the Christians, which tho≈øe that po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed it, not being able to defend, again≈øt ≈øo powerful an Enemy ≈ølighted it; and retired to the City, leaving the Ordnance behind them: Out of this Orchard by the advice of one George Trapain a Chri≈øtian Runagado, the Turks battered the Tower, ≈øtanding about 300 paces from the City with great Fury, and having made a Breach indeavoured to have entered, but were beaten off with great lo≈øs; after which they framed a Bridge upon Boats, over a frith of the Sea, fa≈øtening by Ropes, ≈øo indeavouring to be≈øiege the Tower both by Sea and Land; the which was no ≈øooner fa≈øtened, but the Ropes were all cut in ≈øunder, by one Garvais Rogers a mo≈øt expert Engli≈øh Sea-Captain, and after that attempting to make another Bridge, and plant pieces of Cannon in Lighters and foi≈øts, the Bridge was broken, and the Lighters ≈øunk by Anthony Damboi≈øe the great Ma≈øters Brother, who with his Artillery planted for that purpo≈øe on the Ba≈øtions, beat them to pieces; but it had not been long e'r Caly Ba≈ø≈øa the younger Arriving in the Camp, it was noi≈øed that Mahomet was coming with an additional Army of 100000 Turks, which ≈øo terrified the Spaniards (for the Garri≈øon was Compo≈øed of all Chri≈øtian Nations) that they de≈øired to be Shipped out of the I≈øland, and to return home; but for ≈øuch their Cowardize, being ≈øharply reproved by Peter Damboi≈øe the great Ma≈øter, a mo≈øt expert and Valiant French man, they, as a≈øhamed of what they before propo≈øed begged Pardon, and
afterwards notably defended the City during the Siege.

Me≈øues perplexed that he could not carry the City by Force, though with his Artillery he had levelled the Walls in many places, which were as ≈øoon repaired, he re≈øolved by Treachery to perform what otherwi≈øe he could not Effect, and therefore made large Offers to ≈øeveral di≈øcontented Rhodians to poi≈øon the great Ma≈øter, which ≈øome of them undertook to bring to pa≈øs, but e'r any thing was done in Relation thereto the wickedne≈øs was di≈øcovered, and the undertakers worthily Executed; upon notice of which the Ba≈ø≈øa more perplexed then before, and yet not knowing without lo≈øs of Honour how to rai≈øe the Siege, ≈øent ≈øeveral Me≈ø≈øengers to the great Ma≈øter in his Name, to promi≈øe him extraordinary Matters if he would ≈øurrender to him the City, and to denounce all the Mi≈øeries of War upon his Refu≈øal: To which the Heroick Old man returned An≈øwer, that he would not willingly in his ≈øure≈øt E≈øtate u≈øe the Council of his Enemy, neither in his greate≈øt di≈øtre≈øs refu≈øe Cheerfully to yeild his Life unto Almighty God, to whom he did owe it, and that with far better Will, then to ≈øurrender the City upon any Conditions, bear they never ≈øo fair a ≈øhew of Honour or Profit. The Me≈ø≈øengers perceiving this con≈øtant Re≈øolution of the great Ma≈øter, by other Arguments indeavoured him at lea≈øt to become Tributary to the Emperor, paying a ≈ømall matter yearly for his Peace; but he knowing that to be the ready way to be brought under the Turki≈øh Slavery, utterly refu≈øed; upon which the Me≈ø≈øengers returned greatly di≈øcontented to him that ≈øent 'um, who thereat greatly perplexed gave another general A≈ø≈øault, battering the City for four days without Intermi≈ø≈øion, but not prevailing after three Months ≈øiege, having lo≈øt 9000 of his Men, and 15000 dangerou≈øly
≈øick of their Wounds, and mortal Di≈øtempers, he with great ≈øhame rai≈øed his Siege; and after having de≈øtroyed all the Trees in that part of the I≈øland, imbarked his Men for Con≈øtantinople, where at his return he received but a Cold Welcom from his imperious Ma≈øter.

Whil≈øt Me≈øites be≈øieged Rhodes, Achmetes Ba≈ø≈øa pa≈ø≈øed over into Italy, and be≈øieged Otranto a Famous City in Puglia; the which after the lo≈øs of many of his Turks took it, ≈øpoiling all the Country round about it, which brought ≈øuch a Fear upon Italy, that Sextus Quartus Bi≈øhop of Rome, being only dreadful to the Chri≈øtian Princes, was about to fly and leave this once Mi≈øtre≈øs of the World, as a prey to the Infidels; and doubtle≈øs at that time the greate≈øt part of Italy had been ≈øubdued, had not the Ottoman Forces been Converted another way; for the Carramanian King, aided by the Per≈øians and Sultan of Egypt; having entered the Turki≈øh Dominions on that ≈øide, had in a mortal Battle overthrown Bajazet, Mahomet's elde≈øt Son (then Living) with the Slaughter of well nigh all his Army, to revenge which Mahomet called home his great Ba≈ø≈øa Achmetes, with all the European Soldiers, and in Per≈øon pa≈ø≈øed over into A≈øia; but upon the way within two days journey from Nicomeda a City of Bythinia he fell ≈øick, and there for the ≈øpace of three days grievou≈øly Tormented with a pain in his Belly (which ≈øome ≈øuppo≈øed to be the Collick, though others to proceed from the effects of Poi≈øon) he Dyed, Anno 1481. of his Age 52 years, and his Reign 31 years. His Body being afterwards Magnificently buried in a Chappel, near unto the great Mahometan Temple, which him≈øelf had built at Con≈øtantinople; Leaving his Empire to Bajazet again≈øt whom Bandied (till ≈øuch time he was Poi≈øoned by the Bi≈øhop of Rome, who at the Commandment of Bajazet dur≈øt do no other) Zemes,
or Zizimus his younger Brother, as in the Life of Bajazet will appear.

div.head: CHAP. XIII. The Life of Bajazet the ≈øecond of that Name, and ≈øecond Emperor of the Turks, his memorial Exploits, Victories, and Death.
div.p:
MAhomet being dead, and Bajazet and Zemes his two Sons ab≈øent (for the Turki≈øh Tyrants will not permit their Sons to remain at Court when they are Men grown, le≈øt they ≈øhould a≈øpire to Empire before their time) the great Ba≈ø≈øas, and Aga of the Janizaries Con≈øpired together, e'r either of them could arrive, to make Corcutus younger Son to Bajazet Emperor, which accordingly they did; of which Bajazet upon his approaching the City of Con≈øtantinople, hearing, horribly Exclaimed again≈øt the perfidious dealings of the Ba≈ø≈øas, and ≈øo laboured that at the In≈øtance of Cher≈øeogles Vice-Roy of Greece, and the Aga, or Captain of the Janizaries; the young Emperor being of a mild and Courteous Nature, overcome by their Intreaty, and the Reverence of his Father, re≈øigned unto him his Imperial Government, which he took upon him, with the general liking of the men of War, the fine≈øt token of any Turki≈øh Emperors E≈øtabli≈øhment; for if they oppo≈øe it 'tis in vain for them to hope for Empire, and in lieu of this Re≈øignation, Bajazet made him Governour of Lycia, Caria, Ionia, and all the plea≈øant Countries adjoyning; where being altogether
given to ≈øtudy, he Lived quietly all the Reign of Bajazet, but after his Death was ≈øtrangled by the Command of Selymas his Brothers Son, as will in his Reign more at large appear.

During the≈øe Troubles, Ferdinand King of Naples, ≈øent his elde≈øt Son Alphon≈øus Duke of Calabria, with a great Power to be≈øiege Otranto, which after ≈øeveral ≈øharp Conflicts he had delivered up to him, with all the Country lying about it, which had been by Achmetes Ba≈ø≈øa taken from the Chri≈øtians, during the Reign of Mahomet; to recover which an Army was a ≈øecond time prepared, under the leading of the ≈øame Ba≈ø≈øa; but e'r he arrived in Italy, he was Countermanded upon notice that Zemes was coming out of Ama≈øia with an powerful Army, to Wre≈øtle with Bajazet for the Empire: In which Expedition Achmetes was made General, who meeting Zemes by plain Force, drove him out of the Field with great ≈ølaughter of his Army; in≈øomuch, that not thinking him≈øelf ≈øafe in his Brothers Dominions, he fled into Syria, and from thence into Egypt, to Caytbeius Sultan of Egypt and Syria, who received him with many great Expre≈ø≈øions of joy, and at his Reque≈øt ≈øent an Amba≈ø≈øador to Bajazet, to intreat in his behalf, that ≈øome part of that ≈øo great an Empire might be allotted him; but the Proud Turk having gotten Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion, would not yeild to have ≈øo dangerous a Partner: Whereupon the Amba≈ø≈øador effecting nothing, he joyned with the Caramanian King, who by ≈øuch a Conjunction hoped to recover his Territory taken from him, by Mahomet, Prince Zemes Father, again≈øt who≈øe joynt Forces, but few in number, Bajazet advanced with 200000 Hor≈øe and Foot, of which the Princes having notice, and finding them≈øelves too weak by far to oppo≈øe ≈øo great a Power, not finding as they had been put in hopes, any to revolt from Bajazet to them; they thought it
good to retire before the ways were be≈øet, through the Straights of the Mountain Amanus, which done, they di≈øper≈øed their little Army, and ≈øoon after Zemes went to Rhodes, where of the great Ma≈øter he was kindly received, with Promi≈øe of Protection from the Fury of his Brother, hoping by this means, if Bajazet ≈øhould die a natural Death, or otherwi≈øe mi≈øearry, this Prince might be ≈øet up Emperor, and by means ever remain a firm Friend to the Chri≈øtians.

During the≈øe Tran≈øactions, there wanted not ≈øome in the Court of Bajazet, who Envying the Pro≈øperity, Achmetes Coun≈øelled the Emperor to put him to Death, fal≈øly in≈øinuating that he held private Corre≈øpondence with Zemes: Whereupon at his return from the Wars, Bajazet as in kindne≈øs to his Ba≈ø≈øas made a Royal Supper, where after they had Drunk plentifully of Wine which by their Laws is forbid, yet frequently among≈øt the Great ones u≈øed at their Fea≈øts; he in token of Honouring them, cau≈øed a Rich Garment to be ca≈øt over each of them, but when they came to Achmetes, they ca≈øt over him a black Velvet Garment, by the Turks called the Mantle of Death; for who≈øoever that Garment is ca≈øt upon, none of the Ba≈ø≈øas dare be ≈øo hardy as to intreat for his Life, which the other Ba≈ø≈øas perceiving, mo≈øt of them being before privy to the Matter by leave of the Emperor, after having ki≈ø≈øed the Ground whereon he ≈øtood departed; among≈øt whom Achmetes would likewi≈øe have gone out, but was Commanded to ≈øtay for the Emperor, and no ≈øooner were the Ba≈ø≈øas gone out, but the Mini≈øters of Death (which are certain ≈øtrong Men bereaved of Speech, whom the Turki≈øh Tyrants keep as In≈øtruments of their Cruelty) Entered, and were about to ≈øtrangle the Ba≈ø≈øa; when one of the Eunuches in great Favour with the great Emperor, ≈øtood up and advi≈øed „Äà‚óä„Äâ not to be too ha≈øty in Executing ≈øo great a Man,
≈øo beloved by his Soldiers, and be≈øt men of War, but rather to defer the Execution, till he ≈øaw how the matter would be dige≈øted, and in the mean time by Torture to make him confe≈øs what might render his Execution more rea≈øonable, of which Coun≈øel Bajazet approving, commanded him immediately to be ≈øtripped, and delivered into the Hands of the Tormentors. The which whil≈øt they were doing, his Son having gotten notice in what Extream danger his Father was in, rai≈øed the Jannizaries, who upon notice that their beloved Captain ≈øtood on the Brink of the Grave flowed from all parts, like a Torrent to the Pallace, Thundering at the Gates as if they would have beaten the Pallace about his Ears, whereupon cau≈øing the outward Gate to be ≈øet open, he ≈øhewed him≈øelf to 'um through an Iron Window; demanding the cau≈øe of that Tumult and Uproar, to which they an≈øwered, that they would by and by, teach him as a Drunkard or Bea≈øt, and a Ra≈øcal to u≈øe his great place, and calling with more Sobriety and De≈øcretion, Loading him with many more ≈øuch like opprobrious Expre≈ø≈øions, Commandin forthwith to deliver Achmetes, or el≈øe they would beat the Pallace about his Ears, which demand of the in≈øolent Janizaries he dur≈øt not deny, but Commanded that he ≈øhould be forthwith delivered to them, who for ha≈øt was brought out half Naked, with the marks of his ≈øevere u≈øage on his Body; who had no ≈øooner got him, but they ≈øtripped the Emperors Minions, and with their Spoils Cloathing him, carryed him out of the Court on their Shoulders in great Triumph, tho the Ba≈ø≈øa did what he could to appea≈øe the Tumultuary Joy they conceived for his deliverance.

Bajazet knowing by experience how deeply the Ba≈ø≈øa was rooted in the affections of the men of War,
dur≈øt not pre≈øently ≈øhew his Anger, tho Burning with the de≈øire of revenge, therefore the better to bring to pa≈øs what he had purpo≈øed, he took Achmetes into favour again, promoting him more then ever; which the Loyal old man tru≈øting too far, was as he was ≈øitting at Supper, by the command of Bajazet thru≈øt through with a Sword, and Slain after he had Conquered 7 Kingdoms, and Annexed them to the Ottoman Empire, being the mo≈øt expert Commander, that ever the Turks could Boa≈øt off. But Bajazet's Spleen not ≈øo ≈øatisfied, he purpo≈øed to de≈øtroy the whole order of the Janizaries, in revenge of the in≈øolency they had offered him, but his de≈øign upon their lives coming to their knowledge, and they ≈øtanding upon their Guard, he found it a matter not to be compa≈ø≈øed without great difficulty, tho to execute his plea≈øure, he had ≈øent for the Acanzii, accounted the be≈øt Soldiers next the Jamzaries, throughout all his Dominions; therefore he was forced to forego his Bloody and Tyrannical purpo≈øe, and the better to Colour the matter pretended he had ≈øent for tho≈øe Soldiers to War again≈øt Moldavia: But the Janizaries not greatly tru≈øting him, Inbattled by them≈øelves, refu≈øing to receive him into the middle of their Ranks, as was their u≈øual manner, but ≈øhaking their Weapons, bid him ≈øend his Executioners, for they were ready to receive them; but by the mediation of the Ba≈ø≈øas, at length matters were accorded, and they received Bajazet among≈øt them, for the Turki≈øh Emperors never marched but in the middle of the Janizaries.

The Tumult pacified, Bajazet with his Army pa≈ø≈øed over Danubius, and entering Moldavia be≈øieged Kele or Achilleia, which after many furious a≈ø≈øaults was delivered to him, as afterward was Ac-Gimen or A≈øproca≈øtron, the Turks u≈øually changing the Names of ≈øuch Cities & Towns, as fall into their hands.

Zemes being at Rhodes, Bajazet was not a little troubled, le≈øt he ≈øhould prove a Thorn in his ≈øide, & therefore u≈øed many Endeavours, to get him into his po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion, but the great Ma≈øter abhorring Breach of tru≈øt, notwith≈øtanding the many Threats and Promi≈øes of the Tyrant, would not deliver him, nor was he ≈øought only by his Brother, but by Charles the French King, Matthias King of Hungary, and Pope Innocentius the Eight of that Name Bi≈øhop of Rome, all of them thinking to advantage their Affairs, by having a Prince of the Ottoman Blood in their Cu≈øtody; the King and the Emperor in their Wars, and the Pope of a mind more Ignoble, by getting a yearly Pen≈øion from his Brother Bajazet, for the ≈øafe keeping him to the la≈øt; of which after Reiterated intreaties, the great Ma≈øter delivered him, in lieu of which be was Created Cardinal, nor was the Popes Expectation vain, for he yearly received of Bajazet 40000 Ducats, yearly for the ≈øafe keeping him, but of this more hereafter.

Bajazet being frequently troubled by the ≈øuddain Inva≈øions of the Caramanian King, re≈øolved to ≈øubdue the remaining part of his Country, the which with a great Army out of Europe he invaded, ≈øpoiling all before him, but the wary Prince knowing him≈øelf far too Weak, to meet ≈øo powerful an Enemy in the Field, kept him≈øelf with his few forces in the Fa≈øtne≈ø≈øes of the Mountain, whereupon Bajazet be≈øieged Tar≈øus in Cilicia, and had it delivered to him, upon condition that the Citizens might depart thence with their Goods, and not be further prejudiced, either in their Lives or Liberties; but by this time Abraham, Ali√†s, Pyramet King of Caramania having obtained con≈øiderable forces of Caytbeius Sultan of Egypt, he was re≈øolved to try his fortune in the Field, and put all to the Hazard of a Battle, which being
begun the 10th. of May Anno 1486, was Fought with great ob≈øtinancy on either ≈øide, for the ≈øpace of a whole day, when the Turks by Rea≈øon of their Multitude prevailed, in which Battle the King and the greate≈øt part of his Army were Slain, and afterward his Country totally ≈øubdued by Bajazet, who likewi≈øe at that time took into his po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion all A≈øia the le≈øs, becoming Lord of the Sea Coa≈øt from the Straights of Bo≈øphorus to the Confines of Syria.

By this means the Ambitious Emperor Stretching the borders of his Empire, to the bounders of the Egyptian Sultans Territories, re≈øolved to have no peace with him, by Rea≈øon he had not only a≈ø≈øi≈øted his Brother Zames again≈øt him, but likewi≈øe the Carramanian King in the la≈øt Battle, ≈øo that rai≈øing a great Power, he ≈øent them under the Leading of I≈øhender-Ba≈ø≈øa, Michael-Beg, and Jaxis-Beg his two Sons to wa≈øt the Sultans Dominions in Syria; but pa≈ø≈øing the Great Mountain Taurus, they were intraped by Aladules the Mountain King, who had lay'd an Ambu≈øh of his Savage people for that purpo≈øe, where mo≈øt of the Turks were together with Michael-Beg were Slain, the Ba≈ø≈øa his other Son, and the remaining part taken Pri≈øoners; the news of which defeat being known to Carrago≈øes Ba≈ø≈øa, who was following with more forces, it ≈øo di≈øcouraged him that he would advance no further, yet the next Year pa≈ø≈øing into the confines of Egypt, he was Fought with, and overthrown by the Sultans power: But the≈øe ill haps ≈øo little di≈øcouraged Bajazet, that he more inraged then ever, re≈øolved to invade Egypt by Sea and Land, which the Sultan under≈øtanding re≈øolved to Tran≈øport the Seat of War into the Turks Dominions, and ≈øo with a great Army, he Commanded ∆≤sbeg to pa≈øs into Cilicia, where not far from Tar≈øus, he found the Turks incamped under the command of Cher≈øogles Vice-Roy
of Greece, a mo≈øt Valiant Captain, whereupon a mortal Battle begun, and many thou≈øands Slain, for the Sultans Army con≈øi≈øting mo≈øtly of Mamalukes, ≈øuch an ob≈øtinate Fight was fiercly maintained between them, and the Turki≈øh Jannizaries, that Victory ≈øtood doubtful for the ≈øpace of 2 days, at the end of which the Turki≈øh General having lo≈øt 60000 of his men, in the Night left his Camp and fled, nor was the lo≈øs in the Sultans Army much inferiour, but the Turks lo≈øs ≈øtill proved greater; for Flying through Aladules Country, that King had ≈øo be≈øet the way, that mo≈øt of the remaining part were Slain, and the General taken pri≈øoner, nor fared Bajazet's Fleet at Sea better, for Anchoring in the mouth of Orentes within ≈øight of Antioch, it was by a Tempe≈øt beaten to pieces, all which lo≈ø≈øes coming one upon the Neck of another, cau≈øed Bajazet to ≈øend his Amba≈ø≈øadors to the Sultan to require peace, which was accorded to, and all the Pri≈øoners ≈øet at liberty, when ≈øhortly after the Sultan, who of a Circa≈ø≈øian Slave, by the favour of the Mamaluke's his Fellows become a mighty Monarch dyed.

Peace being concluded in A≈øia, the Chri≈øtian Princes ≈øtirred up thereto by Pope Alexander the Sixth, that Firebrand of di≈øcord, all Chri≈øtendom was in a Flame, at what time Charles the French King ≈øeized upon the Kingdom of Naples, taken from his Father by Ferdinand the fir≈øt, whereupon the Pope and Alphon≈øus the exiled King of Naples, ≈øolicited Bajazet to ≈øend them 6000 Hor≈øe, and as many Foot for the recovery of the ≈øame, laying before him (like ≈øpecial Chri≈øtians) what danger the Mahometan Religion would be in, if the French prevailed; the Pope promi≈øing him al≈øo to Poy≈øon Zemes his Brother, if he would pay him well for ≈øo doing; the≈øe Admonitions and large overtures ≈øo prevailed with the Infidel, that he had
great ≈øtore of trea≈øure, but as it was de≈øigned for evil purpo≈øes, it pro≈øpered accordingly; for the Ve≈ø≈øell in the Adriatick Sea, being boarded by John Roverius, a Venetian, he ≈øeized the ca≈øh before it came to the Popes fingering, yet his Holyne≈øs loath to break his Word, neverthele≈øs, contrary to his Oath made to the Amba≈ø≈øadors, from the great Ma≈øter of Rhodes, Poi≈øoned Zemes, by putting Poi≈øon among≈øt the Sugar which he was wont to mix with his Water, to the great Scandal of the Chri≈øtian Religion, and reproach of St. Peter's pretended Succe≈ø≈øors: nor was God ≈ølow in revenging the di≈øhonor done to his name, for Alexander having a Ba≈øtard Son, named Cae≈øar Borgia, a Profligate Wretch, who after many Outrages and Murthers committed, being about to Poi≈øon ≈øeveral of the Cardinals, at a Supper in the Vattican, by a lucky mi≈øtake of the waiter, in taking up the wrong flaggon poi≈øoned his Father, who notwith≈øtanding his infallibility, was not Poi≈øon proof, nor did this ungracious Son long e≈øcape, for fighting under the ≈øtandard of the King of Navar, he was ≈ølain with a hargubus ≈øhot.

Notwith≈øtanding the death of Pope Alexander, yet he left Chri≈øtendom in ≈øuch a blaze, that the flame of di≈øcord, was not in a long while after quenched, for whil≈øt the Emperor of Germany, and Princes of Italy, were Bandi≈øing again≈øt the French King and ≈øhedding Chri≈øtian Blood, the Turks invaded Podolia and Ra≈ø≈øia, ≈øpoiling the Country and ≈øacking ≈øeveral walled Towns, but by rea≈øon of the Exce≈ø≈øivene≈øs of the Winter, through Hunger and Cold, mo≈øt of the Army Peri≈øhed, yet not di≈ømayed by the Lo≈øs ≈øu≈øtained, he the next year ≈øent Cadumes Ba≈ø≈øa into Illyria, who ≈øpoiling the Country was incountred by 9000 Croats and Hungarians near the River Morava, under the leading of Count Bernard Francopain, where after a
cruel and Bloody fight, the Chri≈øtians were put to the wor≈øt, and 7000 of them ≈ølain, and drowned in pa≈ø≈øing the River, the no≈øes of which being cut off, and hung upon ≈øtrings, were ≈øent to Bajazet as a Barbarous pre≈øent.

Charles the French King being dead, Lewis the 12 Succeeded him in the Kingdom of France, who laying claim to the Dukedom of Millain made a league with the Venetians, whereupon Sfortia the Duke in po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion ≈øent to crave aid of Bajazet, laying before him the danger his Empire was in daily to be invaded, if the French grew ≈øtrong in Italy, preferring Ambition and revenge, before the advancement of the Chri≈øtian Religion; Bajazet by this means ≈øtirred up, re≈øolved to render the Venetians un≈øerviceable to the French, by keeping them bu≈øie nearer home, whereupon he commanded Scander Ba≈ø≈øa his Lievetenant in Illyria, to break in upon the Fruitful Country of Friuli, part of the Venetians Territories on the borders of Italy, the which he did with 12000 Hor≈øe, de≈øtroying all before him as far as Liquentia, driving before him a great number of Captives, the which when he came to the Banks of Tiliaventum, and under≈øtanding that the French and Venetians had driven the Duke of Millan out of his Territories, he barbarou≈øly cau≈øed to be put to the Sword.

After the Sei≈øure of Millan, the Venetians ≈øet out a great Fleet under the charge of Anthony Grimani, who ≈øet upon the Turks Fleet (far Superior in number) as it was coming out of the Bay or Haven of Sapientia, in the I≈øland of Sphraga, but through the Cowardice of the Admiral, in not permitting half his Fleet to come up, tho≈øe that were ingaged retired after a ≈øharp di≈øpute, and the Turks kept their cour≈øe to Naupactum, now called Lepanto, where they found Bajazet already arrived with his Land Army, ≈øo that after
a few days Siege, the Citizens di≈øpairing of Succour Surrendred the City, wherefore the Venetian Admiral upon his return was Bani≈øhed by a decree of the Senate, to one of the Ab≈øytidies I≈ølands, upon the Coa≈øt of Liburnia.

Bajazet by this means having got firm footing in the Venetian Territories, the year following viz. 1500 entered the ≈øtraights of Corinth with an Army of 150000, and pa≈ø≈øing through Peloponne≈øus, lay'd Siege to the ≈øtrong City of Menthon, now called Modon, and took it by ≈øurprize, putting all the Inhabitants to the Sword, upon which ≈øeveral other Cities belonging to the Venetians, yielded by compo≈øition, but after the taking of many Cities on either ≈øide, with great Blood-≈øhed both by Sea and Land. A peace between Bajazet and the Senate of Venice was treated, and finally accorded upon con≈øideration, fir≈øt that the Venetians ≈øhould deliver up the I≈ølands of Neritos and Lucadia (the which during the≈øe Wars they had taken from the Turks) re≈øerving to them≈øelves only the I≈øland of Cephalenia: And that in con≈øideration thereof, Bajazet ≈øhould re≈øtore all ≈øuch goods as had been taken from the Venetian Merchants in the late Wars, and that it ≈øhould be lawful for them (as they were wonted, ≈øafely to trade and traffique into the Euxine Sea, and to Con≈øtantinople, and there to have their Conful or Governour, as they had in former time, and la≈øtly that the Venetian Territories ≈øhould be certainly known and ≈øeperated from the Turks, by certain Bounds or Limits. The≈øe conditions were Solemnly concluded on, and confirmed, both by Bajazet and the Senate of Venice, and ≈øo affirmed: Peace concluded in Anno 1503, after the Wars had continued between them for the ≈øpace of 5 years.

Peace concluded with the Venetians, Bajazet rai≈øed a great Army intending to invade Hungary, but having
been often foiled by that warlike Nation, he changed his mind, and Marched to ≈øuppre≈øs the in≈øurrection in Albania a part of his Territory, which done as he was returning, a Derviller which is a Phanta≈øtical kind of a beggarly Turki≈øh Monk, u≈øing no other apparel but two Sheep Skins, the one hanging before, and the other behind, who coming up to him as if he would have asked an Almes, with a ≈øhort Cimiter, ≈øtrock at him, and beat him from his Hor≈øe, and being about to redouble his blow, had certainly di≈øpatched him, had not I≈øhender Ba≈ø≈øa come in, and with his Hor≈øemans Mace, ≈øtruck the Varlet dead, who afterwards by the Soldiers was hewn in pieces; this treacherous and de≈øperate act ≈øo moved Bajazet, that he pro≈øcribed all them of that Super≈øtitious order, and bani≈øhed them out of his Empire.

Bajazet after the ince≈ø≈øant toiles of War, re≈øolving to repo≈øe him≈øelf, committed the Management of his great Affairs to his 3 Ba≈ø≈øa's, viz. Alis, Achmetes, Kin≈øman to him that was ≈ølain, and Jachia, who having got the Reins of Empire in their hands for the ≈øpace of 5 years, ≈øuffered things to run into ≈øuch di≈øorder, by regarding their private profit, more then the publick good, that a great part of the Le≈ø≈øer A≈øia was in an uproar by the means of Cha≈øan Chelife, and Schach Culi, or Techellis, two Per≈øian Impo≈øters, who ≈øet the Multitude a madding, by ≈øpreading a new fangled Doctrine, more wicked then that of Mahomet their pretended Prophet. To quench this Flame that began dreadfully to blaze into a Rebellion, Bajazet was forced to rou≈øe from his Lair, yet the Doctrine could not, nor is it, to this day extirprated, for being per≈øecuted by Bajazet, they fled into Per≈øia, and there pretending them≈øelves to be the true Succe≈ø≈øor of Mahomet the Impo≈øter, and that none but they knew his Will, and that tho≈øe that believed not in their Doctrine, ≈øhould
never Injoy any happine≈øs after this Life, with a deal of ≈øuch ridiculous Cant they ≈øo be≈øotted A≈øymbeiu ‚Ä¢
∆≤≈øun Ca≈ø≈øanes the Per≈øian King, that he had to the fir≈øt Author of this Doctrine, viz. one Haider, who was Ma≈øter of the≈øe Di≈øciples, given his Daughter Martha in Marriage; but he dying, and his Son Jacup ≈øucceeding him in the Kingdom, began to have his Brother-in-Law in ≈øu≈øpition, by rea≈øon of the multitude that followed him, upon the account of his pretended Sanctity: In≈øomuch that he cau≈øed him ≈øecretly to be murthered, and rai≈øed a great Per≈øecution again≈øt tho≈øe that imbraced his Doctrine; yet this Haider left a Son which he had by Martha his Wife named Hy≈ømael, who afterward became a Sophy of Per≈øia, as will appear in his Wars with Selymus Bajazet's Son, and Succe≈ø≈øor, but upon the Per≈øecution rai≈øed by Jacup Son to ∆≤≈øun Ca≈ø≈øanes, the two afore≈øaid Di≈øciples of Haider fled to Armenia, and there dwelling in Rocks began to tell Fortunes, and other ≈øtrange things which made the Ru≈øticks ≈øuppo≈øe them men more then ordinarily in≈øpired; In≈øomuch that they gathered about them in great numbers, in≈øomuch that they came out of their Iurking Holes into walled Towns, and taught boldly.

During the ≈øpreading of this Doctrine, Hy≈ømael the Son of Haider being grown to mans E≈øtate, and his Uncle Jacup dead, he by the Aid of ≈øuch as favoured his Fathers Doctrine, won the Kingdom of Armenia, and after that overthrowing Eluan the Per≈øian King, Son to his Uncle Jacup in a pitched Battle, wherein the ≈øaid King was ≈ølain, he took Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of all his Grand-fathers Dominions, and from that time was called the great Sophy of Per≈øia, being afterward exceedingly beloved of his Subjects.

This Hy≈ømale was no ≈øooner E≈øtabli≈øhed in his Kingdom, but he E≈øtabli≈øhed to his Power his Fathers Doctrine, which Chu≈øan, Chelife, and Techellis, perceiving,
and under≈øtanding the unlooked for ≈øucce≈øs of their Ma≈øters Son, they re≈øolved not to be Idle, but to try their Fortune likewi≈øe: Whereupon gathering a great number of their Pro≈øelytes in Arms, they wa≈øted again the Countries in the le≈ø≈øer A≈øia, and being incouraged thereto by Hy≈ømale with Promi≈øe of great Succours, they ≈øet down before the City of Iconium; ≈øending out their Proclamations ≈øtrictly to injoyn all the People thereabout to imbrace their Doctrine, threatning them otherwi≈øe with Death, and Confi≈øcation of Goods; which wrought ≈øuch Terror in the Pea≈øants, that they had many of them joyned with them; ≈øo that within a while their number was increa≈øed, from 10 to 50000. Whereupon Orchanes and Mahomites, two of Bajazets Nephews gathering what Forces they could Sallyed out of the City again≈øt them, but were put to flight with the lo≈øs of mo≈øt of their Men: Corcutus al≈øo one of Bajazets Sons, and then Governour of Thyatria, Sypilus, Magne≈øia, and Phocia, having leavyed a great Army, dur≈øt not neverthele≈øs to give them Battle, but waited the coming of Carago≈øes Ba≈ø≈øa, who was rai≈øing great Forces in Cappadocia and Pontus; having ≈øent his Command to Achmetes one of Bajazets Sons to do the like, but e'r he had gathered a ≈øufficient Power, the pretended Prophets came upon him, put ≈øuch Forces as he had to the Rout, and forced Carago≈øes then Vice-Roy of A≈øia, for his ≈øafety to fly into the City of Cutaie, near unto the Mountain Horminius, ≈øituate in the middle of the le≈ø≈øer A≈øia; which City they be≈øieged, took by force, and in it the Vice-Roy his Wife and Children, putting mo≈øt of the Citizens to the Sword, and from thence marched to be≈øiege the great City of Pru≈øa; but in their way hearing that Alis Ba≈ø≈øa was come out of Europe with great Power, and followed hard upon them, they retreated and pa≈ø≈øed another
way to avoid joyning with the Turks in the plain Ground, of which the Ba≈ø≈øa having Notice, and di≈øpairing to overtake them with his Footmen, cho≈øe out 8000 of his ≈øwifte≈øt Hor≈øe, leaving Achmetes with the re≈øt of the Army, after a tedious March he fell in with their Rear: Whereupon Techellis, who was cho≈øen General of the Rebels, put his men in Battle Array; when taking the mo≈øt advantagious Ground, he ≈øtayed the coming of the Turki≈øh Hor≈øe, who charged him in the Front with great Fury, but wanting Foot to ≈øecond them in ≈øo Hilly a Country were driven back, which the Ba≈ø≈øa perceiving drew forth 1000 Harquebu≈øiers, who ≈øerved as Foot to oppo≈øe the Front, whil≈øt the Hor≈øe Charged on the right and left Wings of the Enemies Army, which was performed with ≈øuch Bravery, that Techellis's Men gave Ground, and in the Rear broke and di≈øordered their own Ranks; when Chelife one of the Impo≈øtors fighting de≈øperately was ≈ølain. But Techellis coming with fre≈øh ≈øupplies, re≈øtored the Battle, to break which Alis Ba≈ø≈øa Charging furiou≈øly with fre≈øh Troops of Hor≈øe, & entering too far among≈øt the Squadrons of his Enemies was ≈ølain, which ≈øo di≈øcouraged his men (then at the point to have prevailed) that they fir≈øt fainted, and afterwards betook them≈øelves to plain flight; ≈øo that in pa≈ø≈øing the Mountains many of them were ≈ølain, and more taken Pri≈øoners.

Bajazet hearing of the Succe≈øs of the Rebels, ≈øent Jonu≈øes Ba≈ø≈øa again≈øt them with 40000 Hor≈øe and Foot, upon who≈øe approach they retired into the Mountains, but being driven thence they fled into Armenia: Whereupon the Ba≈ø≈øa fretting that he had not be≈øet the ways, cau≈øed all that he found to imbrace the new Religion, or to have born Arms again≈øt Bajazet on the behalf of Techellis, either to be put to Death, Burnt in the Forehead with a hot Iron, or Tran≈øported into Europe, to prevent any future In≈øurrection;
and upon his return to Con≈øtantinople had Notice, that Techellis and his ≈øcattered Forces in their flight, lighting upon a Caravan of Silks and other Rich Merchandize took the ≈øpoil thereof, for which outrage coming to Tauris, the Captains were all by the Command of Hy≈ømael hanged upon Gibbits, and Techellis for a Terror to others burnt alive.

The A≈øtan Rebellion ≈øuppre≈ø≈øed by the means afore≈øaid, the year following, viz. Anno 1509. a dreadful Earthquake happened in Con≈øtantinople, and the Countries adjacent, which la≈øted with very little Intermi≈ø≈øion for the ≈øpace of eighteen days, or as the Turks affirm a Month; in which time ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ t ‚Ä¢ ew to the ground many ≈øtately Buildings in Constantinople, Hadrianople and other Cities of Greece, and in their Ruins overwhelmed 13000 People; after which a great Mortality happened, which di≈øpeopled many Cities in the Turks Dominions; but both being pa≈øt, Bajazet ≈øet 80000 to repair the mi≈øchief Con≈øtantinople had ≈øu≈øtained by the Earthquake, which they performed in four Months, Beautifying the City more then ever.

Bajazet had by his many Wives eight Sons, and ≈øix Daughters, who lived to be Men and Women grown, and the Sons all Governours in divers Provinces of his large Empire, whom the Turki≈øh Hi≈øtory after this manner reckons up, viz. Abdullah Zelebi, Alem Scach, Tzihan Scach, Achmet, Machmut, Corcut Selim, and Mahomet; yet as Antonius ∆≤trius, Genois, who long time lived in Bajazet's Court, accounts, they were only ≈øix, who≈øe Names he recites thus; Scieni≈øcia, Alem≈øcia, Achometes, Mahometes, Selymus, and Corcutus, and that the two former dyed long before their Father, and were by him greatly lamented; now as for Tizhan, and Abdula Zelebi, the Turks report they were put to Death by their Fathers Command, upon: Su≈øpition that they a≈øpired too high in Conceit of Empire.

Of all the≈øe Sons Mahometes was of greate≈øt hope who was by his Father made Governour of Magne≈øia, but being by rea≈øon of his Youth, ≈øomewhat Frolick≈øome, he often went di≈øgui≈øed, to take a view of his Brothers Courts, how therein they behaved them≈øelves &c. And at la≈øt came with two others in the habit o ‚Ä¢ Sea-faring men to the Court of Bajazet, where not at fir≈øt finding Admittance to the Emperors Pre≈øence they went and bought a fair Chri≈øtian Captive, and then pretending they had a Pre≈øent to deliver, were by the Warders permitted to enter, and having delivered the Pre≈øent found means to depart; being fir≈øt rewarded with three rich Garments, but e'r they were gotten on Ship-board, they were met by a Courtier that knew Mahometes, who allighting would have done him Reverence, but he forbad it, as not being willing to be di≈øcovered, yet it was not kept ≈øo clo≈øe but it came to Bajazet's Ear, who jealous (as always Tyrants are) that under ≈øuch like Intreagues might be hid ≈øome ≈øecret Con≈øpiracy again≈øt his Life, or Empire, he wrote to one A≈ømehemides a Courtier highly in Favour with Mahometes to poi≈øon him, ≈øending withal a poi≈øonous Powder to effect it; which this perfidious Courtier, in hopes to ≈øucceed him in his Government performed, but long it was not e'r the Tyrant repenting him of his inhumane and unnatural Command, ca≈øt the ≈øaid Courtier in Pri≈øon where he mi≈øerably peri≈øhed.

Bajazet having cau≈øed Mahometes to be poi≈øoned, whom he need not to have feared: Selymus the Governour of Trepezond, one whom he intirely Loved, immediately Con≈øpired again≈øt him, and having Corrupted mo≈øt of the great Ba≈ø≈øas of the Court, the better to ≈øtrengthen him≈øelf, married the Daughter of Mahometes the Tartarian King, who Aiding him with 15000 Tartarian Hor≈øe, he left his Government and pa≈ø≈øed over the Euxine into Europe, under pretence of invading
Hungary, where haivng notice that his Father intended to declare Achometes his Succe≈ø≈øor; leaving the Coa≈øt of Hungary, he marched directly towards Hadrianople, where Bajazet lay with his Army, and incamping within ≈øight of the City, ≈øent a feigned Me≈ø≈øage to excu≈øe his coming in a Ho≈øtile manner; the which was as he ≈øaid, only that he might gain Acce≈øs to his Pre≈øence, to ≈øhew him ≈øuch Rea≈øons as he doubted not but he would approve of, why Achometes ≈øhould not ≈øucceed him; but Bajazet not tru≈øting to his fawning, ≈øent him word that if he did not immediately return to his Government in A≈øia and disband his Army, he would not fail to cha≈øti≈øe him with the Scourge of War. But this Speech did not at all di≈ømay the Head-≈øtrong Youth, nor could all the Pre≈øents, and fair Words Bajazet could devi≈øe avert him; but rai≈øing his Camp marched directly towards Con≈øtantinople, which Bajazet perceiving drew his Army out of Hadrianople, and marched to prevent his ≈øurprizing the Imperial City, at who≈øe Departure out of Hadrianople Selymus entered it, and having there refre≈øhed his Army, followed hard upon his Father, cutting off the ≈øtraglers of his Army, and part of his Rear, which cau≈øed the Old man to Face about and bid him Battle, though all the Ba≈ø≈øas except Cher≈øeogles di≈ø≈øwaded him from it, as ≈øecretly favouring Selymus, which Selymus as willing to accept, after both Armies were put into Order, and Bajazet with a moving Oration had incouraged his Men, a cruel Fight began, which continued from Noon, till the ≈øetting of the Sun; at what time the Tartarian Hor≈øe ≈øore Gauled with the ≈øhot of the Harquebu≈ø≈øes, and terrified with the Thundering noi≈øe, di≈øranked and fled in ≈øpite of their Rider, after which the Foot being Charged by the Janizaries were mo≈øt of them ≈ølain, Selymus him≈øelf upon a ≈øwift Hor≈øe hardly ≈øcaping.
