In this Battle fought, Anno 1511. near Chiurlus, 30000 of Selymus his Men were ≈ølain and taken Pri≈øoners, with the lo≈øs only of 7000 of Bajazet's Soldiers, after which Bajazet kept on his way to Con≈øtantinople, where he no ≈øooner arrived, but he bountifully rewarded his Men: Achometes Bajazet's elde≈øt Son being at Ama≈øia, and hearing what had pa≈ø≈øed, rai≈øed an Army of 20000 Hor≈øe and Foot, and by ≈øpeedy marches came to Scutari, Antiently called Chri≈øtophorus, ≈øituate upon the Straights of Bo≈øphorus, over again≈øt Con≈øtantinople, where incamping he ≈øent Me≈ø≈øengers to his Father, reque≈øting him as he had frequently determined to declare him his Succe≈ø≈øor, as by Seniority he ought, and to re≈øign him the Empire, all which Bajazet intended to do, and propo≈øed ≈øuch his Intentions to his Captains; but they bribed by Selymus, oppo≈øed him therein, ≈øaying they would acknowledge no other Emperor but him≈øelf, and as the Captains ≈øaid, ≈øo ≈øaid the Soldiers: Whereupon he ≈øent to Achometes, to inform him of the Ob≈øtinacy of the Soldiers, and de≈øired him to return to his Government of Ama≈øa, till he could mold them into a better Temper by his Bounty; but he impatient of delay, not only abu≈øed the Me≈ø≈øenger, but greatly reproached his Father, ro≈øe with his Army and marching through the Country ≈øpoiled Bythinia, and growing daily more and more inflamed, from being barred of his Expectation, purpo≈øed to have ≈øeized upon A≈øia the le≈øs; upon which calling to him his two Sons, Amurath and Aladine young Princes of great hope, he admoni≈øhed them to take up Arms again≈øt their Grand-father, who prone enough thereto of them≈øelves, and now incited by their Father, in a ≈øhort time rai≈øed a great Army, and joyning with the ≈øtanding Forces; Achometes had before in pay over-run a great part of A≈øia, Achometes cau≈øing him≈øelf every where to be proclaimed King.

The≈øe proceedings greatly troubled Bajazet, in≈øomuch that to prevent Blood-≈øhed, he ≈øent to him his Amba≈ø≈øadors to reprove him for his Di≈øloyalty, and to command him forthwith to ≈øet at Liberty his Nephews Mahometes, and his Brother whom he had taken Pri≈øoners, for refu≈øing to aid him again≈øt their Grand-Father Bajazet; but in≈øtead of performing what his Father Commanded, he cau≈øed the chief Amba≈ø≈øador to be Slain in his pre≈øence, and ≈øtrictly enjoyned the other on Pain of their Lives, to depart his Camp 'ere Sun ≈øet, of which ≈øtrange and Heinous Fact, when Bajazet had knowledge, he was greatly inraged, and cau≈øed him to be proclaimed a Traytor again≈øt his Per≈øon, and Empire, commanding that the European Hor≈øe-men ≈øhould immediately march again≈øt him. But the Ba≈ø≈øas that favoured Selymus, thinking it now a fit time to procure his being called home, and entring again into Favour, in≈øinuated into the old Emperor, that if he de≈øigned to de≈øtroy both his Rebellious Sons, he could do it by no better means, then by calling home Selymus, and making him General of the Army de≈øigned, to march again≈øt Achometes, and that by ≈øuch means one of them was ≈øure to Peri≈øh, and then getting the other into his power, he might de≈øtroy him at his plea≈øure; to this motion of the Ba≈ø≈øas Bajazet hearkened, adn commanded that Selymus ≈øhould be fetched to Court, whither now Corcutus was come to claim his Fathers promi≈øe, as having heard that contrary thereto, he meant to give the Empire from him; to whom Bajazet again made many promi≈øes only willing him to be content, whil≈øt this new Rebellion was ≈øuppre≈ø≈øed, when in the mean while Selymus arrived, and pro≈øtrating him≈øelf at his Fathers Feet, was received into favour, and preferred to the leading of the Army; who no ≈øooner he d ‚Ä¢ d it, but as it was before contrived by the Ba≈ø≈øas, he
by the General Voice was ≈øaluted Emperor, and Mu≈øtapha Ba≈ø≈øa ≈øent to Bajazet peremptorily to demand him to ≈øurrender the Empire, to his Son Selymus, whom as he ≈øaid the Soldiers had ≈øaluted Emperor, and that if he refu≈øed ≈øo to do, they were re≈øolved to ≈øpoil the Pallace, if not commit an out-rage upon his Per≈øon, upon which Bajazet finding him≈øelf betrayed by tho≈øe he mo≈øt relyed on, after having expre≈ø≈øed Indignation and Grief, finding that would, or would he not all was one, with many cur≈øes and Execrations upon his unnatural Son, and the re≈øt of the Traytors he delivered the In≈øigns of Maje≈øty, of which unexpected news Corcutus having notice fled for his Life to Magne≈øia.

Selymus having by the means afore≈øaid Gra≈øped the Empire, could not ≈øuppo≈øe him≈øelf ≈øafe whil≈øt his Father lived, and therefore with great rewards tempted Hamon a Jew, and Bajazet's chief Phy≈øitian to make him away by Poy≈øon, who in order to his Helli≈øh purpo≈øe went to Hadrianople, whither Bajazet was retired, and there through Melancholy and infirmities incident to Age, he found him indi≈øpo≈øed; he offered him Phy≈øick, the which the old man not doubting to be of fatal Con≈øequence, when delivered by the Hand of his old approved Phy≈øitian, at the time appointed took, which he had not long done 'ere he felt a grievous pain in his Stomack, and plain Symptoms of his being Poy≈øoned appeared, ≈øo that amid≈øt Groans and Torturing Pangs, within 24 Hours he gave up the Gho≈øt, Anno 1512, and his Reign the thirtieth.

Bajazet thus Poy≈øoned, the Jew ha≈øted to Con≈øtantinople to receive his reward, which he had accordingly, for not long after his Arrival his Head was ≈øtricken off by the Commandment of Selymus, who afterward Buryed his Father in a mo≈øt ≈øtately Tomb, near to the Great Mahometan Temple, that
him≈øelf had built, and by Rea≈øon two of his Pages mourned for him, he cau≈øed them to be put to Death, but Heavens Vengeance was not long delayed, as will appear in the next Chapter, in his woful and unu≈øual Death.

div.head: CHAP. XIV. The Life of Selymus the fir≈øt of that Name, the third Emperor of the Turks, his Bloody Reign and woful Death.
div.p:
SElymus A≈øpiring to the Empire by Blood and Trea≈øon, could not think him≈øelf ≈øafe whil≈øt any of the Othoman Royal Blood remained in the Veins of his Relations; therefore gathering all his forces, he marched into A≈øia to oppre≈øs Achometes, but mi≈ø≈øing of him at that time, he thir≈øty of Blood cau≈øed 5 of his Nephews, all Princes of great hope to be ≈øtraugled in his pre≈øence, cau≈øing their dead Bodies to be Buryed in Pru≈øa, and afterward ≈øought to ≈øurpri≈øe Amurath and Aladin Mahometes 2 Sons, but they having notice of his wicked intent, one of them fled into Per≈øia, and the other into Egypt, and ∆≤≈øegi Ba≈ø≈øa who was ≈øent to apprehend them at Ama≈øa upon notice beforehand, ≈øent by Mu≈øtapha Ba≈ø≈øa who now was alienated from Selymus, was intrapped by an Ambu≈øh lay'd by Mahometes him≈øelf, taken Pri≈øoner, and mo≈øt of his men Slain, but it coming to Selymus his Ear, that Mu≈øtapha held Corre≈øpondence with Achometes, notwith≈øtanding he had helped him to the
Empire he cau≈øed him to be Slain, ≈øo little A≈ø≈øurance has any man in the favour of a Tyrant, who has the power of Life and Death in his Hand; in revenge of which Achometes put ∆≤≈øegi Ba≈ø≈øa (whom he held Pri≈øoner) to Death.

Selymus ≈øtill thir≈øty of Blood, with all ≈øpeed marched to Magne≈øia, in hopes to have ≈øurprized his Brother Corcutus in his Ca≈øtle, but he having timely notice was fled before his coming, yet he took the Spoil of all his Trea≈øure, and ≈øo leaving a Captain with a 1000 Hor≈øe to ≈øecure the City, and commanding Bo≈øtanges his Son In-Law, with a Fleet to watch the Sea-Coa≈øt that he ≈øhould not e≈øcape, he went to Pru≈øia ≈øuppo≈øing to have found him there, but on the contary he poor Prince was fain to hide him≈øelf in a Cave by the Sea-≈øide, and there for many Days feeding upon Crabs in hopes the Ships would have departed, that he might have wafted over, at length weary of his unwonted diet he ≈øent his Servant to a Shepherds Cottage to purcha≈øe natural Food, who ≈øu≈øpecting by ≈øome words that pa≈ø≈øed, that it was the Prince, like a perfidious Swain, he gave notice thereof to Co≈øhmos one of Selymus's his Captains who was come in≈øearch of him, upon which he was apprehended, and carryed towards Pru≈øa; of which the Tyrant having notice greatly rejoyced, and immediately ≈øent one Kirengi Og'ly a Squint-Ey'd Captain to ≈øtrangle him by the way, who accordingly performed his wicked Ma≈øters plea≈øure; and now none remaining alive to ob≈øtruct the progre≈øs of his greatne≈øs, but Achometes and his two Sons, he re≈øolved to go again≈øt them, but in the beginning of his Expedition, he intercepted ≈øome Letters ≈øigned by ≈øeveral Commanders of his Camp, and directed to Achometes, de≈øiring him to advance towards Selymus with all ≈øpeed, and that he might be a≈ø≈øured upon his approach, a great part of the Army
would revolt, or at lea≈øt in the Battle they would kill Selymus. Upon this di≈øcovery tho≈øe that were found to be concerned therein were Executed, and the Letters notwith≈øtanding ≈øent, upon which Achometes pre≈øuming made ≈øuch ha≈øt, that he left his Footmen behind, at what time 10000 Janizaries were come to Selymus out of Europe, ≈øo that Battle joyning after a mo≈øt Bloody conflict Achometes was overthrown, and ≈øeeking to ≈øave him≈øelf by flight, his Hor≈øe fell with him into a deep Ditch, where he was taken by the pur≈øuers, at who≈øe hands he could not procure him≈øelf to be Slain, tho he earne≈øtly de≈øired it, but was lead Captive to his cruel Brother, who Commanded the Squint-Ey'd Captain that had di≈øpatched Corcutus to ≈øtrangle him with a Bow-String, and now de≈øiring nothing more then to get in his po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion the two Sons of Achometes, who to his great Grief heard they were honourably received, the one in the Per≈øian, and the other in the Egyptian Courts, and that Amurath the Elder aided by Hy≈ømael the Great Sophy with ten thou≈øand Per≈øian-Hor≈øe, was entered into Cappadocia, wa≈øting the Country before him, for fear of whom mo≈øt of the adjacent Provinces had ≈øubmitted to do him homage, he re≈øolved after he had driven him back, in revenge of the aid the Sophy had lent him to War upon his Countries in Per≈øia, wherefore preparing a great Army, tho many of his great Commanders lay'd before him the difficulty and danger of the undertaking, and among≈øt the re≈øt Chendemus Vice-Roy of Natolia a man of great Experience, and of all others in greate≈øt Credit and Authority with Selymus, who u≈øed many Arguments to di≈ø≈øwade him therefrom, which he afterward found to be undeniable truths, but ≈øome of his Flatterers per≈øwading him that Chendemus was bribed by Amurath, to divert his Arms another way, and bring certain Ruffains hired
for that purpo≈øe to atte≈øt what they had ≈øaid, the Tyrant cau≈øed the faithful Ba≈ø≈øa to be ≈ølain, without hearing his Excu≈øe, and then Marching from Ar≈øenga, he came to the Confines of Armenia the Le≈øs, before who≈øe Powerful Army the young Prince fled, but Selymus fearing le≈øt the Mountain Kings not being made his friends, and yet left behind him, ≈øhould fall upon his Rear, ≈øent Amba≈ø≈øadors to them, to de≈øire free pa≈ø≈øage through their Territories, and to ≈øend him provi≈øion for his Money, at ≈øuch time as he ≈øhould be entered into Armenia the greater, to all which they accorded, whereupon with all his Army, he pa≈ø≈øed the Mountain Scodri≈øci, and after 8 days Marching over an other great Mountain, called Mo≈øchi ‚Ä¢ , which the famous River Euphrates with his mighty ≈øtreams, and huge broden Banks, ≈øeparateth from the great Mountain Anti-Taurus, and with perpetual ≈øteep ridges, runneth into Iberia, and Cholchis. Here Selymus with his En≈øigns di≈øplayed, Marching along the Banks of the River, departed not from the ≈øame, for fear in that hot Country he ≈øhould be di≈øtre≈ø≈øed for want of Water, and ≈øo held on his way directly Ea≈øtward, leaving the Country of Armenia the le≈øs, upon the Left, and the Kingdom of Aladeules on the right, and ≈øo along to the Banks of Araxes, finding all the Country before him de≈øtroyed, and by rea≈øon the Mountain Kings kept not their words, in ≈øending him provi≈øion, his Army began to fall into great want, which though too late made him call to mind the faithful Council of Chendemus, yet having Marched thus far, he could not without great di≈øhonour turn back, and therefore pa≈ø≈øing Arazes about the City of Coy, to defend which City ∆≤≈øta Ogli the Per≈øian General approached with his whole power, contrary to the expectation of Selymus, who≈øe Souldiers being oppre≈ø≈øed by want, and for the mo≈øt part were forced to live upon
wild fruit began to Mutinie, ≈øo that whil≈øt either Army lay Hovering at ≈øome di≈øtance, Hi≈ømael came in Per≈øon into his Camp, and from thence ≈øent a harauld to Selymus, to know why he had in ho≈øtile manner entered his Country, having no title thereto, as likewi≈øe to take a view of the Turki≈øh Army, to which demand Selymus replyed that his Grandfather, his Uncle, and him≈øelf had greatly Indamaged the Othoman Empire, by making ≈øeveral Inva≈øions, and Aiding the Rebels in the Reigns of Mahomet, Bajazet, and of late in his Reign, yet he e≈øteemed them not as ≈øufficient cau≈øes of War, but ≈øought after his enemy, young Amurath his Brothers Son, who had of late ≈øpoiled Cappadocia, whom if he would quietly and friendly deliver unto him, he would withdraw his forces, and peaceably return into his own Kingdom, otherwi≈øe with fire and Sword, he would de≈øtroy, not only the frontiers of Armenia, but the heart of Per≈øia al≈øo, and ≈øo di≈ømi≈ø≈øing the Herauld, both the Armies for that day lay ≈øtill in their trenches, expecting the dreadful event of Battle, and after both Armies were Mar≈øhalled and put in order, the Bloody Bla≈øt was ≈øounded, whereupon the Per≈øian Hor≈øemen came on with great fury, making great Havock of the Vaunt-guard of Selymus his Army, overthrowing the Alapi or common Souldiers by heaps, which are ≈øuch as the Turks for the mo≈øt part carry to ≈øtand the fir≈øt Shock of the Enemies fury, and to blunt their Swords, nor did the Turki≈øh Hor≈øe ≈øtand firm, but charged in either Wing gave ground, which Selymus ≈øeeing cau≈øed his orders to open, and began with his great Ordnances to play furiou≈øly, to avoid who≈øe Murthering ≈øhot, the Per≈øian Hor≈øemen, opened likewi≈øe to the right and the left, yet the thundering of the Cannon ≈øo amazed the Hor≈øes that many of them ca≈øt their Riders, yet Hy≈ømale with great fury broke and di≈øordered the Turks
right Wing, compo≈øed of A≈øian Hor≈øemen, but whil≈øt ∆≤≈øta Ogli was indeavouring to do the ≈øame to the left, he was ≈ølain with a harquibus ≈øhot, which much di≈ømayed the Soldiers under his command, yet could they not be forced to retire, till Selymus came on with all his Power of Janizaries, yet gaining little ground, whereupon he commanded all his great Ordnance which he had re≈øerved as his la≈øt refuge, to be furiou≈øly di≈øcharged again≈øt the right Wing of the Per≈øian Hor≈øe, where Hy≈ømael fought; by the violence of which ≈øuch a ≈ølaughter was made, as well of his own men as of the Enemies, mingled together, that what for the du≈øt, ≈ømoak, and thundering of the Artillery, having on both ≈øides lo≈øt their ≈øight and hearing, the Per≈øian hor≈øe were ≈øo terrified that they were not to be ruled, wherefore the battle ≈øoon became broken and di≈øordered, ≈øo that both Armies retired upon the Approach of night, leaving the Victory doubtful: The Turks to expre≈øs the terror of this day, number it among≈øt their di≈ømal ones, calling it the only day of Doom.

Hy≈ømael in this furious battle having received a wound under the left Shoulder, with a ≈ømall ≈øhot, by the per≈øwa≈øion of his friends withdrew him≈øelf, to have his wound ≈øearch'd, which pa≈øt doubt was the ≈øafeguard of Selymus and his Army; for the Per≈øians following their King, left the Victory almo≈øt gotten, but the Per≈øian finding his wound not mortal, was about to return, but hearing of the Death of ∆≤≈øta Ogli his General, a man of Great experience, and that by rea≈øon of the Thundering of the great Ordnance, his Hor≈øemen could not rule their Hor≈øes, he cau≈øed the retreat to be ≈øounded, and ≈øo retired in good order, the Turks ≈øo much di≈øpairing of Victory, that they dur≈øt not follow him; and ≈øo he pa≈ø≈øing by the City of Tauris, admoni≈øhed the Inhabitants to open their gates to Selymus, thereby to avoid being
≈øacked, and ≈øo Marched into the Confines of Media.

The Per≈øians out of ≈øight, the Turks then and not till then dur≈øt ≈øeize upon their Camp, where they found divers rich Pavilions, wrought with Needle-Work, and Gold, as al≈øo many beauteous Ladies, who had accompanied their Husbands to the Wars, all which he pre≈øently cau≈øed to be ≈øet at liberty, unle≈øs one of Hi≈ømaels Wives, whom he gave in Marriage to one of his Ba≈ø≈øas.

In this Battle fought in the Galderan Fields near the City of Coy, Anno 1514. Selymus lo≈øt 30000 of his men, and among≈øt them many Ba≈ø≈øas and great Commanders, even all the flower of his Army, which con≈øi≈øted of 300000 Hor≈øe and Foot, of the Per≈øians there fell not above 8000 Hy≈ømaels Army not con≈øi≈øting of above 30000, ≈øo that the Turks were 8 to 1; And among≈øt the ≈ølain, were found the Bodies of ≈øeveral Per≈øian Women, who Armed had accompanied their Husbands, to participate of their good or evil fortune, at which Selymus admiring, cau≈øed them to be Honourably interred, and then received the Emba≈ø≈øadors of the ≈øeveral adjacent Cities, who upon condition their Goods, Lives and Liberties, might be pre≈øerved, delivered up the Keys of their re≈øpective Cities, ≈øo that having taken po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion thereof, he called a Council of his Ba≈ø≈øas and great Captains, to con≈øult what was be≈øt to be done, him≈øelf being de≈øirous to Winter in Tauris, for oppo≈øing which Mu≈øtapha his chief Ba≈øsa, was by him di≈øgraced and thru≈øt from all his honours, of which the Janizaries having notice, began to Mutiny telling him to his face, they would not ≈øtay in that de≈øolate Country, where they had ≈øuffered ≈øuch hard≈øhip, daily to be expo≈øed to the fury of the Enemy, who was rai≈øing great forces to come down again≈øt them, and that if he would not in time depart,
they were re≈øolved to for≈øake him, whereupon he as needs mu≈øt, changed his former determination, re≈øolving to return into Cappadocia, whereupon contrary to his Promi≈øe, exacting a great Ma≈øs of Money from them of Taurus, and carrying with him 3000 families, the be≈øt Artificers in that City, e≈øpecially tho≈øe that were Skilfull in making Armour, he rai≈øed his Camp, and Marched towards Euphrates, a longer way then that by which he came, fearing to return again by the head of Araxis, and the Mountains of Periardes, le≈øt he ≈øhould meet the Iberian and Albanian Hor≈øemen, who as he was informed were following hard after him, who indeed came within ≈øight of him, as he was pa≈ø≈øing the Euphrates, which rai≈øed ≈øuch con≈øternation in his Camp, that in ha≈øtily pa≈ø≈øing the River, 2000 Turks were drowned, and a great many of his Ordnance, together with much Baggage left as a Prey to the Per≈øians, nor had he better Succe≈øs in pa≈ø≈øing the Huge Mountain Anti-Taurus, for the Mountain Kings de≈øpi≈øing him, by rea≈øon of his bad proceedings with their ≈øavage People, lay'd all the ways, and by frequently falling upon the Rear of his Army, killed many of his People and took great ≈øpoil, though the Kings upon his ≈øending to complain thereof, excu≈øed the matter, promi≈øing to puni≈øh the offenders ≈øo ≈øoon as they ≈øhould be known; At length pa≈ø≈øing the many dangers he came to Ama≈øa, where he wintered with his broken and crazed Army, re≈øolving to return the next ≈øpring with a far greater Power; the cau≈øe why Hi≈ømael being Lord of ≈øuch great Countries, came with ≈øo ≈ømall a Power, was for that he to win the Hearts of his People the better to be e≈øtabli≈øhed in his new acquired Kingdom, had remitted mo≈øt of the Taxes and Cu≈øtoms, formerly pay'd to his Prodece≈ø≈øors, all his forces con≈øi≈øting in the Souldiers of the Court, tho≈øe that were by right bound to ≈øerve him, and ≈øuch
as were ≈øent to him by the petty Princes his Neighbours, when as on the other ≈øide Selymus had always by him an Ine≈øtimable Ma≈øs of Money, kept in ≈øeven Towers in Con≈øtantinople; his yearly tributes and revenues exceeding his expences by a fourth part.

Selymus not thinking him≈øelf ≈øufficiently revenged of the Per≈øians, having rei≈øed his Camp at Ama≈øa, Early in the Spring, pa≈ø≈øing the Euphrates with his whole Army, con≈øi≈øting of 300000 Hor≈øe and Foot, came before Clama≈ø≈øum a City of the Per≈øians, ≈øituate on the further Banks, which he ≈øo ≈øuddenly inve≈øted, and ≈øo furiou≈øly a≈ø≈øaulted, that the Gates being broken up, and the Walls in many places won, the defendants retired into the Market-place, and there fought again≈øt the whole Power of Selymus to the la≈øt man; after the taking of this City, he took two Ca≈øtles not far di≈øtant from it, and being pricked forward with the de≈øire of Glory, purpo≈øed to have ≈øubdued the Kingdom of Per≈øia, which he might the ea≈øier have done, by rea≈øon Hy≈ømael was Waring again≈øt the Bactrians and Hyrcanians, a ≈øavage People dwelling near the Caspian Sea, who had Rebelled again≈øt him, but con≈øidering what damage he had received from Aladeules the Mountain King, and others inhabiting the De≈øolate Countries, at the entrance into Armenia, he purpo≈øed e're he further proceeded, to ≈øubdue him, wherefore he Marched thitherward with all his People, of which the poor Prince having notice, gathered all his ≈øtrength, and drawing his Hor≈øemen, who were but 15000 into a plea≈øant Valley, commanded his Footmen to keep the Mountains, and from thence with ≈øhot of Arrows annoy the Turks in pa≈ø≈øing the ≈øtraights, upon which Selymus con≈øidering the di≈øadvantage of the place, commanded Sinan Ba≈ø≈øa General of the European Hor≈øemen, to charge him with a ≈øquare Battle afront, whil≈øt him≈øelf with the Janizaries and
A≈øian Hor≈øemen, followed him in the Rear, the Ground by rea≈øon of its Scantine≈øs, not admitting the u≈øe of Wings, upon which a fierce fight was begun, and Atadeules fighting Courragiou≈øly at the head of his men, forced the Turki≈øh Hor≈øemen to give ground, which Selymus perceiving and that his Army was ≈øorely Annoy'd by the Archers from the Mountains, drawing out 2000 Harquibu≈øiers out of his own Squadorn, he ≈øent them to reinforce his Hor≈øe, and at the ≈øame time commanded the Janizaries to Mount the Hills, which they doing charged the Foot with ≈øuch Fury, that they being ≈øore di≈øtre≈ø≈øed with the Harquibus ≈øhot, not being u≈øed to ≈øuch engins ≈øcattered and fled, ≈øo that a great number of them were killed, e're they could clamber up the ≈øteep Mountains, and the Hor≈øe at that time being di≈øcomfited, fled by well known ways, into the fa≈øtne≈ø≈øes of the ≈øteep Rocks, after whom Selymus followed burning all before him, but finding he could not overtake the King, who retiring before him, had fortified him≈øelf among≈øt the Impregnible Rocks, and there ≈øtored up much provi≈øion, in hopes to weary the Turks with tedious delay.

Selymus having perfect notice of all that had pa≈ø≈øed, by ≈øeveral Pri≈øoners that he had taken, thought it more fit to prevent his falling into nece≈ø≈øity in ≈øo barren a Country, to u≈øe Stratagems, where force could not prevail, whereupon under≈øtanding that there was no good meaning between Aladeules, and Alis Beg his General, (by rea≈øon that the King had formerly commanded his Father to be ≈ølain, upon ≈øu≈øpicion he de≈øigned to ≈øeize his Kingdom) he relea≈øing the Pri≈øoners, ≈øent them to Alis Beg with great rewards, to incite him to deliver Aladeules into his hands, and that in Lieu thereof he of his bounty would give him the Kingdom, which ≈øo wrought with the treacherous General, that not finding means to kill the King, as he had purpo≈øed, he
cau≈øed all his Army to revolt to Sinan Ba≈ø≈øa, whom Selymus had ≈øent to pur≈øue him; ≈øo that being left alone, flying through many de≈øolate places, at length hid him≈øelf in a Cave, where being di≈øcovered by a Country Pea≈øant, he betrayed him into the Hands of tho≈øe that ≈øought after him, who pre≈øenting him to Selymus, he cau≈øed his Head to be ≈øtricken off, and carried all over A≈øia the le≈øs in manner of Triumph, and afterward ≈øent it to the Senate of Venice, in token of his Victory.

Selymus having ≈øubdued the Kingdom of Aladeules as afore≈øaid, and reduced it into the form of a Province, making the Traitor chief Governour thereof, returned to Constantinople, having, at the ≈øame time he was Waring again≈øt Aladeules by his Ba≈ø≈øas invaded Hungaria; and now having notice from his Corre≈øpondents in Christendom, that Maximillian the Emperor, ∆≤ladi≈ølaus King of Hungaria, Sigi≈ømond King of Poland together with the Princes of Germany, were entering into a League again≈øt him, it cau≈øed him to make great Preparations for the defence of his Territories, but in the end tho≈øe Princes ≈øeperated without doing any thing worthy of their meeting. So that being freed from that Fear, he left a ≈øtrong Guard upon the Fronteers of his Empire, bordering upon Hungaria, and departed to Iconium in Order, to pro≈øecute his War again≈øt the Per≈øian; but during his ≈øtay at that City, he had certain notice that Camp≈øon Gaurus Sultan of Egypt, with a great Army levied in Egypt and Judea, was coming to Aid the Per≈øian King, his Confederate as hating Selymus for his Cruelty towards his Father, Brethren and Nephews, as likewi≈øe being jealous of his a≈øpiring Greatne≈øs, this News was Confirmed on all Hands: Selymus greatly feared that if he ≈øhould pa≈øs over the River Euphrates, the Sultan might enter A≈øia and ≈øpoil his Dominions, wherefore he thought it ≈øafe
if po≈ø≈øible, to make him his Friend, in order to which he ≈øent the Cadele≈øcher, or great Doctor of the Mahomitan Law; A man much reverenced among≈øt the Turks, and Jachis one of his great Captains, as his Amba≈ø≈øadors to de≈øire the renewing the League, ≈øometime made between the Sultan and his Father Bajazet; but the Sultan moved by the pittious Complaints of the Princes, Aladine Son to Mahomet, and the Son of Aladeules, who as exiled Princes remained in his Court, and incouraged by his great Captains to re≈øtore them to their rightful Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øions, would have no Peace unle≈øs Selymus would leave off to invade the Per≈øian, and re≈øtore the Mountainous Kingdom to the young Aladeules; which upon the Report thereof ≈øo inraged Sebymus, that he re≈øolved to lay a≈øide his intended War again≈øt Hy≈ømale, and turn all his Forces upon the Sultan, and therefore with words of incouragement, having animated his Soldiers, he pa≈ø≈øed with his Army over the Mountains in three places, and ≈øo appointing a great Company of the Common Soldiers and Country people, for the opening of the ≈øtraight Pa≈ø≈øages; he Commanded the rough and uneven ways to be made ≈ømooth and plain, ≈øo that in five Days all his Ordnance and Carriages were come into the Plains of Comagena, where he received News of Camp≈øon's Army, from Alis Beg Governour of the Mountain Kingom, which cau≈øed him to march towards him with all ≈øpeed.

By this time Camp≈øon having notice of the approach (whom he could not at fir≈øt believe to have pa≈ø≈øed the huge Mountain of Amanus) ≈øtood long in doubt what was be≈øt to be done, whether to give the Tyrant Battle, or to retire to Dama≈øco and protract the War, whil≈øt fre≈øh Forces could come to his A≈ø≈øi≈øtance: In the latter Opinion Gazelles his great Coun≈øellor, and Governour of Apamia Concurred with him, labouring earne≈øtly to confirm him in that Opinion,
but De≈øtiny ≈øo ordering it, he refu≈øed the good and whol≈øome Per≈øwa≈øions of Gazelles, and imbraced that of Cayerbeius, which was pre≈øently to give the Turks Battle; which Council he gave though he knew it to be De≈øtructive, that by ≈øuch means he might be revenged on the Sultan; who ≈øome years before had cau≈øed his Brother to be poi≈øoned, for de≈øigning to deprive him of his Empire.

Battle being re≈øolved on, and the Turks Army coming on Camp≈øon divided his Army into four Battles; the fir≈øt whereof he committed to Cayerbeius the Traitor, the ≈øecond to Sybeius the Governour of Dama≈øco, a man of ≈øingular Faith and Valour; the≈øe two were appointed at once to Charge both Wings of the Turki≈øh Army, the third was lead by Gazelles, and the la≈øt by Camp≈øon him≈øelf, who ≈øtayed with it for the defence of the Camp: Nor was Selymus Idle, for he had placed the A≈øian Hor≈øemen in the right Wing, and the European in the left, and in the middle the Janizaries, and Artillery before, whom between the two Wings, he had placed his Pentioners all mo≈øt expert, and valiant Soldiers, and in this Order the Turks always fight, if the Ground will admit ≈øo to Mar≈øhall the Army.

Both Armies being thus ≈øet in Order, the Charge was ≈øounded; whereupon Cayerbeius with his Squadron Charged the European Hor≈øemen with great Fury, but re≈øolving to betray his tru≈øt by and by, Wheeling off fell upon the Sullians and ≈øuch other Slaves as kept the Baggage, making ≈øome ≈ømall ≈ølaughter, that as a Valiant and cunning Traitor, he might at the ≈øelf ≈øame time ≈øatisfie the Expectation of his Valour, and of his Trea≈øon; but Sybeius the Governour of Dama≈øco dealt otherwi≈øe, for entering over-thwart the Ranks in the right Wing of the Turks Army; he with his Mamalukes Charged with ≈øuch fury,
that having made great ≈ølaughter of the A≈øian Hor≈øemen, they broak in among≈øt them like a devouring Tempe≈øt, bearing down all before them, till they came to the In≈øigns in the mid≈øt of the Wing: Neither could Mu≈øtapha the Beglerbeg, nor Imbrahor Ba≈ø≈øa with all their Forces with≈øtand him; or re≈øtrain the Flight of their Soldiers, ≈øo that cutting in pieces the right Wing, he re≈øolutely thru≈øt in between the Battle of the Janizaries and the Pentioners, and there made ≈øuch lamentable Slaughter that the whole Army was in great fear for Selymus, by the breaking in of Sybeius, was divided from his Footmen, in whom he repo≈øed his greate≈øt tru≈øt, and now the Janizaries hardly charged by Gazelles ‚Ä¢ ; who following the Fortune of Sybeius, had ≈øet upon the Front of the Enemies Battle, the A≈øian Hor≈øemen al≈øo put to the wor≈øt, found no means how again to re≈øtore the di≈øordered Battle.

In this Confu≈øion Sinan Ba≈ø≈øa came in with the Squadron of Hor≈øe, under his Command, who had been but lightly Skirmi≈øhed with by Cayerbeius, he ≈øtayed the Fury of the Mamalukes; whereby the Turks taking fre≈øh Courage, ≈øoon after wrung the Victory out of their Hands; for the great Artillery being by the Commandment of Selymus di≈øcharged among≈øt them, by the terrible Thundering thereof, their Hor≈øes were ≈øo troubled that they could not well guide them, neither could their Riders them≈øelves though they were men of undaunted Courage prevaile, being on every ≈øide oppre≈ø≈øed with the multitude of their Enemies; yet in that di≈øa≈øter nothing di≈ømayed, ≈øetting them≈øelves clo≈øe together, they brake through the mid≈øt of their Enemies, with great ≈ølaughter of the European Hor≈øemen and Pentioners, and ≈øo with ≈øpeed fled towards the Camp and City of Aleppo; after whom followed Sinan Ba≈ø≈øa with the ≈øwifte≈øt Hor≈øe, ≈øo that the News of the overthrow being known to Comp≈øon the
Sultan, he indeavoured what he could to ≈øtay the flight of his Men, but the pre≈øs being great, and the Turks pur≈øuing hard after them making great ≈ølaughter, every one ≈øhifting for him≈øelf in that general Calamity without Re≈øpect to the Sultan, he was overborn in the Pre≈øs, and there by rea≈øon of the weight of his Armour and great Age, not able to relieve him≈øelf was troden to Death; who after wards being found among≈øt the ≈ølain, was laid to the view of all People, that they might not flatter them≈øelves with his being alive, and ≈øo on his behalf fight more ob≈øtinately for the future.

This great Battle co≈øt Selymus 30000 men, and the Egyptians few le≈øs, among≈øt which there fell 1000 Mamalukes, and was fought on the ≈øeventeenth of Augu≈øt, Anno 1516. After which Selymus received the City of Aleppo into his obedience, the Mamalukes being departed thence to Dama≈øco; after whom he likewi≈øe ≈øent Jonu≈øes Ba≈ø≈øa and followed him≈øelf with all the Army, but before his Arrival they were departed to Cair, and in a full A≈ø≈øembly cho≈øe Tomombeius (a Circa≈ø≈øian born) Sultan in the ≈øtead of Camp≈øon Gaurus, who took ≈øpeedy Care for providing all things nece≈ø≈øary to defend his Countries from the Power of the Turks, mu≈øtering great Companies of ≈øuch, of his Slaves, as he thought fit for the War, as likewi≈øe ≈øeveral Moors and Arabians. His Neighbours hiering certian Per≈øons for great Rewards, to Travel through the Arrabian De≈øerts into Me≈øopotamia, and ≈øo to Hy≈ømale the Per≈øian King with the Letters, earne≈øtly reque≈øting him to invade the Turks Dominions in A≈øia the le≈øs, or with all ≈øpeed to break into Comagena, and ≈øo to inclo≈øe Selymus with both Armies as he lay in the Borders of Judea, and by that means greatly de≈øtre≈øs him, by rea≈øon he had no Fleet at Sea to relieve him with Provi≈øion; and by that means might revenge him≈øelf, and prevent his Territories from Inva≈øion for the future.

Whil≈øt the≈øe things was doing, Sinan Ba≈ø≈øa with con≈øiderable Forces pa≈ø≈øing through part of Arabia, ≈øeized upon the City of Gaza; of which Gazelles having notice po≈øted thither with 6000 Mamalukes, and a con≈øiderable number of Arabian Adventurers, thinking to ≈øurprize the Ba≈ø≈øa; but he having notice of his approach, went to meet him with all his Forces: So that both Armies incountering, the Egyptians after a Bloody fight, being over-powred by numbers, and ≈øore Gauled with Harqucbu≈øs Shot, left the fight and fled towards Cair; but whil≈øt the Turks were departed on this Expedition, the Citizens of Gaza had plundered their Camp, ≈øuppo≈øing them to be retired for Fear, and di≈øcomfited 2000 Turki≈øh Hor≈øes, ≈øent by Selymus to the Aid of Sinan Ba≈ø≈øa, who retreating were almo≈øt ≈ølain by the wild Arabs, and had certainly all peri≈øhed, had they not fortunately met with Juleb Governour of Achaia, ≈øent with another Power; yet the Arabians flocking about them, greatly annoyed them with their Shot from the Hills, not giving them any time to re≈øt; and ≈øuch through weakne≈øs, or for to ≈øeek Provi≈øion ≈øtragled from the Army, and were cut off; ≈øo that had not Imbrahor Ba≈ø≈øa met them out of Syria, they had never pa≈ø≈øed alive through tho≈øe De≈øarts, for the Arabians as men living upon ≈øpoil ≈øtill pur≈øued them, and in a di≈øper≈øed manner were continually hovering over their Army, yet long they had not marched e'r they met with Selymus, who with the remainder of his Army was marching towards Gaza, when having notice from tho≈øe that had been put to flight by the Citizens thereof, what had befell them; he verily believed that Sinan Ba≈ø≈øa and all his men were either ≈ølain or taken Pri≈øoners, till ≈øuch time as he was by the Syrian Scouts informed to the contrary, at which he not a little rejoyced, yet the Arabians daily mole≈øted his Army: In≈øomuch
that he was inforced to place his Harquebu≈øiers, and mo≈øt of his Artillery in the Rear, with order to Charge them as they ≈øaw occa≈øion; and ≈øo in that Order he marched till he came to Jeru≈øalem, which was then altogether ruinated and defaced, from whence after having viewed the holy Sepulcher, kept by a Company of poor, yet devout Chri≈øtians, who payed Tribute for that priviledge to the Sultan of Egypt, and having made his offering, and ≈øome miles di≈øtant met with Sinan Ba≈ø≈øa, who having put to Death the Authors of the revolt of that City, and Exacted a great ≈øum of Money of the re≈øt, came forth to meet him, whom he bountifully rewarded, giving to the Captains Garments of Silk, and to the re≈øt rewards, according to their Demerits.

After he had refre≈øhed his Army at Gaza, for the ≈øpace of four days, he leaving a Garri≈øon therein pa≈ø≈øed over the Dangerous, De≈øolate, and unpeopled Sands; which at many times moved by the Wind, worked like a rough Sea, and ri≈øing in the Air, hindred the ≈øight of the weary Pa≈ø≈øingers; but ≈øuch was the good fortune of Selymus, that a little before he entered them, ≈øuch ≈øtore of Rain fell that it not only allayed the Sand, but furni≈øhed his Army with Water during his pa≈ø≈øage, which took up eight days, yet was he frequently a≈ø≈øaulted by the Arabians.

The De≈øerts pa≈ø≈øed as afore≈øaid, the Turki≈øh Army drew near unto Cair to receive, or rather intrap which Tomombeius the new Sultan, near to a Village called Rhodania had intrenched his Camp with deep Ditches filled with Water, over which he had laid rotten Hurdles, and upon them Earth, and lined all the Banks with Artillery, not doubting but Selymus would march that way; but this their Device, which would certainly have gained them a Victory had it took, was upon the approach of the Turki≈øh Army di≈øcovered to
Selymus, by four Epirot Mamalukes, who ≈øecretly Envying the ≈øudden Advancement of Tomombeius, had in the Night time withdrawn them≈øelves from his Camp: Upon which Selymus altered his determined Cour≈øes, and marching by by-ways ≈øuddenly appeared with his Army, drawn up in Battalia in the Rear of the Egyptian Camp, which put them into a great Con≈øternation, but ≈øeeing no Remedy but pre≈øently to ingage, the Sultan put his Army in readine≈øs, and after the Charge ≈øounded furiou≈øly with his great Ordnance, ≈øpoke his indignation, and was an≈øwered in the ≈øame Language from Selymus his Camp; but after the ≈øecond di≈øcharge of each particular tire, the Armies joyned Charging each other with ≈øuch Force, that all the Ground lay covered with the ≈ølain, the Mamalukes inraged with mortal Hatred, bearing down all before them, when in the mean time the Arrabians incompa≈ø≈øed the Turks Battle, putting the Thracian, Macedonian, and Epirot Hor≈øemen to the flight, the which Sinan Ba≈ø≈øa perceiving came in with his Squadron of Hor≈øe, to ≈øtay the wavering Battle, but being overcharged by Gazelles and Bidon he was ≈ølain, and his men di≈øordered: So that had not Selymus him≈øelf advanced with his ≈øure≈øt ≈øtrength of the Janizary, the Victory had fallen to the Sultan; but with them re≈øtoring the Battle, and the Mamalukes being tired with continual Fighting, at the approach of Night Tomombeius finding his men to be wor≈øted, cau≈øed the retreat to be ≈øounded, and retired towards Cair, leaving his Camp to the Turks.

In this Battle, fought on the 24. of January 1517. Were ≈ølain many Thou≈øands on both ≈øides, and the Turks had certainly been wor≈øted, had it not been for the invincible Courage of the Janizaries. The Turks in pur≈øuit, having taken the Diadare, a man of great Command among≈øt the Egyptians, and Bidon the valiant Captain, whom Selymus unworthily cau≈øed to be ≈ølain in revenge of the Sinan Ba≈ø≈øa.

Tomombeius a man of a warlike Spirit, nothing di≈øcouraged at what had happened; but rather more re≈øolute to revenge his di≈øgrace, gathered his Power from all parts, and incamped Commodiou≈øly between the City of Cair, and the River Nilus, and there con≈øulted, how he might by ≈øtratagem mo≈øt conveniently ≈øet upon the Turks Camp; e'r they under≈øtood what Power he had, not thinking it ≈øafe ≈øo ≈øuddenly to try another Field: But whil≈øt he was thus plotting all his devices were di≈øcovered to Selymus, as they had been before by ≈øeveral Mamalukes, who now beginning to have his fortune in Contempt revolted from him: In≈øomuch that to prevent the firing of his Camp as was intended. Selymus cau≈øed ≈øtrict Watches to be kept, and great Fires to be made, that ≈øo he might di≈øcover the Enemies approaches by night; which the Sultan perceiving by the advice of his great Commanders, retired into the City of Caire, there to expect the approach of the Conqueror, furni≈øhing it with all manner of Warlike provi≈øion, and inciteing the Egyptians, who ≈øtood all this while Newters to take up Arms, in the defence of their Country, which the more wealthy whillingly did, but the poorer ≈øort, who in all Nations ever gape after change of Government, thinking to advantage them≈øelves thereby; yet ≈øuch were the per≈øwa≈øions of the Mamalukes, that in the end mo≈øt of the Citizens re≈øolved upon the defence of that great City, towards which Selymus was advancing a pace, wherefore Tomombeius cau≈øed Trenches to be drawn Cro≈øs the Streets, at the bottom of which were fixed ≈øharp Stakes, and before them, Tin being overlaid with rotten Hurdles, ≈øo to intrap the too eager Turks, for why, the City had no Walls but ≈øituate upon the River Nilus, was adorned with many ≈øtately Towers, Piramides, Pallaces, Temples, and Monuments of the
Egyptian Kings, ≈øerved rather for Plea≈øure then ≈øtrength: He likewi≈øe cau≈øed the Hou≈øes to be furni≈øhed with Harquebu≈øiers, and his Pieces of Culvering, and other ≈ømall Pieces, to be every where planted Advantagiou≈øly for the annoying the Enemy, and in the great Street drew up his greate≈øt ≈øtrength, con≈øi≈øting of Mamalukes; yet Selymus being now come before it, after his having incouraged his Soldiers to undertake the ≈øubduing of that great City, as the la≈øt Refuge of the Sultan, he furiou≈øly entered the Gate called Ba≈øuela, and at one in≈øtant thru≈øt in his Hor≈øemen at divers Caves, but kept his Janizaries in the high Street, where the greate≈øt Power of the Mamalukes were: Whereupon a dreadful Fight was begun on all parts, in≈øomuch that the Channels run Blood like ≈øo many Torrents; the Artillery and ≈ømall Shot ≈øtill thundering from either ≈øide, made all ≈øeem Fire, and covered the tops of the Hou≈øes with Clouds of ≈ømoke; when from their Windows, and Roof of their Hou≈øes, the Egyptians ca≈øt down Stones, Tiles, ≈øcalding Water, Sulphur, Pitch, Tar, and the like, to the great annoyance of the Turks, who ≈øtill pre≈ø≈øing forward many of them fell into the Covert Trenches, and were there impailed on the Stakes; and ≈øuch was the Clamour and Outcries of the enemy, where together with the Cla≈øhing of Weapons, and dreadful Fires, that it ≈øeemed as if the de≈øolation of all things was come, and in this di≈ømal manner continued the Fight for the ≈øpace of two Days, and two Nights, without intermi≈ø≈øion: In≈øomuch that Selymus finding what ob≈øtinate Enemies he had to deal with, began to de≈øpair of winning the City, and therefore was about to ≈øound the Retreat, as his fainting Soldiers mo≈øt earne≈øtly de≈øired, at what time he had News that Mu≈øtapha Ba≈ø≈øa had by the Conduct of ≈øome Fugitive Mamalukes, entered the City on the other ≈øide, and had taken the Mamalukes
Hor≈øes, which they had left there ready Sadled, thereon to make their e≈øcapes, if matters came to the Extremity, which not only Animated the Turks, but di≈ømayed the Mamalukes, who expected no ≈øuch Matter: So that the Fight were renewed on the third day, continuing Bloody and doubtful till the Evening, at what time mo≈øt of the Egyptians were very de≈øirous to be rid of their in≈øolent Lords; the Mamalukes revolted to the Turks, which the Mamalukes perceiving, and that by Rea≈øon of the great number of Turks, that were ≈øent to ≈øtop the Gaps that Death had made, they were no longer able to re≈øi≈øt their Fury, they betook them≈øelves to flight, mo≈øt part of them ha≈øting to the River Nilus with Tomombeius (who in that Battle had all in vain proved the utmo≈øt of his Prowe≈øs and Policy) being Tran≈øported over it in Boats fled to Sege≈øta, others of them fled into the Hou≈øes of the Egyptians, and into Caves, and Vaults in the City to hide them≈øelves. A thou≈øand five hundred of the better ≈øort, betook them to the Temple of their pretended Prophet, where after an ob≈øtinate and tedious defence, being di≈øabled by Wearine≈øs, Thir≈øt, and lo≈øs of Blood; they ≈øurrendered them≈øelves upon Di≈øeretion, part of whom the furious Soldiers ≈ølew in the Porch of the ≈øaid Temple, and the re≈øt within a few days after, being ≈øent down the River to Alexendria, were there contrary to the Promi≈øe of Selymus put to Death.

This great City ≈øubdued after the manner afore≈øaid, Selymus Commanded a part of his Army to extingui≈øh the Fire, which raged vehemently in many places, which done he exhibited a Proclamation, that all the Mamalukes, who within twelve hours would furrender them≈øelves ≈øhould have pardon of Life; upon which many came forth of their ≈øecret places, and that who≈øoever of the Egyptians ≈øhould conceal any
one of them longer then the time ≈øpecified, he threatned to impail them alive on Stakes, and having ≈øold their Wives and Children, to burn their Hou≈øes; which dreadful menace on the one ≈øide, and hopes of Reward, which was al≈øo Promi≈øed on the other, cau≈øed many of the Egyptians contrary to their Promi≈øes to their old Lords, the Mamalukes to deliver ≈øome of them up to the Tyrany of Selymus, who cau≈øed them to be put to Death; but ≈øome of the Egyptians impeached by their malicious Neighbours, cho≈øe rather to ≈øuffer Death, then to prove perfidious in breaking the ≈øolemn Prote≈øtations they had made to their Lords: Nor did the Victorious Turks ≈øpare, though contrary to Selymus his Promi≈øe to rifle the Hou≈øes of the Egyptians, Murther many of them, and defloure their Daughters, and ravi≈øh their Wives even in their Pre≈øence, and to u≈øe all other Cruelties incident to ≈øo great and populous a City, upon the entry of an Hunger-≈øtarved Army greedy of prey.

At the taking of Cair Gazales, the great and Valiant Captain of the Mamalukes was not pre≈øent, but ≈øent by Tomombeius to rai≈øe an Army in Arabia, who upon his return finding all lo≈øt, and that the Sultan was fled he knew not where, not thinking it Convenient to hazard a Battle again≈øt him, whom Fortune ≈øo highly favoured; he came to Selymus upon his Faith before given, for the ≈øafety of him≈øelf and his Followers, which were three Arrabian Captains, and a number of good Hor≈øemen, and being admitted to his Pre≈øence boldly declared, that ≈øince Fortune had made him her Darling, and that he by her aid, rather Conquered the Mamalukes, then by any Force; and that ≈øince Tomombeins was fled, who≈øe part as long as his Kingly Authority and Maje≈øty remained, he had faithfully ≈øerved, he and the re≈øt were at his Devotion; if he ≈øo plea≈øed to ≈øerve him with their Lifes and Fortunes,
of which offer Selymus joyfully accepted, highly Commending Gazeles both for his Virtue and Valour, which for the mo≈øt part gains Credit among≈øt the roughe≈øt Enemies, and not long after ≈øending him to ≈øuppre≈øs the Moors and Arabs, that made Incur≈øions into the Country about Cair; he ≈øuddenly overthrew them, and e'r he was expected returned with Victory.

Tomombeius being in the Country of Sege≈øta, whil≈øt Selymus was ≈øetling his matters at Cair, rai≈øed a con≈øiderable Army, and the rather for that he had frequent advice from the Carians, that if he would come ≈øuddenly upon the Turks, they would rai≈øe ≈øuch a Tumult that he ≈øhould not only recover the City, but de≈øtroy the Army who were but few in number, and mo≈øt of tho≈øe weak through their Wounds and Sickne≈øs, but e'r he could put this De≈øign in Practice, one Albuchomar a man of great Wealth and Authority in the Country of Sege≈øta, di≈øcovered the de≈øign to Selymus; who cau≈øed all ≈øuch Citizens as he ≈øu≈øpected to be ≈øhut up in the Ca≈øtle, and continually guarded the Streets, placing along the River Boats, and Men and Artillery to keep the Enemy from repa≈ø≈øing it, and not well a≈ø≈øured to hold what he had got, from ≈øuch de≈øperate and re≈øolute Enemies as were the Mamalukes; of whom a great Power were again re≈øorted to Tomombeius, he re≈øolved to ≈øend Amba≈ø≈øadors to him, to advi≈øe him to ≈øubmit, and in yielding to his Clemency he would provide for him in ≈øome other part of his Dominions, but e'r the Amba≈ø≈øadors came to his Camp, they were way-laid by certain Mamalukes, who had vowed no Peace with the Turks, and without re≈øpect to their Character ≈øhamefully murthered them, upon notice of which Selymus who was of a hot fiery Nature, was ≈øo inraged that he could ≈øcarcely contain him≈øelf: And thereupon Commanded a ≈øtrong Bridge made of Boats
and Planks, to be laid over Nilus, re≈øolving to revenge the affront done to his Maje≈øty, the which once fini≈øhed he drew the greate≈øt part of his Army out of Cair, (leaving only ≈øo many as might keep the City from revolting) with an intent to pa≈øs into the Country of Sega≈øta, to wa≈øt it with Fire and Sword; of which Tomombeius having knowledge, by ≈øpeedy marches came to the Bridge at what time the A≈øian Hor≈øemen were pa≈ø≈øed over, and ≈øetting furiou≈øly upon them e'r they had well put them≈øelves in Order, making great ≈ølaughter of ≈øuch as re≈øi≈øted: In≈øomuch that many to avoid the Swords of their Enemies by leaping into the River were there drowned, others in pa≈ø≈øing the Bridge were thru≈øt be≈øide and mi≈øerably peri≈øhed in the Water. Nor could Mu≈øtapha Ba≈ø≈øa with all his Courage re≈øi≈øt the Fury of the Mamalukes, all the Turks being filled with Fear and Con≈øternation, as well on the hither as the further Bank; the Artillery was for a while rendered u≈øele≈øs, by rea≈øon that if it had been di≈øcharged, it mu≈øt have been again≈øt the Turks onely, who in fearful Troops covered the further Bank, calling for Help to tho≈øe on the other ≈øide; Selymus ≈øeeing in what ≈øtate A≈ø≈øairs ≈øtood, cau≈øed all his Boats to be brought, and filling them with Janizaries pa≈ø≈øed them over, who Ranging in good order ≈øtayed the Fury of the Mamalukes; when as Carrgolis Son to the Tartar King, and Brother-in-Law to Selymus, with his Hor≈øemen took the Water and Swom over with little lo≈øs: So that now the Battle went hard on all ≈øides, and ≈øtrongly did the Mamalukes pre≈øs on to gain the Head of the Bridg; the which they had done by Cutting the Cables that fa≈øtened it, they had ≈øet it afloat down the River, and de≈øtroyed that part of the Army, with whom they were ingaged, e'r they could have been relieved by their Fellows; which Mu≈øtapha perceiving, had drawn to that place both
his In≈øigns, and his mo≈øt experienced Soldiers, ≈øo that the Fight was for a long time maintianed Bloody and doubtful, but the Turks ≈øtill coming over in great abundance, true Valour was obliged to give place to Multitudes; for the Mamalukes who had done all that men could do, betook them≈øelves to Flight; after whom the Tartarian Hor≈øemen followed with great Slaughter, as likewi≈øe did Mu≈øtapha Gazeles, and Cayrebeius, Selymus being de≈øirous of nothing more then that Tomombeius might fall into his Hands, which at length fell out according to his wi≈øh; for, the next Day he was overtaken, when making head with his ≈ølender Train, he Fought right valiantly, but at length overcome he again fled, yet ≈øo ≈øtrict was Selymus his command, that the great Captains ≈øtill pur≈øued him, denouncing all manner of Torture to the poor Villagers, if they did not ≈øo watch the pa≈ø≈øages of the great Mar≈øh, whereinto he was entered, that he ≈øhould by no means e≈øcape; whereupon on the third day finding him≈øelf hard be≈øet on every≈øide, he willingly gave his followers leave to for≈øake him, and laying a≈øide his In≈øigns of Royalty hid him≈øelf among≈øt the Flags and Bu≈øhes, ≈øtanding up to the Neck in Water, where being found by the Country Pea≈øants, he was drawn thence and delivered to the Ba≈ø≈øa Mu≈øtapha, who brought him together with ≈øeveral of his Captains to Cair, where Selymus re≈øolving before hand to put him to Death, thereby to appea≈øe the Gho≈øts of his ≈ølain Amba≈ø≈øadors would not admit him to his pre≈øence, but commanded him to be delivered to the Tormentors, that with exqui≈øite torments they might make him reveal the Trea≈øure of Camp≈øon Gourus, ≈øuppo≈øed by him to have been hid, all which he indured with a manly courage and ≈øtern Countenance, uttering nothing unbe≈øeeming his Character, after which he in tattered Garments with his Hands bound behind him, being ≈øet upon a lean
Ill-favoured Camel, was in divi≈øion carryed through all the Publick places of the City to be Gazed at as a Spectacle of Mi≈øery, by tho≈øe who not a Month before had honoured with profound Reverence, as their great & mighty King, now by the hand of Fortune thrown from the top fo all worldly honour, into the Aby≈øs of extreame≈øt Mi≈øery, and in this manner the in≈øulting Turks having brought him to the chief Gate of the City, extended their cruelty yet farther by ≈øtrangling him with a Rope, and that he might be the better ≈øeen of all that pa≈ø≈øed by, Hanged him upon a hook under the Gate; nor did any of the Princes of the Mamalukes who fell into the Turks Hands fare otherwi≈øe.

The Terror of Selymus his man Victories now ≈øpreading wide, all the Cities of Egypt ≈øubmitted to the Conquerour, no place between the River Nilus, and the Borders of India and Arabia, that were either Tributaries or Confederates to or with the Sultan, but ≈øent their Amba≈ø≈øadors with Pre≈øents to Selymus, promi≈øing to continue the ≈øame with him, as they have done with the Sultans, only the wild Arabians ≈øtood at defiance till ≈øuch time as with large Gifts he had won many of their great Captains to bring their People over to his obedience; at what time Amyra≈øes ≈øubmitted him≈øelf, and delivered into his po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion the Egyptian Fleet, built to oppo≈øe the Portugi≈øe Trade in the Indias, and ≈øo Swimming in the currant of Fortunes favour, he extended his Dominions as far as the confines of the Great King of Aethiopia called Pre≈øter-John, and thus having reduced all to his obedience, he came down the River Nilus in his Gally to Alexandria, and having well reviewed it, returned again to Cair, from whence he commanded 500 Families of the Wealthier ≈øort of the Egyptians to be removed to Con≈øtantinople, for the Tran≈øportation of which Ve≈ø≈øels were purpo≈øely prepared; as al≈øo a great number of Women and Children
of the Race of the Mamalukes, thereby to prevent future troubles, and then ≈øtaying a while to ob≈øerve the overflowing of Nilus, from which the Egyptians Progno≈øticate a happy or unhappy Sea≈øon, as it ri≈øes little or much, he re≈øolved to depart for Syria, having made Cayrebius the Traytor Governour of Cair, and his great Lieutenant of Egypt, which he had reduced into a Province, whereat Jonu≈øes the Great Ba≈ø≈øa greatly envying, as ≈øuppo≈øing him≈øelf greatly wronged by Selymus, whom he had faithfuly ≈øerved in all his Wars, in heaping upon a Traytor the honour which he greedily expected by opening his mind therein, and refu≈øing to deliver the Large≈ø≈øes appointed for the Soldiers thereby to render his Competior odious, he fell ≈øo far into the Emperors di≈øplea≈øure, that notwith≈øtanding all the excu≈øe he made in defence of him≈øelf, he cau≈øed him to be Strangled even in his pre≈øence, thereby to deter others from daring to pre≈øcribe him what he ≈øhould Act, or on whom he ≈øhould be≈øtow his favours, yet was the fall of this great Ba≈ø≈øa worthily Lamented of the Souldiers, who ≈øpared not to tell the Tyrant to his Face of his many Barbarous Cruelties, repeating all the Inhumane Murthers he had cau≈øed to be committed, but others again remembring how this Ba≈ø≈øa had during his being in favour with Selymus, cau≈øele≈øly Stabed his Fair and Virtuous Wife Manto, upon a jealous, tho fal≈øe and Groundle≈øs Su≈øpicion of her Incon≈øtancy, ≈øaid it was a Judgement of God upon him for that Barbarous and unnatural Crime.

Selymus having left Egypt, and arrived in Syria, received Letters from Himbracor the Great Ma≈øter of his Hor≈øe, whom he had left upon the Frontiers to attend the motions of the Per≈øians, certifying him that Hi≈ømael's great preparations were dwindled into nothing by rea≈øon that mo≈øt of his forces con≈øi≈øting of Voluntary Gentlemen, who ≈øerved at their own charges, and they
not bound to pa≈øs the Limits of their Country, had refu≈øed to invade the Turki≈øh Frontiers, during the Wars with the Sultans of Egypt. All the following Winter Selymus ≈øtay'd to ≈øettle his Affairs in Syria, but early in the Spring having notice from his Lieutenant in Europe; that Pope Leo the tenth had ≈øtirred up the Chri≈øtian Princes, to invade his Territories on that ≈øide, leaving Gazeles his Lieutenant in Syria, he ha≈øted with his Army to Con≈øtantinople, where he no ≈øooner arrived but making great preparations, he re≈øolved to bend all his forces again≈øt the Chri≈øtians; but 'ere he could perform his de≈øign God (who as he ple≈øes re≈øtrains the power of Tyrants, even in their greate≈øt pride, to make him ≈øen≈øible that he was but a mortal Man) ≈øtruck him with a grievous Canker in the Reins of his Back, which deriding Art admitted of no cure, but daily increa≈øing with horrible pains, he ≈øtill Rotting above-Ground, and well-nigh Poy≈øoning ≈øuch as were about him with the noi≈øome Contagion, in his way to Hadrianople, in order to the Solemnizing the profane Fea≈øt called Bai
‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ m (or as they Term it the Fea≈øt of their Prophet) he Breathed out his di≈ømal-Gho≈øt Anno 1520, near to the City Chiurlia, on the very ≈øpot where he had formerly lifted up his Impious Sword again≈øt his Father Bajazet, with purpo≈øe to have bereaved him of his Life and Empire, dying after he had Reigned eight Years and lived 46, filling the World with Murthers and prodigius Slaughters, and was Buryed in a new Temple at Con≈øtantinople, Erected for the purpo≈øe by his Son Solyman, who ≈øucceeded him in the Ottoman Empire, and in token of his re≈øtle≈øs Nature, upon his Tomb is Ingraven in Greek, Turki≈øh and the Sclavonian Tongues, this following Epitaph.
H ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ M ‚Ä¢ ximus ad≈øum Selymus, qui orbem Dom ‚Ä¢ i; non Bell ‚Ä¢ retinquo, &c.

lg.head: In Engli≈øh thus.
lg.l: Lo here I lye great Selymus, who held the world in fear,
The World I leave, yet not the Wars which I ≈øeek, tho not here.
Not Fortunes chance, nor Victors Hand could take from me the Spoils.
And tho my Bones lye Buryed here, my Gho≈øt ≈øeeks Bloody Broils.

div.head: CHAP. XV. The Life of Solyman, the fir≈øt of that Name, and fourth Emperor of the Turks, who for his many great exploits, or rather Lofty Carriage, was Sirnamed the Magnificent.
div.p:
SElymus being dead, his Death was Concealed by Ferha ‚Ä¢ es, the only Ba≈ø≈øa pre≈øent at his Departure, till ≈øuch time as Solyman came from Magne≈øia, le≈øt the Souldier but e≈øpecially the Janizaries ≈øhould have Spoil'd and Plundered the Merchants-Strangers re≈øiding in the great City of Con≈øtantinople, as is u≈øual with them in Interregnums, as they call them, which are accounted from the Death of the proceeding Emperor, to the time the Succeeding Emperor is pre≈øented to be proclaimed by the men of War; but ≈øuch was the Incredulity of Solyman, that knowing his Fathers cruel Nature, & Jealous apprehen≈øion of his intent to A≈øpire to Empire, for which he had often been in danger of
his Life, could not believe what he mo≈øt de≈øired, till he had it certified from all Hands, upon which with more then ordinary ≈øpeed, he ha≈øted to Con≈øtantinople, and there being met by the Great Ba≈ø≈øas, and the Aga of the Janizaries he was lead into the mid'≈øt of the men of War, drawn up for that purpo≈øe, when as the Aga or chief Captain with a loud Voice ≈øaid, Behold your emperor, upon which immediately followed an Univer≈øal Shout, ≈øucceeded with the Joyful Acclamation of, Longlive the great Emperor Solyman (which con≈øent of the men of War is to the Turki≈øh Emperors, the greate≈øt A≈ø≈øurance of their ≈øafe E≈øtabli≈øhment in their Empire) and ≈øo in great Triumph they brought him into the Royal Pallace, and placed him in his Fathers Seat Anno 1520, at what time Charles the fifth was cho≈øen Emperor of Germany.

The Janizaries by this means di≈øappointed of the Spoil of the Goods, belonging to the Jewi≈øh and Chri≈øtian Merchants, in Lieu thereof received of the new Emperor great Sums of money, and had during his Reign, their wage Augmented; upon the Death of Selymus, Gazeles whom he had made Governour of Syria, revolted from Solyman, and drew after him the remaining power of the Mamalukes, ≈øeizing upon ≈øeveral Cities, but being Fought with by Ferates Ba≈ø≈øa ≈øent again≈øt him with a great power, he after a long and Bloody Fight was Slain, and his forces put to Flight; upon which all the Cities of Syria were again reduced to the Turki≈øh obedience: And now Solyman de≈øirous to get him≈øelf a Name, by the Coun≈øel of Pyrrhus-Ba≈ø≈øa his Tutor re≈øolved to bend his forces again≈øt the Chri≈øtians, who by Rea≈øon of the Di≈ø≈øen≈øions among≈øt them≈øelves, lay open to his Inva≈øion (a fatal over-≈øight which ever gave the Ottoman Emperors, the opportunity to inlarge their Dominions on the Borders of Chri≈øtendom) whereupon rai≈øing a great power, and
enteriung Hungaria, he took Belgrade almo≈øt without re≈øi≈øtance, again≈øt which in vain Mahomet the Great, Amurath and Bajazet had lo≈øt 500000 Men; Belgrade ≈øtrongly Garri≈øoned he di≈øper≈øed part of his Army, and returned to Con≈øtantinople, making great preparations for Sea again≈øt the Spring, as having an Eye upon the famous I≈øland of Rhodes, of which the Rhodians not being Ignorant cho≈øe for their great Ma≈øter Philippus Villerius, a man of great Wi≈ødom and Courage, then following the French Court; but upon notice thereof took Shipping at Marcelles, and arrived ≈øafe in the Port of the City Rhodes (tho Solyman had ≈øent out Cortug Ogly, a famous Pirate of the Turks, with ≈øeveral Gallies to intercept them) whereupon at his arrival he was in≈øtalled by the Knights of the Order and Citizens, with great Triumph, and more then ordinary expre≈ø≈øions of Joy.

Solyman not a ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ering his Determination, yet de≈øirous to know how the Rhodians ≈øtood affected, and to learn all that was po≈ø≈øible of their number, and the Strength of the City, ≈øent divers in≈øinuating Letters with Super≈øcriptions of his Thundering Titles to the great Ma≈øter, of which this is one, viz. Solyman by the Grace of God, King of Kings, Lord of Lords, greate≈øt Emperor of Con≈øtaminople, and Trepezond; mo≈øt Mighty King of Per≈øia, Arabia, Syria, Egypt, Lord of A≈øia and Europe, Prince of Mecha and Aleppo, Ruler of Jeru≈øalem and Ma≈øter of the Univer≈øal Sea, to Philippus Villerus Lilladamus great Ma≈øter of Rhodes, &c. But neither the≈øe thumping Titles, nor his Threats and Promi≈øes, could move the great Ma≈øter to hearken to his Reque≈øt, which was that he would become his Tributary, and to deliver into his po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion the City and I≈øland; ≈øo that finding his Expectations Fru≈øtrated, and that his Name was not ≈øo terrible as he ≈øuppo≈øed, after many Letters had pa≈ø≈øed and repa≈ø≈øed, he
cau≈øed a Fleet of 200 Gallies to be furni≈øhed with all things nece≈ø≈øary, for the ≈øiege of that ≈øtrong city, of which the great Ma≈øter being Adverti≈øed, was not wanting on his part to put all things in order for making a mo≈øt re≈øolute defence, cau≈øing Watch and Ward to be kept in every Street, and the great Artillary to be planted upon the Walls, and Bulwarks, opening all the Armories of the City, and furni≈øhing every man with Weapons, appointing to each his Station, there to be ready when occa≈øion required his Service, and then taking a General Ma≈øter of ≈øuch as were fit for Service, he found about 5000 re≈øolute men, among≈øt whom were ≈øix hundred Knights of the order, each of them capable of Commanding a va≈øt Army, as likewi≈øe 500 Souldiers of Cr ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ; there were come thither for fear of the Turks, a number of Villagers, who ≈øerved to Sink Sounds to Countermine the Enemy, and to ca≈øt up Rampires, &c.

Things thus ordered, the great Ma≈øter calling together his Commanders and Soldiers, incouraged them in a mo≈øt Chri≈øtian-like manner, to fight boldly again≈øt the Enemies of Chri≈øt, and rather to dye in the defence of their Religion, then to ≈øubmit them≈øelves to the Tyra ‚Ä¢ my of the Barbarous Infidels, putting them in „Äà‚óä„Äâ of the Valour of their Ance≈øtors, and of the aid they were to expect from the Chri≈øtian Princes, &c. Which S ‚Ä¢ ee ‚Ä¢ h ≈øo Animated the Commanders and Souldiers, that they de≈øired nothing more then to ≈øhew their prowe≈øs to the World.

By this time the Turks Gallies were put to Sea, and about twenty being the forerunners of the Fleet for many Days braved the Rhodians before their own Port, whereupon the Great Ma≈øter called a Council to know whether they ≈øhould be Fought with or not, to procure which the Chancellor a man of Admirable Courage earne≈øtly Laboured, but the de ‚Ä¢ andents being but
few, and therefore the ≈ømalle≈øt lo≈øs at Sea, tho they ≈øhould gain the Victory, might be a means to Weaken the City, yet at length it was re≈øolved upon, that they ≈øhould be permitted to Land in any part of the I≈øland, except the Port without re≈øi≈øtance, which they accordingly did, burning up the Corn, and making great Spoil as they pa≈ø≈øed, yet dur≈øt they attempt nothing again≈øt the City, but again entering their Galley ≈øtood off to Sea, to joyn with the re≈øt of the Fleet, which on the 26 of June, Anno 1322, was from the Watch-Tower ≈øtanding upon St. Stephens Hill di≈øcerned, and notice given thereof to the Great Ma≈øter, who cau≈øed Publick Prayers to be put up to God, that as it was his plea≈øure, that they at that time ≈øhould become the Champions of the Chri≈øtian Religion, that ≈øo of his infinite Goodne≈øs, it would plea≈øe him to ≈øtrengthen them, and give them Victory over the Enemies of his name, &c.

Prayers ended every man betook him to his charge, when as the fleet ≈øailing by in Triumph, the Vice-Admiral of the Turks in the middle, having a fair Wind, ≈øtrook Sail directly before the Mouth of the Haven, and cau≈øed his Galley to row towards the entrance of the Port, Guarded with two ≈øtrong Towers, from which he received ≈øuch a thundering welcom, that he was inforced to retire, and ≈øo with the re≈øt of the fleet failing along the coa≈øt they came to a Promontory called by the Inhabitants Bow, where thru≈øting their Gallies into a ≈ømall Haven, they landed their Artillery, and other nece≈ø≈øaries fit for the Siege, the whole Army con≈øi≈øting of 200000 men; and whil≈øt they were preparing to intrench them≈øelves, the Great Ma≈øter ≈øent Emba≈ø≈øadors to Charles the Emperor, and the French King, as likewi≈øe to the Pope, and Princes of Italy for aid, but they by rea≈øon of the broils among≈øt them≈øelves, returned the Emba≈ø≈øadors only with fair promi≈øes in ≈øtead of performance.

The City of Rhodes is Situate upon plain ground, every where to be be≈øieged, except towards the North, which is defended with a good Haven, and is incompa≈ø≈øed about with a ≈øtrong double Wall, and deep Trenches, threatning the Enemy with 13 ≈øtately Towers, 5 Bulwarks, and many ≈øtrong Gates, and what was more available, within the City was kept a ≈øtrict and orderly manner of warlike di≈øcipline. The defence of the whole City was thus proportioned; From the French Tower the which for its exceeding height ≈øeems to ki≈øs the Clouds, ≈øtood the Frenchmen with the Lillies in their En≈øign, under Johannes Abinus a Knight of the order, from thence to St Georges Gate lay the Germans with their Eagle En≈øign, in the third ≈øtation were placed the French of Avernois with the Spaniards, for that the ditches in that place were neither ≈øo deep nor broad as in others, next to them lay the Engli≈øh, commanded by the great Ma≈øter him≈øelf, and la≈øtly were placed they of Narbona and the Italians, under the Command of Petrus Balinus, and Gregorius Morgutus, Valiant Knights of the Order.

Whil≈øt Affaires ≈øtood thus, ≈øeveral Turki≈øh Women ≈ølaves to the Rhodians, had con≈øpired that when the A≈ø≈øault was given, they would ≈øet their Ma≈øters hou≈øes on fire, thereby to di≈øcourage the Souldiers, and draw them from their defences to extingui≈øhing the flame, but this treachery being timely di≈øcovered the Con≈øpirators were executed; by this time the Turks had planted ≈øeveral batteries, and began to play upon the Engli≈øh Bulwark, but without doing any con≈øiderable damage, when on the other ≈øide, the Cannon from the Walls furiou≈øly playing upon the Turki≈øh Pioneers, as they were breaking Ground, ≈øcattered their dead Bodies all over the Plain, when at the ≈øame time a ≈øtrong party Sallying out, cut off a great number of ≈øuch as were ≈øent to guard them, during
their running the trenches, which ≈øo di≈øcouraged the re≈øt, that they began to Murmur and Mutiny again≈øt their Commanders, ≈øeeming daily more and more unwilling to hazard their lives again≈øt ≈øo ≈øtrong a City, and ≈øuch re≈øolute Enemies, which cau≈øed Pyrrhus Ba≈ø≈øa General of the Army, to ≈øend Letters to Solyman then re≈øiding at Con≈øtantinople, to inform him: That if he would have the Siege go forward, he mu≈øt without delay come in per≈øon, for that the Souldiers without regard of ≈øhame were ready to ri≈øe in Mutiny, and to abandon the Siege, refu≈øing to be commanded by their Captains, upon notice of which Solyman cau≈øed his Gallies to be made ready. And on the 28 of Augu≈øt came him≈øelf to the Camp, where reading in the Countenances of his Souldiers, the little mind they had to continue the Siege, he was exceeding wroth, when cau≈øing them all to be di≈øarmed, he commanded 15000 harquibu≈øiers to incompa≈øs them (which Harquibu≈øiers he had brought with him) and Mounting his Pavilion for that purpo≈øe erected, he rated with many bitter words, calling them Slaves and Cowards, after which he incouraged them to a≈ø≈øume their Pri≈øtine courage and fight manfully again≈øt the City, till they had ≈øubdued it, and thereupon pronounced pardon to all that had offended, and ≈øwore them again to his obedience, after which the City was furiou≈øly battered, with ≈øhot of incredible weight, and huge ≈øtones for many days, and was as manfully defended by the Rhodians, ≈øo that in 200 ≈øhot there were but 10 men ≈ølain, though ≈øeveral hou≈øes were ≈øhattered, with their force, of which the Turks having notice from one Appella a Citizen of Rhodes, who was for the ≈øame executed as a Traytor.

The Turks perceiving the former Battery ineffectual, rai≈øed a huge Mount, on which they placed 40 great Ordnance with which they played furiou≈øly upon the
Tower of St. Nicholas, which was valiantly defended by one Guido a Frenchman, to whom the charge of it was committed, but e'r they had made many ≈øhot, mo≈øt of their Pieces were di≈ømounted by the Cannon from the City, nor dur≈øt they, when they had made a Breach, enter it; but u≈øed great Diligence to undermine the Wall, thirty two of which Mines were fru≈øtrated by Countermines; yet they ≈øo plyed it, that on the fourth of September having undermined the Engli≈øh Bulwarks, they blew part of it up, and in it divers of the Defendants; at which Breach the Turks attempti ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ to ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ t ‚Ä¢ r, were k ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ed in the Breach to the number of 2000. Which the re≈øt ob≈øerving, betook them≈øelves to „Äà‚óä„Äâ Heels, but being forced thereby to plea≈øe the Tyrant, they three days after renewed the A≈ø≈øault, but with wor≈øe ≈øucce≈øs then before; yet though they did as much as in them were po≈ø≈øible, Soly ≈øent them a „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ to enter at the ≈øaid Breach, in attempting which ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ 0 were ≈ølain, among≈øt whom were many great Commanders, though not without ≈øome lo≈øs to the be≈øieged; for in expul≈øing them fifty Knights of the Order, and 100 of le≈ø≈øer Note were ≈ølain. The≈øe great Lo≈ø≈øes made the Ba≈ø≈øas more wary, re≈øolving not longer to a≈ø≈øail the be≈øieged with plain Force, but to work under ground, and by that means to overthrow the Walls, but therein, for the mo≈øt part they were un≈øucce≈øsful, as being fru≈øtrated by the Countermines; yet by ≈øo weakening the Walls, they rendred it more liable to the Force of their Artillery, beating down great Pieces thereof, yet ≈øtood hovering about, being afraid to enter, and yet not daring to retire, though they were mowed down in abundance by the great Shot, for fear of the Tyrants di≈øplea≈øure; yet at length creeping under the Walls to the Spani≈øh Bulwarks, they ≈øurprized it, whil≈øt their Soldiers were drawn off to relieve their Fellows,
hardly Charged by Achmetes Ba≈ø≈øa, but e'r they had kept it two hours it was again recovered, and all the Turks either put to the Sword, or thrown over into the Ditch, where they mi≈øerably peri≈øhed: And the Ba≈ø≈øa ≈øore Gauled by the Flankers was forced to retire, though not without great ≈ølaughter of his Men, who lay on heaps in the Ditch and Breaches, which Solyman perceiving cau≈øed the retreat to be ≈øounded; in this A≈ø≈øault, by the Valour of the Chri≈øtians, 20000 Turks fell, which ≈øo grieved Solyman, that in a great rage he Commanded Mu≈øtapha Ba≈ø≈øa, the fir≈øt mover of the War to be ≈ølain, as likewi≈øe Pyrrhus Ba≈ø≈øa, for daring to intreat for him; but upon the humble Supplication of his Men of War on their behalf, he remitted the Execution of the Sentence, but would not for a long time receive them into Favour. He al≈øo Commanded the Admiral of his Gallies to be put to Death, for ≈øuffering Provi≈øion to be carried by Sea into the City; but at the intreaty of Achmetes his Life was ≈øpared, but he not ab≈øolutely pardoned; for being ≈øet upon the Stern of his Ship, he there as a Slave by the Commandment of Solyman received 100 Stripes, and ≈øo much was the Tyrant grieved for the re-ite-rated lo≈ø≈øes ≈øu≈øtained in that Siege, that he was about to have rai≈øed his Camp and returned to Con≈øtantinople, the which he had done, had not Achmetes Ba≈ø≈øa per≈øwaded him to the contrary, by Prom≈øing to make him ≈øpeedily a way into the City; at which he taking Courage again heartned his Men to continue the Siege, who≈øe Re≈øolutions had long before fainted; upon which Achmetes to make good his Promi≈øe, a≈ø≈øailed with all the Forces under his Command, the Vamures of the Avergnon Station, the which although they were not high, were valiantly defended by the Rhodians; yet the Turks Power increa≈øing, they were at la≈øt taken, and a great Pent-Hou≈øe claped to the Wall,
to ≈øecure the be≈øiegers from the Shot of the be≈øieged, notwith≈øtanding Per≈øanes a notable Engineer cau≈øed ≈øuch abundance of Wild-Fire, Pitch, Tar, Lead, hot A≈øhes, and Water to be thrown on them, that they were forced to retire; but ≈øuch was the mi≈øerable Condition of the Turki≈øh Soldiers, that they were forced back again by their Commanders, even into the mouth of Slaughter, or el≈øe by them ≈ølain as Cowards, or Flyers; yet for all they could do, the Rhodians forced them to retire in great di≈øorder, which inraged Solyman even to Madne≈øs, but perceiving that his Honour lay at Stake, he again by many per≈øwa≈øive Arguments prevailed with them, to give another A≈ø≈øault, promi≈øing them great Rewards if they prevailed, and threatning tho≈øe with Death, that ≈øhould be remi≈øs in the performance of their Duty, which either, through Hopes or Fear Animated them to another A≈ø≈øault, but with no better ≈øucce≈øs then before; for being mi≈øerably rent by the murthering Shot from the Flankers and Countermurers, they were forced to retire leaving Piles of their Dead in the Breach and Ditch; and now being altogether heartle≈øs, yet extreamly vexed that they ≈øhould be foiled with a handful of Men, they re≈øolved for the futere to be the more wary, and rather to tire the Rhodians with continual Alarums then venture upon them, when in the mean time they ≈øet their Pioneers at work, to make way through the Breach deep in the Ground, and for their defence turned their great Artillery upon it, to prevent the Rhodians Sallying, and with their multitude proved therein ≈øo ≈øucce≈øsful, that in a ≈øhort time they had gained within the City 200 paces in breadth, and 150 in length; yet dur≈øt not Sally out to Scale the Countermurers, which the Rhodians had made of the Hou≈øes beaten down by the Turks Shot, which Solyman perceiving at the in≈øtance of Achmetes, cau≈øed a parley to be offered; offering many
rea≈øonable Conditions, if the Rhodians would at length ≈øurrender the almo≈øt ruined City; but, and in Order thereto ≈øent Hieronymus Monelia a Genoway, who having procured ≈øafe Conduct, would not deliver his Me≈ø≈øage but to ≈øome particular men, which ≈øo incen≈øed the Knights of the Order, who now had ≈øet down a Re≈øolution to dye in defence of the City; that one Franci≈øcus Farnovius a French Knight of ≈øingular Valour, bent his Piece again≈øt him, and would not ≈øuffer him to do his Me≈ø≈øage; but the Citizens hearing there were Terms of Life and Liberty offered by the in≈øulting Tyrant, came to the Hou≈øe of the great Ma≈øter, and be≈øeeched him to take pitty on them, their Wives and Children, and that ≈øince he well ≈øaw that the City was not long tenable, he would in time provide for their ≈øafety, and not expo≈øe them to the Fury of their Mercile≈øs Enemies; whereat the great Ma≈øter, a man of ≈øingular Piety, as well as Warlike Ardour, being moved to Compa≈ø≈øion ≈øent Antonius Groleus, and Robartus Baru≈øinus his Amba≈ø≈øadors to Solyman, having fir≈øt received Pledges for their ≈øafe return, who coming into the Emperors Pre≈øence, told him that they were ≈øent to know for what cau≈øe he had ≈øent to require Parly, who in a fuming heat as if he had been Ignorant of the matter ≈øaid, there was no ≈øuch thing offered, and thereupon Commanding them pre≈øently to avoid his Camp, ≈øent them away with Letters to the great Ma≈øter and Citizens to this Effect.

If I had not Compa≈ø≈øion of human Infirmities, which often times tumbleth Head-long mens Ambitions, and haughty minds into mo≈øt dangerous and unnece≈ø≈øary Mi≈øchiefs; truly I would not have directed to you the≈øe Letters at this time, but as you have well de≈øerved, per≈øecute you with Death, and mo≈øt Mi≈øerable Servitude, which how ea≈øie a thing it were for me to do, you your ≈øelves know, but having now
≈øufficiently tryed my force, if you be wi≈øe make proof of my Clemency, you have already ≈øatisfyed your own fury, your own mad humour: Therefore now advi≈øe your ≈øelves, lay your Hands upon your Hearts, and without delay yield your ≈øelves, as I command your Lives, I give you your Wealth, and more then that your choice to tarry there ≈øtill or depart, refu≈øe not the Grace freely Offered, which was of you to have been mo≈øt heartily de≈øired; it ≈øhall not be always Lawful (as at this pre≈øent) to make choice of both, &c.

Upon the return of the Amba≈ø≈øadors, the Citizens of all ≈øorts flocked together, to the Great Ma≈øters Hou≈øe, ≈øtanding near the Breach to implore him to accept of any Rea≈øonable terms, who after he had di≈ømi≈ø≈øed the Multitude, calling to him the Knights of the Order, and chief Citizens, after the Letters read, he expre≈ø≈øed him≈øelf after this manner.
