You heard (≈øacred Fellows in Arms, and Valiant Citizens of Rhodes) the≈øe imperious and ≈øorrowful Letters, whereunto how we are to an≈øwer, requireth no great deliberation; we mu≈øt as re≈øolute men either yield or dye, all hopes of Victory is gone, except forrain aid come ≈øpeedily to our Succour; wherefore if you will follow my Coun≈øel, let us with Weapons in our Hands until the la≈øt Ga≈øp and ≈øpending the la≈øt drop of our Blood like Valiant men, defend our Faith and Nobility, received from our Ance≈øtors, and the honour which we have of long time gotten, both at home and abroad, and let it never be ≈øaid that our honour dyed but with our ≈øelves.

This Speech was approved of by all the Knights of the Order, and mo≈øt of the Soldiers, but the Citizens looking back upon their Wives, Children, and Wealth, ≈øtood mute for a good while, but at length Pity working in their Bre≈øt, they humbly be≈øought
the Great Ma≈øter; that he would yet have Compa≈ø≈øion on them, and accept of the Tyrants rea≈øonable Conditions, ≈øince Fame ≈øufficient had been won by their doing all that men were capable of performing, and that they would yet hazard their Lives to the utmo≈øt, if they perceived any hopes of defending the City, or that any forain aid in time would come to their a≈ø≈øi≈øtance, but ≈øince neither of them were to be expected it was but rea≈øonable to yield to inevitable nece≈ø≈øity. After the≈øe and many the like Arguments, and others of the re≈øolute Soldiers, and Commanders on the contrary, it was concluded that the City was not capable of being defended by ≈øo ≈ømall a Power, again≈øt ≈øuch a numerous Army, whereupon Me≈ø≈øengers were ≈øent to require a Truce for 4 Days, which was accordingly granted, during which time the Turks pre≈øuming on the Truce, came in great number to View the Works, at which Fornovius a French man being greatly offended, in a great heat without any command from the Great Ma≈øter, cau≈øed a Fire of Artillery to be di≈øcharged among≈øt the thicke≈øt of them; whereupon they pretending a Breach of Truce on the part of the Rhodians, thru≈øt in at the Breach in great Troops, but after a ≈øharp Skirmi≈øh were forced to retire, in revenge whereof one of the Turks Fencers having taken 3 Chri≈øtians, cut off their Hands, No≈øes and Ears, and in that po≈øture ≈øent them into the City, threatning within 4 Days to ≈øerve the Great Ma≈øter after the ≈øame manner; yet Solyman di≈ø≈øembling the matter, ≈øigned and ≈øwore to the Articles of Peace brought to him for that purpo≈øe by Nicholas Vergotus, and Georgius Sandriticus, which were to this Effect; That the Churches ≈øhould remain unto the Chri≈øtians inviolate, that no Children ≈øhould be taken from their Parents, or any Christians be inforced to imbrace the Mahometan Super≈øtition: That ≈øuch Chri≈øtians as were Contented to
remain in the City, might ≈øo do at their Plea≈øure, and that ≈øuch as would depart, might have Liberty ≈øo to do with all their Sub≈øtance, to be furni≈øhed with Convenient Shipping, Provi≈øion, and Ordnance as far as Creet, that the Chri≈øtians ≈øhould appoint a rea≈øonable Day for their Departure, and that in Con≈øideration thereof, the City to be delivered up to ≈øuch as Solyman ≈øhould appoint to take Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion thereof.

Upon the afore-mentioned Articles, though they were not all ob≈øerved by the Turks; the City was delivered up Anno 1522. after it had indured ≈øix Months Siege, and co≈øt Solyman the Lives of 80000 of his Soldiers, having been in the Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of the Knights of the Order 214 years: Upon which the great Ma≈øter being for his Gravity, Virtue, and Valour highly Honoured, and applauded by the Conqueror imbarked (together with the Knights of his Order, and ≈øuch others as would accompany him) and the Gallies for that purpo≈øe ready in the Port, and ≈øailed to Me≈øina, where he was joyfully received, and after invited to the Courts of mo≈øt of the Chri≈øtian Princes, having with Indignation refu≈øed Solyman's great Offer made to him, provided he would have accompanied him to Con≈øtantinople, and have ≈øpent the remainder of his Days in his Service.

And thus for want of Relief (the Chri≈øtian Princes at that time being at Variance among≈øt them≈øelves) the famous Rhodes was lo≈øt, where Solyman having ≈øtayed awhile to ≈øettle his Affairs appointed a Governour, and ≈øo breaking up his Army returned to Con≈øtantinople, where for the ≈øpace of three years he lived Peaceably, giving him≈øelf up to all manner of Plea≈øures; but at the end thereof perceiving the Di≈øcord among≈øt the Chri≈øtian Princes, managed by Pope Adrian the ≈øixth to grow hot (a fatal over-≈øight that ever gave the Ottoman Kings and Emperors opportunity
of extending their Dominions) he conceived it be≈øt to fi≈øh in troubled waters, and thereupon rai≈øing an Army of 200000 Hor≈øe and Foot; he fell like a Tempe≈øt upon Hungary, ≈øubduing all before him till he came within ≈øight of the Walls of their chief City, at what time Lewis the young King per≈øwaded thereto by Tomoreus a Fryer, who a≈ø≈øured him of the Victory, and ≈øeveral other ra≈øh Coun≈øellors, not regarding tho≈øe of more Gravity, that di≈øwaded him from ≈øo ra≈øh an Attempt; with an Army of ≈øcarce 30000 raw Soldiers gave him Battle, but was overthrown with mi≈øerable Slaughter of his men, and him≈øelf ≈øeeking to e≈øcape, pa≈ø≈øing over a Fenny Ditch his Hor≈øe fell backwards, upon which, he was loaden with his Armor, and none coming to his Relief, he was ≈ømothered in the Water and Mud: In this Battle fought on the 29. of October Anno 1526. peri≈øhed mo≈øt of the Hungarian Nobility, and well near all the Common Soldiers.

After this great great Victory obtained, Solyman having mo≈øt of the ≈øtrong Cities delivered into his Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion; gave the Kingdom to Joannes Sepu≈øius ∆≤ayvod of Tran≈øilvania, and taking with him ≈øuch things of Price as he thought convenient, leaving two of his Ba≈ø≈øas with flying Armies on the Frontiers, he returned to Con≈øtantinople, but he was no ≈øooner departed and John Crowned by the Con≈øent of the remainder of the Hungarian Nobility (who dur≈øt do no other for fear of the Turks) but Ferdinand King of Bohemia laid Claim to the Kingdom, and to make his Title more apparent, ≈øent his Amba≈ø≈øadors to the Courts of divers Christian Princes, to declare from whom he derived his Claim; when aided by Charles the Emperor his Brother, he entered Hungary with a great Army, and without any con≈øiderable Re≈øi≈øtance took the ≈øtrong City of Buda; at what time many of the Hungarians joyned with him, as not in the
lea≈øt favouring John; ≈øo that fearing delays might be dangerous, he cau≈øed his Army under the leading of his expert Captains to pa≈øs over the River Tibi≈øcus upon a Bridge of Boats, and marched directly to the Cattle of Tocai, where King John lay with his Army; where the Battle being joyned after a ≈øharp Di≈øpute, the Victory fell to Ferdinand; when as King John ≈øeeing all lo≈øt and pa≈øt recovery, fled with ≈øeveral of his tru≈øty Followers into Polonia; upon who≈øe departure Ferdinand by the advice of ≈øuch Hungarians as favoured his Cau≈øe, was Crowned King at Alba-Regalis the u≈øual place for the Coronation of the Hungarian Kings: Whereupon having di≈øpo≈øed all things to the be≈øt advantage, and appointing Stephanus Bator his Vice-Roy, hereturned into Bohemia.

King John by the means afore≈øaid thru≈øt of his Kingdom, grew extreme impatient, and often con≈øulted with Sigi≈ømond King of Polonia to re-in-throne him in his Kingdom, offering to bear the Charge of the War; but the Pole being already in League with Ferdinand, would not ≈øeem unle≈øs underhand to favour John, but wi≈øhed him to take coun≈øel with Hieronymus La≈øcus a great Politician, what was be≈øt to be done in his Affairs, the which La≈øcus advi≈øed him to crave Aid of Solyman now at Lea≈øure to a≈ø≈øi≈øt him; and urged ≈øo many Rea≈øons for it, that he was content to ≈øend him his Amba≈ø≈øador to Con≈øtantinople, who there with Trea≈øure and fair Speeches, ≈øo allured the Ba≈ø≈øas of the Court to ≈øecond him in his Reque≈øt, that Solyman promi≈øed again to enter Hungaria with a pui≈ø≈øant Army, and by the In≈øinuation of this ≈øly Councellor, that when King Ferdinand ≈øent Amba≈ø≈øadors to him, to make out his Title, by which he laid Claim to the Kingdom, he would ≈øcarcely give them Audience; and when he did, in≈øtead of an An≈øwer to their Amba≈ø≈øy, he Herauld-like denounced again≈øt their King, all the
Calamities that attend on War, and ≈øo commanded ≈øpeedily to depart the City; all which upon their Arrival at Vienna, they made known to the Kings Lieutenant, who was ≈øo far from believing them, that he looked upon them as vain and idle Tale-bearers, which they perceiving ha≈øted to the King at Spires, who then was Labouring to get him≈øelf cho≈øen King of the Romans, and declared to him all they had in Charge: Whereupon he well knowing, that the Turk de≈øirous of Glory, and the inlarging of his Dominions, ≈øeldom broke his Word on ≈øuch occa≈øions; he put all his Forces in a readine≈øs, earne≈øtly, both in Per≈øon and by his Amba≈ø≈øadours, craved Aid of the German Princes for the Defence of his Kingdom of Hungary, again≈øt the common Enemy; but his Brother Charles having his hands full of his Wars in Italy, and he wanting Money to rai≈øe a ≈øufficient Army to fight ≈øo powerful an Enemy, was forced to ≈øuffer him without Controul to enter Hungaria, for fear of whom the Citizens of Buda mo≈øtly fled to Strigonium, Alba-Regalis, and Po≈ø≈øonium: So that marching from Belgrade (where King John came to wait upon him, and received a Confirmation of the Promi≈øe he had made to La≈øcus, of re≈øtoring him to the Kingdom of Hungary) he came before it, and had it yeilded with little or no Re≈øi≈øtance, as likewi≈øe the ≈øtrong Ca≈øtle, though contrary to the Will of the Captain, yet contrary to his Promi≈øe, he cau≈øed all that were found in the latter to be put to the Sword, except the Captain, whom the Soldiers had ca≈øt in Bonds, for refu≈øing to joyn with them in their treacherous delivery of that ≈øtrong Piece.

Buda taken mo≈øt of the other Cities of Hungary ≈øurrendred; whereupon he re≈øolved to invade Au≈øtria, a part of King Ferdinands other Dominions, in Order to which he ≈øent Achometes Ba≈ø≈øa with the voluntary Hor≈øemen, who running through the Heart of Hungary,
entring into Au≈øtria with Fire and Sword pa≈ø≈øed by Vienna, mi≈øerably burning and de≈øtroying the Country before them, even as far as Lyntz, driving the Country People like Sheep, deflowring Vigins, riping up Women alive, da≈øhing Infants again≈øt the Rocks, with all other imaginable Cruelties; after whom Solyman followed with the gro≈øs of his Army, con≈øi≈øting of 500000 Hor≈øe and Foot, as many Writers affirm, who by the way having taken the Ca≈øtle of Altenbury, and in vain a≈ø≈øaulted Neapolis; he came before the great City of Vienna, and incamped about it in five places, covering the Ground with his Tents, and the multitude of his People 8 miles in Circumference. So that Fredrick Count Palatine of the Rhine, and Duke of Bavaria General of King Ferdinand's Forces, not being able to get into the City with his Army ≈øent for that purpo≈øe, was forced to ≈øtay at Chrem≈øe; yet was his Nephew Philip the Pal≈øgrave, a little before the coming of Solyman to the great joy of the Citizens, entered with ≈øeveral Troops of valiant Hor≈øemen, as likewi≈øe Nicholas Count of Salma, the Lord William Regendorf Steward of the Kings hou≈øhold, Johannes Cazzianer, Nicholaus Turianus, Johannes Hardecus, Leonardus Vel≈ø ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ s, Hector Ram≈øack with divers others, all men of great Experience and Valour, and daring Re≈øolution; yet was the City but badly defended with a Brick Wall, without Grafts or Flankers, the Ditch altogether dry, and although at that time there were found 400 Pieces of Ordnance, yet they could find means to mount no more then a 100, notwith≈øtanding the Citizens and Soldiers u≈øed all diligence, in rai≈øing Rampires, and Barocading the Gates, unle≈øs tho≈øe they re≈øerved to Sally at, and by the Command of the Governour every man was a≈ø≈øigned his Quarter, keeping ≈øtrict Watch upon the Walls, to prevent the Enemies approach, for that the Bulwarks were not
of Con≈øiderable ≈øtrength: The Count of Salma, and the Lord Regendorf, walking hourly from one place to another, to ≈øee all things put in a po≈øture of defence, the Citizens laboured continually in ≈øtrengthening the Fortifications, and rai≈øing Batteries, whereon to plant ≈øuch Pieces as lay u≈øele≈øs, for want of where to mount them: they made likewi≈øe divers Fire-works, and continually kept Coppers of Tar, Pitch, Ro≈øin, Oyl, and ≈øcalding Water, in a readine≈øs to pour upon the Enemy, by that means to prevent their Scaling the Walls, every one from the greate≈øt to the lea≈øt, expre≈ø≈øing a Cheerfulne≈øs for the defence of this place, the Metropolis of Au≈øtria, and chief Hope of the German Empire, which the Turks conceived ≈øo Con≈øiderable, that they doubted not, but it won, all Au≈øtria, Stiria, and Corinthia, would be ≈øoon at their Devotion.

The City by this time ≈øtrengthened and provided, of many nece≈ø≈øary for a ≈øtrenuous Defence; Me≈ø≈øengeres were ≈øent to Count Fredrick to draw near with his Army, the more to terrifie and amaze the Enemy, who≈øe numerous Camp could not long ≈øub≈øi≈øt, if ≈øupplies of Provi≈øion were cut off; upon the Arrival of the Me≈ø≈øenger, the Count highly approved of the Re≈øolution of the be≈øieged, and declared he would be always at hand, and omit no Indeavours to ≈øuccour them, admoni≈øhing the Me≈ø≈øenger to remember him to his fellow Soldiers, and in his Name intreat them to play the Men, for the defence of the Chri≈øtian Religion, and Glory of the German Nation, who≈øe Ruin the Infidels ≈øought; and ≈øo with ≈øeveral pre≈øents, he di≈ømi≈ø≈øed the Me≈ø≈øenger, who returning related what he had in Charge: Whereupon the Lord Regendorf a≈ø≈øembled all the chief Commanders, and principal Citizens, and with an undaunted Courage, made this ≈øhort Oration.

Chri≈øtians and fellow Soldiers, the time is now
come, wherein we are to fight under the Banner of our Lord Je≈øus Chri≈øt, whom the≈øe barbarous Nations have defied, let us then ≈øhew forth our Courage to the utmo≈øt, even in the Mouth of Slaughter; let not Death nor Danger terrifie us, ≈øince we fight in a good Cau≈øe, even for our Religion, our Lives, our Wives, Children, and all that we hold dear, for what it can be but Ambition, and thir≈øt of Chri≈øtian Blood, that drew this Bloody Mon≈øter with his numerous Ho≈øt, from ≈øuch remote Countries: Therefore I ≈øay, rather let us dye like Men, fighting it out to the la≈øt Drop of Blood, then yield our ≈øelves to the≈øe Barbarous Infidels, who know not how to ≈øhew Mercy, who≈øe Leagues, Vows, and Solemn Prote≈øtations are all but Wind, kept no longer then they prove Advantagious to them≈øelves; I for my part, have fixed my unalterable Re≈øolution to defend this Place to the la≈øt Ga≈øp, re≈øolving not to ≈øurvive its lo≈øs.

This Oration ≈øpoken with great Earne≈øtne≈øs, plainly Demon≈øtrating the Zeal of a brave General, was ≈øeconded with loud ≈øhouts, every one promi≈øing to Live and Dye with him in the defence of the City: Whereupon it was re≈øolved, that the next Morning a Sally ≈øhould be made upon the Enemies, to give them a Ta≈øte of Chri≈øtian Valour, and how little they valued their Lives fighting in ≈øo good a Cau≈øe; whereupon every one being di≈ømi≈ø≈øed went to his Quarters, to give nece≈ø≈øary Orders, and take a View how the Turks lay incamped, who≈øe multitude covered all the Hills and Plains before the City. The Watch being ≈øet, the General went round the City, attended by ≈øeveral Officers; Carefully to ≈øurvey each Quarter, and to ≈øee that none neglected his Duty; ≈øo that all things being in good Order, about Midnight ≈øix Reigments drew up with a Re≈øolution to fall upon the Enemies Camp, but whil≈øt Orders were in giving, in what manner they ≈øhould make their approach, a Chri≈øtian Captive having made his e≈øcape from the Turks, came running almo≈øt breathle≈øs, and begged to be received into the City: Whereupon the Soldiers drew him up with a Pike, who being que≈øtioned about the ≈øtate of the Turki≈øh Camp declared, that every night ≈øince they came forty thou≈øand men were driven up in Battalia, to Guard the Camp; which was not as yet well intrenched, upon notice of which the General changed his Re≈øolution as to the Sally.

During the preparation within Solyman was not idle, (having ≈øworn to carry the City by force e're he departed, if he could not have it otherwi≈øe) but appointed to every man his ≈øtation, dividing his Army under Ibrahim the Great Ba≈ø≈øa, Michael Ogli and Becrambeius, ≈øo that all things being in a readine≈øs, many ≈øalleys were made by the Chri≈øtians with great ≈ølaughter of the Enemies though the A≈øapi and Janizaries from their Trenches poured ≈øhowers of Arrows into the City, for as yet the Turks great Artillery were not come up the Danubius, but were dayly expected; of which Wolfgangus Hoder a Valiant Captain under≈øtanding by ≈øeveral Turki≈øh Pri≈øoners ≈øailed out of the Bay of Po≈ø≈øonium, and meeting with the Turks Galleys, ≈øunk tho≈øe in which the Ordinance were, taking a great Booty, of which Solyman having notice, was greatly inraged, and finding that his ≈ømall pieces did little other damage than beat down the battlements, and over-jets made of wood in ≈øtead of Flankers, he cau≈øed the Miners to be ≈øet to the Wall, but this their chief hope which with wonderful labour attempted in thirteen places at once, was not ≈øo ≈øecretly done, but that it was by Drums layed upon the Ground, Ba≈øons filled with Water, and deep ≈øounds perceived by the defendants, who with Countermines not only defeated many of them, but de≈øtroyed in them by Wildfire, and other Combu≈øtible matter Eight Thou≈øand Turks, when to prevent ≈øuch di≈øcovery, Solyman commanded continual Alarums ≈øhould be given, that ≈øo the Chri≈øtians being imployed in defending the Walls, might not regard the Miners which ≈øucceeded ≈øo to his wi≈øh, that a great part of the Wall near the Gate that leadeth towards Carinthia was thrown down by the ≈øpringing of a Mine; at which the Turks in great numbers indeavouring to
enter, were mi≈øerably cut off with the Murthering ≈øhot bent again≈øt the breach for the purpo≈øe; which no ≈øooner cea≈øed, but they were furiou≈øly charged by the Germans; and in de≈øpite of all re≈øi≈øtance beaten back with incredible ≈ølaughter: Not long after, the Wall being blown up in two other places, they again attempted to enter; but were repul≈øed as before, leaving heaps of ≈ølain in the Breaches, and Ditch; nor was their third A≈ø≈øault any more ≈øucce≈øsful; ≈øo that after three hours with≈øtanding the fury of the re≈øolute Defendants, they retired to the Camp Ten Thou≈øand le≈øs than they came. A while after, the Lord Regendorfe perceiving the Turks by parties ≈øcatter from their Camp, came with a Company of German Hor≈øe, ≈øet upon a Party of Five Thou≈øand Three Hundred with ≈øuch ≈ølaughter, that not above One Hundred and Forty of them returned to tell the News: Nor did other Commanders of the be≈øieged le≈øs indamage the Enemies by frequent Salleys, which ≈øo inraged the Tyrant, that he animated to a fourth A≈ø≈øault, promi≈øing them great rewards if they prevailed, which ≈øo far prevailed with them, that they re≈øolved among≈øt them≈øelves either to win the City, or dye in the undertaking; but when they felt the ≈øhot from the be≈øieged like a tempe≈øt fall on them, they were of a different opinion, ≈øo that leaving many Thou≈øands of the ≈ølain and wounded behind them, they retire to the Camp; which Solyman perceiving, and fretting that his Honour had ≈øo much ≈øuffered by ≈øo great a lo≈øs of his Men, and ≈øo many Repul≈øes, di≈ø≈øembled the matter as well as he could, and that the Germans ≈øhould not ≈øuppo≈øe he rai≈øed his ≈øiege, becau≈øe he de≈øpaired of winning it; he cau≈øed ≈øeveral Pri≈øoners to be richly cloathed, and giving them ≈øtore of Money, ≈øent them into the City to inform the
Commanders that he came not to take the City of Vienna, but to fight King Ferdinand, and re≈øtore the Kingdom of Hungaria to King John: therefore ≈øince he could not draw his Enemy into the Field to give him Battle, he would remove thence to ≈øeek him, wherefore they ≈øhould do well to yield them≈øelves; the which if they would, he promi≈øed not to enter into the City, but to receive both the Citizens and Souldiers into his protection, re≈øerving unto 'um their Lives and Goods with perpetual freedom, which offer coming to the knowledge of the Princes and great Captains of the Chri≈øtians ≈øcornfully refu≈øed, whereupon the Imperious Turk perceiving his de≈øires not an≈øwered as he expected, having cau≈øed all the Pri≈øoners to be murthered, in a great heat rai≈øed his ≈øiege and departed, not ≈øtaying till he came to Buda, where having re≈øtored the Kingdom to John in con≈øideration of his becoming his Tributary, he returned to Con≈øtantinople, yet plotting in his mind to di≈øturb the Chri≈øtians, and revenge the di≈øgrace he had received before at Vienna, the next year, viz, 1530, he leavyed an Army greater than the former, purpo≈øing with him≈øelf to over-run Au≈øtria, Carinthia, Styria, and mo≈øt part of the German Empire; to effect which, he allowed three years, but was altogether deceived in his expectation: for Charles the Emperor having ended his Wars in Italy, was now at lei≈øure to attend upon the In≈øolent Turk; who calling together his Valiant Captains, ≈øent them into Spain, Italy, Flanders, and other Countreys to leavy Forces, which they did in ≈øuch abundance to oppo≈øe the common Enemy, that upon the Mu≈øter of the Army there were found Ninety Thou≈øand old experienced Foot Souldiers, and Thirty Thou≈øand Hor≈øemen well appointed, all the flower
‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ermany, Italy, Bohemia, and Hungaria, as likewi≈øe One
Hundred and Forty Thou≈øand of le≈øs experience, the whole Army con≈øi≈øting of One Hundred and Sixty Thou≈øand Men; the approach of which ≈øo terrified Solyman, that after he had in vain be≈øieged Gonza, and harazed the Countrey, though with the lo≈øs of Ten Tou≈øand of his Men, he returned to Con≈øtantinople, carrying with him into mi≈øerable Captivity Thirty Thou≈øand poor Chri≈øtians taken in divers Countries through which he pa≈ø≈øed, and to appea≈øe his fury, put no le≈øs a number to the Sword. And now had the Chri≈øtian Army, compo≈øed of divers Nations, pur≈øued the Turk by Land and Sea, as the Emperour earne≈øtly de≈øired they might have driven him quite out of Europe; but Emulation ari≈øing among≈øt the Commanders and the Soldiers, frequently mutining this great Army, effected nothing more than to oblige Solyman to retire.

The Empire mindful of the damage ≈øu≈øtained by the Turks in Au≈øtria, Hungary, and other Countries to revenge the ≈øame early the ≈øpring following, ≈øet forth a Fleet con≈øi≈øting of Thirty Five great Ships, and Forty Eight Galleys, under the Conduct of Andreas Aurea, a mo≈øt expert Captain, who ≈øailing to the Bay of Ambracia, thought there to have met with the Turks Admiral, who had under his Command Sixty Galleys, but he having notice of his coming from the Venetians, who ≈øtood Newters, was ≈øailed to the ≈øtrong Haven of Calcide; whereupon Auria directed his cour≈øe to Corone, a ≈øtrong City upon the Coa≈øt of Pelopone≈øus, and had it yielded unto him upon condition that the Gari≈øon might depart with bag and baggage; where leaving a Garri≈øon of Spaniards, he ≈øailed to Patras another City in the ≈øame Tract; took it, and ran≈øacked it, permitting the Garri≈øon neverthelele≈øs to march out in ≈øafety; after which, he took all the Ca≈øtles that
guarded the ≈øtraight of Naupactum without any hindrance, which gave Saluiatus General of the Malta Galleys opportunity to wa≈øte the Coa≈øt of Corinth, and take great booties; which done, he returned loaden with ≈øpoils to Naples, and from thence to Genoa the place of his birth and re≈øidence.

The Turks grieving at their great lo≈øs, early in the Spring, Anno 1533, lay'd ≈øiege to Corone both by Sea and Land; of which Mendoza the Governour by Letters advi≈øed the Vice-Roy of Naples, craving ≈øpeedy aid, with all, a≈ø≈øuring him, he would defend the Town to the utmo≈øt extremity; upon which, Auria was ≈øent with a well appointed Fleet; the terror of who≈øe coming ≈øo frighted the Turks, that they left the ≈øiege, having lo≈øt many Men before it, and for ha≈øte left all their heavy Carriages, which became a Prey to the Garri≈øon Soldiers, which exalted their courage to that degree, that they reque≈øted Macicaus the Governour to lead them forth to the ≈øiege of Andru≈øa a Garri≈øon of the Turks not far di≈øtant from Corone, but their coming being di≈øcovered, they could not ≈øurprize it as they intended, yet ran≈øacked the Suburbs, and made great ≈ølaughter of the Turk, Hor≈øemen, quartering therein, though with the lo≈øs of Macicaus the Governour, and divers others; yet not long after they took the City, being abandoned by the Garri≈øon as not tenable; but upon their return to Corone, the Plague began to rage ≈øo fearfully, that fearing if they ≈øtay, they ≈øhould all peri≈øh, and fit opportunity offering it ≈øelf by rea≈øon of the Arrival of ≈øeveral Galleys from Sicily with Corn, all the Spaniards, together with as many Greeks as would imbarqued with the Cannon, and what el≈øe they thought convenient; leaving the Town to be again po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed by the
Turks, though not without the con≈øent of the Emperor. Anno 1534 Aloy≈øus Grittus, Son to the Duke of Venice, and Solymans great Favourite, being by him ‚Ä¢ ade Leiutenant of Hungary inwardly envying at Ameri ‚Ä¢ us Vayvod of Tran≈øylvania at the in≈øtance of one Docia, cau≈øed him to be murthered in his Tent, which ≈øo incen≈øed the Tran≈øylvanians, that they Arming them≈øelves to the number of Forty Thou≈øand, under the Leading Maylat, a Valiant Gentleman, and Kin≈øman to the Vayvod, pur≈øued the Murtherer, who ≈øled to Mega, which the Tran≈øylvanians be≈øieged, and not without great difficulty took, and in it Aloy≈øus and Docia; the former of which they beheaded, and the latter tore in pieces, taking the ≈øpoil of their Goods, which was very great; for about Aloy≈øus were found as many precious ≈øtones as were e≈øteemed worth Forty Millions.

Solyman thir≈øting after Glory, and re≈øolving not to let his Soldiers lye idle, re≈øolved to invade at once both Africk and Per≈øia: the charge of the fir≈øt he committed to Barbaru≈øa, (who of a poor Fi≈øher-Boy became a Pirate, and afterward King of Argire, and then travelling to Con≈øtantinople, was upon the recommendation of Achometes the Great Ba≈ø≈øa, made one of the Ba≈ø≈øas of Solymans Council.) Whereupon he can≈øed all his Galleys to be in a readine≈øs, appointing the afore≈øaid Barbaru≈øa Admiral of all his Sea Forces; who had no ≈øooner taken upon him the Command, but ≈øailing out of Helle≈øpontus with Eighty Galleys, (leaving Amurath with twelve to tran≈øport Solymans Army in to A≈øia,) he ≈øhaped his cour≈øe for Italy, when pa≈ø≈øing the Straights between Italy and Sicily, he brought ≈øuch a fear upon the Inhabitants on either ≈øhoar, that they fled with all their ≈øub≈øtance further into the Countrey; after which, he
layed ≈øiege to Saint Lucidius, formerly called Temp≈øas which he took, putting mo≈øt of the Inhabitants to the Sword, from whence with a rich booty, and many Pri≈øoners, he marched to Citrarium, which he took and burnt, together with Seven Galleys that lay in the Port; and ≈øo ≈øailing by Naples, he ≈øeized upon Spelunca, from which he marched over Land to Fundi, ten miles from Spelunca, on purpo≈øe as was thought to have ≈øeized on Jula Gonzaga, a Lady of incomparable Beauty, whom he intended to have pre≈øented to Solyman, but ≈øhe though half naked getting on Hor≈øeback, fled to the Mountains, yet he took the City, and put mo≈øt of the Inhabitants to the Sword; and ≈øo coa≈øting along Italy, and taking many Cities, Towns, and Ca≈øtles, he brought ≈øuch a fear upon Rome (once Mi≈øtre≈øs of the World) that many conjectured that if he went directly thither with his Fleet, the Romans would have for≈øaken the City; but then contrary to the expectation of mo≈øt, he ≈øhaped his Cour≈øe for Africk, re≈øolving to invade the Kingdom of Tunes, over which Reigned one Mulea≈ø≈øes, having a little before ≈øtepped into the Throne, by treacherou≈øly cau≈øing to be Murthered all his Brethren, except Ro≈øcetes and Abdemelech; the former of which having tryed his utmo≈øt fortune for the recovery of the Kingdom, in right appertaining to him as Elder Brother to Muea≈ø≈øes, he for his ≈øafety was fled to Con≈øtantinople, which opportunity Solyman laying hold on, to advantage his Wars in Africk, kept him as a Pri≈øoner at large, ≈øo that Babaru≈ø≈øa landing, and every where proclaiming the Name of Ro≈øcetes, whom the Moors and Numidians greatly favoured, hating Mulea≈ø≈øes for his extraordinary Tyranny; he had Biferta immediately pat into his po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion, the Moors thinking, as indeed the Turks gave it out, that
Ro≈øcetes was in the Fleet, and that the Turks had made ≈øo great a Preparation to re≈øtore him to his Fathers Kingdom.

Barbaru≈ø≈øa having ≈øecured Bi≈øerta with a ≈øtrong Garri≈øon, doubling the Promontorie where old Carthage ≈øtood, came to Gulletta, a ≈øtrong Ca≈øtle ≈øtanding within the Bay of Tunis, where in token of Friend≈øhip he ≈øaluted it, and had the like returned; but upon the reque≈øting the ≈øurrender thereof, he was an≈øwered, that it ≈øhould be alwaies at his Command, who ruled the City of Tunes, ≈øo that returning from thence, he came before the City, upon which by the per≈øwa≈øion of ≈øuch as affected Ro≈øcetes, Mulea≈ø≈øes fled with a ≈ømall number of his Favourites, and for ha≈øte left behind him mo≈øt of his Trea≈øure, which afterwards became a prey to the Enemy; Mulea≈ø≈øes fled, the people joyfully received Barbaru≈ø≈øa into Tunes, and with eager Eyes, and longing expectations, flockt into the high ≈øtreets to have a ≈øight of their new King, but when they perceived him not, and heard the Soldiers in their Acclamations name none but Solyman and Barbaru≈ø≈øa, they began to doubt as the truth was that, in≈øtead of their new King, whom they ≈øo much de≈øired, thay had received the Turki≈øh Government, which above all things they utterly abhorred; which ≈øu≈øpicion once confirmed by ≈øeveral of Ro≈øcet's Friends, whom Barbaru≈ø≈øa had brought with him on purpo≈øe to delude the people, who grieved to ≈øee the ruine of their Countrey at hand, for fear of pre≈øent danger did not ≈øpare to tell their Friends and Acquaintance, that in vain they expected Ro≈øcetes, who remained in Bonds at Con≈øtantinople, which wrought ≈øo ≈øudden an alteration in the minds of the Citizens, that perceiving them≈øelves deceived at the in≈øtance of Abdahar the Me≈øuar, or chief Magi≈øtrate,
who had before per≈øwaded Mulea≈ø≈øes to fly, in hopes of bringing in Ro≈øcetes, they every where run to their Arms, and from all parts of the City a≈ø≈øailed the Turks, but for the mo≈øt part being ≈ølightly Armed, and in a tumultuary di≈øorder they were not able to ≈øtand the fury of the Harquebu≈øiers; but after a long and ob≈øtinate Fight, wherein a great number were killed on both ≈øides, they ≈øubmitted them≈øelves; of which Mulea≈ø≈øes having notice, fled to Con≈øtantina, the Regal City of Dorax, a Numidian Prince his Kin≈øman, where he remained in ≈øafety till the coming of Charles the Emperor into Africk, as will appear in the ≈øequel of this Hi≈øtory.

Tunes thus taken, or rather ≈øurprized by Barbaru≈ø≈øa, all the other Cities thereto appertaining, were won with little difficulty, and annexed to the Turki≈øh Empire, till they were again ≈øundred by the Germans, and Mulea≈ø≈øes the Exil'd King re≈øtored by the Emperor: And in this po≈øture, leaving the Affairs of Africk, I ≈øhall take a view of Solyman's proceeding again≈øt the Per≈øians.

Hi≈ømael being dead, and Tamas his Son ≈øucceeding him, Ibrahim the Great Ba≈ø≈øa, who could do all with Solyman, per≈øwaded him that now a fit opportunity offered to be revenged on the Per≈øians, and the rather by the revolt of ∆≤lemus, a Noble Man of Per≈øia, who had E≈øpou≈øed King Tama's Si≈øter, who having Imbe≈øled the Revenues of the Crown, for fear of being called to account for ≈øo doing, was fled to Con≈øtantinople: But Solyman's Mother, and fair Concubine Roxolan greatly de≈øirous of his Company, much oppo≈øed the Motion of the Ba≈ø≈øa, laying before Solyman the danger and inconveniency of ≈øo tedious and dangerous an Expedition; but not being able to prevail, they ever after became Ibrahim's Mortal Enemies, not leaving to urge Solyman, till at
la≈øt he gave command that he ≈øhould be murthered.

Solyman re≈øolved upon an expedition again≈øt the Per≈øian, to revenge, as he pretended, the manifold injuries done to his Grandfather, Father, and him≈øelf, rai≈øed a great Army, part of which he ≈øent before him, under the Command of Ibrahim the Great Ba≈ø≈øa, and ∆≤lemas the Fugitive Per≈øian, who by ha≈øty Marches over the Mountains, and along the Banks of Euphrates, that ≈øetting down before the great City Taurus, and the Citizens de≈øpairing to be relieved by their King, he had the City delivered into his po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion, of which King Tames having notice, ha≈øted thither with his Army, but e're he attempt any thing for the recovery thereof, Solyman with a great multitude of Soldiers had joyned the Ba≈ø≈øa, whereupon he thought it not good to give Battle to ≈øo powerful an Enemy, but to hover about his Camp, and take all advantages, well knowing ≈øuch a World of people could not ≈øub≈øi≈øt, without exceeding ≈øtore of Provi≈øions and other nece≈ø≈øaries; which device of the Per≈øian, Solyman well perceiving, left a ≈øtrong Garri≈øon in Taurus, and marched again≈øt him, who ≈øtill retired before the Turks, even to the Walls of Sultania; near to which, Solyman pitching his Camp, lay many dayes to expect him; during which time, ≈øuch a horrible Tempe≈øt aro≈øe, that the Winds driving the Snow off from the ≈øteep Hills, buryed many Thou≈øands of the Turks alive, overthrowing mo≈øt of their Tents, and although it was but the middle of September, froze ≈øo hard, that many were froze to Death, others lo≈øt the u≈øe of their Limbs, and mo≈øt of the Camels and Hor≈øes peri≈øhed; which bad Omen, together with their Apprehen≈øions they had of the approach of the Enemy, and the horrible darkne≈øs of the Night, ≈øo di≈øcouraged
the Soldiers that they would all have fled, had they known which way. This Tempe≈øt they concluded to be rai≈øed by the Per≈øian Magicians to de≈øtroy them, but whether ≈øo, or not, it greatly di≈øcouraged Solyman, ≈øo that rai≈øing his Camp, he marched into A≈ø≈øyria, and ≈øet down before Babylon now Bagdat, which being altogether unprovided, upon the flight of the Governour, fell into his hands, as likewi≈øe did mo≈øt of the Cities, both of A≈ø≈øyria and Me≈øopotamia; and ≈øo far extended the terror of his Name; that mo≈øt of the Countreys round about, ≈øent their Emba≈ø≈øadors to tender their ≈øubjection; and in Babylon he Wintered his Army, placing Governours in the adjacent Cities. And a Beglerbeg, as they proudly term him, that is, a Lord of Lords. In Babylon, and under him, divers Sanzacks, or petty Lords, during his aboad here, he al≈øo cau≈øed his chief Trea≈øurer to be executed for Imbe≈øling his Revenues.

Tamas the Per≈øian King having by this time rai≈øed a con≈øiderable Army, marched to Tauris, at who≈øe approach the Garri≈øon fled; of which Solyman having notice, and being ≈øtrengthned with new ≈øupply out of Egypt, Syria, Judea, and Comagena; he left Babylon, re≈øolving to provoke the Per≈øian to Battle, or to ≈øack his regal City Tauris before his face, but Tames knowing him≈øelf too weak to give him Battle, at his approach drew out his Army, and fled into the Mountains of Hyrcania, de≈øtroying all before him, to prevent its falling into the hands of his Enemies; upon who≈øe departure, the Citizens opened their Gates to the Turks, whom they were no wayes able to re≈øi≈øt: yet notwith≈øtanding, at the Commandment of Solyman, the City was ≈øacked, the Kings Palace, and other ≈øtately Buildings levelled with the Ground, and a great number of
the Citizens lead into mi≈øerable Captivity, and thinking him≈øelf ≈øufficiently revenged, he re≈øolved to return with his Army into Me≈øopotamia; but having notice that the Per≈øian was following, even at his heels, he divided his Forces, leaving the Ba≈ø≈øas of Cair and Syria with ∆≤lemus the Fugitive Per≈øian, with Eighteen Thou≈øand to follow in the rere of his Army, to repel the a≈ø≈øaults of the Fore-runners of Tamas's Army; he marched with the re≈øt by ≈øpeedy Journeys to Amida, now called Caraemida: In the mean while Tamas coming to Tauris with his Army, being the flowr of Parthia, Media, Iberia, and Armenia; and beholding what de≈øolation the Turks had made in that famous City, was ≈øo inraged thereat, that he would have pur≈øued them with all his Army to revenge the injury at the hazard of a Battle, but being per≈øwaded they were gone too far to be overtaken, and the Gentlemen of which his Army chiefly con≈øi≈øted, ≈øeemed altogether unwilling to undertake ≈øo tedious a march, he was content to ≈øtay at Tauris, and ≈øend Delimeuthes, a Noble Man of Per≈øia, (who freely offered him≈øelf to undertake it) with Five Thou≈øand ≈øwift Hor≈øe to follow them; and as he ≈øaw his advantage to cut off the Enemies rear, the which he ≈øo ≈øpeedily performed, that ≈øurprizing the Eighteen Thou≈øand under the Command of the two Ba≈ø≈øas, and ∆≤lemas, as they lay ≈øecurely near the Ca≈øtle of Belthis, that being a≈ø≈øi≈øted with the Garri≈øon Soldiers, he put them almo≈øt all to the Sword,, the Ba≈ø≈øas and ∆≤lemas hardly e≈øcaping upon their ≈øwift Hor≈øe to tell the news, for which ≈øervice he was highly rewarded by Tamas.

The≈øe reiterated lo≈ø≈øes greatly perplexed Solyman, ≈øo that calling to mind the pre≈øages his Mother had made of his evil ≈øucce≈øs in that expedition of that he was wholly lead thereto by the Council Ibrahim, Ba≈ø≈øa,
he therefore conceived ≈øuch a di≈øplea≈øure again≈øt him, as ended in his de≈øtruction: for upon his Arrival to Con≈øtantinople, he gave ≈øuch countenance to tho≈øe that brought complaints, again≈øt which before they dur≈øt not do; that at the earne≈øt Reque≈øt of Roxo ‚Ä¢ ana ‚Ä¢
who≈øe Son Bajazet the Ba≈ø≈øa hindred from a≈øpiring to „Äà‚óä„Äâ Empire, and rather favouring Mu≈øtapha, Solym ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢
„Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ another Woman, that he con≈øented to his „Äà‚óä„Äâ made away; and by rea≈øon he had ≈øworn never to injure his per≈øon whil≈øt he lived; he cau≈øed for the ≈øaving of his Oath, an Eunuch to cut his Throat whil≈øt he ≈ølept; which Je≈øuitical Eva≈øion he learned of the Mu≈øti, or Chief Mahometan Prie≈øt, who being con≈øulted on the matter, gave his opinion that Men only are alive, when they Move, Act, and Enjoy their perfect Sences: and that ≈øleep depriving them of their rea≈øonable Faculties, rendered them as dead Men. Some there are that report the fall of this great Man, who whil≈øt he ≈øtood high in his Ma≈øters favour, in effect ruled the Turki≈øh Empire to be cau≈øed by his too much favouring the Chri≈øtians, who having in his younger years been brought up in that profe≈ø≈øion, ≈øtill continued a Chri≈øtian in his heart; and that to ≈øpare the ≈øhedding of Chri≈øtian Blood as much as in him lay: He turned the Emperors Forces again≈øt the Infidels; yet, however it happened, his Body with a great weight fixed to it, was ca≈øt into the Sea, and all his Wealth, which was ine≈øtimable, except a ≈ømall portion alotted for the maintenance of his Wife and Children, was ≈øeized to the behoof of Solyman.

Tunes as afore≈øaid being taken by Barbaru≈ø≈øa, and all the other Cities obliged to ≈øubmit to the Turki≈øh obedience, Charles the Emperor, who was likewi≈øe King of Spain, not liking ≈øo potent a Neighbour,
leavyed great Forces, ≈øolicited thereto by Mulea≈ø≈øes the Exil'd King; and in revenge of the Injuries ≈øu≈øtained by Barbaru≈ø≈øa, re≈øolved to drive him out of that part of Africk, when appointing Alphon≈øus, D'valus, Va≈øtius, General of the Footmen; he with Seven Hundred Sail of great and ≈ømall Ships and Galleys, ≈øtood with the African Coa≈øt, when dubling the Promontory of Carthage came to an Anchor before a Ca≈øtle, which by rea≈øon of a great Well beneath, is it called by the name of Aquaria, or the Water Ca≈øtle; who≈øe unexpected arrival ≈øo terrified Barbaru≈ø≈øa, dreaming of nothing le≈øs that he was about to have fled with all his Turks; but then fearing to fall into Solymans di≈øplea≈øure, which to do, he knew was certain death; upon ≈øecond thoughts, though he re≈øolved to make all the defence he was able again≈øt ≈øo powerful an Army as the Emperor lead after him, and thereby get him the name of a valiant Soldier, though he de≈øpaired with the Forces he had to keep either the Cities or Ca≈øtles; whereupon he did what he could to incourage his men with many vain-glorious-≈øpeeches; and into the ≈øtrong Ca≈øtle of Guletta, ≈øtanding upon the bottom of the Bay of Carthage upon a point of Land incompa≈ø≈øed almo≈øt round with the Sea, and the great Lake; he thru≈øt his mo≈øt re≈øolute Captains and Janizaries, him≈øelf remaining in Tunis to expect ≈øupplyes out of Numidia; at what time the Emperor having with his great and ≈ømall ≈øhot obliged tho≈øe that guarded the ≈øhoar to retire. He landed his men, and intrenched them every Nation by them≈øelves, during which, they had ‚Ä¢ equent skirmi≈øhes with the Numidian Hor≈øemen, nor were they le≈øs mole≈øted by the Garri≈øon, who ≈øallyed as often as they ≈øaw their advantage; when one dayes ≈øallying under the Command of Salacia ‚Ä¢
Arch-Pirate,
they came up to the Mount, near the Ca≈øtle, commanded by Count Serney, a man famous both for the Honour of his Hou≈øe, and great Exploits in War; who not u≈øing to be ≈øo braved, de≈øcended with the Italians under his Command to drive them back by force; but the Enemy being far ≈øuperiour in number, and the Spaniards who were intrenched next him, looking on, and not coming out to ≈øuccour him, he there fighting valiantly, was ≈ølain; but the Spaniards, though they ≈øecretly rejoyced at the overthrow of the Count, who had ≈øo often eclip≈øed their Glory, fared not better; for the next day Tobacches another of the Turks Captains ≈øallying out, charged them in their Trenches, killing many of them, and taking what they found therein.

The≈øe Lo≈ø≈øes made the General ≈øharply reprove the Captains of their neglect of duty, in watching to prevent the dangerous attempts of ≈øo politique an Enemy; which ≈øo wrought with the Captains and Soldiers, that to regain their credit, they vowed to ≈øhun no danger, nor were they inferiour to their promi≈øe; for Giaffer, Captain of the Janizaries ≈øallying out again≈øt the Spaniards, was him≈øelf ≈ølain together with mo≈øt of his Men whom the Chri≈øtians pur≈øued, even to the Gate of the Ca≈øtle, and had entered with tho≈øe that fled, had not tho≈øe that were entered, ≈øhut out a great number of their Fellows to prevent it, who were all ≈ølain or taken Pri≈øoners: after which, the Emperor cau≈øed his Batteries to be mounted, whil≈øt Auria with the Fleet blocked up the Ca≈øtle to the Sea-ward, ≈øo that what from the Ships and the Mounts, the great Ordnance in manner of an Earthquake ≈øo terribly roated, that their continual „Äà‚óä„Äâ made it ≈øeem as if the Earth would have ‚Ä¢ ent in ≈øunder,
and cau≈øed the Sea, which before was calm, to mount, as if it had been inraged with a Tempe≈øt; the Air likewi≈øe became thick, and the Sky was darkned with ≈ømoak, ≈øo that after ten hours ince≈ø≈øant battery, the Vamures, and Walls of the Ca≈øtle were in many places beaten down: the Turks Canon and Canoneers lying buried together in the Rubbi≈øh, ≈øo that the defendants utterly de≈øpairing longer to hold it, fled over a wooden Bridge layed for that purpo≈øe, who being fiercely pur≈øued by the Chri≈øtians, were mo≈øt of them ≈ølain; in≈øomuch, that the Surface of the Lake was well nigh covered with dead bodies.

The ≈øtrong Ca≈øtle thus taken, and mo≈øt of the Turks Fleet of Galleys at A ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ hor in the Lake, yielded to the Conqueror; upon notice of which, Mulea≈ø≈øes the Moori≈øh King came to the Emperors Tent, and humbled him≈øelf at his Feet, promi≈øing to become his tributary, de≈øiring as his Va≈ø≈øal to be received into his protection, ≈øwearing never to forget ≈øo great a Benefit, with many the like expre≈ø≈øions; which ≈øo moved the Emperour, that he promi≈øed to re≈øtore him without any other Tribute, than yearly paying a brace of Falcons, and a brace of Barbary Hor≈øes; as likewi≈øe to maintain a Thou≈øand Chri≈øtian Soldiers to keep for him the Ca≈øtle of Guletta, and ever after to be kind to all Chri≈øtians either Inhabiting, or that ≈øhould have occa≈øion to pa≈øs through his Countrey, telling him further, that if he failed in any point, tho≈øe Armes that re≈øtored him, could again depo≈øe him.

Matters thus concluded, the Emperour marched again≈øt Tunis, where Barbaru≈ø≈øa, with the remainder of his Forces were in Garri≈øon, who upon the
approach of the Chri≈øtians, drew out his Forces, con≈øi≈øting for the mo≈øt part of Numidian Hor≈øemen, but ≈øcarcely endured the fir≈øt charge, e're he betook him≈øelf to flight, and again entered the City of Tunis, where in his mad mood, he determined to kill all the Chri≈øtian Pri≈øoners; and had put his bloody intent into practi≈øe, had he not been di≈ø≈øwaded therefrom by Sinan a Jew, one of his chief Captains, which turned to his great di≈øadvantage; for the Captives, to the number of Six Thou≈øand, hearing in what danger they were in, bur≈øt out of the Dungeons in the Ca≈øtle where they lay in Irons, and killing ≈øuch Turks as they found therein, barracaded the doors, ≈øeizing on ≈øuch Armour as came fir≈øt to hand, made ≈øigns to the Emperor, from the Battlements, that they kept the Ca≈øtle to his behoof; which Barbaru≈ø≈øa perceiving, and that all his intreaties for the rendition of it was in vain: he in a great rage abandoned the City with ≈øuch of his followers as would attend him, and fled by Sea in Fourteen Galleys to the City of Bona.

The Turks having de≈øerted Tunis, the Magi≈øtrates came forth with the Keyes to meet the Emperor, who without any re≈øi≈øtance entered the City, which he laboured to ≈øave from the ≈øpoil, but ≈øuch was the fury of the Soldiers, that they could not be re≈øtrained neither by the Emperor, nor Va≈øtius the General, but ≈øeizing upon all they found, killed ≈øuch of the Moors as re≈øi≈øted them; ≈øo that in a ≈øhort time all was in a confu≈øion, and great riches carryed to the Ships and Galleys, together with many Captives: mo≈øt of which the Emperor cau≈øed to be re≈øtored, and the re≈øt were redeeme ‚Ä¢ by Mulea≈ø≈øes.

Barbaru≈ø≈øa not thinking him≈øelf ≈øafe at Hippona, upon the coming of Auria with the Fleet, fled to
Argier, of which the Emperor having notice, he placing Mulea≈ø≈øes in the Kingdom of Tune≈ø≈øes, and furni≈øhing Guletta with all manner of Warlike Provi≈øion, with a Thou≈øand Spaniards to ≈øecure it, returned in Triumph to Naples, Anno 1537; when the ≈øame year Solyman envying at the Portugals trade in the Ea≈øt-Indies, ≈øent Solyman Ba≈ø≈øa, accompanied with A≈øau Beg, a famous Pirate, commonly called the Moor of Alexandria, with a Fleet to mole≈øt them, who ≈øailing through the Red-Sea, came as far as the River Indus, where with all their power they a≈ø≈øaulted Dium a Ca≈øtle of the Portugals, ≈øcituate upon the mouth of that great River; but after many dayes ≈øiege, both by Sea and Land having tryed their utmo≈øt force, they were glad to retire, leaving behind them for ha≈øt mo≈øt of their great Ordnance: when coming to Aden, a rich City in Arabia Foelix, they allured the King thereof on board their Galleys, with promi≈øe of ≈øafe conduct, but having him in their power contrary to their Oaths, they hanged him up at the Yards Arm of the Admirals Galley, and plundered the City; the like they did to another City in the ≈øame Tract called Zibith, and returned to Con≈øtantinople, one by Sea, and the other by Land; at what time Solyman ≈øolicited thereto by John Forre≈øt the French Kings Amba≈ø≈øador, was preparing for the Inva≈øion of Italy, and having for that purpo≈øe rai≈øed Two Hundred Thou≈øand Men, ≈øending before him Lutzis Ba≈ø≈øa, and Barbaru≈ø≈øa, with a great Fleet, who landing at Otranto, and conducted by one Troilus Pignatellus, a Fugitive Italian, ≈øeized on Ca≈øtrum, which contrary to their Faith given, they plundered; carrying mo≈øt of the people Pri≈øoners, at what time Solyman had by night ≈øent over ≈øeveral Troops of Light-Hor≈øemen in great Palendars, who running all along
the Sea Coa≈øt from Tarentum to Brundu≈øium, for the ≈øpace of Forty miles, rummaged the Countrey, carrying away a great booty, and had been likely enough, had Solyman, as he intended, ≈øeconded them with his great power to have overrun all Italy; but providence ≈øo ordered it, that by the wilfulne≈øs of Alexander Contarenus a Venetian Captain, who meeting with the Admiral of Callipolis, and he not vailing his top-≈øail, nor in token of Reverence and Friend≈øhip di≈øcharge his great Ordnance, offended with his proud in≈øolency, fiercely a≈ø≈øailed the Squadron of Galleys under his command, of which he ≈øunk two, the Admiral him≈øelf peri≈øhing in one of them, and not long after, for the like in≈øolency, the Venetian Admiral cau≈øed Junusbeus, Solymans chief Interpreter, pa≈ø≈øing by Coreyrae to be a≈ø≈øailed, when to ≈øave him≈øelf and his Turks, he forceing his Galleys on ≈øhoar near unto the Mountains, called Acroceraunii, he fell into a wor≈øe danger, for being taken by the Mountainiers, mo≈øt of his people were ≈ølain, and him≈øelf hardly relea≈øed for a great ≈øum of money.

The≈øe Breaches of Peace, as the Turks termed them, ≈øo much incen≈øed Solyman, that he recalled his Forces then in Puglia, re≈øolving to turn his whole power upon the Venetians, upon who≈øe return Auria falling in with Twelve Galleys laden with Janizaries, and cho≈øen Hor≈øemen of the Court after a ≈øharp conflict to them all, which proved a great weakning to the Tyrants Fleet, yet he de≈øperately bent again≈øt the Venetians, re≈øolving to take from them the rich I≈øland of Corcyra, but by the way him≈øelf had like to have been ≈ølain in his Tent by a Mountainier, which had been effected, had he not been di≈øcovered by the cracking of a bough; to revenge which, he ≈øent his Janizaries, and other
his approved Soldiers, who hunting the people inhabiting the high and rough Mountains of Chimera, like wild Bea≈øts killed many of them, and returned with ≈øuch ≈øpoil, as they found, after which, he with a great Fleet landed on the I≈øle of Corcyra, now called Corfu, (for fear of whom, the Venetian Admiral ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ thdrew with his Galleys into the Adriatick Gulf, „Äà‚óä„Äâ to expect the other part of his Fleet) yet „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ long while battered the chief City, in vain „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ him≈øelf with the ≈øpoil of the Villages, „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ Thou≈øand Chri≈øtian Pri≈øoners departed; „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ return landing on the I≈øle of Naxos,
„Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ the City, which not being furni≈øhed to „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ ≈øo powerful an Army, con≈øented to pay the T ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ant Five thou≈øand Duckates a year Tribute, and to hold the Seigniorie of him, whereupon, without doing further harm, he departed to Con≈øtantinople; at who≈øe return Lutzis Ba≈ø≈øa was accu≈øed by his Wife, Solymans Si≈øter of Sodomy, and for that ≈øhe having in private reproved him thereof, he had ≈øtruck her a box on the Ear, and confined her as a Pri≈øoner to her Chamber; which complaint ≈øo incen≈øed Solyman, who for his Si≈øters ≈øake had rai≈øed him from a low Degree, to the highe≈øt Honour next him≈øelf, that he bani≈øhed him into Macedonia, where he ≈øpent the remainder of his dayes in a poor and private life.

Though Solyman was returned to Con≈øtantinople, yet his Wars with the Venetians ended not, for he ≈øent ≈øtrict command to his Governours and Lieutenants bordering upon their frontiers, to vex them them with all manner Ho≈øtilities; who were not wanting to ≈øatisfie him therein, nor the Venetians on their part to revenge the injuries; but the fiercene≈øs of the Turks were ≈øomewhat re≈øtrained by a War undertaken by King Ferdinand again≈øt them,
to revenge former injuries, who rai≈øing a great power of gallant Soldiers of divers Nations, ≈øent them under the leading of Cazzianer, by who≈øe Cowardize in leading them through Woods, and by-wayes, many of them peri≈øhed for hunger; others to avoid that calamity, de≈øerted him, and in fine, the General for≈øaking his Army (for which he was afterward executed) It was overthrown near Exek, and all the Soldiers either ≈ølain, or taken Pri≈øoners.

The news of this great overthrow much troubled the Chri≈øtian Princes to repair; which di≈øgrace the Emperor, the Venetians, and the Pope ≈øet out a great Fleet of Galleys, which meeting at Corcyra, the Admirals con≈øulted what was be≈øt to be done, when upon notice that Barbaru≈ø≈øa lay with the Turki≈øh Galleys in the Bay of Ambracia, they re≈øolved to ≈øail thither, where having a while braved him, the bold Turk incited thereto by one of Solymans Eun ‚Ä¢ chs, came forth to give them battle, which Auria perceiving contrary to the minds of the Captains, ≈øtood away to Corcyra, in the rear of whom the Turks fall, took ≈øeveral of the ≈øtragling Galleys: This retreat, or rather flight, much eclip≈øed the fame of Auria, who before was accounted a ≈øecond Neptune; but being ≈øtill followed by Barbaru≈ø≈øa, he returned into Italy, to the great di≈ølike of the Venetians, without effecting any thing worthy of memory; which gave the proud Turk opportunity to make great ≈øpoil on the Sea Coa≈øt, and on the I≈ølands of the Sea, yet held by the Venetians, and to recover Ca≈øtronovum, a little before taken by the Chri≈øtians, though not without infinite ≈ølaughter on either ≈øide; it being for a long time manfully defended by Sarmentus a Valiant Spani≈øh Captain, who among≈øt heaps of ≈ølain expired in the bed of Honour.

Things being at this pa≈øs, the Emperor made a peace with the French King, both which Potentates ≈øolicited the Venetians by their Emba≈ø≈øadors to continue the War again≈øt Solyman, but they weary thereof, as lying mo≈øt obnoxious to his fury, could not be per≈øwaded thereto, but laboured to procure a peace, which with much difficulty they obtained. In con≈øideration whereof they yield unto him Nauplium and Epidaurus, two Cities of Pelopone≈øus, together with Nadium and Labrania, two Ca≈øtles of Dalmatia, which happened by rea≈øon the ≈øecrets of their Emba≈ø≈øey was beforehand di≈øcovered to Solyman by ≈øeveral treacherous Venetians, bribed by him for that purpo≈øe; ≈øome of which being afterward taken, were worthily executed at the ≈øame time; a ≈øecret con≈øideration between John King of Hungary, and Ferdinand King of Bohemia (including that upon the decea≈øe of the former, the latter ≈øhould enjoy his Kingdom) was di≈øcovered to Solyman, which grievou≈øly incen≈øed him again≈øt the Hungarian King, whom by his Armes he had re≈øtored to his Kingdom to appea≈øe, which he was content to marry I≈øabella, Daughter to Sigi≈ømund, King of Polonia, by whom he had I≈ø≈øue a Son, who after his Fathers Death was crowned King of Hungary, and taken into Solymans protection, by that means bereaving King Ferdinand of his hope of a peaceable po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion; whereupon after having reque≈øted it by his Emba≈ø≈øadors of Solyman, and de≈øpairing that way to obtain it, he with a great Army entered the Kingdom, and ≈øeized upon Vicegrade, Pe≈øth, Vacia, and Alba Regalis: To oppo≈øe which ≈øudden Tempe≈øt e're it had ≈øwept away all her Cities; the Queen ≈øent her Emba≈ø≈øadors to Solyman to crave Aid again≈øt King Ferdinand, whereupon he not only ≈øent the young King her Son ≈øeveral Rich Pre≈øents, but his
Letters Mandatory to his Lieutenants on the Frontiers, with all their Forces to a≈ø≈øi≈øt her, threatning that if by their neglect ≈øhe received any dammage, their heads ≈øhould make ≈øatisfaction; and withal, cau≈øed La≈øcus, King Ferdinands Emba≈ø≈øador at that time re≈øiding at Con≈øtantinople to be impri≈øoned.

This news was joyful to the Queen, whereupon ≈øhe drawing together all her Forces, joyned them with tho≈øe Mahometes, and ∆≤stref, two of Solymans Ba≈ø≈øas had brought into the field, and immediately layed ≈øiege to Vacia which they took, and to prevent its again falling into the hands of the Bohemians, ≈øet it on fire; Vacia thus layed wa≈øte, they removed to Pe≈øth, to which they layed ≈øtraight ≈øiege, but after many un≈øucce≈øsful attempts to carry it by ≈øtorm, rai≈øed their Camp, and returned over Danubius, upon which King Ferdinand ≈øent a great Army under the Leading of the Lord William Regendorff, who entring the Kingdom, layed ≈øiege to Buda, and ≈øent Me≈ø≈øengers to ≈øummon the Queen to ≈øurrender the City to his Ma≈øter, and that in lieu thereof, and of the other Cities, ≈øhe ≈øhould have be≈øtowed on her freely the Seignory of Sepu≈øia, to which George, Bi≈øhop of Veradium, who altogether governed the Queen, an≈øwered that ≈øhe ≈øhould accept no ≈øuch proffer, and with many opprobrious words di≈ømi≈ø≈øed the Me≈ø≈øengers, whereupon Regendorff having mounted his Canon, furiou≈øly battered the City, making ≈øeveral wide breaches, but they were ≈øo notably defended, that the Germans nor Spaniards could not enter, which they perceiving, ≈øo dealt with one Bornemi≈ø≈øa a great man in the City, that he promi≈øed to deliver them a Gate in the night to enter by, which accordingly he performed, but having agreed that none but Hungarians ≈øhould enter, the better to prevent the effu≈øion of blood; and Regendorff
contrary to that agreement, ≈øending in Germans under the Leading of their Captains, to be more ≈øure of the City, the Traitor repenting of what he had undertaken, refu≈øed to lead them to the Market place, and they ≈øtill remaining in the narrow ≈øtreets, and not knowing which way to go, a ≈øufficient number could not enter e're the Alarum was taken, upon which the Citizens, and Garri≈øon Souldiers running to their Armes, a≈ø≈øaulted them on every ≈øide, who being in a ≈øtrange place, and their fear augmented by the terror of the night, fled back fa≈øter than they advanced.

Spring being come, Solyman ≈øent a great Army under the Leading of Mahometes Ba≈ø≈øa, to the A≈ø≈øi≈øtance of the Queen; which pa≈ø≈øing, the Danubius intrenched within half a mile of the Bohemians, Germans, and Italians, under the command of the Lord Regendorff, and dayly with skirmi≈øhes perplexed him, having likewi≈øe fortified an I≈øland lying in the River, called Ceppelia, as the General of the Chri≈øtians had done another oppo≈øite to his Camp, between which pa≈ø≈øed likewi≈øe many skirmi≈øhes, but at length the Turks pouring a great number of their men on ≈øhoar in the I≈øland held by the Chri≈øtians, cau≈øed them to leave the Fortifications, and flie over the Bridge layed to pa≈øs, and repa≈øs to the Camp, but by the valour of the German Soldiers all was quickly regained, and the City furiou≈øly a≈ø≈øaulted, though without ≈øucce≈øs, for that a great number of the be≈øieged continually kept ≈øuch breaches as the Canon had made, and the Be≈øiegers, by rea≈øon of the nearne≈øs of the Turks Army, dur≈øt not go to the a≈ø≈øault in ≈øuch number as otherwi≈øe they might have done, yet they had ≈øo battered the Walls, that they de≈øpaired not to win it in a ≈øhort time; but in the height of their Expectation, news came, that Solyman
with a great power, was near at hand to joyn the Ba≈ø≈øa already incamped, which infu≈øed ≈øuch a fear into the Chri≈øtians that the Soldiers whether their General would or no, re≈øolved to rai≈øe the Seige and pa≈øs the Danubius. So that he was con≈øtrained to accord to the re≈øolves, and in the dead of the night rai≈øed the Siege, but not ≈øo ≈øecretly but the Turks had notice ≈øent them of what had happened, by tho≈øe in the City: Whereupon bur≈øting out of their Camp, and the Citizens at the ≈øame time ≈øallying by the light of a ≈øtack of ≈øtraw, and pur≈øued them with great ≈ølaughter; in≈øomuch that mo≈øt part of the Army was either drowned in the ha≈øty pa≈ø≈øage, or fell by the Sword, not above a third part of them e≈øcaping to Comora. So that a great booty by that means fell into the hands of the Turks.

Upon this defeat Pe≈øih being de≈øerted of her Garri≈øon, was taken without re≈øi≈øtance by Ca≈øon, the Turks Fleet then in the Danubius, and mo≈øt that were found therein put to the Sword. The Lord Regendorf as a man not de≈øirous to outlive ≈øo foul a di≈øhonour brought upon him by the wilfulne≈øs of his unruly Souldiers, would have died fighting among≈øt the thicke≈øt of his Enemy, had he not again≈øt his will by ≈øtrong hand been forced into a Pinace, and ≈øo carryed by his Captains to Comora, within five days after Solyman came to Buda, and according to his wonted cruelty cau≈øed all the Pri≈øoners to be put to death, and one among≈øt the re≈øt a German Souldier being of wonderous height, he appointed to be ≈ølain by his Dwarff, who≈øe head reached not pa≈øt his knees, which he ordered to be done in deri≈øion of the German Nation.

Solyman having pitched his Camp near Buda, ≈øent his Amba≈ø≈øadors with Pre≈øents to the Young King, viz. Three beautiful Hor≈øes, with their Bridles of
Gold, and their Trapings ≈øet with precious ≈øtones, and three Robes of cloth of Gold, and unto every one of the chief Nobility a chain of Gold, and rich Gowns; upon the delivery of the≈øe pre≈øents, as they had it in charge, they reque≈øted that the Queen would cau≈øe the young King to be ≈øent to the Camp to Solyman, who was greatly de≈øirous to ≈øee him and that he was re≈øolved to take him and his Kingdom into protection, until ≈øuch time as he ≈øhould of him≈øelf be able to defend it again≈øt his potent Adver≈øary. This reque≈øt of the Amba≈ø≈øadors (though not without ≈øome ≈øcruple) was granted, and the young King being then in his ≈øwadling Cloths, was ≈øent in a rich Chariot, together with his Nur≈øe and ≈øeveral great Ladies, attended on by ≈øuch of the Nobility, to whom Solyman had ≈øent pre≈øents; upon who≈øe Arrival the Tyrant took him in his arms, and looked upon him commanding his ≈øons then pre≈øent, viz. Selymus and Bajazet begotten on the fair Ro ‚Ä¢ colana to ki≈øs him, in token of there love to him: from thence forward yet notwith≈øtanding the≈øe fair ≈øhews, he con≈øulted with his Ba≈ø≈øa's whether he ≈øhould retain the King and ≈øeize on the Kingdom of Hungary, having before cau≈øed his Soldiers to po≈ø≈øe≈øs them≈øelves of one of the Gates of Buda, called Sabatina, it was likewi≈øe debated whether all the Nobility then in his po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion ≈øhould be put to death, or carried into bondage; of all which opinions were ≈øome of his Ba≈ø≈øa's, and others of a far more mild opinion. So that Solyman, when he well con≈øidered what had been argued, re≈øolved upon a method between the one and the other, when entering Buda on the 30th. of Augu≈øt, anno 1541. after he had ≈øacrificed to his vain Prophet, in the Cathedral, dedicated to the Virgin Mary, he publi≈øhed a Decree (the fatal doom of that flouri≈øhing Kingdom, under which it at this day
groans.) That Buda ≈øhould from that day be kept with a Garri≈øon of Turks, and the Kingdom be converted into a Province of the Turki≈øh Empire, that the Queen with her ≈øon, the young King ≈øhould pre≈øently depart the City and live in Lippa, a fertil and quiet Countrey beyond the River Tibi≈øcus near to the borders of her fathers Kingdom, and to be ≈øafely conducted thither with all her Wealth and Jewels by the Janizaries; of which hard conditions the Queen was glad to accept upon which the Hungarian Nobility, all but Valentinus her General were ≈øet at Liberty, having before been retained as Pri≈øoners in the Turki≈øh Camp.

King Ferdinand re≈øiding at Vienna, upon notice of what had pa≈ø≈øed, and that Solyman was purpo≈øed to invade his Territories; fir≈øt ≈øending to collect his di≈øper≈øed Forces, afterwards he ≈øent Count Salma and Sigi≈ømund Lethe≈øtaine, noble and grave Councellors his Amba≈ø≈øadors to Solyman with rich pre≈øents which were a ≈øtanding cup of Gold after the German fa≈øhion, richly be≈øet with pearls and pretious ≈øtones, and a wonderful Silver Globe of mo≈øt rare and curious device, daily expre≈ø≈øing the hourly pa≈ø≈øing of the time, the motion of the Planets, the Change and Full of the Moon, the motion of the Superiour Orbs, ever moving by certain wheels or weights curiou≈øly conveyed within the ≈øame, exactly keeping due time and motion, lively expre≈ø≈øing the wonderful motion and conver≈øion of the cele≈øtial frame, a curious and ≈øtrange peice of work devi≈øed and perfected by the mo≈øt cunning A≈øtronomers of Maximilian the Emperour, who≈øe noble mind never ≈øpared for any co≈øt to obtain things rare of ≈øtrange device.

The Amba≈ø≈øadors arriving at Solymans Camp, after they had been fea≈øted by the Ba≈ø≈øa's with Mutton and Rice onely, and delivered their Pre≈øents, they
made it their reque≈øt that he would deliver Hungary to their Ma≈øter, to whom of right it appertained, and that in lien thereof he would become his tributary; but were ≈øo far from having their de≈øires granted, that the proud Turk demanded tribute for Au≈øtria, the which being refu≈øed with di≈ødaign he ≈øent the Governour of Belgrade to ≈øpoil that Country, as likewi≈øe Moravia, to whom he joyned Ca≈øon the Admiral of his Fleet; but by rea≈øon of the overflowing of the Rivers and great Rains, it being now Autumn they were forced to return without doing any con≈øiderable dammage: after which Solyman appointing a Hungarian of his own name Governour of Buda returned to Con≈øtantinople, having fir≈øt ≈øet La≈øcus King Ferdinand's former Amba≈ø≈øador (whom he held Pri≈øoner) at Liberty, and within a while after having cau≈øed Mayle Vayvod of Tran≈øilvania to be apprehended, and impri≈øoned contrary to his promi≈øe, by Mahometes his great Ba≈ø≈øa; he to recompence the Queen of Hungary and her ≈øon for what he had taken from them, gave the young King the Province of Tran≈øilvania.

Whil≈øt the≈øe things pa≈ø≈øed, the Emperour Charles at the earne≈øt reque≈øt of his Subjects of Spain, to who≈øe Trade the Pirates of Argier had put a ≈øtop, prepared a great Fleet to invade the Kingdom, and take the City, at that time commanded by A≈øan Aga, or A≈øan the Eunuch, whom Barbaro≈ø≈øa in his ab≈øence had appointed his Lieutenant, when as the Emperour after con≈øiderable dammage by ≈øhipwrack coming before the City of Argier; ≈øent a Herald on ≈øhore to demand the City, and upon the refu≈øal of its delivery landed his men, who with great courage beating the Turks, Moors, and Numidians from their defences, leaped on ≈øhore, where after divers skirmi≈øhes they encamped in three Battles, being in all
60000 Men but long they had not con≈øidered which way to make their approaches, e're by a horrible Tempe≈øt (≈øuppo≈øed to be rai≈øed by Inchantment) which continued for the ≈øpace of two dayes, the greate≈øt part of the Fleet con≈øi≈øting of 280 Ships and Gallies was beaten, and ≈øuch as by ≈øwimming e≈øcaped the danger of the Sea, were kill'd by the Numidians and Moors, who came down from the Mountains to enrich them≈øelves by the mi≈øery of the Chri≈øtians. In this ≈øtorm which was accompanied with prodigious Rain, Thunder and Lightening almo≈øt all the Previ≈øion, and great Ordnance were lo≈øt: nor fared they on ≈øhoar much better, for there three parts of the Tents were torn up, and all things in them ≈øpoiled by the deluges of Water, ≈øo that Famine within three dayes ≈øorely vexed the Camp; yet the Emperour, a man of invincible Courage, comforted his men in the be≈øt wi≈øe, cau≈øing ≈øuch Hor≈øes as were on ≈øhoar to be killed, and their Fle≈øh di≈øtributed among≈øt the Souldiers, which at than time proved excellent fare; but finding he could not ≈øub≈øi≈øt, by the per≈øwa≈øion of the Duke of Alva his General, he re≈øolved to imbark on tho≈øe few Ships and Gallies that were left, and return into Italy, whereupon to make room for the Souldiers he cau≈øed all the Hor≈øes to be thrown overboard, but ≈øuch was his hard fortune, that he was no ≈øooner imbarked but another Tempe≈øt terrible as the former, aro≈øe and ≈øcattering his Fleet, drove two Ships loaden with Spaniards into the Port of Argier, who by rea≈øon of the departure of the other Gallies had been there ≈ølain by the Moors and Numidians, had not A≈øan Aga at their earne≈øt reque≈øt taken them into mercy, and driven away the barbarous people, who like ravening Wolves ≈øought eagerly to prey upon their Lives: Many ≈øhips in their return were likewi≈øe
≈øwallowed up of the Sea, but Heaven ≈øo ordered it that at length the Emperour with the remainder of his ≈øhattered ≈øhips arrived at the Port of New Carthage in Spain, not being overcome by the Enemy but by the Tempe≈øt, his ≈øad di≈øa≈øter being at the beginning of his Expedition foretold, by a Witch then living in the City of Argiers.

Frances the French King being greatly offended with the Emperor, for that Antonius Rinuo his Amba≈ø≈øador, upon his negotiation to Con≈øtantinople, was by ≈øome of the Emperors Captains ≈ølain, for that it being reported that he there di≈øcovered all the Emperours intentions, and incen≈øed Solyman to take up Arms again≈øt him, being the principal occa≈øion of his la≈øt Expedition into Hungary; whereupon he having ≈øent Polinus in the ≈øtead of Rinuo, he incited Solyman to revenge the indignity as well offered to him as to himfelf, by ≈øending Barbarus with a ≈øquadron of Gallies to mole≈øt the coa≈øt of Spain, and the Emperours Territories in Italy, whil≈øt his Ma≈øter warred on his Countries in Flanders and other places. To undertake the like he ≈øolicited the Venetians, but at that time both his negotiation proved ineffectual, for the Venetians utterly refu≈øed to intermeddle, and the Turk at that time being but ≈ølenderly provided with ≈øhipping, and tho≈øe was inforced to u≈øe on the Danube for the defence of Hungary, which King Ferdinando in confederation with the German Princes invaded with a great Army, under the leading of Joachimus Marque≈øs of Brandenburgh, who pa≈ø≈øing the Damibius encamped before Pe≈øth, which they battered for ≈øeveral dayes, making divers large breaches, but upon notice that Mahometes Ba≈ø≈øa was coming from Belgrade, with a great Army to relieve the City, though the ≈øtory was altogether feigned, the cowardly General rai≈øed the ≈øiege, and returned to
Vienna where that great Army con≈øi≈øting of 50000 Hor≈øe and Foot was broke up, without doing any thing worthy of name.

Solyman being rid of this fear began to hearken to the reque≈øt of the French Amba≈ø≈øador, and having Commanded Ru≈øtan Ba≈ø≈øa his Son-in-law to Fea≈øt him, he gave order for the making ready his Fleet of Gallies, which he ≈øent under the command of Barbaro≈ø≈øa to the Aid of the French, who to wreck his private revenge called in the common Enemy, too prone of him≈øelf to lay Chri≈øtendom wa≈øt. In their way when once di≈øpatched they took Rhegium, burnt it, and carried away the Garri≈øon, and Citizens, at which time Solyman with a great Army entered Hungary, to revenge him≈øelf upon the Authors of the late Ho≈øtilities, and had the ≈øtrong City and Ca≈øtle of Walpo delivered to him by the Souldiers, contrary to the will of the Governour, but he was no ≈øooner po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed thereof then he gave them the due Reward of their Treachery, by cau≈øing them all to be put to the Sword; and then having left there a ≈øufficient Garri≈øon, he marched to Strigonium, ≈øending Amurathes Ba≈ø≈øa with a part of the Army to take in Soclo≈øia, which he having won, put mo≈øt of the Inhabitants to the Sword.

Solyman having layed ≈øiege in the mean while to Strigonium, in which commanded as Governours Li≈øcanus and Salamanca, two proud and covetous Spaniards, with a Garri≈øon of 1300 Souldiers, but e're Solyman began to batter the City, he ≈øent to promi≈øe them Life, Liberty, and whatever Goods they were po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed of if they would ≈øurrender; or upon refu≈øal to denounce again≈øt them all the mi≈øeries that attend on ≈øtormed Cities, yet this nothing daunted the Souldiers, who returned for an≈øwer, that they repo≈øed their la≈øt hope in their Arms,
and were not to be won by gifts, nor terrified with threats, upon notice of which their ≈øtout re≈øolution he commanded his Cannon already mounted to play from ≈øeveral Batteries, the which was put in Execution with ≈øuch fury, that the Walls were beaten down in ≈øeveral places, at which breaches the Turks in great number attempting to enter were beaten back three times ≈øucce≈ø≈øively, with great lo≈øs and ≈ølaughter, and among≈øt the ≈ølain fell Bultaces Sanzack of Selymbria, a man of great account among≈øt the Turks, but in the end the weakne≈øs of the City being di≈øcovered to the enemy, by a fugitive Calabrian, the two afore≈øaid Governours con≈øulting for their own ≈øafety, intended ≈øecretly to leave the City, and carry with them all their Riches; but their purpo≈øe being di≈øcovered to the Captains and Soldiers, they propo≈øed a parly, per≈øwading the defendants that the City was not to be held again≈øt ≈øo powerful an Enemy; upon which the City was yielded, and the Garri≈øon ≈øuch as would marched to Po≈ø≈øonium, where the two cowardly Governours (who notwith≈øtanding the promi≈øe of ≈øafe conduct had been robbed by the Turks) were by Count Salme committed to ≈øafe cu≈øtody, to an≈øwer for their cowardly yielding up the City.

Strigonium being thus obtained on the 10th. of Augu≈øt, Anno 1543. and the Chri≈øtian Churches converted to the Mahometan ≈øuper≈øtition, he marched towards Alba regalis, taking in his way the Ca≈øtle of Tatta antiently called Theodota, which he utterly ra≈øed; after which coming before Alba regalis, a City famous for the Coronation of the Hungarian kings, ≈ø ‚Ä¢ ituate in a Mar≈øh, and incompa≈ø≈øed with a Lake. He cau≈øed the ≈øaid Lake with infinite labour to be filled up and thereafter many terrible A≈ø≈øaules, in which he lo≈øt 20000 of his men, took the Suburbs, putting
all he found therein to the ≈øword, and afterward had the City delivered into his po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion, where entering, he contrary to his faith plighted, he cau≈øed the mo≈øt wealthy Citizens to be ≈ølain; after which, leaving Ballabanus Governour thereof, and placing Governours in other places by him ≈øubdued; in this Expedition he returned to Con≈øtantinople.

By this time Barbaru≈ø≈øa and Polinus were arrived at Mar≈øelles, where having refre≈øhed them≈øelves, they departed to Province, where they laid ≈øiege to Nice, a City belonging to the Emperour, which after a long ≈øiege they took, but the Ca≈øtle being defended with a ≈øtrong Garri≈øon, they in vain a≈ø≈øaulted it, which ≈øo enraged Barbaru≈ø≈øa, that he threatened to impri≈øon Polinus for not performing his promi≈øe made at Con≈øtantinople to furni≈øh his Army with all nece≈ø≈øaries, when as he ≈øaid Powder and ≈øhot were wanting even in the Country of France, which divi≈øion between the French and the Turks was ended, by the rai≈øing the ≈øeige, upon notice that Alphon≈øus Va≈øtus the Emperors General was coming out of Italy with a great Army, when as the French Forces retiring, Barbaru≈ø≈øa ≈øent mo≈øt part of his Fleet to Argeir, with a command to return early the next ≈øpring to Mar≈øelles.

The great preparations of Barbaru≈ø≈øa to aid the French King gave Mulea≈ø≈øes ≈øu≈øpition that they were intended again≈øt him; whereupon leaving the management of the Affaires of his kingdom of Tunes in the hand of his tru≈øty Coun≈øellors, as he ≈øuppo≈øed, and the management of his men of war, his ≈øon Amida, he went to Naples to wait upon Charles the Emperor, and of him to crave aid, when in the mean time by the per≈øwa≈øion of ≈øuch as hated Mulea≈ø≈øes his ≈øon u≈øurped his kingdom, who upon notice thereof returning with ≈øuch Forces as he could gather in Italy, was overthrown, taken pri≈øoner,
and by his unnatural Son deprived of his ≈øight, dealing to him therein the ≈øame mea≈øure that he had dealt. Yet the unnatural Son e≈øcaped not altogether ≈øcotfree, for Tovarres Governour of Gullet for the Emperour, ≈øending for Abdamelech brother to Mulea≈ø≈øes, of whom I have before ≈øpoken, he in the ab≈øence of Amida ≈øurprized the City and Ca≈øtle of Tunis, but injoyed no more then 26 dayes e're he died when leaving his Son Mahometes a Child his Succe≈ø≈øor, he was ≈øoon thru≈øt out and Amida re≈øtored, whereupon Mulea≈ø≈øes fled fir≈øt to Guletta, and afterward into Sicily, where at the Emperours command he was maintained at the common charge of the I≈ølanders.

The French King being by this time weary of his new come Gue≈øt, the Turks having fir≈øt largely rewarded them ≈øent them away, who in their return ≈øpoil'd the I≈øland of Elba belonging to the Duke of Florence, upon the Governours refu≈øing to deliver the Son of Sinan the Jew, held Pri≈øoner there, ≈øince his being taken at Tunis, and after that committed many outrages upon the Coa≈øt of Italy; burning many Towns, and carrying away the people into mi≈øerable Captivity, but he long enjoyed not his Triumph ere him≈øelf was by death lead into Captivity, viz. anno 1547. In which year died Mahomet, Solyman's Elde≈øt Son, Frances the French King, and Alphon≈øus-Daualus-Valtius the Emperours renowned General.

Solyman having now not made any per≈øonal Expedition for the ≈øpace of three years re≈øolved to invade the Per≈øian King, being ≈øolicited thereto by Erca≈øes Imirza King of Sirnan, and that Kings Brother, but after great toil to little or no purpo≈øe for the ≈øpace of 1 year and 9 Months, he returned with his „Äà‚óä„Äâ , to Con≈øtantinople, Imirza in the mean while being
delivered to his brother Tamas the Per≈øian King by Treachery was put to death, during which Tran≈øaction one Dugat a notable Pirate, having taken Africa a City in Tunis, formerly called Aprodi≈øe, he greatly troubled the Moors by Land and the Chri≈øtians by Sea, when to remove ≈øo trouble≈øome a man, the Knights of Malta pa≈ø≈øed over with a con≈øiderable power, and after a furious a≈ø≈øault po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed them≈øelves of the ≈øaid City, the which by rea≈øon it was not tenable without exce≈ø≈øive charge they razed, carrying away a rich booty, and 7000 Captives, whereupon the Pirate fled to Con≈øtantinople, craving aid of Solyman, who ≈øent with him Sinan the Jew made Admiral in the ≈øtead of Barbaro≈ø≈øa, with a great Fleet; who in revenge of what had happened to Africa, landed on the I≈øland of Malta, and attempted (though in vain) the winning that ≈øtrong City. Yet ≈øailing into Africk, they after great ≈ølaughter of their men took Tripolis in Barbary, at that time po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed by certain of the Malta Knights, for which Sinan Ba≈ø≈øa having as it were Triumphed, left Drugat Governour thereof, by the Title of San≈øack returned to Con≈øtantinople.

Anno 1551.
