Solyman, notwith≈øtanding the five years peace made with King Ferdinand, ≈øent Achmetes his Lieutenant in Europe, to invade ≈øeveral Towns in Hungary, who upon his Arrival took Teme≈øwar and Zolnock, which Queen I≈øabel perceiving, and that the Turk contrary to his Faith plighted, daily incroach upon her Territories, who≈øe power ≈øhe was not in a capacity to repel by force, ≈øhe agreed with King Ferdinand to re≈øign her and her Sons Title to the Kingdom of Hungary in con≈øideration of Ca≈ø≈øovia, and a yearly pen≈øion of 100000 Ducats. After which the King recovered mo≈øt part of the Kingdom from the Turks, and for the better
keeping thereof as ≈øome ≈øay cau≈øed George Bi≈øhop of Veradium, a great favorite of Solymans though by Birth a Hungarian to be murthered, in his own Hou≈øe. Upon which the Ba≈ø≈øa of Buda drawing together what Forces be could Be≈øieged Agria, but after the lo≈øs of many of his be≈øt Souldiers he gave over the ≈øiege.

Henry ≈øucceeding his Brother Francis in the Kingdom of France, and de≈øirous to mole≈øt the Emperor, ≈øent the Lord Avomont to incite Solyman, to wa≈øt the Coa≈øt of Italy; whereupon he ≈øending a great Fleet in the Tyrrenan and Tu≈øcan Seas, wa≈øted the Coa≈øt of Calabria, S ‚Ä¢ cilia, Majorca, Sardinia, Elba, Cor≈øica and Cerbe, the Frontiers of the Emperours Dominions, and the ≈øame year, viz. anno 1554. Solyman incited thereto by Roxolana, once his Slave and Concubine, but now his imperious Wife, and by the Treacherous in≈øinuation of Ru≈øtan Ba≈ø≈øa, who had Married Chameria her Daughter by Solyman, cau≈øed his Son Mu≈øtapha the chief hope of the Oth ‚Ä¢
man Family, begot on a S ‚Ä¢ yrca≈ø≈øian Woman to be ≈øtrangled in his Pavilion, without ≈øuffering him to clear him≈øelf of what had been fal≈øly laid to his charge during his ab≈øence, the which barbarous cruelty when Tzihunger, Roxolana's Son by Solyman, whom ≈øhe purpo≈øed to rai≈øe to the Empire after his decea≈øe, and for that purpo≈øe had procured the death of Mu≈øtapha, came to know he had dete≈øted his Fathers cruelty, with his Dagger killed him≈øelf, and fell down dead upon his Brothers dead body; nor was Solyman in ≈øafety when the matter came to be once known, for the inraged Souldiers with their drawn Swords (after they had killed a great number of tho≈øe that came thither to fetch the Riches in Mu≈øtaphaes Tent) came to his Pavilion Threatning him with pre≈øent Death, and after many
reproaches were hardly appea≈øed, ≈øwearing at their departure if the Accu≈øers of Mu≈øtapha were not brought to light they would neverthele≈øs kill him, when to ≈øatisfie them in their demands, he deprived Ru≈øtan Ba≈ø≈øa of all his Honours, taking from him the ≈øeal whereof he had the keeping, and delivered it to Achomates Ba≈ø≈øa, and Ru≈øtan commanded to leave the Camp upon pain of Death, but not long after by the means of his Mother-in-Law, who had by the means of a Jew, bewitched Solyman with her charms he was again re≈øtored, and to make way for him Achomates who had ≈øtept up into his places of Honour by Solyman's command, in the Divano cau≈øele≈øly was ≈øtrangled. While≈øt the≈øe things were doing Haly Ba≈ø≈øa having for a long time be≈øieged Zigeth, defended by Marcus Horworth, a valiant Captain was beaten off, by Polviller and Serineus two of King Ferdinandoes Captains with the lo≈øs of half of his Army. Nor fared the Turks better at Sea, for Gui≈øe Lord Prior of the Knights of St. John in France, took ≈øix Ships and Gallies richly laden, and now God intending to puni≈øh the Tyrant for ≈øo many Murthers ≈øuffered his Son Bajazet gotten upon Roxolana, to ri≈øe up again≈øt him Arms under pretence of ≈øupplanting his Brother Selymus, all the remainder of the afore≈øaid wicked ≈øtock, who by ≈øetting up a counterfeit Mu≈øtapha (and pretending he that was killed was no other, but one much re≈øembling the true Mu≈øtapha, ≈øent for great rewards to try his Fathers fury) drew after him a World of people being ≈øecretly encouraged thereto by his mother, who preferred him before his Elder Brother whom Solyman would have his Succe≈ø≈øor, and ≈øuch was her power with Solyman, that after the Plot was di≈øcovered the counterfeit taken and executed, ≈øhe made Bajazets peace and re≈øtored to favour as
much as ever; yet ≈øuch was the fiery nature of the head ≈øtrong youth, that knowing his Life was dated with his Fathers, if his Brother ≈øucceeded him he again took up Arms, being generally favoured of the Soldiers, again≈øt whom Selymus was ≈øent with a great Army, between whom was fought a dreadful Battle, in which 300 Turks were ≈ølain, and Bajazet put to the wor≈øt, who after much adver≈øe fortune flying to the Per≈øian King, was by the procurement of Solyman contrary to Faith given by the Per≈øian, he together with his four Sons was mur ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ed.

Anno 1558 Charles the Fifth, and warlike Emperour of Germany, ≈øtricken in years, and worn out with the toils of tedious War, re≈øigned the Empire to his Brother Ferdinand, having before put his ≈øon Philip in po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of all Hereditary Kingdoms, and then retiring lead a private Life, and ≈øhortly after changed it for Life Eternal; after he had with great reverence and integrity Reigned 39 years, after who≈øe death at the earne≈øt reque≈øt of the Knights of Malta, the Chri≈øtian Princes ≈øet out a Fleet for the recovery of Tripolis in Barbary, when coming to the I≈øland of Zerbi belonging to the Turks they ≈øpoiled it, and after a ≈ømall battery to the Ca≈øtle in which the I≈ølanders put their cheif hope, but this Expedition proved unfortunate to the Chri≈øtians: for Pial Ba≈ø≈øa Solymans Admiral, coming upon them with a great Fleet, ≈øuddainly ≈øurprized many of the Ships and Gallies out of order, and unable to make re≈øi≈øtance, took them and put mo≈øt of tho≈øe he found therein to the Sword, and ≈øuch as could ≈øtand off to Sea fled, leaving Don Alvarus De Sandee a valiant Gentleman of great Spirit, and long Experience, General of the Chri≈øtian Forces on ≈øhoar, who together with ≈øuch as were ≈øied from the Fleet entered the Ca≈øtle, which was
mo≈øt re≈øolutely defended till ≈øuch time as hunger and thir≈øt compell him to ≈øurrender, not le≈øs then 18000 Chri≈øtians by one means or other being lo≈øt, from the ≈øetting out of the Fleet to the time the Ca≈øtle was delivered to the Turks, the which by the Ba≈ø≈øa being ≈øtrongly Garri≈øoned, he with the Chri≈øtian Captives there taken returned in Triumph to Con≈øtantinople, and long was ere the Spani≈øh and Italian Nobility there taken could be ran≈øomed; and to make up this unluckly year, viz. 1560. on the 25th. day of November, Auria the great Sea Captain died being 94 years old, to the great Rejoycing of the Turki≈øh Pirates who≈øe terror he had been for more then Thirty years, nor was the following year fortunate, for King Philip of Spain ≈øending out his Fleet under Mendoza his Admiral, Five and Twenty Ships and Gallies by ≈øtre≈øs of Weather were broken on the Coa≈øt of Sicily, on one of which the Admiral peri≈øhed, little or nothing being ≈øaved in that di≈ømal and unexpected Calamity.

Anno 1562. The Emperour Ferdinand ≈øo laboured with the Electoral Princes, that he procured his ≈øon Maximillian then King of Bchemia, a Prince of great hope to be cho≈øen K. of the Romans, who likewi≈øe the year following, on the 8th. of September with all ≈øolemnity Crowned at Presburg King of Hungaria, to confirm which choice Solyman ≈øent Ibrahim Ba≈ø≈øa as his Amba≈ø≈øador, to the Emperour, as likewi≈øe to conclude in his name an eight years peace, and the better to gain credit, he ≈øent his Letters of credence not u≈øually done by the Turki≈øh Emperors, who≈øe proud ≈øtile therein, I think not ami≈øs to in≈øert which take as followeth.

I the Lord of Lords, Ruler of the Ea≈øt and We≈øt, who am of power to do and not to do what≈øoever plea≈øeth me, Lord of all Grecia, Per≈øia, and Arabia, Commander
of all things which can be ≈øubject to King and Command, the great worthy of the≈øe times, and ≈øtrong Champion of the wide World, Lord of all the white and black Seas, and of the Holy City of Mecha, ≈øhining with the brightne≈øs of God, of the City of Medina, and of the Holy and Cha≈øt City of Jeru≈øalem, King of the mo≈øt noble Kingdom of Egypt, Lord of Jovia and of the City of Athens, Senan, of the Sacred Temple of God, Zabilon, and Ba≈ø≈øio, Reth≈øans and Magodini, the Seat and Throne of the great King of Na≈øhin Rettam, and Lord of the I≈øland of Argiers, Prince of the Kingdom of Tartary, Me≈øopotamia, Media of the Georgians, Morea, Anatolia, A≈øia, Armenia, Valachia, Moldavia, and of all Hungary, and many other Kingdoms and Territories whereof I am Emperour. The mo≈øt mighty Monarch Sultan Solyman, Son of the great Emperour Sultan Selym, who hath power from God to rule all People with a bridle, and ≈øtrength to break open the Gates and Bars of all Cities, and ≈øtrong places, into who≈øe mighty hand are delivered all the ends of the World, none excepted, I Ruler of the Ea≈øt, from the I≈øland of T≈øein unto the farthe≈øt bounds of Africa, whom God hath appointed a mighty Warrior in the edge of Sword, among≈øt who≈øe mo≈øt mighty Kingdoms the impregnable Ca≈øtle of Cae≈øarie, is reputed the lea≈øt, and in who≈øe Hereditary Dominions the Kingdom or Empire of Alexander the Great is accounted of us a trifle, with me is the ≈øtrength of the whole World, and Virtue of the Firmament. For as much as thou King Ferdinand, &c.

Their audacious ≈øtile being read in the German Court, moved ≈øome to indignation, and others to ≈øecret laughter, yet the nece≈ø≈øity requiring it, peace was concluded, but kept no longer then the Emperour lived; for upon his Death which happened two years after, viz. 1564. new troubles aro≈øe in Hungary, and ≈øeveral Towns and Ca≈øtles were won and lo≈øt on either ≈øide, whereupon Solyman re≈øolved in
per≈øon to come into Hungary, but upon ≈øecond thoughts he changed his mind, and bent his Forces again≈øt the I≈øland of Malta lying between Africa and Sicilia, in length twenty and in breadth twelve miles, exceeding fruitful and plean≈øantly ≈øcituate were it not in Summer time too much ≈øcorched by the Sun, which deprives the inhabitants of their fre≈øh water, before which the Turks coming with a Fleet of Two Hundred Ships and Gallies, after ≈øome lo≈øs ≈øu≈øtained both by the Sea and I≈ølanders, Landed and layed ≈øiege to St. Michaels Ca≈øtle, which they furiou≈øly battered, but it being defended by ≈øeveral Knights of the Order, they received great lo≈øs before it, whereupon they con≈øulted among≈øt them≈øelves to leave the ≈øiege of St. Michael and be≈øiege the Ca≈øtle of St. Elmo, the which with the lo≈øs of 18000 of their men they took, when in the mean while Valetta, the Great Ma≈øter fortified St. Michael both City and Ca≈øtle ≈øending to the Viceroy of Sicilia for aid, but the Turks incouraged by the comming of the King of Argier, with his Ships and a great ≈øupply of Victuals be≈øieged St. Michaels Ca≈øtle a ≈øecond time, as al≈øo the City Thundering again≈øt it for the ≈øpace of eight days without intermi≈ø≈øion, but ≈øuch was the courage of the be≈øieged, that they either repaired the breaches, or beat back the A≈ø≈øailants who made ≈øuch ≈ølaughter of tho≈øe that attempted to enter, that their dead bodies filling the breaches ≈øerved as a Rampire to keep out the re≈øt, and thus they continued furious to a≈ø≈øault the City almo≈øt every day, till upon notice of the Viceroy of Sicily's approach with a great power both by Sea and Land, they rai≈øed their ≈øiege and departed to meet him near Melita, where in a ≈øet Battle they were overthrown, and mo≈øt of them ≈ølain with the lo≈øs of 5000 Chri≈øtians onely, yet tho≈øe that e≈øcaped in their return landed
on the I≈øland Chios and took it, it being before almo≈øt de≈øerted of its inhabitants, by rea≈øon it lay always obnoxious to the fury of the barbarous Infidels.

Solyman inraged at this defeat re≈øolved to revenge him≈øelf upon the Chri≈øtian Princes, and therefore with a great Army undertook his before determined War again≈øt Hungary, ≈øolicited thereto by the Vayvod of Tra ‚Ä¢ ≈øylvania, who hoped to be made King thereof; but Maximilian being Crowned Emperour, he railed a great power being aided by the German Princes, and ≈øent them under the leading of ≈øeveral valiant Captains, but e≈øpecially Count Serenus, and Count Helffeu≈øtin who≈øe good Fortunes proved ≈øuch, that within a ≈øhort time the Turks were ≈øtripped out of mo≈øt of their Garri≈øons, and a great number of them ≈ølain, for Maximillian the Emperour, long before adverti≈øed of Solymans purpo≈øe had rai≈øed as is ≈øaid, a gallant Army, con≈øi≈øting of 40000 Hor≈øe and Foot, the flower of all Chri≈øtian Nations, be≈øides a Fleet upon the River Danubius, which hindered the Turks Provi≈øions and other nece≈ø≈øaries from being brought by water.

By this time Solyman coming to the River Dromus, over which with infinite labour he cau≈øed a Bridge to be made for the pa≈ø≈øage of his Army, which done he encamped before Sigeth, of which Count Serenus was made Governour, a valiant man, and mortal Enemy to the Turks attended on by a Garri≈øon of 2300 re≈øolute Germans and Hungarians, who like a brave Souldier with a mo≈øt Chri≈øtian Oration incouraged his men, not to be di≈ømaid at the multitude of their Enemies, but to tru≈øt in God, and be of good courage, for he by his Almighty power was able by a few to confound the Armies of the proud. Concluding that as for him≈øelf, as he was a Chri≈øtian
and free born ≈øo he would by the Grace of God, in the ≈øame Faith and Freedom end his dayes, and that no proud Turk ≈øo long as he could hold up his hand ≈øhould have power to command over him, or the ground whereon he ≈øtood, nor failed he in his re≈øolves, for after he had done all that man was capable of doing, killing ≈øuch numbers of Turks, that the Plains lay ≈øcattered with the dead, the Walls being for the mo≈øt part beaten down, and the Town fired about his Eares, the Turks in great number entring every where, and no relief coming to his a≈ø≈øi≈øtance, he called the poor remainder of his Souldiers about him, with whom he was retired into the Ca≈øtle and with an undaunted re≈øolution, ≈øpake the≈øe his la≈øt words.

p.hi: The hard fortune of this ≈øinful Kingdom, hath together with our own overtaken us, but let us, noble Hearts, indure with Patience what≈øoever is by God to us a≈ø≈øigned, you know what we have before promi≈øed, which hitherto God be thanked, we have accordingly performed, and now let us with like re≈øolutions perform this la≈øt, the place you ≈øee is not longer to be kept, the devouring fire grows fa≈øt upon us and we in number are but few; wherefore let us as becometh valiant men break out into the utter Ca≈øtle, and there dye fighting in the mid≈øt of our Enemies to live afterwards with God for ever, I will be the fir≈øt that will go out follow me like men.

div.p:
Thus having ≈øaid, the Heroick Count worthy of Eternal fame, or a name greater then ever Roman yet could boa≈øt, with his Sword in his hand charged the thicke≈øt of his foes, laying them round him on heaps, even till the Rampart of the dead hemmed him in, nor dur≈øt the Turks with their multitude incounter him long at clo≈øe fight, but cowardly at a di≈øtance ≈øhot him through the head upon which he fell dead among≈øt the heaps of his Enemies, in token
of who≈øe matchle≈øs prowe≈øs the Turks buryed his body and ≈øent his head as a token of his being ≈ølain to Count Salma his kin≈øman in the Emperours camp with this following Letter.
Muhamet Ba≈ø≈øa to Eccius Salma, gree ‚Ä¢ ing.
In token of my Love, behold here I „Äà‚óä„Äâ thee the head of a mo≈øt re≈øolute and valiant Captain, thy Friend, the remainder of his body I have hone≈øtly buryed, as became ≈øuch a man, &c.

That which lightened the Chri≈øtians ≈øadne≈øs for the lo≈øs of ≈øo brave a Captain, and the taking of Sigeth, was the Death of Solyman, who far ≈øpent with years and di≈øtempers died at Quinque Eccle≈øiae of the Bloody Flux, on the 4th. of September, anno 1566. when he had lived 76 years, and reigned 46, not living to ≈øee the end of the ≈øiege; his death was by the Ba≈ø≈øa kept ≈øecret to prevent di≈øorder in the Army, who according to their wonted policy ≈øatisfied the inqui≈øitive Janizaries by ≈øhewing them his dead body ≈øitting in his Hor≈øe-litter, giving it out that he was extream ill when after Sigeth having by Trea≈øon taken Gyula, for which the Traytor was afterward de≈øervedly put to death by Selymus Solymans ≈øucce≈ø≈øor, the Ba≈ø≈øa's with the Army returned to Con≈øtantinople where they publi≈øhed the death of Solyman, and proclaimed Selymus his now onely remaining Son Emperour in his ≈øtead.

div.head: CHAP. XVI. Selymus the ≈øecond of that name, and fifth Emperor of the Turks, His Life and Actions.
div.p: SOlyman being dead upon the return of the Army out of Hungaria towards Con≈øtantinople, Mabumet Ba≈ø≈øa by letters adverti≈øed Selymus thereof then re≈øiding at Cutai a City of Galatia who glad of the news ha≈øted to take po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of the ≈øo long expected Empire, when being conducted over the ≈øtraights of Bo≈øphorus, he was by Bo≈øtanges Ba≈ø≈øas, and Scander Ba≈ø≈øa conveighed into the Imperial Pallace on the 23 of September, Anno 1566, from whence he departed to meet his fathers Corps, not yet arrived at Con≈øtantinople, upon the meeting of which he cau≈øed the In≈øignes to be let fall, in token of the Emperors death, which had been till that time kept ≈øecret from the Soldiers, to prevent di≈øorders, and ≈øo with it Marching in the head of the Army returned to Con≈øtantinople, being fir≈øt by the men of War ≈øaluted Emperor; who upon his Arrival, to quiet the unruly Soldiers di≈øtributed a large ≈øum of mony among≈øt them, with a Promi≈øe to augment their wages as is u≈øual at the in≈øtallment of the Ottoman Emperors, or el≈øe by rea≈øon of the in≈øolency of the Janizaries and other Soldiers of the Court of their Pallace would prove too hot to hold them.

Selimus thus ≈øetled in his Empire, with Royal ≈øolemnity buried his father, in a Chappel which he afterward
built, together with a Colledge and Ho≈øpital, erecting over him a ≈øtately Tomb, near unto which is at this day to be ≈øeen the Magnificent Tomb of his beloved wife Roxolana, mother to Selimus, and of certain of his Murthered children. By him hangs his Scimiter, in token that he dyed in war, an honour not otherwi≈øe granted to the Mahometan Princes. The Revenues ari≈øing of the Countrey about Sigeth, won from the Chri≈øtians a little before his death, were given to maintain the hou≈øes by him built for devotion, which for Magnificence exceed all others Erected by the Mahometan Kings and Emperors, except tho≈øe of Mahomet the Great, and Bajazet the Second. It was by many thought that Soliman was in good time taken out of the way, for that he re≈øolving to winter in Hungary the next Spring purpo≈øed with him≈øelf to have over-run Au≈øtria, and a great part of Germany.

Anno 1567, Solyman being dead great trouble aro≈øe notwith≈øtanding in Hungary, occa≈øioned by John the Vayvod of Tran≈øilvania, who u≈øed his utmo≈øt endeavour to di≈øpo≈ø≈øe≈øs Maximilian the Emperor of tho≈øe Cities and Fortre≈ø≈øes he held in that Kingdom, but they were ≈øoon after appea≈øed by a peace concluded between the two Emperors, Maximilian and Selimus. The principal points on which the peace depended being the≈øe. That the German Emperor ≈øhould yearly pay 30000 Ducates to Selimus, as a Tribute for Hungary, the Tribute to begin upon the conclu≈øion of the Articles of Peace. That the Subjects of the Turks ≈øhould pay nothing to the Subjects of the Emperor, nor on the other ≈øide the ≈øubjects of the Emperor pay nothing to the Subjects of the Turks, but to remain both of them exempted from payment of Tax, Duty or Contribution, and that either Prince ≈øhould inviolably hold what he
was in po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of at the conclu≈øion of the Treaty, which peace was confirmed for the ≈øpace of 8 years; in which was included the Vayvod of Tran≈øilvania, as the Turks Tributary. This peace was concluded Anno 1568, as was likwi≈øe the year following a peace concluded between Selymus and Tamas the Per≈øian Kings after which the Turk de≈øirous to undertake ≈øome „Äà‚óä„Äâ exploit, that might get him a name, and out of the Revenues of which he might build him a Temple exceeding any of his Predece≈ø≈øors, which tho≈øe ≈øuper≈øtitious people hold to be for the good of their ≈øouls; be plotted in his mind many things, but at length being by his mi≈øchievous Coun≈øellors, of whom he wanted not, he was ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ged to the conque≈øt of the rich I≈øland of Cyprus, lying in the Cicilian Sea, and hath on the We≈øt Pamphilia, on the Ea≈øt Siria, on the South Egypt, and on the North Cilicia, now called Caramania. This I≈øland at ≈øuch time as Selymus was intent on the conque≈øt thereof, was in the po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of the Venetians, with whom he had contracted a League ≈øince the death of Solyman; but in vain are Leagues with Infidels any longer then they ≈øerve their own turns, yet Muhamates the Great Ba≈ø≈øa laboured all he could to di≈ø≈øwade him therefrom; and Marcus Antonius Barbarus the Venetian Amba≈ø≈øador then re≈øiding at Con≈øtantinople ≈øo wrought that he procured the la≈øcivious Turk to ≈øend Cubates as his Amba≈ø≈øador to the Senate of Venice, with a letter to certifie them upon what grounds he undertook to invade their Territory ≈øince the League had till that time been kept inviolable, which was done more to gain time, then for any hope he had that Selymus would alter his determination; which Amba≈ø≈øador not obtaining what Selymus de≈øired, which was to have the fertil I≈øland peaceably put into his po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion, but on the contrary finding the Venetians re≈øolved to de≈øend it with all
their power he returned again to his faithle≈øs Ma≈øter, and related what he had in charge; whereupon the Great Fleet before prepared for the inva≈øion of Cyprus, put to Sea, Mu≈øtapha Ba≈ø≈øa being General of all the Forces, and within a while ≈øtood with the ≈øaid I≈øland, where the greedy Turks landing, ≈øpoiled many goodly Villages, and after ≈øome deliberation having by pri≈øoners taken, under≈øtood the con≈øtitution of the Countrey, and of what ≈øtrength the I≈ølanders were, re≈øolved to be≈øiege Nico≈øia, a City ≈øtanding in the mid≈øt of the I≈øland, in a plain and Champain ground, being in circuit about five miles, incompa≈ø≈øed with a ≈øtrong wall, defended by eleven ≈øtrong Bulwarks, and three great Fortre≈ø≈øes, rai≈øed by the Venetians, the Governour of which was Nicalaus Dandalus, a man too weak for ≈øo great a burthen, as having been alwayes brought up in civil affairs; in Gari≈øon were 8000 hor≈øe and foot, but mo≈øt of them raw ≈øoldiers, and not acquainted with Martial di≈øcipline, too few to oppo≈øe ≈øo powerful an Army as the Ba≈ø≈øa drew after him, which con≈øi≈øted of near 150000 hor≈øe and foot.

On the 22 of July Anno 1569 the Ba≈ø≈øa with his Army Encamped within a mile and half of the City, covering with their Tents the hill called Mandia, and with incredible labour bringing their Trenches from far, ca≈øt up ≈øeveral Forts which they rai≈øed ≈øo high, that they overlooked the walls of the City, and from their Mounts terribly battered the walls with ≈øeventy pieces of great Artillery, who≈øe dreadful thundring made the earth to tremble, and having by this time run their Trenches to the brim of the ditch, hotly a≈ø≈øaulted the City in ≈øeveral places, which was as valiantly defended by the be≈øieged, in≈øomuch that the ditches were well nigh filled on that ≈øide with the bodies of the ≈ølain, and what was
beaten down in the day time was with great labour repaired in the night.

During the≈øe pa≈ø≈øages the Venetians having leagued with the Pope, King of Spain, and ≈øeveral of the Italian Princes, prepared their fleet, con≈øi≈øting in all of one hundred and ≈øeventeen ≈øail; but whiles they lingered for the Additional Forces of the King of Spain, the plague ≈øo raged among≈øt the Marriners and Souldiers, that twenty thou≈øand dyed e'r its fury was abated, and among≈øt them many men of account, but it cea≈øing, and the ≈øummer half ≈øpent, the Venetian Admiral no longer expecting the coming of the Spaniards, ≈øailed to Corcyra, and there calling a Council, it was re≈øolved they ≈øhould pa≈øs over to Cyprus and de≈øtroy the Turks fleet; but in the height of this expedition dyed Petrus Loridanus Duke of Venice, Leaving the care of the war to Aloy≈øius Mocenicus, who ≈øucceeded him in the Dukedom.

Mu≈øtapha advertized of the approach of the Chri≈øtian fleet, u≈øed his utmo≈øt endeavour to carry the City by a≈ø≈øault, but being valiantly repul≈øed, he cau≈øed ≈øeveral letters to be ≈øhot over the walls fa≈øtened to Turki≈øh Arrows, therein per≈øwading the Citizens to open their gates, and receive him their Mild and Merciful Conqueror, and that in ≈øo doing they ≈øhould deliver them≈øelves from the mi≈øeries that attended on be≈øieged Cities; but the≈øe fair promi≈øes nothing prevailing, he incouraged his ≈øoldiers to a fre≈øh A≈ø≈øault, in attempting which he lo≈øt 4000 of his men, and was forced to ≈øound the retreat; but in the many conflicts the Chri≈øtians being wa≈øted either by death, ≈øickne≈øs, or wounds, expecting ≈øuccours from the Princes of the We≈øt, and none coming to their aid, wearyed with continual watching, the Turks in the dead of the night ≈øecretly entred a Bulwark the day
before ≈øore battered by the Ordnance from the mount, and putting the drou≈øie Italians and Epirots, they found therein to the ≈øword, e'r the Allarm could be taken; let in ≈øuch a number of their fellows, that the be≈øieged were not able to repell them, but with the continual Vollies of ≈øhot, were on all ≈øides overwhelmed, which Eugenius a valiant Captain perceiving, and as a man de≈øperate, endeavouring to retain his flying Soldiers, in thicke≈øt danger, was ≈ølain by a Harquibus ≈øhot; and now the Turks like a Torrent flowing in at all the Ports, made ≈øuch de≈øtruction that it was lamentable to behold, ≈øparing in their fury neither man woman nor child; whereupon the Soldiers and many of the Citizens, ca≈øting them≈øelves in a Ring in the Market-place, with their weapons in their hands, as men de≈øperate, re≈øolved to dye fighting, again≈øt whom the Governour of Aleppo cau≈øed ≈øeveral Murthering Pieces to be bent, which they perceiving, and finding they ≈øhould be killed at a di≈øtance, without having power to revenge them≈øelves on their Enemy, ca≈øt down their weapons, and yeilded them≈øelves to the mercy of the Enemy, and were thereupon for a while ≈øpared; but the Gates being ≈øtrongly guarded, that none ≈øhould e≈øcape, Dandalus the Governour, Contarenus Bi≈øhop of Paphos, and other the chief men of the City, having retired them≈øelves into the Town-hall, there re≈øolving to dye like men, if they could find no other means to e≈øcape, ≈øent to the Ba≈ø≈øa for life, which reque≈øt he ≈øeemed well to approve; but whil≈øt me≈ø≈øengers pa≈ø≈øed too and fro, the barbarous Turks broke in upon them, and put them all to the ≈øword, when raging on they likewi≈øe killed all tho≈øe that had ≈øubmitted them≈øelves, and were taken to mercy, as is ≈øuppo≈øed not without the ≈øecret command of the Ba≈ø≈øa, a deadly enemy to the Chri≈øtians; and ≈øo great
was the inhumane ≈ølaughter that eighteen thou≈øand were in all reported to peri≈øh by the ≈øword, neither was there any end of the ≈øpoil, till the avaritious enemy had carryed away all that long peace had accumulated, which according to the moderate≈øt computation amounted to 20000 Millions of Ducates; and notwith≈øtanding the fury of the Barbarous Enemy 200 youths were re≈øerved, and ≈øent as a pre≈øent to Selymus in order to his training them up in the order of Janizaries. In the City likewi≈øe were taken two hundred and fifty Pieces of Great Ordnance. This City was won on the 9 of September, 1570, and to this day remains in the hands of the Turks, as doth the whole I≈øland.

Nico≈øia won, the Ba≈ø≈øa ≈øent one of his Sanzacks to ≈øummon the City of Cyrene of which Palacius was Governour, who upon ≈øight of the Turks Army cowardly yeilded the ≈øame into their hands; which ≈øo heightened their courage, that they laid ≈øiege to Famagu≈øta, ≈øending to Summon it to Surrender, but finding the re≈øolution of the Garri≈øon to defend it, and withall having notice that the Chri≈øtian Fleet was at hand, he rai≈øed his ≈øiege, and billeted his ≈øoldiers for that winter, in certain villages adjacent, nor was Fames rumour founded upon idle report, for the Fleet ≈øet out by the King of Spain, the Venetions, and the Pope, commanded by Auria Zanius and Columnius loo≈øing from Crect, had given the Turks battle, had not Auria the Spani≈øh Admiral oppo≈øed it, and after him many of the Great Commanders; for Zanius and Venetian Admiral, and Commnius the Popes Admiral ab≈øolutely declared that they had expre≈øs Command to fight the Turks, but the other alledging the great di≈øadvantage they ≈øhould receive by fighting upon the Enemies Coa≈øt, and the weakne≈øs of the Fleet by rea≈øon of the Pe≈øtilence that had de≈øtroyed
the mo≈øt expert Seamen abruptly departed for Me≈ø≈øina, leaving the other Admirals to ≈øhift for them≈øelves, who not able to contend with ≈øo powerful an Enemy returned likewi≈øe to Corcyra, where by a Decree of the Senate, Zanius the Venetian Admiral was di≈øcharged of his command, and ≈øent pri≈øoner to Venice, and Seba≈øtianus Venerius Governour of Coroyra Commi≈ø≈øioned Admiral in his ≈øtead.

The rich prey for the mo≈øt part taken in Nicolia, being put on board the Admirals Gally, a Woman Captive taken there, in a de≈øperate Mood giving fire to the Gunpowder blew up the Gally, and by that blow beat in pieces two others that lay near it, de≈øtroying thereby a great number of Turks, the Ba≈ø≈øa him≈øelf narrowly e≈øcaping by being a little before gone on ≈øhoar.

The new Admiral of the Venetians to get him a name re≈øolving to attempt ≈øomething upon the Turks, and having a fit opportunity offered he ≈øailed into the Bay of Ambriaca, and by the aid of the Mountain people inhabiting. Acroceraunian took the ≈øtrong Ca≈øtle of Chimaera putting to the Sword and taking Pri≈øoners 300 Turks there ingarri≈øoned, and not long after Querinus the Vice-Admiral ≈øailing along the Coa≈øt of Pelopone≈øus, Landed his men near the Bay of Maine, and in five hours took a ≈øtrong Ca≈øtle of the Turks, built to guard the pa≈øs, and in it 500 Turks, whom he cau≈øed to be put to the Sword, and taking out the Ordinance cau≈øed the Ca≈øtle to be razed. The City of Famagu≈øtan being again blocked up by the Turks huge Camp, the Governour ≈øent Hieronimus Ragazonius Bi≈øhop of the City, and Nicholaus Donaius to Venice, they to make known to the Senate the danger the be≈øieged were in, and to require them not to delay ≈øending them ≈øuccour, whereupon the Senators wrote to the Admiral, to put a ≈øupply both of men and provi≈øion who
commiting the care thereof to Quirinus the Vice-Admiral, he as an undaunted Captain filling four Ships with all manner of Provi≈øion, and 1700 ≈øelect Souldiers, waiting his opportunity with Twelve Gallies, accompanyed them to the mouth of the Port which Ships the Turks that lay at Anchor beholding, came forth in hope of a prize, but being ≈øet upon by the Gallies were obliged to retire in great di≈øorder, and run them≈øelves for the mo≈øt part on ≈øhoar; where they were beaten in pieces by the great Ordnance from the Venetian Gallies, and then entring the Haven relieved the Citizens as he had in charge, to their unexpre≈ø≈øible joy; when coming forth again and roaming about the Seas, he took two of the Enemies Ships richly laden, who were coming to the Camp in Cyprus, and then wa≈øted the Coa≈øts of Pamphilia he returned to Venice, the news of which coming to the knowledge of Selymus, it ≈øo inraged him that he cau≈øed the Governour of Chios his head to be ≈øtricken off, the Governour of Rhodes to be di≈øcharged of his Government and Pial Ba≈ø≈øa, to be turned out from being Admiral.

The Turks encroaching thus upon Chri≈øtendom did not a little Alarum the Confederate Princes, in≈øomuch that they again con≈øult how to with≈øtand the barbarous Enemy, and if po≈ø≈øible to relieve the remaining Cities of Cyprus, but were a long while ere they came to any conclu≈øion. In which ≈øpace after many terrible a≈ø≈øaults, and the lo≈øs of 14000 Turks, Tramogu≈øta was taken, and all manner of cruelties exerci≈øed (contrary to the Faith of the Ba≈ø≈øa before given) on the Souldiers and Citizens, and the ≈øame ri≈øque ≈øoon after run all the other Cities of Cyprus, but by this time the Amba≈ø≈øadors ≈øent by the Venetians to Tamas the Per≈øian King to joyn in League with the Confederate Princes being returned, with onely this an≈øwer, that the Per≈øian would not ha≈øtily
enter into a War again≈øt the Turk, but would for two years expect the ≈øucce≈øs of the Chri≈øtians Arms, the King of Spain, Venetians and Pope, with ≈øeveral of the Italian Princes entred into a perpetual League, and with all diligence prepared their Fleet again≈øt the ≈øpring, every one being proportioned his charge in the War, and to have proportion of the ≈øpoiles, to be taken according to the number of Ships and Gallies ≈øet forth.

By this time the Turks having po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed them≈øelves of the famous I≈øland of Cyprus, and not content therewith gaped for Crete, now called Candia, lying in the Mediterranean, and once as Seneca and others witne≈øs po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed of 100 Cities, being exceeding fruitful, and then in the po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of the Venetians, on which the Turks landing in great number, did what harm they po≈ø≈øibly could, by burning and ≈øpoiling all they found in their way, till at length they were incountered by Franci≈øous Ju≈øtinianus who but a little before their Landing came into the I≈øland with a 1000 Souldiers, and now joyning with the I≈ølanders, charged them as they di≈øper≈øed to ≈øeek for prey with ≈øuch fury, that killing many of them he obliged the re≈øt to make a ≈øwift though a di≈øorderly retreat to their Gallies, but the next day they again landing in greater number burnt divers Towns, ran≈øacked Setia and Rhetimo, wherein they found much riches, and carried away mo≈øt of the inhabitants into mi≈øerable bondage. But loaded with their booty di≈øper≈øed and dreading no danger they were ≈øuddainly charged by Lucas Michael a valiant Captain 2000 of them ≈ølain, and all the prey recovered together with the pri≈øoners, and they again forced to betake them≈øelves to their Gallies, after which they weighed Anchor and ≈øailed along the Coa≈øt, pa≈ø≈øing by Cythera, Zazinthius and Cephalemia
I≈øland belonging to the Venetians, doing much dammage in divers parts of them, and carryed 6000 of the I≈ølanders into Captivity, and departing thence failed along the Coa≈øt of Epirus, which the Venetians had ≈øtirred up to Rebel again≈øt the Turks, but not ≈øending them the promi≈øed Aid they were inforced to ≈øubmit to the Mercy of their mercyle≈øs Enemies, after which they recovered all the Ca≈øtles and Towns the Venetians had taken on the Sea Coa≈øt, which brought a great fear upon mo≈øt of the I≈ølands yet po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed by the Chri≈øtians, e≈øpecially when that part of the Fleet which had done ≈øo much harm was augmented, by the arrival of Haly Ba≈ø≈øa, and within a while after all the Fleet met at Aulona, and on the 26 Aug. 1571. ≈øailed directly to Corcyra, which little I≈øland ≈øeemed to be incompa≈ø≈øed with their huge Fleet. There Partus Ba≈ø≈øa Vice-Admiral of the Turk upon his arrival landed 800 Hor≈øemen, and 1000 Foot, who ranging up and down the I≈øland did great harm by burning and de≈øtroying all before them, till they came to the Suburbs of Corfu which they attempted to ≈øet on fire, but were beaten off by the Garri≈øon Souldiers, who ≈øallyed upon them with great fury killing a great number of them, and among≈øt the re≈øt Paphus Rays a man of great account cau≈øing the re≈øt to betake them≈øelves to flight, who coming on board the Gally, weighed Anchor and ≈øailed to the Bay of Corinth otherwi≈øe called Lepanto, having on board the Fleet 15000 Captive Chri≈øtians, taken in the I≈ølands belonging to the Venetians.

The outrages of the Turks made the Chri≈øtian Confederates ha≈øten out their Fleet, which met at Me≈ø≈øina where the Admirals and other great Commanders called a Councel, to con≈øider what was be≈øt to be done in the management of the War again≈øt ≈øo powerful an Enemy, not doubting the victory
for why the Venetian Fleet, con≈øi≈øted of 108 Gallies, 6 Gallia≈ø≈øes, 2 great Ships, and many ≈ømall Galliots to whom were joyned 12 Gallies of the Popes, Commanded by Columnius. And with Don John General of Spain, Ba≈øe Son to Charles the 5th. and Auria the Spani≈øh Admiral came 81 Gallies, of which three appertained to the Knights of Maita. In this Fleet be≈øides Mariners were reckoned to be 20000 Men, an Army not onely mo≈øt beautiful for ≈øhew, as con≈øi≈øting of able Men, but for the mo≈øt part compo≈øed of old experienced Souldiers, among≈øt whom were a great number of the Chri≈øtian Nobility, who came to ≈øerve again≈øt the Infidels of their own accord, drawing after them a number of their Favorites, whom they at their own charge maintained. The chief of which were Alexander Farne≈øius Prince of Parma, Franci≈øcus Maria Prince of ∆≤rbin, and Paulus Jordanus ∆≤r≈øinus of the Honourable Family of the Roman ∆≤r≈øini.

All things being thus in a readine≈øs, the Venetian Admiral in the Coun≈øel, called to determine what was to be done, vehemently pre≈ø≈øed the General and the re≈øt of the great Commanders in≈øtantly to give the Enemy Battle, and was ≈øeconded by ≈øeveral others of Note, as well Spaniards as Romans, whereupon Commandement was given for putting the Fleet in order, which by the three Admirals of Venice, Rome, and Spain being brought into the Ocean was martialed in this manner. In the right wing which con≈øi≈øted of 53 Gallies, was Auria the Spani≈øh Admiral placed. In the left wing Augu≈øtinus Barbadious with the like number of Gallies, and in the middle Battle ≈øtood the General him≈øelf, with 70 Gallies, on the right hand of the General ≈øtood Columnius, and on the left Venerius his A≈ø≈øociates, and thus with equal form the Fleet ≈øet forward as if they
in≈øtantly had been to joyn the Enemy.

During this preparation of the Chri≈øtians the Turks were not idle, but calling a Council of the chief Commanders held a long debate, whether they ≈øhould give the Chri≈øtians Battle, or decline it, but at length tho≈øe that held it dangerous to give Battle being over-ballanced by tho≈øe that were of the contrary opinion, it was re≈øolved that the whole Fleet ≈øhould be put in order of Battle, which at the command of Haly Ba≈ø≈øa, General of the Land Forces, and Great Admiral of the Turki≈øh Gallies, coming out of the Bay of Corinth or Lepanto, they were put into order of the Battle after this manner. The middle Battle in number much like the Chri≈øtians, was conducted by Haly Ba≈ø≈øa and Partau, attended upon by Agan Ma≈øter of the Turks Ar≈øenal, Mu≈øtapha Zelibi the Trea≈øurer, Achmat Bay with Mahomet his younger brother, the ≈øons of Haly Achmat Aga Governor of Teuthrania, A≈ø≈øis Caiga Governour of Calipolis, Caracoza Ca≈ø≈øanes Son to Barbaro≈ø≈øa Malamur Governour of Mytilene, Dely Solyman Gider Captain of Chios, Ca≈ø≈øambeius Governour of the Rhodes, Provi Aga Captain of Nauplium, Giaper Zelibi Pre≈øident of Calabria, Dordagnan Dondomeni, with many others too tedious to recite. The right wing was by the appointment of the Ba≈ø≈øa's commanded by Mahomet Bey, with 56 Gallies, to whom were joyned many Captains of great Experience in Sea affairs. The left wing was commanded by ∆≤luzales Viceroy of Argiers, an old experienced Pirate compo≈øed of 90 Gallies, accompanyed with Cariolo, and Araby, his two ≈øons, attended on by a multitude of Pirates who entered into the War, in hopes to get great ≈øpoil. In the Rearward was placed Amurath Dragut with 30 Gallies, and divers other ≈ømall ve≈ø≈øels.

Both Fleets being ≈øet in order of Battle, about
noon a fierce ingagement happened in the beginning of which God ≈øo ordering it, the Wind turned about to the great advantage of the Chri≈øtians, driving the ≈ømoake of the great Ordnance, and vollies of ≈ømall ≈øhot in the face of the Infidels, whereupon for a long time the fight continued with equal ≈øucce≈øs, victory inclining to neither ≈øide, but after four hours ≈øpace the Turki≈øh Admiral being ≈ølain, his Gally taken, and about 40 others ≈øunk and fired, victory began to declare her ≈øelf for the Chri≈øtians. Yet the de≈øperate Turks as ≈øearing Selymus Anger if they ≈øhould return vanqui≈øhed fought de≈øperately, but true valour prevailing and all the chief Commanders, except ∆≤luzales ≈ølain or taken Pri≈øoners, and he re≈øolving to re≈øerve him≈øelf to his better fortune, fled (after 5 hours de≈øperately fighting) with between 30 and 40 Gallies into the Bay of Lepanto, leaving the victory to the Chri≈øtians, who having pur≈øued him as far as they thought convenient, returned to take the ≈øpoil, where it was a horrible ≈øpectacle to behold the Sea coloured with blood, and covered with the bodies of the ≈ølain, fragments of broken Ships, and ≈øuch weapons as were ≈øubject to float upon its ≈øurface. The number of the Turks lo≈øt in this great overthrow, could not be known by rea≈øon of the Multitude that were buryed in the Sea, but Antonius Gnarnaerius writing the Hi≈øtory of this war reported 32000 to have peri≈øhed and among≈øt them the≈øe of Note, viz. Haly Ba≈ø≈øa General, Mahomet Bey (otherwi≈øe called Chiroche or Siroche) Governour of Alexandria, Ca≈ø≈øanes the Son of Barbaro≈ø≈øa, together with his ≈øon Mulaune Governor of Mitylene, Gider Governour of Chios, Ca≈ø≈øambaunes Governour of Rhodes, Provi Aga Captain of Nauplium, Mu≈øtapha Zelibi the great Trea≈øurer, Caracoza Viceroy of Argiers, with many others. The
chief Pri≈øoners taken in this Battle were Achmet and Mahomet ≈øons to Haly Ba≈ø≈øa, and Nephews to Selymus, who being afterwards ≈øent as a Pre≈øent to the Pope, the Elde≈øt died at Naples, and Machmet Bey Governour of Euboea, and of le≈ø≈øer note 3500, of the Enemies Gallies were taken 161, & 40 ≈øunk in the fight, and taken about 60 Galliots and other ≈ømall ve≈ø≈øels.

This notable Victory thus obtained, Don John Venerius and Columna coming together, friendly embraced each other, and afterwards in a mo≈øt Chri≈øtian manner on their knees returned mo≈øt hearty thanks to Almighty God for giving them ≈øo Great a Victory over the Enemies of his Name; which pious example was ≈øeconded by all the Captains, Mariners, and ≈øouldiers of the Fleet of the Chri≈øtians in this bloody fight died about ≈øeven thou≈øand five hundred ≈øixty ≈øix, the chief of which were John and Bernardinus of the Honourable family of Cordona in Spain, Horatio Caraffa and Ferantes Bisballus Virginius and Horatius Noble Romans of the Venetian Nobility were flain; Augu≈øtinus, Barbadicus, Benedictus, Superantius, Vincentius, Quirinus, Johanes Lauritanus, Marinus Contarenus, Catharinus, Malepetra, Georgius, Andreas Barbadicus, Marcus Antonius, Laudus Franci≈øcus, Bonus Hieronimus, Contarenus, Antonius Pa≈øchaligus, and Hieron Venerius, all of the Order of the Senators, be≈øides divers other Honourable Gentlemen, well de≈øerving to be inrolled in the Records of Fame. There were likewi≈øe many of note wounded, and among≈øt the re≈øt Venerius the Venetian Admiral by a ≈ømall ≈øhot that pa≈ø≈øed through his foot.

This great and welcom victory publi≈øhed in the City of Venice, cau≈øed ≈øuch a General joy as the like was never till that time; nor only did the Venetians alone rejoyce, but likewi≈øe all Chri≈øtian Nations; for in this fight the Turks lo≈øt ≈øo many ≈øub≈øtantial
Gallyes, able Commanders, Seamen, that to this day that lo≈øs hath been a weakning to that ≈øo mighty Empire, and ≈øuch was the Griefe conceived by Selymus thereat, that he retired him≈øelf for certain days, not permitting any to ≈øpeak with him, and then in his fury pa≈ø≈øed a Decree for Ma≈ø≈øacring all the Chri≈øtians within his Dominions, which bloody and barbarous Edict had been put in Execution had not Muhamat the chief Ba≈ø≈øa by many per≈øwa≈øions averted his wicked purpo≈øe; yet that his lo≈øs might ≈øeem the le≈øs, he di≈ø≈øembled it as well as he could, giving ≈øtrict orders for the ≈øpeedy building of new Gallies, to ≈øupply the place of tho≈øe that were lo≈øt, which he had the more lea≈øure to do, by rea≈øon that after this ≈øo ≈øignal a victory, the Chri≈øtian Fleet ≈øeparated, with a re≈øolution to meet again the next ≈øpring at Coreyra; yet the Venetians not ≈øatisfied for the lo≈øs of Cyprus ≈øpoiled the Turks Frontiers winning ≈øtrong holds, and among≈øt the re≈øt, the ≈øtrong Town of Suppoto, formerly taken from them, which cau≈øed Selimus to put to Sea all the Gallies he had, appointing ∆≤luzales a Renegado Chri≈øtian, but now turned Turk Admiral, in the room of Haly Ba≈ø≈øa, ≈ølain in the battel of Lepanto, of which the Venetian Admiral having notice, ≈øent to Don John to come to his Aid, but he bearing a grudge again≈øt the Venetians for hanging up one of his Mutinous Captains, ≈øtood a long time in doubt whether he ≈øhould ≈øend any of his Gallies to his a≈ø≈øi≈øtance or not; but at length being by his Captains per≈øwaded, that his honour would ≈øuffer, if through his neglect the Chri≈øtan cau≈øe ≈øhould be prejudiced; he ≈øent Lilly of Andradu, with twenty two Galleys to joyn with the Venetian Fleet, then lying before Corcyra; nor was the Pope ≈ølow in ≈øending his Galleys, in≈øomuch that the whole Fleet con≈øi≈øted of 155 Galleys, 6 Gallia≈ø≈øes,
and twenty ≈øhips of war; nor was the Turks inferiour in number, lying about Malua≈øia in the entrance of the Bay called Sinus Argolicus, of which the Venetian Admiral having notice, re≈øolved to give them battle what ever happened, but the wary Pirate ∆≤luzales could not be drawnthereto, having before to his co≈øt tryed the courage of the Chri≈øtians lying ≈øtill in the bay, hoping thereby to gain ≈øome advantage, without which he re≈øolved not to fight, but finding the Chri≈øtians every day ready to charge him as he lay, he for his better ≈øecurity found means to ≈øail to Corona, upon which the Chri≈øtian Fleet retired to Cerigo, not finding any opportunity of giving the enemy battle

Whil≈øt matters went thus Don John ≈øent a Frigate to adverti≈øe the Venetian Admiral that he was arrived at Corcyra, commanding him to meet him at Zacynthus, there to con≈øult about the carrying on the war; but when they came thither, the General not regarding his word delayed to meet them, which did not a little trouble the Venetians; but not ≈øtaying there they ≈øailed to Cocyra, where joyning the ≈øhips newly ≈øent to their Aid by ≈øeveral Chri≈øtian Princes, they re≈øolved to ≈øeek out the Enemy, and if po≈ø≈øible to oblige him to fight; whereupon they loo≈øed Anchor, and for the mo≈øt part ≈øailed by night, thinking by that means to oppre≈øs the Enemy e'r he was provided to defend him≈øelf; but this purpo≈øe being di≈øcovered by ≈øome of the Turks Scouts, the Chri≈øtians were prevented in their undertaking; yet ≈øo re≈øolute was the Venetian Admiral that he pre≈ø≈øed the other Generals to enter the Bay, and give them Battle even in the mouth of the Harbour; but this his re≈øolution (though it had pa≈øt doubt proved ≈øucce≈øsful, had it been put in execution) was oppo≈øed by the Spani≈øh General, and Columnius the Popes Admiral,
as not ≈øea≈øonable, but altogether dangerous, even to the hazarding the Chri≈øtian Fleet, which as they alledge was the Bullwark of Chri≈øtendom; yet lying before Nauarinum, they re≈øolved to be≈øiege the Ca≈øtle of Modon both by Sea and Land, which Ca≈øtle lying in mouth of the Bay, defended the Turks Fleet, whereupon Sailing before it, they landed ≈øeven thou≈øand of their mo≈øt re≈øolute Soldiers, and at the ≈øame time appointed ≈øeveral of the Gallea≈ø≈øes and Gallies to batter it with their Great Ordnance; the which more advantagiou≈øly to effect they joyned two Galleys together, with Ma≈øts, Ropes, and other tackling, in the nature of a floating battery, on which they planted Baskets of Earth, and ≈øeveral Pieces of Great Ordnance; but being overcharged with too great a weight, they became u≈øele≈øs, by rea≈øon of the abundance of water that entred them, and at the ≈øame time having notice that a con≈øiderable number of Turki≈øh hor≈øemen had entered by night into the Ca≈øtle, they thought good to give over the ≈øiege, which made the Turks ≈øo adventurous as to ≈øend ≈øeveral of their Galleys out of the Bay to ≈øeize upon a great ≈øhip of the Venetians, that was coming from Zacynthus with provi≈øion for the Fleet, but they were ≈øoon obliged to retire, which all of them did in ≈øafety, except Mahomet, Nephew to Barbaru≈ø≈øa the famous Pirate, who to get him a name, ≈øtayed on purpo≈øe to dare the Chri≈øtians; but being Grapled by the Marque≈øs of St. Crux, after a fierce Engagement he with almo≈øt all his men were ≈ølain, and the Galley taken in the ≈øight of the Turks Fleet, they not daring to come to his a≈ø≈øi≈øtance; after which the Chri≈øtians be≈øieged the ≈øtrong Ca≈øtle of Nauari
‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ m, antiently called Pylus, the charge of which was by General con≈øent of the great Commanders committed to Alexander Farne≈øius Prince of Parma, whom the
Venetians furni≈øhed with Munition and Victuals for the better performance of that ≈øervice, which he no ≈øooner received, but landing 2000 Italians, 1000 Spaniards, and five hundred Germans, with twelve Pieces of Ordnance, did batter the Ca≈øtles ince≈ø≈øantly; but not encompa≈ø≈øing it, as he ought, in the night time a Great number of Turks having made their way through a pathle≈øs Forre≈øt, entered at an un≈øu≈øpected Port, whil≈øt tho≈øe of the Garri≈øon were skirmi≈øhing with the be≈øiegers; whereupon the Princes di≈øpairing to carry it by a≈ø≈øault, rai≈øed the ≈øiege.

The Turks Fleet ≈øhut up in the Bay of Modon, and as it were be≈øieged by the Chri≈øtians, by this time felt great want, which cau≈øed a Pe≈øtilence to rage ≈øo violently among≈øt the Soldiers and Marriners, that many of the Galleys were de≈øerted, and the re≈øt ≈øo ≈ølenderly manned, and ≈øo unprovided of nece≈ø≈øaries, that had the Chri≈øtian Fleet rode it out a moneth longer before the Bay, the Enemies fleet had fell into their hands almo≈øt without fighting; but ≈øuch was the perver≈øene≈øs of the Spani≈øh General, that he would needs return with his Fleet, notwith≈øtanding all the pregnant rea≈øons, and arguments the Venetian Admiral u≈øed to per≈øwade him to the contrary, and ≈øo re≈øolutely was he therein, that he re≈øolved to depart not only without the con≈øent of the Venetians but without their privity, he having in order thereto ≈øtrictly commanded all his Captains, and Ma≈øters of his Gallies, ≈øpeedily to weigh Anchor, and to ≈øtand for the Coa≈øt of Sicily; of which the Venetian Admiral having notice, and not a little troubled thereat, came on board his Galley, and renewed his per≈øwa≈øions for his ≈øtay; but finding all arguments vain, he at lea≈øt reque≈øted him to ≈øtay ≈øo long, till the 2 Gallies fa≈øtened together for a floating Battery might be fetched off, and not be left there as a prey, to which
he hardly con≈øented, alledging that his victuals fell ≈øhort, and if he ≈øhould ≈øtay longer abroad his Fleet would be oppre≈ø≈øed with famine, yet promi≈øed that if he met with the ≈øhips he had ≈øent for out of Sicily loaden with provi≈øion, he would in≈øtantly return, but kept not his word, though he incountred them upon the Coa≈øt of Corcyra; ≈øo that the half ≈øtarved Turks, upon his departure by degrees got out of the Bay, to their no ≈ømall joy, mo≈øt of them getting in ≈øafety to Constantinople. For after the departure of the Spaniards to Me≈ø≈øina, the Venetian and Popes Admiral departed likewi≈øe, the one to Rome, and the other to Venice, having done nothing worthy of ≈øo great preparations as were ≈øet forth by the Chri≈øtian Princes.

About this time Amida King of Tunes being driven out of his Kingdom fled to Don John for Aide, humbly reque≈øting him that he would re≈øtore him to his Kingdom, to which the crafty Spaniard ≈øeemingly hearkned, but having landed his Forces, taken po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of Tunis and other ≈øtrong places, he ≈øent Amida together with his wife and children into Sicily, there to remain as pri≈øoners at large, during their lives, and placed Mahomet his brother in his ≈øtead, who by rea≈øon of his Seniority was rightful Heir to the Kingdom. But withall taking of him a ≈øolemn Oath, that he ≈øhould become and from thenceforth remain a va≈ø≈øal to the Spani≈øh King, and alwayes be ready to do what≈øoever he commanded, and having beaten the Turks and wild Arabs out of the Countrey, he built a new Ca≈øtle in the Middle way, between Culetta and Tunes, and having put a ≈øtrong Garri≈øon therein, as likewi≈øe into Guletta, he returned into Sicilia.

The Venetians ≈øinding no tru≈øt to be repo≈øed in the Spaniards, and of them≈øelves too weak to deal with
the Turks, re≈øolved if po≈ø≈øible to conclude an honourable peace with Selymus, thinking it more for their advantage than to be ≈øubject to the in≈øolent humours of the Spani≈øh General; and thereupon after much debate in the Senate hou≈øe it was re≈øolved that Amba≈ø≈øadors ≈øhould be ≈øent to ≈øound the mind of the Turk; who as it afterward appeared, was no le≈øs de≈øirous of peace then them≈øelves, though he a long time di≈ø≈øembled it; whereupon the Amba≈ø≈øadors arriving at Con≈øtantinople, after much debate ≈øub≈øcribed the Articles of Peace; the ≈øub≈øtance of which were the≈øe. Fir≈øt, that the Venetians ≈øhould pay unto Selimus 300000 Ducates, 100000 to be paid down, and the re≈øt in two equal portions the two ≈øucceeding years. Secondly, That ≈øuch places of the Venetians, as were in the po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of the Turks ≈øhould ≈øtill remain in the hands of the Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øors, but that ≈øuch Towns and Places as the Venetians, during the war had taken from the Turks ≈øhould be in≈øtantly re≈øtored.

This Peace thus concluded, was proclaimed in Con≈øtantinople on the twentieth of March Anno 1574, and at Venice the thirteenth of April following, to the great amazement of the Confederates, when the better to ju≈øtifie them≈øelves in what they had done, the Venetian Senators ≈øent for the Spani≈øh Amba≈ø≈øador and Popes Nuncio, into the Senate hou≈øe, to whom the Duke in a Grave Speech, addre≈ø≈øed him≈øelf to this purpo≈øe. That anger and Hope two evil Coun≈øellors being ≈øet a≈øide, he had concluded a Peace with the Turk, not for that he was de≈øirous of the Turks friend≈øhip, which what account it was to be made of, he right well knew, but for the love he bare to the State, which was not only with lo≈øs but even with death it ≈øelf to be maintained; how he had been ≈øpoiled of the Kingdom of
Cyprus; he further declared, that the Venetian State grew weaker and weaker by continual war, and therefore before it was reduced to extremity, and they not being able to maintain war again≈øt ≈øo Potent an enemy, were to take a ≈øurer cour≈øe for the pre≈øervation of what yet of their Signory remained unto them, for that the ≈øafety of the Venetian State ≈øhould at all times be a ≈øure Fortre≈øs and Defence of the Chri≈øtian Commonweale, again≈øt all the furious attempts of the enemy, and uncertain events of time.

This Peace though di≈øliked of other Chri≈øtian Princes, was advantagious to the Venetians, for as much as the war had made their Trade to cea≈øe, both in the Adriatick and Mediterranean Seas, which upon the conclu≈øion of Peace with the Turks, returned again more then ever, by rea≈øon few other Chri≈øtian Merchants had the like liberty. This peace was the ea≈øier obtained of the Turk for as much as the Spaniard had reduced the Kingdom of Tunis to his obedience, and that the Knights of Malta had an eye upon Tripolis and other Sea port Towns holden by the Turks, upon the Coa≈øt of Barbary, that he might be the more at lea≈øure to defend what he po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed, and if po≈ø≈øible to recover that which his father had lo≈øt, viz. the Kingdom of Tunis; yet declining that enterprize for a time, he converted his Forces again≈øt John the Vayuod of Valachia, who a little before having driven Bogeanus out of Moldavia, had po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed him≈øelf of that Province, but upon his refu≈øing to pay Selymus double the Tribute he agreed for, he held him in ≈øuch di≈øtru≈øt, that he re≈øolved to take from him both his Principalities, and annex them to the Ottoman Empire, to prevent which if po≈ø≈øible, the ≈øaid John rai≈øed a great power, calling to his a≈ø≈øi≈øtance the Co≈ø≈øacks a warlike people of Polonia, who living
upon the Frontiers ≈øecure the kingdom from the incur≈øions of the Tartars, and maintain them≈øelves for the mo≈øt part by ≈øpoiles taken from the enemy, who now in great number under the leading of Su≈øerceuius their Captain, came to the a≈ø≈øi≈øtance of the Vayvod.

Selymus hearing what had pa≈ø≈øed, ≈øent 30000 Turks, and 2000 Hungarians, to joyn ≈øuch Forces as were rai≈øed by the Palatine of Valachia Tran≈øalpine with a Command that he ≈øhould take John the Vayvod, and ≈øend him in bonds to Con≈øtantinople, and in his ≈øtead placed Peter his brother, of which the Palatine an utter Enemy to John was not a little glad nor delayed, but upon the Arrival of the Turks and Hungarians, with an Army of 202000 fighting men pa≈ø≈øed over the River Moldavius, not doubting but with his multitude to oppre≈øs his adver≈øary, but putting too much confidence in his ≈øtrength, and by rea≈øon thereof incamping di≈øorderly, on the Bank of the River, the Vayvod and Captain of the Co≈ø≈øacks ≈øet upon with ≈øuch fury, that ere his Souldiers could recover their Hor≈øes then di≈øper≈øed in the adjacent Medows, or put them≈øelves in a po≈øture of defence, they overwhelmed with ≈øhot, and every where di≈øordered ≈øo, that flying in great confu≈øion mo≈øt of them were ≈ølain or drowned, in attempting to repa≈øs the River, the Palatine and Peter his brother hardly e≈øcaping to the Ca≈øtle of Brailonia in Valachia. In the Palatines Camp, were found ≈øtore of Riches, which the Vayvod be≈øtowed upon his Souldiers, and with Fire and Sword entered Valachia Tran≈øalpine, putting all to the Sword that came in his way, without re≈øpect either to Age or Sex till he came to the Ca≈øtle of Brailonia, in which he under≈øtood that the Palatine and his Brother were in this Ca≈øtle, together with a fair City bearing the ≈øame name, ≈øtandeth on the Banks of Danubius, which at that time was
defended by a ≈øtrong Garri≈øon of Turks, near unto which incamping his Army he wrote to the Captain thereof, commanding him to deliver into his hands the Palatine and his Brother, who had cau≈øele≈øly invaded his Territories, and being overthrown in Battle was fled unto him, the which if he refu≈øed to do, he vowed never to depart from thence till he had con≈øtrained him to yield them up; which Me≈ø≈øage being ≈øent to the Captain by two Valachian Pri≈øoners, he returned four Me≈ø≈øengers, with ten great ≈øhot, ten ≈ømall ≈øhot, and two Turki≈øh Arrows; giving them in charge to tell the Vayvod, that fora≈ømuch as he knew him to be a ≈øervant to his dread Soveraign Selymus he did re≈øpect him, but would in no wi≈øe deliver into his hands tho≈øe he required, but fora≈ømuch as he under≈øtood that he of late had ≈ølain a great number of his Lords Servants, who by his commandement were bringing Peter the Palatines Brother into Moldavia, he therefore commanded him to rai≈øe the ≈øiege or he would make him and his Souldiers ≈øeed upon tho≈øe di≈øhes (meaning the Bullets and Arrows) till gorged to the full they dangerou≈øly ≈øurfeited and ca≈øt. This an≈øwer ≈øo incen≈øed John, that he cau≈øed the Me≈ø≈øengers to be cruelly intreated by cutting off their No≈øes, Lips, and Ears, and nailing them by their feet to a piece of Timber hung them up before the City, with their heads downwards as a terror to the re≈øt, and they furiou≈øly battering the Walls till large breaches appeared, the Souldiers entred by plain force put all to the Sword that they found therein: In≈øomuch that the blood running like a Torrent into the Danubius, crim≈øoned ore its ≈øtream for many a mile. There the greedy Souldiers found ine≈øtimable Wealth, heaped up in many peaceful years; but perceiving the Ca≈øtle not ≈øo ea≈øily to be won as the City he upon
notice of the approach of 15000 Turks to the relief of the former, razed the latter, and ≈øuddainly went to meet them with his Co≈ø≈øacks and 8000 Moldavian Hor≈øemen, and by ≈øpeedy Marches entred their di≈øordered Camp ere they heard he had rai≈øed the ≈øiege, where the inraged Souldiers ≈øo laid about them that ≈øcarcely 1000 of the Turks e≈øcaped, which were afterwards put to the Sword in Teira, which City the Vayvod took and utterly razed, and returning from thence overthrew another Army of the Turks with incredible ≈ølaughter, ≈øo that his name became terrible to the Turks, and made Selymus doubt the keeping of his Dominions in Europe, but as Trea≈øon is always the wreck of pro≈øperous affairs, ≈øo it happened to the Vayvod, for he di≈ø≈øolving a part of his Army and appointing Czarnieuiche, one of his great Captains, and a man ≈øingularly by him beloved, for the Guarding his Frontires and preventing the Turks pa≈ø≈øing the Danubius, corrupted with the Turks Gold he ≈øuffered Peter with a great Army the next Spring to enter Valachia without re≈øi≈øtance, of which the Vayvod having notice, lying then before the Ca≈øtle of Teine, he ≈øent the Captain of the Co≈ø≈øacks, and the Moldavian Hor≈øemen to oppo≈øe their pa≈ø≈øage, who meeting with 6000 of the forerunners of the Turks Army, after a light skirmi≈øh put them to flight and taking one of them though mortally wounded, inquired of him the ≈øtate of the Army that had pa≈ø≈øed Danubius, but he dealing unfaithfully with them, would not make them ≈øen≈øible of the great power which was at hand; yet the Captain of the Co≈ø≈øacks doubting to be oppre≈ø≈øed by multitudes, and having in di≈øtru≈øt the fidelity of Czarnieuiche, ≈øent to the Vayvod to adverti≈øe him thereof, and to de≈øire him to provide for him≈øelf and the ≈øafety of his Army, but he as a man re≈øolved
to give the Turks Battle, returned for an≈øwer that in the fir≈øt place he little doubted of the Faith of him whom he had found mo≈øt faithful in the time of his greate≈øt di≈øtre≈øs, and u≈øed as a mo≈øt tru≈øty companion in all his Travels, and that it was no time now to ≈øtand in doubt or be afraid, and that as for him≈øelf, he would ere long come with the re≈øt of the Army, and take a view of the Enemies Camp, for that he was not come ≈øo far to fly but to fight in the defence of his Subjects and Country, and ≈øo within four dayes after he joyned with the forerunners of his Army, and incamped near a Lake, which runneth out of Danubius, and with ≈øeveral of his tru≈øty followers a≈øcended a high Hill, the better to take a veiw of the Enemies huge Camp, upon which plainly perceiving that he was betrayed by Czarnieuiche, who had then under his command 13000 of his choice Souldiers, he ≈øent for him, but he doubting his Trea≈øon was di≈øcovered, ≈øent him word that he could not now come, the Enemy being ≈øo nigh at hand, but that he ≈øhould without delay ≈øee him in the Field as forward as the mo≈øt couragious again≈øt the Enemy, but herein he failed his Lord; for Battle being joyned he cau≈øed his En≈øigns to be let fall, and revolted to the Enemy, which ≈øo di≈øcouraged the re≈øt of the Souldiers that after a de≈øperate and bloody fight, finding them≈øelves oppre≈øs'd with multitudes, and their Countrey-men who ≈øhould have a≈ø≈øi≈øted them, fighting again≈øt them, they gave back, which the Vayvod perceiving cau≈øed the retreat to be ≈øounded, and with 20000 Foot men, and ≈øuch Hor≈øemen as e≈øcaped the Battle, retired in as good order as the danger would permit, into the ruins of an old Town which a little before he had razed, and therein ≈øtrongly Fortified him≈øelf round about, which next day the Turks incamped, but
perceiving that it was not onely difficult but dangerous to a≈ø≈øault him in his ≈øtrength, they ≈øent Me≈ø≈øengers to him, to per≈øwade him to yield to Mercy and not expo≈øe his own Life, and the lives of ≈øo many of his Subjects to the fury of the inraged Souldiers, or mi≈øeries they would be ≈øhortly reduced to by Famine, offering the Oaths of all the chief Commanders for his own ≈øecurity and the ≈øecurity of his people, to which propo≈øals he being per≈øwaded to hearken he in con≈øideration that the Co≈ø≈øacks might be permitted to return with their Hor≈øes and Armes, into their own Countrey; that him≈øelf might be alive conveyed into the pre≈øence of Selymus, there to make his defence, and that his Subjects might return to their re≈øpective homes, or take ≈øervice with the Turks; agreed to come out of his ≈øtrength and ≈øubmit him≈øelf, to which his demands Capucius Ba≈ø≈øa General of the Turks Army con≈øented, and him≈øelf with the re≈øt of the great Commanders ≈øwore ≈øeven times (a u≈øual cu≈øtom among≈øt the Turks for the ≈øolemnly obliging them≈øleves) to fulfil his reque≈øt. Whereupon he came forth onely accompanied with O≈ømolius a Polonian Captive, but after four hours continuance in the Turks Camp the perfidious Ba≈ø≈øa ≈øending for him unexpectedly with his Scimiter ≈øtruck him cro≈øs the face, and afterwards wounded him in the Belly, upon which ≈øignal the Janizaries pre≈øent took him and cut off his head, which they fixing upon the point of a Lance, carrying it in deri≈øion through the Camp: nor ≈øatisfied with barbarous and ba≈øe indignities, they at the commandment of the Ba≈ø≈øa tore his body in pieces with Camels, and ≈øoon after put all the Chri≈øtians whom they had allured out of their ≈øtrength to the Sword who yet fell not unrevenged, for the Co≈ø≈øacks perceiving the hard plight they were in, ≈øered together, and with
their weapons in their hands made a great ≈ølaughter of the Enemy, but being few in number except their Captain, and ≈øome other men of note they were all ≈ølain.

After this ≈øhameful Murther the Turks over run all Moldavia and Valachia, recovering in a ≈øhort time the ≈øtrong places that were po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed by the Vayoods Garri≈øons, after which Selymus intent for the recovery of the Kingdom of Tunis in po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of the Spaniards ≈øent 300 ≈øail of Gallies under the command of Sinan Pial, and ∆≤luzales his chief Ba≈ø≈øa's to reduce it to his obedience, who after the lo≈øs of 30000 Turks, with great difficulty took the ≈øtrong Ca≈øtle of Guletta, and the new Ca≈øtle built at the Commandment of Don John in his late expedition again≈øt the Moori≈øh Rebels, which ≈øtrong hold lo≈øt, Tunes ≈øurrendered without making any con≈øiderable re≈øi≈øtance, and in it was taken Mahomet the late inve≈øted King, whom the Turks ≈øent Pri≈øoner to Con≈øtantinople. But Selymus long ≈øurvived not this victory over the Spaniards, but being ≈øpent with Wine and Women, to whom he had given his greate≈øt ≈øtrength he died on the 9th. of December, anno 1574. having lived 51 years, and thereof Reigned eight, he lies buryed at Hadrinople, leaving his Empire to Amurath his Elde≈øt Son, who ≈øucceeded him by the name of Amurath the Third, as will appear in the ≈øeries of his Life and Reign.

div.head: CHAP. XVI. The Life, Reign, and Memorable Tran≈øactions of Amurath the Third of that Name, and ≈øixth Emperor of the Turks.
div.p:
SElymus dead, and his Death kept ≈øecret from the Janizaries for the ≈øpace of twelve dayes, at the end of which Amurath arriving at Con≈øtantinople, was received into the Seraglio, and took po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of the Empire, when having pacified the unruly Souldiers with great liberality, he cau≈øed according to the Turki≈øh policy, Mu≈øtapha, Solyman, Abdula, O≈øman and Tzihanger his five brethren to be ≈øtrangled, with how ≈øtrings even in his ≈øight, the rea≈øon of which ≈øtrangling is becau≈øe they would not ≈øpill any of the Othoman ≈øacred blood as they term it on the ground, upon the death of whom the Mother of Solyman overcome with grief and di≈øpair, ≈øtabbed her ≈øelf to the Heart with a Dagger, at which Tragical ≈øight it is reported that Amurath wept, as not delighted with ≈øuch unnatural cr ‚Ä¢
elty, but that the manner and nature of his Government ≈øo required, for that by rea≈øon of the largene≈øs of the Ottoman Empire, if many of the Princes of the blood lived at one and the ≈øame time, they would probably with civil di≈ø≈øen≈øions rend it in pieces.

Anno 1575 Amurath e≈øtabli≈øhed many whol≈øom Laws, altered the Coin, and bountifully relieved the poor, and albeit he was of a mild and peaceable nature, yet that he might ≈øeem like to his Predece≈ø≈øors
he pro≈øecuted his Fathers Wars, and aided by the Tartars entered into Ru≈øcia part of the Territories of the King of Polonia, where he burnt and de≈øtroyed 200 Ca≈øtles, be≈øides a great number of Towns and Villages, putting multitudes of the poor people to the Sword, and carrying as many into mi≈øerable Captivity, but the Tartar had little joy of their ≈øucce≈øs, for whil≈øt they were bu≈øie in Ru≈øcia the Co≈ø≈øack brake into their Kingdom, and de≈øtroyed all before them for the ≈øpace of 100 miles.

That which gave the Turks encouragement to enter the Territories of Polonia, was the divi≈øion among≈øt the nobility for Henry D' Valoys their King, upon notice that his brother Charles the Ninth French King was dead, ≈øecretly departed to take upon him the Kingdom of France, to which he was rightful Heire, whereupon one party was for Electing Maximilian the German Emperour, and the other ≈øtrongly oppo≈øing them would have introduced the great Duke of Mu≈øcovy. Of which Amurath having notice, and ≈øuppo≈øing that to which ≈øoever of them it fell he would prove a trouble≈øome Neighbour, he ≈øent a Letter to di≈ø≈øwade the Nobility and Coun≈øelors of the Kingdom to chu≈øe neither, but to Elect a King among≈øt them≈øelves, or el≈øe Stephen Buttor Prince of Tran≈øylvania, and in ≈øo doing they ≈øhould find him their con≈øtant Friend, or in refu≈øing to comply with his de≈øire to expect all the calamities that attend on War. In this Letter the proud Turk ≈øtiled him≈øelf God of the Earth, Governour of the whole World, the Me≈ø≈øenger of God, and faithful ≈øervant of the great Prophet. Yet ≈øo it effectually wrought with the Polonian Nobility, that notwith≈øtanding Maximilian the Emperour was by the Arch Bi≈øhop of Gne≈øna and ≈øome others, Elected King; yet was that their Election by the great part of the
Electors di≈øannulled, as al≈øo the great Duke of Mo≈øcovy rejected, and the Noble Prince≈øs Anne of the mo≈øt Honourable Jagelionian hou≈øe cho≈øen Queen of Polonia, upon condition that ≈øhe ≈øhould Marry Stephen Prince of Tran≈øylvania, which ≈øhe afterward performed, as in the ≈øeries of this Hi≈øtory will appear.

Amurath upon the afore-mentioned conditions having drawn his Army out of Ru≈øcia, and taking advantage of the di≈øcord ari≈øing in the Kingdom of Per≈øia, upon the death of Tamas re≈øolved to bend his Forces to the Conque≈øt of that great Kingdom, which (the di≈ø≈øen≈øion among≈øt the Sons of the decea≈øed King about the ≈øucce≈ø≈øion, made him ≈øuppo≈øe) was ea≈øie to be effected, whereupon rai≈øing ≈øuch great Forces as held Chri≈øtendom in ≈øu≈øpence, he yet declined attempting any thing till he had knowledge what effects the civil broyls had wrought, which were that after a long contention, and the Murther of many of the Sons and Grandchildren of the decea≈øed King, Mahomet Elde≈øt ≈øon to Tamas, who had before rejected the Diadem, to prevent the ruin of his Native Country, took upon him the Regency, though not without the envy of many of the great Sultans, who≈øe guilt upon his being proclaimed King had cau≈øed them to fly, who like thorow paced Traitors in their exile ≈øolicited Amurath by all means ≈øpeedily to invade the Kingdom of Per≈øia, laying before him the facility of conquering that noble Kingdom, abounding with all manner of riches, and that the Georgians and Saracens evily affected towards the new King, would not fail upon the approach of his Army to joyn with him. The≈øe and the like per≈øwa≈øions fired the Turk with hopes of ≈øo glorious an atchievement, that notwith≈øtanding he was in League with the Per≈øian, yet after long debating the
matter in the Divan, it was re≈øolved that the War ≈øhould be undertaken and carryed on with all vigor, and that the fir≈øt attempt ≈øhould be made upon the Countrey of Servan, the better to effect which by alaruming the Enemy in divers places, he ≈øent to his Ba≈ø≈øa's Governours of Babylon, Van, and other places on the Per≈øian Frontiers, to mole≈øt the Territories by frequent inroads, to perform which they were no ways wanting. And now Stephen the Prince of Tran≈øilvania having marryed Queen Anne, and being confirmed by the free choice of the Nobility King of Poland, he ≈øent his Amba≈ø≈øadors to Amurath, to conclude a firm and inviolable League, which was granted by the Turk very advantageous to the Chri≈øtians, that he might not be hindered in his Per≈øian War, which in Anno 1578. he undertook, ≈øending a great Army under the leading of Mu≈øtapha Ba≈ø≈øa (who in the Reign of Selymus had Conquered Cyprus) into the Countrey of Servan, compo≈øed of the≈øe following Nations, viz, 12000 Me≈øopotamians, 14000 Babylonians and A≈ø≈øyrians, 2000 Syrians, 10000 Natolians, 1000 Jews of Pala≈øtine, 4000 Cilicians, after which followed the Soldiers of Grecia, the Glory and Hope of the whole Camp to the number of 10000, as likewi≈øe 10000 Janizaries, Harquibu≈øires, to whom 4000 of the Citizens of Er Zic≈øhum were added be≈øides many Voluntiers of divers Nations: in≈øomuch that the whole Army con≈øi≈øted of 110000 Hor≈øe and Foot, be≈øides this multitude of men, Mu≈øtapha brought into Per≈øia 500 pieces of Artillery, and 50 Waggon loads of Money to leavy other Soldiers, if occa≈øion required it.

The Ba≈ø≈øa with the Army afore≈øaid, arriving at Chars, after three dayes ≈øtaying there, during which time being marvellou≈øly troubled by rea≈øon of a ≈øuddain Tempe≈øt, he rai≈øed his Camp and departed to
the foot of the Mountains of Chielder, otherwi≈øe Periardo, where he had knowledge of the Per≈øian Sophies Army Approach, which cau≈øed him to put his Army into order of Battle, dividing it among≈øt his great Commanders, which were Deruis Ba≈ø≈øa of Caraunt, and O≈øman Mahomet, and Mu≈øta Fada Ba≈ø≈øas; as for the Per≈øian Army under the leading of Tocomac an experienced Captain, whom for his known valour and Loyalty, the Sophy had made General, it con≈øi≈øted not of above twenty thou≈øand, all Hor≈øemen, gathered out of Georgia, Media, and Antropatia, who mi≈øinformed by their Scouts of the Turks number, boldly held on their way, re≈øolving to give them Battle, who from the Hills perceiving their intent, put them≈øelves in a po≈øture to receive them: whereupon about one in the Afternoon, a dreadful ≈øight began, wherein at the fir≈øt charge were ≈ølain ≈øeven of the Turks Sanzacks, with a Great number of Soldiers without any apparent lo≈øs to the Per≈øians, who fighting clo≈øe together ≈ølew the Turks at a di≈øtance with their ≈øhot of Arrows, and the continual thundering of their Harquibuzes, of which Engins by this time they had learned the perfect u≈øe. But Mu≈øtapha, who with a great power of his choice ≈øouldiers, having waited a fit opportunity, peirced the Squadrons of the hor≈øe, having fir≈øt made a lane by the reiterated Vollies of his Artillery, and charged with ≈øuch fury, that although the Per≈øians incouraging each other did all than men were capable to perform, yet being overpowered with number, were at length broken and di≈øordered; they under the ≈øhelter of the night retired, which the Turks without much difficulty permitted, they not having any cau≈øe to rejoyce at the Victory ≈øo gotten, their lo≈øs was ≈øo great, yet keeping the field all that night, the next morning in token of his good ≈øucce≈øs, Mu≈øtapha ≈øent
the heads of five thou≈øand Per≈øians, and three thou≈øand live pri≈øoners to Amurath, and for the greater terror of the enemy, cau≈øed the heads of three thou≈øand others to be ≈øtricken off, and piled on heaps; the Turks lo≈øt in this battle near twenty thou≈øand, many of their chief ≈øouldiers.

The next day after the battle Manuchlars, a Prince of the Georgians ≈øent a me≈ø≈øenger to Mu≈øtapha, to acquaint him that he was coming to confer with him, which did not a little rejoyce the Turk; in≈øomuch that he cau≈øed all his Great Commanders with Trumpets, En≈øigns di≈øplayed, Drums beating, and the di≈øcarge of all the Great Ordnance to receive him, and in like manner to conduct him to his Pavillion (not doubting but that the revolt of this Prince would greatly further his affairs) which being being done, and he entering the Ba≈ø≈øa's Tent, he there was cau≈øed to ≈øit down on his right hand, when after having made him pre≈øents of ≈øuch chings as for that purpo≈øe he had brought, he gave the Ba≈ø≈øa to under≈øtand, That for the honour and e≈øtimation he conceived of the Turki≈øh valour, he was ever devoted to the hou≈øe of the Ottomans, and as he had often times de≈øired to venture his life and fortune in their ≈øervice, ≈øo at this pre≈øent time he moved by his former de≈øire, allured by the ≈øtrange fame of his wonderful and victorious Army, and ≈øtirred up by a particular Fanta ‚Ä¢ e to learn the Turki≈øh Di≈øcipline in martial affairs, under ≈øuch a General as was the Ba≈ø≈øa, to whom he offered all his devotion and ≈øervice, things as he ≈øaid not offered to any before, and in ≈øine be≈øought him to accept of him in the name of Amurath, who≈øe obedient va≈ø≈øal he had vowed him≈øelf.

This Speech ended the Ba≈ø≈øa highly commended him for his prudent choice and good will towards the Turks; and the more to confirm him in the opinion
he had of the Ottoman Greatne≈øs, he cau≈øed him to be led throughout his Camp, that ≈øo he might take a view of the Turki≈øh Magnificence, where among≈øt other things he with dete≈øtation beheld the Pile of Per≈øian heads, and then returning to Mu≈øtaphas Tent, he was pre≈øented with Garments of cloth of Gold, a Gilt Battle Ax and Target enameled with divers precious ≈øtones, and never permitted him to go from his Pavillion without a train of his ≈ølaves attending on him.
