Things being at this pa≈øs, the Ba≈ø≈øa was about to rai≈øe his Camp, to march into the very heart of Per≈øia, when loe the face of the Heavens became black as Egyptian darkne≈øs, and upon a ≈øudden ≈øuch Prodigious Thunders, Lightning, Rain and Hail, broke from the yielding Clouds, that it ≈øeemed to mo≈øt that the di≈ø≈øolution of all things was at hand, the wind every where renting the Turki≈øh Tents in pieces, and carrying them into the Air; which Tempe≈øt and the noi≈øom ≈øtench ari≈øing from the Carka≈øes of the dead, cau≈øed ≈øuch a Pe≈øtilence in the Camp, that upon the mu≈øter taken four dayes after forty thou≈øand Turks were wanting, yet when the weather cleared up he removed, pa≈ø≈øing by the ≈øides of the Great Mountain, and in his way taking in ≈øeveral Ca≈øtles and Fortre≈ø≈øes, though not without the lo≈øs of many of his men; nor were the Per≈øians wanting to cut off his rear and the ≈øtraglers of his Camp, as they found opportunity, by which means many thou≈øands of their Forragers and ≈øuch as greedy of booty left the Army, were cut ≈øhort, yet having received a great ≈øupply of Provi≈øion from Aleppo, he marched into the Country of Siruan, when by the way Ale≈ø≈øandro another Prince of the Georgians came to the Ba≈ø≈øas Pavillion & ≈øubmitted him≈øelf, as the former had done, being thereupon welcomed in the ≈øame
nature, receiving rich pre≈øents from the Ba≈ø≈øa as a token of his favour, as likewi≈øe a promi≈øe that upon his return he would pa≈øs through his Countrey to pay him a vi≈øit.

The Turks traveling twelve dayes by long marches came into the confines of Sirvan, but finding all the Country de≈øtroyed before them, they fell into many ill conveniencies, for by the means afore≈øaid pale famine began to ≈øtare them in the face, which obliged them to ≈øearch for provi≈øion in all places, yet finding little, as they were about to return to the Camp they happened on ≈øeveral Per≈øian ≈øpies, out of whom they extorted that after they had pa≈ø≈øed certain Mar≈øhes where Canac di≈øcharged it ≈øelf into Araxis they ≈øhould find certain fields of Rice and ≈øtanding Corn, together with divers herds of Cattle, enough to ≈øuffice the whole Army for a months ≈øpace, which being made known unto the Ba≈ø≈øa, he not greatly credited the Report, and therefore would not pa≈øs thither with the whole Army, but freely permitted ≈øuch as would, to go, ≈øo that about ten thou≈øand of the mo≈øt hunger≈øtarved, with ≈øuch nece≈ø≈øaries as they thought fit, went to ≈øei≈øe upon this booty, but had no ≈øooner pa≈ø≈øed the River and ≈øome ≈øew Mar≈øhes, but they fell into the Per≈øian Ambu≈øh, laid for that purpo≈øe, who put them almo≈øt all to the ≈øword; but whil≈øt they were taking the ≈øpoil Mu≈øtapha having notice by the flyers what had happened, came upon them with the whole Army ≈øo ≈øuddenly that he hemmed them, as it were in an I≈øland, made by the meandring of Araxis and Canac, where ≈øetting upon them, after a bloody fight put them to the wor≈øt, killing a great many of them, and forcing other to take the River, wherein many of them peri≈øhed, Tocomac the General and three other great Captains hardly e≈øcaping.

After which Mu≈øtapha re≈øolved to pa≈øs the River Canac, of which the Souldiers having notice, began not only to murmur but to Mutiny throughout the Camp, alledging that he carryed them to their certain de≈øtruction for that being in a ≈øtrange Countrey, where all nece≈ø≈øaries whereby to ≈øub≈øi≈øt were wanting, whereby they ≈øhould ≈øub≈øi≈øt, they mu≈øt inevitably peri≈øh, but he urging that it was the command of Amurath, and if no man but him≈øelf would pa≈ø≈øe over he him≈øelf would obey his Lords command, whereupon notwith≈øtanding the unwillingne≈øs of three parts of the Army the next day the better to encourage his Captains and Souldiiers him≈øelf waded over, and after him followed a great number of his ≈ølaves, and the re≈øt of the great Commanders, but ≈øo ≈ølowly by rea≈øon of the ≈øwiftne≈øs of the River, that night approached ere half the Army had gained the farther bank, when the ≈øtream ≈øwelling with the force of the Wind and darkne≈øs making the Souldiers fearful, 8000 of them were driven headlong down the currant into the deep places, where they mi≈øerably peri≈øhed together, with a great number of Camels and Hor≈øes, ≈øo that the Per≈øians living upon the Banks many miles di≈øtance, perceiving the number of dead Turks together with their weapons floating with the ≈øtream, concluded the Army was overthrown, nor was the fortune of tho≈øe that pa≈ø≈øed over for a time much better, for coming into a barren Countrey, a great number of them died for want, yet having pa≈ø≈øed thus far a greater mi≈øchief would have befallen them had they returned, and therefore being every way be≈øet with danger they re≈øolutely marched forward, either to find relief or to end their days in mi≈øery. But contrary to their expectation, after two dayes hard marching they came into a plentiful Countrey ≈øtored with all manner
of Provi≈øions which did not a little revive them, being before even at the point to peri≈øh, after which having mo≈øt of the Cities of Sirvan yielded to him, he put Garri≈øons therein and furni≈øhing them with all nece≈ø≈øaries at the importunity of his Souldiers re≈øolved to return home and ≈øo pa≈ø≈øing through the Countrey of Prince Aleflander, where he revictualled and relieved the Garri≈øon of Te≈øtis, who through Famine were reduced to ≈øuch nece≈ø≈øity, that no unclean thing was left uneaten, and ≈øo pa≈ø≈øing through the ≈øtraights of the rough Mountains, where he lo≈øt a number of his people, he at length arrived at Erzirum where without any mu≈øter he di≈øcharged his Army; thereby to hide the great lo≈øs he had ≈øu≈øtained from the knowledge of Amurath, and forgot not by Letters to magnifie his own exploits; ≈øending withal the two Georgian Princes who had ≈øubmitted them≈øelves, with Letters of recommendation to Amurath.

It was not long after the departure of Mu≈øtapha, but the Tartars in confederacy with the Turks, having left the Fens of Moetis, and the unmountable ≈øhoars of the Black Sea, pa≈ø≈øing over the Rocks upon Colchis, and the frozen crags of the Mountain Cauca≈øus, entered Sirvan with an Army of 30000 Hor≈øe, under the leading of Abdilcherai, who no le≈øs terrified the Per≈øians then had the Turks, but after the taking of many Cities, and ranging about the Country for prey, as one day they lay di≈øper≈øed in a Valley near to E'res, Emire Hamze Mirize Elde≈øt Son to Mahomet the Per≈øian Sophy, came upon them unawares with 12000 Hor≈øemen, and ere they could put them≈øelves in a po≈øture of defence, ≈ølew 15000 of them and took almo≈øt all the re≈øt Pri≈øoners, and among≈øt them Abdilcherai Son as he pretended him≈øelf to the great Cham, who being ≈øent Pri≈øoner to
Cabiu the Regal ≈øeat of the Per≈øian Sophy, ≈øo won upon the favour of the King and Queen, but ≈øpecially of the latter, who was ≈øaid to be more prodigal of her favours towards him then ≈øtood with her honour, and at the ≈øame time Mahomet intending to match him to his Daughter, thereby to procure the Friend≈øhip of the great Tartarian Cham: it ≈øo far moved the Sultans or great men of the Court with envy that they ≈ølew him in the Palace, and at the ≈øame time as many reported ≈øtrangled the Queen, whom they found over familiar with him in his Chamber, but whether ≈øo or not certain it is ≈øhe was never afterwards ≈øeen.

The Tartars Forces thus de≈øtroyed, the Terror of the young Per≈øian Prince was ≈øo great, that what by Stratagem and plain Force, he wre≈øted out of the Turks hands mo≈øt of the Cities they had before po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed. In≈øomuch that (the City of Derbent of which O≈øman Ba≈ø≈øa was Governour with the title of Vizar of Sirnan excepted) the Turks were driven out of all their ≈øtrong places, nor was it long ere the Per≈øian Sophy practi≈øed with Shahamel, Lord of the Mountain of Brus, who≈øe Daughter O≈øman had married to betray him and the City into his power, for that he was the onely man among≈øt the Georgians whom O≈øman tru≈øted, who won by the great promi≈øes of the Sophy, without any re≈øpect to the Turk as he was his Son-in-Law, undertook to gratifie him in his de≈øire, but he carried not the matter ≈øo clo≈øe but his Daughter under≈øtanding what that pa≈ø≈øed, and more ≈øtudious for the pre≈øervation of her Husband, than furthering her Fathers purpo≈øe, ≈øhe ≈øtill revealed all ≈øhe knew; which ≈øo inwardly perplexed O≈øman that he re≈øolved to prevent the Treachery of his Father-in-law by taking him out of the way, whereupon as his u≈øual manner was inviting him to a
≈øolemn Fea≈øt with a chearful countenance he commanded 500 of his Soldiers to be in a readine≈øs, and that as ≈øoon as Sahamel was entered the Court off his Pallace to ≈øeize him, and after having cut of his Head to put all his followers to the Sword, which was accordingly put in execution, and not ≈øo contented, he ≈øent out 2000 Hor≈øemen to ≈øpoil his Countrey, to the great a≈øtoni≈øhment of all the neighbouring Princes, but to the exceeding grief of the Sophy who found his hopes fru≈øtrated by the death of Sahamel.

The year following, viz. 1578. Amurath calling to him his Ba≈ø≈øa's, con≈øulted what was further to be done in relation to the Per≈øian War; when after a long debate, it was upon mature deliberation re≈øolved that it was a matter of dangerous con≈øequence to ≈øend an Army into the heart of Per≈øia, where they ≈øhould not only have a fierce Enemy to deal with, but likewi≈øe many other difficulties, as hunger, overflowing of Rivers, pa≈ø≈øing craggy Mountains and the like: But that it was therefore nece≈ø≈øary, that by degrees they ≈øhould pa≈øs conquering on from the Borders ≈øtill ≈øecuring all at their backs, the care of managing which being referred to Mu≈øtapha, he ≈øent into all the Heredatary Countries of the Empire, commanding the re≈øpective Governours to ≈øend him ≈øtore of Pioners, and men skilled in Architect, as likewi≈øe a great number of the mo≈øt expert Souldiers, but e≈øpecially tho≈øe that had been disbanded the year before, upon notice of which great multitudes flocked to the ≈øervice, who early in the Spring met at Erzirum, from whence they marched under the command of the Ba≈ø≈øa to Chars, a City on the Frontiers of Sirnan, which in the late War had been demoli≈øhed; yet now again Rebuilt and Fortified within the ≈øpace of 23 dayes, notwith≈øtanding
the abundance of Snow that fell during their labouring therein, the which was no ≈øooner fini≈øhed but news came that the ≈øtrong Ca≈øtle of Te≈øtis was be≈øieged by the Per≈øians, who had reduced the Garri≈øon to ≈øo great a ≈øtraight that through Famine, they would be obliged to yield up the place if they were not ≈øpeedily relieved. Upon which in great perplexity he ≈øent Ha≈ø≈øan Ba≈ø≈øa, Son to Mahomet Principal Vizar of the Court, and Re≈øuan Captain of the Adventurers with 20000 Hor≈øe and Foot, furni≈øhed with Provi≈øions and others Nece≈ø≈øaries for the relief of the Be≈øieged, who pa≈ø≈øing the ≈øtraits of Tomanis, were ≈øet upon by 8000 Per≈øians under the leading of Aliculi Cham and Simon two expert Captains, who in tho≈øe intricate mazes ≈ølew many of them, and took con≈øiderable ≈øpoil, which ≈øo hightened them that within a while after ≈øetting upon the Turks, and thinking to have the like advantage fell into their Ambu≈øh, ≈øo that mo≈øt of the Per≈øians fell by the Sword or were taken Pri≈øoners, and among≈øt the latter Aliculi Cham; wwhich gave Ha≈ø≈øan opportunity to march without further controul to Te≈øtis, where through Famine he found half the Garri≈øon lo≈øt, yet encouraging them in the be≈øt wi≈øe, and ≈øtoring them with all manner of Provi≈øion and Warlike Munition, he having at their reque≈øt di≈øplaced Mahomet the Governour, and con≈øtituted Amet Ba≈ø≈øa in his ≈øtead he was about to return the ≈øame way he came, but upon notice that Simon had ≈øtrongly po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed him≈øelf of the afore≈øaid ≈øtraights, and barrocadoed them with his great Artillery, he was wonderfully perplexed as di≈øpairing of his ≈øafe return, which Aliculi perceiving promi≈øed upon con≈øideration that he would relea≈øe him, to ≈øhew him a way both plain and ea≈øie, through which he might pa≈øs without any danger from the
Per≈øians, whereupon the Ba≈ø≈øa ≈øwore to perform what he reque≈øted; but afterwards, as is very u≈øual among≈øt tho≈øe Infidels revoked his Oath excu≈øing him≈øelf, by ≈øaying, it was not in his power to relea≈øe any Pri≈øoner taken in War without the con≈øent of his General: of which perfidious dealing Sinan having notice, who before in con≈øideration of the delivery of Aliculi had winked at their pa≈ø≈øage, he with his Light-Hor≈øemen pur≈øued hard after them, when overtaking the Rear he charged them with ≈øuch fury, that in great confu≈øion they fled. In which flight a great number were ≈ølain and taken Pri≈øoners with a great booty, e≈øpecially the Trea≈øure of the Ba≈ø≈øa, and of Re≈øuan Captain of the Adventurers, which lo≈øs ≈øo ≈øen≈øibly afflicted Mu≈øtapha that upon notice thereof he broke up his Army, not thinking it convenient to attempt any thing further that year, and ≈øoon after he being di≈øcharged of his General≈øhip was called home, where upon his arrival at Court, he was accu≈øed by Sinan Ba≈ø≈øa, for neglecting the Emperours affairs, wa≈øting his Trea≈øure in unnece≈ø≈øary buildings, and rather giving the Enemy cau≈øe to contemn the Ottoman Forces, then to fear their Prowe≈øs.

The≈øe and many other ≈øuch like complaints being exhibited again≈øt him ≈øo incen≈øed Amurath, that he re≈øolved he ≈øhould be ≈øtrangled; in order to which he ≈øent his chief Gentleman Porter, attended on by fifteen others to the Ba≈ø≈øas Pallace, but the crafty old blade being forewarned of what was intended again≈øt him, cau≈øed him≈øelf for a long time to be denyed, but when the me≈ø≈øengers impatient of delay, urged that he mu≈øt and ≈øhould render obedience to the Emperors warrant (which they then produced) they were admitted to his pre≈øence, but fru≈øtrated
of their de≈øign, by a Guard that inclo≈øed the Ba≈ø≈øa with weapons, forbidding any acce≈øs further then a circle made for that purpo≈øe, which they perceiving, thought it no time to put their de≈øign in practice, but rather to intreat him by fair means to come to Court, which he refu≈øing, they pre≈øented him one of the Emperors Letters, in which he commanded him that if he would not come in per≈øon, yet to ≈øend his Chancellor and Trea≈øurer, to give up their accounts, and to an≈øwer to the accu≈øation again≈øt him and them, to which he con≈øented, upon promi≈øe that they ≈øhould not be prejudiced thereby, yet upon their arrival they were ≈øent pri≈øoners to the Tower called Jadicula, but by the Mediation of certain Great Ladies of the Court, bribed with Jewels of Extraordinary price, the Ba≈ø≈øas peace being made, and he coming into the Emperors pre≈øence, all was blown over, and his two Mini≈øters ≈øet at liberty, without any further examination.

During the≈øe pa≈ø≈øages the Great Vizar Ba≈ø≈øa Muhamet was ≈øtabb'd in the Divano by a private Souldier, whom he had bereaved of his Pen≈øion, got at the price of his long ≈øervice in the wars, for which the ≈øaid ≈øouldier was put to death with mo≈øt exqui≈øite Torments, in who≈øe place Mu≈øtapha Ba≈ø≈øa laboured to be cho≈øen as his right by cour≈øe, but Amurath inwardly di≈øplea≈øed with his proceedings, rejected his ≈øute, and ≈øent the ≈øeal to Sivan Ba≈ø≈øa, whom he al≈øo made General for the Per≈øian war, who preparing a great Army marched to the Frontiers, and there expected the ≈øucce≈øs of Maxut Chau the Per≈øian Amba≈ø≈øador then arrived at Con≈øtantinople to ≈øue for peace, but not obtaining his de≈øire on ≈øuch Articles as he in≈øi≈øted on, both Potentates prepared for a re≈øolute and vigorous war, the one to offend, and the other to defend, during which time Mu≈øtapha Ba≈ø≈øa dyed at Con≈øtantinople,
≈øuppo≈øed either to have been poy≈øoned by the command of Amurath, or el≈øe that to prevent the fate of ≈øtrangling he had poi≈øoned him≈øelf.

The Per≈øian Amba≈ø≈øador being returned to his Ma≈øter, and giving him to under≈øtand that there was no peace to be had with the Turk unle≈øs he would peaceably deliver into his po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion the Country of Sir ‚Ä¢ an, and that him≈øelf being taken for a Spye in the Turki≈øh Court, was glad to give Amurath great hopes of obtaining his de≈øire, to prevent death or impri≈øonment, yet that it remained at the plea≈øure of the King whether he would ≈øtand to any thing that had been by him propo≈øed; for which good ≈øervice of Mexut Chau the Sophy made him Great Trea≈øurer of Tauris, which at that time was Governed by Emir Chau his mortal enemy, who ≈øought by all the means he could to de≈øtroy him; wherefore declining to go thither in per≈øon, he officiated his Office by his Deputy, of which Emir taking hold of as a fit opportunity to work his de≈øtruction, ≈øecretly induced the Sophy to believe that he held ≈øecret corre≈øpondence with the Turks, and for that rea≈øon lay hovering on the Frontiers, placing a ba≈øe fellow as his Deputy to officiate ≈øo great a Tru≈øt which was not a little di≈øhonour to the Maje≈øty of the Per≈øian King; whereupon the Sophy gave him power to ≈øeize Mexut Chau and mo≈øt of his principal ≈øervants, and by Torture to wring out of them the truth of the matter.

Glad was Emir to have ≈øo fair an opportunity to de≈øtroy Mexut, and thereupon without further delay ≈øent fifteen ≈øtout fellows to Caffangich Mexuts place of abode to fetch him and his ≈øervants by force, who arriving there, and having admittance to his pre≈øence, he promi≈øed to go with them, and gave to each of them a pre≈øent, ordering his Steward to
make them merry, whil≈øt he prepared him≈øelf to accompany them to their Lord Emir, but with ≈øecret command to make them drunk, which his Steward ≈øo ≈øuddenly effected, that within an hours ≈øpace they fell fa≈øt a≈øleep, which Maxut perceiving, fa≈øt bound them with ropes, and throwing them into a deep well, with all his family fled to the Turki≈øh Ba≈ø≈øa, then with his Army on the Frontiers, who upon notice of what had happened kindly received him.

Sivan Ba≈ø≈øa having ≈øtayed at Chars with the Turki≈øh Army eight dayes, he by ea≈øie marches came to Teflis, having by the way lo≈øt many of his Forragers cut off by the Georgian Hor≈øemen, but arriving at the place afore≈øaid he was recruited out of Syria and Judea, and having di≈øtributed part of his Trea≈øure among≈øt the Souldiers, and ≈øet all things in order, he with his Army departed thence; when pa≈ø≈øing the Strait of Tomanis, he had notice from Mu≈øta≈ø≈øad (afterwards Governor of Aleppo) that not far di≈øtant on the right hand, were ≈øeveral fields of ≈øtanding Corn and Herds of Cattle grazing ≈ølenderly guarded, which the Ba≈ø≈øa induced to believe, ≈øent the ≈øaid Mu≈øtafsad with a ≈øtrong power to ≈øeize upon that booty, of which his Army ≈øtood ≈øo much in need, but they were no ≈øooner within danger, but the Per≈øians and Georgians bur≈øt out upon them in great numbers, putting them on every ≈øide to flight, whom they pur≈øued ≈øo fiercely that ≈øeven thou≈øand of them were ≈ølain, many taken Pri≈øoners, and all their Cammels and other bea≈øts of burthen taken, of which Sivan, having notice, in a great rage di≈øpatched the Ba≈ø≈øa of Caramania, with twenty thou≈øand hor≈øe and foot to pur≈øue the Per≈øians, after whom him≈øelf followed with the whole Army, but too late, for that perceiving from a high mountain what was intended had withdrawn them≈øelves,
yet ≈øome ≈øtraglers fell into the Turks hands, part of whom they ≈ølew, and part they ≈øaved alive; yet the Turks holding on their way came to Triala, where they under≈øtood that the Per≈øian King being departed from Tauris, was coming again≈øt them with a great Army, re≈øolving to give them battle, upon which Sivan gave ≈øtrict command throughout his Army, that every man on pain of death ≈øhould be in a readine≈øs to March, he re≈øolving to meet the King on his way; after which he de≈øcended into the large Plains of Chielder, where a former battle had been fought between the Turks and the Per≈øians, where not hearing of the Kings approach, after having mu≈øtered his Army, he re≈øolved to March to Tauris to inrich him≈øelf with the ≈øpoiles of that City, but by the way under pretence of trying his men, he cau≈øed a counterfeit battle tobe fought among≈øt his own Souldiers, as in ca≈øe of a General mu≈øter, which ever after rendred him a by-word to his Souldiers, and loytering in the afore≈øaid plains for the ≈øpace of eight dayes; in the mean ≈øpace Aider the Aga as an Amba≈ø≈øador from the Per≈øian King came to his Camp, offering in the name of his Ma≈øter ≈øuch propo≈øals as Maxut had before done at Constantinople, which were that Chars and Teflis ≈øhould be quietly po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed of the Turks, that ≈øo a good corre≈øpondence might be continued between the Subjects of both Potentates, for accompli≈øhing of this de≈øired peace, Sinan promi≈øed to deal with Amurath, provided the Per≈øian would ≈øend an Amba≈ø≈øador to Con≈øtantinople, which being re≈øolved on, the proud Ba≈ø≈øa returned to Chars, and from thence departed to Erizirum, where he di≈ømi≈ø≈øed his Army, having done nothing worthy the name of a General.

In the year 1581 Amurath cau≈øed his ≈øon Mahomet to be circumci≈øed after the Hebrew manner; in honour
of which ≈øolemnity he made a fea≈øt which continued with ≈øhews and ≈øports, for the ≈øpace of forty days, where all, or mo≈øt of the Chri≈øtian and Mahometan Princes Amba≈ø≈øadors were pre≈øent; and among≈øt them the Amba≈ø≈øador of Per≈øia, whom Amurath (after ≈øuffering many affronts to be put upon him) cau≈øed to be impri≈øoned with all his Retinue, ≈øo ≈øtraightly, that though one hundred of his ≈øervants dyed of the Plague, yet much adoe had he to get him≈øelf removed to Erzirum. This hard handling of the Amba≈ø≈øador made the conceived hopes of Peace to vani≈øh, in≈øomuch that either Potentate prepared for war, when as Amurath not well liking the proceedings of Sivan, con≈øtituted Mahomet Ba≈ø≈øa, nephew to Mu≈øtapha Ba≈ø≈øa decea≈øed, which choice Sivan greatly inveighed again≈øt, though all in vain; for early in the ≈øpring, he taking charge of the Army de≈øigned for the Per≈øian war, departed from Erzirum accompanied with the Ba≈ø≈øa of Caramite, carrying with him great ≈øtore of provi≈øion, and a huge ma≈øs of mony, but ≈øuch was his bad fortune that in his way to Teflis, pa≈ø≈øing a River his Army was routed by the Per≈øians and Georgians, and mo≈øt of his be≈øt Souldiers ≈ølain or taken pri≈øoners, a great part of the mony and provi≈øion, fell likewi≈øe into the hands of the enemy; ≈øo that not having ≈øufficient to relieve the Gari≈øon, hardly oppre≈ø≈øed by famine, he had much adoe to per≈øwade the Souldiers to continue in it, and exceedingly to ≈øtraighten his di≈øcomfited Army to ≈øupply that place with mony and provi≈øion; all which calamity being ≈øuppo≈øed to happen by the Sini≈øter Council of one Mu≈øtapha a Renagate Georgian, then in the Turks Camp, who was more then ≈øu≈øpected to hold corre≈øpondence with his Country; wherefore Mahomet with other his tru≈øty Coun≈øellers re≈øolved his death, whereupon he called a Council in his own Pavillion, pretending
letters of in≈øtruction from the Emperor, and ≈øecretly gave order that upon the coming of Mu≈øtapha, whil≈øt the Letters were in reading, the Janizaries ≈øhould cut off his head, but the Georgian having notice, cho≈øe out fifty of his faithful followers, and imparting to them what was intended, commanded them to be near at hand and at the fir≈øt call to enter the Pavilion, where if they perceived any violence u≈øed towards his per≈øon, they ≈øhould not ≈øpare the General him≈øelf. Matters being brought to this pa≈øs, and Mu≈øtapha entred the Pavilion of the Ba≈ø≈øa, the counterfeit Letters were ordered to be read, which done, and the Georgian about to depart, promi≈øing to perform what ever the King ≈øhould command, Capagi Ba≈ø≈øa Mahomets Great u≈øher, came to him and plucking him by the ≈øleeve, would have forced him to have ≈øat down, which he perceiving, and knowing his life was in danger, drew his ≈øword, and ≈øtruck Mahomets Lieutenant ≈øo forcibly on the head, that he clove him to the ≈øtomach, then rever≈øing his blow, wounded the Ba≈ø≈øa of Caramite, as likewi≈øe many others, and had killed the General him≈øelf, had not the uproar cau≈øed many to enter the Pavillion, and among≈øt others his fifty followers, who carryed him in ≈øafety to his Tent. This action cau≈øed grievous complaints to be ≈øent to Amurath from either party, whereby he under≈øtanding the evil ≈øtate of his affairs in tho≈øe Parts, exceedingly blamed his Ba≈ø≈øa's for pu≈øhing on into ≈øuch a dangerous war, and in a rage thru≈øt Sivan Ba≈ø≈øa from his Vizar≈øhip, placing Sciaus Ba≈ø≈øa (a Hungarian born, and to whom he had married his ≈øi≈øter) in his ≈øtead.

The Turks affairs being at this pa≈øs Anno 1582, they had ≈ømall mind to proceed in their war again≈øt the Per≈øians, nor was the Per≈øian King le≈øs de≈øirous to
be rid of ≈øo trouble≈øome a gue≈øt, that he might be the better at lea≈øure to ≈øuppre≈øs the Rebellion rai≈øed by his Son Abas Mirize, who countenanced by the chief of the Sultans, had ≈øeized upon many ≈øtrong places, and was now Fortifying him≈øelf in Ateri, whither his father pa≈ø≈øed with a great Army by the way, recovering ≈øuch Towns as had revolted from his obedience, and putting ≈øuch of the Traitors as he found therein to death; but coming before the City, the young Prince wrote ≈øuch ≈øubmi≈ø≈øive Letters to his father and elder brother, then in his fathers Camp, that the old man was well content, that he ≈øhould by his Amba≈ø≈øadors be admitted to purge him≈øelf of ≈øuch crimes as were laid to his charge, which he did ≈øo effectually that the whole matter appearing to be framed and contrived by Mirize Sulmos, who notwith≈øtanding had per≈øwaded the King to make that Expedition again≈øt his Son that he might advantage him≈øelf by being made General of the Army; to put an end to further differences the ≈øaid Mirize Sulmus was by the Kings command beheaded, as being indeed the Author of tho≈øe inte≈øtine troubles.

The≈øe things thus di≈øpo≈øed, the Sophy was now at lea≈øure to oppo≈øe the invading Turks, wherefore gathering a great Army he ≈øtriped them out of many of their holds, which ≈øo enraged Amurath that appointing Ferat Ba≈ø≈øa his General, whom with full in≈øtructions he di≈ømi≈ø≈øed with a great Army, with which having roamed about Sunan and Georgia all Summer, Anno 1583. with the lo≈øs of many of his men, and the revolt of Mu≈øtaffa, he in September returned to Erzirum having done nothing more, then de≈øtroyed the Countrey of Mu≈øtaffa, and relieved Teflis.

The following year the P ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ≈øian King re≈øolving to
drive the Turks out of his Countrey, rai≈øed a great Army, and encamped in the Plains before the City of Tauris, of which Ferat having notice would not depart from Erzirum before he had ≈øent to Amurath to have his opinion therein, who ≈øent him an expre≈øs to relieve if po≈ø≈øible the Garri≈øon of Teflis with a ≈ømall power to oppo≈øe the re≈øt of the Army again≈øt the Enemy, whereupon he re≈øolved to put in practice the plea≈øure of his Lord. In order to which the better to ≈øecure the pa≈ø≈øage or ≈øtrait of Tomanis, he built a Ca≈øtle in the enterance thereof 1700 yards in compa≈øs, furni≈øhing it with all nece≈ø≈øaries, and then ≈øent a detachment of 20000 Hor≈øe and Foot, under the leading of Re≈øuan Ba≈ø≈øa for the releif of Teflis, but fearing that power not ≈øufficient ≈øent others after him, under the leading of the Ba≈ø≈øa of Caramite, of which Simon the Georgian Prince having notice yet deceived in their number, ha≈øted over the Countrey by ≈øhort cuts to give them Battle, which he was the readier to do becau≈øe he at fir≈øt di≈øcovered no more then 6000 Turks, the re≈øt lying behind a Hill, but Battle once joyned they came down upon him like a Tempe≈øt, and ≈øo oppre≈ø≈øed his ≈ømall number not exceeding 4000, who yet fought de≈øperately, that he and all his men had been ≈ølain, had not the other Turks ≈øent by Ferat to ≈øtrengthen Re≈øuan, appeared upon the Hills at a di≈øtance, whom tho≈øe Turks that were fighting ≈øuppo≈øed to be Per≈øians, and by that means not daring to pur≈øue the retiring Georgians for fear of being drawn into an Ambu≈øh, they ea≈øily found means to e≈øcape, and the Ba≈ø≈øa the like, to relieve Teflis, and with the ≈øame facility to return to the Camp which by this time began to be ≈øorely oppre≈ø≈øed with Famine, in≈øomuch that a bu≈øhel of Wheat was ≈øold for 100 Ducates, which cau≈øed the Camp to ri≈øe, and
march towards the Countrey of Mu≈øtaffa, formerly called Manucchiar the Georgian Prince who now revolting from the Turks took part with the other Georgian Princes, but the many difficulties being apparent to the Soldiers by rea≈øon of the advancement of the Sea≈øon, they flatly denyed to obey his command threatning him with great mi≈øchief if he did not ≈øpeedily return to Erzirum, nor did they forbear to a≈ø≈øault him in his Tent threatning him with pre≈øent death, if he continued to expo≈øe them to the mi≈øeries of Hunger and Cold, which ≈øo that finding no means to re≈øtrain their in≈øolency, or to quiet their continual clamours, but a ≈øpeedy return to Erzirum, he was forced to yield to their reque≈øts where arriving after a tedious march wherein he lo≈øt many of his be≈øt Souldiers, he broke up the Army. The Per≈øian King hovering about Tauris, and having notice of all that had pa≈ø≈øed, ≈øent away a great part of his Army, an fora≈ømuch as Emir Cham Governour of that City had neglected to oppo≈øe the Turks during their building ≈øeveral ≈øtrong Fortre≈ø≈øes to keep the pa≈ø≈øages of the ≈øtraits, nor a≈ø≈øi≈øted him as he ought, he cau≈øed his Eyes to be put out and him≈øelf to be ca≈øt into pri≈øon (where ≈øhortly after he died of grief) and made Aliculi Cham who a little before had e≈øcaped from the Turks Camp Governour in his ≈øtead.

About this time the League between Amurath and R ‚Ä¢ dolphus the German Emperour, by rea≈øon of ≈øome Ho≈øtilities committed between their Subjects, had like to have ended; but upon more mature con≈øideration of what had pa≈ø≈øed, and reparation on the part of the Aggre≈ø≈øors for dammages ≈øu≈øtained, it was again renewed for the ≈øpace of 8 years, after which Ferat Ba≈ø≈øa upon the complaint of the great Captains falling into di≈øgrace with Amurath he
was depo≈øed from his tru≈øt of General, and O≈øman Ba≈ø≈øa Governour of Sirvan (who for his many victories over the Tartars was become famous) appointed General in his ≈øtead, and made chief Vizar; (The greate≈øt honour that can be conferred on any per≈øon by the Ottoman Emperors.) And now Amurath ca≈øting in his mind the ≈øubduing of Tauris, cau≈øed a great Army to be rai≈øed, and the better to make the Per≈øian neglect the Fortifying of that City, cau≈øed it to be bruted that he intended to invade Na≈ø≈øivan; but whil≈øt the≈øe preparations were intended again≈øt the Per≈øians, the Villany of a Venetian Captain had gone near to turn them upon the Chri≈øtian, the manner thus. The Widow of Ramadan Ba≈ø≈øa late Governour of Tripolis in Barbary, with her Children and Servant being imbarqued in three Gallies, in order to their being tran≈øported to Con≈øtantinople, ≈øailing by the mouth of the Adriatick were by contrary Winds driven into the Gulf where, Petrus Emunius a Venetian Captain, of the order of the Senators, lying with certain Gallies ≈øet upon tho≈øe before mentioned and boarded them, where he exerci≈øed mo≈øt barbarous cruelty, as well upon the Women as the Men. For having ≈ølain the Mariners in number 250, and the Son of Ramadan, a Child in his Mothers lap, he cau≈øed the Women fir≈øt to be Ravi≈øhed, and then having their Brea≈øts cut off to be ca≈øt into the Sea; nor did he exerci≈øe this cruelty upon the Turks onely, but upon ≈øuch Chri≈øtians likewi≈øe as he found on board, u≈øing ≈øuch barbarity as was thought to prevent the di≈øcovery of the great Riches he found in tho≈øe Gallies. Yet was it afterwards made manife≈øt by one of the Turks, who during the ≈ølaughter had hid him≈øelf in the hold, and was afterwards ≈øaved by a Cretian, who had in like manner been formerly pre≈øerved by the
≈øaid Turk, who coming to Con≈øtantinople declared what had happened, which ≈øo enraged Amurath that he ≈øent to the Venetians ≈øpeedily to make reparation or to expect their Frontiers to be invaded. To which the Senators an≈øwered, they were altogether Ignorant of what had happened, but if ≈øo as the Me≈ø≈øengers related, upon enquiry, reparation ≈øhould be made, which being found according to the relation of the Turks, they cau≈øed Emus to be beheaded, the Gally to be re≈øtored, and to ≈øupply the lo≈øs of the ≈ølaves delivered them a like number of Turks and Moors, which for that time appea≈øed the indignation of Amurath.

Amurath anno 1585. having con≈øtituted Ha≈ø≈øan Ba≈ø≈øa the Queens Eunuch Governour of Caire, afterwards ca≈øting his Eyes upon Ebraim Ba≈ø≈øa, a Sclavonian about 23 years of Age, re≈øolved to make him his Son-in-law, and to rai≈øe him to a condition worthy ≈øo great an honour as to marry the Daughter of an Emperour, he made him ≈øoveraign Judge of Egypt, of which Ha≈ø≈øan having notice, and by rea≈øon of the ≈øuddain advancement of Ebraim, doubting his ≈øafety fled to Con≈øtantinople, and fell at the Emperours feet, de≈øiring to know what crime he had committed to have a Ma≈øter ≈øo ≈øuddainly ≈øet over him, but had no other an≈øwer then that he mu≈øt to Pri≈øon, where after he had continued a long time ≈øtill expecting the fatal hour, he was at the earne≈øt interce≈ø≈øion of the Empre≈øs, and the great Ladies of the Court ≈øet at Liberty, but all his riches ≈øeized and converted to the Emperours u≈øe.

Ebraim being ≈øettled in his Government of Egypt, by extorting great ≈øumms of money from the Egyptians and other people ≈øubject to his rule, in a ≈øhort time heaped up great Riches, when at the end of three years Amurath ≈øent for him to Con≈øtantinople,
to Celebrate the intended Marriage, charging him withal to pa≈øs through the Countrey of the Dru≈øians, a people inhabiting a large Countrey invironed with Joppa, Cae≈øaria, Pale≈øtina, and within the Rivers Orantes and Jordan, ≈øtretching it ≈øelf even to the Plains of Dama≈øco near to the Hills that compa≈øs it about, upon the Coa≈øt of Mount Libanus, and are ≈øaid to be the race of tho≈øe Chri≈øtians that ≈øeated them≈øelves there in the time that the Princes of the We≈øt ≈øent their Armies to ≈øubdue the Holy Land, but have ≈øince bin perverted to the Mahometan Super≈øtition, and at the coming of Ebraim into tho≈øe parts with his Army, they were divided under many Princes of which the≈øe were the chief, viz. Ebne Man, of the Turks called man Ogli, Serafadin, Mahamet Ebne-Man≈øur, Eben Frec, and Ali Ebne-Carfus, by the Turks called Ali Carfus-Ogli, under whom were divers Lieutenants called their Macademi or Agents, all of which except Eben Man Ogli, upon the arrival of the Ba≈ø≈øa ≈øent him rich Pre≈øents; whereupon he entering the Countrey of the ≈øaid Ogli wa≈øted it with Fire and Sword, which made the re≈øt of the Princes exceeding angry, and underhand to ≈øend aid to their Compere, with which incamping him≈øelf advantagiou≈øly, he fell upon Veis Ba≈ø≈øa who lead a part of the Turks Army and di≈øcomfited him, puting 500 of his Men to the Sword, and carrying away a rich booty, which ≈øo inraged Ebraim that he u≈øed his utmo≈øt diligence to intrap the afore≈øaid Prince, but finding no means to effect the ≈øame, he began with fair Promi≈øes and Pre≈øents, to corrupt his Macademes, one of which together with 300 Dru≈øtans, he got into his power, whom in revenge of Veis his overthrow he cau≈øed to be flead alive, and all his followers ≈ølain, and again raged with Fire and Sword throughout the Countrey, when
afterward by di≈ø≈øimulation and feigned Friend≈øhip, he got Eben Man≈øur into his power, whom he cau≈øed to be fa≈øt chained and ≈øent to the Gallies, after which he took the ≈øpoil of his Countrey, and afterward with a great Booty returned to Con≈øtantinople, where he was in triumph received by his Friends, among≈øt whom he be≈øtowed Liberally the ≈øpoils taken from the Dru≈øians, even to the value of one Million of Ducates, and 200000 Sultanies. But upon his departure out of the Dru≈øians Countrey, they joyning with the Arabian to revenge the injuries them≈øelves ≈øu≈øtained, entered the Turks Confines and committed many outrages, burning and de≈øtroying all before them, not in their anger ≈øparing Man, Woman or Child, pa≈ø≈øing on even to the Gates of Jeru≈øalem, being a≈ø≈øi≈øted covertly by the Sub-Ba≈ø≈øa of Bethlehem, who di≈øplea≈øed with the rule of Ebraim, watched his opportunity to revolt to the Enemy, but was prevented by being ≈ølain, alive at the Commandment of one of the Sanzaks of Jury.

Whil≈øt affairs ≈øtood thus in Egypt and the Dru≈øians Land, O≈øman had compleated his Army at Erzirum, which upon Mu≈øter was found to con≈øi≈øt of 180000 choice Souldiers, with which on the 11th. of Augu≈øt 1585. he marched toward Tauris keeping on his way till he came into the va≈øt Chalderan, memorable for many Battles fought therein between the Turks and Per≈øians, where ≈øtraitned for want the Soldiers mutined again≈øt him, upbraiding him with many reproachful words, and threatning him with death, for that as they ≈øaid contrary to his promi≈øe he had drawn them into a place of danger to become a prey to the Enemy; at which the Ba≈ø≈øa being much perplexed ≈øent for the Captain, and by telling them it was the Sultans expre≈øs Command, and that he did not in the le≈øt doubt but to become victorious,
and therefore prayed them to re≈øt contented, and not Eclip≈øe their honour by their civil di≈ø≈øen≈øions among≈øt them≈øelves, which would rather give the Enemy advantage again≈øt them then any thing el≈øe, and that if it was given out upon the rai≈øing the Army, that it was intended for Na≈ø≈øivan, that ≈øpecious pretence was as he ≈øaid to render the Per≈øian more ≈øecure, and thereby to hinder his great preparations. The≈øe and ≈øuch like ≈øpeeches, together with a ≈ømall di≈øtribution of money calmed the Tempe≈øt the Mutiners had rai≈øed, and thereupon the Army ri≈øing pa≈ø≈øed on towards Cay, from thence to Marant a City Subject to the Per≈øians, and ≈øo keeping their way came within ≈øight of Tauris the mark at which they aimed, upon which propo≈øing to them≈øelves a kind of ≈øecurity, the Van of the Army fell to ≈øpoiling the Countrey, and ≈øeizing upon what be≈øt liked them, keeping little or no order in their March, of which Emir Hamze King Mahumets Elde≈øt Son perceiving, with 10000 Hor≈øemen lay in Ambu≈øh in a way where they mu≈øt pa≈øs, and having got them within his danger, bur≈øt out upon them with ≈øuch fury that he overrun that part of the Army, put 7000 to the Sword, and carrying away a number of Pri≈øoners, and ≈øo with great ≈øpoil retired ere the gro≈øs of the Turks Army could come up. Yet O≈øman upon notice of what had happened, ≈øent Mahomet Ba≈ø≈øa and the Ba≈ø≈øa of Caramite after him, the victorious Prince with 14 Hor≈øe and Foot, who by ≈øpeedy Marches overtaking him had with him a bloody conflict, in which 6000 Turks were ≈ølain, nor had any e≈øcaped had not the darkne≈øs of the night cau≈øed the retreat on both ≈øides to be ≈øounded.

The next Morning the Turks Camp removed, and came within two Miles of Tauris, where Aliculi Chan of whom I have before ≈øpoken was Governour,
who de≈øirous to revenge him≈øelf upon the perfidious Turks i≈ø≈øued out of the City with about 6000 re≈øolute Per≈øians, and charging tho≈øe that were advanced beat them back into their Trenches with great ≈ølaughter, but upon the opening the Tires of Ordnance, and advancing of the Janizaries, finding him≈øelf not capable of incountering ≈øuch a multitude he retired into the City, after whom the Turks in a confu≈øed manner pre≈ø≈øed, but in the enterance ≈øo ≈øtrongly re≈øi≈øted, that the pa≈ø≈øages were filled with their dead carka≈ø≈øes, and all the Ditches ≈øwum with their blood, but fre≈øh ≈øupplies coming on and the City Walls no way built for defence, badly furni≈øhed with Defendants, and wor≈øe with Ordnance, at length the Turks entered, ≈øpoiling with incredible barbarity that great City the Regal ≈øeat of the Per≈øian Kings. Yet ≈øuch compa≈ø≈øion wrought in the brea≈øt of O≈øman the General, that he cau≈øed Proclamation to be made, that upon pain of death none ≈øhould kill any that made not re≈øi≈øtance, and when the tumult was over came him≈øelf to take a view thereof, and gave Orders for its Fortification, ≈øending out partys daily to reduce the other place adjacent to the Turki≈øh obedience, and ≈øo ≈øpeedy were they in Fortifying, that within the ≈øpace of 36 days a ≈øtrong Ca≈øtle was erected.

Five dayes after the building of the new Ca≈øtle was began, even when the Tauri≈øians thought them≈øelves ≈øecure, news was brought into the Turki≈øh Camp that 8 Janizaries and divers Spaoglians were ≈øeen ≈øtrangled in a Bath, within the City of Tauris, whereupon the Zani Spahini and Janizaries in a great rage went to the Generals Pavilion, telling him that although he had with too much clemency given Order that none ≈øhould mole≈øt or hurt the Tauri≈øians, and that according to his plea≈øure every
man had u≈øed his mode≈øty towards them, and obedience to him, yet the Tauri≈øians them≈øelves had mo≈øt audaciou≈øly ≈øtrangled ≈øeveral Janizaries and Spaoglians, which injury and in≈øolency they ≈øaid was not to be ≈øuffered. This outrage (whether true or only rai≈øed by ≈øuch as de≈øired to ≈øatifie their inordinate lu≈øts, is uncertain) ≈øo moved the Ba≈ø≈øa, that without any further delay hecommanded the City to be ≈øacked, leaving it wholly to the di≈øcretion of the Souldiers, who like hell-hounds greedy of blood run with full cry into the City, filling every place with ≈ølaughter of the amazed Tauri≈øians, Matrons were Ravi≈øhed, Virgins defloured, young Children da≈øhed again≈øt the pavement, hou≈øes fired, and other outrages committed that are commonly attendants upon ≈øuch General calamities; ≈øo that it was a mi≈øery almo≈øt inexplicable to behold that City ≈øo populous, ≈øo rich, honoured with the Palace of the Per≈øian Kings, now ≈øubject to the fury of the Turks plunged in calamity and utter de≈øtruction.

The outrages committed in Tauris coming to the knowledge of the Per≈øian King he was greatly offended, in≈øomuch that he re≈øolved with the hazard of a Battle, to revenge the indignity, of who≈øe approach O≈øman who then lay ≈øick in his Pavilion haveing notice, Command Sinan Ba≈ø≈øa and Mahumet Ba≈ø≈øa ≈øhould with all the Greek Soldiers, and others, to the number of 74000 ≈øhould go out and meet the Enemy, who by the craft of the forerunners of his Army drawing the Turks within his ≈øtrengths, had with them there a mortal Battle, wherein 10000 of their Souldiers were ≈ølain, and the two Ba≈ø≈øa's in great confu≈øion obliged to fly to the Camp, leaving mo≈øt of their In≈øigns, and all their baggage as a prey to the Per≈øians: who hightned with this ≈øucce≈øs advanced within ≈øight of the Turks Camp ≈øending
a Herauld to the ≈øick General to demand of him Battle, of which accepting though not able to be there pre≈øent, when as Battle being joyned, after a long and doubtful fight victory inclined to the Per≈øians, who in the end ≈ølew 20000 of the Turks, and among≈øt the re≈øt the Ba≈ø≈øa's of Caramite and Trepez ‚Ä¢ nd, and Sanzack of Bru≈øia, with five other Sanzacks, and among the Pri≈øoners were taken, Amurath Ba≈ø≈øa of Caramania, and divers other of note.

Upon news of this bad ≈øucce≈øs, the Genral fearing to have his Army wa≈øted to nothing by continual skirmi≈øhes in a ≈øtrange Countrey, having Fortified Tauris, and made Giaffer Ba≈ø≈øa of Tripolis Governour, he was about to decamp, when on a ≈øuddain the neighing of Hor≈øes, the noi≈øe of Drums and Trumpets were heard, which putting the Army into a great con≈øternation, and ≈øoon cau≈øed them in great confu≈øion to run all to that ≈øide, where they ≈øuppo≈øed the noi≈øe was, when in the mean while Emir the Per≈øian Prince on the other ≈øide, without any ≈øound of Trumpet, or beat of Drum, with 28000 Souldiers entered their Camp, took 18000 Camels laden, whom he ≈øent away by 6000 of his Souldiers, and then charging furiou≈øly upon ≈øuch as he found, in≈øomuch that after a hard Battle fought 20000 Turks lay ≈øcattered on the Plain, many of which were ≈ølain by their own Artillery, which by O≈ømans Command being furiou≈øly di≈øcharged at the Armies, the murthering ≈øhot made lanes before them without di≈øcerning between Friend and Foe, but night coming on, and the Per≈øians weary with ≈ølaughter retired, and were for a while faintly pur≈øued by the Turks.

O≈øman lying all this while ≈øick in his Pavilion, ≈øore afflicted with the Bloody Flux, and hearing
what havock the Per≈øians had made died, the grief of ≈øo great a lo≈øs ha≈øtening his end. Yet was his death for a long ≈øpace kept ≈øecret lea≈øt thereby the Army ≈øhould be di≈øcouraged which now was returning under the leading of Sinan (or Cicala as ≈øome called him) Ba≈ø≈øa, O≈øman in his Will having delivered to him the charge of the whole Army. Yet the Per≈øian Prince with 14000 Hor≈øe and Foot followed them at the heels, ≈øtill cutting of the ≈øtraglers, and had utterly de≈øtroyed them had not his de≈øign been di≈øcovered, which obliged him to retreat with the lo≈øs of 3000 of his Men; ≈øo that by long and tedious marches, the Turks wa≈øted Army arriving, the Van after the publication of the Generals death were di≈øcharged, all but a certain number retained, who under the leading of D ‚Ä¢ ut Chan a Renegado Per≈øian, were ≈øent to the relief of Teflis, which without any lo≈øs they performed. Now the Ca≈øtle built in Tauris much grieved the Per≈øians, to take which they u≈øed their utmo≈øt endeavour, but it being ≈øtrong of it ≈øelf, and defended by a ≈øtrong Garri≈øon their attempts proved un≈øucce≈øsful. When at the ≈øame time great mi≈øchief aro≈øe in the Kingdom of Per≈øia, for 10000 Turcomans a people bordering upon the Georgians, and re≈øolving to revenge them≈øelves for the death of Emir Chan offered their ≈øervice to the Per≈øian Sophy, under the leading of their two Captains, Mahomet Chan and Calife Chan, to whom the Sophy as a pledge of his love and their ≈øafety delivered Tamas his young Son, whom they had no ≈øooner got into their power but they proclaimed him King of Per≈øia, and in all ha≈øt marched towards Casbiu the Regal City in hopes to ≈øurprize it, and ≈øeat young Tamas, on his Fathers Throne of which the Sophy and his elde≈øt Son having notice pur≈øued hard after
them when overtaking them at a place called Cali≈øteza, a dayes journey on this ≈øide Casbiu, the Prince gave them Battle, and after a dangerous and doubtful conflict put them to flight. In which they being ≈øwiftly pur≈øued the two rebellious Captains were taken, and by the Kings Command had their heads ≈øtricken off, young Tamas being likewi≈øe taken was ≈øent Pri≈øoner to the Ca≈øtle of Cabaca, tho≈øe that e≈øcaped the Battle fled to Solyman Ba≈ø≈øa of Babylon, which put an end to the Rebellion.

Giaffer Ba≈ø≈øa Governour of Tauris after the departure of the Turki≈øh Army under≈øtanding that the Per≈øian Prince was Levying a great Army to Be≈øiege the City, ≈øent an Expre≈øs to Sinon or Siculi Ba≈ø≈øa to ≈øend him Aid, for the defence of the City and Ca≈øtle, the which by rea≈øon of the flight of ≈øome and death of other≈øome of his men, mu≈øt otherwi≈øe fall into the hands of the Enemy: now notwith≈øtanding great preparation for that purpo≈øe were made, they could not be put into the City, by rea≈øon of the near approach of the Per≈øian Army without manife≈øt hazard, of expo≈øing them to the mercy of their Enemies. Yet it ≈øo fell out that the Governour without any recruits maintained the City and Ca≈øtle, the Per≈øians not being ≈øo urgent for the recovery of the ≈øame as was expected.

Upon notice of O≈ømans death, Amurath cho≈øe Ferat Ba≈ø≈øa once more his General, who departing from Con≈øtantinople in the month of April 1586, and pa≈ø≈øed over into A≈øia, where having compleated his Army at Sinas, upon notice that Tauris was in danger, he marched thitherward, though with great caution the enemy ≈øhould charge him at unawares, and by
rea≈øon of the di≈ø≈øen≈øions ari≈øen among≈øt the Per≈øian Captains ≈øent to oppo≈øe him, and the Trea≈øon of Aliculican, now alienated from his Prince, and holding ≈øecret corre≈øpondence with the Turki≈øh General, he without any lo≈øs relieved Tauris, and having cau≈øed a ≈øtrong Fort to be built at Churchine, near unto the ≈øaid City, and two others at C ‚Ä¢ y and Carn, and left therein ≈øufficient Garri≈øons, and ≈øtore of provi≈øion, he ≈øent ≈øuccours to Teflis in Georgia, and ≈øo with little or no lo≈øs returned to Erzirum.

By this time the Per≈øian Prince (who and Mahomet his father, now grown old, ruled the Kingdom) had notice of the Trea≈øon of Aliculi Chau, and Emanguli Chan, whom he had drawn into his confederacy, he prepared his Forces to march again≈øt them, whereupon the latter ≈øubmitted, and was received into favour, but how≈øoever it happened, whether with his knowledge or not, the Prince the chief glory of Per≈øia ≈øleeping in his Pavilion, was by an Eunuch run through the body, ≈øuppo≈øed to be done at the in≈øtance of Abas Miriza his younger brother, to advance whom to the Per≈øian Diadem, Aliculi Chan, had revolted from the obedience of the Sophy, and plotted with the Turki≈øh General to betray Emir Hamzes the Prince into his hands, who≈øe death ≈øo unfortunately happening, cau≈øed great mi≈øeries to befall the Per≈øian State.

Chri≈øtendom having thus long been Exempted from the fury of the Turks, who had their hands full of the Per≈øian war, now as it were, de≈øtiny ≈øo ordering, they having time to breath by rea≈øon of the divi≈øions in Per≈øia, turned their re≈øtle≈øs Arms upon Hungaria, which ≈øtorm the Chri≈øtians perceiving, to hang black over their heads, re≈øolved to provide again≈øt it; and therefore to ≈øhow the Tyrant, that
they dreaded not his utmo≈øt indignation, ≈øeized on the Ca≈øtle of Coppan in Hungary, not far from the Lake of Ballaton over which being hard frozen, they pa≈ø≈øed undi≈øcovered; to requite which, the Turks drawing five thou≈øand hor≈øe out of ≈øeveral Garri≈øons, entered the Chri≈øtian Territories, and de≈øtroying ≈øeventeen Villages, returned laden with great ≈øpoils, and many mi≈øerable Captives, whereof George Count Serine Son to the renowned Count of that name, ≈ølain at Ziget, having knowledge, rai≈øed ≈øuch Forces as the time would give leave, which exceeded not two thou≈øand, and laying the wayes by which the Turks mu≈øt pa≈øs, encountred them ere they could recover any ≈øtrong hold, and put mo≈øt of them to the ≈øword, recovering all the booty and Captives; among≈øt tho≈øe that were made pri≈øoners the Sanzack of Quinque Eccle≈øiae, ≈øon to Haly Ba≈øs, ≈ølain in the Battle of Lepanto; the Ba≈ø≈øa of Ziget, Sanzack of Koppan, and divers others, Sinan Beg Sanzack of Mohaz, endeavouring to e≈øcape, and his hor≈øe ≈øticking fa≈øt, was ≈øhot through the head; of the Turks hor≈øes were taken, fifteen hundred, and of the Turks five hundred, be≈øides three thou≈øand ≈ølain. This bad beginning ≈øo di≈øcouraged Amurath, that in a rage he cau≈øed the Ba≈ø≈øa of Buda to be ≈øtrangled, for that he had began the ho≈øtilities in Hungary, and by that means violated the League between him and the Emperor; at what time a great fire happened at Con≈øtantinople, which con≈øumed ≈øeven Temples, twenty five great Inns, and fifteen thou≈øand hou≈øes, with their warehou≈øes and ≈øhops, kindled as was ≈øuppo≈øed by the Janizaries a little before, in a tumult for want of their pay, due ≈øince their la≈øt Per≈øian Expedition; which was the rather believed, for that it being their duty to endeavour the extingui≈øhing any fire that ≈øhould happen in the Imperial
City; They not only refu≈øed to put their hands thereto them≈øelves but hindred ≈øuch as attempted it.

The≈øe things hapning in Anno 1587 and 1588, the year following to prevent tumults which are u≈øual where the ≈øouldiers are unimployed in the wars, the new Ba≈ø≈øa of Buda, with Amuraths good liking, having drawn to him a ≈øtrong power, invaded the upper Hungary, but being encountered by Claudius Ru≈ø≈øel, General of the Chri≈øtians in tho≈øe parts, he received a great overthrow, three thou≈øand of his Turks being ≈ølain and drowned in the River Seago; upon which the General pur≈øuing his good fortune, broke into the Turks Territories, and took from them the Ca≈øtles of Blave≈øtine, Ge≈øtes, and ≈øeveral Forts in the upper Hungary; upon which Sinan Ba≈ø≈øa of Buda was called home, and Ferat the late General again≈øt the Per≈øians appointed Ba≈ø≈øa in his ≈øtead.

Amurath having not a little been terrified with the great preparations of King Phillip of Spain, in 1588, wherewith he invaded England, and now under≈øtanding that he had received a fearfull overthrow, with the lo≈øs of thirteen thou≈øand of his Marriners and Souldiers, and mo≈øt of his ≈øhips and Gallies; he ≈øent a Letter to Queen Elizabeth to congratulate her happy victory, and to intreat her not upon any terms to make peace with the Spaniard, in which Letter he ≈øtiles her the mo≈øt honourable Matron of the Chri≈øtian Religion, Mirror of Cha≈øtity, adorned with the brightne≈øs of Soveraingty, and power among≈øt the mo≈øt chief women of the people, which ≈øerve Je≈øus, Mi≈øtris of great Kingdoms, reputed of Greate≈øt Maje≈øty and Prai≈øe among≈øt the Nazarites; Elizabeth Queen of England.

Anno 1590 the Tartars having broken into the confines of Polonia, and taken a rich booty, were driven out by the Co≈ø≈øacks, who making of them great ≈ølaughter, recovered all, which Amurath taking in evil part as done to his confederates, but indeed ≈øeeking occa≈øion to war upon the Chri≈øtians, that had not the Queen of Englands mediation prevented it, he had turned his Arms upon Polonia; yet impatient of Peace he called his Ba≈ø≈øas to con≈øult what war was mo≈øt expedient to be taken in hand, among≈øt whom there were eight ≈øundry opinions, whereof the fir≈øt was that the wars again≈øt the Per≈øians ≈øhould be renewed, the ≈øecond for the Inva≈øion of the Kingdoms of Fe≈øs and Morocco, the third was for a war to be taken in hand again≈øt the King of Spain, The fourth for the be≈øieging of Malta, The fifth, to war upon the Venetians, The ≈øixth to invade Italy, the ≈øeventh, to war upon Sigi≈ømund King of Poland, The eighth and la≈øt to invade the Territories of Rodolphus the Emperor; all which being patiently heard by Amurath, with the ≈øundry rea≈øons of the Ba≈ø≈øas: at length, the eighth opinion was confirmed, and the Tyrant re≈øolved once more to turn his Forces towards the We≈øt. Whereupon he cau≈øed great preparations to be made, re≈øolving if po≈ø≈øible to annex the remaining part of Hungary and Au≈øtria, to his other Territories, having by this time and for this purpo≈øe concluded a war with the Per≈øian King, wherefore he commanded his Garri≈øons on the Frontiers as they ≈øaw occa≈øion to mole≈øt the Chri≈øtian Frontiers, with fire and ≈øword, which they letted not to do, prone enough of them≈øelves to act any great wickedne≈øs, nor was it long e'r they ≈øurprized Willitz the Metropolis of Croatia, and committed therein many outrages, and their Army ≈øtill increa≈øing, they upon an unexpected advantage inclo≈øed
6000 Foot, and 500 Hor≈øe of the Chri≈øtians (who had taken the Mountaines, Woods and Straight pa≈ø≈øages, and ≈øo hardly be≈øet them that few of them e≈øcaped; tho≈øe that were ≈ølain the Turks cut off their heads and therewith loaded ≈øix Waggons.

Upon this Alarum the Chri≈øtians drew forth their Armies, and to put a ≈øtop to the Infidels, who by rea≈øon of the unexpected breach of the League had ≈øeized upon many Ca≈øtles and Strong holds, in that ≈øecurity unprovided of ≈øuch nece≈ø≈øaries as would have rendered them impregnable, and lea≈øt A ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢
rath ≈øhould alledge that tho≈øe Ho≈øtilities were committed without his knowledge, the Emperour ≈øent to him by his Amba≈ø≈øadors to under≈øtand the rea≈øons that induced him to break the League, but being able to get no ≈øatisfactory an≈øwer, he thought it high time to ≈øtand upon his guard, and cau≈øed all his power joyned with Forces of the German Princes to march directly into Hungary, under the Command of Rupertus Eggenber his General, who approaching the Enemy con≈øulted with his chief Commanders what was be≈øt to be done, who were all of opinion that to give ≈øpeedy Battle was mo≈øt convenient, thereby to prevent the Enemies for joyning the other Forces, coming to their Aid, ≈øo that upon a ≈øign given the whole Army (in number 40000) forthwith removed and with great ≈øpeed ha≈øted toward the Turks, of which they having notice by their E≈øpials, put them≈øelves in Battle Array, and after their vain glorious manner dreamt of nothing but the ≈øpoil of the Chri≈øtians, whom they already concluded overthrown by rea≈øon of the di≈øproportion of number, they being indeed much inferiour in that nature to the Infidels. Yet had the Emperours General ≈øo ordered his Battles, that placing the Crotians and Hu≈ø≈øars in the Vauntguard,
tho≈øe of Carol≈øtat and the Harquibu≈øires of Keriva in the Left wing. In the Right the Borderers of Carania all Hor≈øemen in the main Battle, the re≈øt of the Souldiers with the Hor≈øemen of Sile≈øia, under the conduct of Sigi≈ømund Paradi≈øe, the Rereward was incompa≈ø≈øed with three Companies of the Emperours Souldiers, nor were the Turk idle but Mar≈øhalled their Battle in the be≈øt wi≈øe, when as the Charge being ≈øounded the Crotians and Hu≈ø≈øars in the Vaunt-gard gave the fir≈øt on≈øet with ≈øuch fury, that being ≈øeconded by the Lord Anersburgh, they after a cruel Fight obliged the Turks to give ground, and with Ha≈ø≈øan Ba≈ø≈øa their General retire towards the River Odder, after whom the Chri≈øtians following furiou≈øly many endeavouring to ≈øave them≈øelves by pa≈ø≈øing over were drowned, and tho≈øe that ≈øtayed in a fearful manner on the Banks overwhelmed by the continual Tempe≈øt of ≈øhot, from the Flankers, ≈øo that within three hours ≈øpace all the Army was in a confu≈øion, every man ≈øeeking for his own ≈øafety, in≈øomuch that 18000 Turks peri≈øhed, either by the Sword, or in the Rivers Odder and Kulp, and among≈øt the re≈øt Ha≈ø≈øan Ba≈ø≈øa, Mahomet Beg, Achmet Beg, Saffer Beg, Meni Beg, Framatan Beg, Curti Beg, Operd Beg and Go≈øchus the Ba≈ø≈øa's chief Coun≈øelor, together with Sinan Beg, Amuraths Nephew, the onely Son of his Si≈øter, after which ≈øignal victory obtained, the Chri≈øtian Army falling on their knees gave Thanks to God, to whom alone they a≈øcribed their miraculous pre≈øervation. The news of which overthrow coming to the knowledge of Amurath he like a frantick man bla≈øphemed the God of Heaven, and per≈øwaded thereto by the tears and intreaties of his Si≈øter, to revenge the death of her Son, ≈øent a proud and bla≈øphemous denunciation of War to the Emperour
Rodolphus, wherein he ≈øtiled him≈øelf, The onely Monarch of the World, a great and mighty God on Earth, an invincible Cae≈øar, King of all Kings from the Ea≈øt unto the We≈øt, &c. and proceeded to threaten the ≈øaid Emperour and his People, with all the mi≈øeries that attend on War, impiou≈øly declaring that the Crucified God of the Chri≈øtians long ≈øince dead and buried, had not been able to deliver his own Countrey out of his hands, much le≈øs the German Empire, which in de≈øpite of him he was re≈øolved to take, knowing him≈øelf a ≈øubverter and ≈øworn Enemy of the Chri≈øtians, and of all that called upon the name of Chri≈øt. And thereupon the more to terrifie the Chri≈øtians, he ≈øent a great Army under the Command of Sinan Ba≈ø≈øa their implacable Enemy, who upon his Arrival layed ≈øiege to Ci≈øeg, which he took putting all he found therein to the Sword, and after that took ≈øeveral other places of le≈ø≈øer note; yet not without con≈øiderable lo≈øs, and breach of Faith to the be≈øieged, who finding them≈øelves oft too weak to defend places of little ≈øtrength again≈øt ≈øo powerful an Enemy, would ≈øurrender them upon promi≈øe of Life and Liberty, but falling into the hands of the barbarous Infidels ≈øeldom obtained either.

The≈øe proceedings of the Turks did not a little alarum the Chri≈øtian Princes, who having mu≈øtered 18000 Men under the Command of Count Hardeck Governour of Rab, he with marching from Comara came before Alba-Regalis, which by force of his Artillery he in a ≈øhort time made ≈øaultable, to the relief of which the Ba≈ø≈øa of Buda ≈øent Sinan Ba≈ø≈øa, with 20000 Hor≈øe and Foot, but he being encountered by the Chri≈øtians was put to flight with the lo≈øs of mo≈øt of his men, whereupon as victors the Chri≈øtians returned to the ≈øiege, but finding the ≈øea≈øon
far advanced, and a great number of Turks that e≈øcaped in the overthrow to be got into the City, the Count rai≈øed his Camp and returned again to Rab, but early in the Spring a≈ø≈øi≈øted by fre≈øh ≈øupplies the Emperours Captains dividing the Army, took the ≈øtrong Ca≈øtle of Sabatzka, the City of Fileck, the Towns of Seete≈øchiu, Blane≈øtine, and Salleck, the three latter being through fear abandoned by the Turks, having fir≈øt ≈øet them for the mo≈øt part on Fire. At the ≈øame time the Lord Palfie with a ≈øtrong party marching to Dregel, and Palanka found them like ‚Ä¢ i≈øe abandoned by the Turks, the which having furni≈øhed with ≈øtrong Garri≈øons of his own he took by force Ainacke, Sellecke, We≈øtkee, and divers other places, ≈øo that the Turks were in a manner driven out of the Lower Hungary, and new Buda, and Alba-Regalis the onely Strong holds, po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed by the Turks in tho≈øe parts began to doubt their ≈øecurity, for whil≈øt a party out of the latter coming forth to bury the dead, that lay ≈øcattered round the Walls, and by their contagion infected the City, they were ≈øo ≈øuddainly incountered by a Captain of the Hu≈ø≈øars, Commanding a Troop of Light Hor≈øemen, that near 200 of them were ≈ølain, and 50 taken Pri≈øoners.

The≈øe proceedings coming to the Ears of Amurath, and he from all hands certified that the ≈øtrength of the Chri≈øtians daily increa≈øed, he began to doubt his Empire in Europe, and therefore to defend the ≈øame rai≈øed a pui≈ø≈øant Army anno 1594. at the head of which he re≈øolved to march in per≈øon, a thing he had not done ≈øince his taking upon him the Government, but on the 11th. of January, as the Army was upon its march, not far from Con≈øtantinople ≈øuch a terrible Tempe≈øt of Hail, Rain, Snow, Wind, Thunder and Lightning aro≈øe, that by its impetuo≈øity
it overturned the Tents, Chariots, Waggons, Hor≈øe and Men, few being able to ≈øtand upright before it. The which the Tyrant taking as ominous to his proceedings, in great perplexity returned with his formidable Army to Con≈øtantinople, where ca≈øting him≈øelf upon his bed, after much tumbling and to≈ø≈øing, falling a≈øleep he dreamed that he beheld a man of exceeding Stature, ≈øtanding with one his feet upon the Tower of Con≈øtantinople, and the other over the ≈øtraight fixed on the A≈øian ≈øhoar, who ≈øtretching out his Arms held the Sun in one hand and the Moon in the other, at whom whil≈øt he was wondering the Mon≈øter with his foot ≈øtruck the Tower, which forthwith fell down, and in its fall overthrew the great Temple with the Imperial Palace, who≈øe Thundering awaking the Turk he much troubled with the ≈øtrangene≈øs of the dream imediatly ≈øent for his Necromancers and Wizards to Interpret it, who to curry favour with their Prince hypocritically an≈øwered, That for as much as he had not with all his Forces, as with a Tempe≈øt impugned the Chri≈øtians, their great Prophet Mahomet threatned by that dream to overturn the Tower, Temple, and Imperial Palace, which by a ≈øymbolical meaning denoted the Turki≈øh Religion and Empire: which vain and fictitious Interpretation ≈øo moved the ≈øuper≈øtitious Tyrant, that having fir≈øt asked pardon of his Impo≈øtor Prophet, he ≈øwore from henceforth to turn all his Forces upon the Chri≈øtians, and not to give over War till he had done his utmo≈øt to ≈øubdue them. The≈øe vain threats did not in the lea≈øt di≈ømay the Chri≈øtian Princes, yet to ingage a ≈øure Friend on their ≈øide, they cau≈øed publique prayers to be put up in all Churches, and that people might perceive on what ≈ølender and impious grounds the Tyrant, had re≈øolved the pro≈øecution of the War, had the vain Dream and the vainer
Interpretation, read in the Churches of Tran≈øylvania and mo≈øt of the Churches of Hungary.

The Chri≈øtian Army having taken the Field, and a Pre≈øent of the Turks ≈øpoiles, taken ≈øome time before ≈øent to Rodolphus the Emperour, the Arch-Duke of Au≈øtria be≈øieged Novograde, which after ≈øeveral a≈ø≈øaults was delivered by capitulation, in con≈øideration of Life and Liberty, which ≈øtrong Town after it had been Turki≈øh for the ≈øpace of 60 years, was by the Arch-Duke committed to the care of Lord Rebei a Noble Hungarian, and the Turki≈øh Governour upon his arrival at Buda was by the Ba≈ø≈øa's Command impri≈øoned.

Whil≈øt the≈øe things were in doing the Emperour ≈øent his Emba≈ø≈øadors to the great Duke of Mu≈øcovy, the King of Poland, and Prince of Tran≈øilvania, in all who≈øe Courts their Negotiation proved ≈øucce≈øsful, nor in the mean time was the young Count Serinus idle, for that he with 300 Harquibu≈øires, and certain Troops of Hor≈øe, and Companies to the number of 10000 took the Ca≈øtles of Bre≈øenza, Sige≈øta and Babo≈øtcha, by the recovery of which ≈øtrong holds he opened a ≈øafe pa≈ø≈øage even to Ziget, the Ba≈ø≈øa of which ≈øtanding at that time in no ≈ømall doubt to be be≈øieged. The≈øe things perplexing the Turki≈øh Tyrant, who was preparing great Forces for the ≈øecuring his Province on this ≈øide the Danubius, he in the mean while ≈øent a Fleet into the Adriatick to be≈øiege Zegna, an Imperial City, ≈øcituate upon the Sea Coa≈øt in the Bay of Quernero, called in antient time Flanaticus Sinus, in order to the pro≈øecution of which he ≈øent his Amba≈ø≈øador to the Venetians to require the u≈øe of their Ports in tho≈øe Seas, and that his Gallies might pa≈øs and repa≈øs without any mole≈øtation from the Gallies of that State, but the Senate doubting the fidelity of the
Turk, and loath thereby to di≈øoblige the Chri≈øtian Emperour would by no means con≈øent, yet u≈øed the Amba≈ø≈øador honourably, and ≈øent him away without obtaining his purpo≈øe.

In the Upper part of Hungaria the Lord Tenffenbeck, Commanding as the Arch-Dukes Lieutenant, with an Army of 2000 Hor≈øe and Foot be≈øieged Hatvan, a ≈øtrong Town of the Turks, lying about ≈øix miles from Buda, Fortified with a Triple Ditch and Bullwarks of exceeding ≈øtrength, to the relief of which the Ba≈ø≈øa of Buda came with fifteen thou≈øand Souldiers, thinking at unawares to ≈øurprize the Chri≈øtian Camp but was fru≈øtrated in his project, for the Lord Tenffenbeck drawing off from before the City, pa≈ø≈øed through with much difficulty the River Sagijvay, when ≈øetting upon the Ba≈ø≈øa's Army after a hard fight he put it to the Rout, having the execution of the Turks for many miles, ≈øo that about Ten Thou≈øand of them were ≈ølain and taken Pri≈øoners, with a great Booty of Provi≈øion and Ammunition, after which the Chri≈øtians returned to the ≈øiege, yet finding the hazards and difficulty that they ≈øhould meet with in winning it, by the directions of the Arch-Duke who with Forty Thou≈øand Men at the ≈øame time be≈øieged Strigonium, the Siege of Hatvan was given over, yet upon the rai≈øing thereof the Lord Tenffenbeck di≈øcomfited the Ba≈ø≈øa of Buda a ≈øecond time, as he was again coming to the relief thereof, in which conflict Five Thou≈øand Turks were ≈ølain.

Strigonium after a long ≈øiege, and the burning of the old Town, being relieved by the coming of Sinan Ba≈ø≈øa with a great Army, the Arch-Duke thought it not yet convenient to let him take breath, but on the 28th. of June pa≈ø≈øed Danubius to expect the motion of Sinan Ba≈ø≈øa with his huge
Army, compo≈øed of Turks and Tartars, and by frequent on≈øets daily weakned his Camp, nor were the Ra≈øcians ≈ølow to revolt from the Turki≈øh obedience. So that having rai≈øed a confu≈øed power, to the number of Fifteen Thou≈øand they took many ≈øtrong Places, and obtained two notable Victories, one over the Ba≈ø≈øa of Teme≈øwar, in which him≈øelf and three of his Sanzacks, and about Nine Thou≈øand Five Hundred of his Turks were ≈ølain. And the other over another Ba≈ø≈øa that ≈øucceeded him, upon which they ≈øent to the Arch-Duke to receive them and their Countrey into the Emperours protection, and that in con≈øideration thereof they would maintain Ten Thou≈øand Men in the Field, who≈øe Propo≈øals were by the Imperial General accepted.

About this time the Emperour the better to con≈øult the defence of his Provinces, called a Diet at Ratisbone, where in the a≈ø≈øembly of the German Princes, he declared how matters ≈øtood, and repeated the manifold injuries he had ≈øu≈øtained by the Turks, contrary to the League made with Amurath, and that among≈øt the re≈øt he contrary to the Law of Nations had impri≈øoned Frederick Creckovitz his Amba≈ø≈øador fir≈øt at Con≈øtantinople, and cau≈øed the greate≈øt part of his followers to be thru≈øt into the Gallies, and afterwards to have ≈øent him with a few of his attendants to Belgrade, and thereto have kept him in pri≈øon till he ended his dayes. To revenge which indignities tho≈øe daily offered, and ≈øuch as were like to en≈øue from the great Army at hand, he de≈øired the Princes to con≈øider a mo≈øt ≈øpeedy way, and not by delay to indanger the greate≈øt part of Chri≈øtendoms falling into the hands of the mercyle≈øs Enemy. To which the Electoral Princes after a due con≈øideration, replyed, That they had
a regard to his Imperial Maje≈øty, and for the pre≈øervation of Hungary, and others his Hereditary Countries, as al≈øo for repre≈ø≈øing the fury of the Turks, yet by rea≈øon of the late dearth, they were not capable of maintaining ≈øuch Forces as might be expected, yet be≈øides their Annual Contributions they would for the ≈øpace of ≈øix years, grant ≈øuch further relief as they well hoped would prove ≈øufficient for the maintenance of a defen≈øive War, both for the pre≈øent and for the time to come, after which re≈øolves of the Princes the Diet broke up, and all diligence was u≈øed for increa≈øing the Army, and Fortifying the ≈øtrong Holds in Hungaria, Au≈øtria, Styra, and Carinthia, Countries mo≈øt obnoxious to the Incur≈øions of the Turks.

Sinan Ba≈ø≈øa all this while not ignorant of the Emperors proceedings, lay with an Army of One Hundred and Fifty Thou≈øand Fighting men, between Buda and Alba Regalis, frequently ≈øending out Parties to wa≈øt the Countries in po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of the Emperour, yet with ≈øuch indifferent ≈øucce≈øs that he had no cau≈øe to boa≈øt, which made the Ba≈ø≈øa to rai≈øe his Camp, and in ≈øight of the Chri≈øtian Army which ≈øtill attended his motions, battered Dolis and St. Martins with ≈øuch fury that within a ≈øhort time they fell into his hands, the Imperiali≈øts at ≈øo great an odds not thinking it convenient to hazard a Battle to relief their be≈øieged Friends, and after doing other mi≈øchief in their Territories layed ≈øiege to the City of Rab ≈øcituate on the South≈øide of Danubius, where the River dividing it ≈øelf makes a mo≈øt fertile I≈øland called Schut, about twelve German miles from Vienna, in which I≈øland lay the Chri≈øtian Camp. This City was defended by a Garri≈øon of Five Thou≈øand Men, under the Command
of Count Hardeck a more valiant then at this time faithful Friend, for when every one ≈øuppo≈øed the City impregnable, and that the Turks for many dayes had without intermi≈ø≈øion battered it with Sixty pieces of Cannon, and made ≈øeveral un≈øucce≈øsful a≈ø≈øaults with the lo≈øs of Fourteen Thou≈øand of their men the ≈øaid Count contrary to the minds of his Commanders and Souldiers capitulated with the Ba≈ø≈øa, and in con≈øideration of his departing with all his Trea≈øure, delivered that ≈øtrong piece in his hands. For which upon his arrival at Vienna, he by the judgement of Sixty of his Peers, had his Head and his right Hand ≈øtricken off, it being proved again≈øt him that he in leiw of the ≈øurrender had of the Ba≈ø≈øa received two bags of Ducats.

During the ≈øiege of Rab the Chri≈øtians in the I≈øland of Schut received a great lo≈øs, for Ten Thou≈øand Turks and Tartars getting over in Boats or ≈øwimming upon their Hor≈øes, came ≈øo ≈øuddainly upon their Camp, that having ≈ølain Two Thou≈øand of them and put the re≈øt into a great con≈øternation, they entered their Trenches and carryed thence a booty valued at Five Hundred Thou≈øand Ducats, which lo≈øs for a while after ≈øore weakned the Chri≈øtians. Nor were the Turks onely bu≈øie in ≈øpoiling Hungary, but Italy al≈øo, for with a great Fleet under the leading of Ciala Ba≈ø≈øa Amuraths Admiral, they ≈øurprized Rhegium in Calabria, and utterly razed it, after which they ≈øpoiled all the Countrey about it, as likewi≈øe the Sea Coa≈øts of Italy in many other places, taking ≈øeveral Ships richly laden in the ≈øight of the Garri≈øon of Me≈ø≈øina, and carrying away a great number of poor people into mi≈øerable Captivity.
Sinan Ba≈ø≈øa having by this time received new ≈øupplies and repaired Rab, putting therein a ≈øtrong Garri≈øon marched to Comara, before which he incamped, but upon the approach of Matthias the Arch-Duke with a pui≈ø≈øant Army of Germans, Bohemians, and Hungarians to relieve it, he rai≈øed his ≈øiege not thinking it ≈øafe at that time to hazard a Battle, and by a Bridge of Boats Tran≈øported his Army over Danubius to Dolis, where he the following day di≈ømi≈ø≈øed them, upon which the Arch-Duke without any hinderance coming to Comara, cau≈øed the breaches to be Repaired, and then leaving it to the protection of the Governour, viz. The Lord Bruun, who had faithfully defended it, he departed to take a view of the other Cities.

About this time Sigi≈ømund Prince of Tran≈øilvania, weary of the grievous exaction and injuries they ≈øu≈øtained at the hands of the Turks, re≈øolved to ca≈øt off their ≈øervile yoak which being known to certain of the Nobility pen≈øioners to Amurath, they ≈øecretly advertized him of the Princes purpo≈øe, promi≈øing to ≈øend him in Chains to Con≈øtantinople, and with the Turks good liking to ≈øet up one Balthazor Bator the Princes nigh Kin≈øman in his ≈øtend, but the Trea≈øon being di≈øcovered mo≈øt of the Traitors were taken and executed, upon which the Tar
‚Ä¢ ars to the number of Forty Thou≈øand brake into Tran≈øilvania burning and de≈øtroying all before them in a fearful manner, which obliged the Prince to rai≈øe the whole power of his Countrey, and to crave aid of the Ra≈øcians and other his Neighbours giving freely to his Subjects and Confederates what ever they could take from the Turks, who in their fir≈øt interprize were ≈øo ≈øucce≈øsful, that they
≈øurprized ≈øeven of the Turks Gallies laden with Provi≈øion, Rich Merchandize, and ≈øtore of Trea≈øure, and mi≈ø≈øed but narrowly of the eighth, which was the Admiral which lo≈øs was ≈øo great to the Turks, Sinan Ba≈ø≈øa upon notice of what had happened is reported to have ≈øaid that if tho≈øe Gallies had come to him in ≈øafety he could with the Trea≈øure have bought Vienna, as he had done Ra ‚Ä¢ b, after which the Tran≈øilvanians hightened with this ≈øucce≈øs marched towards Teme≈øwar, but hearing that the Tartars were about to return, they retired for the defence of their own Countrey; yet by this time headed by their Prince they took many ≈øtrong Holds from the Turks, and ≈øtill following their returning Army in the rear cut many Thou≈øands of them ≈øhort, and by his example ≈øoon after the Valachians and Moldavians ro≈øe up in Armes again≈øt Amurath and Confederated them≈øelves with the Tran≈øilvanian Prince who with one con≈øent ≈øent to Rodolphus the Emperour to make a League with him again≈øt the common Enemy which was accordingly concluded very Honourable to the Confederates which made Amurath begin to doubt his ≈øafety even in Con≈øtantinople, and much more when they with their victorious Armies overrun his Countries on every ≈øide, for grief of which, and the di≈øorderly tumults he found among≈øt his Janizaries and his other Souldiers of the Court, he fell Sick, when greatly afflicted with the Stone and Falling Sickne≈øs, his wonted Di≈øea≈øe, as a man both in Soul and Body tormented, he with great Impatiency and Agony of mind gave up the Gho≈øt, departing this Life on the Eighteenth of January, Anno Domini 1595. When he had
lived One and Fifty years, or as ≈øome ≈øay Two and Fifty years, and thereof Reigned Nineteen years. At the time of who≈øe Death aro≈øe ≈øo Terrible a Tempe≈øt at Con≈øtantinople that many thought the world ≈øhould have pre≈øently been di≈ø≈øolved, his dead Body within a while after was with all Funeral Solemnities u≈øed among≈øt the Turks, buryed by the Body of Mahomet his Elde≈øt Son, in the Mo≈øchie which him≈øelf had builded near unto his Palace.

div.head: CHAP. XVII. The Life of Mahomet Third of that Name, ≈øeventh Emperor of the Turks.
div.p: A Murath being dead, his death to prevent tumults was kept ≈øecret till ≈øuch time that Mahomet his Elde≈øt Son then living, came from Ama≈øia to Con≈øtantinople, where contrary to the mind of the Janizaries, who generally affected Amurath his younger brother, he was ≈øaluted Exmperour; when by a wile getting his Ten Brethren into his power, he cau≈øed them to be ≈øtrangled, nay ≈øo far extended his barbarity that at his Commandement ten of his Fathers Wives and Concubines, whom he ≈øu≈øpected to be with Child were drowned in the Sea, one of which number as ≈øome affirm was his own Mother. The≈øe violent proceedings made the great Commanders envy him, and the better to wreck their ≈øpleen ≈øecretly to ≈øtir up the Janizaries, who committed for the ≈øpace of ≈øeveral days ≈øuch di≈øorders that the like in no Interregnum had happened, and great had the di≈øorder been even to outraging the Emperour him≈øelf, had not the Ba≈ø≈øa Governour of the City cau≈øedall the great Ordinance to be bent again≈øt them, and ≈øwore by the head of Ali to di≈øcharge them among≈øt u'm.

Whil≈øt the≈øe troubles happened at Con≈øtantinople, the Chri≈øtian Princes were not wanting to revenge the injuries they had ≈øu≈øtained by the Turks, e≈øpecially
the Princes or as the Turks call them Vayvod of Tran≈øilvania, Valachia, and Moldavia, who with many fortunate inroads into the Othoman Dominions greatly inriched them≈øelves and Souldiers, taking and Fortifying many ≈øtrong Ca≈øtles, and de≈øtroying an Army of Four Hundred Thou≈øand Tartars, with which they had often conflicts.
