Nor was Rodolphus the Emperour behind with the forwarde≈øt, as well knowing that he had to deal with an implacable Enemy, who would have no peace any longer then it ≈øerved his own purpo≈øe, wherefore the ≈øaid Emperour, and th States of Hungary ≈øent their Amba≈ø≈øadors to the King of Poland, who then had a≈ø≈øembled a Parliament at Cracovia, to ≈øolicite his Aid again≈øt the common Enemy; of which Mahomet having notice, ≈øent likewi≈øe two Chiaus in nature of his Amba≈ø≈øadors to fru≈øtrate the negotiation of the Chri≈øtian Amba≈ø≈øadors in the Poli≈øh Court, and to engage that King to take up Arms on his behalf, but pa≈ø≈øing through Valachia, they were contrary to the mind of the Vayvod ≈ølain by ≈øome of his followers; yet the Turk ≈øent two others who fetching a greater compa≈øs through the Tartarian Dominions arrived ≈øafe in Polonia.

The≈øe proceedings of the Chri≈øtians rou≈øed Mahomet, and in≈øpired him who was of a feirce and froward nature, to take revenge, in order to which he ≈øent for Sinan Ba≈ø≈øa out of Hungary, to confer with him about the management of the war, which once ≈øtated, he returned again to Belgrade, where upon his fir≈øt Arrival, by what mi≈øchance, yet ≈øuppo≈øed to be by the contrivance of the Janizaries, the cords of his Tent were cut, and it was let fall about his ears; now at his coming, ≈øo great was the dearth in all the parts of Hungary, where the Turks had their
po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øions, that ≈øeveral Tartarian women following the Camp, killed their own children, and ate them, which ≈øamine ingendered ≈øuch a Pe≈øtilence, that the Turks and Tartars dyed in abundance, in≈øomuch that of eighty thou≈øand of the latter, which the year before came at divers times to the a≈ø≈øi≈øtance of the Turks, not above eight thou≈øand remained alive. And now the Chri≈øtian Army ha≈øtened from all parts to the Imperial ≈øtandard; ≈øo that of Germans, Saxons, Bohemians, Hungarians, Spaniards, Italians, Romans, Flemings, Franks and Sweeds, in a ≈øhort time there were found fifteen thou≈øand nine hundred hor≈øe, and fifty thou≈øand foot, under the conduct of mo≈øt re≈øolute Commanders, of which Matthias the Arch Duke was General, and Count Mansfelt ≈øent by the King of Spain with 2000 hor≈øe, and 6000 foot, was appointed by the Emperor his Lieutenant.

Thus all things being in a readine≈øs, nothing wanting but an enemy, on whom to exerci≈øe tho≈øe Arms, which long was not wanting, for Mahomet by this time had rai≈øed a great power, yet had but a bad welcome, for at fir≈øt the Ba≈ø≈øa of Buda, with a great number of Turks, attempting to doe ≈øome memorable exploit in Tran≈øilvania, was overthrown by Ge≈øtius Ferents, a valiant Captain, with the lo≈øs of mo≈øt of his men; when almo≈øt at the ≈øame time a great power of the Turks under the leading of their General, entering Valachia, were incountred by the Lord Nada≈øti, commanding there for the Emperor, who a≈ø≈øi≈øted by the Valachians and Tran≈øylvanians, and in a great battle di≈øcomfited, with the lo≈øs of ten thou≈øand men, and their ≈øttandard imbroidered with Pearls and Precious Stones, valued at 30000 Dollars, which the ≈øaid Lord ≈øent to the Tran≈øylvanian Prince, then at Alba Julia, and had it returned him again as
a reward of his good ≈øervice, which evil ≈øucce≈øs being perceived by the crafty Tyrant Mahomet, he dealt under hand by great promi≈øes with Aaron Vayvod of Moldavia, to revolt from the Tran≈øylvanian and by any means if po≈ø≈øible to depo≈øe him, which thing coming to light, and made manife≈øt by ≈øeverall intercepted Letters, the ≈øaid Vayvod with his wife and children being then retired into Tran≈øylvania, were ≈øecured, and a while after by the con≈øent of the Moldavian Nobility, one Stephen Rozwan, placed in his ≈øtead, which Mahomet perceiving, and that his practi≈øe was brought to nought, ≈øent an Amba≈ø≈øador to Sigi≈ømund Prince of Tran≈øylvania, to be at peace with him, and ≈øuffer, as formerly, his Armies to pa≈øs through his Countrey into Hungaria, and that in lieu thereof, he ≈øhould have peaceable po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of Tran≈øylvania, Moldavia, and Valachia, paying no more then a ≈ømall acknowledgment which ≈øhould not be exacted by the way of Tribute, but the Prince having too often experienced the perfidious dealings of the Turks, would in no wi≈øe accord to what was demanded, but re≈øolved upon pro≈øecuting the war to the utmo≈øt, the which his re≈øolution once made known to the Bulgarians, they ≈øent me≈ø≈øengers in ≈øecret to a≈ø≈øure him that if he proceeded with any good ≈øucce≈øs, they would be ready to follow his fortune, and by joyning hands with him, again≈øt the cruel Tyrant, ≈øhut up all the pa≈ø≈øages that way into Valachia, Moldavia, and Hungaria.

The greate≈øt part of the aid, promi≈øed by the Chri≈øtian Princes, for the maintenance of the war, being come to Vienna, Count Mansfelt called a council of the chief Commanders, to con≈øult whether they ≈øhould lay ≈øiege to ≈øome place of Importance, or march to give the enemy battle, whom he ≈øaid
he had Intelligence was on his way; in which Council the former propo≈øal being re≈øolved on, the whole Army in number afore≈øaid, was mu≈øtered at Altenberg, after which he be≈øieged Dolis, but at the ≈øame time had his eye upon Strigonium, the other being undertaken only to amu≈øe the Turks, and exhau≈øt the Garri≈øon of Strigonum, both of men and warlike provi≈øion, to relieve their brethren in Dolis, which ≈øupply the Count permitted to enter the Town, and then when he was lea≈øt ≈øu≈øpected, ≈øuddenly rai≈øeing his ≈øiege ≈øet down before Strigonum, to the great amazement of the Turk, who not in the lea≈øt dreamed of any ≈øuch matter, yet was it not carryed ≈øo privately but e'r he could intrench him≈øelf, ≈øeveral Walloons Heidons, ≈øtraggling from the main battle, were ≈øet upon by the Turks, and put to the rout, but the Pioniers having run the Trenches within half Musket ≈øhot of the wall, fired ≈øo ≈ømartly upon the defendants, many of them were ≈ølain, none being able to appear upon the wall, yet the Chri≈øtians at at the beginning of the Siege, having taken a little I≈øland in the Danubius, and put on ≈øhoar ≈øeveral Hungarian Companies, of which the Turks of Buda having notice, they in ≈øeveral Boats and Gallies, coming down the River by night, landed three thou≈øand men, who unawares ≈øetting upon the Chri≈øtians, put mo≈øt of them to the ≈øword, and recovered the ≈øaid I≈øland, but that lo≈øs was ≈øoon repaired; for after many furious a≈ø≈øaults (notwith≈øtanding the threats of the Ba≈ø≈øa of Buda to Impail the Strigonians if they ≈øought it not out to the la≈øt man) the higher City was laid open to the Chri≈øtians, who ju≈øt as they were about to enter, had notice that the Ba≈ø≈øa of Buda (whom Mahomet had threatned with the lo≈øs of his head, if he ≈øuffered that City which he e≈øteemed worth a whole Kingdom, to be lo≈øt) was coming
to relieve it with twenty thou≈øand Turks, re≈øolving to fight his way into it; whereupon divers parties were ≈øent out to skirmi≈øh, and by retiring to draw the enemy into the danger of the Chri≈øtian Army, which project was not un≈øucce≈ø≈øeful, for the re≈øolute Ba≈ø≈øa coming on between the hills of St. George and St. Thomas near to the Suburbs called the Ru≈øcian City, put his Army in order of Battle, as did the Chri≈øtians, when in the mean while the Lord Paifi with his Hungarian hor≈øemen fetching a compa≈øs about the hill, on the one ≈øide and the Lord Swartzenburg with ≈øuch hor≈øe as he had under his command, on the other ≈øide, ≈øo inclo≈øed the Turks rear, that they could not without great danger retire, when as both Armies were orderly ranged, the ≈øignal of battle was given, the Turks without any great harm to the Chri≈øtians di≈øcharged ≈øeventeen Pieces of Artillery, after which, with ≈øhowers of Arrows and the ≈ømoak of the Harquibu≈øes the Sky was darkned, and in a trice, not without great ≈ølaughter, the battle was brought to the ≈øword, at what time Victory declared for the Chri≈øtians, the Turks being every where mo≈øt mi≈øerably beaten down, crying out for mercy, and flying as they found opportunity, and in the end the Ba≈ø≈øa him≈øelf from his ≈øtand, perceiving his Army in the rout, and that the day was irrecoverably lo≈øt, fled for his life, and about midnight recovered Buda, with not above twenty of his followers, filling that City with the laments of ≈øuch as had in the battle lo≈øt their friend. The ≈ølain and tho≈øe taken pri≈øoners were fourteen thou≈øand, and the ≈øpoil of the Camp con≈øi≈øting of rich Pavilions, Money, Plate, Ammunition, fair hor≈øes, provi≈øion, Camels, and the like, was valued at 300000 Ducates, part of which was ≈øent to the Emperour, part to the Arch Duke, and
part di≈øtributed among≈øt the Souldiers, to every one according to their de≈øerts.

The Turki≈øh Army thus overthrown, the Chri≈øtians returned again to the ≈øiege, when as the Count ≈øent to Summon Alis Beg the Governour to ≈øurrender the City, and that in con≈øideration thereof, he and all that were with him ≈øhould be ≈øuffered to depart, but the me≈ø≈øengers finding the froward old man ob≈øtinate, notwith≈øtanding the great dearth that was then in the City, he returned without effecting any thing; upon which a terrible battery being placed again≈øt the lower City, it thundred again≈øt the walls and Bullwarks ≈øo long, that laying open a fair breach, the Souldiers entred with ≈øuch fury, that bearing down all before them, they upon the coming of the Marque≈øs of Burgave with fre≈øh Troops, they po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed them≈øelves of it, driving the Turks into the Ca≈øtle and upper City, with great ≈ølaughter, ≈øparing in their rage none that came in their way, yet the malitious Turks e'r their departure, to deprive the Chri≈øtians of the benefit they might reap by the ≈øpoil, had by Trains laid for that purpo≈øe, fired the building in ≈øeveral places, ≈øo that inraged by the wind, the flame could be hardly extingui≈øhed, till it had laid mo≈øt of the goodly building wa≈øte, yet was this great Victory accompanied with ≈øorrow for the death of the Count Mansfelt, who by drinking cold Liquors, after his great pains taken in the late battle, fell into a feaver, which turning to the bloody Flix, deprived him of his life, to the great grief of the Chri≈øtian Princes, who on his Courage and Conduct, had repo≈øed next to God the ≈øucce≈øs of their Arms, yet the Chri≈øtians continued the ≈øiege, nor was it long e'r the be≈øieged lo≈øt Alis Beg their Governour, who walking upon the wall to give directions in places of mo≈øt danger, had
his arm ≈øtruck off with a great ≈øhot, of which he dyed, when in his ≈øtead the Janizaries in Garri≈øon cho≈øe the Ba≈ø≈øa of Natolia, who upon the overthrow of the Ba≈ø≈øa of Buda, had e≈øcaped into the City with a hundred hor≈øemen; when upon notice of the death of Count Mansfelt the Arch Duke came to the Camp, who when he had well viewed the Army, and the manner of the ≈øiege, he a≈ø≈øembled his chief Commanders, to con≈øult what was be≈øt to be done, who after ≈øome debate re≈øolved to give a generall a≈ø≈øault, which was maintained with great re≈øolution, but the be≈øieged as ob≈øtinately defending their walls; the Duke cau≈øed the Retreat to be ≈øounded, and then by his E≈øpials under≈øtanding that the Turks near Buda were gathering together, to relieve the be≈øieged, he commanded 8000 cho≈øen hor≈øe ≈øpeedily to march thither, who a little before ≈øun≈øet ≈øetting upon them, expecting nothing le≈øs, made of them a great ≈ølaughter, and taking a number of pri≈øoners, and among≈øt the re≈øt the Sanzack of Copan, returned again to the ≈øiege; when as the be≈øieged finding there was no hope of relief, and that the famine was greivous among≈øt them, the Governour overcome with ≈øuch like difficulties, and the continual cries of the Citizens and Souldiers, at length con≈øented to parly upon rea≈øonable conditions, ≈øo that in fine it was agreed that the Garri≈øon and all the Citizens Turks ≈øhould be ≈øent with bag and baggage to Buda, and in con≈øideration whereof Strigonium the Metropolis of Hungaria, which for the ≈øpace of 52 years, had groaned under the oppre≈ø≈øion of the Turki≈øh Tyrants, was delivered into the hands of the Arch Duke, and the conditions with the Turks accordingly performed, twenty Ships being for that purpo≈øe imployed by the ≈øpace of two dayes, after which the Duke ≈øent 18 thou≈øand to be≈øiege Vicegrade otherwi≈øe called Plindenburg,
a ≈øtrong Ca≈øtle of the Turks, ≈øcituate upon Danubius, between Strigonium and Buda, which they took, and in their march brought ≈øuch a fear upon Buda, that had not the Ba≈ø≈øa ≈øhut fa≈øt the Gates, mo≈øt of the Inhabitants had fled over the Danudius.

During this good ≈øucce≈øs of the Imperiali≈øts the Prince of Tran≈øylvania was not idle, but with an Army of his be≈øt Souldiers, ≈øetting upon thirty thou≈øand Turks (who as unbidden Gue≈øts were coming to his wedding, which he was then ≈øolemnizing with Maria Christina, daughter to Charles the late Arch Duke of Au≈øtria) he gave ≈øuch a welcome, that few of them returned to tell the news, after which, pro≈øecuting his victory he took Lippa, a ≈øtrong Town, with divers other Towns and Ca≈øtles of the Turks, out of which they had for a long time annoyed the Countries round about them; about the ≈øame time the Lords Herben≈øtien, Lucowitz and Eckenburg incountered with the Ba≈ø≈øa of Bo≈øna, as he was returning with ten thou≈øand Turks and Tartars, from the taking of Babotzka, whom after a hard fight they overthrew, putting mo≈øt of them to the ≈øword, the Ba≈ø≈øa him≈øelf, upon a ≈øwift hor≈øe hardly e≈øcaping.

The≈øe ≈øucce≈ø≈øefull proceedings of the Chri≈øtians ≈øo inraged the Turk, that imputing ≈øeveral of the di≈øgraces that had happened to the neglect of Ferat Ba≈ø≈øa, he by the advice of Sinan Ba≈ø≈øa, ≈øent for him, who tru≈øting to his innocency, boldly came to an≈øwer to what ≈øhould be objected again≈øt him, though warned to the contrary, but he was ≈øcarce arrived e'r by the command of Mahomet he was ≈øtrangled and his goods to the value of five hundred thou≈øand Ducats confi≈øcated.

After the death of Ferat, who was ≈øomewhat a favourer of the Chri≈øtians, Sinan the proud Ba≈ø≈øa,
≈øon to a Fi≈øherman, and their mortal enemy, was ≈øent with a great Army into Valachia, to reduce that and the other revolted Countries to the Turki≈øh obedience, but being encountred by the Tran≈øilvanian Forces, his Army was overthrown with great ≈ølaughter, and him≈øelf in his flight falling into a Limepit, hardly e≈øcaped with life; after which he fled to Can≈øtantinople, to plead his own cau≈øe, having promi≈øed upon his undertaking that Expedition at the price of his head, to reduce Valachia, Moldavia, and Tran≈øylvania, to their former obedience.

Not long after the overthrow of Sinan, the Lords Eckenberg and Leucowitz overthrew twenty thou≈øand who under the leading of the Ba≈ø≈øa of Bo≈øna, invaded the country of Crotia, and following their Victory, entred the Turki≈øh Dominions and burnt 15 Villages, carrying away a great booty, and ≈øoon after took Petrina, which after a clo≈øe ≈øiege, and ≈øome furious a≈ø≈øaults was abandoned by the Turks. In the mean while Sigi≈ømund the Tran≈øylvanian Prince, rai≈øed a greater power than before, upon notice that Sinan Ba≈ø≈øa was again upon his march to invade his Countries; at what time the Ziculi or Sciculy, a people bordering on the North of Tran≈øilvania, ≈øent to him to offer him their ≈øervice, as weary of the Turki≈øh thraldom; who according to agreement, be≈øides many rich pre≈øents, and ≈øtore of provi≈øion, ≈øent him forty thou≈øand men well appointed, which no ≈øooner joyned him, he had notice that Sinan had pa≈ø≈øed Danubius, by a bridg of Boats; whereupon he marched with all dilligence to meet him, and in another ≈øet battle, gave him a fatal overthrow, in which there were thirty thou≈øand ≈ølain and taken pri≈øoners, be≈øides a rich booty; nor did the River Danubius upon their ha≈øty repa≈ø≈øing the bridge,
which was near two miles over, devour a le≈øs number, in≈øomuch that Sinan ≈øwore in a great rage, that the young Prince had in a ≈øhort time Eclip≈øed all the renown he in the cour≈øe of his whole life had got.

After this overthrow of the Turks, which they number among≈øt their great mi≈øchances, the Ca≈øtle and I≈øland in the River with little lo≈øs were recovered, and then in great Triumph laden with the Turks ≈øpoils the Prince returned to Alba Julia, at what time by his Captains he took the ≈øtrong Ca≈øtle of Jenna, and intercepted about 70 waggons richly laden, which they of Teme≈øwar fearing to be be≈øieged were ≈øending, together with their wives and children, to places of greater ≈øtrength.

The≈øe things perplexing the proud Turk, he ≈øent his ≈øpecial Me≈ø≈øengers to ≈øtir up the Crime≈øian Tartars, (a people living for the mo≈øt part on ≈øpoil) to invade Moldavia, Tran≈øylvania, and Valachia, who were likewi≈øe incouraged thereto by the Chancellor of Polonia, he ≈øo far in≈øinuating with the King, that Moldavia was taken from the Tran≈øylvanian Prince, and a new Vayvod placed therein, who opened (contrary to his faith given) three wayes for the Turks and Tartars to invade Tran≈øylvania, of which perfidious dealing Pope Clement the Eighth by his Letters to the King of Polonia, grievou≈øly complained; and likewi≈øe again≈øt Cardinal Zamoskie, the Chancelor, and fir≈øt mover of this mi≈øchief, whom he cited to appear before him at Rome, there to an≈øwer to what ≈øhould by the Amba≈ø≈øadours of the Chri≈øtian Princes, be objected again≈øt him, charging them both with breach of faith, and di≈øloyalty to the King of Heaven, by betraying the Chri≈øtians into the hand of the ≈øworn enemies of the Chri≈øtian Religion, yet both the King and Chancelor
u≈øed ≈øuch endeavours that they ≈øatisfied the Pope in the nece≈ø≈øity of their writing better to him to that purpo≈øe, when at the ≈øame time Cham Kazikieri the Tartarian King wrote to Sigi≈ømund King of Polonia, to put him in mind of his promi≈øe to give his Army free pa≈ø≈øage, as likewi≈øe to de≈øtroy the Co≈ø≈øacks, who as he ≈øaid by daily incur≈øions wa≈øted his Frontier, and to make a perpetual League with him yet onely the former reque≈øt was ob≈øerved.

The Chri≈øtians not plea≈øed with the proceedings of the Polonian, to ≈øhew how little they e≈øteemed his Friend≈øhip, inraged as it were with his revolt burnt and de≈øtroyed all the Turki≈øh Garri≈øons uppon his Frontiers, whom he dur≈øt not protect for fear of having his own Dominions wa≈øted in the like manner, but what happened this year 1596 advantagious to the Chri≈øtians was the death of Sinan Ba≈ø≈øa their ≈øworn Enemy, who having by his Friends and many rich pre≈øents e≈øcaped the fury of the angry Sultan Mahomet who had vowed his death, ≈øoon after through grief and ≈øhame of his late overthrow died, after he had for Fifty years wa≈øted the Earth with Fire and Sword, Yet the following Spring Mahomet with a great power purpo≈øed in per≈øon to pa≈øs into Hungary, but by rea≈øon of the Plague and Famine, that raged throughout his Empire he could not accompli≈øh his de≈øign, but was more and more perplexed by the revolt of the Georgians, and the great Army the new King of Per≈øia was rai≈øing for the recovery of Tauris, notwith≈øtanding to prevent the wor≈øt the Tran≈øilvanian Prince in per≈øon went to the Courts of the Emperour and Pope to crave Aid, where he was with great kindne≈øs received, and promi≈øed ≈øuch ≈øupplies of Men and Mony as his occa≈øion ≈øhould require, but
during his ≈øtay there the Sciculi ro≈øe up in arms again≈øt him, yet the Rebellion was blown over by the execution of the chief Promoters of the Tumult, and Ten Thou≈øand Ra≈øcians in a fit time proffered him their ≈øervice, for the Tartars were by this time on their way, whereupon having received ≈øeveral rich Pre≈øents he returned home, being every where joyfully received of his People. All this time the Lord Palfi with the Garri≈øon Souldiers of Strigonium was not idle, but u≈øed his utmo≈øt dilligence to ≈øurprize the Turks Convoys and Garri≈øons, nor was his expectation fru≈øtrated, for overrunning the Country as far as the Walls of Teme≈øwar he got many rich booties, and removed ≈øuch Chri≈øtians as were in danger of the Turks Garri≈øon nearer his own mi≈ø≈øing but narrowly of the Ba≈ø≈øa of Teme≈øwar with all his Trea≈øure, as he was going to Belgrade to give place to a new Ba≈ø≈øa, but however he fell into the hands of the Hungarian Heidons, who overthrew his Convoy, ≈ølew him, and took all his riches laden in Seventy Five Waggons to the value of Two Hundred Thou≈øand Hungarian Ducats, which ≈øo inraged the Turks that gathering Forty Thou≈øand ≈øtrong they be≈øieged Lippa, but after the lo≈øs of ≈øix Thou≈øand of their number in many furious a≈ø≈øaults, they left their Trenches and in great confu≈øion retired, which flight was occa≈øioned by the Governour of Lugaz his ≈øurpri≈øing the Suburbs of Teme≈øwar, and ≈øetting them on fire, which being ≈øeen in the Turks Camp cau≈øed among≈øt them that great con≈øternation, as thinking the Prince of Tran≈øilvania with his whole Army was coming on, and even at their backs. After who≈øe flight the Hungarian Heidons pa≈ø≈øing the Danubius took Plenia, in revenge of which the Turks took Cli≈ø≈øa, out of which they had not long before been driven; not long after the Lord Palfi took the
≈øtrong Ca≈øtle Sombock, which the Turks in a rage upon the enterance of the Chri≈øtians ≈øet on fire, but thereby ≈øo exa≈øperated the Souldiers that they ≈øpared none they found therein, but put them all to the Sword without re≈øpect either to Age or Sex.

The≈øe continual currants of Victory carryed the Tran≈øilvanian Prince to the Siege of Tame≈øwar, which he for many dayes furiou≈øly battered, but upon notice that the Ba≈ø≈øa of Natolia the forerunner of Mahomets Army, was come to Belgrade with Fourteen thou≈øand Turks, and Mahomet with an Army of One Hundred and Fifty Thou≈øand was coming after him to the Relief of the City, and he not having yet received the ≈øupplies promi≈øed by the Chri≈øtian Princes his Confederates, thought good to rai≈øe his ≈øiege and depart for Lippa, where having left a ≈øtrong Garri≈øon he kept on his way to Alba-Julia, and a≈ø≈øembled there the States of his Principality to con≈øider the mo≈øt expedient means for rai≈øing more Forces to repre≈øs ≈øo potent an Adver≈øary.

Mahomet approaching with his Forces which daily increa≈øed, ≈øent to Michale the Vayvod of Valachia to promi≈øe him great rewards if he would become his Tributary and revolt from the Tran≈øilvanian Prince, but finding nothing would prevail with the Vayvod to break his Faith he came with his whole Army now increa≈øed to the number of Two Hundred Thou≈øand to Buda, yet ere he could attempt any thing Maximilian the Emperours General, (made ≈øo in the ≈øtead of Matthias the Arch-Duke, who upon the Death of Ferdinand the Emperors Uncle, had the rich County of Tirol be≈øtowed upon him whither he was retired) had taken Vacia, Hatvan, and ≈øeveral other places, but long re≈øted not Mahomet before, he with his huge Army be≈øieged Agria,
which after the lo≈øs of Twenty Thou≈øand of his Men not by force but by ≈øurrender, for the Soldiers perceiving the new Ca≈øtle, the place in which they only put their tru≈øt, undermined; and about to be blown up, and that all hopes of being relieved were vain, they layed hands upon Paulus Niari and Terskie the Captain of the Garri≈øon Souldiers and Governour of the City, and ca≈øting them in Pri≈øon capitulated with the Turks to deliver the City and Ca≈øtle, in con≈øideration that they might depart with bag and baggage, but the faithle≈øs Infidels ere they had pa≈ø≈øed through the Camp contrary to their faith given cut them in pieces, after which the Ba≈ø≈øa of Bo≈øua with a ≈øtrong power layed ≈øiege to Petrina, but upon notice that the Lords Herben≈øtein and Bencowitz were coming to relieve it, and in their way had overthrown Six Thou≈øand Turks he rai≈øed his ≈øiege in great ha≈øt leaving behind him part of his Carriages. But now the two pui≈ø≈øant Armies of the Chri≈øtians and Turks coming in view of each other and nothing but a ≈ømall River parting them, drew frequently up in Battalia, and had ≈øeveral skirmi≈øhes at a di≈øtance, but the vain glorious Turks not thinking it ≈øufficient to di≈øcharge their great Artillery, and skirmi≈øh in ≈ømall parties at the Command of Mahomet, Ten Thou≈øand of them, and Six Thou≈øand Tartars pa≈ø≈øed the River, but were ≈øo hotly welcomed that few returned, which advantage the Chri≈øtians following pur≈øued the flyers, and ≈øet upon the gro≈øs of the Turks Army, putting all into confu≈øion and con≈øternation; ≈øo that Mahomet fearing a total overthrow retreated to his Camp, whither the Chri≈øtians as eagerly pur≈øued, but whil≈øt they di≈øordered them≈øelves to take the ≈øpoil, (although the General had cau≈øed Proclamation to be made, that none on pain of death ≈øhould attempt
it till the victory was obtained.) They being afre≈øh charged and many of them cut off by the Turks great Artilery, betook them≈øelves to plain flight not to be ≈øtayed by the threats nor intreaties of their Commanders, ≈øo that the German Hor≈øe di≈øordering their own Foot put all into confu≈øion, which the Turks contrary to their expectation perceiving followed hard after them, making great ≈ølaughter, yet ≈øo con≈øcious were they of their weakne≈øs, that fearing the return of the Chri≈øtians, that in the night they ≈øecretly rai≈øed their Camp and returned to Agria, leaving their Cannon and Baggage in the Trenches for the ≈øpace of three dayes, ≈øo ≈ølenderly guarded that Five Thou≈øand men might have taken the ≈øpoil; Mahomet him≈øelf confe≈ø≈øing that he feared to have been taken Pri≈øoner, and would not for the future venture his per≈øon in places of ≈øuch imminent danger.

In this Battle or rather running fight, called from the place where it happened, the Battle of Kare≈øta, Forty Thou≈øand Turks and Fifteen Thou≈øand Chri≈øtians were ≈ølain mo≈øt of the latter in the ra≈øh and unadvi≈øed flight, the which had it not contrary to all rea≈øon happened never had a more glorious victory been obtained over the Infidels. Yet Mahomet after he had furni≈øhed Agria with a Garri≈øon of Ten Thou≈øand choice Souldiers returned to Belgrade, and having divided his Army in two parts, the one he left in the Countrey to ≈øecure it again≈øt the Chri≈øtians, and with the other departed to Con≈øtantinople, but by the way being ≈øet upon by Barbelius Jancaechie the Tran≈øilvanian Princes Lieutenant, and the Vayvod of Valachia, who with a ≈øtrong power for that purpo≈øe had pa≈ø≈øed the Danubius, they cut off ≈øeven Thou≈øand of his men.

Early in the ≈øpring as a≈øhamed of their di≈øgrace the Chri≈øtian Princes recruited their ≈øcattered Forces which meeting together near to Pa≈ø≈øonium and Altenburg, marched to Papa, which they be≈øieged and after eight dayes battery took it, and ≈øo again returning to Altenburg the Army mu≈øtered, from whence they marched to Rab and be≈øieged it, but upon the approach of the Turks Army under the Command of Mahomet Ba≈ø≈øa, rai≈øed the ≈øiege, as finding it both difficult and dangerous, and ≈øo marched over into the I≈øland of Schut, when in their ≈øight they permitted the Turks to take Dolis.

Michael the Vayvod of Valachia, having his Countrey almo≈øt de≈øtroyed by the Turks, and they promi≈øing him great favours and bounties more then ever, if he would again return to his obedience; he to ≈øave his Countrey from utter de≈øtruction, complied with the Tyrants de≈øire in part, viz. to own him for his Soveraign, and to pay him half the wonted Tribute, but denied upon any terms to aid him again≈øt the Chri≈øtians, which the Turk for a while di≈ø≈øembled and ≈øeemed well contented with his ≈øubmi≈ø≈øion, but afterward contrary to his Oath oppre≈ø≈øing him with great Taxes, both he and the Prince of Tran≈øilvania recommended the protection of their Countries to Rodolphus the Emperour, who thereupon called a Diet to con≈øult about rai≈øing contributions ≈øufficient for the management of the War again≈øt the Turks, and ≈øuch ≈øucce≈øs had his arms immediately thereon, through the good conduct of the Lord Swartzenburg, Rab was ≈øurprized for certain Engineers coming by night to the Gates, finding the Portculli≈øes drawn up in expectation of Waggons loaden with Provi≈øion to come from Alba Regalis, they fa≈øtened ≈øeveral Petards to the ≈øaid
Gates which deadly Engins once fired rent 'um in pieces, ≈øo that the Army which followed at their heels pre≈ø≈øing in, after a long fight killed two of the Turks Ba≈ø≈øa's, and put the re≈øt to the flight, who ≈øuch as could e≈øcaped over the Wall, and tho≈øe that could not fell by the Swords of the inraged Soldiers, who in the City found ≈øo great a booty that many of them were greatly inriched thereby, be≈øides One Hundred pieces of great Ordnance, and ≈øtore of all manner of Provi≈øions. That City though ≈øo ea≈øily recovered, being one of the ≈øtronge≈øt Fortre≈ø≈øes in Chri≈øtendom, the taking of which ≈øo incouraged the General of the Imperiali≈øts, that (upon notice that great differences were ari≈øen between the Janizaries and the Sphai, the Turks be≈øt Footmen and Hor≈øemen upon a point of preheminency) he re≈øolved to be≈øiege Buda the Turks chief ≈øtrength in Hungary, and thereupon marching thither with all his Army, on the 16th. of October, 1598. he ≈øar down before it, and for many days battered it with ≈øixteen pieces of Cannon. But in fine ≈øeeing no hopes of winning it, and having notice that a great Army of Turks was ha≈øting to its relief having plundered the Suburbs the General drew his Army out of the Trenches and departed to Strigonium.

The Tran≈øilvanian Prince having exchanged his Country with the Emperour for the Dukedoms of Oppel and Ratibor, and yearly Fifty Thou≈øand Joachim, or the Revenues of the Bi≈øhoprick of ∆≤rati≈ølavia, Territories lying in Sile≈øia and repenting him of what he had done, he came again into Tran≈øilvania in di≈øgui≈øe, and was joyfully received by his Subjects, at what time Maximilian the Emperors Generals was marching with the Army to take po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of it, which had like to have cau≈øed great
di≈ø≈øen≈øions among≈øt the Chri≈øtian Confederates had not the Prince by many ≈øubmi≈ø≈øive Letters pacified the Emperors di≈øplea≈øure. Now were the Turks Army arrived in Hungary and had layed ≈øiege to Veradinum, which City being at the point to be yielded, was relieved by the Lord Ba≈øta the Emperours Lieutenant, who making ≈øemblance to give the Turks Battle, and by that means drawing them out of their Trenches, in the mean time by an un≈øu≈øpected way, thru≈øt Eight Hundred Souldiers into the City and ≈øo drew off, through which ≈øupply the City was ≈øo long defended that the Turks weary of the ≈øiege, and by rea≈øon of the approach of Winter departed, leaving for ha≈øt many of their Tents and great Ordnance as a prey to the be≈øieged, after which the Imperiali≈øts ≈øpoiled that part of the Lower Hungary, which was in the po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of the Turks even to the gates of Buda, which brought a great fear upon the Garri≈øon and Citizens. When at the ≈øame time Michael the Vayvod of Valachia, having gathered a ≈øtrong power took and ≈øacked Nicopolis, the rumor of which coming to Con≈øtantinople where the Plague then raged, it greatly perplexed Mahomet and brought a fear upon that great City. Yet to put a ≈øtop to the Vayvods proceedings, he cau≈øed a great number of Turks under the leading of Taut Ba≈ø≈øa to march again≈øt him, who joyning the forces of Mahomet Satergi with which he had be≈øieged Veradinum; yet the Vayvod not in the lea≈øt di≈ømayed, marched 100 Miles into the Turks Territories, and de≈øtroying all before him obtained a great Booty. But now contrary to the expectation of all men the Tran≈øilvanian Prince, in≈øtigated thereto by the Polonian King, re≈øigned the right he had in that Principality, to his Cozen Andrew Battor, and thereby defrauded the Emperour of that which by way of
Exchange was properly his, the Tran≈øylvanians having thereupon ≈øworn him fealty, yet not to di≈øcourage his Confederates the Emperor ≈øet light thereby, though the proud Cardinal, to whom it was re≈øigned ≈øubmitted him≈øelf a Va≈ø≈øal to Mahomet, and thereby deprived the Chri≈øtian Commonwealth of one of her ≈øure≈øt Bulwarks.

Buda blocked up by the Chri≈øtians, and thereby reduced to great extreamity, the Ba≈ø≈øa thereof upon notice that ≈øeveral waggons laden with provi≈øion, were on their way, i≈ø≈øued out with ≈øix hundred hor≈øe to conduct them ≈øafe; but being ≈øet upon by the free Hadducks, his Guard was overthrown, his ≈øon ≈ølain, and him≈øelf taken pri≈øoner; and within a while after the Lord Palfie incountering the Ba≈ø≈øa of Bo≈øna, who was coming with ten thou≈øand men to relieve the ≈øaid City, overthrew his power, ≈ølew the Ba≈ø≈øa, and took all the waggons laden with provi≈øion, and at the ≈øame time five thou≈øand Tartars being ≈øet upon by the Lord Swartzenburgs Regiment, were all cut in pieces; upon notice of Ibraim Ba≈ø≈øa with a great power ≈øet forward from Con≈øtantinople, but part of his Forces being encountred by the Imperiali≈øts under the command of the Lord Palfis Lieutenant, were overthrown, and rich booty taken, containing all the provi≈øion of the Camp, and one hundred thou≈øand Dollars which were coming up the Danubius to pay the Souldiers, which lo≈øs greatly di≈øcontented the Ba≈ø≈øa, and then when he had notice that the Imperiali≈øts intended again to be≈øiege Buda, which he by rea≈øon of the ≈øaid lo≈øs was not in a capacity to relieve, as al≈øo at the ≈øame time news came of a great ≈ølaughter of the Turks before the City of Agria, the which City had the Chri≈øtians a≈ø≈øaulted in any con≈øiderable number, the con≈øternation was ≈øo great, that they might ea≈øily have
≈øurpri≈øed it, yet as it happened they took a hundred pri≈øoners and five hundred hor≈øes, the free Haducks al≈øo entring the Turks Territories, did great hurt by burning their Villages and carrying away a great number of Inhabitants.

Buda now had not e≈øcaped falling into the hands of the Chri≈øtians had not Ibraim Ba≈ø≈øa received an unexpected ≈øupply, which increa≈øed his Army to the number of one hundred and thirty thou≈øand, with which upon his approach the Chri≈øtians too weak to encounter him were obliged to rai≈øe their ≈øiege, yet ≈øo much was the Ba≈ø≈øa out of love with war, that having relieved the City, he by the command of Mahomet the Turki≈øh Emperor, laboured to procure a peace with Rodolph the German Emperor, in order to which ≈øeveral great Commanders on either ≈øide met, but the Turks proud demands ≈øeem'd ≈øo unrea≈øonable to the Chri≈øtian Commi≈ø≈øioners, that they rejected them with di≈ødain, and ≈øo all hopes of peace vani≈øhing, the Vayvod of Valachia invaded Tran≈øylvania, now wholly devoted to Mahomet, again≈øt whom Cardinal Batter prepared his Forces, being ≈øtrengthened over and above with thirty thou≈øand Turks and Tartars, ≈øent by Ibraim yet in a mortal battle he was overthrown by the Vayvod, and the Cardinal in endeavouring to e≈øcape was ≈ølain, and his head ≈øent to the Emperour, after which mo≈øt of the Cities of Tran≈øylvania revolted from the Turki≈øh obedience. The news of which greatly troubled Sigi≈ømund the late Prince, who re≈øided in Polonia, but more Mahomet the Turki≈øh Emperor, imbroiled in new troubles by the revolt of Chu≈øahin or Ca≈ø≈øan the great Ba≈ø≈øa of Carra
‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ , who had cau≈øed mo≈øt of the Countries in the letter A≈øia, to ca≈øt off the Turki≈øh yoke, but Mahomet ≈øending great Forces again≈øt him under Mahomet
Ba≈ø≈øa, who after ≈øeveral conflicts ≈øpoiling the po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øions of the Rebells in Arms, he ≈øo dealt with the chief of them, that by bribes and large promi≈øes, he prevailed with them to leave their ringleader, he was taken and brought in chains to Con≈øtantinople, where with mo≈øt exqui≈øite torments, he was put to death. The end of which dangerous Rebellion, gave the Ottoman Emperor more lea≈øure to pro≈øecute his wars in Hungary, to oppo≈øe who≈øe Forces, the Chri≈øtians were not wanting, for in an other Diet a≈ø≈øembled, new ≈øupplies were granted by the Electoral Princes for the carrying on the war, toward which the Bi≈øhop of Rome contributed very largely, ≈øo that Anno 1600 the Chri≈øtian Army early in the Spring took the field (though to breed delay therein the Turki≈øh Ba≈ø≈øa in the name of his ma≈øter, had made many offers tending to peace) but e'r any notable action was performed, the renowned Lord Palfie, the greate≈øt Commander of that Age dyed at his Ca≈øtle of Biber≈øperg, whereupon the Lord Swartzenburg was by the Emperor appointed Governor of Strigonium in his ≈øtead, who to the great grief of the Army, ≈øoon after ≈ølain with a ≈øhot as he was reducing Papa to its obedience, it having a little before at the in≈øtigation of De la Mot, a ≈øeditious French Commander there in Garri≈øon revolted from the Emperor, and yet ≈øtood neuter, not permitting the Turks to enter, yet was it again reduced notwith≈øtanding the death of the Lord Swartzenburg and mo≈øt of the Rebels Executed, after the ≈øevere≈øt manner that could be invented.

The≈øe things pa≈ø≈øing, the troubles in Hungary daily increa≈øing, and the Turks were every where put to the wor≈øt, and among≈øt the re≈øt the Ba≈ø≈øa of Sigeth with five thou≈øand of his Turks, and his head ≈øent to the Emperor. Jula was likewi≈øe ≈øurprized,
and the Ba≈ø≈øa thereof with two Sanzacks, and Five Hundred common Souldiers ≈ølain, and now the Government of Tran≈øilvania being vacant (by the death of Cardinal Battor and the ab≈øence of the Prince) the Emperor confirmed it to the Vayvod of Valachia, who rai≈øing a great power went again≈øt the Prince who aided by the Turks, Tartars, and Polonians, was coming to try a field Battle for the recovery of his Inheritance, and in a ≈øet battle overthrew him with great ≈ølaughter of his men, him≈øelf hardly e≈øcaping, after which he ≈øeized upon the Countrey of Moldavia, cau≈øing all the inhabitants to ≈øwear Allegiance to him, when the better to incourage him to invade the Turks Dominions the Emperour not only confirmed him in that Principality al≈øo, but ≈øent him ≈øix Thou≈øand Men under the leading of D. Petzen, with a ma≈øs of mony to pay his Souldiers appointing him one of his Council, and cheif Intendant for tho≈øe Countries, but he behaving him≈øelf roughly towards the Tran≈øilvanian Nobility, they ≈øent Amba≈ø≈øadors to Ba≈øta the Emperors Lieutenant General praying, him to take then into the protection of the Emperor onely, and that they might obey no other Soveraign Prince, whereupon Ba≈øta after mature deliberation re≈øolved to grant their de≈øires, and to protect them from the fury of the Vayvod, whom he yet not able to appea≈øe by fair means he re≈øolved to compel by force of Armes to acquie≈øce with what he determined, and therefore gathering ≈øuch forces as he could with Eighteen Thou≈øand well appointed Souldiers he awaited on the Frontiers of Tran≈øilvania his coming, and near to a Village called Mivi≈ølo adventured to give him Battle, though under his ≈øtandard he had double the number, and after ≈øix hours de≈øperate fighting put him to flight, with the lo≈øs of Ten Thou≈øand of his men, taking likewi≈øe
≈øeveral Pri≈øoners, and a great ≈øpoil, yet neverthele≈øs the Vayvod bating of his proud temper by the mediation of Friends they were afterwards reconciled. Yet the Vayvod jealous of the Imperiali≈øt as being al≈øo without cau≈øe per≈øwaded thereto by the Polonians, to prevent as was ≈øugge≈øted to him his being taken Pri≈øoner, with a few of his followers fled into the fa≈øtne≈øs of the Mountains, whereupon one Simon was placed in his ≈øtead by the haughty Chancelor of Poland, which choice Ba≈øta altogether di≈øliking re≈øolved to di≈øplace the up≈øtart Vayvod, but the Tran≈øilvanians de≈øirous of freedom, and in order to recover it rai≈øing many rumours portending the mi≈øchief intended again≈øt the Imperiali≈øts, at that time hindered his violent proceedings, ≈øo that for the future the whole matter was referred to the Emperour. The Tran≈øilvanians likewi≈øe ca≈øting them≈øelves upon him, and when they perceived no remedy, de≈øired that Maximilian the Arch-Duke might take upon him the Government of that Province; but whil≈øt the≈øe affairs were in controver≈øie, the Turks with a huge Army be≈øieged Cani≈øia a ≈øtrong City of Stira, to the relief of which came the Imperial Army con≈øi≈øting of Forty Thou≈øand Hor≈øe and Foot, compo≈øed of divers Nations, under the leading of Duke Mercury General of the Emperours Forces in Hungary, to oppo≈øe which Ibrahim Ba≈ø≈øa drew out of his Trenches, thinking by their multitude to oppre≈øs the Chri≈øtians, but was therein deceived, for after a bloody and doubtful fight for the ≈øpace of eight hours victory declared her ≈øelf again≈øt him, yet not ≈øo apparently but that the next day by rea≈øon of the di≈øcord among≈øt the Chri≈øtian Captains, who at the Command of their General refu≈øed to charge the Turks in their ≈øtrengths the ≈øcale was turned, and
their Convoy of Provi≈øion upon its way to the Camp being taken by the Tartars, they were ≈øo ≈øtraightned that after having layn ≈øtill for the ≈øpace of three dayes, they ro≈øe in the night but not ≈øo ≈øecretly but that the Turks following hard after them cut off Three Thou≈øand of the rearmo≈øt, took ≈øeveral pieces of Cannon, and a great part of their Baggage, and afterwards had the City of Cani≈øae yeilded to them upon condition that the Garri≈øon ≈øhould be ≈øafely convoyed over the River Mur, with Bag and Baggage, and hightened with this ≈øucce≈øs they afterwards forraged the Countrey of Stira, for fear of whom the Inhabitants with ≈øuch of their ≈øub≈øtance, as they conveniently carry with them fled to the Mountains, whereupon the Ba≈ø≈øa ≈øent forth a Proclamation commanding them to return, and that ≈øuch as would willingly ≈øubmit them≈øelves to the Turki≈øh obedience ≈øhould be taken into ≈øafe protection, upon which Proclamation many of the half ≈øtarved people returned and ≈øubmitted them≈øelves, but the ever renowned mirrour of Vertue and Valour, the Heroick Count Serenus being the man that the Ba≈ø≈øa aimed at, as well knowing whil≈øt he went free his new Conque≈øts were ≈ølightly cemented to the re≈øt, he the better to decoy the Noble Youth into his power wrote to him as followeth.

body.head: We Ibraim Ba≈ø≈øa Chief Vizar Ba≈ø≈øa, Co≈øen to the mo≈øt Pui≈ø≈øant Sultan Mahomet, to the Count Serenus, ≈øendeth Greeting,
body.p:
WE have often heretofore written to thee, concerning the matter thou knowe≈øt of, but what the cau≈øe is we received no an≈øwer we know not; yet could I not but write unto you again, that if thou can≈øt be content to begin the matter aright, and to ≈øubmit thy ≈øelf to our protection we will be ready to receive thee: thou ≈øee≈øt
what we foretold thee is now more then fulfilled, both upon thee and thine, which thou woulde≈øt never believe; neverthele≈øs for the ≈øtaying the further effu≈øion of blood as well of thy Subjects as our, and to come to ≈øome good attonement, 'tis high time for thee to lay thine hand upon thine heart, and to con≈øider how much more it concerneth thee then us, and that the benefit thereof redoundeth more unto thine then to ours, what our affections are towards thee Hierom the Vayvod can tell thee, &c.

div.p: This Letter the Count well enough knew were but an outward ≈øhew of Friend≈øhip, and therefore he thinking it not good to tru≈øt the Infidel, ≈øo long as he had his Sword in his hand, would not ≈øo much as dain to return him an an≈øwer, whereupon he in a great rage returned to Belgrade vaunting that if Mahomet ≈øo Commanded, he would the next year lay ≈øiege to Vienna, and ≈øo much extol'd his exploits to the great Sultan, that he commanded publick Triumphs for the ≈øpace of four days in Con≈øtantinople, for joy of his good ≈øucce≈øs in Stira, and ≈øent the proud Ba≈ø≈øa a Robe of Gold, and a leaders Staff ≈øet wit Pearl and pretious Stones.

The lo≈øs of Cani≈øia ≈øore troubled the Chri≈øtian in≈øomuch that Paradi≈øer the Governour, who had ≈øo tamely yielded it into the hands of the Turks, coming to Vienna was there impri≈øoned, and many things being proved again≈øt him, his En≈øign Bearer, Lieutenant, and the Mayor of the Town, they after many ≈øtrict Examinations were at the command of the Emperour executed.

Notwith≈øtanding the death of the Ba≈ø≈øa of Carramani in manner as afore≈øaid, the Rebellion was not altogether thereby extingui≈øhed but ≈øecretly kept alive by the countenance of the Per≈øian Sophy, ≈øo
that now it again began as if revived from its Embers to break out into a flame, and in a trice ≈øwept away ≈øeveral Towns, whereupon Mahomet ≈øent to the Per≈øian to demand for the more a≈ø≈øurance of the League one of his Sons as Ho≈øtage, which was ≈øo evilly taken that the Sophy commanded the Turks Amba≈ø≈øador to be ≈ølain, and although that rigorous ≈øentence was remitted, yet by the ≈øecond Commandment of the Sophy he was ba≈øtinadoed, and in de≈øpite of him that ≈øent him returned with great di≈øgrace, the which though it highly offended Mahomet, yet he finding him≈øelf at that time not in a condition to revenge it, only blu≈øtered a little and to prevent the wor≈øt, put ≈øtrong Garri≈øons into his Frontire Towns.

Anno 1601, The Chri≈øtian Confederates brought a ≈øtrong Army into the Field, for fear of which the Turki≈øh General propo≈øed many ofters of Peace, but ere any was concluded, the ≈øaid General Ibraim Ba≈ø≈øa died, when as the Chri≈øtians not to omit any opportunity took divers ≈øtrong places, and among≈øt the re≈øt after a terrible battery, and the lo≈øs of Eight Thou≈øand men Alba Regalis, one of the chiefe≈øt and ≈øtronge≈øt Cities of Hungary, into which the furious Souldiers entering through Streets of fire and over heaps of the ≈ølain, put all they met to the Sword, few or none except the Ba≈ø≈øa being taken to mercy, inriched them≈øelves with a great ≈øpoil, e≈øpecially the Walloons, who ≈øpared not to rifle the Tombs of the Hungarian Kings, which barbarity the Turks them≈øelves had ab≈øtained from. Yet hardly was the ≈øpoil taken but news came that A≈ø≈øan Ba≈ø≈øa made General in the ≈øtead of Ibraim, was coming with a great Army to relieve it, whereupon Duke Mercury drew out his Forces and in a mortal Battle ≈ølew the Ba≈ø≈øa, and mo≈øt of his men, taking his
rich Camp, and a great number of Pri≈øoners, and among≈øt the re≈øt Fifty of the Rebels that fled from Papa, who yet at the in≈øtance of the ≈øaid Duke were pardoned.

The Chri≈øtians hightened with this ≈øucce≈øs, were now re≈øolved to attempt the recovery of Cani≈øia from before which (after they had a long time be≈øieged it, and layed open with their furious battery ≈øeveral breaches, killing in the ≈øeveral a≈ø≈øaults a number of Turks) they were by the un≈øea≈øonablene≈øs of the weather obliged to depart, to the great grief of the Commanders, though joy of the Souldiers, who through the exce≈ø≈øive Cold that then happened were become un≈øerviceable, many of them being frozen to Death in the Trenches. The Turks now greatly di≈øinaid and almo≈øt driven out of Hungary, unhappy chance turned the Chri≈øtians Swords, upon them≈øelves for although Michael the Vayvod of Valachia was reconciled to the Emperour, yet the Tran≈øilvanians de≈øirous to be Governed by Sigi≈ømund their natural Prince, ca≈øt Ba≈øta the Emperours Leiutenant, and by him appointed Governour of that Province, into Irons; and immediately ≈øubmitted them≈øelves to Sigi≈ømund, and likewi≈øe impri≈øoned ≈øeveral of the Nobility, whom they ≈øu≈øpected to favour the Emperour, returning again to the Turki≈øh obedience, and this by the contrivance of the Chancelor of Polonia. Yet at the mediation of Friends Ba≈øta was ≈øet at Liberty; who thoroughly inraged at the di≈øgrace done to him, and the indignity offered thereby to the Emperour his Ma≈øter, rai≈øed an Army and joying with Michael the Vayvod, invaded Tran≈øilvania, and in a dreadful Battle overthrew Prince Sigi≈ømund with great ≈ølaughter of his men, upon which Claudiopolis and divers other Cities
of Tran≈øylvania returned to the Emperours obedience.

After this great victory the Vayvod ≈øtill envying at the ≈øucce≈øs of the Imperiali≈øts, and ≈øecretly grudging again≈øt Ba≈øta, by Letters held ≈øecret corre≈øpondency with the Ba≈ø≈øa of Teme≈øwar, intending in con≈øideration of Valachia, Moldavia, and Tran≈øilvania, to become the Turks Tributary, and by the a≈ø≈øi≈øtance of the Ba≈ø≈øa's drive out the Imperiali≈øts, to prevent which it was agreed that he ≈øhould be ≈øent Pri≈øoner to Vienna. In order to which a Walloon Captain was ≈øent into his Tent with ≈øixty followers, but he making re≈ø≈øi≈øtance was by the ≈øaid Captain ≈ølain, which cau≈øed a great uproar among≈øt his Souldiers, but when they under≈øtood the cau≈øe by Letters produced under his own hand, their anger was allayed, them≈øelves prote≈øting that had they known ≈øo much they would long before di≈øpatched him. After the Death of the Vayvod the Tran≈øilvanians wholly ≈øubmitted to them≈øelves to Ba≈øta. Yet continued not long in that obedience ere ≈øtirred up by ≈øome re≈øtle≈øs ≈øpirits they again Revolted and Proclaimed Sigi≈ømund, denying obedience to any other; at which ≈øuddain mutation of this un≈øtable people Ba≈øta not a little troubled to prevent his being again impri≈øoned, (as he had been formerly by them, withdrew him≈øelf with his Followers, into a ≈øtrong Town on the Frontiers, from whence he by Letters advertized the Emperour of what had happened, and reque≈øted him to ≈øend him ≈øpeedy Aid, whereby he might be able to reduce them to their former obedience.

During the≈øe troubles in Tran≈øylvania, the Turks taking the advantage did mi≈øchief in Hungary, yet were often met with by the Imperiali≈øts, and among≈øt the re≈øt the Ba≈ø≈øa of Agria, as he was going to be≈øiege Toccaie with ten thou≈øand Turks, who being encountered by Ferrant Gonzaga the Emperors Lieutenant was overthrown, with the ≈ølaughter of almo≈øt all his followers; nor was Mahomet the Emperor le≈øs perplexed with the Carramanian and Natolian Rebels, who now getting to a great head under the leading of one Scrivano, had given ≈øeveral overthrows to his Ba≈ø≈øas ≈øent again≈øt them, and ≈øpread their borders wide, drawing into their Confederacy all A≈øia the Le≈ø≈øer, and a part of the Greater, and at the ≈øame time the Janizaries were in an uproar in Con≈øtantinople, threatning the Emperor and charging him with Cowardi≈øe, and the neglect of his affairs, to appea≈øe whom Cicala Ba≈ø≈øa was obliged to be≈øtow among≈øt them a great ≈øum of money, and the Mu≈øti or chief Mahometan Prie≈øt declaring that all the≈øe di≈øorders happened, for that Mahomet their Prophet was offended at the exce≈øs of wine that was drunk in the City; whereupon Proclamation was made that upon pain of death all tho≈øe that had any wine in their hou≈øes, the Amba≈ø≈øadors of the Chri≈øtian Princes excepted, ≈øhould immediately bring it forth and ≈øtave it; whereupon ≈øuch abundance was ≈øpilt, that boats in the high ≈øtreets might have ≈øwam in wine of all ≈øorts.

By this time Ba≈øta having received Forces from the Emperor, had ≈øo ≈øtraitned the Tran≈øylvanians, that Sigi≈ømund ≈øent to offer him all the Towns that were in his po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion, at the time of his being expelled Tran≈øylvania, of which offer Zachel Moy≈øes the Princes Lieutenant, having notice, re≈øolved not to ≈øuffer any agreement upon ≈øuch conditions, and
therefore with the Forces under his Command compo≈øed of Turks, Tartars, and Tran≈øylvanians, he ha≈øted to oppre≈øs Ba≈øta in his Camp, but finding him as ready as him≈øelf, a dreadful battle was fought between them, wherein Ba≈øta with his Germans prevailed, making a great ≈ølaughter of the enemy; To excu≈øe which ra≈øh action Sigi≈ømund ≈øent ≈øeveral of his Nobility to the Imperial Camp, offering to perform what ever he had promi≈øed, and to go in per≈øon to the Emperor, which once put in practi≈øe all the Countrey returned again to the Emperors obedience, nor was Valachia at this time le≈øs troubled about Election of a Vayvod, that Province being divided into two Factions, the one was for choo≈øing Radol a Noble man, affecting the Emperors intere≈øt, and the other for Electing Jeremias, who had promi≈øed to hold his Province Tributary of the Turk; whereupon many Battles were fought with various ≈øucce≈øs, but in the end Rodolph a≈ø≈øi≈øted by the Emperors Forces overthrew his competitor, and obtained a great Victory; in which battle two of the Turki≈øh Ba≈ø≈øas were ≈ølain, with all their followers, and ≈øoon after, having overthrown a great power of the Tartars, he recovered the Principality; nor was Hungary free from the Turki≈øh outrages, who bearing them≈øelves upon their ≈ømall ≈øucce≈øs, attempted to ≈øurprize Alba Regalis, but were by the Chri≈øtians overthrown with great ≈ølaughter, and ≈øoon after two hundred of their Waggons laden with provi≈øion and Amunition, was taken by Count Serinus, on its way to Cani≈øia, and about the ≈øame time took Ali Ba≈ø≈øa Governour of Pe≈øth pri≈øoner, and with him ≈øeventy thou≈øand Hungarian Ducates, which Ba≈ø≈øa for his ran≈øom over and above offered 300000 Sultanies.

Mahomet not a little troubled with the continual news of his Lo≈ø≈øes in Hungary, and re≈øolving to revenge him≈øelf on the Chri≈øtians ≈øent Ha≈ø≈øau Ba≈ø≈øa, with an Army of one hundred and fifty thou≈øand Turks and Tartars, who upon their arrival, pa≈ø≈øing the Danubius, laid ≈øiege to Alba-Regalis, of which the Count Y≈øolon was Governour, when rai≈øing three Batteries, they ince≈ø≈øantly thundered again≈øt the wall and Bulwarks, and was by the Defendants an≈øwered in the ≈øame Language, and by frequent Sallies, cut off a number of the enemies, but having all their walls on the We≈øt ≈øide beaten down, and mo≈øt of the Souldiers either killed or di≈øabled, the Count him≈øelf wounded in the thigh, their powder being almo≈øt ≈øpent, and no hopes of relief, they capitulated to deliver the Town upon condition that they ≈øhould depart thence with all their Goods and be conducted in ≈øafety to the neighbouring Garri≈øon, which was ≈øworn to by all the Turki≈øh Commanders; but having once entred the City, they not only ≈øpoil and plunder it, but de≈øtroyed and put to the ≈øword all the Souldiers and Citizens, ≈øparing none alive but the Count him≈øelf, and ≈øome few Captains, whom they ≈øent in Chains to Con≈øtantinople, in≈øomuch that the ≈øtreets flowed with the blood of three thou≈øand Chri≈øtians, in revenge of this lo≈øs, the Lord Ru≈øsworm with thirty thou≈øand men laid ≈øiege to the ≈øtrong City of Buda, and took the ba≈øe Town, where he got ≈øtore of Riches, and afterwards laid hard ≈øiege to the upper City, but finding it a work of great difficulty, he re≈øolved to turn his Forces upon Pesth a ≈øtrong Garri≈øon lying on the other ≈øide the River, from whence the Turks with their great Ordnance annoyed his Army before Buda, which place he without much difficulty won, and then again returned
to the ≈øiege of the upper City of Buda, but having lo≈øt eight thou≈øand of his men, and having notice that the Tartars were at hand with a great Army, re≈øolving to relieve it, he rai≈øed his ≈øiege, having fir≈øt repul≈øed the Vizar Ba≈ø≈øa before Pe≈øth, with the lo≈øs of half his Forces.

Scrivano having rent the Turks Dominions in A≈øia, by taking from them their principal Cities, fell ≈øick, of which ≈øickne≈øs he dyed, to the great grief of the Rebels, who neverthele≈øs cho≈øe his younger brother to lead them, who ≈øoon after in a great battle overthrew the Turki≈øh Army, that was ≈øent again≈øt him, under the leading of Ha≈ø≈øau Ba≈ø≈øa, and ≈ølew the Ba≈ø≈øa him≈øelf, together with almo≈øt all his followers; whereupon Mahomet doubting his Empire in A≈øia, was obliged to withdraw his Forces out of Hungary, yet incited the Tartars by frequent inroads to bu≈øie the Imperiali≈øts, till he could be at lei≈øure to return his Captains with a greater power, who according to their wonted mi≈øchievous natures committed ≈øundry outrage, burning and de≈øtroying all in their way, but in the end were mo≈øt of them cut off by the Chri≈øtians again≈øt who≈øe joynt Forces, they were no wayes able to ≈øtand, as being rather inured to ≈øpoil than fight.

Anno 1603 The Turks in the ≈øeveral Garri≈øons roaming abroad in the depth of winter, when Danubius it ≈øelf was frozen over, committed many outrages in Hungaria, but in their return, being met by Colonel Coblonitz, a great number of them were cut in pieces, and all the booty recovered, ≈øo that for want of Victuals Buda was greatly di≈øtre≈ø≈øed, but ≈øee again the change of fortune, for the Turks coming out of Buda upon the Frozen River, braving the Garri≈øon of Pe≈øth, the Souldiers ≈øallyed out upon them, but being overpowred were two hundred of
them ≈ølain, yet this lo≈øs was ≈øhortly revenged by the Garri≈øon Souldiers, who ≈øurprizing ≈øeveral of the Turki≈øh Nobility, ≈øporting with their wives in the hot Baths not far from Buda, put all the men to the ≈øword, and ≈øuffered the women to e≈øcape naked into the City, to who≈øe flight, fear added wings, and ≈øo with the ≈øpoil of their rich garments returned in Triumph, but want of Victuals increa≈øing, they were obliged to feed upon all manner of unclean things, when at the ≈øame time their neighbours of Buda having received a great Convoy of Victuals, derided them, and ≈øent three or four thundering Peals of Cannon over the river again≈øt the Town, but their mirth was ≈øoon ≈øpoiled, for by the carele≈øsne≈øs of the Engenier ≈øeveral barrels of Povvder taking fire not only killed a great number of them, but likevvi≈øe overthrevv four yards of their Wall, and thus the Winter pa≈ø≈øed over vvith many skirmi≈øhes, and the taking of ≈øeveral places in Hungary on either ≈øide; When early in the Spring the nevv Vayvod of Valachia over run the rich Countrey of Sili≈øtria, reducing the greate≈øt part of it to his obedience, and ≈øoon after Colloninitz gave the Turks another great overthrow, and took a great booty on its way to Cani≈øia, and afterwards laid ≈øiege to Baboz, but finding it ≈øtrongly Garri≈øoned, and furni≈øhed for a long ≈øiege, he withdrew from before it, yet he ≈øurprized many of the Turks and intercepted ≈øeveral Waggons laden with provi≈øion, about which time news came that the Janizaries were up in Arms at Con≈øtantinople, as likewi≈øe Sphai, and that they committed ≈øeveral outrages on the Ba≈ø≈øas, and ≈øpared not to abu≈øe their ma≈øter, telling him they would (≈øeeing he neglected to) reform his Government, ≈øvvearing that unle≈øs he vvould deliver into their povver the
Capi Aga, and ≈øuch others as they ≈øhould require, they would turn all into confu≈øion, which threats ≈øo ≈øcared the Pu≈øillanimous Tyrant that he was contented to yield to their demands, who having got tho≈øe Favorites they mo≈øt inveighed again≈øt, they with all de≈øpight put them to death; whereupon the Tyrant not to be outdone in cruelty, cau≈øed ≈øeveral of the Ba≈ø≈øa's and chief men of his Court, whom he knew the Souldiers affected, to be ≈ølain, which cau≈øed ≈øuch a hatred again≈øt him, that many of his great Ba≈ø≈øa's con≈øpired to depo≈øe him, and ≈øet up his ≈øon Mahomet in his ≈øtead, which they were the more animated to put in practice, for that he had at the ≈øame time made a di≈øhonourable peace with the A≈øian Rebels, giving mo≈øt of their ring-leaders great Commands, whil≈øt tho≈øe that had faithfully ≈øerved him were rejected, of which intent of his men of war, the Tyrant having notice, cau≈øed his ≈øon, and ≈øo many as he could under≈øtand were any wayes concerned therein to be put to death.

The≈øe things happening in the foregoing year, the year following the Tartars in great numbers intending to invade Hungary, were denyed pa≈ø≈øage by the Polonians, whereupon they re≈øolved to make their way through Valachia, with whom the Vayvod had many hard conflicts, killing at one time three thou≈øand of them, but their number being great, he was forced at length to let them pa≈øs; who upon their arrival in Hungary and Stira, made great ≈øpoil e'r Collonitz could take the field, who at length joyning with Count Serinus, gave them a fatal overthrow, and recovered about five thou≈øand Chri≈øtian Captives; yet tho≈øe that e≈øcaped from the battle roving about did great harm, till ≈øuch time as they were met with by the Lord Nada≈øti and his Ha≈ø≈øars, who with a furious charge over≈øet their battle, and
brought them to final de≈øtruction, when ≈øoon after Collonitz returning fell upon Two Thou≈øand Turks all or mo≈øt of which he ≈ølew, and then pa≈ø≈øing on be≈øieged the Ca≈øtle of Loqua which in a ≈øhort time he took, but by neglect of the Soldiers injoyed not long, for the Palizadoes being fired ≈øet fire to the Ca≈øtle and laid it wa≈øt. After which he marched towards the Ca≈øtle of Boulouvenar, upon who≈øe approach the Garri≈øon fled, but in their flight being met were overthrown with great ≈ølaughter, and ≈øuch as were taken Pri≈øoners together with all their ≈øub≈øtance brought back to the Ca≈øtle, into which the Collonel having put Four Hundred Haducks, and Two Hundred Hu≈ø≈øars, returned to Comara, where with a great Booty he arrived in ≈øafety.

Turning a little from the troubles of Hungary, a Countrey ≈øubject to the continual Inroads of the Turks, I ≈øhall return to Tran≈øilvania, which by this time was for the mo≈øt part reduced to the Emperours obedience. For Moy≈øes the Rebel after his being overthrown by Ba≈øta, doubting his ≈øafety in the Ca≈øtle of Solemo≈øe, delivered it to the Turks and fled to Teme≈øwar, a City in their po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of which Ba≈øta the Emperours Leiutenant having notice re≈øolved to recover the Ca≈øtle, which the Turks ≈øuppo≈øed impregnable by rea≈øon of its ≈øcituation, as being founded upon a ≈øteep and hard Rock, but the Germans having by ≈øtrength of Arms drawn their Cannon to the top of a little Hill, not far di≈øtant from it, after a terrible battery made had it delivered to them, the Turks well perceiving they were no longer able to keep it.

This ≈øtrong place thus gained many of le≈øs account that held out again≈øt Ba≈øta ≈øurrendered, whereupon a≈ø≈øembling the principal men of Tran≈øilvania,
he in a ≈øhort Oration admoni≈øhed them to be ≈øtedfa≈øt to the intere≈øt of the Emperour, and not to have any regard to the faithle≈øs and wavering Turks, &c. To which they replyed, That they were willing to obey the Emperour in all things, but that their people in continual Wars being wa≈øted, they de≈øired him to con≈øider how little able they were to keep an Army in the Field, without which the Countrey could not be defended; but if the Emperour would protect them, and ≈øecure them with a ≈øtanding Army, they would yearly pay towards the defraying of the charges Fifteen Thou≈øand Hungarian Ducats, and furni≈øh them with all things nece≈ø≈øary. It being a thing more Honourable and Profitable for a Prince moderately to u≈øe his Subjects, then for covetou≈øne≈øs to devour them in one day, and in their lo≈øs to lo≈øe him≈øelf for ever. This their offer was by Ba≈øta accepted, and the minds of the people by many per≈øwa≈øive arguments kept in their dutiful Allegiance to the Emperour. But whil≈øt peace was expected on all ≈øides Moy≈øes the Rebel, with a great power of Turks and Tartars entered Tran≈øilvania, at ≈øuch time as Ba≈øta was ab≈øent dreaming of no ≈øuch matter, and ≈øeizing upon Wi≈øceborongh, ≈øome other places of ≈ømall importance, his name began to ≈øpread wide. In≈øomuch that Mahomet the Sultan under≈øtanding what he had done, promi≈øed to ≈øend him more Aid, and to make him his Leiutenant if he pro≈øpered in his Wars, which puffed up the Rebel to that height that hearing of Ba≈øta being with ≈ømall Forces in the Town of Somo≈øinar, he re≈øolved to march thither and be≈øiege him, but that experienced Captain knowing how much it impaired the credit of a General, to be inclo≈øed within Walls, upon notice of his approach, after he had put that place in a po≈øture of
defence departed thence, and after having received a ≈øupply of eight Thou≈øand men from the Vayvod of Valachia, he went to oppo≈øe the Torrent, but ere he could prevent it the City of Claudinople fell into the Rebels hands, who u≈øed the Citizens with all manner of cruelties. Yet at length meeting with them before he was aware, fell into their danger, not expecting them to be above half the number, he found them ≈øo that he not exceeding Nine Thou≈øand, and the Rebels not le≈øs then Thirty Thou≈øand, when he had done all that became a valiant Souldier retired in good order, leaving his Baggage, Tents, and Artilery with the dead Bodies of One Thou≈øand of his men as prey to the Conquerours; but they more greedy of the ≈øpoil then to pur≈øue him, fell to plundering the Tents with ≈øuch eagerne≈øs, that he thereof advertized, and turning his recollected Forces ≈øuddainly upon them, who dreamed of nothing le≈øs entered among≈øt them unarmed as they were, every one with his hands full of ≈øpoiles, made ≈øuch a ≈ølaughter that ≈øcarcely a third part of them e≈øcaped, ≈øo that by their carele≈øsne≈øs within le≈øs then four hours, the vanqui≈øhers were vanqui≈øhed and among≈øt the ≈ølain fell Moy≈øes him≈øelf, who≈øe head was after fixed upon a Launce and ≈øet up upon the Walls of Carol≈øtadt.

This Rebellion ≈øuppre≈ø≈øed another Rebel aided by the Turks Tartars and Co≈ø≈øacks to the number of Six Thou≈øand, made head about Lippa, but Three Thou≈øand Haducks being ≈øent out again≈øt him, his Forces were defeated and him≈øelf, for the ≈øafety of his own Life glad to fly, after which good ≈øucce≈øs One Hundred of the Rebels In≈øignes, and the Hor≈øe on which Moy≈øes fought, traped richly with Gold and Pretious Stones were as a grateful pre≈øent ≈øent to the Emperour, and afterward the Army under
the Command of Ba≈øta, being increa≈øed to Twenty Thou≈øand, he with Five and Twenty pieces of Cannon marched to be≈øiege Teme≈øwar, but ere he long had lain before it, by his Souldiers eating of green Fruit, the Bloody Flux raged ≈øo in his Camp, that death triumphing every where over his men he was forced to depart.

Spring being come the Chri≈øtian Army in Hungaria being Five and Thirty Thou≈øand ≈øtrong took the Field, under the Command of the Lord Ru≈øworm, who having carefully provided for the ≈øeveral Garri≈øons incamped near to Pe≈øth at what time an Army of One Hundred Thou≈øand Turks ≈øhewed it ≈øelf on the other ≈øide the Danubius, for fear of which ≈øeveral of the Garri≈øon Souldiers of Pe≈øth fled over to Buda, and there were highly entertained by the Ba≈ø≈øa, who thought to u≈øe them as decoys to train their fellows over, but this project failed though at that time their wants were great, though not long, for in ≈øpight of the Turks endeavours to hinder them, two Convoys of Provi≈øion and other nece≈ø≈øaries, the one by Water, and the other by Land were brought thither, at what time a Turki≈øh Captain upon ≈øome di≈øplea≈øure flying from Alba Regalis to Rab, informed the Governour that if he would march thither he would ≈øhew him an ea≈øie way to ≈øurprize the Suburbs if not the City it ≈øelf, whereupon the Chri≈øtian Souldiers giving credit to the Infidel by his direction ≈øucceeded in taking the Suburb as they wi≈øhed, and in it a great Booty, but de≈øpairing in any further advantage returned with great joy to Rab.

The Rebels in A≈øia being again in Arms, Mahomet finding him≈øelf not ≈øtrong enough to ≈øuppre≈øs them by Force, laboured by his Amba≈ø≈øadors to reconcile
them offering ≈øuch advantagious terms of peace as ≈øhould to all men ≈øeem rea≈øonable, but they not caring to tru≈øt the Tyrant rejected his offers and would have no peace, whereupon what the Infidels refu≈øed he thought fit to offer to the Chri≈øtians, but on this ≈øide he demands ≈øo unrea≈øonable (viz. that in con≈øideration of his delivering up Agria and Cani≈øia he might have Tran≈øilvania, Strigonium and Pe≈øth) that the Emperour would not accord to any peace upon ≈øuch terms, ≈øo that the treaty broke off, upon which Ho≈øtilities that for a while cea≈øed began afre≈øh, ≈øo that Collonitz with Six Thou≈øand Imperiali≈øts falling upon the Rear of the Turks Army, cut off ≈øeven Hundred men, taking a great ≈øpoil and many Pri≈øoners, among≈øt whom was Saxur Beg, a man of great repute among≈øt the Turks, who upon Examination confe≈ø≈øed the de≈øign Ha≈ø≈øan Ba≈ø≈øa had to be≈øiege Strigonium, and Pe≈øth, and the number of Turks and Tartars that were daily expected to joyn him, of which General Ru≈øworm being informed, as al≈øo of the ≈øtate of the Turks Army, and al≈øo that upon ≈øome di≈øcontent the Tartars were returned into their own Countrey, to the great weakening of the Ba≈ø≈øa's Forces, wherefore to prevent their putting a Convoy into Buda, he cau≈øed ≈øeveral Forts to be built, and permitting the Turks to pa≈øs ever the Danubius by a Bridge trained them into an Ambu≈øh layed in the Flags and O≈øiers for that purpo≈øe, ≈øo that with little lo≈øs on the part of the Chri≈øtians, 10000 Turks were ≈ølain, drowned in the River, and taken Pri≈øoners; ≈øo that a great booty con≈øi≈øting of eighteen En≈øigns, two Cornets, four Bra≈øs peices, much rich Armour, and many Waggons loaden with Provi≈øion fell into the hands of the Chri≈øtians, whereby the
Turks were ≈øo much di≈øcouraged that they for a long while attempted nothing.

Affairs ≈øtanding thus in Hungary, A≈øia was ≈øtill in a flame, e≈øpecially upon the revolt of one of Mahomets great Ba≈ø≈øa's, whom he had de≈øpightfully depo≈øed from being General, of which confu≈øion the Per≈øian King taking the advantage, layed ≈øiege to Tauris a ≈øtrong City, taken by Amurath from his Father, as is before-mentioned, the which by the Aid of ≈øeveral Chri≈øtians, after a terrible battery made again≈øt it he took, ≈øo that the Turk on every ≈øide be≈øet, was greatly perplexed in mind not knowing which way to turn him≈øelf, nor fared he better by Sea for the A≈øian Rebels, under pretence of a reconciliation and tran≈øporting them≈øelves into Europe to ≈øerve him in Hungaria, ≈øeized upon many of his Gallies ≈øent to Tran≈øport them, as al≈øo the great Duke of Florence's Admiral meeting with Amurat Rais an old Pirate and Mahomets Admiral overthrew his ≈øquadron of Gallies, taking ≈øome and ≈øinking others, ≈øo that few e≈øcaped: and his great Army in Hungary after the lo≈øs of Thirty Thou≈øand Men in divers conflicts with the Chri≈øtian, atchieving nothing worth mention, except putting a Convoy of Victuals into Buda, returned to Belgrade under the covert of darkne≈øs, in manner of a fearful flight which was no ≈øooner perceived by the Lord Ru≈øworm who had often in vain urged the Ba≈ø≈øa to fight, but he ≈øent his Light Hor≈øemen to pur≈øue them who cutting off the Rearmo≈øt for many Miles, returned with a con≈øiderable booty, after which he layed ≈øiege to Hatvan, and had it (after ≈øeveral fierce a≈ø≈øaults delivered into his po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion, the Garri≈øon and Citizens, as it was agreed on marching out were conducted by certain Troops of Hu≈ø≈øars to Solvock, when having put a ≈øtrong Garri≈øon into it,
and relieved ≈øuch other places as he thought convenient, and now the depth of Winter coming on he broke up his Army, ≈øending as a certain token of ≈øeveral ≈øucce≈øsful exploits ≈øixty four of the Turks En≈øigns, to the Arch Duke Matthias, ≈øo that till the next Spring nothing of moment happened.

No ≈øooner was the frozen Earth freed from the cold embraces of Winter, but new ≈øtirs began in Tran≈øilvania as likewi≈øe in Moldavia, where the Tartars in great number de≈øtroying the Countrey were overthrown, and almo≈øt all of them ≈ølain; at what time Zellali the chief of the A≈øian Rebels whom Mahomet by great rewards had allured to his intere≈øt, entered the Kingdom of Bo≈øna with a great power of his followers, where having trained Zeffer Ba≈ø≈øa the Governour thereof into his danger, he ≈øet upon him and ≈ølew mo≈øt of his men, and ≈øeized upon the Kingdom, upon notice of which Mahomet in a great rage ≈øent his Letters to him, commanding him forthwith to repair to Con≈øtantinople, but he not thinking it convenient to tru≈øt the Tyrant with his head, he returned for an≈øwer that he was already po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed of the Kingdom promi≈øed him for his ≈øervice, and that he as a Loyal Subject would keep it to his behoof, with which an≈øwer Mahomet was forced to content him≈øelf, as fearing that if he ≈øhould go about to expul≈øe him by force he would revolt to the Chri≈øtian Emperour, and ≈øo prove a more dangerous Enemy to him in Europe then he had done in A≈øia. Wherefore to prevent the wor≈øt he re≈øolved if he could obtain ≈øuch conditions as might ≈øute with his greatne≈øs to have Peace with the Emperour, in order to which Commi≈ø≈øioners met at Buda, and many Pre≈øents were given and received on either ≈øide, the Turks expre≈ø≈øing great joy for the hopes they conceived, that at length they ≈øhould re≈øt from
the toils of War but after many propo≈øals on either ≈øide, the demands of the Turki≈øh Sultan was ≈øo unrea≈øonable that nothing was concluded, ≈øo that after a ≈øhort truce Ho≈øtilities began afre≈øh, when as the Turks ≈øeeking to wa≈øt Valachia were with great ≈ølaughter by the Vayvod overthrown, at what time the Lord Nada≈øti the Valiant and Renowned Captain of the Chri≈øtians died, to the grief of all the Confederate Princes there not being a man left who≈øe Council, and Conduct in Martial affaires equalled his, but this grief was ≈øomewhat alayed upon certain News that Mahomet the great Sultan was likewi≈øe departed this Life, dying about the latter end of January, Anno 1604. When he had lived 44 years, and thereof Reigned 8, being altogether pu≈øillanimous and given up to plea≈øure, and lyes buried in a Chappel of white Marble at Con≈øtantinople, near to the Church of St. Sophia; in who≈øe ≈øtead Achm ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢
his Third Son was ≈øaluted by rea≈øon of the death of his two Elder Brethren, one of which was ≈øtrangled by the Commandment of his unnatural Father and the other very young died a natural death.

div.head: CHAP. XVIII. The Life of Achmat the Eighth Emperour of the Turks, and fir≈øt of that Name.
div.p:
UPon the death of Mahomet the Third his Son Achmat then but fifteen years of Age, was by the great Ba≈ø≈øa's and men of War ≈øaluted Emperor, having purcha≈øed the good will of the latter at two Millions and a half of A≈øpers; upon which after he was ≈øolemnly Crowned, he ≈øent Amba≈ø≈øadors to the King of Per≈øia, as he likewi≈øe did to the Emperor, but according to the proud humour of his Predece≈ø≈øors his demands were ≈øo unrea≈øonable, that they would not be accorded to, neither in Europe nor A≈øia, whereupon the Turks ere the Treaty was ended with the Emperour, under pretence of Friend≈øhip indeavoured to ≈øurprize Pe≈øth, but by the vigilancy of the Garri≈øon Souldiers were put by their purpo≈øe, which Treacherous dealing made manife≈øt the Treaty was utterly broken off, whereupon great preparations were made for War on either ≈øide, during which time the Per≈øian King was not idle, pro≈øecuting his Wars had recovered almo≈øt all that the Turks had taken from his Predece≈ø≈øors. Yet the Turks le≈ø≈øened his victory, and the more to amu≈øe the Chri≈øtians ≈øpread a fal≈øe report, that near unto Babylon his Army was overthrown, and him≈øelf taken Pri≈øoner, not forgeting to magnifie the Forces of their Emperour, who indeed for his years was very active in the affairs of
Government though cruel withal towards his own Subjects, and farther they gave it out that at once he intended to invade with pui≈ø≈øant Armies, both Hungary and Per≈øia; purpo≈øing to annex them to the Ottoman Empire: but the≈øe great words (though in truth the Chri≈øtians were more negligent in their preparations then the occa≈øion required) proved but Air.

But leaving the Turks awhile I ≈øhall ≈øurvey the mi≈øeries of the once fertile Countrey of Tran≈øylvania, which now through civil di≈øcord among≈øt them≈øelves, and Rebellion again≈øt the Emperour was ≈øo ≈øpoiled, that Famine coming fa≈øt on them for want of the Earths due increa≈øe, it by long continuance reduced them to that extremity that the Pea≈øants and poorer ≈øort of people, having eaten up for dainties all the Dogs, Cats, Mice, Rats, and live Hor≈øes, fell to eating ≈øuch ≈øtarved Bea≈øts as through want they found to have peri≈øhed in the Woods and Fields, and at length when nothing was left they fed upon human fle≈øh, men eating men, and Women their Children; yea Thieves and Malefactors hauged for their Villanies, were by the mi≈øerable people cut down and eaten, to remedy which the Emperour cau≈øed to be a≈ø≈øembled the States of the Province, wherein it was accorded that all Ho≈øtilities ≈øet apart, the Gentlemen of Tran≈øilvania having by their Rebellion forfeited their Lives and Lands ≈øhould be pardoned as to Life, with three fourth parts of their Lands re≈øerved unto them, and that for ready money they might of the Emperour redeem the fourth part, but concerning the moveables of ≈øuch as were dead in the time of trouble, and already confi≈øcated to the Emperour, they ≈øhould ≈øo remain, and that they ≈øhould pay their tenths of their Wines and Fruits to the
Emperour, and that no other then the Romi≈øh Religion ≈øhould be exerci≈øed in that Province, and that Clau≈øenburg and Cron≈øtad ≈øhould within three weeks after pay the one Twenty Thou≈øand Dollars, and the other Eight Thou≈øand, and that the Governours of tho≈øe Towns ≈øhould put their Keys into the hands of the Emperours Leiutenant. And la≈øtly, That the Gentlemen who would not be accounted in the number of the Rebels, ≈øhould for the ≈øafety of their per≈øons take Letters of Pardon from the ≈øaid Lieutenant. This pacification gave ≈øom ‚Ä¢ little hopes to the di≈øtre≈ø≈øed Tran≈øylvanians, but I la≈øted not long, for the Nobility weary of the German yoke ≈øoon revolted from the Emperours o ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ence, and again took up Arms, which plunged them into their former mi≈øeries; wherein for a while I mu≈øt leave them and return again to the Turki≈øh affaires.

The ≈øeveral Ho≈øtilities having bani≈øhed all hopes of Peace, ≈øeveral skirmi≈øhes pa≈ø≈øed between the Chri≈øtians and Turks, in which the latter were for the mo≈øt part put to the wor≈øt, and had been more di≈øtre≈ø≈øed had not the Imperial Souldiers mutined, and for want of pay ≈øpoiled the Countrey of Au≈øtria even within the ≈øight of Vienna, the Suburbs of which City they had ≈øacked, had not the Governour come again≈øt them with a great power, and forced them to lay down their Arms, cau≈øing the Ring-leaders to be puni≈øhed with death and impri≈øonment. But whil≈øt the≈øe things were doing Zellaly was driven out of Bo≈øna, by Zeffer Ba≈ø≈øa ≈øent in order thereto by the Sultan with a great power, yet the better to calm his high Spirit, and to make the A≈øian Rebels have a better opinion of the young Emperour, he was made Governour of Teme≈øwar, and ≈øo became a mortal Enemy to the Chri≈øtians,
