his fir≈øt undertaking being to ≈øurprize Lippa, but therein found ≈øuch bad ≈øucce≈øs, that he hardly recovered his own Garri≈øon, leaving mo≈øt of his men dead behind him, and ≈øoon after a terrible fire happening in Cani≈øia layed it almo≈øt wa≈øt, firing the Magazine of Powder and blowing up the Cittadel, Towers, Hou≈øes, and Wall, ≈øo that had any forces of the Chri≈øtians been near in that General con≈øternation, they might ea≈øily have ≈øurprized it, after which lo≈øt the Turks ≈øu≈øtained another for Two Hundred of the Garri≈øon of Buda, going abroad to forrage, were by the ≈øallying of the Garri≈øon of Pe≈øth all cut off.

During the≈øe ≈øtirs the re≈øtle≈øs Tran≈øylvanians having called to their a≈ø≈øi≈øtance divers Turks and Tartars, had ≈øeized upon ≈øeveral ≈øtrong places, driving out the Imperial Garri≈øons to repre≈øs who≈øe in≈øolency Ba≈øta ≈øent the Haducks, under the leading of Horwal their Captain, who lying in ambu≈øh for them who were but few in number, and ea≈øily overthrown, as being by Famine bereaved of their ≈øtrength, they were mo≈øt of them put to the Sword; after which the Haducks robbed the poor Villagers at their plea≈øure, killing ≈øuch as refu≈øed to contribute to their greedy de≈øires. So that all was again reduced to the ≈øame extremity as before, and when the ≈øaid Captain was by the Leiutenant Commanded to re≈øtrain his men from committing any more ≈øuch outrages, he an≈øwered, that it was impo≈ø≈øible to keep Souldiers in order amid≈øt extremity of Famine, for that the belly was an inexorable u≈øurer, which took pitty upon nothing but with great rigor exacted that which it thought due for the nouri≈øhment of it ≈øelf.

The Forces of the Chri≈øtians increa≈øing in Hungary, the Ba≈ø≈øa of Buda to retard their proceeding made many fair ≈øhews of the great de≈øires his Lord the Emperor had of peace, and the better to make it be believed, he wrote a di≈ø≈øembling letter ≈øignifying as much to the Governour of Strigonium, but his fair Glozing was not of force to lull the Chri≈øtians into a ≈øecurity; which hypocri≈øie of the Ba≈ø≈øa's ≈øoon after appeared by his ≈øurpri≈øing Simnin, a Ca≈øtle held by the Chri≈øtians, upon the banks of the Danubius, and ≈øetting it on fire.

The Per≈øian King having joyned hands with Caracas the chief Leader of the Rebels, a man of great power, in a ≈øet Battle overthrew Cicala Ba≈ø≈øa, with the lo≈øs of almo≈øt all his Turks, taking the Ba≈ø≈øas ≈øon pri≈øoner, by ≈øecret Me≈ø≈øengers invited the bordering Nations to revolt from the Turki≈øh obedience, to prevent which, the ≈øame Ba≈ø≈øa was with another huge Army ≈øent into tho≈øe parts, where in a ≈øhort ≈øpace, he received two ≈øeveral overthrows, in which, be≈øides what he lo≈øt in the fir≈øt battle, ≈øeventy thou≈øand Turks peri≈øhed; ≈øo that now the Terror the Per≈øian breathed even upon Con≈øtantinople it ≈øelf, having over-run the greate≈øt part of the Turks Dominions in A≈øia, at what time Achmat fell ≈øick of the ≈ømall Pox at Con≈øtantinople, and hardly recovered, when during the time of his ≈øickne≈øs it was agreed among≈øt the Ba≈ø≈øas that his brother Mu≈øtapha the only ≈øurviver of the Ottoman family if he had dyed, ≈øhould have been taken out of the Seraglio, where he remained no better then a pri≈øoner, and have been proclaimed Emperor, nor would the Souldiers believe but that he was dead, till ≈øuch time as he recovering his ≈øtrength, rode for their better ≈øatisfaction through mo≈øt of the Principal ≈øtreets of the Imperial City of Con≈øtantinople.

The Per≈øian ≈øtill prevailing, and it being rumoured, that he advanced apace at the head of one hundred thou≈øand fighting men, to whom Bagages the di≈øcontented Ba≈ø≈øa had joyned him≈øelf, Achmat ≈øent Ha≈ø≈øan Ba≈ø≈øa his General to maintain the wars in Hungary, and Cicala Ba≈ø≈øa (notwith≈øtanding he had been thrice overthrown) again≈øt the Per≈øian and A≈øian Rebels; but amid≈øt his great preparation the Tartarian Cham ≈øent him word that he could not come to his a≈ø≈øi≈øtance in per≈øon, but that he would ≈øend his ≈øon with a great power into Hungary, (now the rea≈øon that this great Monarch is ≈øo ready at all times to ≈øerve the Turk, is for that they often interchange in Marriages, and that if the Ottoman family fail, the Empire de≈øcends to the Tartar Cham, and la≈øtly, which indeed is the greate≈øt motive, by rea≈øon of the large Pen≈øion that Prince living in a needy Country receives yearly from the Turki≈øh Emperor.)

To oppo≈øe the Turks and Tartars, Rodolphus the Emperor ≈øent Maximilian his nephew in the quality of an Amba≈ø≈øador to the Pope and Princes of Italy, to crave aid, who upon his arrival at Rome, was honourably received, and after having fini≈øhed his negotiation, ≈øent back with many pre≈øents and a full a≈ø≈øurance of a ≈øpeedy ≈øupply, the Pope for his part having promi≈øed out of his Trea≈øury 150000 Crowns, to be paid towards the defraying the charges of the war, in which he was not le≈øs then his word; but by this time the Tartars being upontheir march towards Hungary, (where Ha≈ø≈øan Ba≈ø≈øa was with a great power of Turks arrived) and denyed pa≈ø≈øage through Polonia, brake violently into Valachia, mi≈øerably ≈øpoiling and de≈øtroying the Country, to abate who≈øe fury the Valachians aided by Ba≈øtas Forces ≈øtill following them in the rear, cut off a great number of them, yet at length they pa≈ø≈øed into Hungary, and there joyned the Ba≈ø≈øas Forces, whereupon (after ≈øeverall
skirmi≈øhes, and the taking of ≈øome (not important) places on both ≈øides) he ≈øet down with all his power before Strigonium, to prevent who≈øe intrenching, the Chri≈øtians Sallyed out, killing many of them, and driving the re≈øt from their works, upon news of which ≈øiege, Ba≈øta taking a new oath of the Tran≈øylvanians, came with all his Forces to endeavour its Relief, who upon his arrival confronted the enemy, and rai≈øing a huge Fort of Earth, not far from their Camp, from thence with ≈øeveral Pieces of Cannon greatly annoyed them, ≈øo that what with continual ≈øallyes of the be≈øieged, and the skirmi≈øhes Ba≈øtas Souldiers had with them after a tedious ≈øiege, and the lo≈øs of twenty thou≈øand men, the haughty Ba≈ø≈øa rai≈øed his Camp, and departed towards Buda, Ba≈øta ≈øtill following them, and cutting off a great number of ≈øuch as marched in the rear, and took ≈øeveral pri≈øoners of note, yet ≈øuch was the fera, that the Turks brought upon Hatvan, during their be≈øieging Strigonium that the Garri≈øon abandoned it, carrying with them all their moveables, and ≈øeveral Pieces of Cannon, though the Turks had attempted nothing again≈øt it.

During the≈øe troubles in Hungary, Bethlem Habor, chief of the Rebels in Tran≈øylvania a≈ø≈øi≈øted by Beckberes Ba≈ø≈øa, with four thou≈øand Turks, entered the Province, to have taken po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion thereof, in the ab≈øence of Ba≈øta, but being incountered by Count Tambire, when he ≈øu≈øpected no ≈øuch matter, he was overthrown, and a thou≈øand of his men ≈ølain, him≈øelf and the Ba≈ø≈øa hardly e≈øcaping, and three dayes after the ≈øaid Count, lighting on ≈øeveral Troops of Turks ≈øent to the a≈ø≈øi≈øtance of the Rebels, by the Ba≈ø≈øa of Teme≈øwar, put mo≈øt of them to the ≈øword, yet the Rebellion cea≈øed not ≈øo, for one Botscay a di≈øcontented German, having drawn a
great number of de≈øperate fellows to take part with him, and countenanced by the Grand Signiour, took the field in the upper Hungary, again≈øt whom Belgio≈øia a valiant Captain advanced with ≈øuch Forces as he in ha≈øte could mu≈øter up, but ≈øuch was his ill hap, that joyning battle he was overthrown by the Rebels, and mo≈øt of his Souldiers ≈ølain, after which defeat of the imperiali≈øts the City of Ca≈ø≈øonia was ≈øurrendered to the Rebels, upon notice of which Ba≈øta having gathered a con≈øiderable Army marched again≈øt Botscay, to put a ≈øtop to his proceedings e'r he po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed him≈øelf of any more of the Hungarian Cities, yet the people Generally favouring their cau≈øE which wore a mask of Religion and Liberty, the number daily increa≈øed, and notwith≈øtanding the diligence of Ba≈øta, many ≈øtrong holds were put into their hands, yet after a tedious march, the renowned Lieutenant, put to flight the forerunners of their Army, and after many difficulties, and the lo≈øs of ≈øeveral of his Souldiers, came to a pitched field, of which after a cruel and bloody fight he won, putting Botscay and his Rebel followers to flight, with great ≈ølaughter, and by that means recovered many Cities and Ca≈øtles that had ca≈øt off the Emperors obedience, and taken part with the Rebels.

The Turks in Per≈øia fared little otherwi≈øe then tho≈øe in Hungary, for Cicala Ba≈ø≈øa, with all his Forces were overthrown by the Per≈øian King, and the City of Babylon, now called Bagdat taken, of which he ≈øent to advertize the German Emperor, intreating him to joyn hands with him for abating the Turks pride, which he was re≈øolutely determined to do, re≈øolving not to give over the war till he had ≈øtripped him out of all his Cities in A≈øia, and therefore de≈øired the Emperor to ≈øend an Amba≈ø≈øador to
confer with him about a la≈øting peace, which was accordingly done; nor were they all the trouble the Turki≈øh Empire ≈øu≈øtained, for by rea≈øon of ≈øome differences between the Ba≈ø≈øas of Dama≈øco and Aleppo, they wage mortal battle one with the other, wherein the latter was overthrown, and flying to his City, there be≈øieged, till compelled therto by famine, he yielded to what the Ba≈ø≈øa of Dama≈øco demanded; about what time Sultan Achmats fir≈øt ≈øon was born, for which there was great rejoycing at Con≈øtantinople.

Anno 1605. The troubles in Hungary and Tran≈øylvania more and more increa≈øed, the former being occa≈øioned by the Bi≈øhops (in their late a≈ø≈øembly) pa≈ø≈øing a decree that all of the reformed Religion ≈øhould be burnt, or bani≈øhed, again≈øt which wicked Decree, though the Nobility of the Kingdom openly prote≈øted again≈øt, yet were their Churches ≈øeized, and Publick and Private wor≈øhip forbidden, as al≈øo the reading of the Bible; to redre≈øs which grievances, Ba≈øta promi≈øed redre≈øs, but Botscay having made them a ≈øtirrup to help him into the ≈øaddle would hearken to no peace, unle≈øs Tran≈øylvania might be delivered to him, and that the Lieutenant of Hungary might be a Hungarian born, and that all offices might be be≈øtowed upon Hungarians, and the Souldiers of other Nations withdraw except ≈øuch as were in Garri≈øon, and tho≈øe not to pa≈øs their appointed limits; and la≈øtly, that Hungarian Souldiers ≈øhould receive the Emperors pay, and that when ever an A≈ø≈øembly of the E≈øtates was held at Presburg, the Emperor him≈øelf ≈øhould be there in per≈øon. The≈øe propo≈øals were ≈øent to Ba≈øta by two Hungarians, but without ≈øucce≈øs, whereupon all manner of Ho≈øtilities were u≈øed, and more ≈øpoil made

The≈øe inte≈øtine troubles gave the Turks opportunity to po≈ø≈øe≈øs them≈øelves of the Cities of Vacia and Vicegrade, and committed great outrages in many places, and what was more to the di≈øadvantage of the Emperor, the Haducks his chief ≈øtrength favouring the Rebels, revolted from him, which Ba≈øta perceiving, and finding his Forces daily to decrea≈øe, procured of the Emperor a General pardon for all offences pa≈øt, as well Temporal as Eccle≈øia≈øtical, promi≈øing upon their ≈øubmi≈ø≈øion to re≈øtore them to their Liberties, priviledges, and Religious wor≈øhip as formerly exerci≈øed, and that no man ≈øhould be mole≈øted, by vertue of any Decree made by the Bi≈øhops, &c. this pardon was proclaimed with the beat of Drum and ≈øound of Trumpet in ≈øeveral places upon which ≈øome of the Nobility, who≈øe E≈øtates lay in danger to be ≈øpoiled by the Souldiers, came in and ≈øubmitted them≈øelves, yet the Rebels Army was no whit le≈ø≈øened, but rather increa≈øed, in≈øomuch that the Haducks drawing them≈øelves apart be≈øieged Sacinar, in which was an Imperial Garri≈øon, and after divers a≈ø≈øaults took it, and marching from thence indeavoured to have ≈øurpri≈øed the ≈øtrong Ca≈øtle of Tocay, but their de≈øign was fru≈øtrated by the ≈øtout re≈øi≈øtance of tho≈øe in Garri≈øon; but that which had like to have proved wor≈øt of all to Basta was the mutiny of his own Souldiers, which he hardly appea≈øed with a great ≈øum of mony.

The Haducks ≈øtill roaming about as men greedy of prey, lay ≈øiege to Fileck, which after ≈øome lo≈øs they took, and placed a ≈øtrong Garri≈øon therein; upon which Amba≈ø≈øadors were ≈øent to Bo≈øcay the head of the Rebels, to treat with him in the Emperors name, about a peace, but without receiving any ≈øatisfaction,
they were forced to return, the Rebel declaring that if they came from the E≈øtates of Hungary he would give them Audience, but if from the Emperor the Articles of peace he had propo≈øed, he expected to be confirmed without delay, if the Emperor expected any, and after the departure of the Amba≈ø≈øadors; he ≈øent forth his Letters mandatory to A≈ø≈øemble the Nobility at Serentium, on the ≈øeventeenth of April to ≈øettle the affairs of the Kingdom, many of which accordingly met, but concluded on nothing material, the Rebel and ≈øuch as were of his faction ≈øtill over-ruling them in all their con≈øultations, as well knowing the Emperors Forces for the mo≈øt part had their hearts with him, which cau≈øed them frequently to mutiny and reproach their Commanders, under pretence of wanting their pay. The Haducks now increa≈øed in number po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed them≈øelves of Newhaw≈øel, Cibinium, Dort. feld and Schemnitze.

Thus whil≈øt all Hungary, Au≈øtria, and Stira were as it were in a flame. The Turks again be≈øieged ≈øeveral Ca≈øtles which at that time were governed by valiant Captains, ≈øo that they prevailed not greatly yet the General confu≈øion made the Emperour de≈øirous of Peace, in order to which he ≈øent Sigi≈ømund Forgat with full in≈øtructions to Kyrpa where the E≈øtates of Hungary were to a≈ø≈øemble, thither likewi≈øe came ≈øeveral Commi≈ø≈øioners from Bot≈øcay and the Turki≈øh Ba≈ø≈øa's of Buda, Pe≈øth, &c. when as in the mean time other Imperial Mini≈øters were ≈øent to Comara, to Treat only with the Turks, they having ≈øo required but the demands of the Turks and Rebels were ≈øo unrea≈øonable, that many believed they only ≈øet that treaty on foot to protract the preparations of the Imperiali≈øts, ≈øo that all hopes
of an amicable conclu≈øion vani≈øhing, fierce War began to rage more terrible then before, all the Countreys round being covered with the ≈ømoak of flaming Villages by day, and illuminated with ≈øhining ‚Ä¢ ires by night, nor did the Rebels ≈øpare to ≈øell the poor Chri≈øtians like bea≈øts to the mercile≈øs Turk, by them to be carryed into perpetual ≈ølavery, nor de≈øi≈øted from comitting ≈øuch cruelties as even amazed the Infidels to ≈øee them≈øelves out done. To prevent which outrages the Imperiali≈øts drawing together in a body, ≈øet upon a ≈øtrong power of the Turks and Rebels, who thought to have ≈øurprized them in their Camp, and after a ≈øharp di≈øpute drove them with great ≈ølaughter to the Walls of Canu≈øia, and afterwards put ≈øtrong Garri≈øons into mo≈øt of the important towns and Ca≈øtles, which bad ≈øucce≈øs made the Rebels again bethink them≈øelves of a timely peace ≈øo that Bot≈øcay their Ringleader having received Letters of ≈øafe conduct from Matthias the Arch-Duke, came with his Wife and Children to Vienna, and there by frequent by conferring with the Imperial Commi≈ø≈øioners, matters were ≈øo ordered that peace was concluded between the Emperour and his Rebel Subjects of Hungary according to the Tenour of the≈øe Articles.
Articles of Peace agreed upon Anno 1606. between the Emperor and his di≈øcontented Subjects of Hungary.
1. That from thenceforth it ≈øhould be lawful for every man throughout the Kingdom of Hungary, to have the free u≈øe of his Religion and believe what he would.
2. That if the Hungarians ≈øo thought good, they might chu≈øe a Palatine for their Governor, and that in the mean time the Arch-Duke Matthias ≈øhould no more u≈øe the Title of Governour but Vice-Roy.
3. That the Crown of Hungary ≈øhould ≈øtill be left in the Emperors keeping.
4. That the Bi≈øhops that were nobly de≈øcended in Hungary and had Lands of their own, ≈øhould be forthwith admitted into the Council but the other Bi≈øhops not to be ≈øo received.
5. That Bot≈øcay for him≈øelf and his heirs male ≈øhould ever hold Tran≈øilvania.
6. That the ≈øame Countrey of Tran≈øilvania ≈øhould be ≈øtill ≈øubject to the Kingdom of Hungary.
7 That for his Arms he ≈øhould bear three Royal Crowns, and three open Helmets.
8. That he ≈øhould not more ≈øtile him≈øelf Prince but Lord of part of Hungary.
9. That they ≈øhould pay the Heyducks their wages who had leavyed them.
10. That the harms done on both ≈øides ≈øhould for ever be forgotten.

11. That Bohemia, Moravia, Lan≈øni≈øium and A ‚Ä¢
≈øtria ≈øhould not only with their Letters and Seals confirm the Articles, but al≈øo ≈øwear at Vienna to keep the ≈øame, ≈øo far as they conerned them.
12. That the Hungarians likewi≈øe ≈øhould ≈øend ≈øome to Vienna, who in their behalfs ≈øhould with their Letters, Seals and Oaths, Confirm and Ratifie the≈øe Articles.
13. That the a≈ø≈øembly of the States of Hungary ≈øhould be referred unto a more convenient time for their meeting.
14. That the≈øe things being done this Agreement ≈øhould be publickly confirmed and inrolled in the Records of the Kingdom of Hungary.
15. That it ≈øhould be lawful for the Hungarians by their Amba≈ø≈øadors, to invite the Princes of the Empire to the Approving and Confirming of the≈øe Articles.

Peace thus concluded with the Hungarians, the Treaty of Peace between the Turki≈øh Sultan and
the Emperour went on, and with ≈øuch good ≈øucce≈øs that a Peace was ≈øoon after concluded to the joy of all the Emperors Subjects, who weary with the continual toils and mi≈øeries of War, were now de≈øirous of nothing more then to repo≈øe them≈øelves in the downy armes of Peace. After which Bot≈øcay called an a≈ø≈øembly of the E≈øtates of Hungary recommending to them the care of pre≈øerving inviolable the Articles, and the ≈øpeedy Election of a Palatine, and that above all things they would maintain and incourage the Reformed Religion, and in the next A≈ø≈øembly labour to have the Articles for burning Hereticks repealed, and as much as in them lay to re≈øtore the lo≈øt Trade of the ≈øpoiled Provinces.

The≈øe things done Bot≈øcay fell ≈øick, which ≈øickne≈øs increa≈øing he greatly bewailed his late Rebellion, and the blood therein ≈øhed, wi≈øhing nothing more then that before he died, he could beg pardon for the ≈øame of the whole Roman Empire, yet had not his wi≈øh, but of that ≈øickne≈øs died at Co≈ø≈øovia, on the 30th. of December, 1606. per≈øwading in the time of his ≈øickne≈øs ≈øuch as had been his followers to adhere to the Emperours intere≈øt, yet his Coun≈øel was not ≈øo well ob≈øerved, but that after his death (notwith≈øtanding Matthias the Arch-Duke had cau≈øed him≈øelf to be Crowned King of Hungary, including the Principality of Tran≈øivania) there wanted not ≈øome who a≈øpired to the Title of Prince, which cau≈øed new di≈øcontents, but with relinqui≈øhing of that Title they vani≈øhed.

Achmat having made Peace with the Emperour, re≈øolved to turn his arms again≈øt the Per≈øian King and A≈øian Rebels, again≈øt whom Anno 16 ‚Ä¢ 7. early in the Spring he ≈øent the Vizar Ba≈ø≈øa, who by Policy more then ≈øtrength appea≈øed the latter, when upon notice that the Ba≈ø≈øa of Aleppo had overthrown
the Ba≈ø≈øa's of Tripolis and Dauca≈øco, and that at the reque≈øt of the Sultan he refu≈øed to lay down his arms, he marched again≈øt him with One Hundred Thirty Thou≈øand men, which pui≈ø≈øant Army the Ba≈ø≈øa of Aleppo incountered with Fourty Thou≈øand, and in three Battles remained victor; but upon notice that the Ba≈ø≈øa's of Dama≈øco and Tripolis, were coming to the Aid of the Vizar Ba≈ø≈øa with great Forces, and he by rea≈øon of the lo≈øs he had ≈øu≈øtained not able to with≈øtand their united power fled, with mo≈øt of his Friends to the Mountains. Yet at the interce≈ø≈øion of the Vizar Ba≈ø≈øa but more for fear he ≈øhould revolt t the Per≈øian, he was afterwards pardoned and received into favour: upon which the King of Per≈øia wrote to the King of Spain, intreating him to joyn Forces with him again≈øt the common Enemy, but more e≈øpecially to ≈øend his Ships of War into the Gulf, and the rather to induce him ≈øo to do he ≈øent him ≈øeveral rich pre≈øents.

Whil≈øt the≈øe things pa≈ø≈øed the Turki≈øh Garri≈øons, who for the mo≈øt part lived by ≈øpoiles, impatient of Peace with the Chri≈øtians committed ≈øome outrages, and ≈øecretly incouraged the Heyducks to commit more, of which Achmat having notice ≈øent ≈øtrictly to charge the Ba≈ø≈øa of Buda, not (upon pain of his head) to infringe the Capitulation, whereupon Six Hundred Heyducks being abroad, and not a≈ø≈øi≈øted by the Turks as they expected, were intercepted by Humanoius an Imperial Captain and almo≈øt all of them ≈ølain; yet ≈øoon after the kind of proling men a≈ø≈øembling to the number of Fifteen Thou≈øand laid ≈øiege to Tilesk, having for their incouragement received Three Hundred Thou≈øand Duccates, by the order of the Turki≈øh Sultan, and great Ordnance
(the better to inable them to take the Town, which they were to deliver to the Turks) from Agria, upon notice whereof the Hungarian E≈øtates A≈ø≈øembled at Presburg, but by rea≈øon of the ab≈øence of the Arch-Duke, who by the Emperours appointment was to have ≈øat as Pre≈øident, there was nothing worthy of mention tran≈øacted, whereupon an Imperial Diet was a≈ø≈øembled at Ratisbon, where after debating many matters the Deputies of the ≈øeveral Princes fell at variance among≈øt them≈øelves, which ≈øtill increa≈øing notwith≈øtanding the indeavours u≈øed to prevent it, the Arch-Duke then Pre≈øident di≈ømi≈ø≈øed the a≈ø≈øembly.

The≈øe great Councils proving fruitle≈øs, Troubles and Di≈øcontent in the un≈øettled Provinces of Hungary, Au≈øtria, &c. aro≈øe, to alay which the Arch-Duke came to Presburg and a≈ø≈øembled the E≈øtates, who out of them≈øelves chu≈øe Commi≈ø≈øioners to appea≈øe the Tumults on foot, to hear and determine all Grievances, who ≈øo well performed their tru≈øts that Peace for a while in≈øued.

Affairs Anno 1608. ≈øtanding thus in Hungary, &c. about the beginning of Spring Jerome Prince of Valachia died leaving behind him a Son about 13 years of Age whom the Emperour admitted (as yet not being capable to manage the affairs of Government under Tutors) unto the Succe≈ø≈øion of the Principality, which thing the Valachians not being willing to endure, and bearing them≈øelves upon the Turks, went about to Elect another Prince, for which cau≈øe the Prince≈øs, Widow to the decea≈øed Vayvod, by Letters certified Pollo≈øcie her Son-in-Law of the intended outrage of her Subjects, and having received of him a great ≈øumm of money, Leavied Ten Thou≈øand good Souldiers to ≈øecure her Sons right, who
in a great Battle overthrew ≈øuch forces of Valachians, Turks and Tartars as the Nobility had rai≈øed to oppo≈øe the Succe≈ø≈øion of the young Prince, and by that means pre≈øerved the Principality to the behoof of her Son, but what had like to have proved fatal to Chri≈øtendom, was the difference ari≈øing between the Emperour nad the Arch-Duke Matthias upon the ‚Ä¢ atters laying ab≈øolute claim to the Crown of Hungary, without acknowledging to hold it of the Empire, but when both parties had armed and matters had like to have come to extremity, ≈øeveral Princes laboured ≈øo far therein that a Pacification was made, and the Arch-Duke having received the In≈øigns of Royalty, from the Emperours Amba≈ø≈øadors upon acknowledging him his Soveraign, broke up his Camp and returned to Vienna, where he was joyfull received. Yet the Prote≈øtant E≈øtates of Au≈øtria, refu≈øed to ≈øwear Allegiance to him, till he had confirmed the Article of free exerci≈øe in matters of Religion, which he for a con≈øiderable time refu≈øing to do, great Troubles had thereupon like to have ari≈øen; for the Prote≈øtant E≈øtates not regarding his Regal Authority further then ≈øtood with the Articles of Pacification, for non performance thereof betook them≈øelves to Arms, but the E≈øtates of Bohemia and Moravia interpo≈øing, all was for a while quiet, the King promi≈øing that although for fear of di≈øplea≈øing the Pope and King of Spain, he could not tolerate the Reformed Religion, yet he would wink at the free exerci≈øe throughout his Dominions, and that as to the di≈øpo≈øal of Offices and places of Tru≈øt, he them according to the merits of his Subejcts: Upon which the E≈øtates proceeded to the Election of a Palatine, which honourable Dignity they be≈øtowed on Illi≈øha≈øcius, a Noble man of Hungary, who faithfully
di≈øcharged his tru≈øt for the ≈øpace of one year and then died to the great grief of the Hungarians, of whom for his great Wi≈ødom and Uprightne≈øs he was generally beloved, in who≈øe ≈øtead the Nobility elected George Tur≈øon, who got a good e≈øteem among≈øt them, by his pacifying the Troubles that immediately upon the death of Illi≈øha≈øcius aro≈øe in Bohemia about Religion.

Anno 1608 on the 19 of October, the Turki≈øh Amba≈ø≈øador came to the Emperors Pallace at Prague, having by the way vi≈øited the new King of Hungary, where being received with the re≈øpect due to his Character, he delivered the pre≈øent ≈øent by his Ma≈øter the Grand Signeor, which were principally a Rich Tent of divers Colours mo≈øt curiou≈øly wrought with Pearls of great value, four couragious hor≈øes trapped with Gold and precious Stones, certain Turki≈øh weapons ≈øet and garni≈øhed with precious Stones, a Princely Turki≈øh Robe, ≈øuch as they u≈øe at their Marriages, Gli≈øtering with Gold and pretious ≈øtones, with divers other rarities of le≈ø≈øer value, together with which he delivered Achmats Letters, and withall de≈øired the confirmation of the Peace before made for twenty years, to be again renewed; after which he was honourably treated and di≈ømi≈ø≈øed with the Emperors Letters to the Sultan, and many rare pre≈øents, no whit inferiour to tho≈øe he brought, and with a train of two hundred hor≈øe conducted him to the Turki≈øh Frontiers.

In the year 1609, nothing worthy of mention happened, but the year following, the King of Per≈øia having overthrown the Turks Forces, ≈øent to ≈øtay the current of his Victories, entred into the Province of Babylon, with an intent to annext it to his other Conque≈øts, which ≈øo alarmed Achmet, that Leavying a great power he ≈øent them under the Leading of Na≈ø≈øut Ba≈ø≈øa, to ≈øecure his Territories on
that ≈øide, but ≈øuch was the evil fortune of the Ba≈ø≈øa, that joyning battle, he was overthrown, and twenty thou≈øand of his men ≈ølain; after which good ≈øucce≈øs the Per≈øian King ≈øent other Amba≈ø≈øadors to the Roman Emperor, with many rich pre≈øents to incite him to break his League with the Turks, but notwith≈øtanding the many pregnant arguments u≈øed by the Ama≈ø≈øador, the Emperor could not be induced to break his faith, but di≈ømi≈ø≈øed him with a return of pre≈øents, and many thanks to his ma≈øter, for the re≈øpect he had towards him, and his care for the Chri≈øtian Commonwealth.

About the ≈øame time the Knights of Malta putting ≈øeveral Galleys to ≈øea, fought the Turks Galleys with various ≈øucce≈øs, ≈øometimes one prevailing, and ≈øometimes the other; nor did the Duke of Tu≈øcany le≈øs annoy them with a ≈øquadron of Gallies, under the command of Admiral Jughiraim, who running along, the coa≈øt of Barbary took many Turki≈øh Gallyes, and landing his men in divers places, ≈øpoiled the Country and took greate booties; nor fared the Mori≈øques or new Chri≈øtians in Spain this year to their contents, for the Spani≈øh King upon a Capricio Bani≈øhed them out of his Dominions to the number of 900 thou≈øand per≈øons, mo≈øt Moores and Jews, who for profits ≈øake had ≈øuffered them≈øelves to be baptized, but now upon the Publication of the Kings Edict, they were forced to wander like vagabonds over the face of the earth to ≈øeek new places to re≈øide in; at what time there happened a conte≈øt between Muley Xequy King of Fe≈øs, and Muley Sidan his younger brother, which increa≈øed to that height that mortal wars aro≈øe, when after many fields fought, the latter prevailed, and po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed him≈øelf of the Kingdom, which cau≈øed the former to flye into Spain, there to crave aid of King Phillip, who in con≈øideration of the Barbarians promi≈øe to
deliver Alarache a ≈øtrong Town ≈øeated on the mouth of the River Lucus, in the Kingdom of Fe≈øs, into his po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion, furni≈øhed him with 100 thou≈øand Duccates, therewith to leavy Souldiers in his own Countrey, and ≈øent with him likewi≈øe his ≈øhips of war, under the conduct of the Marque≈øs of St. Germaines, manned with ten thou≈øand Spaniards, who coming before the Town, landed the King, who was received by ≈øeveral of his friends into a ≈øtrong Ca≈øtle that guards the mouth of the River, which he put into the hands of the Spaniard, but it was no ≈øooner known that he had ≈øo done, but the Mores from all parts run to their Arms, ≈øo that e'r they could po≈ø≈øe≈øs them≈øelves of the Town, an ob≈øtinate fight was maintained for the ≈øpace of three hours, in which ≈øpace five hundred Spaniards and three thou≈øand Moores were ≈ølain, but in the end the former prevailed, and po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed them≈øelves of that ≈øtrong place, which had by them been ≈øo often de≈øired, the news of which cau≈øed great rejoycing in Spain. This year was fought a great battle between the Son of the late decea≈øed Cham of Tartary, and his uncle, upon the latters u≈øurping the Imperial dignity, during the formers remaining a ho≈øtage at Con≈øtantinople, in which 40000 men were ≈ølain, and the Victory re≈øted upon the rightful Heir.

Anno 1611, ≈øuch a Contagion happened in Con≈øtantinople that it ingendring a Pe≈øtilence, which raged ≈øo vehemently that thirty thou≈øand died in one month, and among≈øt the re≈øt, one of Achmats ≈øons, nor did the Barron of Salignac the French Kings Amba≈ø≈øador e≈øcape, to ≈øucceed whom as ≈øoon as the Mortality cea≈øed, the Barron of Mole was ≈øent, who upon his arrival, after having vi≈øited the Mufti or chief Mahometan Prie≈øt, and the great Ba≈ø≈øa's of the Court, him≈øelf and his retinue were attired in
Turki≈øh habit (no Amba≈ø≈øadors being permitted in the proper habit of their own Countrey to approach the Sultan) was conducted to have his Audience of the Grand Seigneour, through a litte Court paved with Marble; after which, he entred the Royal Chamber, which was inriched on one ≈øide with many Pillars of Marble, and ≈øquare ≈øtones of the ≈øame, beautified with two Fountains, on either ≈øide the planchers were gilt with Gold, and the Walls Inameled with flowers, and the flour covered with cloath of Gold and ≈øilver, at the entery of which ≈øtood ≈øix Capigi or Royal Porters, two of which took the Amba≈ø≈øador by either arm to lead him to the Grand Seigneor (a Ceremony pretended for honours ≈øake, but indeed to prevent any violence, that upon ≈øuch near acce≈øs may be offered, and has been in u≈øe ever ≈øince Amurath the fir≈øt was ≈øtabbed in the fields of Co≈ø≈ø ‚Ä¢ via) and the re≈øt carryed the pre≈øents; ≈øo that the Amba≈ø≈øador having ki≈ø≈øed the hem of the imperious Turks Garment, was carryed out another way backward, becau≈øe it ≈øhould not be ≈øaid that the Mini≈øter of any Forrein Prince turned his back upon the Emperor, in like manner his attendants fared, being obliged to withdraw till the Infidel was more at lei≈øure, for as then he ≈øtood peeping out at a window to view ≈øome di≈øports that were made below for his diver≈øion and a while after being admitted, he delivered his letters written in the Turki≈øh Language, and in a pithy Oration, delivered what el≈øe he had in charge.

Notwith≈øtanding the Peace between the Imperiali≈øts and the Turks, the latter cea≈øed not covertly to ≈øtir up di≈ø≈øen≈øions, by which means they procured the revolt of Gabriel Battori Vayvod of Tran≈øilvania, who rai≈øing a great power, cha≈øed Raduille
Prince of Valachia out of his Principality, who thereupon fled to Con≈øtantine Vayvod of Moldavia, when reinforced by the Moldavian, he returned again, and in a great battle overthrew Gabriel, forcing him to flye with his ≈øcatered Troops to Herm≈øtad, where he committed many Cruelties under pretence that the Citizens went about to deliver him into the hands of his mortal enemies. The divi≈øion ≈øtirred up Fortga ‚Ä¢ ≈øie the King of Hungary to pa≈øs into Tran≈øylvania, to reduce the revolted Cities to the Kings obedience, but being waylaid, he was forced to travel through de≈øart places, where through famine and di≈øea≈øes that raged in his Camp, mo≈øt of his men dyed; ≈øo that fearing to fall into the hands of tho≈øe he intended to oppre≈øs, he fled into Polonia with a ≈ølender Train, yet ended not the trouble, for by this time the Turks had ≈øtirred up di≈øcontents in Moldavia, by ≈øending thither a Competitor to wre≈øtle with Con≈øtantine for his Principality, but finding him≈øelf too weak, and not a≈ø≈øi≈øted as he expected, fled to Con≈øtantinople, there to crave aid of Achmet, but finding many delays he travelled to the Courts of many Chri≈øtian Princes, and among≈øt others came into England, and made his application to King James, who moved with his heavy complaints, and ≈øpecious pretences of ju≈øt claim to the Principality of Moldavia, that his Maje≈øty was plea≈øed bountifully to relieve him, and by his Letters to recommend him to the care of Sir Thomas Glover, his Amba≈ø≈øador then re≈øiding at Con≈øtantinople, who recommended him to the Grand Signeur, but ≈øuch were the counterplots of Con≈øtantine, that by bribing the great Ba≈ø≈øa's he not only prevented him in his purpo≈øe but greatly indangered his being made away, which had certainly happened had not Sir Thomas ≈øheltered him under his protection, and by fortifying his hou≈øe, daunted the bloodthir≈øty
Janizaries, whom the Grand Vi≈øier had imployed to take him thence by Force, but Sir Thomas being ≈øoon after recalled; The Moldavian de≈øpairing to obtain the Principality he ≈øo much de≈øired, in a rage renounced the Lord that bought him, and imbraced the Turki≈øh ≈øuper≈øtition, whereupon he was made Bey of Bur≈øia in A≈øia, but enjoyed not that dignity long e'r Na≈ø≈øuf Ba≈ø≈øa returning from the Per≈øian war, di≈øpo≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed him.

This year the Gallyes of Florence, Malta and Naples, greatly endamaged the Turki≈øh Dominions on the Sea-Coa≈øts, taking likewi≈øe ≈øeveral rich prizes, and among≈øt the re≈øt the Carravan Gally coming from Egypt, to Con≈øtantinople, with the Tribute of that rich Kingdom, ≈øinking at the ≈øame time five others, and de≈øcending upon the I≈øle of Lango, and took the Town from which the I≈øland takes its name, putting a number of Turks to the ≈øword, and taking a great ≈øpoil, and ≈øoon after entered the Bay of Corinth ≈øo ≈øecretly, that Landing they ≈øurprized the City, ≈øacked it and carryed away, be≈øides a rich booty five hundred ≈ølaves.

The≈øe things made the Turki≈øh Sultan wi≈øh for peace with the Per≈øian, that he might be at lea≈øure to turn his Arms upon the Chri≈øtians, e≈øpecially upon the Knights of Malta, who greatly ob≈øtructed his Navigation, and that which furthered his purpo≈øe was the arrival of the Per≈øian Amba≈ø≈øador at Con≈øtantinople, whereupon to welcom him he concluded a Marriage between Mehemet Ba≈ø≈øa, ≈øon to Cicula, late decea≈øed, and his Si≈øter, and another between Mechmet Ba≈ø≈øa his great Admiral, and his Elde≈øt daughter, which were cellebrated with all imaginable ≈øplendor, but ≈øoon after the Pe≈øtilence began again to rage in that great City, whereupon
Achmat withdrew him≈øelf to his rural Palace at Durat Ba≈ø≈øa, where whil≈øt he was viewing the Mo≈øque that he had cau≈øed to be built, a Dariveler or Turki≈øh Monk, ca≈øt at him a ≈øtone with ≈øuch force that it overthrew him; whereupon the Traytor was ≈øeized, and ordered by Torture to be con≈øtrained to confe≈øs what moved him to that outrage; but the officers of the Port with out further examination the next day executed him, which made ≈øome conjecture, that either they or ≈øome great men whom they favoured, ≈øet him on work.

During the≈øe Pa≈ø≈øages Moldavia groaned under Clande≈øtine Tumults, the Turks ≈øtill endeavouring to depo≈øe Con≈øtantine, and he with all his power on the contrary, labouring to ≈øupport his dignity, ≈øo that the Villages in all places went to Rack, the Countrey for the mo≈øt part being laid wa≈øt; to calm which differences the Polonian Amba≈ø≈øador came to the Court of Con≈øtantinople, expecting a ≈øudden Audience, but was contrary to his expectation, after ≈øix weeks attendance clapt up in pri≈øon, with notice that he could not be delivered till ≈øuch time as the two Capigis which Con≈øtantine carryed Captive into Polonia, nor was Tran≈øylvania free from fraction and civil di≈ø≈øen≈øion occa≈øioned by one Giezy ≈øet up by the Ba≈ø≈øa of Buda, to oppo≈øe the Palatine of Hungary, to whom that Province, according to the late Articles of peace does appertain, but the up≈øtart finding his Forces too weak too gra≈øp the Government ≈øoon after relinqui≈øhed his claime.

Achmat the more to amu≈øe the Per≈øian Amba≈ø≈øador, and oblige him to wonder at his greatne≈øs, re≈øolved to ≈øhew him≈øelf in all his pomp, and thereupon making as if he went to Darut Ba≈ø≈øa to take the air, after a dayes ≈øtay, returned in this manner. Before him a great number of men at Arms marched on
hor≈øe-back, and after them ≈øome Troops of Foot; The Cadies of Con≈øtantinople, or his chief Ju≈øticers; Then all the Tali≈ømans, or tho≈øe of Mahomets Law in great number; then the Vizar Ba≈ø≈øas in great ≈øplendor; after whom followed ten of the Sultans hou≈øhold, leading ten goodly hor≈øes in rich Capari≈øons, the la≈øt of which had a Bridle and Saddle pondered with precious ≈øtones, and unto the ≈øaddle was fa≈øtned the Sultans Target, and upon it were fa≈øtened Ta≈ø≈øels of Pearls, hanging almo≈øt with the ground, and over the≈øe a hor≈øe-cloth richly imbroidered with Pearl, after which followed the re≈øt of the Sultans hou≈øhold in divers Troops, fir≈øt fifty Janizaries on foot, every one of them leading dogs in Le≈øhes, for the mo≈øt part Iri≈øh-greyhounds, pre≈øented to him a little before by the French Amba≈ø≈øador, next to whom in order ≈øucceeded the Sultans Footmen called Pelks, who were Per≈øians born, all well attired, wearing on their heads bonets of Silver, after the Indian fa≈øhion, Then ≈øixty Archers, in the mid≈øt of whom came Sultan Achmat attired in a rich robe of Cloath of Gold, imbroidered with Pearls and Diamonds, and his ≈ølave clad in the ≈øame manner, his Turbant was covered with a Plume of black Feathers, inriched with great Diamonds, and a chain of the ≈øame ≈øtones, about the lower part of it upon his fingers he had Diamonds of ≈øuch largene≈øs, as they ca≈øt admirable light; his hor≈øe had Capari≈øons imbroidered with Diamonds, Pearls, and other precious ≈øtones, the Ground being Gold, and the ≈øtirrups of beaten Gold ≈øet with Diamonds, and from his Hor≈øes neck hung great Ta≈ø≈øels of Pearl, of a more than ordinary ≈øize; after him there followed three men on Hor≈øeback, the one carrying his Cloak, the other his arms, and the third his Imperial Turbant, and the≈øe were attended on by certain E≈øquires on hor≈øeback.
Then came the Mu≈øick after the Turki≈øh manner, con≈øi≈øting of ≈øixty men on Hor≈øeback, which played upon Fiets, Chardons and Trumpets; next followed one hundred of the Sultans Pages bravely mounted, followed by as many Eunuches, fifty of which carryed each of them a Falcon upon his fi≈øt, having their heads inriched with Diamonds; after them came thirty Guards of the Port, and fifty Falconers and Huntsmen, richly attired, each of them carrying upon his ≈øaddle bow a Leopard covered all but the head with a Cloath of Gold attended on by an other train of Pages, very beautiful, cho≈øen from among≈øt the Tribute infants, having their Garments be≈øet with pretious ≈øtones, the ground being Cloath of Gold curled, and after the≈øe followed a Troop of youths in plain attire, who were appointed to ≈øerve the pages; The rear of which proce≈ø≈øion was clo≈øed with all the great Officers of the Turki≈øh Empire, that were then re≈øident at Con≈øtantinople, and to make the Magnificence more compleat, as the Archers pa≈ø≈øed by the Sultans lodging 100 pieces of Silk, were ca≈øt among≈øt them.

Four days after this pompous ≈øhew Achmat gave Audience to the Per≈øian Amba≈ø≈øador, who pre≈øented him on the behalf of the King his Ma≈øter, with 100 Bales of Silk, a Beazor ≈øtone, as big as a mans fi≈øt, 9 bags of Turquoi≈øes of a foot and half long, and above a finger broad, ≈øeveral rich pieces of Tapi≈øtry, interwoven with Silk and Gold, with ≈øome other things of great price, among≈øt which he delivered his ma≈øters Letters; whereupon they began to treat of peace, which ≈øoon after was accorded principally upon the≈øe Articles: Fir≈øt, That the Per≈øian King ≈øhould pay unto the Turki≈øh Sultan yearly by way of Tribute two hundred Camells Loads of Silk, That the King of Per≈øia's Son ≈øhould be called Ba≈ø≈øa of Iauris, and that
the Cadi or Soveraign Judge of that City ≈øhould be ≈øent from Con≈øtantinople.

The Peace thus concluded to the advantage of the Turks and di≈øhonour of the Per≈øians, the Amba≈ø≈øador with many rich pre≈øents, was di≈ømi≈ø≈øed, leaving allmo≈øt all his Retinue behind him dead of the plague; nor did he long ≈øurvive them, for upon his arrival at Tauris, his ma≈øter under≈øtanding upon what di≈øhonourable Terms he had concluded the peace, cau≈øed his head to be cut off, and ≈øent back the Chiaus that was come with his Amba≈ø≈øador to ≈øee him ≈øwear the peace, ≈øo that not long after all vani≈øhed into nothing.

During the≈øe Tran≈øactions, Rodolphus the Emperor died, to ≈øucceed whom the Electoral Princes made choice of his brother Matthias King of Hungary, who upon his taking upon him the Imperial ≈øway, ≈øent his Amba≈ø≈øadors to Con≈øtantinople to intreat a confirmation of the peace made between his brother decea≈øed, and the Sultan, and to complain of the daily outrages committed in his Province of Tran≈øylvania, but the Turk who keep no League any longer then it turns to their advantage, not only refu≈øed to redre≈øs the grievances in Tan≈øylvania, but denyed the Emperor to have any right to that Province, although in the League it was expre≈øly mentioned, that Botscay dying with out Heirs male, the Principality ≈øhould totally remain a member of the Roman Empire, but after all was ≈øaid that could be ≈øaid, the Amba≈ø≈øador was di≈ømi≈ø≈øed without the ≈øatisfaction he expected.

About the end of September, Anno 1612, great troubles aro≈øe in the Kingdoms of Fe≈øs and Morocco occa≈øioned by a quarrel between the Prince Xerif-Muley-Cidan and Xerif-Muley-Achet-Ben-Abdula his nephew, when after many, battles fought between
them, the latter was overthrown, and in his flight ≈ølain, having drawn the people into Rebellion again≈øt his uncle under the pretence of a Prophe≈øie that foretold his ri≈øe, and the flouri≈øhing State of Barbary under his Government, which Prophecy him≈øelf not long before invented, yet many imagined that he dealt by inchantment, and often would he boa≈øt that no Bullet could hurt him, and indeed many were the Victories he gained over Cidan, even with a handful of men in compari≈øon to the great Armies which Cidan lead again≈øt him, his Allegation was that he was ≈øent from Heaven to purge the world of wicked men.

About this time the E≈øtates of the United Provinces under Prince Maurice, ≈øent Cornelius Hage their Amba≈ø≈øador to Con≈øtantinople with Commi≈ø≈øion to treat of the deliverance of the captive Hollanders, that had bin taken by the Turki≈øh Gallies, and to require free Traffick in all the Ports of the Ottoman Empire in con≈øideration of which to propo≈øe perpetual Amity with the Sultan, in all which he ≈øucceeded ≈øo well, that the Spani≈øh King was not a little grieved thereat, though him≈øelf was afterward obliged to enter into League with the Turk.

Tran≈øilvania altogether di≈øquieted, and weakned by civil di≈øcord, the Sultan thought it a fit time to reduce that Province to his obedience, and therefore rai≈øed a mighty Army and marched directly thither but whil≈øt he was on his way Fortifying all the important places in his pa≈ø≈øage, Co≈ømo d' Medicis the great Duke of Tu≈øcany, ≈øetting out a Fleet of Gallies ≈øpoiled the Sea Coa≈øts in the Mediterranean, and took many places from the Turks and among≈øt the re≈øt the ≈øtrong City of Agliman, with 2 Gallies that lay in the Port putting a number of Turks to the Sword by who≈øe example an. 1613. the Gallies of Sicily ≈øet out and de≈øtroyed the Turks Gallies in the Levant, making terrible ≈øpoil on the Sea-Coa≈øt landing ≈øeveral times on the I≈ølands of Chios, Samos and Cyprus, taking rich ≈øpoils and freeing many Chri≈øtian Captives, to oppo≈øe whom Ten
Turki≈øh Gallies came but after a terrible engagement, ≈øeven of them fell into the Chri≈øtians hands, and one was ≈øunk, the other two hardly e≈øcaping under the ≈øhelter of the night.

Achmats Army arriving in Tran≈øilvania committed many outrages, but upon notice that Bethlem Gabor was acknowledged Prince under the protection of the Sultan, and had ≈øent his ≈øubmi≈ø≈øion to him, the Tempe≈øt fo War grew calm, and the Turki≈øh power dreadful to the German Empire returned to Con≈øtantinople, at what time S ‚Ä¢ gi≈ømund Battor the Warlike Prince of Tran≈øilvania, who had depo≈øed him≈øelf and was retired to Prague, there to lead a private Life died; but the Turks upon their arrival at Con≈øtantinople found the City almo≈øt de≈øolate by rea≈øon the Plague raged there ≈øo, that Achmat and all his followers retired them≈øelves to Darut Ba≈ø≈øa, till the Contagion cea≈øed, and then in great pomp entered the City, publi≈øhing an Edict that all the Dogs therein ≈øhould be tran≈øported to Scutary in A≈øia, formerly called Chir≈øopolis, but the Inhabitants of that place, not willing to be trouble with ≈øuch Gue≈øts, although provi≈øion was allowed them, humbly be≈øought the Emperor to di≈øpo≈øe of them el≈øewhere, ≈øo that they were to the number of Fifty Thou≈øand put on ≈øhoar in a de≈øolate I≈øland where they all peri≈øhed. The rea≈øon why they were not killed was for that the Mufti had told Achmat it was not lawful, alledging that Dogs had Souls.

To conclude this year 1613 the Per≈øian King upon a ≈øu≈øpicion that the Armenians were about to reconcile them≈øelves to the Pope, and yield obedience to the See of Rome, which ≈øu≈øpicion was grounded upon forged Letters, he cau≈øed Twelve Hundred of them to be put to death, and kept ≈øtraightly
impri≈øoned double that number which made the Grca≈ø≈øians, Georgians, and Armenians with other Ea≈øtern Chri≈øtians ≈øend their Amba≈ø≈øadors to Achmat imploring Aid to protect them from the rage of the Per≈øians, to counterpoi≈øe which the Per≈øian King ≈øent likewi≈øe his Amba≈ø≈øador, but the Sultan would not admit him to Audience, till ≈øuch time as he heard his Ma≈øter had ≈øtayed the Per≈øecution.

Anno 1614. divers direful Prodigies were ≈øeen in Hungary, Sile≈øia, Au≈øtria, and other parts of Chri≈øtendom, which greatly amazed mo≈øt people, who ≈øuppo≈øed them to be the forerunners of great calamities but nothing followed except the downfal and death of the Na≈ø≈øuf the grand Vizar, who fell from the top of Honour into the depth of mi≈øery by offending his ≈øoon offended Ma≈øter, and by the Sultans Command was by Be≈øtanges Ba≈ø≈øa ≈ølain in his own hou≈øe, and that Head which during the time he ≈øtood high in the Sultans favour, had Governed the whole Ottoman Empire, ≈øtricken off and carried as a pre≈øent to Achmat, and in his ≈øtead Mechmet who had Marryed the Sultans Daughter was made chief Vizar.

Tran≈øylvania now rent from the German Empire, the Emperour laboured to recover it, and for that purpo≈øe ≈øent ≈øeveral tru≈øty Councelors to deal with the Nobility to ca≈øt off the Turki≈øh yoke, and to return to their former obedience; of which the Turki≈øh Sultan getting notice, ≈øent to the Emperor to admoni≈øh him to keep inviolate the peace concluded between them, and not to meddle in the affairs of Tran≈øylvania, though at the ≈øame time, by his Ho≈øtilities in Hungary he had mani≈øe≈øtly broke it, to which the Emperor replyed he was on his part
re≈øolved to keep the peace inviolate though the Sultan had already broken the Articles of the League, but as to his tamely parting with his Province of Tran≈øylvania confirmed to him by the ≈øame League, he would re≈øolve nothing therein till he had con≈øulted Princes of the Empire, with which an≈øwer the Chiaus returning to Con≈øtantinople.

The Emperor A≈ø≈øembling the E≈øtates, laid before them the ju≈øt Grievances of his Subjects, and the indignities offered to him≈øelf, with the manife≈øt breach of the League on the part of the Turks, in not only a≈ø≈øi≈øting his Rebels, but with great Companies of them≈øelves, making great ≈øpoil in his Hereditary Countries. To which the E≈øtates an≈øwered, that with all their power they would maintain the Dignity of the Emperor, and defend the Empire, of which re≈øolve Achmat was no ≈øooner advertized, but the better to encourage Bethlem Gabor, to invade the Emperors Frontiers, he ≈øent him a ≈øtrong power under the command of Sander Ba≈ø≈øa, with which he be≈øieged Lippa, and had it delivered to him, as he had al≈øo had ≈øeveral other places of le≈øs importance, which places were put into the po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of the Turks, but to remain part of the Tran≈øylvanian Principality.

Affairs ≈øtanding thus in Tran≈øylvania, Moldavia, was at the ≈øame afflicted, and brought low by the Tyranny of Stephano their Vayvod, who the better to ≈øecure him in his E≈øtate, had cau≈øed mo≈øt of the Nobility to be cruelly and ≈øhamefully murthered, upon which the Moldavians di≈ødaining the Tyrants rule, who was wont to ≈øay, that he valued not his Subjects love, ≈øo they feared him, ro≈øe in Arms again≈øt him, choo≈øing for their Prince Alexander ≈øon to Jeremy their former Vayvod, who with a great power entering the Countrey, had many ≈øtrong places put into
his po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion, which the Tyrant under≈øtanding, and finding the hatred of his Subjects generally bent again≈øt him, he fled, till ≈øtrengthened by a ≈øupply of Turks and Tartars, he again returned, and gave the Prince Battle, but was therein overthrown; after which Alexander was proclaimed with the con≈øent of all the Nobility Vayvod of Moldavia, whereupon he ≈øent Amba≈ø≈øadors to the Grand Seigniour, to inform him that he would do nothing prejudicial to his Imperial Maje≈øty, but that what he had done was at the in≈øtance of the Nobility, to free the Countrey from a Tyrant, but e'r the≈øe Amba≈ø≈øadors could arrive at Con≈øtantinople they were impri≈øoned, at the commandment of the Ba≈ø≈øa of Buda, and being afterward put into the power of Stephano, he cau≈øed their heads to be cut off and their bodies to be ca≈øt into the Danube, and then having recruited his Forces, returned again into Moldavia, where in a ≈øecond battle he was overthrown, and mo≈øt of his Army ≈ølain, him≈øelf hardly e≈øcaping to Michna Prince of Valachia; but ≈øoon after Alexander, having notice that the ≈øaid Michna and Hebraim a Turki≈øh Ba≈ø≈øa were rai≈øing great Forces to a≈ø≈øi≈øt Stephano, he ≈øent Boyartsk ye his Amba≈ø≈øador to Michna to make him his friend, or at lea≈øt to per≈øwade him to de≈øi≈øt from taking part with the Tyrant, but the proud Ba≈ø≈øa, contrary to the will of the Vayvod Michna, cau≈øed the Amba≈ø≈øador to be clapped in Irons, and ≈øent pri≈øoner to Con≈øtantinople, where upon his arrival, contrary to the Law of Nations he was condemned to the Gallies, to excu≈øe which, the Vayvod ≈øent an Amba≈ø≈øador to Prince Alexander, promi≈øing him that unle≈øs it were by the ab≈øolute command of the Grand Siegniour, which he dur≈øt not di≈øobey, he would not a≈ø≈øi≈øt his Competitor, and at the ≈øame time it being rumoured that Bethlem Gaber
was likewi≈øe rai≈øing Forces to invade Moldavia, the Prince ≈øent an other Amba≈ø≈øador to him, who to the Amba≈ø≈øador prote≈øted his innocency therein, and that he intended no harm to Alexander his ma≈øter, but on the contrary greatly de≈øired his friend≈øhip, and for his fathers ≈øake would a≈ø≈øi≈øt him in what lay in his power, but that which cau≈øed a great trouble in Moldavia was the death of Prince Vi≈ønouviskie, who was poi≈øoned by a Greek Prie≈øt in receiving the Sacrament, for which the impious actor was fryed to death in a wyer chair, having fir≈øt confe≈ø≈øed that he was induced to commit that helli≈øh exploite, at the in≈øtance of the Princes enemy, who upon the Prie≈øts detection were fled.

Anno 161.. at the ince≈ø≈øant intreaty of Stephano the Sultan ≈øent Skinder Ba≈ø≈øa with a powerful Army to to re≈øtore him to the Vayvod-≈øhip of Moldavia, whereupon Prince Alexander ≈øent to his friends as well in Polonia as in other parts of Chri≈øtendom, to Aid him again≈øt the Common Enemy, and thereupon received great Aid, e≈øpecially out of Polonia, under the leading of Prince Coreski, who ≈øhortly after Marryed the Prince≈øs Alexandrina, Si≈øter to Prince Alexander, and having refre≈øhed the Army, the two Princes as joynt Commanders, marched again≈øt the Ba≈ø≈øa, and in a ≈øet battle overthrew him near unto Cochona, together with the Forces of Stephano, and pur≈øuing their Victory entered Valachia, where entering Bonza without re≈øi≈øtance, he was by the E≈øtates of that Province, intreated to take upon him the Vayvod≈øhip; for that they being weary of the Turki≈øh thraldom, from which Michna their Vayvod had ab≈øolutely refu≈øed to free them, they re≈øolved for that rea≈øon to chu≈øe an other, but the Prince refu≈øed the charge, he would not deprive his friend of his po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion, yet con≈øented that
Prince Cherbanne ≈øon to the late Vayvod ≈øhould take the charge upon him, but whil≈øt the≈øe things were in agitation Shindar Ba≈ø≈øa had gathered a great power; and proclaimed Michna Vayvod of Moldavia, Stephano by rea≈øon of his frequent overthrows, being now fallen into di≈øgrace with the Sultan, and on a ≈øudden the ≈øaid Ba≈ø≈øa with his multitude invironed the Princes Camp, where he together with his mother, Prince Coreskie, and his fair Prince≈øs Alexandrina were taken pri≈øoners, as were all the Camp, except five hundred Polonians, who under the leading of the Lord Tischevi≈øh cut their way through the Army of the Turks, yet for a long time the Princes remained di≈øgui≈øed among≈øt the common pri≈øoners, in hopes of being admitted to their ran≈øoms, but at length all except the Prince≈øs Alexandrina were carryed to Con≈øtantinople; but ≈øhe falling into the hands of a Tartarian Captain, was carryed into Tartary, where ≈øhe was hardly dealt with, till at length ≈øhe was ran≈øomed for 3000 Chequins, having during her Captivity been delivered of a fair ≈øon.

The year following the Turks ≈øpoiled the Seacoa≈øt Towns of Italy, taking many rich prizes, and had the like repayed them by the Chri≈øtian Gallies in the Mediterranean, and greater mi≈øchiefs had in≈øued had not Achmet the Turki≈øh Sultan died, having lived thirty years, and reigned fifteen, appointed by rea≈øon of his ≈øons minority, his brother Mu≈øtapha whom he had a long time kept pri≈øoner, to ≈øucceed him in the Ottoman Empire.

div.head: CHAP. XIX. Mu≈øtapha the fir≈øt of that Name Ninth Emperour of the Turks his Life and Actions.
div.p:
AChmat being dead Mu≈øtapha his Brother, (the Fir≈øt that had been ≈øaved alive ≈øince the foundation of the Ottoman Empire) ≈øucceeded him by his appointment, his Children of which O≈øman was the Elde≈øt being too weak to ≈øway the Scepter of ≈øo mighty an Empire. So that this Mu≈øtapha, brought from a ≈øtraight Pri≈øon every day expecting Death, now advanced to a Throne to rule the Ea≈øt, forgeting his former devout Life, began to Tyrannize over his Subjects more then his Predece≈ø≈øors; which cau≈øed him to be hated of many, e≈øpecially for that he impri≈øoned the French Amba≈ø≈øador and his ≈øervants, breaking thereby the Law of Nations; upon pretence that they had been in≈øtrumental in the e≈øcape of Prince Coreskie out of the Black Tower, who by the a≈ø≈øi≈øtance of a Greek Prie≈øt de≈øcended from the top thereof, on a rople Ladder drawn up by a bottom of Packthred brought in a Pie to the ≈øaid Prince by the Amba≈ø≈øadors Secretary, though contrary to his knowledge, with the Prince likewi≈øe e≈øcaped one Rigaut a French Captain, who by the a≈ø≈øi≈øtance of the ≈øaid Prie≈øt, di≈øgui≈øed in Prie≈øtly Ve≈øtments for that purpo≈øe prepared, got pa≈ø≈øage into Italy, notwith≈øtanding all the Ports were be≈øet with their pur≈øuers. Nor was the Amba≈ø≈øador only impri≈øoned but his ≈øervants and him≈øelf
evilly intreated, e≈øpecially the former, two of which were put to the torture according to the Turki≈øh manner, which is to Iay them upon their Belly on a Table, and to beat their Buttocks, the Calves of their Legs, and Soles of their Feet, with a flat ≈øtaff, giving them ere they cea≈øe 100 or 200 blows, yet the Servants confe≈ø≈øed nothing, whereupon they caught a Weaver being a Turk, who≈øe Shop was near the Amba≈ø≈øadors hou≈øe: whom they tortured in the like manner, but he as the others had done could reveal nothing again≈øt the Amba≈ø≈øador, who for all that was obliged to pay 30000 Sultanies for his own relea≈øe and his Servants. The≈øe and ≈øuch like in≈øolencies, together with the Impri≈øonment of young O≈øman and his Brethren, made the Grand Vizar, who was then on the Confines of Per≈øia to ha≈øte to Con≈øtantinople with his Army, at who≈øe approach O≈øman was taken out of Pri≈øon and Proclaimed Emperour (≈øo ≈øuddain are the changes of fortune in great as well as little affairs) and the proud Sultan Mu≈øtapha inforced for fear of the inraged Souldiers to betake him≈øelf again to his Cell, or rather Pri≈øon, where for a while I ≈øhall leave him, and relate what happened during the Reign of O≈øman.

div.head: CHAP. XX. The Life and Actions of O≈øman the Fir≈øt of that Name, Tenth Emperour of the Turks.
div.p: THE Uncle after he had proudly Tyrannized for the ≈øpace of two Months, being depo≈øed, the Nephew was advanced to his Fathers Throne, being not full Thirteen years of Age, wherefore he was wholly governed by the Vizar Ba≈ø≈øa, as was al≈øo the whole Ottoman Empire, when the fir≈øt thing of moment that happened was the complaint of the French King, by two Gentlemen ≈øent for that purpo≈øe, by whom he demanded reparation of the new Emperour for the indignity he had ≈øu≈øtained by the Impri≈øonment of his Amba≈ø≈øador, and the evil treating of his Servants, letting him under≈øtand that he could not ≈øend any other Amba≈ø≈øador to his Court to condole the Death of Sultan Achmat his Father, nor congratulate his coming to the Empire till he had received ≈øatisfaction from him becoming his dignity. and the wrongs he had received in his Amba≈ø≈øador.

The Grand Vizar and Mufti hearing this Emba≈ø≈øie, and con≈øidering what had pa≈ø≈øed, adverti≈øed the young Emperour to ≈øend an Amba≈ø≈øador to the mo≈øt Chri≈øtian King, to Confirm the League, and to te≈øtifie both by Words and Letters, how much he was di≈ø≈øatisfied for his di≈øcontent; whereupon ∆≤ri
Chiaus was ≈øent with ample in≈øtructins, and ≈øo great an acknowledgment of the wrong done to the Baron of Mole, that the French King re≈øted ≈øatisfied, and calling the ≈øaid Amba≈ø≈øador home, he ≈øent the Earl of Sezi to ≈øucceed him as Amba≈ø≈øador at Con≈øtantinople.

The War continuing between the Turks and Per≈øians, about this time a great Battle was fought between them, wherein the Turks prevailing put the Per≈øians to flight with the lo≈øt of Ten Thou≈øand of them, and thereupon the Ba≈ø≈øa General of the Turki≈øh Army, pro≈øecuting his victory entered into the heart of Per≈øia, wa≈øting with Fire and Sword all that ≈øtood in his way, but at length having through daily skirmi≈øhes with the Enemy, and Di≈øea≈øes ari≈øing from want and evil Diet, lo≈øt a third part of his Army, he accepted of the Sophies propo≈øals of Peace, which were that he would yearly pay the Tribute of Silks, and at pre≈øent relieve his Army with all things nece≈ø≈øary. This Peace concluded by the Ba≈ø≈øa was allowed on by the Emperour and Ratified at Con≈øtantinople, whereupon Two Hundred Cammels laden with Silks were for many years after ≈øent to the Emperour according to Agreement.

Anno 1618. A fearful Comet was ≈øeen over the City of Con≈øtantinople, in form like a Turki≈øh Scimiter, placed near unto the Zenith under the Horizon, of a fiery colour, appearing very terrible for the ≈øpace of eight nights which made many conjecture it the forerunner of great blood≈øhed.

∆≤ri Chiaus returning out of France after he had di≈øpatched his affairs at that Court, came into England, where he was received and conducted to the
Court, and had Audience of King James his Speech being as followeth.

body.head: The Mo≈øt True Incomprehen≈øible and Mo≈øt High God, increa≈øe and multiply your Maje≈øties years, in all happine≈øs, Amen, O Thou Lord of the World.
body.p: THE mo≈øt invincible, mo≈øt mighty, and mo≈øt happy Sultan O≈øman Chan of the Othoman Empire Monarch, ≈øendeth to your excellent Maje≈øty a hundred thou≈øand Salutations and Greetings, evermore praying the mo≈øt High God, for your Maje≈øties happyne≈øs, ≈øendeth to your Highne≈øs with all po≈ø≈øible Honour and Renown, this his Imperial and mo≈øt Noble Letter, and with all hopeth that the Sacred bond of Peace, which hath been hitherto inviolably on your Maje≈øties part kept and ob≈øerved, your Maje≈øty will be plea≈øed ≈øtill on your part, with daily increa≈øes of more and more Friend≈øhip earne≈øtly to continue therein. And his Imperial Maje≈øty on his behalf is al≈øo re≈øolved in like manner evermore punctually to keep and continue the ≈øame.

Al≈øo the mo≈øt Mighty Emperours Tutor, and his chief Vi≈øier Ba≈ø≈øa, hath addre≈ø≈øed to the du≈øt of your Noble Feet, this his mo≈øt Honourable Letter, with a Thou≈øand commendations, praying everla≈øtingly the Mighty God, for Your Maje≈øties long Li≈øe and Happyne≈øs.

Al≈øo Your Maje≈øties Amba≈ø≈øador at Con≈øtantinople, your ≈ølave Paul Pindar bowing his forehead to the du≈øt of your Maje≈øties Feet, and mo≈øt humbly ki≈ø≈øing your Highne≈ø≈øes ble≈ø≈øed Feet, hath directed unto your Maje≈øty this his ≈øubmi≈ø≈øive Letter.

div.p:
This Speech ended, and the Emperours Letter delivered with ≈øuch other as the Chiaus brought, he was by the Kings command in great ≈øplendor conducted
to his Lodging, where after five or ≈øix days ≈øtay, he came again to Whitchall and made his conjue of leave upon his departure in the≈øe words, as near as they can be Tran≈ølated out of the Turki≈øh Language.

body.p: Mo≈øt happy Emperour, as I have with my own hands howing my ≈øelf to the du≈øt of your Princely feet, pre≈øented unto your Excellent Maje≈øty, the mo≈øt mighty and high Sultan O≈øman my Lord and Ma≈øter his Imperial Letter, ≈øo likewi≈øe I be≈øeech your Maje≈øty, that you will be plea≈øed in conformity thereof, to vouch≈øafe your Princely an≈øwer by your noble Letter, and to deliver the ≈øame into the hands of me your ≈ølave, and be ever partaker of all ble≈ø≈øedne≈øs and happine≈øs.

div.p: After he had made this Oration and received the Kings Letters, he was conducted to Dover by ≈øeveral of the Nobility, where imbarking in one of His Maje≈øties Ships he ≈øailed to Con≈øtantinople.

Anno 1619 great trouble aro≈øe in Bohemia upon the Emperours ≈øending an Army into that Country to ≈øuppre≈øs the Prote≈øtant Religion there flouri≈øhing, ≈øo that the Prote≈øtants tired with the cruelties of the popi≈øh Souldiers ≈øent to Bethlem Gabor Prince of Tran≈øilvania, to acquaint him with the ≈øtate of their affairs, who after he had obtained leave of the Grand Signeour, came with an Army of Eighteen Thou≈øand men into Hungary, and took many Towns, ≈øpoiling the Countrey as he went, nor ≈øo contented but he entered Au≈øtria, Stiria, and Carinthia, ≈øubdued all before him without oppo≈øition, but fearing if the Bohemians ≈øhould be ≈øubdued, the ≈øtorm would ≈øall upon him, he would not make a League with the Bohemians tell he was a≈ø≈øured of the Grand Signeours a≈ø≈øi≈øtance in ca≈øe his affairs required
in whereupon he ≈øent his Amba≈ø≈øador to Con≈øtantinople, who ≈øo dealt with the great Ba≈ø≈øa's of the Court that by their advice O≈øman ≈øwore to protect him, and becau≈øe the Oath for the ≈øtrange wording of it will not be ami≈øs to be recited I ≈øhall here in≈øert it verbatim.

body.p: BY the Grace of God unconquerable Turki≈øh Emperour Swears, by the highe≈øt Almighties, and Almighty Gods Holine≈øs, by his Kingdom, by the ≈øub≈øtance of the Heavens, the Sun, the Moon, and the Stars, by the Earth, and all under the Earth, by the Brains and all the hairy ≈øcalp of my Mother, by my Head, and all the ≈øtrength of my Soul and Body, by the Holy and great Mahomer, and by my Circumci≈øion, That I thee my Brother and Son Bechlem Gabor ≈øucceeding King of Hangaria in no manner of way in thy great and weighty affairs will leave, though it be to the overthrow of my Kingdom to be brought to nothing, until there ≈øhall be no more left but my ≈øelf, or four or five Turks at the mo≈øt, yet will I be ≈øtill obliged to de≈øend thee, and all tho≈øe that do any ways appertain unto thee, and if thou ≈øhalt have need of me, I ≈øhall be always ready to go with thee, and in ca≈øe this my promi≈øe ≈øhall in any wi≈øe be fru≈øtrated, then let Gods Ju≈øtice fall upon my Head and de≈øtroy me and my po≈øterity, and wipe away what≈øoever belongeth unto me, and gather it together into a Rock of ≈øtone or ≈øub≈øtance of Earth, and that the Earth may cleave in≈øunder and ≈øwallow me Body and Soul.

closer.dateline: Dated at Con≈øtantinople the 5th. of Jan. 1619.

div.p: The Tran≈øilvanian by this Oath a≈ø≈øured of the Grand Signeours favour ≈øent his Amba≈ø≈øadors to Prague, where meeting with the Commi≈ø≈øioners ≈øent thither for that purpo≈øe by the States of Bobemia, a perpetual League was concluded, and in June following the Prince a≈ø≈øembled the E≈øtates of Hungary at Newhau≈øell, where he propo≈øed to them the nece≈ø≈øity of rai≈øing an Army, to defend the Provinces, again≈øt the Forces of the Imperiali≈øts, who by their great preparations made it vi≈øible that they would no peace till they had de≈øtroyed all the Prote≈øtants, to this motion the E≈øtates con≈øented, when at the ≈øame time came their Amba≈ø≈øadors from the Grand Signeour, the Venetians and Polonians, all which made in the names of the re≈øpective principals a League with Gabor, which ≈øo much plea≈øed the E≈øtates of Hungary, willing to ≈øhake off the Imperial yoke that by the advice of their Palatine, the Tran≈øilvanian was proclaimed King of Hungary, upon which rai≈øing an Army of Fifty Thou≈øand Hor≈øe and Foot, he ≈øubdued almo≈øt all Au≈øtria, Carinthia, and Stiria, before the Emperours Forces could take the Field in any fit number to make head again≈øt him, at what time ≈øuch a fear was brought upon the great City of Vienna, that with the Emperours con≈øent the Prote≈øtants remaining therein, ≈øent their Deputies humbly to be≈øeech him that he would ≈øpare the City and Countrey for theirs their Wives and Childrens ≈øakes.

About this time a ≈øtrange apparition was ≈øeen in the Air over Medina Taluabi in Arabia, where Mabomet the Impo≈øtor lyes buryed, which terrified all the Countrey thereabouts, and was as followeth, about the 20th. of September at midnight there happened a terrible Tempe≈øt, accompanied with ≈øuch prodigious Thunder and Lightning, that many
thinking the di≈ø≈øolution of all things was at hand ‚Ä¢ leaped out of their Beds to gaze on the Element, at fir≈øt ≈øeeming all on Fire, and then covered with thick darkne≈øs, after which all was ≈øerene and calm, when in Arabian Characters the≈øe words appeared in the Firmament, viz. O why will you believe in lies, and ≈øoon after a Woman beautiful to behold, arrayed in white and incompa≈ø≈øed with rayes of Light appeared, holding in her hand a book, coming from the North, and oppo≈øite again≈øt her were ≈øeen Armies of Turks, Per≈øians, and other Mahometans, being ≈øo conjectured by their garbs ranged in Battalia, ready to charge her, but ≈øhe keeping her ≈øtanding no ≈øooner opened the book but they all fled, upon which a ≈øuddain murmur as of a Whirlwind troubled the Air, and immediately the lamps that were placed about Mahomets Tomb went out, and in this manner the Prodigy appeared for ≈øeveral nights together, whereupon a Dervice or Religious Turk undertaking to expound the meaning of that unu≈øual ≈øight, and declaring that it fore≈øhewed the overthrow of the Mahometan ≈øuper≈øtition, he was therefore mi≈øerably put to death, calling to the la≈øt upon the Woman with the Book to ≈øave him, and he had no ≈øooner given up the gho≈øt but a fearful Tempe≈øt in≈øued.

Anno 1620 Ga≈øparo the expul≈øed Vayvod of Moldavia a≈ø≈øi≈øted by the Poli≈øh Co≈ø≈øacks, and ≈øuch other Troops as he could rai≈øe invaded Moldavia, in which the Suitan had placed another Vayvod, and in revenge of a de≈øign the Turks had to ≈øtrangle him during his Vayvod≈øhip, made great ≈øpoil putting all the Turks he found to the Sword, and reducing great part of that Province to his obedience, which cau≈øed the Sultan to rai≈øe a great power, drawing all his choice Forces out of both the A≈øia's to the
number of Two hundred thou≈øand and cau≈øed a great Fleet of Gallies to put to Sea, which ≈øpoiled the Coa≈øt of Sicilia and Landing Five Thou≈øand Turks in the Kingdom of Naples, ≈øurprized the ≈øtrong Town of Manfredonia, carry 1500 Chri≈øtians into mi≈øerable Captivity, and then joyning with the Pirates of Argier they made a de≈øcent upon the I≈øland of Jani≈øa near Majorca, po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed by the Spaniards, which I≈øland they took making great ≈øpoil, putting to the Sword and carrying into Captivity all the Inhabitants.

The Turks thus ≈øucce≈øsful at Sea made them the le≈øs doubt their ≈øucce≈øs by Land, therefore having found an occa≈øion of quarrel with the Polonian King, for that the Co≈ø≈øacks in revenge of the injury they ≈øu≈øtained by the Tartars, had manned out many ≈ømall ve≈ø≈øels and ≈øpoiled the Turks Sea-Coa≈øt Towns upon the Bo≈øphorus, giving an overthrow to their Gallies, and brought away great ≈øpoiles) O≈øman in per≈øon at the head of 300000 men, pa≈ø≈øing through Moldavia which he again reduced to the obedience of the new Vayvod, he entered Podalia Anno Dom. 1621. where he found the great Chancelour of Poland, and the Prince Son to the Polonian King ≈øtrongly intrenched with an Army of 50000 re≈øolute Souldiers, and becau≈øe he could not draw them out of their ≈øtrengths he with his multitude inclo≈øed their Camp. So that by the frequent attacks and ≈øallies that were made, a great number were ≈ølain on both ≈øide, but e≈øpecially of the Turks; during which the Tartarian Prince then a≈ø≈øi≈øting O≈øman with 30000 light Hor≈øemon marched into the heart of Poland burning and de≈øtroying all before him in a mo≈øt terrible manner, and upon his return to the Camp be≈øides other ≈øpoils brought with him 25000 Pri≈øoners of the poor Countrey
people which his ravenous crue had ≈øcraped together, but after two months be≈øieging the Poli≈øh Camp, want growing great in the Sultans Army, and by rea≈øon of the advancement of the Sea≈øon ≈øuch terrible Rains fell, that Tents, Hor≈øes, Men, and Carriages were frequently carryed away by the impetuo≈øity of the Torrents thereby occa≈øioned. The Turks de≈øirous to depart ≈øent to the Chancelor to treat of Peace, which at the earne≈øt in≈øtance of Radulae Prince of Valachia was hearkened to, and ≈øoon after accorded the principal points being the≈øe.

Fir≈øt, That the Emperour ≈øhould rai≈øe his Army, and retire from the Confines of Poland, and that the Tartars the occa≈øion of this War, ≈øhould ≈øend an Emirze (that is one of their Princes) to re≈øide as a pledge to ≈øecure them from in≈øuing incur≈øions. The Chancelor in the Name of his Ma≈øter promi≈øing to ≈øend another Pledge to re≈øide in the Court of Tartary, with condition to pay yearly Forty Thou≈øand Florins as a donative from the King of Poland, promi≈øing moreover for the better maintainance of the Peace to maintain a Re≈øident in the Ottoman Court, and by every ≈øuch Amba≈ø≈øador to ≈øend a rich Pre≈øent, and as the Grand Signours Amba≈ø≈øador that was to re≈øide in the Court of Poland, ≈øhould undertake to ≈øecure the incur≈øions of the Tartars, ≈øo the Poli≈øh Amba≈ø≈øador ≈øhould undertake the ≈øame for the Co≈ø≈øacks, and that the Merchants of Poland ≈øhould have free Trade with the Subjects of the Grand Signeour making their u≈øual Pre≈øents, and this Peace not to be binding till ≈øuch time as the Achiaus ≈øhould arrive in the Poli≈øh Court with the overtures, and in the mean time a Parliament to be a≈ø≈øembled for the Ratification of the≈øe Articles.

Affairs being brought to this pa≈øs O≈øman rai≈øed his Camp, and returned to Adrinople, having lo≈øt in this Expedition eighty thou≈øand of his men, and of the Poles by rea≈øon of the un≈øea≈øonablene≈øs of the weather, and their often skirmi≈øhes, no le≈øs then twenty thou≈øand peri≈øhed. Now upon notice of the Turks approach, at the reque≈øt of the Polonian King, the Emperor of Germany, had ≈øent to his a≈ø≈øi≈øtance eight thou≈øand high Dutch Souldiers, upon notice of which O≈øman in a great rage proclaimed war again≈øt the Emperor, charging him with the manife≈øt breach of the League between them, though him≈øelf had been the fir≈øt aggre≈ø≈øor, by aiding the Tran≈øilvanian, but the King of Poland under≈øtanding, that what had happened was upon his account, (and that O≈øman kept his Army on foot about Adrinople, intending to invade the Emperors Countrey early in the ≈øpring, for that purpo≈øe having cau≈øed twenty thou≈øand Tartars to ≈øtay upon the frontiers) he called the Turki≈øh Chiaus before him, and declared that unle≈øs the Grand Seigneour his ma≈øter changed his purpo≈øe, he could not conclude with him any peace, for as much as he was bound to a≈ø≈øi≈øt the Emperor his confederate, if his Countries were invaded, which re≈øolve of the Kings being made known to O≈øman by his Chiaus, he called a Council of his Ba≈ø≈øa's wherein it was concluded that he ≈øhould leave Adrinople, and in≈øtantly ≈øet forward for Con≈øtantinople, which was accordingly put in execution, and the Tartars on the Frontiers di≈ømi≈ø≈øed, ≈øo that the war intended again≈øt the Emperor being laid a≈øide, news came that the Emir of Syria was ri≈øen in Rebellion, and had po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed him≈øelf of the City and Ca≈øtle of Tripolis; whereupon 60 thou≈øand Chequins were delivered out of the Trea≈øury, to repair the Grand Seigniors Pavillions and Carriages, him≈øelf with a powerfull
Army intending to make an Expedition again≈øt the Rebel, though contrary to the advice of mo≈øt of his Ba≈ø≈øa's, and the Mufti, who alledged that it was altogether needle≈øs, for his Maje≈øty to expo≈øe him≈øelf to the ill conveniencies of ≈øuch a war, as by the meane≈øt of his Ba≈ø≈øa's might be expiated, it being certain, that the Emir would not ≈øtand his Forces, but upon their approach fly into ≈øome part of Chri≈øtendom, and therefore if he ≈øet out his fleet of Gallies, he would either by Sea or Land fall into his hands, nor was it ≈øafe to leave Greece to the attempts of the Chri≈øtians, who in his ab≈øence might ≈øpoil it at their plea≈øure, the≈øe and ≈øuch like rea≈øons cau≈øed him to decline going in per≈øon, yet he ≈øent forth his Fleet and Army after the be≈øt manner ≈øending for Aid to Argire and Tunis, to awe the Spaniards likewi≈øe, who had ≈øixty Galleys and ≈øix Gallions at Me≈ø≈øina, prepared as was then conjectured to revenge the taking of Manfredo, and the ≈øpoil the Turks had made upon the Coa≈øts of Italy the year before, another Fleet of le≈ø≈øer con≈øequence he ordered to keep the black ≈øea, there to hinder the Co≈ø≈øacks from ≈øpoiling his Sea-Towns; after which, contrary to the Advice of his Council, he marryed the Grandchild of a Sultan a wife to Pertan Ba≈ø≈øa, only for her beauty, being indeed the Paragon of her ≈øex, which wedding was performed without any ≈øolemnity, and truly this marriage was greatly di≈øliked, for that his Ance≈øtors for many years pa≈øt, had not marryed at all in re≈øpect of kindred, nor taken any women to their Concubines of the Turki≈øh race, in re≈øpect of kindred, and that which rendred this young Prince more contemptible, was his walking up and down the City in di≈øgui≈øe, with a Page or two at the mo≈øt, and prying into Taverns, and other places like a petty Officer.

Things being at this pa≈øs, news came from the Ba≈ø≈øa of Buda, that Bethlehem Gabor had concluded a peace with the Roman Emperor, which greatly di≈øplea≈øed the Sultan and his Council, e≈øpecially for that the peace between him≈øelf and the Polack was not yet ratified, but the Poli≈øh Amba≈ø≈øador daily expected, in order thereto, when in the mid≈øt of his perturbations, Sir Thomas Row Amba≈ø≈øador from his Maje≈øty of Great Brittain, arrived at the Port, and had his Audience, delivering his Maje≈øties Letter, wherein he demanded redre≈øs of the injuries his ≈øubjects had ≈øu≈øtained by the Pirates of Algire and Tunes, then in ≈øubjection to the Sultan, as likewi≈øe the delivery of ≈øeveral of the Poli≈øh Nobility, and one Scotch Gentleman, which had been taken pri≈øoners in the late expedition into Poland, and among≈øt them the Prince Coreskie, who had formerly made his e≈øcape, out of the black Tower, with ≈øeveral other things that might create a good under≈øtanding and a continuation of the League between them, ≈øome of which were granted, and the other denyed, as the Grand Vizier (to whom the management of that affair was committed) thought fit, little to the ≈øatisfaction of his Maje≈øties Amba≈ø≈øador, but ≈øoon after the Grand Siegneor ≈øent his Letter to his Maje≈øty, containing a ≈øatisfactory reply to all that was demanded, except the relea≈øe of the Poli≈øh pri≈øoners.

Anno 1622, The Grand Seigneur, not hearing of the Duke Sbaraskie, cho≈øen Extraordinary Amba≈ø≈øador for the King of Poland, to con≈øummate the Peace, he gave it out that he would go to Mecha, and from thence to Medina in Arabia to vi≈øit Mahomets Tomb, contrary to the Council of Vi≈øiers, who knew not the de≈øign, and even to the hazzard of a General Revolt, for they were jealous that under colour
of that Voyage he had ≈øome other project, and that the Poli≈øh Duke arriving in his ab≈øence, would not follow him at a venture, nor treat with his deputies left at the Port.
