So that thereby all hopes of Peace would vani≈øh, which did not a little trouble the Turks, who≈øe Trade was greatly impaired by the roving Co≈ø≈øacks, which the Emperor under≈øtanding, and re≈øolving not to delay his journey, (or indeed his de≈øign to cut off the whole order of the Janizaries, for the in≈øolencies frequently offered him, by tho≈øe Ma≈øterful ≈ølaves) he ≈øent to ha≈øten Sbaraskie, upon who≈øe arrival a peace was concluded, though much to the prejudice of his Territories in Hungaria, and now that ob≈øtacle being removed, he ≈øent his Carriages over into A≈øia, with all his Trea≈øure, not ≈øparing the Plate and Ornaments of his Pallace, which made the Janizaries mi≈øtru≈øt ≈øome de≈øign more then ordinary, whereupon they re≈øolved to ≈øtop his proceedings, and therefore the day before he intended to depart, they with great clamour run to the Seraglio, though unarmed, and demanded Delavir the Vizier Ba≈ø≈øa, Hoja the Emperors confe≈ø≈øor, the Ca≈ølariago Governour of the women, the Deflardar or Trea≈øurer, the Cadelescher or chief Judg, with ≈øome other prime officers, whom they ≈øaid had Coun≈øelled their Emperor to undertake this dangerous Voyage, for which they re≈øolved to puni≈øh them with death, charging the Emperor ≈øtrictly that he ≈øhould neither go to Mecca, nor pa≈øs over into A≈øia.

To calm this Tempe≈øt the Emperor came forth in per≈øon, and u≈øed many arguments to per≈øwade them to their duty and Allegiance, promi≈øing he ≈øhould lay a≈øide his purpo≈øe, but now nothing would ≈øerve the≈øe mi≈øcreants, but they mu≈øt have the afore≈øaid Officers delivered to them, To which the Emperor replyed,
that his honour would greatly ≈øuffer if he ≈øhould permit his friends to be torn from him, but if they had offended in ought, and it was proved again≈øt them, in the Divano, whether they ≈øhould be brought to an≈øwer any accu≈øation that ≈øhould be objected again≈øt them, they ≈øhould be puni≈øhed by Law, but this did not pacifie them, for they clamoured yet louder, ≈øaying they knew them guilty, and that ≈øhould be ≈øufficient; whereupon they run to the hou≈øe of the Hoja, and not finding him there, plundered it, and from thence pa≈ø≈øing to the Grand Viziers hou≈øe, they thought to have done the like there, but finding it fortifyed, they ≈øet Guards in ≈øeveral parts of the City all night, and the next morning came before the Pallace with their Arms, making their demands as before; whereupon the Ho≈øa Cadeleschar and Tefterdar fled, and were not for a time found, as likewi≈øe did the Grand Vizier, with the con≈øent of the Emperor, who promi≈øed him≈øelf to weather this ≈øtorm, though in the end he proved too weak, yet was the Vizier brought back by a Hermit, a reputed Saint, after he was got into A≈øia, who tru≈øting to his innocence, re≈øolved to face the Tempe≈øt, but the rude multitude without re≈øpect to his Reverend Age, and great Merits, having gotten him into their power, cut him to pieces in the ≈øight of the Emperor, which he perceiving would, though too late, have fled over into A≈øia, for now all means were cut off, for the Janizaries had ≈øtopped the Port, and in a great rage demanded Mu≈øtapha the Emperors uncle, who was kept a pri≈øoner in the Seraglio, and the fir≈øt day of the Tumult by the Emperors command, put into a ≈øecret vault, with two Negro women, where after much ≈øearch, and the racking of ≈øeveral ≈øervants to make them di≈øcover him, he was found and born in Triumph through
the ≈øtreets, to the old Seraglio, having not yet been able to lay hands on O≈øman, by rea≈øon he kept him≈øelf within his ≈øtrengths, but hearing they intended to proclaim his uncle Emperor, he at the per≈øwa≈øion of the Mufti, putting him≈øelf in mourning, went with a few of his followers, and among≈øt them the Aga of the Janizaries, to the old Seraglio, and pre≈øented him≈øelf to the inraged Souldiers with tears, be≈øeeching them to return to their former obedience, and Loyalty, offering to make them any ≈øatisfaction, repenting him of his error, and finally invoked them by the merits of his Father and all his Anee≈øtors, to have ≈øome pitty upon him their true ma≈øter, This ≈øubmi≈ø≈øion a little calmed their fierce natures, ≈øo that they began to relent, and had again acknowledged their Lord, had not the Aga, ≈øuppo≈øing to Curry favour with the Emperor, ≈øharply reproved them of ingratitude and di≈øloyalty, which again rai≈øed the not extingui≈øhed fire, into ≈øuch a flame, that it was no more to be ≈øubdued; but fir≈øt having ≈ølain the Aga, and Huzein Ba≈ø≈øa, with ≈øeveral of the Emperors followers of le≈ø≈øer note, they ≈øeized on his per≈øon, and carryed him before Mu≈øtapha, demanding ≈øentence again≈øt him, when as the for≈øaken Prince, pleading for his life (and the new Emperor, not knowing how to condemn, only nodding in token that they might do what they plea≈øed) They after a con≈øult among≈øt them≈øelves, determined only to impri≈øon him whereupon they ≈øet him on hor≈øe-back, an in≈øolent Spahy changing Turbants with him, and carryed him to the ≈øeven Towers, denying by the way a draught of water, and then returning placed Mu≈øtapha in the Throne proclaiming him Emperor, and went to Sack the Hou≈øes of tho≈øe they had murthered.

Mu≈øtapha having once again mounted the Throne
and of a mi≈øerable Captive made the ≈øecond time Emperor, was per≈øwaded by Darut Ba≈ø≈øa, a villaine rai≈øed to that dignity by the new Emperor, that if O≈øman lived he would ≈øit unea≈øie in his throne, and that the Janizaries cooling on the matter, would again advance him the rightful Heir of the Ottoman Empire, whereupon it was concluded he ≈øhould be made away, the charge of which was committed to this wicked Coun≈øellor, who knowing his dignity would expire with Mu≈øtaphas, ≈øtrangled young O≈øman in pri≈øon, after he had reigned three years and ≈øome odd dayes, not exceeding ≈øixteen years of Age, and ≈øo an end was put to the de≈øign he had to ≈øubdue the German Empire, and afterwards all Europe, with ≈øuch ≈øucce≈øs he flattered him≈øelf, little remembring that when man propo≈øes, God di≈øpo≈øes.

One thing is worthy of note, a little before this Tumult happened, O≈øman dreamed that he rid a Camel, and being mounted he could not force him to go by fair means nor ≈øtripes, and that then de≈øcending in a rage to revenge it with his ≈øword, the body of the bea≈øt vani≈øhed, leaving in his hand only the head and bridle, at which dream being exceedingly troubled, he the next day ≈øends for one of his Wizards to interpret it, but he refu≈øed, per≈øwading him to apply him≈øelf to the Mufty, which he did, and had this Interpretation, viz. That the Camel ≈øignified his Empire, his Riding his abu≈øe in Government, his de≈øcen≈øion or alighting, his depo≈øing, the vani≈øhing of the body of the Bea≈øt, the revolt of his Subjects, the head and bridle remaining in his hand only a bare Title, and that he ≈øhould ≈øhortly dye and lo≈øe his Empire, the empty name only of Emperor accompanying him to his grave. And thus much for O≈øman Tenth Emperor of the Turks.

div.head: CHAP. XXI. Mu≈øtapha Reinthronized, with an Account of his proceedings till his ≈øecond Depo≈øing.
div.p:
M∆≤≈øtapha having as has been related, cau≈øed his nephew young O≈øman to be ≈øtrangled in pri≈øon, he made ≈øeveral new Ba≈ø≈øas, di≈øplacing ≈øuch as had been made by his Predece≈ø≈øor, lea≈øt getting power they ≈øhould revenge the death of O≈øman, nor were there ≈øome wanting that both de≈øired and attempted it, e≈øpecially Mechmet Ba≈ø≈øa Governour of Erzirum, in
‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ≈øia.

During the con≈øternation of the A≈øian Turks, at the death of their Emperor, putting them in fear the Empire would be di≈ø≈øolved, the Per≈øian King was not idle, but with a powerful Army recovered mo≈øt places taken from him, by the Turki≈øh Sultans, and the like might have been effected by the Chri≈øtians, had they not been at di≈øcord among≈øt them≈øelves, ≈øo that, that much dreaded Empire, would have been reduced into a ≈ømall circumference, which many afterwards though too late repented.

The new Sultan altogether governed by his Imperious Officer not yet ≈øuppo≈øing him≈øelf fa≈øt in the Throne, con≈øented to the making away the brethren of O≈øman, and children to Achmat the late Emperor, in order to Execute which bloody purpo≈øe, the Capi-Aga or Major Domo of the Seraglio, went to their Lodgings, with a purpo≈øe to ≈øtrangle
them, but the children crying out, ≈øeveral of the Pages run to their re≈øcue, and falling upon the me≈ø≈øengers of death, ≈ølew the Capi-Aga, and evilly intreated the others that attended him, and thereupon ≈øent word to the Janizaries and Spahis, who approved of their proceedings, commanding the body of the Aga to be hanged up in the Hippodrome, as a terrour to tho≈øe that ≈øhould attempt the like for the future, and in a rage went to the Pallace demanding Ju≈øtice on them that had Councilled ≈øo wicked a purpo≈øe, but the new Emperor, who differed not much from an ideot, ≈øolemnly prote≈øted he was altogether ignorant of the matter, and if ≈øuch command were procured, it was gotten by ≈øabreption, which Prote≈øtation was ea≈øily believed, yet Darut Ba≈ø≈øa, and the Emperors mother were vehemenly ≈øu≈øpected, when to appea≈øe the angry ≈øouldiers, the Ba≈ø≈øa was di≈øplaced from the Vizier≈øhip, Hazein Ba≈ø≈øa placed in his ≈øtead, and the Emperors mother hid in the Pallace till the Tempe≈øt was over, which could be no otherwi≈øe allayed then by a ≈øhowr of Gold Chequins.

After which, the new Vizier prote≈øting either to reform the affairs of the Empire, or fall a Sacrifice, did a little re≈øtore the face of Ju≈øtice, by making examples of ≈øome, and terrifying others with threats, in≈øomuch that he was looked upon as a man fit for tho≈øe boi≈øterous times, nor was that his only aim, but he re≈øolved when once ≈øettled in his place, to remove Mu≈øtapha, and place Morat brother to O≈øman in the Imperial ≈øeat, not thinking him≈øelf ≈øafe, under a man that was altogether governed by an imperious woman, de≈øirous of Rule, and was no further capable of the pa≈ø≈øions of love and hate then they were infu≈øed into him.

During the≈øe troubles of the Ottoman Empire, the
Duke Sbaraskie lay upon the Frontiers, and would not advance to ratifie the peace between the King his ma≈øter and the new Sultan, till ≈øuch time as Sir Thomas Rowe his Maje≈øty of Great Brittains Amba≈ø≈øador, then re≈øident at the Port had given him his faith for his ≈øecurity, which done, the Duke advanced, and upon his arrival at the Port, was magnificently entertained by the new Vizier, yet e'r any thing was ab≈øolutely concluded, a matter happened which had like to have turned all into nothing; for on the 17 of June 1622 Prince Coreskie, who had been taken in the late war between O≈øman and Sigi≈ømund King of Poland, was ≈øtrangled in pri≈øon at Con≈øtantinople, which put all into murmur and deep con≈øideration, to what intent it was done, when ≈øo great a ran≈øom might have been had for his relea≈øe, but mo≈øt believed it was done out of a Politick end, for that the Prince being a mortal enemy to the Turks, if he ≈øhould have been ≈øet at liberty, his re≈øtle≈øs nature would not have ≈øuffered the peace to have continued long inviolable, yet the urgent affairs of Poland ≈øo requiring, the Peace was concluded in nineteen Articles, much to the advantage of the Polonian King, the Turks greatly fearing at that juncture, the Chri≈øtians uniting again≈øt them, might di≈ømember their Empire.

The new Vizier by this time having won the affections of the Souldiers, re≈øolved upon his former purpo≈øe of Depo≈øing Mu≈øtapba, and ≈øetting up Morat Brother to O≈øman, then a child, and the better to forward his purpo≈øe, he cau≈øed the Aga of the Janizaries, and ≈øeveral Officers of the Court to be ≈øeized, as contrivers of the death of Coreskie, whom him≈øelf had commanded to be ≈øtrangled, which rai≈øed another Tumult; for the Janizaries running furiou≈øly to the Court, demanded their Captain, whom
the Ba≈ø≈øa had ordered to be put to death, and had done great mi≈øchief had he not been delivered, nor were they ≈øo contented, but peremptorily demanded the head of the Vi≈øier, ≈øolemnly prote≈øting to facrifice him for the affront done to their order; upon which e≈øcaping through the Emperors Garden, he took boat and pa≈ø≈øed over into A≈øia, whereupon they ≈øacked his hou≈øe, and found therein great ≈øtore of Trea≈øure, they likewi≈øe demanded the heads of ≈øeveral others, but in the end all was hu≈øhed, yet they proceeded to the Election of a new Vi≈øier, making choice of one Mu≈øtapha, a man of a ≈øoft nature and ea≈øily ruled, who ≈øcarcely dur≈øt do Ju≈øtice for fear of offending any man, which proceeding of the in≈øolent Janizaries neverthele≈øs, cau≈øed the wi≈øer ≈øort of men to retire from office and imployment, and to the in≈øufficient daily change and ruine; for the Emperor dur≈øt not move but by the directions of the Souldiers who≈øe creature he was, ≈øo many in≈øolencies were frequently committed, and all A≈øia greatly endangered to be lo≈øt, for at Bagdat antiently Babylon, the Captain of the Janizaries killed the Ba≈ø≈øa, burnt the Mufti, and gave his daughter in Marriage to one A≈ø≈øan Beg, pretender to an Antient Inheritance of a bordering Province, to cantonize that part nor A≈øia only ≈øtood in ≈øu≈øpence what to do, but the Dominions of the Turki≈øh Sultan in Africk, greatly wavered, as doubting whom to obey.

On the 22 of Augu≈øt, an Extraordinary Amba≈ø≈øador from Bethlehem Gabor Prince of Tran≈øylvania arrived at the Port, who among≈øt other in≈øtructions had order to excu≈øe his ma≈øter, and to declare the rea≈øons, why he had made peace with the Emperor, without the knowledge of the Sultan, which were, that the war had continued three years in the Kingdom of Hungary and had ≈øo wa≈øted the Country, that
it was impo≈ø≈øible for him to ≈øtay longer in the field unle≈øs he would have expo≈øed his Army to tho≈øe wants, that would have reduced him to have accepted of an inglorious peace, or to have ≈øuffered a great part of his Souldiers to peri≈øh for want, and that if he had ≈øtood out upon the peace concluded between the Sultan and the Polonian, the whole ≈øtre≈øs of War would have re≈øted on him and therefore he de≈øired to be excu≈øed, adding that he meant not long to con≈øerve the peace, therefore de≈øired that he and the Ba≈ø≈øa of Buda might have it in joynt Commi≈ø≈øion to rai≈øe ≈øuch Forces as they thought convenient to invade the Empire, when opportunity offered, but this reque≈øt not agreeing with the intere≈øt of the Sultan it was rejected.

About this time the Janizaries in a tumultuary way came to the Court and demanded all the Offices of gain, and to be Stewards of the Revenues of the Churches which are great as likewi≈øe to take the Farms of Cu≈øtoms wherein they committed many outrages, the Vi≈øiers not daring to deny them any thing they demanded. They drunk Wine in the ≈øtreets without prohibition contrary to their Law, and exacted money of the Chri≈øtians to purcha≈øe it, and if denyed took it by force, and murthered without being puni≈øhed, and when at any time complaint was made the Magi≈øtrates an≈øwered they dur≈øt not meddle with them, that had murthered their King, and the Ba≈ø≈øa's them≈øelves de≈øired the complainants patience, telling them that they would bear a part with the general ≈øufferance.

About the ≈øame time the Janizaries in the Gallies which rid before Smirna commanded by Halil Ba≈ø≈øa,
a≈ølaulted again≈øt his will the hou≈øes of the Chri≈øtian Con≈øuls, in≈øomuch that the Engli≈øh Con≈øul with all tho≈øe of that Nation, were forced to run naked from their Lodgings, and ≈øave their lives by ≈øwimming to the Admirals Gally, upon which the ma≈øterle≈øs Turks ran≈øacked the lower part of the hou≈øe there, making ≈øpoil to the value of Two Thou≈øand Dollars. The French ≈øu≈øtained more lo≈øs, and the Venetians at lea≈øt ten Thou≈øand Dollars, the Con≈øul having likewi≈øe one of his men cut in pieces, nor could the Admiral either by threats or intreaties re≈øtrain the≈øe outrages, but was forced for the prevention of further mi≈øchief to put to Sea.

In A≈øia there were three Rebellions, one at Babylon, another at Arzirum upon the borders of Per≈øia, and a third at Me≈øopotamia, which threatned the ruine of all A≈øia; yet to prevent the wor≈øt ≈øeveral new officers were made, and an Army rai≈øed in Grecia, in order to pa≈øs the Helle≈øpont, but in the end nothing was done more then a≈ø≈øembling to little purpo≈øe, all the Turki≈øh Forces on Europe ≈øide, which ≈øo impoveri≈øhed the Trea≈øury that the like had not formerly been known, nor were any Exactions and Extortions omitted to rai≈øe mony for defraying the nece≈ø≈øary charges.

About this time came to the Court of Poland, an Amba≈ø≈øador from the great Duke of Mu≈øcovy to intreat a peace, which was hardly granted by rea≈øon ≈øeveral Letters of the ≈øaid Amba≈ø≈øadors being intercepted, plainly demon≈øtrated that at his fir≈øt ≈øetting out his de≈øigns were otherwi≈øe, upon notice that a Peace was concluded with the Sultan, he feigning him≈øelf ≈øick upon the Frontiers, had ≈øent for new in≈øtructions.

Darut Ba≈ø≈øa who had married Sultan Mu≈øtapha's Si≈øter falling into the di≈øplea≈øure of the Vi≈øier, he ≈øo dealt with the Spahi, that coming to the Court they demanded his Head for the murthering the late Emperour, and having gotten him into their hands were about to behead him, but whil≈øt he was upon his knees, every woman expecting the fatal blow, the Janizaries at the in≈øtance of the Sultans Mother re≈øcued him and carryed him to their Colledge, promi≈øing him their protection, for which he be≈øtowed among≈øt them Forty Thou≈øand Chequins. But that availed not, for ≈øoon after he was taken thence and carryed to the pri≈øon where he had murthered young O≈øman and there ≈øtrangled, now the better to plea≈øe the Polonians and ob≈øtruct the cau≈øe of War for the future, the Amba≈ø≈øador was not only di≈øpatched with ≈øeveral Noblemen of Poland, who had ≈øince the late War remained Pri≈øoners, but it was likewi≈øe concluded that Jehan Begh, the Tartarian Prince, Author of the War ≈øhould be depo≈øed, and Michmet Geheray his Co≈øen, and fir≈øt of the Blood, late Pri≈øoner at the Rhodes, ≈øhould ≈øucceed him in that large Kingdom.

A≈øia was ≈øtill in doubt to be lo≈øt for that Aba≈ø≈øa Ba≈ø≈øa Governour of Arzirum, with an Army of one hundred thou≈øand Hor≈øe and Foot had ≈øiezed upon mo≈øt of the Provinces, though without doing any harm to the inhabitants, but where≈øoever he found any of the Janizaries he ≈øacrificed them to the Gho≈øt of the dead Emperour, he as he ≈øaid being by God appointed the revenger of his Death, and for that cau≈øe he had taken up arms declaring that he would come to the Port and demand Ju≈øtice upon the Murtherers, and that if he was found a Traytor or
guilty, he would lay down his head willingly; but if tho≈øe he accu≈øed were found guilty, he would ≈øee execution done, nor did the Nobility of Con≈øtantinople much di≈øapprove of his march, rather e≈øteeming him a friend then an Enemy, who came to deliver them from the Tyranny of the Janizaries, who≈øe in≈øolencies were in≈øufferable. Yet to prevent the wor≈øt it was re≈øolved that Mu≈øtapha ≈øhould be depo≈øed, the Janizaries not gain≈øaying it, for that they well knew they alone ≈øhould be expo≈øed to the fury of the Ba≈ø≈øa, at the rooting out of who≈øe order he chiefly aimed, though he had likewi≈øe other de≈øignes which were to wre≈øt the Grand Vi≈øier≈øhip from him that held it, and make him≈øelf Governour of the young Prince Brother to O≈øman, whom he intended to advance to the Empire; yet rather for ≈øhew then otherwi≈øe the Souldiers were ordered to pa≈øs the Helle≈øpont in great numbers, but the Janizaries would not ≈øtir for two rea≈øons, fir≈øt for that the time of receiving their pay was at hand, and ≈øecondly fearing alone to be expo≈øed to the fury of the A≈øian Army, greatly doubting that if it came to a Battle their Fellows would revolt, and by that means ea≈øily bring them to de≈øtruction.

div.head: CHAP. XXII. The Life and Reign of Morat or Amurath the 4th. the 11th. Emperour of the Turks.
div.p: IN this di≈øtraction of the Ottoman Empire, the better to calm the tempe≈øt ere it turned all into confu≈øion by Shipwracking the State, the Grand Vi≈øier going with the Janizaries and Spahi to the Seraglio, demanded to ≈øpeak with Mu≈øtapha, and that he would an≈øwer them a few que≈øtions, which he being no ways able to do, and refu≈øing to appear they entered the Palace, and took thence Morat or Amurath Brother to O≈øman, and Son to Achmat then about 14 years of Age, and carrying him through the ≈øtreets in triumph, cau≈øed him every where to be proclaimed Emperour to the great content of the Con≈øtantinopolitans, who by this mutation hope for peaceful times, and the face of Ju≈øtice re≈øtored which for many months had abandoned the City, every man doing in a manner what he plea≈øed.

Thed ay after this innovation the young Emperor made his publique entry, from who≈øe lively countenance and apparent activity, every one promi≈øed great things during his Reign; but at that time ≈øuch had been the policy of the covetous Souldiers whom Mu≈øtapha had continually ≈øupplyed with the Imperial Trea≈øure, to ≈øupport his bad Title to the Turki≈øh Diadem, that Money was wanting to ≈øupply nece≈ø≈øary occa≈øions. In≈øomuch that the Janizaries were obliged to remit the Large≈øs u≈øually be≈øtowed
upon with an Augmentation of their pay at the Coronation of every Emperour, and that money which was found was for the mo≈øt part adulterated, in≈øomuch that the Vi≈øier ≈øent to the Amba≈ø≈øadors of the Chri≈øtian Princes re≈øiding there to borrow Thirty Thou≈øand Dollars, and narrow ≈øearch was made after the Trea≈øure that had been conveyed away by the Ba≈ø≈øa's that bore ≈øway during the di≈øtraction in which ≈øearch Eight Hundred Thou≈øand Dollars were found that had been imbezled by the Vi≈øier Darut.

During the≈øe Tran≈øactions Aba≈ø≈øa Ba≈ø≈øa had po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed him≈øelf of all mo≈øt all A≈øia, whereupon it was thought nece≈ø≈øary by fair means to per≈øwade him to lay down his Arms, and the rather to induce him ≈øo to do, the Emperour ≈øent unto the Capigi Ba≈ø≈øa with a Ve≈øt, Sword and Letters of Credence giving him thanks for the love he had ≈øhewed to his Brother and his Blood, but now the revenge belonged to him≈øelf of which he would take care, and therefore de≈øired him if he were a true ≈øubject as he profe≈ø≈øed him≈øelf to be to return to his Government of Arzirum, after having di≈ø≈øolved his Army, and there to re≈øt till further occa≈øion required his ≈øervice. Upon this order from the Emperor he excu≈øed him≈øelf, that the far advancement of the ≈øea≈øon would not permit him to retire, but promi≈øed to live in peace until the ≈øpring and then to return in obedience to his Government. Nor was this all for the Ba≈ø≈øa or Emir of Sidon was up in Arms, and with an Army of Thirty Thou≈øand men had ≈øeized the ≈øtrong City and Ca≈øtle of Dama≈øcus, and was ≈øuppo≈øed to hold confederacy with the Chri≈øtian Princes being him≈øelf no favourer of the Mahometan ≈øuper≈øtition, and be≈øides he was a Prince by de≈øcent and claimed a right to tho≈øe Countries, as the antient inheritance of his Predece≈ø≈øors
nor was the Emperor in a condition to repre≈øs him by force, therefore intreaties were u≈øed as to the former with many large promi≈øes, nor was the Tran≈øilvanian Prince quiet though in a different nature, for contrary to his League with the Emperor in a ho≈øtile manner he entered Hungary, and po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed him≈øelf of ≈øeveral Towns: To oppo≈øe whom the Imperiali≈øts rai≈øed a con≈øiderable Army and incamped in the way he was to pa≈øs, yet was his coming ≈øo ≈øuddain that he cut off ≈øeven hundred ≈øtraglers of the Imperiali≈øts, and had ≈øurprized the Camp had not the alarum been given by ≈øome that fled, yet with his whole Army he ≈øo pre≈ø≈øed them, that they were forced to betake them≈øelves to a ≈ømall Town Ghoding upon the River of Moran, where they Fortified under a Ca≈øtle that defended it; but in the end oppre≈ø≈øed with cold and hunger they ≈øent to the Prince to make truce which with the con≈øent of Sultan Morat was accorded on the≈øe con≈øiderations. Fir≈øt, That the Emperour ≈øhould di≈øclaim all right to Hungary, and ≈øhould leave the people free under the Government of the Prince of Tran≈øilvania. Secondly, That the Prince and all the Provinces that had ≈øent their Amba≈ø≈øadors to the Port, and had made league with him, and had taken the Imperial protection ≈øhould be re≈øtored to their antient Liberty and E≈øtates. Thirdly, That the Emperor ≈øhould pay an annual Tribute of forty thou≈øand Dollars, pretended to be granted in the dayes of Solyman for Au≈øtria, and that the Prince, and the Ba≈ø≈øa of Buda, ≈øhould have full power, if they found it convenient at any time to conclude a Peace on the part of the Ottoman Emperor, and that all Cities, Towns, and Ca≈øtles ≈øhould remain in the hands of tho≈øe that po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed them, a free intercour≈øe of Trade being
allowed between the Subjects of the one and the other Empire.

This done the Prince of Tran≈øilvania made ≈øhew as if he would redeem all the poor Captives taken by the Turks at his own charge, with ≈øome ≈ømall a≈ø≈øi≈øtance from the Imperiali≈øts, upon whom he layed the fault, that it was not done, for as much as they failing to ≈øend their Commi≈ø≈øioners to treat about the matter, the Turks in the night time decamped, and carried away with them contrary to his plea≈øure twenty thou≈øand Chri≈øtians into mi≈øerable Captivity. He likewi≈øe warned the Turks to keep in order and not to ≈øtraggle in their retreat, nor to commit any in≈øolency or ≈øpoil, for that the Country was all in Armes, and already inraged, but they not following his Council two thou≈øand Hungarian Hor≈øe fell upon their Rear, and cut off ≈øix hundred of them; whereupon they turned head and de≈øtroyed many Villages, killing and taking Pri≈øoners all that came to hand, and among≈øt the re≈øt one of the Hungarian Lords.

By this time the Per≈øian de≈øirous to di≈ømember the Ottoman Empire, with a powerful Army entred the Turki≈øh Dominions in the Province of Babylon, and greatly Alarumed that City, whereupon a war was proclaimed again≈øt him at the Port, and all Souldiers in the Emperors pay commanded to repair to the rendezvous upon pain of Confi≈øcation, and their wives and children being ≈øold for ≈ølaves, it was likewi≈øe propounded that a reconciliation ≈øhould be made between the Emperor and Aba≈ø≈øa Ba≈ø≈øa at any rate, lea≈øt he ≈øhould joyne with the Per≈øian, and that being ≈øo gained he might be imployed as General of Turki≈øh Army, but the Janizaries would not hear of the advancement of their mortal enemy, but rather ‚Ä¢ e≈øired to be led again≈øt him and fight it out to the
utmo≈øt, but the Spahi were of another mind, as rather inclinable to the Ba≈ø≈øa, yet the Janizaries di≈øplaced their Aga, for di≈ø≈øwading them therefrom, and ≈øet up in his ≈øtead a page of the Court.

Thus whil≈øt it was unre≈øolved how to proceed, the Per≈øian King omitted no opportunity, but Conquered the Province and City of Babylon, put to flight Hafis Ba≈ø≈øa, General of that defen≈øive war, and took pri≈øoner Chur Ha≈ø≈øen Ba≈ø≈øa a renowned old Souldier, and cutting in pieces all that oppo≈øed him, found means to ≈øeize upon Mo≈øul (antiently called Ninivie) and Laska, on the Per≈øian Sea, and dividing his Army, ≈øent part towards Van and Diarbeck, and the other towards Mecha, incompa≈ø≈øing by that means all that part of the Turks Dominions.

About this time his Maje≈øty of Great Brittain, by his Amba≈ø≈øador re≈øiding at Con≈øtantinople, complained of the injuries his Subjects Trading in tho≈øe Seas, had ≈øu≈øtained by the Pirates of Argier and Tunis, who in two years ≈øpace, had taken about one hundred Engli≈øh Ve≈ø≈øels, mo≈øt of them richly laden, wherefore the Amba≈ø≈øador demanded that they might be puni≈øhed for violating the League, and be forced to re≈øtore ≈øuch Ve≈ø≈øels with their lading, as were found not to be imbezled, or that they might be left to his Maje≈øty to puni≈øh without any offence to the Grand Seigneour, but many of the Ba≈ø≈øas being intere≈øted in tho≈øe Piracies, nothing more could be procured then a Letter to the Ba≈ø≈øas of tho≈øe two Cities, to ≈øend their Commi≈ø≈øioners to to the Port, to an≈øwer to what was objected again≈øt them, and at length to promi≈øe not any more to mole≈øt the Engli≈øh, in order to the confirmation of which, ≈øeveral Articles were drawn, and delivered to Sir Thomas Rowe, then re≈øiding at the Port, with
the Grand Seigneours Letter of command to the Dage Ba≈ø≈øa and Divan of Argier and Tunis to forbear a≈ø≈øaulting or in the lea≈øt injuring any Engli≈øh ≈øhips, or the Subjects of the King of England, in what part of the Ottoman Empire ≈øoever they re≈øided, in≈øomuch that the fear of puni≈øhment, did for the ≈øpace of five years deter tho≈øe Pirates from mole≈øting the Engli≈øh, either by Sea or Land, and the better to ingratiate them≈øelves, they delivered ≈øix hundred Engli≈øh Marriners (which they had taken at divers times) without Ran≈øom, but upon the Expiration of the years afore≈øaid they again robbed and ≈øpoiled the Merchants ≈øhips Trading in tho≈øe parts, but were frequently met withall by the Engli≈øh men of war that were ≈øent into tho≈øe Seas to ≈øecure the Traffick.

Anno 1624 on the 24 of March Ali Ba≈ø≈øa the great Vi≈øier, by who≈øe means Morat was advanced to the Crown, was ≈øent for into the Seraglio, where being que≈øtioned by the young Emperor about the affairs of the Per≈øian Inva≈øion, and not an≈øwering to the ≈øatisfaction of tho≈øe pre≈øent, he was then and there at the commandment of the Emperour beheaded, and his body ca≈øt out into the ≈øtreet (which cau≈øed much murmuring among≈øt his friends) and one Creques Mechemet advanced to the Dignity of Grand Vi≈øier, but he was not ≈øettled in his place before news came that the Roman Emperour had entered Hungary with an Army of Fifty Thou≈øand Hor≈øe and Foot, re≈øolving to recover the Towns a little before take by Bethlem Gabor Prince of Tran≈øilvania, and that the Co≈ø≈øack with four hundred Boats were abroad in the Black Sea, and had taken many ve≈ø≈øels laden with Provi≈øion, as likewi≈øe made great ≈øpoil upon the Coa≈øt. To prevent which the Ba≈ø≈øas of Buda, Teme≈øwar, Bo≈øna, Cani≈øa, and Agria, received
Orders to joyn with the Tran≈øilvanian, and ≈øeveral Gallies di≈øpatched into the black Sea, nor were the preparations again≈øt the Per≈øians ≈ølackned, who ≈øtill marched on conquering, for by this time Aba≈ø≈øa Ba≈ø≈øa upon the receipt of the Grand Signeours pardon had ≈øubmitted him≈øelf, and with the forces under his command marched towards the frontires, to joyn with Hafis Achmet Ba≈ø≈øa who made head on that ≈øide, by which the ≈øu≈øpicion of the Janizaries being removed they to the number of Thirty Thou≈øand were mu≈øtered for the Wars, and Forty thou≈øand Spahi, their rendezvous being appointed about Bru≈ø≈øia, and at the ≈øame time Biram Ba≈ø≈øa was di≈øpatched General of the frontires of Poland and Bugdania with Four thou≈øand Souldiers, and Orders to command all the Begs and Sanzacks, to rai≈øe ≈øuch forces as they could and joyn him to prevent the incur≈øions of the Co≈ø≈øacks, and more Gallies ≈øent into the black Sea, to tran≈øport Jean Gheray Han Prince of Tartary the year before depo≈øed by Mechmet, and to re-e≈øtabli≈øh him in his Kingdom, but Mechmet having notice of his arrival, rai≈øed an Army of Sixty thou≈øand Hor≈øe, and drove him from the Land with the ≈ølaughter of many Turks, which ≈øo inraged the Grand Signeour that as he ≈øaid, his honour being engaged he re≈øolved to re-inthrone him, for Mechmet was ≈øu≈øpected of holding corre≈øpondence with the Per≈øian, to who≈øe proceeding the Turks and Arabians had by this time put a ≈øtop, but failed therein, for the Captain Ba≈ø≈øa with a great Army Landing the ≈øecond time was routed, two Ba≈ø≈øas and about Five thou≈øand Turks ≈ølain, as many taken Pri≈øoners, and Twenty pieces of Cannon, with much rich Furniture left to the Tartars, who by that means found that they were able to deal with the Turks.

Things falling out thus in Tartary, the Co≈ø≈øacks taking the advantage of the Turki≈øh Fleets ab≈øence, with Eighty Boats or ≈ømall Barks entered the ≈øtraights of Bo≈øphorus, where lying before Con≈øtantinople, they brought a general fear upon that great City, and after having plundered and razed ≈øeveral Towns upon the Sea Cea≈øt, they returned in Triumph unoppo≈øed, which good ≈øucce≈øs imboldened them with a greater number of Ve≈ø≈øels to adventure a ≈øecond time, when as before they returned with a great booty, the Turks not being able to prevent it. About the ≈øame time the Pirates of Tunis and Argiers revolted from the Grand Signeours obedience, and robbed many of his Ports in the Mediterranean, taking ≈øuch Ships as they found therein, and ≈øetting fire to a great number of Storehou≈øes, ≈øo that the lo≈øs the Chri≈øtian Merchants ≈øu≈øtained by them in one Expedition amounted to 4 Millions of Ducates, nor did they le≈øs harm by Land to ≈øuch as bordered on their Country, neither regarding Friends or Foes any longer then ≈øtood with their conveniency and profit, being indeed Enemies to all men; which inte≈øtine troubles obliged Morat to conclude a Peace with Mechmet, the Tartar Prince di≈ø≈øembling the intentions he had to depo≈øe him, laying all the fault of what had happened upon the Captain Ba≈ø≈øa, who≈øe head had like to have gone off to have rendered his Ma≈øters ≈øtory plau≈øible, ≈øuch danger are tho≈øe in that live under a Tyrant, who≈øe will is his Law, not weighing Ju≈øtice nor good de≈øerts further then may ≈øerve his purpo≈øe. Yet blood was not wanting for Huzein Ba≈ø≈øa who ≈øometime before fled, being taken and brought to Con≈øtantinople, where (after in hopes to ≈øave his Life, he had confe≈ø≈øed his Trea≈øure) he was ≈øtrangled. Aba≈ø≈øa Ba≈ø≈øa notwith≈øtanding the ≈øpecious ≈øhews he made to march again≈øt the Per≈øians,
linger'd greatly, which gave the Janizaries a ≈øu≈øpicion that he had contrived the matter only to draw them into his danger, and then to de≈øtroy them as he had formerly purpo≈øed, which opinion of theirs had turned all again into confu≈øion, had he not at that in≈øtance reconciled him≈øelf to the Grand Vi≈øier, and prote≈øted that he would not hurt the Janizaries, but u≈øe his Arms in defence of the Empire. So that by ≈øwearing three times on the Alcoran, that no violence ≈øhould be done on either ≈øide, all animo≈øities vani≈øhed, the Government of Arzirum being confirmed to him, and he allowed a competent number of Souldiers to guard the frontires, as likewi≈øe places of tru≈øt be≈øtowed upon mo≈øt of his chief Officers, but upon the Janizaries putting many of his Friends to the Sword who had yielded them≈øelves to the Grand Vi≈øier, he in a rage fell into their quarter, making ≈ølaughter of three or four thou≈øand of them, though not without the lo≈øs of as many of his own men, but finding that the Vi≈øier had drawn up his Army in Battalia, he ≈øounded the retreat and marched to his Government, and the Vi≈øier kept on his way towards Diarbecher to ≈øeek the Per≈øian, when in the mean time the Per≈øian General treated with Aba≈ø≈øa to deliver up the City of Arzirum, to the King his Ma≈øter promi≈øing in lieu thereof great rewards, but he knowing upon ≈øuch terms he could at any time make his peace who ever was Conqueror, ≈øeemingly hearkened to that motion; ≈øo that gaining credit eight thou≈øand Per≈øians was ≈øent to take po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion thereof, who he no ≈øooner got within his danger, but he ≈øet upon them, put one thou≈øand to the Sword, and took mo≈øt of the remainder Pri≈øoners, which cau≈øed the Turk to have a better opinion of him then formerly, in≈øomuch that
they nominated him for Grand Vi≈øier the en≈øuing year.

Anno 1625. a new Rebellion broke out in A≈øia, headed by an ordinary Spahi, who drew down ten thou≈øand men before the City of Smirna, the which after ≈øome re≈øi≈øtance he entered, and pretending to reform abu≈øes cut off the heads of two Cadees, puni≈øhed divers others, place and di≈øplaced the Magi≈øtrates as he plea≈øed, and then departed without ≈øuffering any ≈øpoil to be made, pretending the Grand Signeours order for what he had done, and indeed the Court connived at his proceedings, for awing corrupt Officers, he re≈øtored the face of Ju≈øtice in tho≈øe parts, but not long after, he with a greater power marched toward Bru≈ø≈øia in Natolia, u≈øing the Name of Morat to colour his purpo≈øe, pretending to work a Reformation in the State, but in the ending of great preparations were making to oppo≈øe him, he disbanded his Army and retired him≈øelf. And now the mortality raged at Con≈øtantinople in ≈øuch ≈øort, that Fifty thou≈øand died in a ≈øhort ≈øpace, ≈øo that the City was left almo≈øt de≈øolate; which known to the Co≈ø≈øacks, they came again in their Boats, and ≈øailing through the Bo≈øphorus made great ≈øpoil on Europe ≈øide, attempting to burn the Ar≈øenal, to prevent which all the Gallies and ≈ømall Ve≈ø≈øels in the Port were manned out, ≈øo that between them there happened a fierce ingagement; but the Co≈ø≈øacks Boats being ≈ømall though many in number, thirty of them by the ≈øhot of the Gallies were ≈øunk and overturned, in≈øomuch that five hundred Co≈ø≈øacks were drowned and taken Pri≈øoners, and double the number of Turks ≈ølain, for the Boats being in all three hundred, and each Boat manned with thirty or forty Mu≈øquetiers, they ≈øhowered
their Bullets ≈øo thick upon the Decks of the Gallies, that ≈øcarce a Turk peeped out but he was cut off; twice they boarded the Admirals Gally, and had taken it had not the Sea of a ≈øuddain gone high, and the Wind ≈øtood again≈øt them.

Upon the approach of great Vi≈øier towards the Province of Babylon, the King of Per≈øia ≈øent to de≈øire a Treaty of Peace, which was only to protract time, it in the end coming to nothing, yet the Princes of Georgia ≈øent their Amba≈ø≈øadors, as willing to be freed from the Per≈øian yoke, which Amba≈ø≈øadors were kindly entertained by the Vi≈øier, their demands granted, and the Bi≈øhop of Calcedon their Countrey man ≈øent back with them to ≈øee the Peace Ratified; upon which they rai≈øed a great Army, and invaded the Territories of Per≈øia, to oppo≈øe whom the King ≈øent part of his Army under the leading of his great Leiutenant, who joyning Battle was overthrown, with the lo≈øs of ≈øeven thou≈øand of his men, which greatly incouraged the Vi≈øier, ≈øo that he re≈øolved the next year to be≈øiege Babylon, in which was a Garri≈øon of eight thou≈øand Per≈øians, be≈øides the Citizens who were five times the number, yet early in the Spring.

Anno 1626. having refre≈øhed his Army, he pitched his Camp before that great City, but as they were making their approaches Twenty Thou≈øand Per≈øian Hor≈øe, who attended the motion of the Turks, fell into the Vi≈øiers quarter doing great excution, and by that means troubled the whole Army, but in fine the Per≈øians were obliged to retire, yet not before they had ≈ølain about Six Thou≈øand Turks, upon which a mu≈øter was taken of the Army, which was found much le≈øs then was expected for that a number of the Spahi and Janizaries that were
inroled, had forborn to undertake that dangerous, and ≈øo often fatal Expedition, and ≈øeven Princes of the Arabs Tributaries to the Grand Signeour having rai≈øed their power, refu≈øed to advance any further then the Borders of their Principalities, alledging that they dur≈øt not di≈øplea≈øe the po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øors of Babylon, but were ready to obey if the City fell into the hands of the Turks, which weakne≈øs known to the Per≈øian King he drew thither the ≈øtrength of his whole Kingdom, and running Trenches round about the Turks Camp, be≈øieged it in ≈øuch manner that all Provi≈øions and Succors was cut off, and in≈øtead of hoping to win the City, they were ≈øolicitous of nothing more then how to retreat. This danger of the Army was made known to the Emperor and Divano at Con≈øtantinople, but nothing was done till it was too late, for through want and di≈øea≈øes the Army was ≈øo wa≈øted, that they were no wayes able to make head again≈øt their Enemies; be≈øides a great number of them were ≈ølain in the frequent fallies the be≈øieged made out of the City, and the Per≈øians Incur≈øions, who ≈øeldom failed to beat up one quarter or other of the Camp, and hearing of no ≈øupplies dur≈øt advance, or were in a probability to relieve the half ≈øtarved Souldiers, who had left no unclean thing uneaten, it was re≈øolved that under the favour of the night the Camp ≈øhould ri≈øe and force a way through the Per≈øian Squadron, rather choo≈øing to die like men then pine with hunger; Whereupon they brake their great Artilery, and ca≈øt into the Euphrates all ≈øuch things as they could not convey away, to prevent their falling into the hands of the Enemy, and then with as little noi≈øe as po≈ø≈øible, broke through one quarter of the Per≈øian Camp, yet not ≈øo ≈øuddainly but that the Per≈øians taking the Alarum, overtook them ere they reached
Ninive, and had the execution of the Army for the ≈øpace of ten dayes, in which time ≈øeventy thou≈øand Turks and Tartars fell by the Sword, when to ca≈øt the odium upon the Ba≈ø≈øa's, and to ≈øave his credit at the Port the Vi≈øier cau≈øed three of their heads to be ≈øtricken off. This great blow cau≈øed the revolt of many Cities, upon the Frontires of Per≈øia, and indangered the revolt of all A≈øia. The Turks not having received the like blow, ≈øince the overthrow of Bajazet the fir≈øt by Tamerlane the great, which cau≈øed a general heavyne≈øs throughout the City of Con≈øtantinople, few therein but lo≈øt one Friend or other in this unfortunate War, of which the Emperour of Germanies Amba≈ø≈øador taking advantage pre≈ø≈øed for a ≈øpeedy conclu≈øion of Peace, and laboured to cro≈øs the purpo≈øe of the Tran≈øylvanian Prince, but in the interim the Imperial and Tran≈øylvanian Armies being abroad, on the 16th. of October near to the River Gran a mortal Battle was fought between them, wherein the latter was put to the rout, and in pa≈ø≈øing confu≈øedly the River over two Bridges layed for that purpo≈øe, Six thou≈øand were ≈ølain drowned and taken Pri≈øoners, yet Winter coming on the Prince retired with his Troops, and without the con≈øent of the Turks made a Truce with the Imperiali≈øts for three months, ≈øending to the Port to excu≈øe him≈øelf for ≈øo doing, by ≈øhewing the nece≈ø≈øity that induced him ≈øo to do. But ere a Peace could be concluded as was intended Count Mansfelt and Duke Erne≈øtus, who were the greate≈øt inciters thereto died, ≈øo that nothing for a time was done therein, but it was left in the power of the Prince, and Ba≈ø≈øa of Buda to War upon the Emperour, as they found it convenient or mo≈øt advantagious, in≈øomuch that they rai≈øed great forces intending to make Au≈øtria the ≈øeat of War, but upon further negotiation
that de≈øign was layed a≈øide, all Parties being more de≈øirous of Peace then War, and ≈øo matters were left doubtful.

About this time an Amba≈ø≈øador from the King of Per≈øia, with overtures of Peace arrived at Aleppo, but could get no Audience of the Vi≈øier, who remained there with his broken Army till an other Amba≈ø≈øador with pre≈øents arrived at Con≈øtantinople, where he made ≈øuch overtures that they were approved by many, but the non-delivery of Babylon a little before taken by the Per≈øians, put a ≈øtop to the negotiation, the Turks not being willing upon any other Terms to hearken to Peace, for that their Army in A≈øia was by this time recruited and again entered into Per≈øia, to avert which the Per≈øians be≈øieged Achiska a ≈øtrong City near Arzirum, being incouraged thereto by Aba≈ø≈øa Ba≈ø≈øa, to whom the Vi≈øier ≈øent to draw out his forces, and in conjunction with the Georgians, to joyn with ≈øuch forces as he ≈øhould ≈øend him which were three thou≈øand Janizaries under the leading of twelve Captains, with whom he ≈øent Provi≈øion and other nece≈ø≈øaries, but for the hatred the Ba≈ø≈øa had to that order he commanded them to be ≈øet upon in the night, and allmo≈øt all cut in pieces, tho≈øe that remained and were taken Pri≈øoners he ≈øent to the Per≈øian King, and then with ≈øuch forces as he had Fortified him≈øelf in Arzirum. The news of this di≈øgrace coming to the ear of the Vi≈øier, he drew down with all his forces toward the Rebel, re≈øolving to puni≈øh him if he could by any means get him into his hands.

Now the treaty between the Imperial Mini≈øters, tho≈øe of the Grand Signeours and Tran≈øylvanian
Princes growing ripe, a Peace was concluded though ≈øeverally, for the Prince having under≈øtood that the King of Denmark who was coming to his aid had been overthrown by Wal≈øtain the Emperours General, and that the Ba≈ø≈øa of Buda bought with German Gold, had cro≈ø≈øed all his purpo≈øes at Con≈øtantinople, and di≈øcovered his inmo≈øt Councils, he grew jealous of his own ≈øtate, and therefore thought it be≈øt to make Peace whil≈øt he was in a capacity to obtain honourable condition, which Treaty compri≈øed in ten Articles were Ratified at Presburg. The chief points of which were, That either ≈øide ≈øhould cea≈øe from Ho≈øtilities, and forbear directly or indirectly to a≈ø≈øi≈øt each others Rebells, and that all the City and Towns taken in the late War, ≈øhould be redelivered. Nor were the Turks ≈ølow in fini≈øhing their Treaty, as being no ways able to maintain an Army in Europe by rea≈øon of their troubles in A≈øia, ≈øo that much to the ≈øame purpo≈øe as the former contained in eleven Articles, the Peace was concluded at the Port, to the great joy of all parties e≈øpecially of the Turks, who were now at lea≈øure to recover their Towns, and quell the Rebellions in A≈øia.

Anno 1627. Halil Ba≈ø≈øa the great Vi≈øier and General of the Turki≈øh Army, in having for ≈øometime be≈øieged Aba≈ø≈øa Ba≈ø≈øa in Arzirum, and finding his attempts to win the City vain, by rea≈øon of the many inconveniencies in his Camp, he was forced to ri≈øe, which the Rebel perceiving ≈øallied out and with all his forces followed hard after for ≈øeven dayes, cutting off all his Rear, and took his Trea≈øure, Cannon and Baggage, which ≈øo di≈øcouraged the Souldiers, that they mutined again≈øt their General and ≈øought to ≈øtone him, and long was it
ere they could be appea≈øed, whereupon he wrote to the Grand Signeour informing him that there was no hopes of obedience unle≈øs the reverence of his per≈øon did revive it, yet he re≈øted at Tocat and for the better quieting di≈øorders disbanded a part of his Army, who almo≈øt naked to the great di≈øgrace of the Vi≈øier came to Con≈øtantinople, which gave Aba≈ø≈øa Ba≈ø≈øa opportunity to hold corre≈øpondence with the Poles, Tartars, and Co≈ø≈øacks, whereupon Hu≈ø≈øeruph Ba≈ø≈øa a Vi≈øier of the Bench, and late Aga of the Janizaries, was cho≈øen conductor of the Militia, and pa≈ø≈øed over into A≈øia with ≈øuch forces as could be in≈øtantly rai≈øed, and many great Ordinance ca≈øt for the ≈øervice, Gallies were likewi≈øe fitted out, and all preparations made as far as the Trea≈øure would extend, and it was further concluded that Hu≈ø≈øeruph ≈øhould march directly to Diarbecher to oppo≈øe the Per≈øian, and there remain as Ba≈ø≈øa of the Province, and that on his way to prevent charge, the Seal ≈øhould be ≈øent him and he con≈øtituted great Vi≈øier in the room of Halil Ba≈ø≈øa, who≈øe credit therein was had in regard for that he was not ≈øent for home as in di≈øgrace, but in the head of the Army delivered up his charge and ≈øo retired to the Port, there to continue one of the Council Vi≈øiers.

Anno 1628, about the 5th. of April Ha≈ø≈øeruph was declared Grand Vi≈øier, and took upon him the charge of the Army with orders to march directly toward Babylon, for of Aba≈ø≈øa Ba≈ø≈øa they had had enough the year before. Yet he wrote to the Grand Signeour, terming him≈øelf his ≈ølave, promi≈øing him that he would hold the Province of Arzirum for him, but if he ≈øought to expe ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ him by force he would put it into the hands of the Per≈øian, but if he might po≈ø≈øe≈øs it he would defend it again≈øt him, and ≈øtill hold him
as the capital Enemy of the Turki≈øh Empire, nor ≈øhould his forces be wanting to a≈ø≈øi≈øt the new General in his Expedition for the recovery of Babylon, and this was accepted as a plenary ≈øubmi≈ø≈øion.

Whil≈øt the Grand Signeour was thus bu≈øied to ≈øettle affairs of A≈øia, and to reduce Aba≈ø≈øa Ba≈ø≈øa to obedience, the Tartar Han was openly declared a Rebel and Enemy to the Turki≈øh Empire, and his Brother Schachin Geheray ≈øent out of Per≈øia, to rai≈øe troubles on that ≈øide, having exacted a Tribute of the Princes of Bugdania and Valachia, he was overthrown by Count Emire a Tartar Captain, who undertook to reduce him to the obedience of the Grand Signeour, whereupon it was ≈øuddainly re≈øolved that it ≈øhould be once again attempted to re≈øtore Ghian Geray to that Kingdom, and to expell Mechmet Han, in order to which the Captain Ba≈ø≈øa once more prepared the Fleet of Gallies, ≈øo that for a year the Mediterranean was like to be incumbred, and the Turki≈øh Empire ingaged in ≈øo many troubles, that every thing ≈øeemed to work towards its ≈øubver≈øion, but great bodies have ≈øtrong Luctations and die not with one fit, and ≈øuch was the blindne≈øs and mi≈øery of the times that whil≈øt the Chri≈øtian Princes contended in ambitious and envious rather then ju≈øt quarrels, none of them had lea≈øure to pu≈øh down that Enemy who ≈øtood totterring on the brink of ruine, nor to vindicate the Chri≈øtian honour, nor the Holy Land oppre≈ø≈øed and po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed by a Tyrant, that only ≈øub≈øi≈øted by their di≈ø≈øentions.

About this time great differences aro≈øe between the Greek and Romi≈øh Churches, about ≈øuperiority and forms of Wor≈øhip, which was ≈øtrongly maintained by either party, in≈øomuch that for a long time (to the ≈øcandal of the Chri≈øtian Religion) the
controver≈øie was debated before the Turki≈øh Commi≈ø≈øioners at Con≈øtantinople, who being Enemies to both alike, nay, even to the very name of Chri≈øt, moving no otherwayes then they were bribed, laughing to ≈øee the ≈øimplicity of the Chri≈øtians, to make them Arbitrators of that which they nothing more de≈øired then to de≈øtroy, but in the end after infinite Trea≈øure ≈øpent, the Pope proved the richer, and therefore prevailed to have ≈øuch of his Clergy as had been di≈øpo≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed of their Colleges, Mona≈øteries, and the like in the Turki≈øh Empire re≈øtored, e≈øpecially the Je≈øuits who had been thru≈øt out of St. Bennets Church and Mona≈øtery in Galatia, concerning the re≈øtitution of whom the Grand Signeour, at the in≈øtance of the French Amba≈ø≈øador ≈øent his Letters mandatory to A≈ø≈øan Ba≈ø≈øa Captain of the Sea, and to the Cadee of Galatia.
About this time Sir Thomas Row, Amba≈ø≈øador at the Port for His Maje≈øty of Great Brittain, procured leave to depart, by whom the Grand Signeour ≈øent this following Letter.

body.head: The Grand Signeours Letter to his Maje≈øty of Great Brittain.
body.p: TO the mo≈øt glorious among≈øt the greate≈øt Maje≈øties of the Princes of Je≈øus, mo≈øt reverenced among≈øt the People of the Me≈ø≈øiah, ≈øole Director of the important affairs of the Nazarean Nation, Lord of the limits of Honour and Power, Patron of Grace and Authority Charles King of Great Brittain and Ireland, to who≈øe la≈øt dayes we wi≈øh all compleat and true happine≈øs.

Be it known unto your Maje≈øty at the ≈øight of this Letter, That your Ambaffador Sir Thomas Rowe, re≈øpected and beloved among≈øt the Chri≈øtians, to whom we wi≈øh a happy end, being heretofore ≈øent to re≈øide as your Amba≈ø≈øador
at our happy Port, to be watchful over all offices of good corre≈øpondence between us, and that all requi≈øite terms of honour ≈øhould be fulfilled, and to renew the mantle of our affections, hath from his fir≈øt arrival here until this pre≈øent, mo≈øt perfectly attended upon the charge impo≈øer in him, and in all his actions proceeded with extraordinary diligence and indu≈øtry, for the high honour and great fame of your Maje≈øty His Soveraign, and now your Maje≈øty having ≈øent in his place one of the chief of your mo≈øt e≈øteemed Sir Peter Wyche, to re≈øide at our Imperial Port, and that the ≈øaid Sir Thomas Rowe hath taken re≈øolution to return to your Maje≈øty, with our Imperial con≈øent we ≈øend him unto you, with the≈øe our Imperial Letters, hoping in the mo≈øt High God, that when as he is mo≈øt ≈øafely arrived with you, out of your abundant and innate clemency, and your ≈øingular and ≈øincere goodne≈øs, in re≈øpect of his good and faithful ≈øervice, that you will ≈øet him honoured and rewarded, and to ≈øee that the great affection and love which we nouri≈øh towards your Maje≈øty, may be daily increa≈øed we de≈øire you readily imploy your benign care in the keeping and ob≈øerving our Imperial Capitulation with every Article therein contained, as we on our part will likewi≈øe do in all things that are meet to be done, concerning their perfect ob≈øervation, whereof you ≈øhall find a good and clear Te≈øtimony by our future effects.

div.p:
With this Letter and ≈øeveral pre≈øents, Sir Thomas Rowe imbarqued on the Samp≈øon Frigat, in order to ≈øail for England, but coming before Malta, and being there becalmed, four Gallies came out of the Haven and ≈øet upon the Engli≈øh Ve≈ø≈øel, but after ≈øeven hours hot di≈øpute were forced to retire with the lo≈øs of thirty ≈øix Knights of the Order, and two
hundred ≈øixty four common Souldiers and Rowers, when in the Samp≈øon only one Jew a Pa≈ø≈øenger was killed, and about ≈øix men wounded, yet the Ship was grievou≈øly rent with Culverin ≈øhot, and had been lo≈øt had the Sea been outragious.

Sir Peter Wyche His Maje≈øty of great Brittains new Amba≈ø≈øador at Con≈øtantinople, had not long continued there before ≈øome di≈øturbance happened, occa≈øioned by one William-Bundock an Engli≈øh Captains taking a Ship belonging to the Port, as ≈øhe was ≈øailing to Me≈ø≈øina, which cau≈øed the owners to demand with much clamour reparation, in≈øomuch that the Chimacham or Chief Officer of the Port, cau≈øed an Imbargo to be layed upon two Engli≈øh Ve≈ø≈øels then riding at Anchor in the Haven of Con≈øtantinople, nor could the Amba≈ø≈øador procure their relea≈øe without a promi≈øe of reparation for the dammages ≈øu≈øtained, and that the Actor ≈øhould be puni≈øhed, nor would the in≈øolent Souldiers though no way intere≈ø≈øed therein till five hundred Dollars were be≈øtowed among≈øt them.

Anno 1629. The Grand Signeour after much debate in coun≈øel, made Provi≈øion to renew the War in Per≈øia, as the only de≈øign of Honour and Con≈øequence, for though the Turki≈øh Empire ingaged in many troubles required a judicious and more then common providence to ≈øupport it, be≈øet with dangers on every ≈øide, and bearing more apparent ≈øigns of its declination then ever. Yet the di≈øgrace of Halil Ba≈ø≈øas retiring from Babylon, and from before Aczirum, and the lo≈øs of the Trea≈øure and Munition, ≈øo in≈øpired Hu≈ø≈øeruph the new General with revenge, that he de≈øired nothing more then to blot out tho≈øe ≈øtains that Eclip≈øed the Turki≈øh Diadem, whereupon having recruited his Army, he came before
Babylon, but after ≈øome bravadoes retired to Aleppo, without performing any thing worthy mention, and there to ≈øatisfie his mutinous Souldiers, exacted mony of all the Merchants ≈øtrangers and native inhabitants, incouraging every ba≈øe fellow to accu≈øe Rich per≈øons of one crime or other, and then him≈øelf ≈øitting as Judge would lay great fines on them, which they mu≈øt pay or be impri≈øoned, upon the the like pretence he impri≈øoned the Engli≈øh Con≈øul re≈øiding there, and hanged his Bruggerman or Interpreter, which in≈øolencies made known to His Maje≈øties Amba≈ø≈øador at Con≈øtantinople, he complained to the Grand Signeour but had no redre≈øs. Yet within a while after his ill conduct being made known he was di≈øplaced, and Haffis Achmat Ba≈ø≈øa made great Vi≈øier in his ≈øtead, though not without much difficulty, could he be induced to render his charge, for having by large Bribes won the Souldiers, he fortified him≈øelf in Mo≈øul or Ninive biding defiance to his Ma≈øter, yet at length he was reduced to obedience, but would not tru≈øt him≈øelf in the City of Con≈øtantinople, but at a di≈øtance plotted innovation, and therein proceeded ≈øo far that he can≈øed the Janizaries and Spahi to mutiny, and force the Grand Signeour to deliver into their hands the new Vi≈øier, whom they in≈øtantly tore in pieces, and not ≈øo contented they made a further demand of the Mufti and Teftarder put into their power, but at the earne≈øt intreaty of Morat they were appea≈øed, though not before he promi≈øed to made Hu≈ø≈øeruph a ≈øecond time Vi≈øier, and that Regeb Ba≈ø≈øa ≈øhould officiate till his arrival.

The ≈øtorm allayed the Grand Signeour began to con≈øider that Hu≈ø≈øeruph had rai≈øed it by the Influence he had upon the Souldiers, and therefore lea≈øt he ≈øhould attempt any thing further, ≈øecret order was
given to the Ba≈ø≈øa of Buda in who≈øe Government he re≈øided to ≈øend his head to Court, which was done accordingly, but not ≈øo privately but that the Soldiers getting notice thereof, ≈øuddenly made up their many headed mon≈øter, and in a great rage came to the Seraglio demanding the heads of tho≈øe that had been any way councelling or con≈øenting to the death of Hu≈ø≈øeruph, otherwi≈øe they threatned all with ruin, but having no an≈øwer ≈øuitable to their minds they ran to the hou≈øe of Regeb, demanding of him who it was that had councelled ≈øo great a wickedne≈øs. Whereupon to ≈øave his Life (which was then in no ≈ømall danger) he prote≈øted he knew not, and that him≈øelf was innocent of the matter, yet they forced him with them to the Palace, and made him their Orator to demand what they de≈øired, upon which the Aga Mufti and Teftardar with a private Servant of the Grand Signeours fled, but the latter being the next day taken and ≈øent back, he was delivered up as a ≈øacrifice to the in≈øolent Souldiers, who after their u≈øual manner in ≈øuch like ca≈øes tore him in pieces. Yet they were not ≈øo contented, but upon a rumour that the Grand Signeour had put his three Brethren to death, they broke into the Palace and could hardly be quieted, although the young Princes were produced, and that ≈øeveral officers ≈øwore upon the Alcoran, that they ≈øee the grand Signeour lay his hand upon the book and ≈øwore they ≈øhould have their demands ≈øatisfied.

In the≈øe Tumults the goods of Merchants ≈øtrangers went to wrack, and divers affronts and indignities were offered the ≈øeveral Amba≈ø≈øadors re≈øiding at the Port, nor was this all, for about the ≈øame time Eleas Ba≈ø≈øa Rebelled again≈øt the Grand Signeour, and ≈øiezed upon the City of Ama≈øia about a League from Smirna, infe≈øting all the Countrey with divers
outrages, his Souldiers living altogether upon ≈øpoil, in≈øomuch that the Merchants and Con≈øuls at Smirna were forced to remove with their goods to Scio, but an Army being ≈øent again≈øt him, he was in a pitched Battle di≈øcomfited and had mo≈øt of his followers ≈ølain, him≈øelf hardly e≈øcaping, and now the Grand Signeour ≈øuppo≈øing Regeb Ba≈ø≈øa (though indeed he was not) the Author of the late tumults, ≈øent for him into the Seraglio and there cau≈øed him to be ≈øtrangled.

About this time a fight for the ≈øpace of four hours was maintained by two Engli≈øh Merchantmen, again≈øt thirty of the Turks Gallies, till at la≈øt the Engli≈øh finding them≈øelves too weak for ≈øuch odds fired their Ve≈ø≈øels and ca≈øt them≈øelves over board, where many of them peri≈øhed, and tho≈øe that were taken up put to the Oares; in this fight a thou≈øand Turks were ≈ølain, and among≈øt them ≈øeveral Begs and men of note, of this apparent injury done by the Turks, His Maje≈øty of Great Brittain by his Letter complained to the Grand Signeour, requiring that tho≈øe that were taken Captives might be re≈øtored to their Liberty, that ≈øo a right under≈øtanding might continue, but the Turks alledging that the Voyage of the two Ships were unlawful, by rea≈øon they Traded in the Levant for Corn, the Amba≈ø≈øador could little prevail, and had much ado to ≈øave the lives of the Captives. Yet in the end to hinder the di≈ø≈øolution of the Turki≈øh Trade, and to plea≈øe the Grand Signeour, a Decree pa≈ø≈øed in the Star Chamber prohibiting the Corn Trade in the Levant, upon which ≈øeveral of the Captives were ≈øet at Liberty.
Three dayes after this action, a Fire happened in Con≈øtantinople which con≈øumed Seventy Thou≈øand Hou≈øes.

The Per≈øian War yet continuing, that King with a great Army be≈øieged Van, a ≈øtrong City upon the Confines of Diarbecher, the news whereof arriving at the Port, great preparations were made to prevent that important place from falling into the hands of the Per≈øians, it being Decreed that all the Beghs of A≈øia, ≈øhould repair thither with ≈øuch forces as they could leavy, and endeavour its releif, and to joyn them the Grand Vi≈øier pa≈ø≈øed over with all European Souldiers, but ere any thing could be done the City was taken, whereupon the Vi≈øier marched towards Aleppo, exacting great ≈øums of money, and the better to furni≈øh him≈øelf, ≈øent the Cadee a ≈ølave to Cyprus, and ≈øiezed upon all his Trea≈øure.

Soon after the Turks under pretence of the Chri≈øtians ri≈øing, ≈øiezed all their Arms, making it death to tho≈øe in who≈øe hou≈øes any were found after a time prefixed, nor content with this they hanged a Venetian Merchant only for his Money, and Impri≈øoned all the Chri≈øtian Merchants in Con≈øtantinople, ≈øetting a ran≈øom of two thou≈øand Dollars upon each, and that if the money was not payed in four dayes they ≈øhould be executed. The four Amba≈ø≈øadors of England, France, Holland, and Venice were likewi≈øe convented before the Ba≈ø≈øas in the Ar≈øenal, and charged for building a Hou≈øe and Chappel without leave from the Grand Signeour, to have done it in contempt of his Imperial Maje≈øty, and much ado they had to e≈øcape being impri≈øoned, but in the end upon the Chappels being demoli≈øhed, and all the Armes they had in their Hou≈øes delivered to an officer appointed to receive them, the Grand Signeour was pacified, though indeed this was u≈øed only as a trick to extort mony from them.

This being the pre≈øent ≈øtate of things in the Imperial Port, the Engli≈øh Amba≈ø≈øador in the behalf
of his King and Nation, made known the ju≈øt re≈øentments of his Ma≈øter, for the affront offered in the per≈øon of him his Amba≈ø≈øador, as likewi≈øe did the re≈øt exclaiming of inju≈øtice, in≈øomuch that the Captain Ba≈ø≈øa told them that indeed the proceedings were too rigid, and that for the future care ≈øhould be taken to prevent the like, as for their Armes taken away he ≈øaid they had been ≈øeen by the Grand Signeour, and therefore could not be re≈øtored, but that they had liberty to buy more, and the money exacted of the Merchants could not at that time be re≈øtored by rea≈øon of the urgent occa≈øion of the ≈øtate, and therefore intreated them to be pacified, but the French Amba≈ø≈øador was ≈øo far fallen into the Grand Signeours di≈øplea≈øure that his Death was determined, the execution whereof was with much danger to the di≈ø≈øwaders deferred, and upon ≈øecond thoughts changed into an Impri≈øonment, the cau≈øe of which was for that he had ≈øiezed upon ≈øixty thou≈øand Dollars ≈øent by the Town of Mar≈øeilles, to pay his Predece≈ø≈øors Debts contracted in Con≈øtantinople, which money he converted to his own u≈øe, thereby defrauding the Creditor and obliging them to clamour for Turki≈øh Ju≈øtice, which in it ≈øelf is cruelty and oppre≈ø≈øion.

The≈øe inte≈øtine troubles gave the Per≈øians Liberty to make them≈øelves Ma≈øters of many ≈øtrong places, which greatly alarumed the Ottoman Empire, in≈øomuch that great preparations were every where made, the Grand Signeour in per≈øon intending to take the Field. But ere the Army could be rai≈øed and all things gotten in a readine≈øs, the Per≈øians were far advanced, and taken many places of importance, and among≈øt the re≈øt Reivan a ≈øtrong place, Garri≈øoned by the Turks, taken from the Per≈øians
the year before, putting all they found therein to the Sword and Ran≈øom.

The report of the≈øe lo≈ø≈øes arriving, ere the Grand Signeour had put him≈øelf in a readine≈øs to accompany his Army, he layed a≈øide his purpo≈øe of going in per≈øon, and full of di≈øcontents remained at home to con≈øult his own ≈øafety, which was now threatned with ≈øuch a ≈øtorm, that to ≈øhun it was not imagined a po≈ø≈øibility in humane Providence, for the Souldiers that were abroad began to expre≈øs their di≈øcontents, refu≈øing to receive their pay or to be commanded by the Grand Vi≈øier, for the Turks War with the Per≈øians unwillingly, there being no other cau≈øe for their invading each other then the emulation of greatne≈øs, which has ≈øucce≈ø≈øively fired the Lords of tho≈øe two mighty Empires. Be≈øides the Turks ≈øeldom meet in Per≈øia with any plentiful ≈øpoils, ≈øo that they are neither incited by their own freene≈øs, nor allured by the hopes of any large reward. But on the contrary to the Wars of Hungary and Poland, they ha≈øt as to ≈øome delightful ≈øpectacle, induced thereto by a ≈øuper≈øtitious zeal, as making religion a ground for their attempts, and an a≈ø≈øurance of large ≈øpoiles, where the Countries abound in all manner of Plenty.

This danger of the Souldiers mutiny abroad reached not pre≈øently the ears of the Grand Signeour to terrifie him with the apprehen≈øions of a double ≈øtorm, for he had enough to do with the Janizaries, who now began to ≈øu≈øpect another de≈øign on foot for the extirpation of their order which made them ca≈øt off all obedience, and ≈øet the great City of Con≈øtantinople in an uproar, which obliged the Citizens every where to provide for their ≈øafeties, for the unruly Souldiers having gotten the knack of making and unmaking Emperors at their
plea≈øure, were grown to that height of in≈øolency that they ≈øuppo≈øed the center of Government to re≈øt in them≈øelves, and each individual man of them thought him≈øelf ≈øuperior to any Officer in the Empire, in≈øomuch that they accounted the Grand Signeour but as their Steward intru≈øted by them with the Government, and that his Life and ≈øafety wholly depended on their plea≈øure, which he well perceiving knew no better means to render them tractable, then by di≈øtributing large ≈øums of money among≈øt them, which neverthele≈øs at this time much availed not, for being bent on mi≈øchief they plundered the hou≈øes of ≈øeveral Merchants and rich Burghers killing and wounding ≈øuch as re≈øi≈øted them, and in a fury ran to the Palace demanding ≈øuch Favourites as they named which being denyed, they pre≈øently fell into a con≈øultation about depo≈øing their Emperour. Nay, ≈øo far proceeded that many per≈øwaded to take away his Life as they had done his Brother O≈ømans, but ≈øo divided were they in their Councils, that they could come to no re≈øult at that time, but ≈øoon after a≈ø≈øembling it was propo≈øed, that if the Grand Signeour would make amends by ≈øome acknowledgment of his ill intents toward them, and confirm their Order and Priviledges, his Government (he being one that was not in≈øen≈øible of their power) might prove advantagious to them, but that if his di≈øpo≈øition re≈øted yet undi≈øcovered, it might render the cour≈øe of their Lives obnoxious to incertainties, for the Grand Signeour in the beginning of his Reign, not exceeding fifteen years of age expre≈ø≈øed a natural inclination to action, which wits his years increa≈øed, and this had ≈øettled ≈øome good opinion of him in the unruly Souldiers, who≈øe de≈øire is War that by plunder they may inrich them≈øelves. Though of late many of the Janizaries
(contrary to their fir≈øt in≈øtitution, and the long continued cour≈øe that former Emperors had obliged them to) had married Wives ≈øettled them≈øelves to Merchandize and were become both rich and effeminate.

In the≈øe and the like mi≈øchievous con≈øultations many dayes were wa≈øted, nor could the Janizaries wanting their u≈øual Confederates the Spahi, who were then under the leading of the Grand Vi≈øier at Arzirum effect their purpo≈øe as they were wont which made them more cautious in their proceedings and to keep together in one ≈øtrong and intire body as fearing to be de≈øtroyed by a general Ma≈ø≈øacre if they ≈øeparated, ≈øuch a rumour (whether ≈øpread by them≈øelves to countenance them in their unlawful purpo≈øes or really intended) being ≈øpread about the City, and that in the room of them a new Militia ≈øhould be e≈øtabli≈øhed, le≈øs chargeable and more tractable, after the ≈øame method as Delavire Ba≈ø≈øa had formerly purpo≈øed, and that many were for that purpo≈øe inrolled on the Frontires, e≈øpecially European Hor≈øemen that were continually in action to prevent the incur≈øions of the Co≈ø≈øacks and free Heyducks, who living mo≈øtly upon ≈øpoil greatly endammaged the Turks, but in the end a right under≈øtanding being created between the Emperour and the Janizaries by the mediation of the great Officers of the Court a Reconciliation was made, though not without a wonderful ma≈øs of money di≈øtributed among≈øt the latter, who frequently mutiny for no other purpo≈øe then by ≈øuch means to inrich them≈øelves, well knowing that the Grand Signeour has no other way to appea≈øe them, then by di≈øtributing large ≈øumms of mony among≈øt them; nor were the Soldiers abroad ≈øatisfied till they had ≈øacrificed to their revenge the chief Trea≈øurer of the Army, the two Aga's of the Spahi's and the Chiaus
Ba≈ø≈øa of the Janizaries, nor till a new Vi≈øier was ≈øent to di≈øcharge the Old one, and to lead them to the Per≈øian War.

During the≈øe troubles an Amba≈ø≈øador from the King of Per≈øia arrived at Con≈øtantinople, with many Rich pre≈øents, which cau≈øed him to have the ≈øpeedier Audience, and promi≈øe of an honourable Peace, bur whil≈øt the Treaty held, the Co≈ø≈øacks driven out of Poland by King Uladi≈ølaus, had ≈øiezed upon A≈øac a ≈øtrong City of the Grand Signeours, ≈øcituate upon the mouth of the River Tanais, upon the declining of a Hill, which they pillaged and afterward Fortified, keeping po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion thereof for the ≈øpace of four years, at what time the Turk again recovered it, as al≈øo great troubles aro≈øe in Tartary, upon the Tartar Hans putting to death the Ba≈ø≈øa Mu≈øti, and Cadi of Caffa, for reproving him of Coward ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ , for thereupon the Grand Signeour ≈øecretly maintained Cautimeri and his faction again≈øt him, who with Fire and Sword wa≈øted his Countrey, and at length pa≈ø≈øing the Nie≈øter ≈øiezed on the Countrey of Budziack near to Beliegrode and Kilea bordering on the Countrey of Moldavia, on which he likewi≈øe incroached drawing a World of People after him, which rai≈øed a jealou≈øie in ∆≤ladi≈ølaus the Polonian King, who doubting they would prove trouble≈øom neighbours, re≈øolved to expell them by force of Armes, but whil≈øt he delayed the Tartar Han executed his purpo≈øe, for ≈øetting upon Cautimeri with a great Army overthrew him, and followed the execution over the large Plains of Dobruc, ≈øo that di≈øpairing to appear any more formidable in the Field he fled to Con≈øtantinople, where the Grand Signeour contrary to his Faith given, to curry favour with Tartar Han cau≈øed him to be ≈øtrangled, together
with his Son, when not long after a Nephew of this Cautimeri killed Tartar Han as he was Hunting, and by a mi≈øguiding path ≈øeparated from his followers, for which Treachery he was applauded at Con≈øtantinople, as a man of admirable courage, and upon news of Hans death cau≈øed Becher Gherey his brother to be Proclaimed King of Tartary.

Notwith≈øtanding the fair Promi≈øes of Morat, the Per≈øian Amba≈ø≈øador was di≈ømi≈ø≈øed without any agreement of Articles in relation to a Peace, and order given to pro≈øecute that War with all imaginable rigor, intending to go him≈øelf in per≈øon and knock at the Gates of Babylon, whereupon he hung out the Hor≈øe taile, a certain ≈øign of his or the Grand Vi≈øiers taking the Field, and increa≈øed the number of his Janizaries, revoking a Decree he had made to the contrary, commanding his Ba≈ø≈øas upon the Chri≈øtian Frontiers to give no occa≈øion of complaint in his ab≈øence that might oblige him to retire ere he had accompli≈øhed his purpo≈øe, and ≈øo with an Army of five hundred thou≈øand Hor≈øe and Foot, whereof three hundred thou≈øand were fighting men, he entered Per≈øia about the end of May 1638. having joyned the Grand Vi≈øier with ≈øuch forces as he had at Iconium; and in his way overthrew a Shegh who had drawn a great number of people into Rebellion under pretence of Religion, out of the Mountains of Anatolia, but the Impo≈øtor e≈øcaping Morat to prevent his further attempts, cau≈øed to be proclaimed that if he was not put into his hands he would de≈øtroy all the Countrey with Fire and Sword, for fear of which he was di≈øcovered by tho≈øe that he tru≈øted with the knowledge of his aboad, and by the Grand Signeours command flead alive, and with his skin off carryed to the wheel, and there broken without expre≈ø≈øing the lea≈øt ≈øence of pain.

This let removed Morat pa≈ø≈øed on, to oppo≈øe who≈øe pa≈ø≈øage the Per≈øian King took the Field with one hundred twenty thou≈øand Hor≈øe, and put 30 thou≈øand men into Babylon, with what was nece≈ø≈øary for their ≈øub≈øi≈øtence, but at the ≈øame time his Countrey on the other ≈øide being invaded by the great Mogul o ‚Ä¢
India, who in favour of Morat had rai≈øed a powerful Army, he did not think it convenient to give the Turks Battle but permitted them to pa≈øs the Euphrates over a Brige, though not without gr ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ t lo≈øs, for the Bridge giving way under ≈øo great a weight, many Men, Hor≈øes, and Camels peri≈øhed in the Water, but it being repaired the remainder of the Army attained the further Bank, and in a ≈øhort time came to Mo≈øul, antiently called Ninive, where all the petty Princes who≈øe Countries were near came to the Camp and tendered their Homage to the Grand Signeour, bringing many rich pre≈øents and promi≈øing to become his Tributaries.

The Army ri≈øing from before Mo≈øul, Morat marched directly to Babylon, (otherwi≈øe Bagdat accounted the anciente≈øt City in the World, reported to be built by Nimrod on the Bank of the River Euphrates) which he ≈øtraitly be≈øieged, ordering his Batteries in three places to be rai≈øed, and each Battalion to be appointed his quarter, him≈øelf being attired like a private Souldier to be the le≈øs expo≈øed to danger, prote≈øting he would never change his Cloathes unle≈øs he might do it within the Walls of Babylon, and with words and gifts ≈øo incouraged the Officers and Souldiers that within three dayes the Trenches were opened, him≈øelf giving Fire to the fir≈øt Cannon, and after that with fifty great pieces he thundered again≈øt the Walls ince≈ø≈øantly, being an≈øwered in the ≈øame Language by the Defendants, who were eighty thou≈øand fighting men,
four or 5 thou≈øand of which frequently ≈øallyed as they ≈øaw advantage making great ≈ølaughter of the Turks for the Per≈øian had put into this important place his Souldiers of greate≈øt courage, thinking by that means to prevent its falling into the Grand Signeors hands, either by their valour or protracting the time till he could be better at lea≈øure to relieve it, but notwith≈øtanding the continual skirmi≈øhes, the Turks numerous Army advanced the Trenches to the brink of the Ditches, railing ≈øeveral redoubts to ≈øecure them≈øelves, and hinder the be≈øieged from ≈øallying, and ≈øo effectually they wrought, hat within one months ≈øpace they filled up the fir≈øt and ≈øecond Ditches with Wool≈øacks, Fagots, and the like; and then in great numbers a≈ø≈øaulted the breaches the Cannon had made, but were ≈øtrenuou≈øly repul≈øed by the Per≈øians, who ≈øhowred on them all manner of warlike in≈øtruments of death. The great Vi≈øier ≈øignalizing him≈øelf above all by his undaunted courage, commanding with his hand and voice was ≈ølain by a Mu≈øquet ≈øhot. This fight within the breach continued for the ≈øpace of five days, where both parties fighting like men in de≈øpair, the dead bodies lay in heaps, and blood flowed like a Torrent. But at length the number of Turks prevailing they under the leading of Mu≈øtapha Ba≈ø≈øa, on the 22th. of December, Anno Dom. 1638. entered the City, and ≈øet up the Royal ≈øtandard, again≈øt whom notwith≈øtanding four and twenty thou≈øand Per≈øians made head, but quarter being offered them they readily accepted it, throwing down their Armes and ≈øubmitting upon the publick Faith of the Grand Signeour for their ≈øafety, who contrary to his promi≈øe cau≈øed them when di≈øarmed mo≈øt barbarou≈øly to be Ma≈ø≈øacred, not ≈øparing either Man, Woman or Child.

The taking of Babylon cau≈øed great rejoycing at Con≈øtantinople, a twenty dayes Fea≈øt being thereupon proclaimed, and many Ceremonies u≈øed according to the Turki≈øh manner, and the Grand Signeour having left a Garri≈øon of thirty thou≈øand Men in his new conquered City returned to the Port, having in this Expedition lo≈øt by the Sword, Famine, and Pe≈øtilence one hundred thou≈øand of his be≈øt men, and him≈øelf very much afflicted with ≈øickne≈øs.

Soon after his return and triumphant enterance, an Amba≈ø≈øador arrived from Per≈øia with propo≈øals of Peace, who being admitted to Audience, and the matter afterwards referred to the Chimacam a Peace was concluded, the chief Article being that Reven ≈øhould remain to the Sophy, and Babylon to the Grand Signeour.

During the Per≈øian War the Venetians having ≈øu≈øtained great dammage by the Pyrates of Algier and Tunis, ≈øet forth a Fleet of Gallies and de≈øtroyed many of tho≈øe Rovers and among≈øt the re≈øt ≈øeven in the Grand Signeours Port of Valona, which he highly re≈øented, but in the end was by ≈øeveral rich Pre≈øents pacified, and the Peace renewed: and ≈øoon after an Envoy extraordinary from the Emperor of Germany arrived at the Port, to congratulate the Grand Signeours ≈øucce≈øs in his late Per≈øian War, but not bringing ≈øuch Pre≈øents as were expected, he was not received with the honour due to his Character; and there happening a di≈øpute between the Engli≈øh Amba≈ø≈øador and this Envoy about precedency, the Turks granted it the former, being made to under≈øtand the difference Chri≈øtian Princes make between an Amba≈ø≈øador and an Envoy. And now Morat ≈øtudying on whom to turn his Arms, at length concluded to invade Germany, and in order thereto
