called him the new Grand Vi≈øier Mu≈øtapha, whom he had left with a part of the Army in Per≈øia, but death fru≈øtrated his project, for drinking exce≈ø≈øively with ≈øeveral of his Favourites and pot Companions he fell into a Fevour, whereupon his Phy≈øitians being called were fearful to admini≈øter remedies, lea≈øt proving un≈øucce≈øsful their lives ≈øhould be indangered, yet at length they concluded to let him blood which ha ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ed his end, ‚Ä¢ he dying the 8th. of February, Anno Dom 1640. of his Reign the ≈øeventeen, and of his Age thirty one, having ruled in the height of all exce≈øs and irregular di≈øorders his youthful years inabled him to ≈øupport having murthered Orchan and Bajazet, two of his Brethren and leaving him≈øelf no I≈ø≈øue, ≈øo that Ibrahim Son of Achmat, and his younger Brother, pre≈øerved by ≈øtrange Providence from his fury ≈øucceeded him in the Empire.

div.head: CHAP. XXIII. The Life and Reign of Sultan Ibrahim, the Twefth Emperour of the Turks.
div.p: MOrat being dead as is before recited, Ibrahim the onely Male ≈øurviver of the Ottoman Race, was taken from the Pri≈øon in which his Brother had confined him and proclaimed Emperor, though Morat in his Life time had by his will bequeathed his Empire to the Tartar. This new Emperor being of a ≈øoft nature ≈øuffered him≈øelf to be wholly governed by his Mother, and ≈øuch Mini≈øters as were about him, him≈øelf being altogether weak in his under≈øtanding. So that the War intended again≈øt the Germans was by the Council of the great Vi≈øier reverted on the Co≈ø≈øacks, yet for ≈øome rea≈øon for a while ≈øu≈øpended, the great Vi≈øier in the mean while ≈øtudying to take ≈øuch out of the way that might Eclip≈øe his grandure, and among≈øt the re≈øt he cau≈øed the Captain Ba≈ø≈øa, the decea≈øed Emperors Chief Favorite to be beheaded in Seli≈øtra, whither he had ≈øent him Governour for that purpo≈øe.

The news of Sultan Ibrahims advancement to the Throne, being known to the Chri≈øtian Princes, few of them deferred to ≈øend Amba≈ø≈øadors to congratulate him on that occa≈øion, each making him large Pre≈øents as the manner is, for as 'tis often ≈øaid in this Hi≈øtory none may have Audience of the Turki≈øh Emperour that comes empty handed.

The Grand Signeour about this time greatly addicting him≈øelf to the u≈øe of Women, fell into an Apoplexy which put many in doubt of his recovery, and rai≈øed the greater confu≈øion by rea≈øon he had no Children, and that it was given out by his Women with whom he had to do, that he was not capable of generation, therefore the Councellors con≈øulted among≈øt them≈øelves, that in ca≈øe he died without I≈ø≈øue the Son of a Si≈øter or Neece ≈øhould a≈øcend the Throne, and that in no wi≈øe the Succe≈ø≈øion ≈øhould devolve to the Tartar, who≈øe right it is upon the failure of the Ottoman Male-line, but he ≈øoon after recovering of his indi≈øpo≈øition put them in ≈øome hopes, though that joy was damped by the advice that came to Court of the ruine of ≈øeveral Important Cities on the Frontires of Per≈øia by a terrible Earthquake. Yet the Grand Signeour to ≈øhow the World that he intended ≈øomething, gave Order to the Grand Vi≈øier to be≈øiege A≈øac, po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed by the Co≈ø≈øacks in the Reign of Morat, as is afore≈øaid which he did both by Sea and Land, and not without great lo≈øs of his be≈øt men, reduced it to the Turki≈øh obedience, Anno Dom. 1641. at what time it was abandoned by the Garri≈øon of Co≈ø≈øacks, who de≈øpairing to hold it long departed with all their ≈øub≈øtance.

About the beginning of the following year the doubt of the Grand Signeours improcreation vani≈øhed for one of his Sultane≈ø≈øes brought forth a Son, who was named Mahomet, which repleni≈øhed the Turki≈øh Empire with joy, which Prince now ≈øways the Ottoman Scepter, during the Triumphs for the birth of the young Prince, the Per≈øian King by his Amba≈ø≈øador renewed his League with the Sultan, which was performed upon an additional Article, that the Sophy would demoli≈øh the Fortre≈øs of Fortrina, which
he had built contrary to Articles on the Frontires, not far from the Ca≈øpian Sea, which that it might a≈ø≈øuredly be performed a Capugibathee was di≈øpatched to ≈øee it effected, after which a con≈øiderable body of Turks gathering together in Hungary, endeavoured to ≈øurprize
‚Ä¢ ab a ≈øtrong Garri≈øon on the frontires in this manner, viz. one hundred men being tru≈ø≈øed up in Carts, and covered with Hay and Straw in the habit of Pea≈øants, who getting enterance, were to leap out and ≈øurprize the Centinels that guarded the Gate, at what time four thou≈øand Turks for that purpo≈øe layed in Ambu≈øh were to enter and po≈ø≈øe≈øs them≈øelves of the place, but this Treachery ≈øucceeded not, the Ambu≈øcado being di≈øcovered by an Officer of the Garri≈øon that was abroad, he made it known to the Guards, who notwith≈øtanding permitted the Carts to enter and then drew up the Bridge and unloaded the Carts, which rendred it apparent the intended Treachery in time of Peace, of which the Emperour ≈øent and Amba≈ø≈øador to Con≈øtantinople, but the Turks being a≈øhamed of what had happened, e≈øpecially of their evil ≈øucce≈øs would not admit the Amba≈ø≈øador to his Audience unle≈øs the Emperor would fir≈øt agree to pay a yearly charge of one hundred thou≈øand Rix-Dollars to the Port, not by way of Tribute but of Pre≈øent, in which unrea≈øonable demand they took more confidence for that they well perceived the Emperour was intangled in his Wars with Sweden, the Chri≈øtians di≈ø≈øen≈øion being ever advantagious to the Turks. To the≈øe di≈øhonorable demands the Emperour would in no wi≈øe conde≈øcend, ≈øuppo≈øing it le≈øs perilous to venture a War in Hungary then to comply with propo≈øitions ≈øo derogatory to the Maje≈øty of his C ‚Ä¢ ≈øa ‚Ä¢ ean greatne≈øs.

Ibrahim addicting him≈øelf to the Company of Women then in which he ≈øeemed in nothing more to delight, ≈øpent more Trea≈øure in the ≈øift Wars of Venus, than his Predece≈ø≈øor had done in his Per≈øian Expedition, and ≈øo laboured he therein that Anno Dom. 1643. he had two other Sons born, which ab≈øolutely took away the reproach of his frigidity and impotency, proving afterward the mo≈øt La≈øcivious and devoted Sultan that ever a≈øpired to the Mahometan paradi≈øe, where the Company of fair Women is the chiefe≈øt felicity promi≈øed. Yet that he might not be forgot abroad, he ≈øent out his Fleet of Gallies, under the command of his Captain Ba≈ø≈øa, who after much Trea≈øure ≈øpent without effecting any thing, except ≈øtrangling the Ba≈ø≈øa of Cyprus for his ≈øtore of Wealth he returned.

About this time a great Plague raging at Alexandria, about ≈øix thou≈øand ≈ølaves found means to e≈øcape and carry with them ≈øeveral Ve≈ø≈øels that rode at Anchor in the road, in which they conveyed them≈øelves to Candia and Malta, and from thence many of them found means to depart to their re≈øpective Countries, of which the Grand Signeour having notice, ≈øent to the Signory of Venice to command their redelivery, which not being performed afterwards occa≈øioned the lo≈øs of Candia, as ≈øhall in the Reign of Mahomet the fourth be di≈øcour≈øed of more at large.

Now the year 1644. beginning Rogotskie Prince of Tran≈øylvania, who ≈øucceeded Gabor in that Principality being of a turbulent nature, he ≈øo wrought with the di≈øcontented Hungarians and Au≈øtrians that he cau≈øed them to Rebel, to whom he joyning his Forces, drew after him fifty thou≈øand Hor≈øe and Foot, with which he took Solnock, be≈øieged Filek and Ca≈ø≈øovia,
for ≈øuppre≈ø≈øing of whom the Emperor cau≈øed his Troops to advance, who in divers skirmi≈øhes wor≈øted the Rebels, and overthrew ≈øix thou≈øand Turks, who were coming to the a≈ø≈øi≈øtance of Rogotski, but at length both parties tired with the toiles of War, on the 14th. of Augu≈øt in the following year a Peace was concluded, and ≈øoon after the Grand Signeors Mother ruling all in effect cau≈øed the Grand Vi≈øier to be put to death, thereby to render her Authority more dreadful to the re≈øt, and cau≈øed her Son to appoint Mahomet Ba≈ø≈øa of Dama≈øcus Grand Vi≈øier in his ≈øtead, who was altogether at her devotion as being fir≈øt promoted to the Ba≈ø≈øa-≈øhip of Dama≈øcus, at her in≈øtant ≈øute to her Son Morat Predece≈ø≈øor to this Emperor.

Whil≈øt the≈øe matters were in agitation the Tartars forgetful of their late Peace, made an incur≈øion with thirty thou≈øand men into Ru≈ø≈øia, again≈øt whom Koni≈øpolski having made head with twenty thou≈øand Hor≈øe and Foot defeated them, killing twelve thou≈øand, and taking three thou≈øand Pri≈øoners pur≈øuing the remainder to the Borders of Valachia, in like manner Wi≈ønowick. a noble Polander happily encountering another party of Tartars, as they were returning from the ≈øpoil of a part of Mo≈øcovia, killed ten thou≈øand of them, and recovered a great booty, ≈øending the re≈øt naked into their own Countrey. The Polonians thus prevailing the Grand Signeour to curry favour with the Polonian King, depo≈øed the Tartar Han from his ≈øoveraignty, which cau≈øed various di≈øcour≈øes, but upon the birth of the Grand Signeours fourth Son that wonder cea≈øed, nor was that all which changed the ≈øcene of admiration, for about this time ≈øix Gallies of the Turks pa≈ø≈øing from Con≈øtantinople to Alexandria were taken by the Knights of Malta, which greatly incen≈øed
the Grand Signeour again≈øt the Venetians who had it in charge according to the League concluded between that Signory and the Port, to guard tho≈øe Seas, in≈øomuch that under Pretence of de≈øtroying the I≈øland of Malta, this and former grievances induced the Grand Signeour to make great preparation for the Inva≈øion of Candia formerly called Grete, yet the Venetian Balio or Amba≈ø≈øador was care≈ø≈øed at ≈øuch a rate as he ≈øu≈øpected no ≈øuch Treachery, but the ≈øtate growing jealous upon notice of the great Naval preparation, provided cautiou≈øly for the ≈øafety of their I≈øland.

During the≈øe preparations the Grand Signeor followed his La≈øcivious cour≈øes keeping his female Court in ≈øuch ≈øplendor, that his greate≈øt Trea≈øure was ≈øpent therein, nor was all the Silks of Italy ≈øufficient to ≈øuffice his Women, but upon the fal≈øe rumour that the de≈øign was again≈øt the Malte≈øians, they were not idle but in the be≈øt manner Fortified their chief places of ≈øtrength, yet in the end the ≈øtorm fell not there but upon Candia, for the Fleet of a hundred Gallies, and fifty great Ships with three hundered Saicks, mo≈øt of the latter being pre≈ø≈øed for the tran≈øportation of Souldiers being arrived at Scio after refre≈øhment of the Army con≈øi≈øting of ≈øeven thou≈øand Janizaries, fourteen thou≈øand Spahies, fifty thou≈øand Timariots, three thou≈øand Pioners, be≈øides Cooks, Bakers and other nece≈ø≈øary followers ≈øet ≈øail for Napoli Di Romagnia, and having ≈øtayed there ≈øome time weighed Anchor and touching at divers I≈ølands, ≈øome belonging to the Venetians, and others not, they at length came to Candia (having taken a Venetian Ve≈ø≈øel laden with Ammunition, and bound for Retimo by the way) where no longer being able to hide their intentions they unmasked them≈øelves, by publi≈øhing the War both there and at Con≈øtantinople,
the latter of which was attended with the impri≈øonment of the Balio or Venetian Amba≈ø≈øador, and giving order through all the Archipelago for the en≈ølaving and de≈øtroying all the ≈øubjects of that Republick, and here the Turk practi≈øed his u≈øual beginning of War with more then ordinary caution, for though with other Princes who≈øe Territories border on him by Land, he u≈øually endeavours to ≈øtrike at the ≈øame time when he gives the ≈øalutation of Peace. Yet here being to contend at Sea where he was con≈øcious his forces were inferiour to tho≈øe of Venice, he practi≈øed by a different method, making many vows and prote≈øtations that no ≈øuch thing was intended till he had ≈øafely Landed his Forces, yet were not the Venetians ≈øo ea≈øie of belief, but that they likewi≈øe Armed thirty Gallies, ≈øeventeen Engli≈øh and Dutch Ships, two Gallia≈ø≈øes, and ≈øeveral other Ve≈ø≈øels of force, rai≈øing a great power by Land to tran≈øport into that important I≈øland, imploring the a≈ø≈øi≈øtance of divers Chri≈øtian Princes, who were not backward to their ≈øaid, ≈øending their Fleet to Sea under the Command of Antonio Capello. Franci≈øco Molino being made Proveditor General, who≈øe good conduct in affairs cau≈øed him to be made Proveditor General, and afterwards Duke of Venice, and an expre≈øs ≈øent to Andree Cornaro Inqui≈øitor in Candia, to Arm out twenty Gallies from the Ar≈øenal of Canea, and to promote this de≈øign the better, two Engli≈øh, an one Dutch Ship then in the Port of Mallomocco were hired to carry Timber, fitted and already ≈øquared for the compleating the ≈øaid number of Gallies, and Franci≈øco Erizzo was appointed General of all the Naval Forces, but he being ≈øtricken in years, whil≈øt he intended to crown the remainder of his dayes with glory was taken off by death, leaving ≈øufficiently graced with
the memory of his pa≈øt actions; yet the Fleet was no ways ob≈øtructed, but with a pro≈øperous gale ≈øailed to Corfu, and from thence to Candia, where the Turks were arrived before them and had landed without oppo≈øition, occa≈øioned by the difference (that antient Remora) among≈øt the Chri≈øtian Princes Confederates, with the Venetians about bearing the flag, which was vigorou≈øly contended for by the Genoways and Florentines, nor could it be reconciled though the Pope earne≈øtly laboured therein, advi≈øing them for the deciding the controver≈øie at a time when the urgency admitted of no delay to wave Ceremonies, yet ere they could come to the a≈ø≈øi≈øtance of the Venetians, the Turks had ≈øpoiled a great part of the I≈øland, and after divers skirmi≈øhes with much blood and ≈ølaughter took Canea, the ≈øecond City of importance, and after that Retimo, in defence of which Andrea Cornaro lo≈øt his Life by a Mu≈øquet ≈øhot.

Anno 1646. The opportunity was fair for de≈øtroying the Turks Fleet as it carele≈øly rod at Anchor near the I≈øle of Theodoro oppo≈øite to Canea, where had the advantage been improved it might ea≈øily have been burnt, but ≈øuch was the contention among≈øt the Chri≈øtian Commanders, that nothing was attempted worthy of mention, whereupon Molino General of the Venetian Land Forces was revoked by the Senate, and di≈ømi≈ø≈øed of his high charge, Capello being appointed to ≈øucceed him, who being ≈øtrengthned with an additional ≈øupply of Gallies, Gallia≈ø≈øes and Ships of War he wa≈øted the I≈øland, whil≈øt Moro≈øini with two and twenty Ships faced the Towers of the Dordanellis in the Helle≈øpont, and braved the Ottoman power incountering ≈øuch Gallies as in a dead calm were ≈øent out again≈øt him, which
after a ≈øharp di≈øpute he obliged to retire, and then ≈øailed to joyn his Admiral per≈øwading him to give the Turks Battle, but whil≈øt he delayed they landed an additional ≈øtrength of forty thou≈øand men on the I≈øland, and kept their Gallies ≈øo clo≈øe within the Harbour that they could not be indammaged without great di≈øadvantage to the Chri≈øtians, nor did the Fire-Ships too late prepared to burn them ≈øucceed, by rea≈øon they took Fire too ≈øoon; yet the ≈øucceeding year Moro≈øini having notice that the Turks were Landed at Scio, and that they carele≈øly romed up and down, came thither with divers Ships of War took ≈øeveral of their Gallies, and in them many pri≈øoners of note, but ≈øoon afterward being ≈øerated from his Squadron in a ≈øtorm, he was ≈øet upon by fifteen Gallies of Rhodes and boarded, where fighting valiantly he was ≈ølain by a Mu≈øquet Bullet, yet his Ship upon the coming in of two Gallia≈ø≈øes was re≈øcued. The funeral ≈øolemnity of this renowned Captain was celebrated with all Pomp at Venice.

Not by Sea only but at Land the Turks invaded the Venetian Territories, for pouring a multitude of men into Dalmatia, yet were not greatly ≈øucce≈øsful for Leonardo Fo≈øcolo the Venetian General, on that ≈øide overthrew their Forces in divers conflicts.

In one of which he took the Sanzack Licca, and ≈ølew his Son, recovered Saccovar, Poli≈ø≈øano, I≈ølan, and Novogrode, the latter of which by order of the Senate he demoli≈øhed, and pur≈øuing his good ≈øucce≈øs took all the Cities and Towns the Turks held on that ≈øide, utterly driving them out of Dalmatia, but this joy was palliated by the unwelcome news of the Fleets being wrecked in the Archipelago, and a great number of Ships and Gallies broken to pieces,
which ≈øo rai≈øed the drooping courage of the Turks that they advanced to the Walls of Candia, and ≈øtraitly be≈øieged it but were ≈øo valiantly repul≈øed by the Chri≈øtians that had put them≈øelves into it that after the lo≈øs of thirty thou≈øand men they were obliged to retire as not being capable of gaining it, though Fo≈øcolo about this time proved ≈øucce≈øsful in taking Cli≈ø≈øa, a ≈øtrong Fort ≈øcituate in the confines of Dalmatia, and overthrew Feckeli Ba≈ø≈øa killing and taking Pri≈øoners the greate≈øt part of his Army, which cau≈øed Morlaches to revolt, and ≈øeveral of the principal inhabitants of Scutary to treat with the Venetian General about putting that City into his hands, to take po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of which ≈øeven thou≈øand men were ≈øent who ≈øeized ≈øome ≈øeveral ≈ømal places, but ere they could arrive at Scutari, their de≈øign was di≈øcovered and they obliged for the pre≈øervation of their lives, to betake them≈øelves to the Mountains for as many as were taken the Turks impailed them alive.

The Grand Vi≈øier inraged for the lo≈øs of Cli≈ø≈øa di≈øpatched Dervis Ba≈ø≈øa into part of Bo≈øna with a powerful Army to a≈ø≈øault Spelatro, again≈øt whom the Venetian General marched together with Serich Capt. of Morlaches, but by rea≈øon of the Chri≈øtians di≈øorderly march, in gathering the ≈øpoil of the Countrey, the Turks ≈øet upon a part of the Army and put it to the rout, though Serich and other Dalmatian Captains did all that men could perform In this conflict 400 Chri≈øtians were ≈ølain and as many taken Pri≈øoners, among≈øt the latter of which was the Captain of Moriaches whom the Turks flayed alive, and afterwards impailed, yet though they ≈øubdued his body they could not conquer his invincible mind, he bearing the ≈øame Con≈øtancy and Re≈øolution in his torments as he had done in Battle.

During the≈øe tran≈øactions Ibrahim indulged him≈øelf in all manner of plea≈øures leaving the management of all his affairs to his Ba≈ø≈øa, him≈øelf being wholly directed by a wench, who in the nature of a Baud or procurer went from bath to bath to take a view of the Ladies, and tho≈øe ≈øhe perceived faire≈øt, ≈øhe inquired out the places of their abode and recommended them to her Lord, who upon hearing her prai≈øe their beauty would in≈øtantly be enamoured of them and ≈øend to fetch them either by fair means or force to his Bed. This cour≈øe taken for a while without coutroul, ≈øhe at length filled his ears with the commendation of a Sultane≈øs, Widow to his brother Morat decea≈øed, but this Woman could by no intreaty be won to his Lu≈øt, nor obliged with pre≈øents to comply alledging ≈øhe had vowed perpetual Widowhood, and that her former Lord to was living in conceit, which denyal the more inraged Ibrahim now grown impatient of delay, wherefore he intended to ≈ønatch that by force that intreaty could not gain, wherefore watching her one day as ≈øhe came out of the Bath, he ≈øiezed her in his armes, which ≈øhe perceiving re≈øolved upon the defence of her Cha≈øtity, and therefore drew her Dagger (a weapon which the Sultane≈øs and Chief Lady wear at their ≈øides) and offered to wound him in her own defence, which ob≈øerving let go his hold, at what time the bu≈øtle cau≈øing a loud clamour his Mother came from her apartment, who under≈øtanding what had happened began to reprove her ≈øon of his la≈øcivious behaviour, during which the Sultane≈øs found means to e≈øcape, which ≈øo incen≈øed Ibrahim that he confined his Mother to the old Seraglio, interdicting her his pre≈øence till with ≈øubmi≈ø≈øion and many intreaties ≈øhe had obtained pardon.

After the lo≈øs of this Sultane≈øs his procurer called by him Shecher Para, ca≈øting her eyes upon the Daughter of the Mufti a young Lady of excellent beauty, ≈øo warmed the heart of Ibrahim with the relation of her rare perfections, that he re≈øolved to have her at any rate, and therefore at fir≈øt re≈øolved to ≈øend for her by force, but con≈øidering the power of the Mufti, he upon ≈øecond thoughts ≈øuppoled it not convenient to incen≈øe him by ≈øuch a ra≈øh action, but rather to ≈øend for him and to treat with him about taking his daughter to be one of his Sultana's, which he did, and rea≈øoned with him about that affair, but the old man who intirely loved his daughter and well con≈øidering the wandering loves of Ibrahim, and that he having already ≈øons her off ≈øpring would be either poi≈øoned, ≈øtrangled or become ≈øad reclu≈øes after his death, inwardly re≈øolved not to con≈øent to his reque≈øt, yet di≈ø≈øembled the matter in excu≈øing ≈øo great an honour to one that was unworthy of it, but withal concluded to deal with his Daughter in the be≈øt mannen to the Sultans advantage, but by their Law could oblige her therein no further then her free con≈øent allowed.

Plea≈øed with this an≈øwer Ibrahim di≈ømi≈ø≈øed the Mufti with ≈øeveral rich pre≈øents, thinking his wi≈øhes ≈øhould now be ≈øatisfied, but the old man having hardened his Daughter not to accept this offer returned with the unexpected news next morning, that notwith≈øtanding his per≈øwa≈øion and paternal commands, his Daughter proved aver≈øe contrary to his expectation, but the rea≈øon he knew not how to conjecture, ≈øince Women are commonly irregular and unrea≈øonable in their affections, Ibrahim in this manner di≈øappointed of what he mo≈øt de≈øired, di≈ømi≈ø≈øed the Mufti with neglect and di≈ødaign, as one who had deceived his tru≈øt ≈øoon after bani≈øhed him the Court
and his pre≈øence, growing un≈øatisfied at all his admini≈øtrations of Ju≈øtice, and re≈øolved another cour≈øe for obtaining the young Lady, the management of which he committed to her who had recommended her to him, who a≈ø≈øaulted her with promi≈øes of greatne≈øs, rich gifts, and many fair words, but finding the Virgin to be deaf to her Sirens ≈øong, ≈øhe at la≈øt taking pitty of ≈øuch innocence and vertue at her reque≈øt and for a great reward, promi≈øed ≈øo to deal with the Sultan that he ≈øhould put her out of his thoughts which ≈øhe attempted but in vain, for Ibrahim who by this time had viewed her rare perfections was ≈øo inamoured of her, that ≈øleeping or waking he fancyed her Ides before him, whereupon finding fair means ineffectual he re≈øolved to u≈øe tho≈øe he had often done, wherefore he commanded the Grand Vi≈øier, that next time ≈øhe came to the bath he ≈øet a Guard upon her, and by force bring her to his Bed, which was accordingly done, and Ibrahim for ≈øome dayes enjoyed her, but ≈øullenne≈øs, tears and reluctancy much abated the plea≈øure he expected for ≈øhe would by no means be comforted, wherefore with ≈øcorn and contempt he returned her to her father, who at fir≈øt di≈ø≈øembled the injury and di≈øgrace, but in the end making his re≈øentments known to Mahomet Ba≈ø≈øa a Principal member of the Divano, one of great Wi≈ødom and practi≈øe in the conduct of affairs, as al≈øo to the Aga of the Janizaries, both Enemies to the Grand Vi≈øier. It was concluded the Queen Mother ≈øhould be drawn into the Con≈øpiracy, but how to do it again≈øt her Son they knew not well, therefore re≈øolved fir≈øt the de≈øtruction of the Grand Vi≈øier by laying to his charge the contrivance of the Rape, as well as the forceable ≈øeizing of the Virgin, though they aimed at depo≈øing the Grand Signeour.

The Plot thus layed the Mufti begged an Audience of the Queen as if the would intreat her to become an humble Interce≈ø≈øor for him to her Son, and being admitted to her pre≈øence, after ≈øome conference he plainly perceived her inveterate hatred again≈øt Ibrahim which made him break his mind more boldly to her and in the end to propo≈øe the Impri≈øonment of the Grand Signeor yet palliated his di≈øcour≈øe with this allay, that he ≈øhould not be ab≈øolutely layed a≈øide but only corrected a while, and thereby put in remembrance of his former ≈øtate, that ≈øo for the future he might be in≈øtructed what moderation and Ju≈øtice meant, and ≈øo in≈øinuated that the Queen in hopes of Governing all con≈øented to what he propo≈øed, whereupon ≈øtrengthening their party they ≈øo wrought that they cau≈øed the Janizaries to mutiny, and went at the heard of them to the Grand Signeour, as ≈øeemingly forced to do by the rude Soldiers, and being admitted they boldly demanded that the Grand Vi≈øier ≈øhould be deprived of his office, and that (as it had been before agreed among≈øt the Con≈øpirators) Mahomet Ba≈ø≈øa ≈øhould ≈øucceed him in his office, which the Grand Signeour at fir≈øt refu≈øed, but being per≈øwaded by his Mother that it was at that time nece≈ø≈øary ≈øo to do for appea≈øing the Tumultuary Souldiers he con≈øented. Achmet the depo≈øed Vi≈øier trembling at the con≈øequences hereof, re≈øolved to commit him≈øelf to the protection of his mercile≈øs Enemy the Mufti, and therefore ha≈øtened to his hou≈øe to attend his return, hoping to find him his protector, but the Mufti returning with the Aga of the Janizaries, and finding the depo≈øed Vi≈øier in his hou≈øe, the latter by the advice of the former delivered him up to the fury of the Souldiers who having ≈øtrangled him threw his dead body before the gate of the new Mo≈øch.

The next day the Janizaries ari≈øing in like tumult as before, demanded of the Mufti whether according to their Law Ibrahim as a Fool, Tyrant, and one unfit to wield the Ottoman Scepter, ought not to be depo≈øed. To which the Mufti gave an≈øwer in the affirmative, and cau≈øed Ibrahim to be ≈øummoned the next day to appear in the Divano to admini≈øter Ju≈øtice to his Subjects, and Souldiers who expected it from him. But the Sultan ≈øuppo≈øing he had ≈øufficiently ≈øatisfied the Souldiers by putting the Grand Vi≈øier out of office, laughed at the ≈øummons the Mufti had made him which being ≈øeconded by a Fetfa (which is a point of Law re≈øolved by the Mufti, who is the mouth and Oracle of the Law, viz. that the Grand Signeour called to account is obliged to appear before the Ju≈øtice.) The Sultan in high di≈ødaign tore the paper, threatning the head of the Mufti, but it was now too late he having ≈øurely fortified him≈øelf with the power and ≈øtrength of his rebellious companions. This Fetfa was immediately ≈øeconded by a ≈øummons of a higher nature which declared that who≈øoever di≈øobeyed the Law of God was not a true Mu≈ø≈øulman or believer, and though the Per≈øon of the Emperour him≈øelf, yet being become by his actions a Rafir or Infidel was ip≈øo facto fallen from his Throne, and no further capable of Authority or Government. This Fetfa being ≈øeen by Ibrahim he likewi≈øe tore it, commanding the Grand Vi≈øier in≈øtantly to put the Mufti to death as guilty of Trea≈øon again≈øt his Emperour, but having by this time lo≈øt his Authority, his commands were not obeyed, nor his per≈øon reverenced, for the Janizaries being a≈ø≈øembled about five in the afternoon came with their u≈øual tumults to the gates of the Seraglio, at who≈øe approach Ibrahim lo≈øing all courage fled to his Mother for protection, begging her a≈ø≈øi≈øtance
who being a bold and ≈øubtle Woman u≈øed all her Rhetorick and Eloquence to per≈øwade the Souldiers not to offer any violence to the per≈øon of their Lord, promi≈øing that he ≈øhould relinqui≈øh the Government, and retire him≈øelf with a guard into the Lodging out of which he was advanced to the Empire. Ibrahim comforted a little that his Life was ≈øpared willingly ≈øubmitted him≈øelf a Pri≈øoner, when in the mean time the Souldiers taking forth his Elde≈øt Son Sultan Mahomet placed him on the Throne, every where proclaiming him Emperour with loud Acclamations of which Ibrahim having notice grew impatient, and often with ≈øad laments beat his head again≈øt the Wall, till at length to put a ≈øtop to his fury four Mutes were ≈øent to ≈øtrangle him, who on the 17th. of Augu≈øt, Anno Dom. 1648. performed that barbarous exploit, ≈øo that according to the ≈øaying of King Charles the fir≈øt of Ble≈ø≈øed Memory. There is but little di≈øtance between the Pri≈øons and Graves of Princes.

Sultan Ibrahim being thus made away Anno Dom. 1648. in the 8th. year of his Reign, and 39 of his Age, the Government was committed into the hands of the Grand Vi≈øier, and the Queen Mother called by the Turks Rio≈øem, and of 12 Ba≈ø≈øa's, who were to manage all affaires with ≈øupream power during the Minority of Sultan Mahomet, who≈øe Reign I ≈øhall pur≈øue in the following chapter.

div.head: CHAP. XXII. The Reign of Mehmet or Mahomet the fourth of that Name, and Thirteenth Emperor of the Turks, who now Reigneth.
div.p:
IBrahim depo≈øed and murthered as in the foregoing Chapter is related, Mehmet or rather Mahomet his Elde≈øt Son of the Age of ≈øeven years ≈øupplyed the empty Throne, during who≈øe minority which was to continue ten years longer, His Grand Mother, the Grand Vi≈øier and twelve Ba≈ø≈øa's took into their hands the Reins of Government, and after many debates re≈øolved to continue the War with the Venetians which Ibrahim de≈øigned to conclude the treaty of Peace in order thereto being far advanced and the Amba≈ø≈øador of that Signiory, then at the Port impatiently expecting an end of his negotiation, but whil≈øt the≈øe affairs were in hand the unruly Spahi's not having received the Large≈øs u≈øually be≈øtowed among≈øt them at the In≈øtallment of a new Emperour, making it their pretence the better to colour their di≈øcontents, that they were re≈øolved to revenge the death of the murdered Emperour who≈øe fall the Janizaries had occa≈øioned, in≈øomuch that a great difference aro≈øe between tho≈øe two orders, the former being the be≈øt Hor≈øemen, and the latter the be≈øt Footmen, and although many laboured to appea≈øe that Tempe≈øt which threatned the di≈ømembering the Empire. Yet many skirmi≈øhes happened between the≈øe contrary Factions in the
≈øtreets of Con≈øtantinople, in which ≈øome hundreds were ≈ølain, but the Spahies being for the mo≈øt part wor≈øted at length abandoned the City.

The≈øe animo≈øities and divi≈øions among≈øt the Turki≈øh Souldiers, gave the Venetians opportunity to provide for their defence, as expecting nothing le≈øs then a War, for that their Amba≈ø≈øador had been clapped up on Pri≈øon for demanding Audience, and chains put upon him, but at the intreaty of the other Chri≈øtian Amba≈ø≈øadors there re≈øiding he was ≈øet at Liberty. Yet to affront him the Grand Vi≈øier cau≈øed his Dugerman or Interpreter to be executed, and his body thrown out at the Ca≈øtle Window, which barbarous act is frequent among≈øt the Turks, either to put a di≈øgrace upon the Amba≈ø≈øador, or to terrifie tho≈øe Interpreters that they ≈øhall not dare to ≈øpeak any thing after an Amba≈ø≈øador though upon his Audience, that ≈øhould be ungrateful to the Grand Signeour, which cau≈øes them many times to mince their words and not render a true interpretation.

The≈øe matters widening differences between the Venetians and the Turks, great preparations were made on either ≈øide, the former with all diligence reinforcing Candia, and the latter to hinder it; ≈øo that many skirmi≈øhed happened by Land and Sea, till at length the Ba≈ø≈øa Governour notwith≈øtanding the Venetian Fleet blocked up the Dardaneles, having received a recruit of 1500 men laid ≈øiege to the ≈øtrong City Candia, and battered it with many pieces of Ordinance, till at length having taken a ≈ømall Fort that flanked it, he lodged his men therein ju≈øt as 6 Gallies of Malta arrived with 600 Voluntiers, and 60 Knights of the Order, who beat out the Turks with great ≈ølaughter, yet they retook it again and planted the Ottoman colours upon the highe≈øt Bullwark
which ≈øo inraged the Chri≈øtians that ≈øallying with all their force they drove the Turks from the Walls with great ≈ølaughter, regained the piece, and cau≈øed the Ba≈ø≈øa with ≈øhame and lo≈øs to rai≈øe the ≈øiege.

The Wars growing hot in Candia, the di≈øcontents between the Spahi and Janizaries that was before ≈øuppo≈øed to be appea≈øed grew hot again, and much ≈ølaughter happened between tho≈øe inveterate factions, when to pacifie the latter the great Vi≈øier was depo≈øed and executed. Yet that little availed nor was that all for ≈øeveral of the Ba≈ø≈øa's denyed to return the Tribute of their Provinces, alledging they would re≈øerve it till the Grand Signeour was of age, and then be to him accountable both for principal and intere≈øt, nor were the Wars in Bo≈øna, Dalmatia, Fo≈øcolo, and other places on the Venetian Frontires neglected, but continued with doubtful ≈øucce≈øs, and great ≈ølaughter, yet part of the Ottoman Forces on that ≈øide were diverted by the Co≈ø≈øacks, who at the in≈øtigation of the Tartar Han covered the Black Sea, with their Boats and committed many outrages in≈øomuch that Con≈øtantinople trembled at their approach as fearing a ≈øack by the hands of tho≈øe re≈øolute people, but in the end having gotten a rich booty they returned to their ≈øtation.

The Venetians finding the Turks re≈øolute bent to make them≈øelves ab≈øolute Lords of Candia in which I≈øland they had got ≈øtrong footing laboured as earne≈øtly to expell them, ≈øo that huge Fleets on either ≈øide were prepared that of the Turks con≈øi≈øting of 1100 Ships, Gallies, Gallea≈ø≈øes, Saiques, Brigantines and le≈ø≈øer Ve≈ø≈øels furni≈øhed with Bombes, Mortar-pieces, and Fireworks, producing ≈øtrange effects, and in that order ≈øet forward from the Port of Con≈øtantinople, with a ≈øtrict command to give Battle of which Mocenigo the Venetian Admiral having notice
with the ≈øame willingne≈øs bore up with them, ≈øo that there began a bloody, and for a long time doubtful Fight, but the Venetians being better appointed than the Turks, broke and di≈øordered their huge Armado, ≈øinking and taking ≈øeveral Galleys, and putting the re≈øt to flight, killing in one of them flying, the Ba≈ø≈øa of Anatolia, who was ≈øent to ≈øuccede Chu≈øadin Ba≈ø≈øa, who had been made Grand Vi≈øier in the General Ship of Candia, yet the Turks having put into the I≈ølands, and conceiving it a ≈øhame for ≈øo great a Fleet to fly from one much inferiour in number, re≈øolved to hazard another Battle, and therefore coming out of the ≈øeveral Harbours, and ranging in the form of a Cre≈øcent, the Captain Ba≈ø≈øa fired two Guns a Stern, in token he was ready to Ingage, which Mocenigo perceiving, bore up with him, and began a ≈øecond fight more dreadful than the former, playing with his Canon ≈øo furiou≈øly, that he broke off her Poop, and killed 100 ≈øo her Men, ≈øinking two Galleys by her ≈øide, and greatly di≈øablihng ≈øeveral others; nor were the Turks idle, but u≈øed their utmo≈øt endeavour to blot out the di≈øgrace they had ≈øu≈øtained by their late flight, but it availed not; for by the Thundering ≈øhot and Fire-works, the Venetians plyed them with, they were evey where put to the wor≈øt; ≈øo that flying in all parts, the Venetian General following the advantage, took 39 Galleys, 23 Ships, 3 Gallia≈ø≈øes, and 3000 Soldiers, 40 Gallies, Ships, and other Ve≈ø≈øels were burnt, or ≈øunk; and in them, and by the great and ≈ømall ≈øhot, 9000 Turks peri≈øhed in both Ingagements, the re≈øt hardly e≈øcaping to Naxos.

This great lo≈øs made the Turks out of heart with marine Affairs, and ≈øo far di≈øcouraged them, that ever ≈øince they have layd a≈øide building Ve≈ø≈øels of Force as u≈øele≈øs, ≈øay that God hath given the Sea to Chri≈øtians, and the Land to Turks.

About this time came news to Con≈øtantinople that the people of Grand Cario and Dama≈øcus taking the advantage of the inte≈øtine broyles, had rebelled, and ≈øhaken off the Turki≈øh yoke; and a≈ø≈øembling to the number of forty thou≈øand, had ≈øeized upon ≈øeveral ≈øtrong places, many of the Ottoman Governours in tho≈øe parts, conniving at their proceedings, which greatly perplexed the Ba≈ø≈øas of the Divan, and obliged them to u≈øe their utmo≈øt Council to contrive a way to extingui≈øh this Combu≈øtion, during which, the Ca ‚Ä¢ di ‚Ä¢ ts had re≈øt, and Fortified their City in ≈øuch a manner, that it became afterwards the wonder of the World, of which the Grand Vizier having notice, and fuming that his neglect had turned ≈øo much to the advantage of the Chri≈øtians, he re≈øolved to try if he could gain it by fair means, and in order thereto ≈øent a Letter written in Letters of Gold to the Venetian Senate, requiring them to deliver Candia up to the behoof of the Grand Seignior, which was the only ob≈øtacle that hindered the conclu≈øion of Peace, de≈øiring that an Amba≈ø≈øador might be ≈øent to treat about it; but the Venetians remembring that the Turks never made any peace, but when nece≈ø≈øity drove them to it, nor kept it longer than they found it advantagious, and withal called to mind how evilly they had intreated their Amba≈ø≈øador, generou≈øly refu≈øed to hearken to any Peace upon tho≈øe terms commanding their Admiral with his Fleet to block up the Dardanellis, which he ≈øo ≈øtrictly ob≈øerved, that for want of ≈øuccour the Turks in the I≈øland of Candia were greatly di≈øtre≈ø≈øed, and began to mutiny, being hardly with great rewards retained in due obedience, upon which, the Divan ≈øent ≈øtrict orders with many Menaces upon refu≈øal to the Captain Ba≈ø≈øa then in the Bay of Rhodes to force his way through the Venetian Fleet, and put men and
Provi≈øion on ≈øhoar at Candia, thereby to cea≈øe the loud complaints of the Souldiers, yet could not be induced thereto, but having plundered certain I≈ølands he returned to Con≈øtantinople with the Gallies, in hopes with his ill gotten booty to appea≈øe the Divan, b ‚Ä¢ t contrary wi≈øe he was ≈øeized on and the goods ≈øeald up with the Grand Siegniours Signet, which none may on pain of death unloo≈øe without command, yet ≈øuch was the pre≈øumption of his Sons that they broke it open, and putting the riche≈øt of the ≈øpoil, into a Galley, fled to di≈øtant Lands, thereby expo≈øing their fathers life to the fury of this enemies, who having di≈øpatched him con≈øtituted the Ba≈ø≈øa of Buda Captain General in his ≈øtead, u≈øing all diligence to rig out a new Navy, which once done, the new Captain de≈øirous to perform ≈øome exploit that might render him worthy of his place, taking his advantage, broke through the Venetian Fleet, but therein ≈øu≈øtained ≈øuch dammage that he had little cau≈øe to boa≈øt, for the Venetians following him even to the harbours mouth, plyed him ≈øo with thundering ≈øhot, that ≈øeventeen of his Gallies were ≈øunk and taken, and four thou≈øand of his men killed, yet he put twelve thou≈øand men on ≈øhoar, and what provi≈øion he could ≈øpare, receiving order to return when he had repaired his dammage, though at the hazard of battle, the which he did, though with more lo≈øs then went, for that the Venetians having notice of what was intended, ≈øtood continually on their guard, neverthele≈øs he ≈øo extolled his own exploits and demeaned the Courage of the Turki≈øh Ba≈ø≈øa, then General of the Forces in Candia, that he wrought the de≈øtruction of the latter, for none being pre≈øent to plead his Cau≈øe, and Officer was in≈øtantly ≈øent to fetch his head, who≈øe place the foul detracter afterwards injoyed, as likewi≈øe that of Great
Vi≈øier, which he ≈øoon after re≈øigned to the Ba≈ø≈øa of Aleppo, a ≈øtirring active man, who after he had placed and di≈øplaced ≈øuch Officers of the Court as he thought convenient, ≈øent to all the Maritim Ports, Commanding tho≈øe that were appointed to over-≈øee them, with Expedition to ha≈øten thence ≈øuch Ships and Gallies as were ≈øit for Service, determining to ≈øet forth a Fleet greater then what had for many Years before been ≈øeen in the L ‚Ä¢ vant, which was accordingly done, but fared no better then tho≈øe that had been formerly Equiped; For Mu≈øtapha the New Captain Ba≈ø≈øa joyning Battle with the Venetians was overthrown, and mo≈øt of his chief Gallies and Ships of War ≈øo rent by the Cannon, that for the future they were rendered un≈øerviceable, and many fell into the hands of the Venetians, the terror of who≈øe Prowe≈øs was ≈øuch, that tho≈øe Turks that could, abandoned their Ship and fled to the ≈øhoar, leaving their Ships to the Chri≈øtians, in which conflict the Venetians lo≈øt only one Ve≈ø≈øel, which over-powered by a number of the Turks Gallies, was fired by her own men.

The≈øe unfortunate Lo≈ø≈øes much di≈øcouraged the Turki≈øh Merchants, and Inhabitants of Con≈øtantinople, who≈øe Trade was not only ob≈øtructed by rea≈øon of the Seas being ≈øhut up, but they were likewi≈øe oppre≈ø≈øed with heavy Taxes for the maintenance of the War, which made them ≈øo de≈øirous of Peace, that mutining in great Number, they ran to the Gates of the Pallace, Exclaiming again≈øt the Mini≈øters of State for protracting the War, and hindering the procurement of a Peace, nor would be appea≈øed till the Grand Vizier was made a Sacrifice to their Revenge, the Muphti hardly e≈øcaping with Life.

For the better quieting the≈øe Tumults, the Ba≈ø≈øas of the Divan were obliged to enter into a further treaty with the Venetians, offering for Ten Millions to withdraw their Forces out of the I≈øland of Candia, and grant them an intire peace, but this unrea≈øonable demand was not accepted, the Senate knowing that the City of Candia was ≈øo well Fortified that the Turks de≈øpaired of winning it, and thereupon that they might ≈øeem the le≈øs to regard the Ottoman power, they revoaked their Amba≈ø≈øador Seignior Capello, but he through Melancholy and di≈øcontent occa≈øioned by his hard u≈øage at the Port, ≈øoon after dyed, leaving his Commi≈ø≈øion with his Secretary, but that Expiring, nothing more was done at that time, in relation to peace, which cau≈øed another In≈øurrection in the City, which had like to have turned all into ruine and de≈øolation, for the Spahi's and Janizaries joyning together, and pretending to reform abu≈øes of State, depo≈øed the Grand Vizier, di≈øcharged the Principal Officers of the Court, and obliged the Muphti to fly for his Life to Jeru≈øalem, nor ≈øcarcely did the Queen-Mother remain ≈øecure in the old Seraglio, and to ≈øo great a height their Rebellion proceeded, that they propo≈øed the depo≈øing the Grand Seignior, and having thus ca≈øt off all duty and re≈øpect to their Prince, they entered the Pallace in a tumultuous manner, where forcing the Guards, they broke up the Trea≈øury, and conveyed thence Two Millions of Sultanies.

Nor in this General combu≈øtion which continued many days, did the Shops and Ware-hou≈øes of the Merchants e≈øcape pillaging, none daring oppo≈øe the fury of the Licentious Souldiery, who had advanced a ba≈øe fellow of their Faction to the Grand Vizier-≈øhip, though afterward the ≈øtorm alayed, he was
decently layed a≈øide, and one Kuperlee a Grave Turk placed in his ≈øtead, who cau≈øed ≈øeveral of the Mutiniers to be Apprehended, and publiquely Executed.

Notwith≈øtanding the≈øe troubles, the Turks de≈øi≈øted not to carry on the War again≈øt the Venetian, ≈øo re≈øolutely were they bent to have Candia; In their po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion therefore Equiping another Great Fleet, they put to Sea in order to relieve their men in the I≈øland, but being again fought with by Mo ‚Ä¢ errigo the Venetian Admiral, all the Fleet was either taken, ≈øunk or ≈øtranded, upon which the Venetians landed on the I≈øland of Tenedos, and in four dayes became Ma≈øters of it, as al≈øo they did of Stalimene antiently called Lemnos, which lo≈ø≈øes ≈øo incen≈øed the Grand Seignor (by this time grown to under≈øtanding, that he re≈øolved to carry the War into Dalmatia part of the Venetians Seignory, but upon ≈øecond thoughts re≈øolved the recovery of the I≈ølands, and in order thereto put another Fleet to Sea, who after a great dammage ≈øu≈øtained by the Venetian ≈øhot, thru≈øt their men on ≈øhoar in great numbers, and by that means the evil Fortified I≈ølands ≈øo lately taken by the Venetians, were by the Turks recovered, in attempting the relief of which, Mocenigo the Venetian Admiral had his Ship blown up by his powder, accidentally taking fire, by which Accident him≈øelf, together with all that were on board peri≈øhed.

The≈øe important places regained, the treaty of peace was offered to be renewed, and ≈øome overtures were made by the Venetians, but now the Turks would hearken to nothing unle≈øs Candia might be intirely put into their hands, with the Fortre≈øs of Cli≈ø≈øia in Dalmatia, and payment made of three Millions of Gold, for the Dammages ≈øu≈øtained by the War, which unrea≈øonable propo≈øals, ≈øo perjudicial
to the honour of their Seignoury, the Senators Generou≈øly rejected, rather re≈øolving to maintain the War, and defend them≈øelves more vigorou≈øly then ever, which intention known, the Grand Seigniour gave ≈øecond orders for his Army to ≈øpoil Dalmatia, but in their March the Grand Vizier who headed them, having cau≈øed the Ba≈ø≈øa of Aleppos brother, who had a command in the Army to be put to death for coming later to the Rande≈øvous than was appointed, which ≈øo ‚Ä¢ nraged the Ba≈ø≈øa, that rai≈øing 40000 men, he advanced even to the Walls of Con≈øtantinople, burning up the Country before him, and there pitching his Tents, ≈øent to demand the head of the great Vizier, in repri≈øal for that of his Murthered brothers, but not finding his expectations an≈øwered, he ≈øent a ≈øecond Me≈ø≈øenger to demand the heads of 4 other Ba≈ø≈øas of the Council, whom he ≈øaid had been con≈øenting thereto, and upon refu≈øals threatened the de≈øtruction of the City, but the Plague raging there at that time, after he had burnt up all the Country about it, he retired into A≈øia, and there ≈øeting up a Youth of Twenty Years of Age, whom he gave out to be the Lawful Son of Sultan Morat, till that time hidden by his Mother from his Uncles fury; His Army was wonderfully increa≈øed, in≈øomuch that he would hearken to no Propo≈øals of an accommodation, though the Government of divers Provinces were offered, but Exhibited a Proclamation, wherein he declared Mahomet the unrightful Heir to the Ottoman Empire, upon which he was pronounced a Rebel, and all men commanded to ri≈øe up again≈øt him, and de≈øtroy him, but in≈øtead thereof mo≈øt of the A≈øian Forces revolted to him, which made the Divan ≈øuppo≈øe it high time to give a check to the Progre≈øs of his Armes, and thereupon ≈øhipped over the Great Vizier with a pui≈ø≈øant Army, compo≈øed
of the Flower of the Ottoman Chavalarie in Europe, who joyning with the Ba≈ø≈øa, was in a great and mortal battle overthrown: and with his broken Forces obliged to retire, which made the Grand Seigniour with ≈øuch Forces as he could rai≈øe, pa≈øs the Bo≈øphorus, and joyning with the Viziers rallied Souldiers Compo≈øed an Army of Thirty Thou≈øand Hor≈øe, and Seventy Thou≈øand Foot, with which he Marched again≈øt the Ba≈ø≈øa, who≈øe heart at the approach of ≈øo great a power began to fail him, and make him more plyable to hearken to Terms of Agreement, which he propo≈øing to his Council of War, and they approving his Re≈øolution, a place was A≈ø≈øigned for Treaty, and Mortaza Ba≈ø≈øa made the Grand Seigniours Plenipotentiary, the Grand Seigniour promi≈øing to ≈øtand to what ever he ≈øhould Act, as indeed he did, for the Ba≈ø≈øa under pretence of a Treaty, being unadvi≈øed, drawn from his Army, was together with Seventeen of his Attendants ≈øtrangled by the ≈øaid Mortaza, and ≈øuch as he had layed in ambu≈øh for that purpo≈øe, upon notice of which his Army that then con≈øi≈øted of Eighty Thou≈øand Hor≈øe and Foot di≈øper≈øed, every Man ≈øhifting for him≈øelf.

For this Exploit Mortaza was greatly applauded by the Grand Seigniour and Grand Vizier, and had a con≈øiderable command conferred on him in the War, again≈øt Rogotski the Tran≈øilvanian Prince, who≈øe Country about this time the Tartars had entered, at the in≈øtance of the Sultan with a great power, yet was not the A≈øia Rebellion thus extingui≈øhed, for a Nephew of the dead Ba≈ø≈øas rai≈øing great Forces in the Territories of Aleppo, advanced with a Re≈øolution to revenge his Uncles death, to whom joyned the two ≈øons of Chu≈øaein Ba≈ø≈øa, whom the Great Vizier had cau≈øed to be put to death, as al≈øo the Bey of
Torgne, and many others, which rendred this Army as formidable as the precedent, gave new ≈øubject of fear at Con≈øtantinople, but the great Vi≈øier ≈øo managed the matter by ≈øowing di≈ø≈øen≈øion among the chiefs, and be≈øtowing large ≈øums of Money on the Soldiers that the Army dayly dimini≈øhed, till at length it came to nothing; leaving many of the Commanders to the mercy of the Vi≈øier, who never ≈øpared any man that was guilty of a crime, or ≈øu≈øpected to be ≈øo.

A≈øia being again reduced to Obedience, the Grand Seignior had lei≈øure to think of his Wars with the Venetians, and therefore gave ≈øtrict command for part of his Army to march into Daimatia, and the other part to be imbarqued for Candia; he re≈øolving to be≈øiege the Me ‚Ä¢ ropolitan City of that Name; nor were the Venetians ≈ølack for having received a reinforcement of Four Thou≈øand French Foot, and divers other Aids ≈øent them by the Chri≈øtian Princes, their Confederates; They took the Forts of Calamo, Calegro, and Epicarno, hardly di≈øtre≈ø≈øing the Ba≈ø≈øa of Canea in the principal City of his Province; in≈øomuch that he was obliged to write to Con≈øtantinople for ≈øpeedy ≈øuccour, le ‚Ä¢ t that City ≈øhould be lo≈øt; for the Venetians dayly battered it, and pre≈ø≈øed it hard with continual A≈ø≈øaults; but a ≈øupply of Three Thou≈øand fre≈øh men being by Night thru≈øt into it, the Venetians rai≈øed the ≈øiege, and marched to New Candia, (built near to Old Canoia) in hopes to beat the Turks out of it, but prevailed not according to their expectation.

About this time, the Vi≈øier with a Great Army arrived at Belgrade, but there falling ≈øick, he returned to Adrinople, to recover his Health; ≈øwearing, that if he found Death approach, he would ca ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ e all his Phy≈øitians to be put to „Äà‚óä„Äâ which „Äà‚óä„Äâ
≈øervation rendred them double-diligent. The≈øe were the principal revolutions in the Ottoman Empire from the time Mahomet a≈øcended the Throne, till the year 1 ‚Ä¢ 60.

Anno Dom. 1661. About the beginning of this year, His Maje≈øty of Great Britain ≈øent the Earl of Winchel≈øea, his Emba≈ø≈øador, to Con≈øtantinople; who upon his arrival at the Port, was received, as became his Character, with all the Grandeur that the Turks allow to any Emba≈ø≈øador; and after his Audience, conveyed with due Ceremony to the prepared for his reception; and now the Turks being at lei≈øure, invaded Tran≈øylvania, in order to depo≈øe Prince Rogotski, who after having depo≈øed him≈øelf and made his ≈øubmi≈ø≈øion, in hopes to be re≈øtored, but finding his hopes fru≈øtrated, and another advanced in his ≈øtead: Again he a≈ø≈øumed his Government, and rai≈øing a powerful Army, made divers Inroads into the Turki≈øh Dominions, till at la≈øt joyning Battle with the Ba≈ø≈øas of Buda and Teme≈øwar near Julia A ‚Ä¢ ba; where being overthrown and wounded, he fled to Varadia, and there within Fifteen days, dyed of the Hurts received in Battle, yet was it no ways ≈øatisfactory to the proud Ba≈ø≈øas, unle≈øs they might reduce that City, which as they alledged, had taken part with their Ma≈øters Rebels; whereupon drawing down their Army, they layed clo≈øe ≈øiege, which ≈øo terrified the Citizens, that they ≈øent their Deputies to the Cae≈øarean Emperor, to require aid, de≈øiring him to take them into his protection; but whil≈øt the Imperiali≈øts delayed, and made many ≈øcruples of breaking the League with the Turks after many furious A≈ø≈øaults, and great Slaughter on either ≈øide the City was ≈øurrendered. In con≈øideration that the Garri≈øon ≈øhould march out with Drums beating, Colour flying, &c. and to go whither they plea≈øed, which conditions
being performed, the Turks took po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of that ≈øtrong Frontire City.

Anno Dom. 1662. The „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ being informed that the Chri≈øtians had rebuilt ≈øeveral Churches, con≈øumed by the Fires that had happened in Con≈øtantinople, and Gala
‚Ä¢ ia, by ≈øome malicious Phari≈øees, cau≈øed them to be demoli≈øhed, and that the Authors of tho≈øe Buildings ≈øhould be Impri≈øoned; for as much as the Mahome

In this di≈øa≈øter the Governour hardly e≈øcaped, and in his return was but coldly received, for that he by his ra≈øhne≈øs had expo≈øed the lives of ≈øo many brave Soldiers, to the cruel Swords of their barbarous Enemies, but this cruelty was ≈øoon after revenged upon the Turks in like manner by Count Serini.

The ≈øiege ≈øtill continuing the Turks angry and inflamed with the di≈øgrace of their late foil, endeavoured

Whil≈øt this renowned Champion in the Chri≈øtian cau≈øe ≈øo bravely behaved him≈øelf on the one ≈øide, the affaires in Tran≈øilvania ≈øucceeded not ≈øo well for the Garri≈øon of Clovinopolis wanting pay mutined and delivered up that important place to Apafi, which rouzed the Germans out of their Lethargy, and made them begin to be≈øtir them≈øelves, and the grand Signeour mad at the lo≈øs he had ≈øu≈øtained by the Arms of Serini, ≈øent ≈øharply to reprove the Vi≈øier of negligence charging under ≈øevere penalties to be more vigilant for the future, but in ≈øpite of all he could do, the Count on who≈øe plumes fledged victory ≈øat perching, having a while taken breath plucked other plumes from the Turki≈øh Empire; when to exa≈øperate him the Vi≈øier ≈øent ≈øeveral Troops to take his new Fort of Serni≈øwar, yet not ≈øo covertly but that he had notice thereof, and immediately di≈øpatched a me≈ø≈øenger to his brother Peter Serini, (whom he had left to guard the frontires him≈øelf

Upon news of this ≈øucce≈øs the Count re≈øolved to be≈øiege Cani≈øia, and in order thereunto went di≈øgui≈øed, onely accompanyed with fourteen of his officers to take a view of its ≈øtrength and ≈øcituation but was not ≈øo private therein, but that the Turks had ≈øecret intelligence of his purpo≈øe, and layed an Ambu≈øh of five hundred Hor≈øe ≈øome di≈øtance without the Walls to intrap him, but providence ≈øo ordered it, that by the ≈øwiftne≈øs of his Hor≈øe he broke through them, when at the noi≈øe 300 of his Crotian Hor≈øe coming up he faced about and valiantly at the head of his Troop, charged the Enemy and made of them ≈øuch ≈ølaughter that few of them e≈øcaped death, or bondage. Among≈øt the ≈ølain one was found compleatly armed, with a ≈øilk twi≈øted Cord of divers colours about his wa≈øt, who by the Captives was reported to have taken a ≈øolemn Oath to bring the Count bound in that Cord, and to have layed him at the Vi≈øiers feet, but in this as in mo≈øt humain affairs it was ob≈øerved that when man propo≈øeth God di≈øpo≈øeth.

After this ≈øucce≈øs the Count made known his intention of War again≈øt the Turks, de≈øiring his approbation who by the advice of the Diet at Ratisbon approved of his proceedings, and ≈øent him ≈øupplies of Men and Money, to per≈øi≈øt in his enterprizes, whereupon he ≈øat down before Cani≈øia, and battered it furiou≈øly, but for want of the ≈øupply promi≈øed he at the approach of the Turki≈øh Army which was very numerous rai≈øed the ≈øiege.

The Diet was not idle in ≈øtudying and contriving the pre≈øervation of the Empire, but finding them≈øelves too weak, advi≈øed the Emperor to ≈øend his Amba≈ø≈øadors to his Maje≈øty of Great Brittain, His Maje≈øty of Poland, and the Princes of Italy, to contribute towards the defence of Chri≈øtendom, who all freely, either with Men or Money, ingaging in the common cau≈øe an Army of Four Thou≈øand Thirty Seven Hor≈øe and Sixteen Thou≈øand Nine Hundred Ninety One Foot was Imbodied, and were promi≈øed ≈øucce≈øs the rather by rea≈øon of the Rebellion in Egypt, where ≈øeveral of the Begs had taken up Armes, and driven out the Ba≈ø≈øas, yet the difference among≈øt the Chri≈øtian Commanders retarded their ≈øucce≈øs, and e≈øpecially ≈øome affronts put upon the renowned Count Serini, which not being taken notice of by the Emperor, he ≈øuppo≈øed he connived at them, and therefore retired from the Army, which put a great ≈øtop to their proceedings, upon which the Turks incouraged be≈øieged many places, but with ≈ømall ≈øucce≈øs, for in the end Hu≈øaein Ba≈ø≈øa, General of the Turks Army being incountered by Count Soi≈øe chief Commander of the Imperials, he was overthrown with great ≈ølaughter of his men, when flying to Strigonium he was denyed enterance, and obliged to March to Newhu≈øel, where he was received, the Garri≈øon there being thin, and the tempe≈øt of War at that time threatning that place.

Soi≈øe animated by this ≈øucce≈øs be≈øieged Barcan a ≈øtrong Garri≈øon of the Turks, on the other ≈øide Danubius near to Strigonium, the which after a terrible a≈ø≈øault he took, and after having plundered it, ≈øet it on Fire, and ≈øo marched back to Romora, the News of which made the Turks pa≈øs the River Rab with part of their Army, for Providence ≈øo ordered it, that in the night time abundance of Rain fell, and
the River ≈øwelling kept the other part from pa≈ø≈øing, ≈øo that being divided, that part which had pa≈ø≈øed being ≈øet upon by the Chri≈øtians was routed with great ≈ølaughter, mo≈øt of them peri≈øhing by the Sword or the Water, the ≈ølain of note on both ≈øides being the≈øe, on the Turks I≈ømale Ba≈ø≈øa of Buda, the General of the Spahies, the Aga of the Janizaries, the younge≈øt Son of the Tartar Han, Three other Ba≈ø≈øas, Ali Beg General of Bo≈øna, Thirty Capugiba≈øhes, Thirty Five of the Vi≈øiers Pages, and Three Hundred of his Guard, Fifty Janizaries, Three Thou≈øand Spahes, Fifteen Hundred Bo≈ønacks, Eight Hundred Albanians. Six Hundred Crotians and Hungarians ≈øubject to the Turks, Two Hundred and Fifty Valachians and Moldavians, Six Hundred Tartars, Fifteen Hundred Anatolians, and Four Thou≈øand other A≈øiaticks, in all Seventeen Thou≈øand; Of the Chri≈øtians were ≈ølain about Three Thou≈øand, the chief of which were the Count of Na≈ø≈øan, Charles Count Bracondorf, Count Fulchire General of the Artillery, and Collonel Pleiter with his Leiutenant Collonel, and Serjeant Major.

This great overthrow cau≈øed the Turki≈øh Forces to Mutinye, declaring the War to be undertaken upon an unju≈øt quarrel, alledging that the Total Eclip≈øe of the Moon had before pre≈øaged their evil ≈øucce≈øs, nor could the Vi≈øier appea≈øe them, or ≈øecure his own Life without a promi≈øe to u≈øe his utmo≈øt intere≈øt for an accommodation of Peace between the Empires, yet kept not his word, but immediately ≈øent his Commands to the Princes of Moldavia and Valachia, who had retired to return to the War, whereupon though very unwillingly they returned, after which the Turks Turk Serni≈øwar, the Imperials not ≈øo much as vouch≈øafing to relieve it, which ≈øo afflicted the Noble Mind of the Count Serini, that
growing Melancholly, to divert him≈øelf he often u≈øed Hunting, when one day Cha≈øing a Bore, whom he wounded in ≈øeveral places, the furious Bea≈øt turned upon him, and with his Tusk ≈øtruck him on the Knee, which made him fall to the ground, when before he could recover him≈øelf with a ≈øecond ≈øtroke, he was mortally wounded in the head, and ≈øoon after dyed in the Armes of one of his Pages; This was the end of this valiant Captain, whom his Enemies could never ≈øubdue, to the great grief of all worthy Chri≈øtians, and the joy of the Turks, who≈øe Mortal Enemy he was, a man in dangers mo≈øt couragious, in War valiant, and patient in labour, in peace courteous, and moderate in his plea≈øure, and in fine he was accompli≈øhed with all tho≈øe vertues that renders a man compleat.

After the death of this Count, the Peace between the Empires was concluded, when as the Grand Seigniour being at lea≈øure, plotted the de≈øtruction of his Brothers, but at the per≈øwa≈øion of the Muphti altered his Re≈øolution.

About this time the Grand Vi≈øier indeavoured to depo≈øe the Tartar Han, and place his Son in his ≈øtead, but the young Tartar though barbarous would not con≈øent thereto, but ≈øent his Father ≈øecret notice what was intended again≈øt him, which ≈øo inraged the Tartar, that he u≈øed his utmo≈øt indeavour at the Ottoman Court to overthrow the Vi≈øier, and promote another to that Office, in order to which he dealt with the Ba≈ø≈øa of Buda, promi≈øing him his utmo≈øt intere≈øt at the Port to make him great Vi≈øier, by which, though contrary to his wi≈øh, he de≈øtroyed him for the Vi≈øier, having notice of what had pa≈ø≈øed, obtained a private Commi≈ø≈øion from the Grand Seigniour, by which he Summoned the Ba≈ø≈øa to appear before him, when immediately without any proce≈øs,
proof or accu≈øation, cau≈øed his Head to be ≈øtricken off.

Anno Dom. 1665. The Genoe≈øe ≈øent the Marque≈øs Durazzo as their Envoy Extraordinary to the Ottoman Court, where by gifts and other means, he ≈øo effectually wrote with the Grand Vi≈øier, that a peace in≈øued between the Grand Seigniour and that Republick, the which was the rather accorded to that the War again≈øt Candia might be the better carryed on, on which the Turks ≈øeemed ab≈øolutely bent in order to the Equiping of Gallies and other things nece≈ø≈øary, the Grand Seigniour came from Adrinople to Con≈øtantinople, but before his arrival great part of the Seraglio was burnt to the ground, fired by ≈øome of the women, to prevent the di≈øcovery of their ≈øtealing divers Jewels that garni≈øhed the Royal Cradle, and upon his arrival he de≈øired of the Earl of Winchel≈øea Fifteen Sail of Engli≈øh Men of War, with the con≈øent of His Maje≈øty of Great Brittain, but the Earl excu≈øed it, ≈øaying, that though his Maje≈øty of England did always entertain a good affection and zealous di≈øpo≈øition towards the affairs of the Ottoman Port, yet at pre≈øent the Wars with Holland, and ill under≈øtanding with France, made his occa≈øions for his own Shipping more urgent then u≈øual, and the time mo≈øt un≈øea≈øonable to pre≈øs his Maje≈øty in that particular, whereupon the Grand Vi≈øier gave order for the building Sixty Gallies again≈øt the Spring, at what time a great Fleet was in a readyne≈øs, ≈øeveral Engli≈øh, French and Dutch Merchant Men, who were at that time found in the prots of Aleppo, Smyrna, and Alexandria, being pre≈ø≈øed for the ≈øervice.

The≈øe proceedings greatly alarumed the Venetians, in≈øomuch that they delayed nothing that was requi≈øite for the defence of their important City of Candia, the which who ever holds, commands the re≈øt
of the I≈øland, whereupon the Marque≈øs Ghiron Franci≈øeo Villa a brave Souldier, was entertained as General of Foot, and a Sallary of twelve thou≈øand Crowns per Annum alowed him, with a large Commi≈ø≈øion not to be ≈øubject to any command, but that of the Captain Generals, who with a great train arriving at Venice made an Oration to the people, wherein he incouraged them to the utmo≈øt to fight again≈øt the enemies of their Country and Religion with wearyne≈øs, and chearfully to provide all nece≈ø≈øaries for ≈øo honourable a War, whereupon they fitted their Fleet with all things nece≈ø≈øary, and ≈øtrengthened their Forts both with Hor≈øe and Foot drawn out of their Garri≈øons on the Terra Firma, being a≈ø≈øi≈øted with Men and Money from other Princes and States; The Pope gave them permi≈ø≈øions to levy four thou≈øand men out of his Countries, the Emperor likewi≈øe notwith≈øtanding the peace furni≈øhed them with con≈øiderable Forces, to which were additions made from other parts of Germany, and indeed from many of the Chri≈øtian Princes, who were grieved to ≈øee an Infidel incroach yet farther into Europe, but above all the French King contributed largely, though at the ≈øame time he ≈øent Moun≈øier d' Vently his Amba≈ø≈øador to the Port, who as the former received many affronts during his re≈øidence there; The Captain of the Ship that brought him thither likewi≈øe was ordered by the Grand Seignior to be Executed, for too rudely pre≈ø≈øing into his pre≈øence, which Sentence had been put in Execution had not the Bo≈øtangi Ba≈ø≈øa interceeded for him, yet he neverthele≈øs was impri≈øoned and put in chains, nor could the Amba≈ø≈øador without a great Sum procure his Liberty, nor at his Audiences had of the Grand Seignior and Grand Vi≈øi ‚Ä¢ r was he received with ≈øuch re≈øpect as became his Character, yet he made the be≈øt on it, boa≈øting to
the other Chri≈øtians, Mini≈øters of the ample ≈øatisfaction he had received both for his own affronts, and the affronts put upon his Predece≈ø≈øors.

Whil≈øt the≈øe things pa≈ø≈øed, the Marque≈øs d' Villa pa≈ø≈øed into Dalmatia to take a view of the Forts and ≈øtrong places on that ≈øide, as fearing whil≈øt the Turks gave out for Candia, they might ≈øuddenly turn their Forces upon that Frontier Territory of the Venetians, but having given ≈øuch nece≈ø≈øary orders as he thought requi≈øite, and being certified from Count Li≈øle the Emperors Amba≈ø≈øador at Con≈øtantinople, that the Grand Vi≈øier early in the Spring would with a pui≈ø≈øant Army land on the I≈øland he ≈øet over, with ≈øuch Forces as he had, to joyn tho≈øe already there.

About the beginning of the Year 1666. great troubles had like to have ri≈øen in the Ottoman Empire, occa≈øioned by one Sabatai Seni a Jew, born at Smyrna, who impiou≈øly pretending him≈øelf to be the Me≈ø≈øia drew after him a multitude of that unhappy nation, declaring that he came to re≈øtore them to their temporal Kingdom, and to gather the ≈øcattered tribes filling their heads with prophe≈øies, dreams and fal≈øe delu≈øions, that they every where credited him, and laying a≈øide all bu≈øine≈øs, prepared for their march to Jeru≈øalem, once more to po≈ø≈øe≈øs the Land of Promi≈øe, and rai≈øe a Glorious Monarchy above what ever their Ance≈øtors could pretend too, and to that purpo≈øe made them≈øelves Garments according to the Levitical Ordinance, ≈øeveral of them affirming that they had ≈øeen Elias, and that he had expre≈øly commanded it, writing to each other many Bla≈øphemous Letters in commendation of their Impo≈øtor, whom they ≈øtile King of Kings, and Lord of all Lords, attributing to him many other vain Titles, nor was it long e'r he became Hydra headed, for other de≈øpicable Jews finding the cheat take ≈øo effectually took up the deceiving
Trade which cau≈øed the Turki≈øh Mini≈øters to nip them, e're they grew too popular, by confining the Ring-Leaders to divers Pri≈øons; and among≈øt other things, the Jews being a≈øhamed that ≈øo many Mi≈ø≈øias ≈øhould at once appear, procured the Impri≈øonment of ≈øome of them, them≈øelves, by accu≈øing them of Adultery, and other heinous Crimes, as for Sabati, he finding his fraud too apparent, renounced the Judai≈øm, and turned Mahometan, and drew many of his Nation to follow his Example, being for that purpo≈øe ≈øet at Liberty, and allowed a pen≈øion for his Maintenance in the Turks Seraglio.

About this time the Emba≈ø≈øadors of either Empire exchanged, that is, the Turks Emba≈ø≈øador returned from Vienna to Con≈øtantinople; and the German Emba≈ø≈øador from Con≈øtantinople, to Vienna; during which, the skirmi≈øhes between the Venetians and the Turks grew hot, Ho≈øtilities being on both ≈øides maintained with great fury, both by Land and Sea, though with various ≈øucce≈øs; ≈øometimes on ≈øide prevailing, and ≈øometimes another; till at la≈øt in was re≈øolved by the Marque≈øs D' Villa, and the Admiral of the Gallies, that by rea≈øon of the great Inundations occa≈øioned by the ince≈ø≈øant rains, that the offen≈øive War ≈øhould be laid a≈øide, and the Forces for better ≈øecurity, incamp near the Walls of Candia, as being the Metropolis of the I≈øland, whil≈øt the Gallies divided into two Squadrons ≈øcowred the Seas, and hindred any new ≈øuccours from Landing; but e're they were incamped, Two Thou≈øand Turks ≈øallying from their Trenches, ≈øet upon the out Guards, beating them from their Po≈øt, and pur≈øuing even to the enterance of the Camp, but being reinforced, the Turk were obliged in di≈øorder to retire; yet the Turks not contented, made another attempt, but with no better ≈øucce≈øs than the former;
though the Lo≈øs was con≈øiderable on either ≈øide; yet the Turks Camp was greatly annoyed by the ≈øhot, from which played furiou≈øly upon their ‚Ä¢ renches; but the Marque≈øs D' Villa having notice of the approach of greater Forces, thought it wi≈ødom to remove his Camp to a place of more advantage, till new aids came to his a≈ø≈øi≈øtance; the which after ‚Ä¢ illing up the Trenches, and blowing up the Forts that they might not profit, the Enemy was performed.

During this Action, the Great Vi≈øier, with a numerous Army Imbarqued on the Gallies at Con≈øtantinople, and after touching at Thebes, arrived at Candia, though by the way, Twelve of his Galleys fell into the hands of the Venetians, mo≈øtly laden with Provi≈øion and Ammunition, taken near the Gulf of
‚Ä¢ olo by the Cavalier, Grimani, Captain of the Gallies; the Vi≈øier upon his arrival went to take a view of the City of Candia, that Bulwark then of Chri≈øtendom, and finding the taking of it would require much time and labour, he returned to Canea, to con≈øult the mea≈øures u≈øed in carrying on the ≈øiege; when in the mean time the Princes of Chri≈øtendom being at di≈øcord among≈øt them≈øelves, were not ≈øo ready in ≈øending the promi≈øed ≈øuccours as was expected, only the Pope and Great Duke of Tu≈øcany kept their promi≈øe, and ≈øome few private men out of their proper Trea≈øury, ≈øent a ≈øupply of Money and Provi≈øion, in≈øomuch, that the juncture did no ways promi≈øed ≈øucce≈øs to the Venetians.

Anno 1667. The Tartars in the depth of Winter entering Poland, layed a great part of it de≈øolate, carrying away One Hundred Thou≈øand Chri≈øtians into mi≈øerable Bondage, which made the Polonian King exhibit a grievous complaint to the Grand Signior; but with all de≈øirous to renew the League between
them: In order to which, he ≈øent his Emba≈ø≈øador with many rich Pre≈øents to the Port, but he being too peremptorie in his demands upon his Audidience, and receiving no an≈øwer agreeable to his expectation, uttered ≈øuch Speeches as cau≈øed the Grand Signior to confine him to his own Hou≈øe, and a Guard to be ≈øet upon him, which ≈øo increa≈øed his fury, that growing high, it ca≈øted him into a Fevour, of which he dyed; when as his Secretary took upon him the character of an Emba≈ø≈øador, expecting a reply to what had been propo≈øed, and within a while after, had an Audience of the Chimacam, but in the end could obtain no other an≈øwer, then that no compen≈øation or pretence ≈øhould ever after be demanded for the damage ≈øu≈øtained by the Tartars in Poland, nor that the Polanders ≈øhould make War upon the Co≈ø≈øacks now revolted from the Obedience of that Crown; but that they ≈øhould immediately make War upon the Mu≈øcovite, and permit the Turki≈øh Merchants to Trade in their Countrey; with this an≈øwer the Secretary was obliged to depart, though it proved nothing grateful to the Poles, who did not vouch≈øafe to return thanks for this une≈øteemed favour, yet by rea≈øon of the differences among≈øt them≈øelves, warred not on Tartary, though ≈øome of the bordering people with any Authentick Commi≈ø≈øion, joyning with a con≈øiderable party of Mu≈øcovians, entered Tartary, and running with Fire and Sword even to the Walls of Coffa their chief City, burnt Three Hundred Villages, and brought away a great booty of Pri≈øoners, Cattle, and the like.

About this time the Ba≈ø≈øa of Ba≈øora revolted from the Grand Signior, and with di≈øplayed In≈øigns marched with an Army of Forty Thou≈øand Hor≈øe and to the great terror of tho≈øe Countreys, which he pretended were of right, his Legal Inheritance
de≈øcended to him by his Ance≈øtors; but the Ba≈ø≈øas of Erzirum, Aleppo, and Dama≈øcus going again≈øt him, routed his Forces, and for the pre≈øervation of his Life, obliged his to fly to the King of Per≈øia.

The Venetian Galleys coa≈øting the I≈øland of Candia, to hinder what in them lay the Landing of Forces on that I≈øland, encountered with Twenty Ships of the Turks, laden with Men and Provi≈øion; mo≈øt of which they burnt, ≈øunk, or took, and a while after had one of the Turki≈øh Galleys brought to them by the Slaves, who had by ≈øtratagem taken it from their Ma≈øters, but the≈øe proceedings ≈øeemed ≈ømall to what afterwards happened; for by this time the Vi≈øier having layed his ≈øiege to one of the ≈øtronge≈øt City in the World, fortified by the mo≈øt indu≈øtrious of men, as far as Humane po≈ø≈øibility could render it impregnable, di≈ømal things in≈øued.

The Town was fortified with ≈øeven great Ba≈øtions, viz. the Sabionera, Vetturi, Je≈øus, Martinengo, Betlem, Panigra, and St. Andrea, all incompa≈ø≈øed with a large and deep Ditch, of which were the Revelin of Spiritto, the Revelin of Panigra flanked to the right, with the Half-Moon of Mecenigo, next thereunto, was the Revelin of Batlem bordering on the work of St. Maries, which to the left had the Revelin of St. Nicholas, and this joyned to the Fortification of de Palma, next whereunto was the Revelin of Priuli, with the redoubt of Crepa Cuore, and over all was the Royal Fort of St. Demetrio, which Commanded the work of Molino, and Sabionera, even to the very Sea.

Before this formidable place, the Vi≈øier pitched his Tents, rai≈øed his Battery, and provided all things nece≈ø≈øary to approach the work, running his Trenches with great celerity to the border of the outworks, but there met with ≈øuch bla≈øts of Aetnean
Fires from the Mines and Farnellos, that they hindred the Turks Traver≈øes, and greatly di≈øincouraged them, con≈øidering that if the Ground was un≈øecure at that di≈øtance, what Aby≈ø≈øes and Cha≈ømas mu≈øt there be prepared to make them Graves under the Walls or enterance of the City, when not to let them breathe, the Chri≈øtians ≈øallyed twice on them, making great ≈ølaughter of ≈øuch as were far advanced in the works; when retiring in confu≈øion, the Collonel of St. Demetrio fell upon them, cutting Two Thou≈øand of them in pieces, e're they could recover their main ≈øtrength; about which time, Captain General Moro≈øini arrived in the Haven with his Galleys, and put One Thou≈øand fre≈øh men into the City, which ≈øo exa≈øperated the Turks, that they re≈øolutely advanced to hinder it, but being within danger by the ≈øpringing of Mines, ≈øome hundreds of them were ≈øent to cut capers in the Air; yet the Turks forced by their Commanders like Moles, continued there working under ground, where many of them dug their own Graves, never more appearing above ground; for being countermined, they were overwhelmed with the bla≈øts of Powder and dreadful Wild-Fires prepared by Ca≈øtellan (the mo≈øt expert Enginere in the World) for that purpo≈øe, yet the Turks with their ≈øtink pots, which flaming, they threw into the works, ≈øo infected the Air with noi≈øom vapours, that long it was e're it could be purged with the burning of Juniper-wood, and Aquavitae.

During the≈øe dayly rancounters, arrived the Auxilarie Galleys from the Pope, and Malte≈øians commanded by Prior Bichi, and Bali Del Bene, as likewi≈øe the Galleys of Naples and Sicily, Commanded by Gianettino Doria, and the Duke of Ferandina, but ≈øuch was the Cowardi≈øe of the≈øe Commanders which
they imputed to, the ≈øtraitne≈øs of their Commi≈ø≈øion, that they dur≈øt not come on ≈øhoar, nor at the in≈øtance of the Marque≈øs D' Villa, ≈øend him ≈øo much as a man, except ≈øuch renowned French Voluntiers as would enter the City, not being under their Command, among≈øt whom was the Cavalier D' Harcourt, of the Hou≈øe of Lorrain, who did ≈øingular ≈øervice by his Valour and Conduct; nor did the≈øe Galleys ought at Sea, but after ≈øome time, coa≈øting the I≈øland, ingloriou≈øly returned home to theirs, and their Ma≈øters Infamy.

The≈øe things happening, the Signior Giavarina ≈øurrendred his charge of Captain of the Galleys to Signeor Pa≈øquelino, and by the order of the Senate, went again to Con≈øtantinople, and from thence pa≈ø≈øed over to treat with the Great Vi≈øier about a truce, but nothing would be con≈øented to, unle≈øs Candia was delivered, whereupon he generou≈øly ≈øcorned to treat further, though the Vi≈øier de≈øired it, and appointed a place for that purpo≈øe, which ≈øo inraged him, that he commanded the Mines about Panigra to be ≈øprung, and a furious A≈ø≈øault to be given, but it proved un≈øucce≈øsful by the great ≈ølaughter of the Turks, who≈øe bodys filled up the ruines of the Mine.

At the end of July arrived Six Hundred Foot, under the Leading of Ottanio Alba, a Noble Venetian bringing with him likewi≈øe Twenty Thou≈øand Ducats, who entring the City, was joyfully received, during which ≈øpaces, the Fights between the Miners under Ground, were as bloody as tho≈øe in the open Field, ≈øo that the Men ≈øeemed to make war in the Grave; nor were the Turks ≈ølow in placing their Mines to advantage, e≈øpecially one, which taking Fire, blew up part of the Half-Moon, leaving thereby a pa≈ø≈øage Twelve Foot wide, at which the Turks pre≈ø≈øing to enter, were mi≈øerably overwhelmed
by the ≈øtorms of ≈øhot that flew like Hail from the Flankers, whereupon the better to make their approaches, the Turks filled ≈øacks of Earth, and planted them near the Walls, which the Chri≈øtians with long Iron hooks drew away, and left them open to the fury of Mu≈øquitiers, who were the more incouraged by another ≈øupply of Five Hundred Venetians, under the Command of Signeour D' Riva, when on the Fifteenth of September, the Chri≈øtians ≈øallyed, and after a hot skirmi≈øh, trained the Turk into the danger of a Mine, which being ≈øprung, ≈øent Three Hundred of them into the Air, yet they continued the Fight very bloody and doubtful, till at length the Chri≈øtians retired under the Ba≈øtion of Betlem, and the Turks with the ≈øhot from thence were beaten off.

About this time, the Grand Signior ≈øent an Expre≈øs to the Vi≈øier, to ≈øend him an exact account how the ≈øiege was carryed on, and what hopes there was
