This proof gave evident Conviction to the Grand Signiors Inqui≈øitor of the ≈øtrength of the place, and difficulty of the work; and having been an Eye-Witne≈øs of what had pa≈ø≈øed, returned with di≈ømal ≈øtories of a cruel War, reporting (perhaps) and it was related in mo≈øt parts of Chri≈øtendom, that this was the place where blood was ≈øpilt day and night, where Gallant Men had forgot to ≈øleep, living in perpetual labours, innur'd to intolerable ≈øufferings, and hourly dangers, there being none ≈øecure in Church, Hou≈øe, or Street; for Granadoes ≈øpouted f ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ e, Cannons thundred out their Iron Globes, Arrows and Stones fell like Hail, ≈øo that there were none in that
place but who quartered on the brink of the Grave.

Winter coming on Ho≈øtilities cea≈øed not though their heat was ≈øomewhat abated, and to the wonder of all men the Vi≈øier could not be per≈øwaded to for≈øake his Trenches, but proving when nece≈ø≈øary he could to ≈øecure his Souldiers from the raging cold and prodigeous Rains he immediately di≈øpatched Letters to the Grand Signeour and Divano, to ≈øend him new ≈øupplies for that his Army was ≈øo wa≈øted that of one hundred and fifty thou≈øand with which he at fir≈øt incamped not a third part of them remained adding that he was re≈øolved to take the City or dye under its Walls, which re≈øolution was highly approved by the Grand Signeour, and a ≈øpeedy di≈øpatch of Men, Provi≈øion, and Ammunition was made when to the Vi≈øier ≈øuppo≈øing to render the Officers of the City more negligent of their tru≈øts ≈øent to propo≈øe certain Articles of Peace and a flag of Truce, but his de≈øign being perceived he drew in his hornes, about which time arrived the new Prove ‚Ä¢ itor Bernardo Navi (the other having been killed with a Mu≈øquet ≈øhot on the Fort of Panigara) bringing with him five hundred Souldiers, and Matteo Mattheus Serjeant General with recruits from the Pope, as likewi≈øe three hundred Meddals, to be≈øtow upon ≈øuch Worthies as ≈øhould be≈øt de≈øerve them.

Anno Dom. 1668. in the month of March a ≈øharp ingagement happened between ≈øixteen Venetian, and twelve Turki≈øh Gallies, the latter not expecting ≈øuch a number in tho≈øe, tho indeed they had been ≈øent to ≈øurprize yet entering into a ≈øharp di≈øpute ≈øix of the Turks Gallies were ≈øunk or taken, and the re≈øt much ≈øhattered e≈øcaped under the ≈øhelter of the

But now what
was the greate≈øt lo≈øs to this famous City the Duke of Savoy (who≈øe ≈øubject the Marque≈øs D' Villa was, recalled him home, his urgent affairs ≈øo requiring, notwith≈øtanding many overtures were made for his continuance, but in obedience to his Prince he imbarked and left his charge to the Marque≈øs St. Andrea Montbrun a Noble man of France, with whom the Venetian Amba≈ø≈øador at Paris by order of the Republick, had prevailed to take upon him the defence and protection of that deplorable reduced now almo≈øt to its ultimate cri≈øis.

Between St. Andrew and the Ravelin of Spirito, where the Turks had planted a Battery of three pieces of Cannon, and rai≈øed ≈øeveral Doubts, a Mine of one hundred ≈øacks of Powder was ≈øprung, which not only overthrew the Battery and Redoubts, but va≈øt quantities of Stones and Timber it carryed into the Air, de≈øtroyed a great number of Turks in their Trenches, and thereupon the Chri≈øtians ≈øallying put them into a great confu≈øion, di≈ømounting and ≈øpiking up their Cannon, but by the lo≈øs of the Duke of Candia who was ≈ølain by a Mu≈øquet ≈øhot, much of the joy for this ≈øucce≈øs was abated, yet three thou≈øand Turks were ≈ølain, and among≈øt them the Ba≈ø≈øa of Canea, and Major General of the Janizaries.

About this time whil≈øt the Grand Signeour was at Lari≈ø≈øa, news came of the near approach of the Excelle ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ≈ø≈øimo Abui≈ø≈øe de Molino Amba≈ø≈øador from the Venetian Republique with Propo≈øitions of Peace, but the haughty Turks before they would admit him to a nearer approach then a days journey, would fir≈øt be re≈øolved whether or no he brought with him the Keys of Candia, to which it was replyed by the Interpreter, that he was not capable of giving them ≈øatisfaction in that particular being but a menial Servant, to whom the ≈øecrets of State and re≈øolutions of great men were not committed, his office being only to render faithfully the words and ≈øen≈øe of his Ma≈øter, and not to enter into the private thoughts, and Cabinet of their Councils. To which the Chimacam proudly and barbarou≈øly replyed, That he ≈øhould go tell his Ma≈øter that unle≈øs he brought the Keys of Candia his head ≈øhould pay for it, and that he pre≈øumed not in per≈øon to approach nearer unto the Court. So the Amba≈ø≈øador remained at a di≈øtance till he received orders to pa≈øs over into Candia, there to treat with the Vi≈øier, who weary of the tedious ≈øiege willingly

Anno 1669 The Turks finding a great cheat through their Empire by light and fal≈øe Moneys introduced by the French, Dutch and Italians (for in

their great Guns to play upon their Enemies Camp, he re≈øolved to fight at the head of the Forlorn hope, con≈øi≈øting of Four Hundred Men, preceded by Fifty Granadeers, flanked with Three Troops of Hor≈øe, Commanded by Count Dampire, and the Regiment of Guards, with Four Troops of Hor≈øe for their Wing flanked with Three Regiments of Foot: The reference con≈øi≈øted of the Regiments of Harcourt, Conti, Lignie ‚Ä¢ es, Ro≈øan, Mont-Pe≈øat, and Vendo≈øme, flanked with Four Troops of Hor≈øe under the Command of Count Choi≈øeul, which placed them≈øelves on a ri≈øing-ground, to hinder all communications between the Vi≈øier, who≈øe Camp was before St. Andrea, and the Janizaries Aga, who was Incamped before Sabi ‚Ä¢

All things being in a readine≈øs, the French about Two hours before day, in the ≈øecrete≈øt manner imaginable, ≈øallied at St. Georges Gate, the Signal to fall on, being the ≈øpringing of the Royal Mine, which through the Dampne≈øs of the Powder, or the timerou≈øne≈øs of the Enginiere, took not effect; the General impatient of delay, not ≈øtaying for the on≈øet of the forlorn-hope, which lay within half Mu≈øquet ≈øhot of the Enemy, a≈ø≈øaulted two redoubts, took them, and put all he found in them to the Sword; with the like courage the other Regiments
entered the Line, and after much blood, and ≈ølaughter, made them≈øelves Ma≈øters of the Trenches, ≈øtorming a Fort, on which was a Battery, directed against St. Demetrio, po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed them≈øelves of it, „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ up all the Cannon found therein, at what time day appearing, di≈øcovered the bloody Scene, which cau≈øed the Turks to ha≈øten from the Hills near New Candia in great number to regain their Trenches, whereupon the Duke D' Navailles perceiving his forlorn hardly be≈øet, came in with Two Troops of Hor≈øe, and two Regiments of Foot; who with great ≈ølaughter beat the Turks out of their Trenches, following the Execution even to the heart of their Camp, but whil≈øt fortune ≈øeemed thus to favour the Chri≈øtians, an unhappy accident fell out, which quite turned the ≈øcale of Victory; for a Magazine of Powder, containing One Hundred Thirty Four Kintals being won from the Turks, and po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed by the Chri≈øtians accidentally, or as ≈øome ≈øuppo≈øe, by lighted Matches purpo≈øely dropped into it; upon its ≈øurrender, blew up with ≈øuch a terrible noi≈øe, that it not only de≈øtroyed mo≈øt of the Battalian of Guards, but terrified the re≈øt of the Army, by making the Earth, as with a violent Earthquake, tremble under them, that they verily believing a great number of Mines were ≈øpringing under them; opened in great confu≈øion to the right and left, and in the end, notwith≈øtanding the endeavours of the Commanders to re≈øtrain them, the Souldiers betook them≈øelves to open and ≈øhameful Flight, nor could they be per≈øwaded to rallie, or once more face the Enemy, but in great di≈øorder, re-entered the City.

The Duke of Beaufort is ≈øaid to have laboured much in re≈øi≈øting the ≈øhameful flight of his Men, and ventering his Per≈øon into danger, from whence he re≈øolved never ingloriou≈øly to retreat, was oppre≈ø≈øed
by Numbers, and fighting couragiou≈øly among≈øt the thicke≈øt of his Enemies, expired on the heaps; but by rea≈øon his Body, though much ≈øought after, could not be found; many conjectured him to have peri≈øhed by the fatal blow of Powder, which ≈øo frighted and di≈øordered the Chri≈øtian Army, nor had the French Fleet much better ≈øucce≈øs; for being driven from ≈øhoar by a ≈øtrong Wind, they little or nothing indamaged the Turks, but received con≈øiderable dammage for a great Ship of Sixty Bra≈øs Guns blew up, in which Two Hundred Ninety Two peri≈øhed, and her ≈øhot pa≈ø≈øing through the Admiral, killed ≈øeveral on board, and indamaged other Ships, by the fall of her Timber and Splinters.

The Lo≈øs the Turks ≈øu≈øtained is uncertain, but however, according to their own report. Eight Thou≈øand are ≈øaid to fall in the Trenches, Forts, and Redoubts; the lo≈øs among≈øt the French con≈øi≈øted mo≈øtly in their Nobility and Officers of note, a fate incident to that Nation, the chief of which were the Duke of Beaufort, Count Ro≈øan, the Marque≈øs D' Fabert, the Chevalier Villereceaux, and the Chevalier D' Quelas, with about Twenty others, all Commanders, and a Thou≈øand common Souldiers, many of note were likewi≈øe wounded, the Pri≈øoners taken, exceeded not Seven or Eight, the chief of which were the Sieur D' Bois, Dauphin Son to a Mar≈øhal of France, of that Name, and the Sieur D' Chateau Neuf the fir≈øt for his youth and beauty, and the ≈øecond for his courage, being afterwards greatly e≈øteemed by the Turks, and both entertained by the Vi≈øier with more genero≈øity than ordinary.

The≈øe proceedings ≈øo amazed and di≈øcouraged the French, that the Duke D' Navailles, now their Commander in chief, could not be per≈øwaded to ≈øtay any
longer in defence of the City, but pretending the Kings expre≈øs command for his return at a time prefixed, and that time being almo≈øt come, notwith≈øtanding the earne≈øt intreaty of the Captain General; he withdrew the greate≈øt part of his Forces, and although he met further orders that injoyned his ≈øtay, yet imbarquing, he returned to France, where for his Cowardi≈øe he was forbid approaching the pre≈øence of the King, or entering the per ‚Ä¢ ues of the Court for a con≈øiderable time.

The French thus departed, the Turks took courage, and attacqued the quarter of Sabionera, and St. Andrea, where putting the out-Guards to flight, they advanced to the Pali≈øado of the new retrenchment, but Vollies of Cannon, and ≈øhowers of Mu≈øquet-≈øhot, with quarries of ≈øtones thrown from the Engines pouring on them, gave a check to their proceedings; but the Candiots perceiving, they oppo≈øed the multitudes of the Enemie in vain, with one voice implored the Captain General to ≈øurrender the City that was not Tenable, and not to expo≈øe them to the fury of a Mercile≈øs Enemy, of whom the Marque≈øs D' Montbourn taking pity, and finding him≈øelf too weak to oppo≈øe ≈øuch powerful Forces as the Turks, by rea≈øon of new ≈øupplys had in their Camp, they as it were already having po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed the main ≈øtrengths of the City, he a≈ø≈øembled a Councel of all the Chief Officers both in the City, and tho≈øe that belonged to the Fleet, who after a ≈øerious con≈øideration, concluded that the City could not by force nor policy be much longer held by rea≈øon of the ≈ømall number of the Defendants, and the incroachment of who≈øe number was ten to one; whereupon the General was of opinion, that having imbarqued all the unnece≈ø≈øary people, and tho≈øe that were wounded, they ≈øhould by firing of Mines
lay the City wa≈øte, and ≈øo leave the Enemy a bloody and inglorious Victory, which Noble Re≈øolution was ≈øeconded by ≈øeveral other Chiefs, but in the end it was agreed that a treaty ≈øhould be had with the Turks about its ≈øurrender, the which after ≈øome debates was concluded on the≈øe Articles.

Fir≈øt, that for obtaining a good and la≈øting peace, it is agreed that the City of Candia with all its Cannon which were planted there before the time of the War, be con≈øigned into the hands of the Vi≈øier.
Secondly, That the quiet po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion be given to the Republique of Suda Carabu≈øa, Spina Longa, and the Territories thereunto belonging, together with the Fortre≈øs of Cali≈ø≈øa and Dalmatia.
Thirdly, That the Venetians may carry away all the Cannon which have been brought into the Town, ≈øince the beginning of the War.
Fourthly, That for Imbarquing the Souldiers, Pioneers, and Inhabitants of all Qualities and Conditions, with their Arms, Provi≈øions, and Baggage Twelve days ≈øhall be allowed.
Fifthly, That what ≈øhall remain un≈øhipped, at the end of Twelve days, the Vi≈øier ≈øhall with his own Boats a≈ø≈øi≈øt the Lading thereof.
Sixthly, That during this time of Truce, no Per≈øon what≈øoever ≈øhall tran≈øgre≈øs his Limits, and he that doth, ≈øhall be treated as an Enemy.

Ninthly, That for better a≈ø≈øurance, that the Venetians will u≈øe all their indeavours to imbarque their
Men; The Turks may imploy two Officers for Eye-Witne≈ø≈øes of the ≈øame.

The≈øe Articles being ≈øigned, the Ho≈øtages were given on both ≈øides, tho≈øe for the Venetians were Fau≈øtino da Riva, Lieutenant General, Giovanni, Commi≈ø≈øary, and Zacar a Mocenigo, who had been Duke of Ca ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ a. Thirteen Millions twelve thou≈øand five hundred weight.

Upon the≈øe Articles Candia was ≈øurrended the news of which coming to the ears of the Grand Signiour he could not for a while believe it, till he had a further confirmation. But as to the renewing the Capitulations the Chimacam ≈øalling at the Grand Signeours feet, implored, That that particular might be deferred untill the arrival of the great Vi ‚Ä¢ er, who≈øe proper power and act it was to make War and Peace, and therefore for him to meddle about capitulations, was to invade the Vi≈øiers Authority, which he dur≈øt not do without putting his Life in danger, or at lea≈øt rendering his per≈øon obnoxious to his irreconcileable di≈øplea≈øure; with which the Grand Signeour being ≈øatisfied, ordered that tha ‚Ä¢ particular ≈øhould be referred to the Grand Vi≈øiers the renewing of which was re≈øerved for the „Äà‚óä„Äâ and „Äà‚óä„Äâ of Sir John Finch, who ≈øucceeded in the Emba≈ø≈øy a ‚Ä¢ ter the death of Sir Daniel Harvy.

Anno 1670. the Grand Vi≈øier having di≈øpo≈øed the affairs of Candia, imbarked for S ‚Ä¢ io, where having ≈øtayed ≈øome dayes revelling in all exce≈øs and drunkenne≈øs he „Äà‚óä„Äâ into a ≈øurfeit, which put ≈øuch an enmity between Wine and him that by ≈øome other motives exa≈øperated, he interdicted the drinking of it upon ≈øevere penalties throughout the Ottoman Empire. The Vi≈øier pa≈ø≈øing from Scio ≈øailed to Rode≈øto, and

The Grand Signeour having before mi≈ø≈øed his de≈øign in making away his Brethren for fear of the Janizaries, now in their ab≈øence mo≈øt of them being bu≈øied in the Wars, renewed his re≈øolution and under pretence of Friend≈øhip poi≈øoned Orcham the Elde≈øt with a bowl of Wine, though ≈øome affirm he was ≈øtrangled with a Bow ≈øtring, and that ere he fell he killed one of the Executioners, but how≈øoever it happened he was made away, who≈øe death once known greatly incen≈øed the people again≈øt the
Grand Signior, and prevented the like effects on the other Brother. All other matters now layed a≈øide about the beginning of the year 1672. preparations were made for the Poli≈øh War though with ≈øuch deliberation as expre≈ø≈øed an unwillingne≈øs thereto on the part of the Ottomans, who having experienced the force of that warlike Nation moved thereto with caution. Upon notice of which the Amba≈ø≈øador was ≈øo ≈øen≈øibly touched that he in a rage ≈øent Letters to the a≈ø≈øembly of the Poli≈øh Nobility to certifie them that he was not only debarred of the allowance u≈øual to Amba≈ø≈øadors but al≈øo was impri≈øoned,
both of which (though untrue, for the former he refu≈øed as too little for one o0f his Character, and the latter being onely his confinement to the City of Con≈øtantinople, by rea≈øon of ≈øome outrages his ≈øervants committed at his hou≈øe at Pera) being believed kindled ≈øuch a flame that the Poles impri≈øoned the Turki≈øh Chiaus, and ordered that all the Countrey ≈øhould be put in Arms rendering the Vi≈øier no other an≈øwer then that when their Amba≈ø≈øador was ≈øet at Liberty and had Licen≈øe to depart, the like ≈øhould be done to theirs. The Grand Signeour having rai≈øed an Army of one hundred fifty thou≈øand men marched towards Poland already ≈øick and langui≈øhing with its own inte≈øtine di≈øtempers, and unable to contend with a body united within it ≈øelf. Yet ≈øuch was the command of the Grand Signeour, that no Souldier ≈øpoiled or outraged any per≈øon, which ≈øo far won upon the affections of the Polonians that they in all places where he pa≈ø≈øed ≈øubmitted, and put them≈øelves under his protection, which ≈øo awakened the Nobility, that a Council being called it was re≈øolved that to buy their Peace, and be ≈øhut of the≈øe new come gue≈øts.
That the King of Poland ≈øhould quit all claim to the ∆≤krain, Pedoli, and Ru≈ø≈øe land.
That Leopolis and the Countrey thereabouts ≈øhould pay a Tribute of ≈øeventy thou≈øand Dollars a year, and all other Capitulations formerly made to ≈øtand in full force and vertue.

The≈øe Articles being ≈øigned the Grand Signeour committed the Government of Veravia, and Podolia to Doro≈øensko General of the Co≈ø≈øacks, and the defence of Cominieck and Chu≈øaein Ba≈ø≈øa, with a Garri≈øon of twelve thou≈øand Janizaries, and ≈øo returned to Con≈øtantinople di≈ømi≈ø≈øing the greate≈øt part of his Army, poor and almo≈øt naked by rea≈øon of their being re≈øtrained from plundering.

About this time Tripol ‚Ä¢ es matined again≈øt O≈øman Ba≈ø≈øa their Governour, for refu≈øing to divide
among≈øt them ≈øuch booties as were taken by Pyracy who thereupon with his Friends and ≈ølaves betook him≈øelf to the ≈øtrong Ca≈øtle, but in the end was ≈øtrangled by his own ≈ølaves, and the gates opened to the Mutiniers who committed all manner of di≈øorders, and re≈øolved to take upon them the ≈øame form of Government with that of Argire, and to be Governed by a Dey, but at length to prevent the effects of the Grand Signeours ju≈øt di≈øplea≈øure, it was re≈øolved to ≈øend their Deputies with great pre≈øents to the Port there to excu≈øe the matter, and to crave a new Ba≈ø≈øa, aggravating the iniquities of the old, all which with ≈øome difficulty was obtained, and fair weather was made between them and their Lord though the Ba≈ø≈øa's of Tripoly, have ever ≈øince been rather in name then power, tho≈øe unruly Pirates doing what they li≈øt, to the great hinderance of Trade, and blemi≈øh to the Ottoman Empire, who living by Theft and Rapine keep peace with none longer then ≈øtands winh their advantage.
In Augu≈øt died the worthy Sir Daniel Harvy His Maje≈øty of great Britains Amba≈ø≈øador at the Port, and ≈øoon after in his room ≈øucceeded Sir John Finch.

The League the Poles made with the Turk was not long ob≈øerved, for after they had recollected them≈øelves being a≈øhamed of ≈øuch inglorious conditions, dealt with the Co≈ø≈øacks to revolt from Doro≈øensko, who had ingaged them in the Grand Signeours intere≈øt, which put all again into hazard and confu≈øion, ≈øo that the Grand Signeour was obliged to give over his pa≈øtimes, and betake him≈øelf to Armes, nor was the unexpected news of the lo≈øs of the Alexandian Fleet, taken by the Gallies of Malta and Cori≈øaries of Legorn le≈øs unwelcome news.

The Poles incouraged by the motion of the Co≈ø≈øacks notwith≈øtanding the Articles, refu≈øed to pay the Tribute agreed on, which by their Amba≈ø≈øador they certified the Grand Signeours Mini≈øters, de≈øiring to have it waved, but the Turk ≈øurprized thereat more earne≈øtly demanded it, though at fir≈øt many fair words were u≈øed but they not prevailing the Grand Signeour gave order for all his Forces to be in a readine≈øs, hanging out the Tough or Hor≈øes tail, and ordering his Tents to be pitched in the Field, & the more to frighten them ≈øent a Letter filled with dreadful menaces agreeable to the Turki≈øh ≈øtile, which threatened them with confu≈øion, Sword, Famine, Fire, de≈øtruction and a thou≈øand other direful puni≈øhments. Yet was not ≈øo forward, for though his Army was imbodied yet that Summer they only pa≈ø≈øed the Danubius, and the en≈øuing Winter quartered about Sili≈øtria, that they may terrifie the Poles the more with their approach, and for the diverting the French Kings Arms from being ≈øerviceable to the Poles, his Amba≈ø≈øador received ≈øatisfaction in what he demanded as to the le≈ø≈øening the cu≈øtoms and allowance of Je≈øuits and Religious Hou≈øes in Juru≈øalem, Galatia and other parts of the Turki≈øh Dominions, and that in all re≈øpects the ≈øubjects of his mo≈øt Chri≈øtian Maje≈øty ≈øhould be every where well intreated, throughout the Ottoman Empire, after which the Amba≈ø≈øador obtained a licen≈øe to travel and take a view of the Countrey, when in the mean while the Poli≈øh Army to the number of 20000 hor≈øe and foot were advancing from the Walls of Leopolis under the command of General Sobieski, and Zircha made General of the Co≈ø≈øacks in the room of Dorisensko, joyning with a party of Ma≈øcovites and Calmuck Tartars, made incur≈øions into the parts about O≈øac, the news of which ≈øo amazed the Grand Signiour that he put off his intended march to
Kemenitiz, and again endeavoured to oblige the Poles by fair means to an ob≈øervation of the Articles, and ≈øatisfie the contents therein concluded, but finding them aver≈øe, he re≈øolved if po≈ø≈øible to compel them thereto by the power of the ≈øword.

The Grand Seigniors forwardne≈øs was not ≈øo great, but that the Poles were as earne≈øt as he, and little regarding his Menaces re≈øolved to be the fir≈øt Agre≈ø≈øors; For General Sobieskie having increa≈øed his Army to the number of Fifty Thou≈øand, boldly pa≈ø≈øed the Nie≈øter, to whom ≈øoon after revolted the Prince, or Vayvod of Moldavia with certain Troops of Hor≈øe and Foot, for that the Ba≈ø≈øa Chu≈øaein had reproached him, and at the head of his Troops ≈øtruck him with his Battle Axe, and the Prince of Valachia was forced into the Poli≈øh Camp by his Souldiers, but he ≈øoon after made his e≈øcape, and was by the Grand Seignior received into favour.

The Armies now approaching, and the Poles having had exact Intelligence of what had pa≈ø≈øed in the Turks Camp; The Battle was begun at what time the Prince of Moldavia in≈øpired with revenge charged furiou≈øly upon Chu≈øeain Ba≈ø≈øa and wounded him, requiting thereby the wound he had received of him. The heat of the fight continued for the ≈øpace of fifteen hours, in which none behaved him≈øelf more valiantly then did Solyman Ba≈ø≈øa the Beglerbeg of Bo≈øna, yet having that day ≈øix hor≈øes killed under him, and finding him≈øelf overpowred, fled the Field, as did Chu≈øaein Ba≈ø≈øa, the Ba≈ø≈øa of Sinas and Chidd-Ogla, but he in flight was ≈ølain, and the other three Ba≈ø≈øa's wounded; The Generals of the Green and Yellow Sangiacks of the Spahies were taken Pri≈øoners, and two other Principal Commanders of that Order killed. The Zagergeeba≈ø≈øa who commanded Eighteen Chambers of the Janizaries was likewi≈øe taken Pri≈øoner
together with the Standard of that Order, and of them Eight Thou≈øand Five Hundred ≈ølain, all the Troops and Attendants of the Ba≈ø≈øa's, with four Sanzacks were ≈ølain, ≈øo that together were computed to be ≈ølain on the part of the Turks in that Battle Twenty Five Thou≈øand Two Hundred Men; The booty taken was very con≈øiderable, for be≈øides the ordinary baggage they took Two Thou≈øand Pur≈øes of Money, newly brought for the payment of the Souldiers, and Twenty Five Thou≈øand Waggons of Provi≈øion and Ammunition.

This victory thus happily obtained, the ≈øtrong Fortre≈øs of Chotin was ≈øurrender'd to the Poles, and many other places of le≈øs importance, for the lo≈øs of which, and the overthrow of his Army, the Grand Seignior was ≈øo highly di≈øplea≈øed with Chu≈øaein Ba≈ø≈øa, that he cau≈øed him to be impri≈øoned, deprived him of all his E≈øtate and Honours, and cau≈øed him to be layed in chains, denying him the u≈øe of Phy≈øitians, or any others, unle≈øs ≈øuch attendants as brought him nece≈ø≈øaries, and thus was this proud Ba≈ø≈øa, who but a while before Lorded it over Princes, plunged into the depth of mi≈øery.

The joy of this great victory that had ≈øo elevated the Poles, was ≈øoon damped upon the death of their King, who departing at a juncture, when the Enemy who by this time had recruited, was at hand with a powerful Army, and the Nation not well ≈øettled cau≈øed divers fears in the people, yet the Army not to be idle divided into divers parties, and in the depth of Winter, a time wherein they well knew the Turks would not travel, entered Moldavia, blocked up Keminitz, and brought away great booties, ≈øpoiling all in their way, till ≈øuch time as the Spring coming on, the Turks with multitudes came again≈øt them, and obliged them to retire, at whiat time the Tartars
committed divers outrages upon their Frontiers, carrying away much People and Cattle, burning and de≈øtroying all before them, the which though it incen≈øed the Tartar Han, yet feigning him≈øelf ≈øick upon ≈øome di≈øplea≈øure received, he refu≈øed to take the field in per≈øon, though the Grand Seignior had commanded it, yet that that might not ob≈øtruct the progre≈øs of the Ottoman Armes, the Great Vi≈øier ≈øent him his own Phy≈øitian, an Italian of great experience, who found him overwhelmed with deep Melancholly, but with Cordials and Medicaments ≈øoon rai≈øed him to his former vivacity.

Keminitz all this while blocked up, was by the approach of the Turki≈øh Army relieved, which the Vi≈øier perceiving, cau≈øed his Troops to March to Chuozim a ≈øtrong Fortre≈øs taken by the Chri≈øtians upon the defeat of Chu≈øaein Ba≈ø≈øa, which was retaken, and the Garri≈øon contrary to Articles put to the Sword, nor dur≈øt the Mu≈øcovites who were far advanced oppo≈øe his Forces, but retired before them, leaving A≈øac di≈ømantled and plundered, which the Turks rebuilt and fortified.

About this time Mahomet Ba≈ø≈øa being made at the in≈øtance of his Favourites Captain of a Squadron of Gallies, plundered and hara≈ø≈øed mo≈øt of the I≈ølands in the Archipelago, which rai≈øed ≈øuch hatred again≈øt him, and the loud complaints of the people being arrived at Con≈øtantinople before him, he at his return had his head ≈øtricken off, and all his ill gotten gains confi≈øcated; So that like an Indian Cormorant, which being made tame, and taught to fi≈øh for the benefit of his Ma≈øter, he was prevented from ≈øwallowing the prey.

Hungary being torn with civil di≈ø≈øentions, the Male-contents de≈øirous to throw off the German yoke ≈øent to the Port, de≈øiring to be taken into the Grand
Seigniors protection, and to become his Tributaries, which made the Turks ha≈øten to ≈øettle their affairs, that they might be the better at lea≈øure to take the advantage of tho≈øe inte≈øtine troubles, for the reducing the re≈øt of that ≈øpacious Kingdom to the Ottoman obedience, and the better to ≈øecure his new conque≈øts, he removed a part of the Co≈ø≈øacks with all their ≈øub≈øtance to the banks of the Black Sea, there a≈ø≈øigning them Lands, and as for the Armenians and Jews that dwelt in Reminitz, he tran≈øplanted them to Philopolis, Adrinople and Con≈øtantinople, giving the younge≈øt and lu≈øtie≈øt of either Sex as a prey to his Souldiers, who ≈øold them for ≈ølaves throughout the Turki≈øh Empire, and then returning with his Army to Adrinople, there to watch all advantages, he ≈øoon after disbandoned part of his A≈øian hor≈øe as chargable and trouble≈øom, but whil≈øt the≈øe projects in State were broaching, great differences aro≈øe between the Latin and Greek Church about the po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of the Holy Sepulchre at Jeru≈øalem, which had been ≈øo po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed by tho≈øe of the Roman Catholick Religion for many years, but now at the in≈øtance of Panajoti the Vi≈øiers Interpreter a zealous Greek, the latter were preferred, and after a long controver≈øie and much Money ≈øpent, the Greek obliged the Romani≈øts dwelling in tho≈øe parts to pay them tribute for ≈øuch places relating to Religion they there held, every Fryer paying a dram of Silver yearly to the Patriarch; So that now the Romani≈øts have po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion neither of the Chappel of Bethlehem, nor of the Sepulchre; The former of which had of a long time held, and the latter as earne≈øtly contended for.

The Grand Seignior not unmindful of the affairs of Hungary, gave order to the Ba≈ø≈øas on the Frontires, ≈øecretly to incourage the Divi≈øion till ≈øuch time as he ≈øhould be at lea≈øure to imploy his Armes on that
≈øide, hoping that an accommodation with Poland would in≈øue, but found not the Poles ≈øo forward therein as he expected, for the Wars ≈øtill continued though not with ≈øuch violence as before, which gave the Grand Seignior leave to Solemnize the Marriage of his Daughter with Rul-ogli, (which in the Turki≈øh Language ≈øignifies the Son of a ≈ølave) who was his great Favourite and Ba≈ø≈øa of Magne≈øia, as al≈øo to Circumci≈øe his Son, the former being 17 years of Age, and the latter 12, to ≈øolemnize which, the Fe≈øtivals were appointed on the 16th. of May, Anno 1675. when in the Morning the Grand Seignior with the young Prince his Son went to their Tents, which were pitched in a Plain before the City exceeding rich, round which all the great men of the Court had their Pavilions placed, among≈øt which was rai≈øed a ≈øtately Throne covered with a Canopy of Cloath of Gold, placed beneath the umbrage of two Elmes, which ≈øhining with many Lamps in the night made a glorious ≈øhew, and in this Seat of State the Sultan placed him≈øelf in the Morning, being accompanyed thither by all the Ba≈ø≈øa's then re≈øiding at Con≈øtantinople, and by the repre≈øentatives of tho≈øe that were ab≈øent, who according to their degrees ki≈ø≈øed his Robe, and in ≈øilken Pur≈øes deliver a note of what Pre≈øents they had brought, which were put into the hands of the Trea≈øurer to ≈øee them duly received, oppo≈øite to the Tents were ≈øeveral Poles fixed, on which by night many Lamps were hung, giving a glorious Light, by which were exerci≈øed ≈øeveral tricks of activity, as Wre≈øtling, Dauncing, Singing and Comedies, Fireworks there were in abundance, but not effectually made; The Night being pa≈ø≈øed, in the Morning the ≈øeveral Trades pa≈ø≈øed before the Tents one after another, every one making their Pre≈øents, and bearing Pageants, Mu≈øick all the while ≈øounding,
after whom came a Cavilcade of all the chief Officers, and among≈øt them the young Prince flaming with Diamonds, Rubies, and other precious Stones, and before them pa≈ø≈øed Twenty Four ≈ømall Nachils or Pageants, and two large, one higher than any Ship-Ma≈øt, ≈øupported by a Hundred Slaves, and were afterward ≈øet before the Seraglio. On the 27th. being Mahomet their Impo≈øtor Prophets birthday, the Grand Signior went publickly to the Mo≈øch of Sultan Selim, with no other Attendance than tho≈øe of his own Court, his Pages richly clad in Cloath of Gold, carryed each a Feather ≈øtudded with Jewels of great value; after the Grand Signior rode the young Prince, who that night was circumci≈øed: During this Fe≈øtival, a great number of people had their Provi≈øion at the expence of the Grand Signior, and about Two Thou≈øand being at that time circumci≈øed, every one of them had a Quilt given him with a Pen≈øion of three A≈øpers a day for Life.

The Solemnity of the Circumci≈øion ended, the Fe≈øtival for the Marriage of Rul-Ogli with the young Prince≈øs, which Ceremony in forme and manner according to the Turki≈øh fa≈øhion was thus, The Kuzlier Aga or Black Eunuch of the Women was Bridegroom or Compere to the Prince≈øs, and the Lord Trea≈øurer to Rul-Ogli, both which in the Name of the Bridegroom and Bride went before the Kedele≈øcher or Chief Judge, who wrote the Articles of Marriage, and pa≈ø≈øed them into an Act, which done, the Pre≈øents were ≈øent, and fir≈øt tho≈øe from the Bridegroom to the Bride, which were a great number of Bea≈øts and Birds made in Sugar, Thirty Mules laden with two Che≈øts of Sweet-Meats a piece, and about each of their necks a Sattin Ve≈øt for the Muliter; after them went ≈øeveral men, carrying Pots of Sherbet, or Water and Sugar boiled, which the Turks
for the mo≈øt part drink; next, a Hundred men carrying Ve≈øts of Silk, Sattin, Velvit, and Cloath of Gold, then five Hor≈øes laden with rich Furniture, followed by men, bearing Cloath of Gold Ve≈øts, with ≈øable Loops richer than the former, for the Loops and Buttons were imbroidered with rich Pearl, and on the top of each were a Rubie Diamond, or Saphier: The≈øe likewi≈øe carryed Shoos, Boots, and Pattens for the Bagneo, all covered with Pearl, as likewi≈øe two dre≈ø≈øing Boxes with Chry≈øtal Gla≈ø≈øes, and a Cap in form of a Crown, a little Cabinet imbroidered all over with Pearl, Eight Girdles ≈øet with Emraulds, Rubies, and Diamonds, a large Diamond Ring, a pair of Pendants of two great Emraulds, with many other things of value.

The≈øe Pre≈øents ≈øent by the Bride-groom, the Grand Signiour, as his Daughters Dowry, according to the cu≈øtom of the Ea≈øtern Countreys, u≈øhered with a Caval-Cade of all the Grandees ≈øent to the Bridegrooms-hou≈øe, two Gardens made of Sugar, Forty little Nachils, Eighty Six Mules laden with rich Furniture for a Hou≈øe, Ten Men with dre≈ø≈øings, as Boots, Shoes, &c. Imbroidered with Pearl and pretious Stones, after them were carryed the Jewels ≈øet on Girdles, Bracelets, and the like; then came Twelve Coaches laden with Slaves, and Thirty Six Black Eunuchs, the≈øe were ≈øucceeded by a Cavalcade, in which was the Bride riding in a Coach covered with Plates of Silver, and drawn by ≈øix Hor≈øes, the ≈øides adorned with Golden ≈øtreams; before which, went the chief Eunuch of the Women, after followed four Coaches with ≈øix Hor≈øes a piece, each carrying two Eunuchs; ≈øome di≈øtance from them, came the Brides Mother in a Coach covered with Plates of Silver, attended by Ten other Coaches; the night following, the Bride was conducted to the
Nuptial Chamber, in Ceremony only as not being yet ripe for con≈øummation of Marriage, though in England of late, the Virgins think them≈øelves wronged to ≈øtay to her Age unmarried.

The Ceremony thus performed, great was the rejoycing demon≈øtrated by Fire-works, Shews, and ≈øounding of Mu≈øical In≈øtruments; After which, the Grand Signiour on ≈øome private con≈øiderations, though to the wonder of the whole Court, removed the great Trea≈øurer to the Ba≈ø≈øa-≈øhip of Grand Cairo, and appointed the Efendi, or Judge-Advocate of the Janizaries to ≈øucceed him in the Office of Trea≈øurer; and now the publick Trea≈øury by the late Wars, and co≈øtly Ceremonies being almo≈øt emptied, divers ways were u≈øed to recrute it with Money, ≈øome was procured by the Sale of great places, from which tho≈øe that would not largely contribute, were thru≈øt, and ≈øome again extorted from the poorer ≈øort, whil≈øt to ≈øave charges the Sedentary Millitia was abridged in their pen≈øions, and ≈øome utterly ca≈øt off, ≈øo that in a while, a great ma≈øs of Money was heaped together, and Forces ≈øent to the Frontires of Poland.

About this time the Republique of Genoa's re≈øident at Con≈øtantinople, for want of that due Income that was expected to accrue by Trade, contracting large Debts, and having ≈øeveral debts contracted by his Predece≈ø≈øors decea≈øed, contracted likewi≈øe with the Turks of Con≈øtantinople, a great Man of War that brought him thither, upon the Republique refu≈øing to pay, was ≈øeized, and layed up in the Ar≈øenal, nor could a relea≈øe be procured, till Thirty Three Thou≈øand Dollars, part of the contracted Debt was payed and ≈øecured, which ≈øo di≈øcouraged the Genoways, that it has ever ≈øince damped their Trade in the Ottoman Dominions, and now the Grand Signeour
moved by chief Cu≈øtomer re≈øident at Smyrna, ca≈øting his Eye upon that Scale of Trade, brought him in great Revenues by way of Cu≈øtom; the better to beautifie it, and re≈øtore its antient Lu≈øtre, built a Ba≈øa≈øteen or Exchange, as likewi≈øe a Cu≈øtom-Hou≈øe Erected on Piles in the Sea, ≈øending his ab≈øolute Decree, that all Merchants Ships ≈øhould there unlade, and make due enteries, which greatly perplexed the Merchants, who before were wont to land their Goods on their own Keys, but in vain was their complaints, for the Grand Signiour would not admit of any rever≈øal, but by his Ralya declared that rather than he would be di≈øobeyed in his own Dominions, he would blow up the Port and Town, upon which an≈øwer the Merchants de≈øpairing of ≈øucce≈øs, were content to unlade their Ships at the Cu≈øtom-Hou≈øe, or there to make a true Entery of the Goods in their Boats; for the Cu≈øtomer being ≈øen≈øible that there was not water enough for the Ships to ride at the Key, was content to di≈øpen≈øe with divers matters that the Innovation might ≈øit more ea≈øie on the Merchants.

Things being at this pa≈øs, the Grand Signior after ≈øixteen years ab≈øence from Con≈øtantinople, which had rendered that City almo≈øt di≈øpeopled, returned thither to the great Joy of the Con≈øtantinopolitans, and frequently took his plea≈øure on the River in his Barge, or on the Bo≈øphorus in his Galley, ≈øtrictly commanding that no Chri≈øtian Mini≈øter ≈øhould be ≈øuffered to dwell upon the Banks of the latter, a prohibition never before made by any of his Predece≈ø≈øors, when ≈øoon after his arrival, the Captain Ba≈ø≈øa dyed, and Zayd Ahmet Ba≈ø≈øa Ogli ≈øucceeded him, and ≈øoon after Ibrahim, Ba≈ø≈øa General of the Forees on the Borders of Poland dyed, nor was the great Vi≈øier far from the Brink of the Grave, by rea≈øon of
his immoderate drinking of Wine and Strong-Waters, which made him incident to the Drop≈øie and Jaundice.

The new Ba≈ø≈øa of Cairo by this time having entered on his Office, u≈øed great diligence to ≈øettle the Revenues of that Kingdom, hoping thereby to plea≈øe the Grand Signior, of who≈øe favour ≈øince his removal from Trea≈øurer, he ≈øtood doubtful, but ≈øo ≈øevere he was in his Exaction, that the Egyptians not accu≈øtomed to be ≈øo u≈øed, complained of his rigour to the Begs or great Lords of Egypt, who though they receive the Turki≈øh Ba≈ø≈øas, pay Tribute, and own them their chief Governours, yet are They in them≈øelves Ab≈øolute Lords in their re≈øpective Provinces; for that Kingdom is rather an Ari≈øtocracy, than a Monarchy. The≈øe great Men much di≈øplea≈øed at the proceeding of the Ba≈ø≈øa, which tended to Tyranny and Oppre≈ø≈øion, took up Arms, and drew after them a great multitude, with which they a≈ø≈øaulted the Ba≈ø≈øa's palace, entered it, and dragging him thence, ca≈øt him into Pri≈øon, which news flying with all ha≈øte to the Ottoman Court, filled all with fear and confu≈øion, upon apprehen≈øion that Egypt was revolted; but a while after the truth of the matter being rightly under≈øtood, the Grand Signior with all ≈øpeed ≈øent a new Ba≈ø≈øa with gentle Letters to pacifie the Begs, and re≈øtore things to their former tranquility; promi≈øing that re≈øtitution ≈øhould be made for all injuries ≈øu≈øtained, which me≈ø≈øage of Grace and Favour made all former di≈øcontents vani≈øh, and re≈øtored a right under≈øtanding, in≈øomuch, that the impri≈øoned Ba≈ø≈øa was ≈øet at Liberty, and ≈øhipped to Candia, where the Grand Signiour had appointed him Governour; the people without any further di≈øturbance returning to their obedience.

About this time happened the unfortunate fall of Che≈øine Aga, a man of great repute among≈øt the Turks, which was after this manner, a woman called Sultana Sporche, with which Sultan Ibrahim had had to do with her in her youth; being now turned Baud, bought many beautiful Female Slaves, which ≈øhe brought up to Singing, Dancing, and many other Exerci≈øes, and then for money, yielded them up to the Lu≈øt of the Great Men of the Court; one among≈øt which for her Wit and Beauty being greatly famed, the Grand Signior ≈øent for her, but the Sultana fearing to loo≈øe her, by whom ≈øhe got dayly gain, and doubting the Grand Signiour would put her into his Seraglio, admoni≈øhed her to a ≈øullen coyne≈øs, as likewi≈øe to declare that ≈øhe was a free-woman, which by the Turki≈øh Law ought not to be defiled, nor carnally know any man, unle≈øs ≈øhe be married; which part ≈øhe played ≈øo well, that the Grand Signior ≈øent her back with di≈ødain and reproach to her Mi≈øtre≈øs, who was not a little glad of her e≈øcape; but ≈øo it happened, that the afore≈øaid Aga ≈øoon after ca≈øting his Eyes on her, and delighted with her quaint Di≈øcour≈øe, fell inamour'd with her, and treated of Marriage, which the Wench highly approved, but her Mi≈øtre≈øs would in no wi≈øe con≈øent to it, declaring that ≈øhe was her Bond-woman, and not at her own di≈øpo≈øal, which for a time put a ≈øtop to the proceedings; but ≈øoon after the Lover contrived away to bring their de≈øigns to pa≈øs, for the Aga having taken her private Lodgings, ≈øhe under the ≈øhelter of the night made her e≈øcape, but upon her being mi≈ø≈øed, her Beldame charged him with conveying away, and concealing her ≈ølave, which he for a while denyed; but ≈øhe ≈øetting many ≈øpies over him, at length found them together, and charging an Officer with them, cau≈øed them to be carryed
before the Great Vi≈øier, who ≈øent to the Grand Signior to know his plea≈øure therein, of which the Aga having ≈øome mi≈øtru≈øt, told the Vi≈øier that he expected no other ≈øentence then that of Death from the Grand Signior, only he de≈øired that his beloved Mi≈øtre≈øs might be ≈øpared, for he was ≈øure he ≈øhould live in her; nor were his fears in vain, for ≈øoon after came a fatal Decree for his Execution, and ≈øent the Woman to the Seraglio This cruelty of the Sultans as mo≈øt conjectur'd, proceeded from the di≈ødain, he conceived that the Wench ≈øhould refu≈øe his proffered kindne≈øs, and imbrace the love of his Slave, for ≈øuch the Sultans account the greate≈øt men in the Empire.

The Grand Signior having ≈øpent mo≈øt part of the Winter at Con≈øtantinople, early in the Spring returned to Adrinople, though the better to comfort the Con≈øtantinopolitans, who by rea≈øon of the ≈øen≈øible decay of Trade that mu≈øt thereon in≈øue, mourned his ab≈øence; he pre≈øumed about Autumn to return again, and for his reception cau≈øed a new Seraglio to be founded, and ≈øo ≈øetting forward, accompanied with a great train of Nobility, and among≈øt the re≈øt, the great Vi≈øier, he marched towards Con≈øtantinople, but by the way the Vi≈øier dyed, having de≈øtroyed him≈øelf by intemperate drinking Wine and Hot Spirits, his Body accompanied with a ≈ølender Train, was brought back to Con≈øtantinople, and there buryed in the Sepulchre of Old Ruperlee his Father.

The Great Vi≈øier dead, the Seal was given to Kara Mu≈øtapha, Ba≈ø≈øa, who for many years had exerci≈øed the Office of Chimacam, or Deputy to the Great Vi≈øier, being a Man of courteous behaviour, wi≈øe and affable, not given to Covetou≈øne≈øs nor Cruelty, but as ≈øoon as he was promoted, he ≈øent to
the decea≈øed Vi≈øiers Servants to condole the Death of their Ma≈øter, promi≈øing them to take them into his care and protection; mo≈øt of which he afterwards promoted to Honourable places, to ≈øuch advantage, that by their dependency on him, they ≈øecured both him and them≈øelves from the malice of ≈øuch as envyed the advancement: Long he had not been ≈øetled in his place, e're he cut off the Chief Pay-Ma≈øters head for bringing fal≈øe Money into the Exchequer, and had given another the ≈øame mea≈øure, had not his Life been redeemed at Forty Pur≈øes of Money, or Twenty Thou≈øand Dollars, though thereby his place was not regained, nor was diligence le≈øs in looking after the corruption of Mini≈øters of State, di≈øplacing and depo≈øing all ≈øuch as he ≈øound remi≈øs in their duty, or that for lucre or gains≈øake oppre≈ø≈øed any of the Grand Signiours Subjects, or ≈øuch ≈øtrangers as traded in any part of his Dominions.

But by the Example of this man it may be ≈øeen how Power and Greatne≈øs can alter the di≈øpo≈øition of Men, and make them ≈øwell with Pride almo≈øt to bur≈øting, for finding the Reins on his neck, without re≈øtraint, he took upon him the Power and Office of the Sultan, it being more difficult to gain acce≈øs to him, than to the Sultan him≈øelf, and in imitation of their Ma≈øter, the ≈øub-Officers grew proud and in≈øolent; in≈øomuch, that the face of things, contrary to mo≈øt mens expectations were changed; and this haughty behaviour was ≈øhewed e≈øpecially towards forraign Mini≈øters, who≈øe Interpreters were not admitted as formerly to private Audiences or Conferences about their Affairs, but only at the publick Divan where their Arzes or Memorials were to be preferred, which was always allowed to the Subjects of the Grand Signiour, and
tho≈øe of Tributary Nations, when they Petition for Ju≈øtice; which Judgment was not only ca≈øt upon interpreters, but on the per≈øons of the repre≈øentatives them≈øelves; an in≈øtance of which was ≈øeen in the French Emba≈ø≈øador, who at the time appointed coming to receive his Audience, was rudely crouded and jo≈øtled by a company of unmannerly Chiau≈øes, who regarded the repre≈øentative of ≈øo great a King at no other rate than they did one of the Grooms, or Laquies of the Sultan. Being come to the Seat of Audience, he perceived the Stool ≈øet for him, was ≈øet beneath the Soffra, and that of the Vi≈øiers upon it; whereupon he commanded one of his Servants to place it equal with that of the Great Vi≈øiers, which he had no ≈øooner done, but it was brought down again by one of the Vi≈øiers Pages, whereupon the Emba≈ø≈øador ≈øeizing the Stool, carryed it up and ≈øat upon it. The report whereof coming to the Vi≈øier, who was in his retiring Chamber, he ≈øent word that he would not come into the Chamber of Audience till the Stool was ≈øet in the place appointed, whereunto the Emba≈ø≈øador replyed that he might di≈øpo≈øe of his Chair as he plea≈øed, but not of his Per≈øon, when in the interim Chiaus Ba≈øhe came in bauling Calder, Calder, which is take it away, take it away; at which unexpected noi≈øe the Emba≈ø≈øador ≈øtanding up to ≈øee what the matter was, had the ≈øtool taken from under him; whereupon he in a great rage flung out of the Audience Chamber, cau≈øing the Pre≈øents which he brought to be again returned with him, and ≈øo mounting his Hor≈øe, departed to his Lodging.

Soon after it was by ≈øome of the Officers intimated to Sir John Finch, His Maje≈øty of Great Britains Emba≈ø≈øador, that he might if he plea≈øed, receive Audience of the Vi≈øier; but upon notice what had
happened to the French Emba≈ø≈øador, he excu≈øed his going, on pretence of an indi≈øpo≈øition of body: But however Venetian, Dutch and Genoan Re≈øidents were content (the better to curry favour with the Vi≈øier) to be admitted to Audience on tho≈øe terms which the Vi≈øier would vouch≈øafe to allow them; for though during the time, he was Chimacam, as is afore≈øaid; he was meek and humble, yet being placed in the highe≈øt dignity next the Sultan, the unexpected Exaltation made him ≈øo far forget him≈øelf, that his pride knew no bounds.

The≈øe things happening, and no hopes of accomodation with Poles, who by this time had Elected Sobieski for their King, great preparations were made for the carrying on that War. The Tartar, Han, in order thereto receiving expre≈øs command to take the Field, which early in the Spring he did, and entering Lithuania, committed many outrages, but being incountered by Sixteen Thou≈øand Poles, and Co≈ø≈øacks his Army was put to the rout, and in great confu≈øion obliged to repa≈øs the Nei≈øter, leaving behind him all the booty, which con≈øi≈øted mo≈øtly of People and Cattle, during which, the Ba≈ø≈øa of Kemenitz, with a great Body of Hor≈øe made an Inroad even to the Walls of Leopolis, which cau≈øed the King to ≈øend his Queen and Children to Cracow, re≈øolving to give the Turks Battle, and in order to ≈øtrengthning his Forces, ≈øummoned all the Poli≈øh Nobility to repair to his Standard, putting him≈øelf and ≈øuch Troops as he had between the City and the Enemy, the better to alienate the fears of the people, who upon the approach of the Turks, who burnt up all before them, had fled, and left the City de≈øolate, had not the Gates been clo≈øed upon them.

The Turks perceiving the great preparations that were making again≈øt them, thought fit with ≈øuch
booty as they had gotten to retire into ∆≤ckrania, but in their retreat were charged by the King with ≈øuch bravery, that Seven Thou≈øand of them were killed, and a great number of Captives re≈øcued to their un≈øpeakable joy.

They finding the Turks were re≈øolutely bent to carry on the War, and that the Kingdom was greatly weakned by the Provinces they had already rent from it, the better to ≈øtrengthen him≈øelf by Alliance, by the Advice of the Senate, ≈øent his Emba≈ø≈øador to the Court of the Czar of Mo≈øcovy, to ≈øolicite Aid again≈øt the common Enemy, who upon his arrival was received with great expre≈ø≈øion of Joy, and due Ceremony being dayly heightened with fair promi≈øes to expect great matters, but in the end, nothing worth mention came on it, yet it ≈øo wrought upon the Turks, that for the better pre≈øervation of what they had already required the Vi≈øier began to be intent on peace, but his propo≈øitions were ≈øo unrea≈øonable, that the Poles generou≈øly refu≈øed them, and early in the Spring prepared to take the Field with a pui≈ø≈øant Army, yet could not ≈øo ≈øoon draw them together, but that the Tartars living on the Frontires, joyning with ≈øome, revolted Co≈ø≈øacks, committed divers out-rages, burning about Two Hundred Villages, carrying away a great number of Chri≈øtians into mi≈øerable captivity, whil≈øt Podolia groaned under the oppre≈ø≈øion of the Turks, who now turned their clemency into rigour, killing and carrying away great numbers of the≈øe di≈øtre≈ø≈øed people, burning their Hou≈øes, and robbing them of the ≈ømall matter they had left in ≈øuch a manner that that fruitful Countrey was layd almo≈øt de≈øolate; to oppo≈øe which Torrent, the King drew out his Forces and by fair promi≈øes and large gifts procured Thre ‚Ä¢ Thou≈øand Co≈ø≈øacks to joyn him when pa≈ø≈øing th ‚Ä¢
Nei≈øter, and falling upon the Straglers as they at plea≈øure were ravaging the Countrey, expecting no ≈øuch matter, and killed Five Thou≈øand, among≈øt whom fell One Ba≈ø≈øa and Two Sanziacks; but upon notice the Tartars in great number was entered the heart of Poland, leaving ≈øome of his Troops under the Command of Witnowitzki, his Lieutenant General, he po≈øted to oppo≈øe them, but upon notice they were Forty Thou≈øand lead by Expert Turki≈øh Commanders; he drew near to Leopolis to encourage that City, which otherwi≈øe terrified at the approach of ≈øo great an Army might have been de≈øerted, when finding the Tartars made divers halts, having put a Garri≈øon into the City, and given ≈øuch nece≈ø≈øary orders as he thought convenient, he marched towards them, and having notice by his Scouts that they approached, he commanded his Army to extend large in Front, and the Wings of Hor≈øe to lie off, that they might ≈øeem more in number than they were; he re≈øolutely de≈øcended from a ≈ømall Hill into the Plain, and after having thrice proclaimed the Name of Je≈øus at the Head of his Troop, fell like an unexpected Tempe≈øt upon the Infidels, in≈øomuch that the Front of their Army was overthrown, before the Rear could come up to their a≈ø≈øi≈øtance; which putting them into a great confu≈øion, when perceiving the re≈øerves advance to charge them in the flank, and ≈øuppo≈øing the whole power of the Kingdom at hand, by rea≈øon of great ≈øhout from the Hills made by the Ru≈øtick, ≈øet there for that purpo≈øe; they fir≈øt gave back, and in the end betook them≈øelves to plain flight, ca≈øting away many of their Arms and Baggage to make the ≈øwifter retreat, upon whom the Polonian Hor≈øemen followed hard, making great ≈ølaughter of them for the ≈øpace of Twelve Miles; but night coming on, to prevent the pur≈øuers from falling into any ambu≈øh
that might for that purpo≈øe be layed, the King cau≈øed the retreat to be ≈øounded, and returning to the City Victorious, he was received with all expre≈ø≈øions of joy, and the next day commanded a publick Thank≈øgiving for the Victory ≈øo miraculou≈øly obtained.

In this Battle Ninety Thou≈øand Tartars, Turks, Moldavians and Valachians were ≈ølain, Seven Hundred taken Pri≈øoners, and a great booty recovered; of the Poles fell only Seven Hundred, their whole Force not exceeding Six Thou≈øand. The rea≈øons were gathered from ≈øome of the Pri≈øoners why the Tartars, &c. were ≈øo ≈øuddenly di≈øcouraged, were two, fir≈øt for that about ten in the Morning of the ≈øame day making a Halt, abundance of Snow and Hail fell upon their Army, and round about them none was ≈øeen to fall, which they took as a bad Omen. Secondly, that when they perceived the large Front of the Poli≈øh Army which extended near a Mile; they verily believed it to be the fore-runner of the Forces of the whole Kingdom, which they had heard were in Arms, and therefore having ≈øo far advanced into the Countrey, and left many Enemies at their backs, they feared to be inclo≈øed, which occa≈øioned their ha≈øty and di≈øorderly retreat.

The≈øe reiterated Lo≈ø≈øes, and the de≈øire the Grand Signior had to po≈ø≈øe≈øs him≈øelf of the re≈øt of Hungary, who≈øe divi≈øions gave him a pro≈øpect of reducing it to his Obedience, made him more willingly hearken to the propo≈øals of the Poli≈øh Emba≈ø≈øador, ≈øo that in the end, upon much the ≈øame Articles as tho≈øe that had before been broke, the Tribute accepted, a peace was concluded, in which the Mo≈øcovite would fain have been included, but he failing to help his Neighbour Prince in his greate≈øt
Extremity, was thought unworthy both by the Poles and Turks; in≈øomuch, that ≈øoon after divi≈øions ari≈øing among≈øt the Bowyers, and great Men of that Dukedom; the Tartars taking the opportunity thereof, over-run a great part of the Countrey, carrying away all that came to hand; but another party ≈øoon after attempting the like, were fought with, and mo≈øt of them cut off, or drowned in repa≈ø≈øing the Bory≈øthenes.

About this time the differences between the Vi≈øier and the French Emba≈ø≈øador greatly encrea≈øed, notwith≈øtanding the mediation of divers Chri≈øtian Mini≈øters then re≈øiding at the Port. The one In≈øi≈øting to take his place during his Audience on the Saffora, and the other as ob≈øtinately refu≈øing to permit di≈øcontented that the Honour of his Ma≈øter ≈øhould be ≈øo much impaired, yet in hopes of a better treatment, he once more re≈øolved to attend his Audience, being introduced, the Chair was brought and ≈øet at the Foot of the Saffora, the which while he was with his own hands about to remove, the Vi≈øiers Servants hindred him, wherefore in a rage he took up the Cu≈øhion and flung it over his head, which happened to fall upon the Great Vi≈øier, who grievou≈øly re≈øenting the Affront, cau≈øed him head and Shoulders to be thru≈øt out of the Audience-Chamber, whereupon the rude Officers (without re≈øpect to his Character, or the Law of Nations, which renders the Per≈øon of an Emba≈ø≈øador Sacred and Inviolable) ≈øo roughly handled him, that he kept his Chamber for ≈øeveral days.

The≈øe are the mo≈øt remarkable occurrences that have happened ≈øince the beginning of this Emperors Reign over the Ea≈øtern Empire, till 1680, the relation of which I have partly received from Authors
of undoubted Credit and Reputation, and partly a≈ø≈øerted of my own knowledg, many of the Tran≈øactions of this Emperors Reign happening during my abode in tho≈øe Countries; But to proceed.

Anno 1680. the Grand Seignior arriving at Adrinople about the middle of December, and being recovered of an Ague that had ≈øometime afflicted him, he commanded his Vi≈øier Ba≈ø≈øa to draw his Forces together from all parts of his Empire, cau≈øing the hor≈øes tail to be hung out, which is a certain ≈øign that the Grand Seignior or Grand Vi≈øier intends to take the Field, and in order to defray the charges, great ≈øums of Money were every where exacted, the Grand Vi≈øier labouring more earne≈øtly therein that he might again recover the Grand Seigniors favour, from which he was fallen, with the≈øe Forces he intended to invade Mu≈øcovy early in the Spring, and to pro≈øecute that War till he had compelled the Czar to ≈øubmit to ≈øuch terms of peace as he him≈øelf ≈øhould propo≈øe, and at the ≈øame time di≈øpatched Achians to the Emperor of Germany, to treat on the behalf of the Hungarian Male-contents, whom he declared he mu≈øt take into his protection, if their propo≈øals for liberty of Con≈øcience was by the Imperial Diet then ≈øitting at Ratisbon rejected, and ≈øoon after him followed the Bi≈øhop of Sebe≈øtini, the Count D' Petrozi, and two or three others of le≈øs note Deputed by the Hungarians, to treat about the ≈øame matter, but their demands ≈øeeming unrea≈øonable, they were di≈ømi≈ø≈øed without the ≈øatisfaction they expected.

About this time Muley Hamet Nephew to Muley I≈ømale King of Morocco and Fe≈ø≈ø, a≈ø≈øi≈øted by a number of Renegado Turks and Moors, mu≈øtered his Army near Suz, and advanced to give his Uncle battle, but near Morocco many of his followers de≈øerting him, and his hor≈øemen in which his chief ≈øtrength con≈øi≈øted,
being overthrown near to Alarach he fled to Tunis, and was there received into protection by the Governour, from whence he ≈øent divers of his Favourites and followers to Con≈øtantinople to pray the Grand Seigniors aid again≈øt his Uncle, who as he alledged unju≈øtly detained tho≈øe Kingdoms, but he being a Prince of no Fortune, and le≈øs power, he nothing prevailed therein, yet his Rebellion proved advantagious to the Garri≈øon of Tangier, the Moors being thereby diverted, whil≈øt the Engli≈øh rebuilt many of their Forts ruined a few months before, and were di≈øincumbered of tho≈øe trouble≈øome neighbours, who had ≈øo long beleagured them, nay more in the end, it occa≈øioned a firm and la≈øting peace.

The French Merchants Trading in the Levant, having ≈øu≈øtained great dammage by the Pirates of Tripoly, and among≈øt other Ve≈ø≈øels the Sa ‚Ä¢ ta Sophia, laden at Alicant with Sa ‚Ä¢ t and Spani≈øh Wool o ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ er way to Venice, a great brigantine bound for Me≈ø≈øina, and a Petach of Ragus, &c. to revenge that injury, and reduce tho≈øe Turki≈øh Pirates to obedience, ≈øeveral Ships and Gallies were fitted out at Mar≈øelles, under the command of the Barron of Que≈øne, who coming before the Port of Trip ‚Ä¢ ly ≈øent his Boat on ≈øhoar, and in it ≈øeveral Officers, in the Name of the mo≈øt Chri≈øtian King, to demand Re≈øtitution for the dammages ≈øu≈øtained by the French Merchants, but receiving no other an≈øwer then that of the Cannon from the Ca≈øtles that guard the Port, he cau≈øed the boat to be haled back, and with many broad ≈øides fired upon the Town, but by rea≈øon of the di≈øtance did no con≈øiderable dammage, but whil≈øt he was cruzing, he had notice that ≈øeven Tripolean Men of War rid at Anchor in the Port of Scio, or Chios, an I≈øland belonging to the Grand Signior, whereupon he ≈øtood away from the Coa≈øt of Barbary, and ≈øailed thither
upon who≈øe approach the Turks ≈ølipped their Anchors, and ≈ønugged clo≈øe under the Ca≈øtle, where notwith≈øtanding they were mi≈øerably torn by the ≈øhot from the French Gallies, which their Admiral perceiving put out a Flag of Truce, and offered to deliver without ran≈øom all the French ≈ølaves that were on board, with two prizes he had lately taken, but the Barron would not hearken to the≈øe offers, well knowing they could not e≈øcape him, yet not thinking it ≈øafe to venture too near the ≈øhoar, he blocked them up; and ≈øent to Tripoly to let the Governour under≈øtand what danger their Ships were in, and that nothing could deliver them out of his hands, but ≈øatisfaction for the wrongs ≈øu≈øtained, and a delivery of all the French Captives ran≈øom free, and immediately to conclude a peace, but receiving no ≈øatisfactory an≈øwer, he re≈øolutely entered the Port with his Gallies, and after having beaten down a great part of the Ca≈øtle, and demoli≈øhed many ≈øtately Edifices, he ≈øunk two of the Ships, took one, and fired the re≈øt, in which Action he lo≈øt but Thirty of his Men, but of the Turks there peri≈øhed Eight Hundred.

This News made known to the Grand Vi≈øier, he in≈øtantly ≈øent for the French Amba≈ø≈øador re≈øiding at Con≈øtantinople, and after having rated him, and ≈øeverely threatned him with death, unle≈øs reparation was ≈øpeedily made for the dammage ≈øu≈øtained in the Grand Seigniors Port, he cau≈øed him to be confined, impri≈øoning likewi≈øe many of his ≈øervants, nor could he obtain his Relea≈øe till he had purcha≈øed his peace at the price of Three Hundred Pur≈øes of Money, each Pur≈øe being accounted Five Hundred Dollars, yet the lo≈øs of the≈øe Ships wrought ≈øuch effects, that the Tripoles ≈øoon after concluded a peace with the French.

Matters being at this pa≈øs, and the troubles increa≈øing in Hungary, Count Teckely ≈øtill oppo≈øing him≈øelf again≈øt the Emperors Intere≈øt, and u≈øeing his utmo≈øt endeavours at the Port to have him≈øelf proclaimed Prince of Tran≈øylvania, the Emperor thought good to ≈øend an Amba≈ø≈øador to the Grand Seignior to put him in mind of the league between the two Empires, de≈øiring that it might be kept inviolable, not any ways infringed by his giving countenance to his Rebels in Hungary, which Amba≈ø≈øador upon his arrival had his Audience of the Grand Vi≈øier, and a promi≈øe made him, that a ≈øtrict command ≈øhould be ≈øent to all his Beglerbegs and Sanzacks on the frontiers, not upon pain of lo≈øing their heads to aid or countenance the Male-contents, and being afterwards with the Grand Vi≈øier, he a≈ø≈øured him that the Grand Seigniors re≈øolution ≈øhould be maintained, that thereby the peace and friend≈øhip E≈øtabli≈øhed between the two Empires might continue, yet the≈øe ≈øpecious pretences were to no other end intended then to protract time, to make their own terms with the Rebels, for ≈øoon after without the lea≈øt provocation the Tables were turned, and not only a≈ø≈øi≈øted them with all manner of Warlike provi≈øion, but with Men and Money, in con≈øideration of ≈øeveral Towns to be put into their hands when taken; They likewi≈øe made great preparations at Belgrade and Buda under pretence of depo≈øing Abafti Prince of Tran≈øylvania, and cau≈øing divers Janizaries to be attired like Hungarians, and to ≈øerve Count Teckely as his guard.

The Turki≈øh Pyrates of Argiers having broke the peace ≈øometime ≈øince made with his Maje≈øty of Great Brittain, and taken ≈øeveral Engli≈øh Ve≈ø≈øels (and among≈øt others, the≈øe by name, viz. the Anne of London, the John of Exeter, the Thamar of
Colche≈øter, the Po≈øt-hor≈øe of London, the Ro≈øemary of Yarmouth, the William of London, the amity of Plymouth, the Fortune of London, the ∆≤nity of Barn≈øtable, and the Mary Land Merchant, which la≈øt fought two Algerine Men of War almo≈øt one whole day; but at la≈øt taking fire, ≈øhe, together with mo≈øt of her men peri≈øhed) To curb their in≈øolency, the Vice-Admiral Herbert with the Squadron of his Maje≈øties Frigates under his command was appointed to cruze in tho≈øe ≈øtraights, who with ≈øuch ≈øucce≈øs happened on tho≈øe roving thieves, that within the ≈øpace of two years he took and de≈øtroyed forty of their Ships, recovering a great number of Chri≈øtian Captives, and brought tho≈øe Pyrates ≈øo low, that not only they, but tho≈øe of Tripole and Sally were obliged to truckle, and receive ≈øuch terms of peace as the Victor would allow; Among≈øt the many ingagements that happened, during the ≈øpace afore≈øaid, this is remarkable, on the 8th. of April 1681. what time the Algerine had One Hundred and Twenty of her men wounded, and near as many killed, all her Ma≈øts ≈øhot by the Board, and five or ≈øix foot deep of water in the Hold, Captain Booth having likewi≈øe all his rigging cut in pieces, and every thing out of order, and apprehen≈øive of ingaging in that condition with the ≈øaid fre≈øh Ship, which he ≈øuppo≈øed to be an Enemy, commanded the Calaba≈øh Fire≈øhip (then attending him lea≈øt the prize ≈øhould e≈øcape) to burn which of them ≈øhe could mo≈øt conveniently grapple, which had been put in Execution, had not the Fire≈øhips Boat been in the night time accidentally ≈øtaved, next Morning by break of day Captain Wheeler came up, and being within half culvering ≈øhot, put out the Engli≈øh Colours, and bearing directly upon the Algerine, ≈øiezed her without firing a Gun; By this action thirty ≈øeven Engli≈øh Captives were redeemed, and of Dutch and Spaniards One Hundred and Thirteen.

The Mu≈øcovite by this time beginning to dread the Tempe≈øt of War that was ready to fall upon him, and not able of him≈øelf to re≈øi≈øt ≈øuch a power as the Grand Seignior had rai≈øed by rea≈øon of inte≈øtine troubles, and de≈øpairing to be aided by the Polonians, whom he had ≈øome years before de≈øerted in their greate≈øt nece≈ø≈øity, he thought it the ≈øafe≈øt to conclude a peace, which by Pre≈øents, and many intreaties he procured to be ratified for the ≈øpace of twenty years; It being the rather con≈øented to by the Grand Seignior, that he might be at lei≈øure to turn his Armes upon Hungary, in which ≈øo many of his Predece≈ø≈øors have been foiled.
