at Belgrade, which they took and converted to their own u≈øe, killing and putting to flight ≈øuch as had the charge of them, upon notice of which the Polonian King, to appear more formidable to the Turks, Tartars and Hungarian Rebels, commanded 2 new Regiments to be rai≈øed, one at the charge of his Queen, and the other at the charge of Prince Alexander his Elde≈øt Son, him≈øelf allotting out of his Patrimonial E≈øtate 100000 Crowns to be di≈øtributed among≈øt his Army, and to rai≈øe 800 Hu≈ø≈øars expert at handling Launces.

On the 11th. of May the Imperial Army after having Randizvouzed at Pre≈øburg, pa≈ø≈øing from Kei≈øer marched towards, and incamped between that Fortre≈øs and Comorra to ob≈øerve the motions of the Turks, who were imbodyed near Newhau≈øel to the number of 15000, daily expecting a detachment of the Vi≈øiers Army upon its march to joyn with them, the Vi≈øier at the ≈øame time being incamped at Greick Weiffenburg, expecting the arrival of the Grand Seignior, who was ≈øome days marching behind.

During the≈øe proceedings Teckely ≈øuddenly collecting his Troops, layed ≈øiege to the ≈øtrong Ca≈øtle of Donowitz, in which was the Barron Joannel with a Garri≈øon of 250 Imperiali≈øts and Hungarians, yet after a furious battery with 8 pieces of Cannon, he made him≈øelf ma≈øter of that important place, making the Governour and the Germans found therein Pri≈øoners of War, when to prevent his further proceedings on that ≈øide, the Pallatine of Hungaria received orders to joyn Major General Schutz, who had pa≈ø≈øed the Waag to meet the Prince of Lubomerski, who advanced with the 6000 Polonian Hor≈øe before mentioned, whereupon the Vi≈øier of Buda ≈øummoned Count Teekely to joyn the Turki≈øh Troops under his command, which he refu≈øed to do, making ≈øeveral pretences
to excu≈øe it of which the King of Poland taking notice ≈øent a Letter to the Count to advi≈øe him to quit the engagement he has with the Turks, (which in conclu≈øion will turn to his ruin) and make his peace with the Emperour, whil≈øt his free grace is offered him; the which had ≈øuch an effectual operation that many were of opinion he would have clo≈øed with the Imperial offered Grace, but after ≈øome debate and new incouragement from the Grand Signior, he re≈øolved to per≈øi≈øt in his rebellious purpo≈øe of oppo≈øing the Emperours intere≈øt, whereupon the Duke of Lorrain who has ab≈øolute power to act as he ≈øees convenient for the advantage of the Empire, ≈øent orders to the Palatine to draw down his Troops and intrench him≈øelf on the banks of the Waag, to ≈øecure the pa≈ø≈øes where the River is Fordable, as likewi≈øe to the Vice-Roy of Crotia to rai≈øe new Forces for the increa≈øe of tho≈øe already under his command, and to keep diligent watch upon the Frontires of that Province to prevent any incur≈øions.

About this time Zathmer was regained, and young Count Serini (true Heir to the valour of his immortal Ance≈øtors) appointed Governour thereof which has put the Turks out of all hopes of recovering it.

The Duke of Lorrain having notice that the Turks were imbodying them≈øelves near Gran, rai≈øed his Camp on the 24th. of May and marched towards them, re≈øolving to give them Battle before the Grand Vi≈øier (who together with the Aga of the Janizaries, was on his march) could arrive in tho≈øe parts, having for that purpo≈øe ≈øtored his Army with all nece≈ø≈øary Provi≈øion and Ammunition ≈øent up the Danubius in boats from Vienna, but during the≈øe preparations the Turks had ≈øo ≈øtrongly lodged them≈øelves upon the Counter≈øcarp to the number of 25000, that he thought it not convenient to attack them in their
≈øtrength, but having made a detachment of 13 men commanding them to pa≈øs the Danubius, and inve≈øt Newhau≈øel a ≈øtrong place about a Leagues from Komora, whil≈øt the re≈øt of the Army followed in good order, with a train of 80 pieces of Artillery, mo≈øt of which carry bullets of between 30 and 40 pounds weight, which made Count Teckeley draw off towards Tokay, ≈øtill declining to joyn the Turks under the command of the Vi≈øier of Buda, in≈øomuch that the Ba≈ø≈øa of Offen fearing to be expo≈øed to the Fury of the Imperiali≈øts ≈øent a Me≈ø≈øenger to the Duke of Lorrain to propo≈øe a Ce≈ø≈øation of Arms for 14 days, which the Duke would in no wi≈øe hearken to, as well knowing it was but to protract the time till a greater power arrived in Hungary, and when it was urged that the Grand Signeour intended to ob≈øerve the Peace with the Emperor, till the prefixed was expired, but the Duke replyed that the Turks by their unju≈øt Ho≈øtilities and manife≈øt outrages had broken it long ≈øince, ≈øo that now they mu≈øt expect no other favour then the Sword would allow them, whereupon he di≈øpatched orders to Count Caprara to batter Newhau≈øel re≈øolving to carry it by ≈øtorm, if it ≈øhould fail to be delivered by capitulation having already overthrown a party belonging to that Garri≈øon, who were returning from ravaging the Country laden with great booties, upon which ≈øucce≈øs 2 parties were ≈øent out to burn the Bridges of Gran, and E≈ø≈øeiniek which they ≈øucce≈øsfully attempted burning the former, and po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øing them≈øelves of the latter, guarded by 700 Turks, mo≈øt of which were killed or taken pri≈øoners.

The Count Caprara His Imperial Maje≈øties Amba≈ø≈øador at the Port, is by order of the Grand Signeour looked narrowly after, not differing much from a confinement, lea≈øt during the≈øe Ho≈øtilities he ≈øhould
withdraw him≈øelf, nor could the interce≈ø≈øion of the Lord Shandois His Maje≈øty of Great Brittains Amba≈ø≈øador re≈øiding at the Port on his behalf remove the ≈øu≈øpition conceived, &c. Thus far having related impartially the ≈øucce≈øs of the Chri≈øtian Armes again≈øt the Turks, I ≈øhall leave them ingaged in a bloody and doubtful War, and conclude ≈øo much of this years Campaigne as to the 4th of June, 1683. has occurred with an exact account of all the Imperial Forces. The Li≈øt whereof take as followeth, viz. The Emperor has in pay 27 Regiments of Foot, making together 55700 men, whereof 25296 follow the Duke of Lorrain, 4692 are appointed to ≈øecure the upper Hungary, 2040 po≈øted at Jabluncka on the frontiers of Hungary, 2040 at Leopol≈øtadt on the Waag, 3640 in Au≈øtria, 2040 at Vienna, 13912 in the Empire, 2400 in Bohemia, 17 Regiments of Hor≈øe making together 13600 men, 7 Regiments of Dragoons containing 5600 men, & 4 Regiments of Croats making 3200, whereof 15200 are at the Camp, 800 in the Upper Hungary, 400 at Jabluncka, 2400 at Leopol≈øtadt, 800 in Au≈øtria, and 2800 in the Empire. So that the general Li≈øt of Hor≈øe and Foot ≈øtands thus, viz. at the Camp 39696, in the Empire, 16712 in the upper Hungary, 7532 making in all 78540 men not accounting the Hungarian Troops under the command of the Palatine, nor tho≈øe in Crotia commanded by the Vice-Roy, nor the 6000 Polonian Hor≈øe brought into the Emperours ≈øervice, by the Prince of Lubornirski, which in conjunction will render the Emperors total Forces no le≈øs then 100000 fighting men. The Turks Army together with the Tartars and Hungarians under the command of Count Teckley, being accounted no le≈øs then 250000.

q.l: But thou, O Lord, on whom all things depend,
In gentle Peace let the≈øe dire di≈øcords end.
Or let firm Concord with the Chri≈øtians dwell,
To turn their Swords on the proud Inf ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ .

div.head: CHAP. XXV. A De≈øcription of the Power, Policy, Forces, Revenues, Religion, and Greatne≈øs of the Ottoman Empire; and by what Means it ≈øub≈øi≈øts and maintains its Grandeur, &c.
div.p: HAving in the ≈øuccinct Series of this Hi≈øtory related the Original of the Ottoman Empire, and its Growth from time to time, till it arrived to the va≈øt Extent it at this Day is found; I ≈øhall now proceed to give the Reader a View of the Grandeur of it, and by what means it is ≈øupported, in the De≈øcription of the Grand Seignior's Port or Palace, Government, Officers, Riches, Forces, Religion, and the like.

The Turks originally a People of Scythia, ≈øuppo≈øed to have ≈øprung from the Ten Tribes carried into Captivity, as is in the former Part of this Hi≈øtory related, began their Second Empire in A≈øia under Othoman, about 1300; and ≈øpreading wide, entred Europe, ≈øeizing at length upon the plea≈øant City of Con≈øtantinople, expelling the Greek Emperour, and making it the Imperial Seat of the Othoman Sultans, now dignified by the Title of Grand Seigniors: A De≈øcription of which City, and of the Seraglio, or Imperial Port or Palace, take as followeth.

Con≈øtantinople, built by Con≈øtantine the Great, is according to the Opinion of many, ≈øixteeen Miles in circuit, called by the Turks, Stambul or Stombolda; the Sea bearing upon it on the North and South ≈øides, and on the
Ea≈øt it is divided from A≈øia by a large Channel, which runneth from the one Sea to the other, being ≈øeven Miles in length, called the Straights of Bo≈øphorus. The City is built upon the declining of a Hill; for Buildings comparable to any in the World: But above all, beautified with ≈øeven Mo≈øques ≈øtanding upon ≈øeven little Hills, founded by ≈øeven of the Ottoman Emperors; of which, that of Sultan Solyman is mo≈øt famous: And the Seraglio, now made the Grand Seignior's Palace, which is three Miles in circuit, ≈øtandeth on the North ≈øide, having on the one ≈øide of it the Sea, and on the other the Haven; the other two Parts being encompa≈ø≈øed with the Building of the City. This Palace, Port, or Seraglio, which you plea≈øe, (for all the≈øe Names it bears) has within it many Gardens, Orchards, Meadows, Woods, plea≈øant Groves, Fountains, and all things el≈øe that can render it delightful. The Entrance is through a Gate of Iron into a large Court, where on the left hand ≈øtands a Building like a Turki≈øh Mo≈øque, which is u≈øed as a Store-hou≈øe for Arms and Provi≈øion; on the Right, are ≈øeveral fair Gardens palazadoed in, from which they pa≈øs to another Court, with a Gate like unto the former; upon which hang many Targets, Scymitars, and other Weapons of War, many Porters attending; through which they pa≈øs into another large Court, planted with Cyprus-Trees; where many Deer are kept: which Court is ≈øurrounded with a Cloy≈øter, which is in length 680 Foot, and in breadth 500; paved with Marble, leaded over, and ≈øupported by 140 Pillars of White and Gray Marble curiou≈øly wrought, ≈øtanding upon Ba≈øis of Copper, with Capitals of the like Mettal. On the North ≈øide ≈øtands the Divano, or Council-Hou≈øe, where the Grand Vizier, and ≈øuch others as are by the Grand Seignior appointed his Councellors, four times a Week, or oftner of Occa≈øion require it, ≈øit to con≈øult the Important Affairs of the Empire; to hear
and determine all Matters of Controver≈øie, and give Audience to Amba≈ø≈øadors, and other Forreign Mini≈øters.

In this Seraglio the Grand Seignior has many Chambers hung with Cloth of Gold, gilded Skins, and Tape≈øtries made of Silk and Gold; wherein are lively repre≈øented the Wars of the Ottoman Emperours. His Lodging-Chamber is garni≈øhed with divers Precious Stones of great value; and con≈øtantly attending him ≈øix young Men, who do Service in his Chamber, and watch his Per≈øon all Night, two and two by turns, with lighted Torches; the one ≈øitting at the Head, and the other at the Feet of his Bed: And when he attires him≈øelf, they put into his Pockets a thou≈øand A≈øpars, and twenty Ducats of Gold; the which, if he does not di≈øtribute that Day, at Night is their Fee; for he ≈øeldom or never puts on one Suit of Apparel twice; and when≈øoever he goes to Hunting, or any the like Exerci≈øe, (be≈øides the Money in his Pockets) his Ca≈ønadar Ba≈ø≈øa, or Chief Trea≈øurer, follows him with great ≈øtore of Money to give away: Of the≈øe ≈øix Young Men, who are changed at Plea≈øure, their Offices are di≈øtinct; for the fir≈øt carries his Shoes, the ≈øecond his Bow and Arrows, the Third his Ve≈øt, the fourth a Ve≈ø≈øel with Water, the fifth his Seat, and the ≈øixth, called Oda Ba≈ø≈øa, is Head of the Chamber.
He hath daily a great number of Per≈øons re≈øident in his Palace, imployed in their ≈øeveral Charges; the chief of which are the≈øe:

list.item: Fir≈øt, The Capi Aga, by whom the Grand Seignior ≈øpeaks to ≈øuch as have any Important Bu≈øine≈øs; for no Amba≈ø≈øador can be admitted to his Pre≈øence, but at his fir≈øt Arrival, when he delivers his Letters of Credit and Pre≈øents: But if afterward any matter ari≈øes, he mu≈øt addre≈øs him≈øelf to the Capi Aga, that is the Grand Vizier, or his Sub≈øtitute.
Secondly, The Ca≈ønadar Ba≈ø≈øa, or Chief Trea≈øurer of the Hou≈øhold.
Thirdly, The Chilergi Ba≈ø≈øa, or Chief Cup-Bearer.
Fourthly, The Seragli Aga≈øi, Steward or Ma≈øter of the Hou≈øhold.
Fifthly, The Chiller Aga≈øi, or Seraider Ba≈ø≈øa, Over≈øeer of the Seraglio of Concubines; who is always an Eunuch.

Sixthly and la≈øtly, The Bo≈øtangi Ba≈ø≈øa, or Chief Gardiner; who is Captain of the Jamoglans, and ≈øteers the Grand Seignior's Barge. When ever he goes by Water, he hath a Protogero or Lieutenant, and many Gardiners, to attend him, which are called Bo≈øtangi; who are frequently li≈øted in the number of Janizaries, when fitted thereto by hard Labour, &c.

div.p: The≈øe Six Officers have no Authority out of the Seraglio; yet the greate≈øt Ba≈ø≈øa's fear them, for that they being always near the Emperour, frequently incen≈øe him again≈øt them to their De≈øtruction.

Near unto the Grand Seignior's Per≈øon, are commonly ≈øix Mutes, Men born both Deaf and Dumb, with whom he makes him≈øelf Pa≈øtime. There are found likewi≈øe about thirty four more of the ≈øame Tribe, which he keeps as Executioners of his Wrath; for upon the lea≈øt Command, they will ≈øtrangle the greate≈øt Ba≈ø≈øa of the Court, or otherwi≈øe make him away, it being their frequent Practice.

Within the Seraglio are kept to the number of five hundred, ≈øuch Youths as are taken up for Tribute-Children in Graecia, and other Parts of the Empire; all Sons of Chri≈øtians, who taken young from their Parents, are in≈øtructed and brought up in divers Arts; and taught more e≈øpecially to manage all ≈øorts of Weapons, and to be perfect in the Mahometan Super≈øtition; few of them being above eight Years of Age at their fir≈øt Entrance. Of the≈øe, ≈øome they make Janizaries; others
are preferred to Offices of Tru≈øt, and come to great Preferment: But none of them may, on Pain of Death, ≈øtir out of the Seraglio, till the Sultan thinks them of a fit Age, and ≈øufficiently qualified for his Service. He has in like manner eighty Mutaferache, or Launce Bearers, who carry his Launce; and are ≈øubject to the Command of none but him≈øelf.

He hath in continual pay a thou≈øand Eunuches, whom the Turks call Hundurni; many of which are imployed to attend his Virgins and Concubines in the Seraglio. They are not only deprived of their Genitors, but in their Youth they have their whole Privities ≈ømoothed off by their Bellies: And in their Turbants they bear a Silver Quill or Crue, through which they evacuate their Urine. This Inhuman Barbarity was fir≈øt commanded by Solyman the Magnificent, who grew jealous of them upon his ob≈øerving a Gelding back a Mare; gathering from thence, that his Eunuches though they had lo≈øt their Genitor, might yet dalliance with his Females.

The Seraglio of Women is within the Palace, in which are con≈øtantly five hundred Virgins, the choice≈øt Beauties that can be procured, being all Daughters to Chri≈øtians, taken from their Parents when they are about eight Years of Age or under; none above are admitted, le≈øt they ≈øhould be debauched e're they enter. The≈øe are brought up to curious Works: And when at any time the Grand Seignior is de≈øirous to have any of them brought to his Bed, he the Day before gives notice to the Captain of the Eunuches; who commands tho≈øe under him to put them in order, and array them in their be≈øt Attire. Which done the Grand Seignior, attended by the ≈øaid Captain, walking between them as they ≈øtand demurely in rowes on either Hand; and where he likes, drops his Handkerchief, of which he has many hanging at his Girdle; which the Eunuches that follow, ob≈øerving, put her (or as many as his Plea≈øure
is to ≈øignifie by ≈øuch Tokens) into a Coach, and carry them to his Lodgings; where they are gorgeou≈øly attired, and u≈øed as he has occa≈øion for them: After which they return, not to the Seraglio of the Virgins, but have other Lodgings appointed them. And when by rea≈øon of the Failure of Tribute-Virgins, the Seraglio grows empty, they purcha≈øe the Faire≈øt they can find in the Market of Con≈øtantinople, whither they are brought to be ≈øold as Slaves.

Another Seraglio there is, in which the Grand Seignior keeps his Sultana's or Sultane≈ø≈øes, and their Children; as likewi≈øe, ≈øuch other Concubines, of whom for his delight he hath cho≈øen from among≈øt the Virgins. He never marries; but when any one is brought to his Bed ≈øide, he gives her a Golden Head-tire, and ten thou≈øand A≈øpers; cau≈øing her to live apart, daily increa≈øing her Maintenance. The fir≈øt that bears him a Child, is called the Sultana or Sultane≈øs, and is accounted Mi≈øtre≈øs of the re≈øt of his Women; and by him, for the mo≈øt part, be≈øt beloved. The re≈øt that hath been brought to his Bed, and with whom he hath dallianced, are returned back to their ≈øeveral Apartments, there to expect the I≈ø≈øue; and if they prove not with Child, then are they given in Marriage to his Slaves; whom for their ≈øakes he advances to great Dignity, for the mo≈øt part.

He hath three hundred Sollacchi, who march continually about his Per≈øon, and make (as it were) his Guard, being under the Command of the Aga of the Janizaries; all of them attired in Linnen-Garments hanging down beneath their Knees; and over them quilted Wa≈øt-Coats, with half Sleeves of Taffety, Damask, or Sattin; and on their Heads Caps and Feathers, carrying Bows and Arrows. There are another ≈øort of Foot-men, called Pei ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ i, wonderful ≈øwift of Foot; whom he imploys in the nature of ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ q ‚Ä¢ ies, or Foot-Po≈øts; being attired in Cloth of Cold, with „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ
of the ≈øame tyed fa≈øt about them; upon their Heads wearing Caps like Butter-pots; with a Silver Pike ≈øtanding out before, in the nature of a Horn.
The Porters of the Court, that give Attendance there, are four thou≈øand; and are attired like the Janizaries, having over them three Capigi Ba≈ø≈øa's.

The Grand Seignior's Power is ≈øo ab≈øolute, and his Government ≈øo tyrannical, that his Subjects term them≈øelves his Slaves; none of them being ≈øure of his Life or Goods beyond his Plea≈øure; for without any Tryal or Proce≈øs, he puts to Death whom it plea≈øeth him, unle≈øs re≈øtrained by the Souldiers, who often re≈øcue their Minions out of his Hands, and oblige him to pardon them.

Their Sutes are few, and tho≈øe very ≈øhort, they rarely being permitted the Favour of Advocates to procra≈øtinate Matters from coming to a ≈øpeedy Re≈øult; tho' commonly he who can bribe mo≈øt, fares the be≈øt: For the Turks are of all Nations the mo≈øt Avaricious, doing no Man a Kindne≈øs unle≈øs they are fee'd; though they have the lea≈øt Certainty of any People, to keep what they have gotten, all (as is afore≈øaid) being at the Di≈øpo≈øal of the Prince. They puni≈øh Crimes with great Severity, and ≈øo ≈øpeedily, that it is ob≈øerved that ≈øeldom any Theft or Murther is committed by any private Turk; but what Outrages do happen in the City, or el≈øewhere, are committed commonly by the Grecians, and tho≈øe that are not of the Progeny of the Turks.

The Grand Seignior's Chief Councellor is the Great Vizier; who wears his Signet, and is ≈øtiled his Lieutenant; every Divano-day giving him an exact Account what is ≈øaid and done: Nor dare he di≈ø≈øemble in ought; for that the Grand Seignior has a Window, from whence he can ≈øee and hear, and yet not be ≈øeen him≈øelf; which Window looks into the Divano. When this Vizier is
abroad, which never happens unle≈øs to be General of an Army, or upon ≈øome ≈øuch like important Occa≈øion; at what time he appoints his Lieutenant to officiate in his Ab≈øence, who is called the Chimacham.

Next unto the Ba≈ø≈øa's, (of which there are many di≈øper≈øed throughout the Empire, to manage the Affairs thereof) are the Beglerbegs, or Lords of Lords: They are Men of great Authority, and have the Command of great Kingdoms and Armies; under who≈øe Obedience are divers Sanzacks, which are ≈øent as Governors into Provinces, during the Princes Plea≈øure; being Men of great Experience; for the mo≈øt part, commanding over the Spahi and Timariots, the Turks chief Hor≈ømen, whom they continually exerci≈øe to render them the more expert. The Chief of the≈øe Beglerbegs, is the Beglerbeg of Romania or Grecia, under who≈øe Command are twenty one Sanzacks; next to him is the Beglerbeg of Buda, who hath under his Command thirteen Sanzacks: The Beglerbeg of Teme≈øwar has under his Command eight Sanzacks: The Beglerbeg of Bo≈øna hath under his Command nine Sanzacks: The Beglerbeg≈øhip of Coffe or Capha, who re≈øideth in Taurica Cher≈øone≈øus, and commandeth over the Sanzacks near unto the great River Tanais, and the Fenns of Maeotis, which was at fir≈øt but a Sanzack≈øhip, and depended upon the Beglerbeg≈øhip of Grecia; and is indeed rather a Beglerbeg≈øhip in Name, than in Power. The≈øe Beglerbegs, or Lords of Lords, great Governours of the Turki≈øh Empire in Europe, be≈øides the Sanzacks, have under their Command 257000 Timariots or Hor≈øe-men, who are bound for certain Lands alotted them by the Grand Seignior, out of his Conque≈øts, to ≈øerve in the Wars upon all Occa≈øions.

The Beglerbegs, or Great Commanders of the Turk's Empire in A≈øia, are thirty in number; under whom are a proportionable number of Sanzacks, and not le≈øs than
400000 Timariots. The Beglerbegs commanding the Turk's Empire in Africa, are four; and have under them fourteen Sanzacks, and ≈øixty two thou≈øand Timariots. Be≈øides the≈øe Timariot-Hor≈øemen, there are the Spahi, who are for the mo≈øt part Europeans, being ≈øuch as were brought up in their Infancy, or taken Captive: As likewi≈øe, Spa ‚Ä¢ hoglanians, Silictarians, and Olofagians; who have likewi≈øe Lands, or Annual Pen≈øions a≈ø≈øigned them; for which they are bound to ≈øerve in the Wars: for no Man in the Ottoman Empire can have any Lands, or Yearly Revenues that way, but mu≈øt be ready, or ≈øend others in his ≈øtead; it being held, that the whole Empire in Fee ≈øimple, is the Grand Seigniors: No Man being permitted to buy or injoy any Lands longer, than it plea≈øes his Prince: Nor can any one claim a Propriety to a Foot, unle≈øs by the Donation of the Grand Seignior, or his A≈ø≈øignment; and that la≈øt, at longe≈øt, but during the Natural Life of him, to whom it is ≈øo given or a≈ø≈øigned. The≈øe Hor≈øemen march under a white Banner, being armed with ≈øtrong Coats, Bows, and Arrows, Culeverings, Scymitars, and Battle Axes.

Another ≈øort of Hor≈øemen there are, called Caripices, not exceeding eight hundred; who ≈øtill ride near the Grand Seignior, as his Life-guard, in the middle of the Battalion of the Janizaries; and are the be≈øt Hor≈øemen accounted of all others, being (for the mo≈øt part) Sons of the Great Commanders.

As for his Foot Forces, the chief Strength con≈øi≈øts of Janizaries, who are Children taken from their Chri≈øtian Parents, and inured in their Youth to all manner of Hard≈øhip, taught all the U≈øe of Arms, and trained up in all Warlike Di≈øcipline, till they are adjudged fit to be inrolled for the War. The≈øe are taken up in Europe, no Children born either in A≈øia or Africa being admitted into their Seminary. The≈øe Men always
inclo≈øe the Per≈øon of the Grand Seignior at what time he marches with his Army; and are the la≈øt that fight, unle≈øs urgent Nece≈ø≈øity require it. They wear white Caps, carry Harquibu≈ø≈øes, and ≈øharp Scymitars; who ≈øince their fir≈øt In≈øtitution have been the chief Supporters of the Turki≈øh Empire; but of late they are much degenerated from their former Di≈øcipline, giving them≈øelves up wholly to Ea≈øe and Plea≈øure; yet keep them≈øelves in good order, for the mo≈øt part. There remains twenty four thou≈øand of them in Con≈øtantinople, and a far greater number in divers Places of the Empire. They are commanded by their Aga, or Captain, to whom nothing is ≈øo fatal as their Love for him; for then the Grand Seignior has him in mi≈øtru≈øt, and well is it if he be not made away. They ≈øleep together in great Halls, their Beds being placed on either ≈øide; and all tho≈øe of a Squadron feed at one Table; the Younger ever ≈øerve the Elder: And if any one of them be ab≈øent from his Lodging in the Night, unle≈øs upon publick occa≈øion, then is he the next day ≈øeverely c ‚Ä¢ dgelled, and neverthele≈øs obliged to ki≈øs the Hand that beat him. Their Imploys are different in time of Peace; for ≈øome wait upon Amba≈ø≈øadors, others upon Merchants and Con≈øuls, others again upon ≈øuch as travel through the Turki≈øh Empire. They likewi≈øe arre≈øt Malefactors, and ≈øee good Order kept, being feared of all Men; in≈øomuch that if they buy any thing, they will have it at their own Price, the Vender not daring to refu≈øe it. They have great Power in their Princes Election; no Emperour thinking him≈øelf ≈øafe in his Throne, till they approve of him: So that to gain their good Opinion, every new Emperour at his entring upon the Government, di≈øtributes large Sums of Money among≈øt them, and increa≈øes their Stipends.

Though the chief Strength of the Turki≈øh Foot Forces re≈øts in the Janizaries; yet are there another ≈øort
of Foot-Men, called Acouices; which is a Forlorn Hope. The≈øe receive no Pay, but have free liberty to plunder; ≈øo that they deliver the fifth Part to the Grand Seigniour. Another kind there are, called A≈øapi; who are but of ≈ømall Account, and rather u≈øed as Pioneers, than to encounter the Enemy; yet are they often thru≈øt into the Front of the Battle, with their Bodies to blunt the Enemies Swords, or to ≈øcale the Walls of Towns; that by being ≈ølaughter'd, their Dead Bodies may fill up the Ditches, and ≈øo give the Janizaries opportunity on their Dead Carka≈ø≈øes to mount the Bullwarks.

The Grand Seignior keeps in continual Pay ≈øix thou≈øand Gunners, whom the Turks call Topegi; and for the Guard of the Powder and Shot, upon the March of the Army, twelve thou≈øand Men are kept in pay, called Jebegi.

The Grand Seignior hath likewi≈øe certain Officers attending on him, to the number of three thou≈øand, whom they call Chiaus; which act in the Nature of Serjeants at Arms. The≈øe Men are well e≈øteemed, and are often employed in Emba≈ø≈øies to Forreign Princes: They al≈øo carry Letters or Commendations from the Grand Seignior, or his Chief Vizier; and are impower'd to apprehend Malefactors: But never go to the Wars, unle≈øs the Grand Seignior be there in Per≈øon. They are commanded by a Chiaus Ba≈ø≈øa; who is of ≈øuch Credit with all Men, that when he is ≈øent by the Grand Seignior to any Ba≈ø≈øa, Sanzack, or Caddi, to have any Man's Head cut off, though he have no Warrant in writing, yet his Authority is not di≈øputed.

Thus have I ≈øet down the Land Forces of the Turki≈øh Empire; in number ≈øo great, that in ≈øhew they ≈øhould breed Confu≈øion, and ruin them≈øelves; yet ≈øuch is the Order and Di≈øcipline, that in that point they give place to none. They live (for the mo≈øt part) on a little Bread
baked in the A≈øhes, with Rice and Powder of Fle≈øh dried in the Sun. Wine is forbidden them by their Law, though 'tis often drunk by them in private, e≈øpecially the Great Commanders. No Women are ≈øeen in their Armies. In their March they ob≈øerve a wonderful Silence; and all the Soldiers are governed by the Beck of the Hand, or Shew of the Countenance. Quarrels and Thefts are ≈øeverely puni≈øhed. When they March they dare not enter any Corn-field or Vineyard. The Valiant are a≈ø≈øured of Preferment, and the Coward of Puni≈øhment.

As for the Grand Seignior's Naval Forces, they are great; he having of late, for Gain-≈øake, allured many Chri≈øtian Carpenters and Shipwrights to his Ar≈øenal, and hath a great number of Men trained up in Marine Affairs, by being continually imployed aboard his Gallies at Rhodes, Cyprus, and Mitylene and Alexandria. He has al≈øo at his Beck the Pirates of Tunis, Tripoley, Sally, Argire, and other Places; from among≈øt whom he choo≈øes his prime Commanders in Marine Affairs.

To maintain the≈øe great Forces, it is requi≈øite a wonderful Ma≈øs of Money ≈øhould be imployed, which is the Sinews of War, and without which ≈øo great an Empire could not be kept in frame, though many are of opinion, that the Grand Seignior's Annual Revenues exceed not eight Millions; meaning thereby, that which is collected of his Subjects, and upon the account of Cu≈øtoms: For which they give the≈øe Rea≈øons: Fir≈øt, That the Turks have no care but of Arms; the which do rather ruin, than enrich a Country. Secondly, They con≈øume ≈øo many Men in their Enterprizes, that they ≈øcarce leave a ≈øufficient number to manure the Land; in≈øomuch that the Subjects de≈øpairing to injoy their Wealth, and nece≈ø≈øary Commodities, which they might get by their Labour and Indu≈øtry, employ not them≈øelves to work
nor traffick, more than by nece≈ø≈øity they are con≈øtrained: For they argue, 'tis to no purpo≈øe to labour for another, their Lives and E≈øtates being daily expo≈øed to the Mercy of their Prince: And for this Rea≈øon, many ≈øpacious Countries in the Turki≈øh Empire lie wa≈øte; which neglect frequently cau≈øes a Dearth. A Third Rea≈øon that is given, why the Grand Seignior's Revenues are no greater, is, for that when he Conquers any Country, he a≈ø≈øigns the Lands therein to his Timariots, who ≈øerve in the Wars, and are no otherwi≈øe liable to accommodate their Prince.

But although his ordinary Revenues amount to no great Sum, in con≈øideration of the large Circuit of his Empire; yet his extraordinary Profits accruing by Confi≈øcations, Pre≈øents, (for no Stranger may approach his Pre≈øence empty handed) and Mony rai≈øed upon Places and Offices of Tru≈øt, amount to a far greater Sum than what has been mentioned. Nor are the Sums ≈ømall, which he draws from the Princes their Tributaries, that are not ab≈øolutely under his Juri≈ødiction; as Moldavia, Vallachia, and Tran≈øylvania, with many more. So that in all, moderate Writers affirm, That his Coffers are yearly ≈øupplied with twenty Millions: The Management of which is left to the Defterdari, or chief Trea≈øurer, who has many Sub-officers under him.

Thus much having been ≈øpoken of the Forces, Revenues, and great Officers; I ≈øhall now proceed to give the Reader a View of their Religion, if it may without offence be ≈øo termed; which they call the Law of their great Prophet.

As for their Religion, it began in the time of Heraclius the Emperor; at what time the Here≈øie of Arius and Ne≈øtorius ≈øpread it ≈øelf: to who≈øe Infamous Pro≈øelytes Mahomet the Impo≈øtor, born in Arabia, joyned him≈øelf; impiou≈øly denying the Divinity of Chri≈øt, and proclaiming him≈øelf a Prophet ≈øent from God, drawing
a Multitude after him: In≈øomuch that ≈øuch as would not receive his impious Tenents by fair means, he compelled by force: And the better to ingratiate him≈øelf with the lewd and licentious ≈øort of People, he tolerated all manner of Lu≈øt, and Worldly Delights. By the Law this Impo≈øtor left, and that now has over≈øpread two Parts of the World, a Di≈øtinction is made between clean and unclean Meats, to content the Jews, who are the greate≈øt Merchants in the Ottoman Empire. They al≈øo maintain Circumci≈øion, but not at the Expiration of Eight Days, according to the Jewi≈øh Cu≈øtom; but at the End of Eight Years, when the Infant is able to make a Confe≈ø≈øion of his Belief; and lifting up his Finger to ≈øpeak the≈øe words in the Arabick Tongue, viz. There is but One God, and Mahomet is his Prophet; one God, and equal Prophets. The Circumci≈øion ended, they fea≈øt three Days. As for the Female Children, they at eight Years old ≈øpeak the ≈øame words; but are not capable of Circumci≈øion. If any Chri≈øtian turn Apo≈øtate, and deny his Redeemer, which (to the lo≈øs of their Souls) too many do, only to avoid Taxations and Tribute, they are led through the Town or City, where they dwell in great Triumph, many People pre≈øenting them with Gifts, as they pa≈øs, to encourage them to per≈øevere in what they have undertaken. And for the Men, at what Age ≈øoever they are, they mu≈øt be Circumci≈øed.
The Law of Mahomet is contained in his Alchoran; wherein he confe≈ø≈øeth One God, and honoureth Je≈øus Chri≈øt as a great Prophet: But impiou≈øly denies him to be the Son of God.

The Turks by their Law are forbid to wor≈øhip Images, or to have any placed in their Mo≈øques: The whole Series of the Alcoran being full of Fables and Fictions, much like to tho≈øe the Poets feigned of the Elizium-Shades; indulging Men in all Sen≈øuality during this
Life, and promi≈øing them a Paradi≈øe, where they ≈øhall enjoy the like more perfectly after Death.

Their Sabbath is kept on our Fryday. They keep Lent thirty Days; during which ≈øpace they eat nothing in the day-time, but take their Repa≈øt after Sun-≈øet, ab≈øtaining from Wine and Women. This Lent is called by them Ramaden.
They likewi≈øe ob≈øerve an Ea≈øter, called Bayran; which continues for the ≈øpace of the three Days, though not always prefixed by rea≈øon they begin it in the New of the Moon.

They have no Bells in their Mo≈øques; neither do they ≈øuffer the Chri≈øtians to have any that live among≈øt them. When they enter the ≈øaid Mo≈øques, they leave their Shooes at the Door, and take them again when they return. Where ≈øoever they ≈øit or ≈øtand in their Religious Hou≈øes, they have Tape≈øtry or Mats under them, as not thinking their Feet holy enough to ≈øtand in that Place, during the Reading their Law; and if they look back, or ≈øcratch their Head till the Orizon is ended, they think they have lo≈øt the Benefit they were at that time to receive by their coming thither. They are not much addicted to Learning; yet of late they have brought up their Children to u≈øe the Arabick Tongue, in which their Law is written.

By this Law they have leave to marry as many Wives as they can maintain; and when once any of them proves with Child, her Husband may not carnally know her till ≈øhe is delivered. They have certain Marriages contracted during Plea≈øure, which they call Kebin, mo≈øtly practi≈øed by Strangers; who may, for a certain Sum of Money, have the U≈øe of a Woman during his Plea≈øure: Yet when he turns her off, if ≈øhe have any Children, he is bound to keep them. A Turk having had to do with a Chri≈øtian Woman, both of them upon Conviction are to ≈øuffer Death, unle≈øs
≈øhe add ≈øin to ≈øin, by renouncing her Faith. The like is to be ob≈øerved between a Chri≈øtian, and a Turki≈øh VVoman; though either Offence, by bribing the Caddi's or Judges, may be omitted.
They allow of Divorce in ca≈øe of Barrenne≈øs or Incontinency.

The chief Interpreter of the≈øe Laws, is the Muphti, or Arch-Prie≈øt, who is cho≈øen by the Grand Seignior; and is greatly reverenced among≈øt the Turks, being Head of their Church, and Decider of all Controver≈øies ari≈øing in matter of their Super≈øtitious Religion. His Eminency is ≈øuch, that all the Ba≈ø≈øa's are ≈øubject to his Direction. He aba≈øeth him≈øelf not ≈øo much as to ≈øit in the Divano; only pa≈ø≈øing through it, when he is ≈øent for by the Grand Seignior; who at his approach ri≈øeth from his Seat, (an Honour not allowed to any other) and then they ≈øit together, and familiarly di≈øcour≈øe of their Affairs.

The next to him are the Cadile≈øquires, or Tali≈ømen: Two Doctors of the Law, who≈øe place it is to Examine the Caddi's or Judges, who are di≈øper≈øed throughout the Provinces of the Empire, and are always attendant upon the Grand Seignior: The one of them having Juri≈ødiction over all the European Caddi's, and the other on tho≈øe re≈øiding in A≈øia; there being few Cities, or great Towns, in which one of the Caddi's have not their Re≈øidence there, to hear and determine Matters of Controver≈øie ari≈øing between Man and Man. The Cadile≈øquires are likewi≈øe Soveraign Judges within their own Juri≈ødiction, in all Cau≈øes belonging to their Religion, as it were Patriarks. They are of great Authority, and have places in the Divano, and in Council with the Ba≈ø≈øa's, con≈øult the weighty Affairs of the Empire.

There is a third Degree of Church-Men, not belonging to their Law, called Mulli; which they account
their Bi≈øhops, and are directed in their Affairs by the Muphti. Their Office is to place and di≈øplace Church-Men as they ≈øee it convenient.

Another ≈øort there are, called the Nuderi≈øi, who act in the nature of Suffragans, and have under them ≈øeveral young Doctors of the Law, who are their Di≈øciples, called Naipi; who are, in the Ab≈øence of the Caddi's, con≈øtituted to hear and redre≈øs Grievances.
After the≈øe are the Hagi, who are employed to write their Books, they in no wi≈øe allowing them to be Printed; and inferior unto the≈øe are the Ca≈ø≈øi, who read unto them what they write, &c.

The≈øe are their ≈øeveral Degrees of Lawyers, and Church-Men; for the Turks are governed by a kind of Eccle≈øia≈øtical Law, according to their Alchoran. Many Colledges they have, which they call Medre≈ø≈øae's, ≈øituate not only in Con≈øtantinople, but in divers other Cities.

And thus, Reader, have I related the Suceinct Series of This History, as near as can be gathered from Authors of undoubted Credit, and my own Knowledge: And now nothing more remains, but to make known the Va≈øtne≈øs of the Ottoman Empire; which is, for the mo≈øt part, the Subject of This Hi≈øtory.

Know then, that ≈øince the Reign of Ottoman, fir≈øt Founder of the Turki≈øh Empire, it has proudly built it ≈øelf upon the Four Monarchies of the VVorld, viz. the A≈ø≈øyrian, Grecian, Per≈øian, and Roman Empires; for they enjoy Babylon, and all Chaldea, with the Kingdom of Media, a great part of Per≈øia, all Greece, with the Kingdom of Egypt, and the greate≈øt Part of Arabia; the I≈ølands of Cyprus, Rhodes, Mitylene, Negropont, Ch ‚Ä¢ o or Scio, Candia, and many others: The
Empire of Trepezond, the Kingdoms of Colchis, now called Mingrelia, Tunis, and Argeirs, Dalmatia, Illyria, and Triballenia; the Countries of Tran≈øylvania, Wallachia, Moldavia, and Bulgaria: A great part of Hungary, and many other Countries, which hold of the Empire, and pay Tribute to the Grand Seignior; who in Europe hath all the Sea-Coa≈øt from the Confines of Epidaurus, the utmo≈øt Boundard of his Empire in Europe, We≈øtward, unto the Mouth of the River Tanais, now called Don; with all that lieth between the City of Buda, and Con≈øtantinople: and Southward, all the Sea-Coa≈øt from Velex or Belis, the Boundard of the Kingdom of Fez, unto the Arabian Gulph, or Red-Sea; and ≈øo proportionably every way: The Greatne≈øs of which may be better conjectured by the Greatne≈øs of ≈øome part thereof; for the Meere of Maetis, which is all at the Grand Seignior's Command, is in Compa≈øs one thou≈øand Miles; and the Euxine, or Black Sea, in Circuit two thou≈øand ≈øeven hundred Miles: The Mediterranean-Coa≈øt, which is ≈øubject unto him, is in Compa≈øs upward of eight thou≈øand Miles. But to ≈øpeak of his whole Territory together, he pa≈ø≈øeth in his own Dominion from Tauris to Buda three thou≈øand two hundred Miles; and the like Di≈øtance from Derbent to Adena: From Bal≈øera, upon the Per≈øian-Gulph, to Tremi≈øena in Barbary, is accounted little le≈øs than about four thou≈øand.

Yet that this great Empire will not long con≈øi≈øt, but like tho≈øe that have preceded it, be again brought to nothing, the Turks them≈øelves have divers Prophe≈øies: Nor is Sacred Writ ≈øilent in this Matter; many of the Prophets plainly foretelling its Ri≈øe and Fall; which will undoubtedly be manife≈øted, when God (in who≈øe deep Coun≈øels the Gr ‚Ä¢ at Revolutions
of Empires and Kingdoms are from Eternity ≈øhut up) ≈øhall in his Infinite Wi≈ødom ≈øee fit time, to the un≈øpeakable Comfort of the poor afflicted Chri≈øtians, that groan under the Oppre≈ø≈øion and Tyranny of tho≈øe proud Infidels, Enemies to the Name of our Lord and Saviour Je≈øus Chri≈øt, God ble≈ø≈øed for ever-more, Amen.

div.head: Adverti≈øement of Books.
div.p: THe Works of Jo≈øephus, Tran≈ølated out of French, new ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ Amended; Illu≈øtrated with Copper-Plates, and a New Map of the Holy-Land; Folio. Printed for Tho. Pa≈ø≈øenger, and Tho. Sawbridge.
Co≈ømography in four Books, containing the Chorography and Hi≈øtory of the whole World; by Peter Heylyn. Printed for Tho. Pa≈ø≈øenger, Tho. Sawbridge, and Benj. Took.

The Third Part of the Pre≈øent State of England, relating to its Trade and Commerce within it ≈øelf, and with all Countries, as it is found at this Day e≈øtabli≈øhed; giving a mo≈øt exact Account of the Laws and Cu≈øtoms of Merchants, relating to Bills of Exchange, Cu≈øtoms, Coyns, Weights, Mea≈øures, &c. To which is added, England's Guide to Indu≈øtry or Improvement of Trade. Printed for Tho. Pa≈ø≈øenger, and Benj. Took.
Eccle≈øia≈øtical Hi≈øtory epitomiz ‚Ä¢ d, deduced to this Pre≈øent Time. Printed for Tho. Pa≈ø≈øenger, and W. Thackeray.
Phy≈øick Refin'd, or a Little Stream of Medicinal Marrow flowing from the Bones of Nature, &c. Printed for Thomas Pa≈ø≈øenger.

div.head: A Continuation of the preceding Hi≈øtory to this pre≈øent time; Containing the Remarkable Siege of Vienna for Sixty dayes, the rai≈øing of it by the Imperial Forces, and the King of Poland: The Ruine of their Army before it, and a Second Fight in Germany; together with a Table to the whole Book.
div.p:
NEw-Hau≈øel Be≈øieged by 13000 Imperial Hor≈øe and Foot, they run their Trenches within a hundred yards of the Wall, and with the Cannon on the Battery rai≈øed on the Ea≈øt part continually for the ≈øpace of two dayes, Thundered again≈øt it, in≈øomuch that divers hou≈øes were beaten down, and a great number of the Enemy ≈ølain, yet encouraged by a Party of Turks who had po≈øted them≈øelves upon an Eminence near Gran, watching their opportunity to annoy the Chri≈øtians, they made divers brisk ≈øallies ≈øo that often coming to handy blows; the di≈øputes grew hot, many on either ≈øide being ≈ølain, but after ≈øeveral un≈øucce≈øsful attempts to take the place by Storm, and notice had that the Grand Vi≈øier was on his way from Belgrade with ≈øixty or ≈øeventy thou≈øand Hor≈øe and Foot, re≈øolving though at the hazard of a Battle to rai≈øe the Siege. The Duke drew off the Be≈øiegers having for that purpo≈øe received an expre≈øs Command from the Emperour
and Council of War, a≈ø≈øembled to debate the important „Äà‚óä„Äâ of the Empire, and uniting them „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ Forces kept clo≈øe in his Camp before „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ , immediately upon who≈øe departure the „Äà‚óä„Äâ in the Town ≈øired all their Cannonry joy of their deliverance, being a little before in great di≈øtre≈øs for Provi≈øion and other nece≈ø≈øaries, having over and above lo≈øt five hundred of their mo≈øt re≈øolute Souldiers.

„Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ the Siege of New-Hau≈øel the Palatine of „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ with a thou≈øand Foot, and five hundred Hor ‚Ä¢ e marching to Scarce a Fortre≈øs of the Turks, ≈øo „Äà‚óä„Äâ Be≈øieged it, that the Garri≈øon being altogether unprovided, after a ≈øhort Battery ≈øounded a ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ rly, and upon condition that they might march out with Bag and Baggage, offered to ≈øurrender the place; but that not being granted, they to ≈øave their lives were contented to become Pri≈øoners of War, in all being but ≈øixty eight per≈øon, of which eight had been killed with the „Äà‚óä„Äâ of the Culverines, upon which the Palatine having put a Garri≈øon of Hungarian Soldiers into it, and ≈øufficiently ≈øtored it with Provi≈øion, „Äà‚óä„Äâ to have an eye upon Teckeley, who was moving towards the Frontires of Sile≈øia, daily expection re-inforcement from the Ba≈ø≈øa of Buda, and to joyn ≈øome Tartarian Troops who were on their March.

The≈øe things pa≈ø≈øing the King of Poland u≈øed all diligence to draw his Forces together near Cracow, giving great encouragement to his Souldiers, and ≈øuch of the nobility as ≈øent any Forces to his a≈ø≈øi≈øtance „Äà‚óä„Äâ the Grand Vi≈øier ≈ølow in his March, as „Äà‚óä„Äâ thereby to draw the Imperiali≈øts to a „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ that conjunction, and ≈øo „Äà‚óä„Äâ was „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ Rivers by Bridging them over with
Boats, Floats, Cask, and pla≈øhing of Trees, that beyond expectation, he arrived at Stat-We≈ø≈øemberg, not above ≈øix Leagues from Commora, before the Imperiali≈øts had notice of his pa≈ø≈øing the Gran, and there encamping received the complements of divers traiterous Hungarian Lords, who encouraged him to undertake the ≈øiege of Vienna, and ≈øeize upon the Hereditary Countreys of the Emperour.

The ≈øudden advancement of the Turks cau≈øed the Emperour to ≈øend an Expre≈øs to Count Chakay Commander in chief of the Garri≈øons upon the Banks of the River Neytray, to demoli≈øh ≈øuch as he ≈øuppo≈øed not tenable, which was accordingly done. And now the two potent Armies approaching, great was the expectation of a battle, but the Turks expecting a ≈øupply of twenty thou≈øand Tartars, who were on their march through Moldavia, protracted the time, as likewi≈øe did the Imperiali≈øts, expecting ≈øomething from the Tran≈øi ‚Ä¢ vanian Prince, who (≈øecretly envying Teckelies advancement, who had by this time proclaimed him≈øelf Prince of Hungary, Coyning money in his own name, and u≈øing the antient In≈øigns of Royalty) had underhand promi≈øed to put him≈øelf under the Emperours protection, and take the field with eighteen or twenty thou≈øand men. But on the ≈øecond of Ju ‚Ä¢ y 1683, the Duke receiving notice that a body of Turks and Tartars
„Äà‚óä„Äâ pa≈ø≈øed the Waag at Segith, and u≈øed all manner of „Äà‚óä„Äâ , burning and plundering, killing and taking pri≈øoners all that fell into their hands „Äà‚óä„Äâ thou≈øand other outrages and in≈øolencies. „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ party to oppo≈øe their advancing „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ into the Countrey and oblige them to „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ , the which he effected, but they „Äà‚óä„Äâ as it they intended to lay ≈øiege either to
„Äà‚óä„Äâ
or
„Äà‚óä„Äâ , to prevent
that purpo≈øe the Imperial hor≈øe po≈øted near Altenberg and the foot in the I≈øle of Scutz, to a≈ø≈øi≈øt upon the fir≈øt offered occa≈øion, but it being ≈øoon perceiving hat the Turks intention was no other then to get between the hor≈øe and foot, and ≈øo render them un≈øerviceable to each other.

The Duke ≈øent away the Baggage under a convoy of ≈øix hundred hor≈øe towards Altemberg, to ≈øeize upon which the Turks advanced with a party of three thou≈øand hor≈øe, ≈øo that a ≈øharp di≈øpute happened till the Turks by the courage of the Imperiali≈øts were obliged to a di≈øorderly retreat, but being reinforced by eight hundred fre≈øh hor≈øe, they rallyed, whereupon the Duke of Lorrain and divers great Commanders, with all convenient ≈øpeed advanced, and the Forces on either ≈øide encrea≈øing the fight grew hot, the Imperiali≈øts behaving them≈øelves very re≈øolutely, but e≈øpecially the Duke of Lorraine who with his Regiment of Guards charged through the thicke≈øt of the enemies ≈øquadron, but the Turks power ≈øtill increa≈øing, and the Imperiali≈øts not being ≈øo ≈øuddenly able to pa≈øs the River as the Action required, after two hours re≈øolute fighting, tho≈øe that convoyed the Baggage were mo≈øt of them cut in pieces, and to the value of forty thou≈øand Guilders fell to the enemy, and in the whole action twelve hundred Imperiali≈øts and ≈øeventeen hundred Turks were ≈ølain, among≈øt the former the Prince of Savoy, General Rabatta, the Count d'Lamberg and Prince of Aremberg, after which the Imperial hor≈øe having made good their retreat, pa≈ø≈øed the River and joyned their foot, who could not though they were speculators of the Action come up, which gave the Turks this con≈øiderable advantage, and ≈øo exalted their ≈øpirits, that upon receiving a new ≈øupply of
eight thou≈øand foot, they be≈øieged Raab, but received ≈øuch welcome from the mouthes of the murthering Cannon, that they were glad to draw off, when having burnt ≈øome few Villages, with what plunder they had got, they marched to the Grand Vi≈øiers Camp; upon which reinforcement, he tru≈ø≈øed up his Tents and marched directly towards Vienna the Imperial chief City, ≈øcituate in Au≈øtria, on the banks of the River Danubius, burning and ruining all his way, in≈øomuch that the Imperial Army being found too weak to encounter him, the Duke retired with it under the walls of that City, to expect the Forces of the Confederate Princes, whil≈øt Count Staremberg Governour thereof, who had been abroad with a party to ob≈øerve the motion of the enemy, was obliged to fight his way through the Vaunt-Corriers of the Turks Army, to get into the City, through which likewi≈øe the Duke of Lorraine pa≈ø≈øed, when he had given ≈øuch nece≈ø≈øary orders as were convenient for maintaining a ≈øtrenuous ≈øiege, leaving therein eighteen or twenty thou≈øand ≈øouldiers under the command of the afore≈øaid Count, who ≈øallying out fired the Suburbs, di≈ølodging and killing a great number of Turks, that he found there plundering the hou≈øes, and upon his return calling together the Chief Citizens, he admoni≈øhed them to behave them≈øelves like men again≈øt the enemies or their Countrey, and Religion, from whom notwith≈øtanding the ≈øpecious pretences they might make, they ≈øhould receive little mercy at the hands of the Infidels if they became victors; he likewi≈øe with ≈øpeech and large promi≈øes of reward, animated his Captains and ≈øouldiers, whom he found re≈øolved to live and dye with him in the defence of that City,
which is the glory of the Empire, prote≈øting rather to ≈øuffer the wor≈øt extremity then hearken to any ≈øurrender.

The Duke of Lorraine having pa≈ø≈øed through the City with his Army, incamped him≈øelf ≈øtrongly near Kremps, re≈øolving there to expect the King of Poland, and the Troops of the Confederate Princess which were on their march, and as opportunity offered both to encourage and ≈øuccour the be≈øieged, whom by this time the Vi≈øier had with his Army con≈øi≈øting of one hundred thou≈øand men blocked up, being the flower of the Ottoman Empire, running his Trenches with great celerity, though to hinder it, the Cannons from the walls ince≈ø≈øantly played, and the be≈øieged frequently ≈øallyed, killing and repul≈øing the Infidels, following the execution even to their Camp, yet the number of their Pioniers increa≈øing, they under the shelter of the night, and favour of their Cannon, in two dayes lodged them≈øelves, running their works to a great depth, leaving the earth archwi≈øe, thinking ≈øo to reach the walls and blow them up, by ≈øpringing their Mines, but ≈øuch diligence was u≈øed by the German Enginiers, that a great number of the Infidels were buryed in their works & ≈øeveral poy≈øoned by the ≈øtench of dead bodied they met with in their Subterranean Progre≈øs, which had been buryed in the la≈øt plague, which the „Äà‚óä„Äâ perceiving commanded eight thou≈øand
„Äà‚óä„Äâ
to lodge them≈øelves in the ruines, and „Äà‚óä„Äâ from ≈øix batteries containing thirty which Cannon, he cau≈øed the City to be battered „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ without intermi≈ø≈øion, and having there

„Äà‚óä„Äâ his men to enter, who in a de≈øperate manner
came on, but were ≈øo warmly received by the be≈øieged, that after three thou≈øand were ≈ølain upon the place, they were obliged to retire, which ≈øo enraged the Vi≈øier that he commanded them to make a ≈øecond Attack, which was done but with altogether as bad ≈øucce≈øs as the former.

The City of Vienna thus ≈øtraitned, the Bi≈øhop of Aich≈øtadt the Imperial Mini≈øter, repre≈øented the danger it was in, to the Diet for that purpo≈øe a≈ø≈øembled at Ratisbone, recommending it e≈øpecially to the care of the Electoral Princes, requiring them in the name of the Emperor to find out ≈øuch effectual and ≈øpeedy ways to rai≈øe men and money for its relief, that it might not fall into the hands of the Infidels, and thereby open a way for them to conquer all the Cities of Au≈øtria. This matter being debated, it was re≈øolved that a fund of money ≈øhould be ≈øpeedily rai≈øed, and all other nece≈ø≈øaries provided, for the ≈øub≈øi≈øtence and relief of the be≈øieged, and to ≈øtay the further progre≈øs of the Turki≈øh Arms. Upon notice of which the Elector of Bavaria drew his forces into the field, and ordered them to the number of ten or eleven thou≈øand, immediately to march and joyn the Duke of of Loraine, whom they found encamped near Kre ‚Ä¢ ps.

Whil≈øt the≈øe things were doing, the Rebels under the command of Count Teckely made great ≈øpoil upon the borders of Croatia and Silefia: be≈ø ‚Ä¢ e ‚Ä¢ ing and taking Budekim by ≈øtorm, ravaging and de≈øtroying all the pleasant places about it, which put the adjacent Gari≈øons into ≈øuch con≈øternation, that ≈øeveral whether through fear or treachery i ‚Ä¢ uncertain, put them≈øelves under his protection, whereby he was pu≈ø≈øed up to that extravagance
that he ≈øent Summons to divers of the Nobility to attend him in Arms as their Prince, under the Penalties of Confi≈øcation, Impri≈øonment and death, which ≈øo afrighted divers, that they came in, but many there were who≈øe Loyalty could not be ≈øhaken which ≈øo enraged the Rebel that he de≈øtroyed their Country dwellings, and ≈øeized on what≈øoever of theirs he could find.

By this time the Turks had far advanced their Trenches, and began to throw their Bombs into the City, whereupon the Citizens covered many of their hou≈øes near the wall with earth, and with the ≈øhot of the Cannons from the Tower, overthrew the mortars, ≈øallying out at the ≈øame time, and making a terrible ≈ølaughter of the enemy, who were advancing to the wall with a de≈øign to enter the new breach, recovering from them a Ba≈øtion of which they had po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed them≈øelves, and cutting in pieces all they found therein.

This bad ≈øucce≈øs making it apparent that the City was not ≈øo ea≈øie to be taken as the Vi≈øier had ≈øuppo≈øed, he commanded Arrows to be ≈øhot over the walls, with Letters fa≈øtened to them, containing his admonition to the be≈øieged, ≈øpeedily to ≈øurrender and receive liberty in their per≈øons, a free exemption of their goods, and ≈øuch treatment as they ≈øhould de≈øire, but if they refu≈øed, and held out ob≈øtinately, till the City ≈øhould be taken by ≈øtorm, or reduced by famine, no mi≈øchief ≈øhould be left unpracti≈øed that wit or horror could invent, but this device not at all prevailed, but rather induced the be≈øieged to contemn the be≈øiegers, who≈øe weakne≈øs thereby they the better under≈øtood, as ob≈øerving from former acts of the like nature, they never capitulate underhand, till
they de≈øpaire of obtaining their ends, or grow weary of the ≈øiege. All this while the Duke of Loraine lay clo≈øe in his Camp within ≈øight of the City, the better to incourage the be≈øieged, daily increa≈øing his number, and as earne≈øtly expecting the Polonian King, who had ≈øent the Prince Lubomirskie before him with ≈øix thou≈øand hor≈øe, and daily Curriers pa≈ø≈øed between him and the Emperor, who with the Court was retired to Pa≈øhaw, there to expect the great event, on which the eyes of all Nations were fixed.

The increa≈øe of the Chri≈øtian Camp did not a little trouble the Vi≈øier, who well knew that if he could not make him≈øelf ma≈øter of the City before the King of Poland arrived, he mu≈øt be obliged to give battle, or rai≈øe his ≈øiege, and that if he mi≈øcarried in the former, it would greatly redound to his di≈øgrace, if not hazzard his life, by rendring him obnoxious to the Grand Signiours di≈øplea≈øure, whom he had a≈ø≈øured of taking the City; whereupon to ha≈øten the enterprize he ≈øpared not his men, but thru≈øt them on even into the mouth of ≈ølaughter, ≈øwearing by Mahomet that in whom≈øoever he found the lea≈øt mark of cowardi≈øe, or neglect of duty he ≈øhould be put to death, and thereupon he commanded the Cannon from all the Batteries to play without cea≈øing, but ≈øuch was the care and skill of the Chri≈øtian Engineers, that they with their great ≈øhot di≈ømounted divers of them, overthrowing their battery, and burying ≈øuch as were there po≈øted in their ruins, yet having made two breaches in the wall, one near the red Tower, and the other not far from the Imperial Pallace, he commanded five thou≈øand Janizaries, and ten thou≈øand other ≈øouldiers to enter the Breach, but
Count Staremberg having drawn his chief ≈øtrength on that ≈øide to oppo≈øe the Torrent, although as men de≈øperate they came on, yet the be≈øieged ≈øallying out and coming to hand ≈øtrokes, by plain force drove them back, killing about three thou≈øand, and recovering the Raveling, and Counter≈øcarp, of which they had ≈øtrongly po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed them≈øelves, yet in this ≈øally five hundred of the Imperiali≈øts fell, and two hundred wounded.

This hot di≈øpute over, and the Turks beaten out of divers of their Trenches, they lay ≈øtill for two days, not attempting any thing, when on the third the Vi≈øier ≈øent to the Count Staremberg for a Ce≈ø≈øation, or a five days Truce to bury the dead, who≈øe noi≈øome ≈ømells greatly afflicted his Camp with ≈øickne≈øs, but the Count returned for an an≈øwer, that he had no need of a Truce, nor would he accord to any, upon which under the ≈øhelter of the night, the Turks in great numbers approached the walls, but being di≈øcovered by lights thrown out for that purpo≈øe, the ≈øhot from the Flankers and Battlements, gabled them ≈øo de≈øperately, that they were obliged to return two thou≈øand le≈øs than they came on, when upon their retreat three thou≈øand of the Imperiali≈øts ≈øallyed, and did great execution; whereupon the Vi≈øier ≈øtorming, and finding the greatne≈ø of the lo≈øs he had at divers „Äà‚óä„Äâ ≈øu≈øtained, „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ un≈øucce≈øsful attempts, repaired his Batterie, and planted as near as he could his Mortars to the wall, with which he threw divers Granadoes and Bombies into the Town, freeing ≈øome hou≈øes, on fire, and killing „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ the inhabitants, the which he continued all the 21 and 22 of July, but by the extraordinary diligence of the be≈øieged, who ≈øtill countermured
the breaches, repaired what was ≈øhattered and earth behind to keep the Bullworks from renting, and the wall from ≈øhaking by the force of the furious ≈øhot, the Turks at that va≈øt expence of powder and ≈øhot were little advantaged.

The Duke of Loraine having received another ≈øupply of five thou≈øand men, part of the Troops of the Circle, and certain notice from the King of Poland, that he was advancing with all diligence, he the better to encourage the be≈øieged, ≈øent a Fi≈øherman to a≈ø≈øure them of ≈øpeedy ≈øuccour, commanding him to give him notice of his ≈øafe arrival, by ≈øetting up a blew flag upon the battlements of the Tower, and that the be≈øieged if they were in danger ≈øhould ≈øet up a red flag, and that rather then the City ≈øhould ≈øall into the hands of the Infidels, he would without the King of Poland endeavour to rai≈øe the ≈øiege, though at the hazard of a Battle, nor was it long e'r he ≈øafely arrived, by ≈øwimming over the Danubius, and gave the fir≈øt ≈øignal, but ≈øo far were the be≈øieged from giving the ≈øecond, that they encouraged thereto by their renowned Governour the Count d' Staremberg, ≈øallyed early in the morning, and finding the Turks advancing their Mines, fell upon them with ≈øuch fury, that they overwhelmed the Miners, and beat the Janizaries, who were appointed to guard them, in≈øomuch that the noi≈øe aro≈øe ≈øo great that the Grand Vizier not well a≈ø≈øured, ≈øuppo≈øed the Chri≈øtian Army had at that time attempted the relief of the City, and for his own ≈øafety cau≈øed him to draw up his Army in Battalia.

Things being at this pa≈øs, the Duke of Loraine in his Camp where he lay had notice that a Convoy

On the 24 of July the be≈øieged made a vigorous ≈øally with five thou≈øand hor≈øe and foot, and charging the Turks in their Trenches with much bravery and re≈øolution, drove them thence, thereby recovering, though not without con≈øiderable ≈ølaughter on either part, divers redoubts of which they had po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed them≈øelves, firing the bavins and planks with which they attempted to fill up the Ditch, in order to a ≈øtorm, which the next morning was intended, but ≈øeven thou≈øand Turks being ≈øent to reinforce tho≈øe that were routed, they with fre≈øh fury returned upon the Imperiali≈øts, to ≈øuccour whom two thou≈øand i≈ø≈øued out of the Town, at what time the fight was renewed, and for a long time continued bloody and doubtful, and mo≈øt of the works the Chri≈øtians had po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed them≈øelves of were recovered, the Turks ≈øtill pre≈ø≈øing on to enter the Town with the be≈øieged, but being within danger, the Imperial Engeniers ≈øprung a mine, and thereby de≈øtroying about two hundred of the forwarde≈øt, put a ≈øtop to the courage of the re≈øt, and gave fre≈øh vigor to the be≈øieged, in≈øomuch that again charging the enemy with the former courage and bravery, they overthrew them far and near, in≈øomuch that five thou≈øand were computed to fall during the action, which carnage ≈øo infected the Turki≈øh Camp, that the ≈øoldiers dyed in great numbers, which obliged the
