The Elector of Bavaria according to his promi≈øe, having rai≈øed an Army of thirteen or fourteen thou≈øand men, for the ≈øervice of the Empire, after having mu≈øtered them in the pre≈øence of the Emperor, cau≈øed them to march directly towards Kremps, to joyn the Imperial Forces, re≈øolving in per≈øon to follow them with all convenient ≈øpeed, when in the mean while General Dunwalt, having notice that ≈øeven or eight thou≈øand of the enemy were fallen into the upper Au≈øtria, he ≈øtrengthening him≈øelf with what Forces he could, marched with all diligence to oppo≈øe their progre≈øs, in which they made ≈øuch deva≈øtation that the like had not been formerly known, and ≈øuch was his good ≈øucce≈øs, that coming upon them at unawares, he put them to the rout, killing a great many of them, and re≈øcuing two thou≈øand Captive Chri≈øtians, whom they had taken in their progre≈øs, as al≈øo recovered a great booty.

Upon notice of the≈øe and the like ≈øucce≈ø≈øes the Imperial Confederates ha≈øtned their quotaes to joyn the Army, and for that purpo≈øe a Conference was held at Hasford on the 27 of July between the deputies of the Elector of Brandenburg, the Bi≈øhop of Bamberg and Wittenberg, the Princes of Han≈øpatch, Bereith, &c. wherein it was re≈øolved that the Troops of Franconia, de≈øigned for the a≈øi≈øtance of the Emperor ≈øhould ≈øet forward on the ≈øecond of Augu≈øt, and that the Bi≈øhop and Chapter of Wirtzberg ≈øhould for this ≈øervice furni≈øh out two Regiments of foot, and that four Companies of the Guards of the Elector of Brandenbxrg, over and
above his Quota, as likewi≈øe a Regiment of new rai≈øed hor≈øe ≈øhould be imployed again≈øt the Turks under the command of the Velt Mar≈øhal Dorfling.

Fre≈øh Troops daily arriving at the Imperial Camp, and the be≈øieged receiving new a≈ø≈øurance of being ≈øuddenly relieved, would by no means admit of any Treaty with the Turks, but generou≈øly ≈øcorned their pretended advantagious propo≈øals, which not a little inraged them, ≈øo that on the 30 of July they renewed their Battery with great fury again≈øt the Red Tower and Scotenburg Gate, continually thundring again≈øt them for twenty four hours, when having made two ≈ømall Breaches they came on with great re≈øolution, but were by the ≈øallyers as ≈øtrongly oppo≈øed, whil≈øt the Cannon from the Tower, Battlements and Flankers, made ≈øuch de≈øtruction among≈øt them, that they retired in great di≈øorder, but whil≈øt the Imperiali≈øts hotly pur≈øued, their own Cannoniers not di≈øcerning them from the enemy, by rea≈øon of a great mi≈øt that fell about that time, divers of them were killed by the great ≈øhot, and ≈øcarcely was the mi≈øtake rectifyed e'r the Turks, being ≈øeconded with ≈øix Regiments of Janizaries and Spahies returned upon them, ≈øo that the fight on all ≈øides was continued with great fury; each being de≈øirous of honour and victory, but at length the Turks not being able to endure the Force of the Chri≈øtians retired, yet being commanded to a third a≈ø≈øault, and receiving fre≈øh ≈øupplies from the Camp, they again returned, ≈øtrongly po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øing the works out of which they had been before beaten, „Äà‚óä„Äâ Count Staremberg accompanyed with divers Commanders and one thou≈øand foot ≈øoldiers coming upon them, ≈øo incouraged his weary men,
who had been in the heat of the action, with little intermi≈ø≈øion for the ≈øpace of ten hours, that a greater ≈ølaughter then ever was made, and in ≈øine the Turks put to flight.

During the≈øe three a≈ø≈øaults not le≈øs then eight thou≈øand of the Be≈øiegers were ≈ølain, not fewer then three thou≈øand of the be≈øieged. So that the Vi≈øier fearing the noi≈øomne≈øs of the Carnage might oblige his men to for≈øake their Trenches, again de≈øired a Ce≈ø≈øation to bury his dead, but it would not be granted, but rather the ≈ølaughter Increa≈øed by another ≈øally the be≈øieged made, whil≈øt their Cannon on the wall being skillfully mounted, overthrew the Turks Cannon, and ruined their new Battery again≈øt the Scotenburg Gate.

This great City; in the ≈øiege of which the Turks have been alwayes unfortunate, had not above ≈øixteen hundred Gari≈øon ≈øoldiers in it the morning of the day wherein it was be≈øieged, and but lightly ≈øtored with provi≈øion; but ≈øo providence ordered it that in the ≈øight of the Turki≈øh Army, two great Ve≈ø≈øels laden with provi≈øion coming up the River Danubius, got into the Port ≈øafe ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ , and the Garri≈øon augmented by ≈øixteen thou≈øand hor≈øe and foot, left there by the Duke of Loraine as he marched through the City in his retreat, nor were the Burgers and Religious Orders le≈øs diligent in the defence thereof then the ≈øouldiers, being by the women animated thereto, but more e≈øpecially by the unwearied example of their Governour, who ≈øpared no pains nor labour, being ever ≈øeen in places of greate≈øt danger, ≈øacrificing his re≈øt and ≈øafety to the Publick good of Chri≈øtendom, and pre≈øervation of his Country, of which that great City is the only Bulwark; and ≈øince
money was mo≈øtly wanting, he borrowed it of the Mona≈øteries and Religious foundations, promi≈øing to refund it with great intere≈øt if the City ≈øcaped falling into the hands of the Infidels, or if it did, ≈øo be it, his Life and Liberty remained to him they ≈øhould lo≈øe nothing.

By this time the King of Poland having mu≈øtered his Army under the walls of Cracovia, and furni≈øhed him≈øelf with all things nece≈ø≈øary, divided it into two parts, and by ha≈øty Marches advanced to joyn the Imperial Camp, now ≈øwelled big by the daily arrival of fre≈øh Troops, and longing to be in action, which the Grand Vizier well noting, u≈øed all diligence in running his Trenches chiefly tru≈øting to his Mines, many of which being ≈øucce≈ø≈øefully ≈øprung, ruined a great part of the outworks, but ≈øuch was the indefatigable endeavours of the be≈øieged that they made them for the mo≈øt part good e'r the Turks could enter, and frequently by digging deep ≈øounds, laying pibbles upon drums, and ≈øetting ba≈øons of water near the walls, di≈øcovered their Mines, which they countermining fru≈øtrated, de≈øtroying the Miners in them for the mo≈øt part, or taking thence the powder

Teckely imagining that the Duke of Loraint dur≈øt not adventure out of his Camp for fear of being attacked by the Ottoman Forces, he with twenty five thou≈øand Turks and Hungars advanced towards Presburg with a de≈øign to be≈øiege it, of which the Duke having notice, drew out a ≈øtrong power, and came upon him ≈øo ≈øuddenly, that in great di≈øorder he retired, but the Imperiali≈øts falling in with his rear, cut off ≈øix or ≈øeven hundred of his men, taking a like number pri≈øoners, together with a thou≈øand Waggons laden
with Ammunition Tents and Provi≈øion, as likewi≈øe burnt a great number of Boats and Casks, brought to pa≈øs a branch of the River Danube, ≈øending after him the Prince Lubomirskie with the Poli≈øh Hor≈øe under his command, to prevent his falling into Moravia, who ≈øtill cut off his rear, ≈øo that from the beginning to the end of the action fifteen hundred of the Rebels and Turks were ≈ølain and taken pri≈øoners, with the remainder of which Army Teckely pa≈ø≈øed the Waag, where the Turks, ≈øeparating from him returned to the Gari≈øons, out of which they were drawn, yet the Duke ≈øtayed upon the banks of the River Merck, two miles from Presburg, till he had certain notice thereof, when increa≈øing the Gari≈øon of that City he returned to his Camp near Kremps, where upon his arrival he had certain notice that the King of Poland was within ten dayes March of Vienna, when to a≈ø≈øure the be≈øieged thereof, he ≈øept a per≈øon into the City, who ≈øafely arrived there, and thereby gave them great incouragement, in≈øomuch that ≈øallying about twilight, they m ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ e a terrible ≈ølaughter of the Janizaries, that were lodged in the Counter≈øcarp, taking divers or them Pri≈øoners, who being ≈øtrictly examined, confe≈ø≈øed the Turki≈øh Camp was exceedingly weakened through ≈øickne≈øs and want of provi≈øion, but e≈øpecially ≈øince the Convoy that was on it's way thither fell into the hands of the Imperiali≈øts.

During the≈øe Transactions a body of Turks a ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ Tartars fell into Croatia, burning and de≈øtroying all before them, leaving no manner of cruelty unpracti≈øed; to oppo≈øe which Torrent, the Vice-Roy gathered the ≈øtrength of the Country, and
coming upon them at unawares, put them to flight, following the execution for ten or twelve miles; Nor was the ≈øucce≈øs of Count Le≈øhly le≈øs again≈øt another party of the Infinels, who greatly infe≈øted the Frontiers „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ Countrey of Moravia, from whom, after he had put them to flight, he took 78 Waggons laden with the ≈øpoils of tho≈øe Countreys, and became the deliverer of divers Chri≈øtians, whom the Infidels were leading fa≈øt manacled into mi≈øerable Bondage.

The Duke of Loraine fearing by this time that the be≈øieged were in ≈øome ≈øtrait for that he had received frequent advice that the Turks pre≈ø≈øed the ≈øiege with great re≈øolution, he to be the better ≈øatisfied ≈øent another per≈øon into the City, who in the habit of a Hungarian Ru≈øtick ≈øafely pa≈ø≈øed the Leaguers, and under the ≈øhelter of the night ≈øwam over the Danube, giving upon his arrival the ≈øignal agreed on, and the ≈øame night returned with advice that the be≈øieged were not as yet in any want either of men or provi≈øion, though the Turks almo≈øt without intermi≈ø≈øion kept them in action, but that which anoyed them mo≈øt, was the bloody flux, of which thirty or forty died in a day.

The Turks having advice of the daily increa≈øe of the Imperial Forces now encamped at Enzesdorf, nearer then before to the City of Vienna, to the great incouragement of the be≈øieged, the more eagerly pre≈ø≈øed the ≈øiege, the Vi≈øier no way ≈øparing his men, but rather as a man de≈øperately re≈øolved rather to lo≈øe the whole Army than go whithout that City, who≈øe Keyes he had promi≈øed to ≈øay at his Ma≈øters feet. He on the twelfth of
Augu≈øt cau≈øed the Cannon from all the Batteries to fire upon the Scottenburg Gate and Red Tower, commanding at the ≈øame time ≈øixteen thou≈øand Grecians, Hungarians, and people of other Nations ≈øubject to the Ottoman Scepter, to make the Attack, and enter the Breach by plain force, promi≈øing a 1000 Sultanas to him that ≈øhould plant the fir≈øt en≈øign upon the Wall, which ≈øo animated them that like men altogether carele≈øs of their lives, they threw them≈øelves into the Ditch, where many of them were impailed upon ≈øtakes, and although a ≈øtorm of ≈ømall ≈øhot, and the loud mouths of eighty pieces of Cannon, plyed them with fearful ≈ølaughter, yet they pre≈ø≈øed on and lodged them≈øelves in the ditch, but upon the be≈øiegeds ≈øallying and ≈øpringing a Mine, they were driven thence, and although great ≈øcarcity raged in the Turki≈øh Camp, in≈øomuch that hor≈øe-fle≈øh was accounted dainty fare, and an Ammunition loaf of bread ≈øold at five Dollars, yet the proud Ba≈ø≈øa ≈øent again to ≈øummon the Governour to ≈øurrender, but the Me≈ø≈øenger not being admitted to enter the City, or parley with ≈øuch as kept the outworks.

That evening a Letter from the Governour to the Duke of Loraine which the Turks had intercepted, was ≈øhot into the City, and another paper in it ≈øigned by the Vi≈øier, admoni≈øhing the Governour timely to provide for his own and the peoples ≈øafety, and not by ob≈øtina ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ly re≈øi≈øting Irritate the Grand Signior, but this ≈øo little availed that in ≈øtead of a „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ in the Morning the be≈øieged ≈øallyed, and „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ part of the Counter≈øcarp, of which the Turks had po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed them≈øelves, drove them „Äà‚óä„Äâ , and ≈øeconding it by ≈øpringing a Min ‚Ä¢ which „Äà‚óä„Äâ their Retreat,
mo≈øt of them were cut in pieces, yet in this action divers of the be≈øieged fell.

The better to incourage the be≈øieged a party of Imperial hor≈øe ≈øent by the Duke of Loraine, pa≈ø≈øing a branch of the Danube, landing upon a ≈ømall I≈øland, fell upon three hundred Turks, put mo≈øt of them to the ≈øword, and with incon≈øiderable lo≈øs on their own part, returned with two hundred Camels laden with provi≈øion, and other nece≈ø≈øaries which good ≈øucce≈øs was ≈øeconded with certain Intelligence to the King of Polands advancing with all ≈øpeed, and that for ha≈øte he with his hor≈øe was four dayes march before his foot, as fearing the ill con≈øequences that might happen by the lea≈øt delay.

The Turks finding the time grow ≈øhort in which they mu≈øt of nece≈ø≈øity win the City or fight a Battle, they pre≈ø≈øed the ≈øiege with more eagerne≈øs, e≈øpecially upon their receiving a ≈øupply of men and provi≈øion; So that on the fourteen, fifteen, and ≈øixteenth of August they advanced thei works in the Ditch, and lodged them≈øelves upon the point of the Ravelin, form whence they had been before beaten, gave two fierce a≈ø≈øaults, in which they were repul≈øed, with great lo≈øs on either ≈øide, and on the ≈øeventeen day, being about to make another attack, the Governour and Count d' Souches ≈øallyed, and having beaten them back, ruined their works in the Ditch, making a terrible ≈ølaughter of ≈øuch of the Infidels as they found too ≈øar advanced, and then returning into the City with the Turki≈øh En≈øigns, the en≈øuing day they made another ≈øally wherein they beat the enemy from the point of the Ravelin, which they had again po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed, killing about three thou≈øand of them, in
which Action Count Staremberg was wounded in the head with a ≈øtone rai≈øed by a Cannon buller that fell three yards ≈øhort of him, and the Count de Souches received a hurt in his leg by an arrow from one of the Trenches, yet like men devoting their lives to the ≈øervice of their Countrey, they pre≈ø≈øed on couragiou≈øly, animating the ≈øoldiers to pur≈øue the flying enemy, which they did, making great ≈ølaughter, and recovering almo≈øt all the works they had po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed, till ≈øuch time as eight thou≈øand Janizaries advancing, the Turks thereby encuraged, returned furiou≈øly, in≈øomuch that the be≈øieged not being able to ≈øtand the charge, under the favour of the Cannon, retreated into the Town, where during the fally the breaches had been made good, yet in this action they lo≈øt two thou≈øand men, and among≈øt them divers officers of note, yet as men not di≈ømayed, finding ≈øtill the Turks incroach, they on the 22 ≈øallyed again, and finding the enemy had made great lodgments in the Ditch, beat them thence, and ruined their works, and the better to hinder their approaches made ≈øeveral retrenchments within the Ba≈øtion, which the Turks perceiving, threw that day a great many Bombies into the Town, which killed twenty men, and fired ≈øix or ≈øeven hou≈øes, playing very furiou≈øly from four Batteries, and by this time having po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øee them≈øelves of divers ≈ømall I≈ølands in the River Danube, as it were blocked up the City by water, yet the Governour re≈øolving to hold out the ≈øiege to the la≈øt extremity, rather then to deliver the City, or come to any capitulation, he on the twenty ≈øixth made another re≈øolute ≈øally, in which coming to handy blows with the enemy, and the fight continuing hot for the
≈øpace of eight hours; the lo≈øs was great on both ≈øides, yet in the end the Turks were beaten out of all their works, and three great Mines of theirs being di≈øcovered, the powder was taken out, but ≈øo much Chri≈øtian blood was ≈øhed in the action, that the Garri≈øon was greatly weakned, and great was the want of Officers, for ≈øince the beginning of the ≈øiege were ≈ølain one Colonel, five Lieutenant Collonels, thirty Captains, and thirty eight Lieutenants, be≈øides divers that dyed of the bloody flux, and were at that time ≈øick, in≈øomuch that it was re≈øolved not ≈øo frequently to Sally, but u≈øe all endeavours to di≈øcover the enemies Mines, and Subterranean Traver≈øes, and thereby defeat them, and that it was convenient to give the Duke of Loraine notice of the ≈øtrait the City was in, whereupon the Count d' Starenberg wrote a Letter, wherein he gave his Highne≈øs to under≈øtand as followeth.

body.head: The Copy of a Letter from the Count D' Staremberg Governour of Vienna, to the Duke of Lorrain, bearing Date Augu≈øt 27th. 1683.
body.p:
I Ca≈øt my ≈øelf at your Highne≈øs feet, humbly to thank your Highne≈øs for the good Opinion you were plea≈øed top expre≈øs towards me in your la≈øt Letter: Your Highne≈øs knows I am perfectly devoted to you, and that I de≈øire nothing more pa≈ø≈øionately, than by my Humble Service to render my ≈øelf worth thereof. Since my la≈øt, the Enemy have ≈øprung ≈øix Mines in the Ravelin, which after having repul≈øed them,
we pre≈øently repaired, and ≈øtill we keep our Retrenchment. The Enemy have hitherto gained no more than a Lodgment on the point of the Ravelin: We ≈øearch above and under ground, and have Countermined three of the Enemies Mines and ≈øprung two Mines, which had good Effect, and would have had better, were our Miners braver, and more expert; but being people that we are fain to get together any way, it is impo≈ø≈øible to make them re-enter the Mine, if they hear the Enemy at work. In the Counter≈øcarp the Enemy have likewi≈øe ≈øprung three Mines near a Retrenchment: Pali≈øadoes which we ≈øtill maintain to cover the Caponiers,
we have in the Ditch, and though the Pali≈øadoes were in ≈øome places beaten down by the la≈øt Mine, yet our men maintained the Post with their Swords in their hands, until ≈øuch time they were made good again, and „Äà‚óä„Äâ ≈øtill keep it. The Enemy have „Äà‚óä„Äâ other de≈øcents in the Ditch, one towards the Ba≈øtion Lebeland, and the other towards that of the Court; out of which our men under the favour of the fire we gave, did in open day di≈ølodge them, whil≈øt others commanded for that purpo≈øe filled up their works, and burnt their Gabbons and Galleries, ≈øo that they mu≈øt begin anew: But Sir, it is time to ≈øuccour us, we lo≈øe a great
many Men, and many Officers, more by the Bloody Flux, than by the fire of the Enemy; for there dies almo≈øt every day ≈øixty of this Distemper: We have no more Granadoes, which were our be≈øt defence; our Cannon are partly ≈øpoiled by the Enemies Battery, and partly burst e're they had endured fifty ≈øhot, by rea≈øon of the ill Temperament of the Mettal; and the Enemy finding they cannot with ≈ømall numbers lodge them≈øelves in the Ditch, make great Lodgments on the Counter≈øcarp, and keep a great number of men there, to make Extraordinary Efforts. For the rest it is certain the Enemy have lo≈øt, and do dayly lo≈øe a great many
Janizaries, and that they have a great multitude wounded, and no le≈øs number ≈øick of the Bloody Flux, which rages among≈øt them. They have ≈øeveral Camps far enough from each other, and may be ea≈øily beaten if they stay for. Your Highne≈øs, which I do not believe they will do: They are not at pre≈øent 60000 fighting men, and one Camp may be beaten before it can be a≈ø≈øisted by the other. We expect your Highne≈øs with the greate≈øt impatience, but I not ≈øo much to be delivered of this Siege, as to have the Honour to a≈ø≈øure your Highne≈øs of the Re≈øpect which I am, &c.

postscript.head: Po≈øtcript.
postscript.p: AT this Instant my Miners Informed me, that they hear the Enemy working beneath them, under the Ba≈øtion of the Court. they mu≈øt have pa≈ø≈øed the Ditch under ground, and there is no more time to be lo≈øt.

div.p: This advice greatly alarmed the Imperial Camp, not ≈øo much for fear as with a de≈øire immediately to march, and adventure the relief of the City, at the hazard of a Battle, whereupon the Duke a≈ø≈øembled the Great Commanders in his own Tent, laying before them the Danger the City was in, and at the ≈øame time informed them that he was re≈øolved to attempt its relief, though at the hazard of Battle, which re≈øolve was liked by mo≈øt, though ≈øome there were, who alledged that ≈øeeing the King of Poland was near at hand, it was not ≈øafe to attempt any thing till both Armies were joyned, and that it was better to hazard the City, than the Army, upon which the ≈øafety of the Empire depended. Notwith≈øtanding the Army had expre≈øs orders to March, and had ≈øet forward the next day, had not advice in the mean while arrived in the camp from the Count d' Staremberg, informing his Highne≈øs that he had di≈øcovered and defeated the great Mine under the Court Ba≈øtion, and di≈ølodged the Turks in the Counter≈øcarp, by ≈øucce≈øsfully ≈øpringing two Mines, which had inabled him to hold out much longer then he ≈øuppo≈øed, therefore he earne≈øtly be≈øought his Higne≈øs not to hazard any thing ra≈øhly.

This advice altered the former re≈øolves, e≈øpecially upon notice of the near approach of the Polonian Hor≈øe, yet the Scouts giving information that a great body of Turks and Hungarians, were on their way to joyn with the Be≈øiegers, under the leading of the Ba≈ø≈øa of Buda; Prince Lubomirskie, with the hor≈øe under his command, and three Regiments of Imperial Dragoones, advanced to meet them, upon whom coming unexpectedly,
after a hot di≈øpute he put them to flight, with the ≈ølaughter of four or five thou≈øand of them, taking many pri≈øoners, and a great Convoy of Provi≈øion and Ammunition, ≈øuch as e≈øcaped flying to Gran, New-hau≈ø≈øel, and other adjacent Garri≈øons.

The Prince was no ≈øooner returned with the≈øe ≈øpoiles to the Camp, but an Officer arrived from the King of Poland, a≈ø≈øuring the Duke of Loraine, that the King was with thirty Regiments of Hor≈øe within twelve or fourteen hours of the Imperial Camp, whereupon his Higne≈øs di≈øpatched the Margrave of Baden, to complement him upon his arrival, and immediately drew up his Army in Battali ‚Ä¢ , to receive him at the head thereof, re≈øolving with all convenient ≈øpeed to give the Turks a Cami≈øado, and withal ≈øent an expre≈øs to the Emperour lying at Pa≈øhaw, to let him under≈øtand the Polonian Kings Aproach, and his re≈øolves to fight the Ottoman Army with the fir≈øt advantage offered, as al≈øo in what danger the City of Vienna had been, and was in, giving at the ≈øame time ≈øtrait command to every officer throughout the Army to be in readine≈øs to March upon ≈øix hours notice.

The Imperial Camp being put into good order, and a re≈øolution taken to fight the Infidels, the King of Poland on the 29 of Augu≈øt arrived with all his Chivalry, and was immediately followed by the remaining Troops of hor≈øe, his foot being at the ≈øame time advanced, ‚Ä¢ within 8 „Äà‚óä„Äâ
German Miles of the Imperial Camp; when upon his arrival, having been by the Margrave congratulated. fir≈øt in the name of his Imperial Maje≈øty,
and then in the name of the Duke and all the great Commanders of the Army; he encamped about a mile on the left of the Imperiali≈øts, and the next day a Tent Royal was pitched between both Armies, where the King, the Duke of Loraine, the Electors of Bavaria, Saxony, and divers other Princes met, and after pa≈ø≈øing the u≈øual complements, fell to debate about the nece≈ø≈øity of their attempting to rai≈øe the ≈øiege, and that no time was to be lo≈øt in that affair, for that the Garri≈øon Souldiers from twenty thou≈øand were by divers di≈øtempers and the fire of the enemy, reduced to five or ≈øix thou≈øand, nor were they ≈ølow in coming to a re≈øolve upon the Method to be ob≈øerved therein.

During the≈øe tran≈øactions the Turks ince≈ø≈øantly Battered the City of Vienna, labouring earne≈øtly in their works, as being greatly de≈øirous to take it by ≈øtorm, and more e≈øpecially to ≈øave the Grand Vi≈øiers oath, who had ≈øworn by the head of Mahomet, to take it or dye under the walls, though afterward it appeared he had not ≈øtrength enough to acquire the former, nor courage ≈øufficient to keep his word in the latter, for ≈øuch was the courage of the be≈øieged, that ≈øallying they beat the enemy once more out of all their works, but by the former ≈øallies and ≈øickne≈øs as before mentioned, they were exceedingly weakned, in≈øomuch that they de≈øpaired much longer to maintain the City, again≈øt the a≈ø≈øaults of ≈øuch ≈øo numerous and re≈øtle≈øs enemies, ≈øo that on the fourth of September Count Staremberg at the earne≈øt intreaty of the Burghers, cau≈øed it to be ≈øignified from St. Stephens Tower by ≈øetting up a purple ≈ølag, the ≈øignal appointed that the City was in
di≈øtre≈øs, which being perceived by the Imperial Scouts, they acquainted the King and Duke, who thereupon drew up in Batalia, and ≈øent out four hundred hor≈øe, to ob≈øerve whether the enemy had po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed the Forre≈øt, and immediately ≈øet forward with the whole Army, altogether full of courage and brave re≈øolution, de≈øiring nothing more than to be in action with the Infidels, when in the mean time, the City being pre≈ø≈øed by two ≈øucce≈ø≈øive a≈ø≈øaults, and a Mine ≈øprung on the point of the Ba≈øtion, the Be≈øieged on the eight, made another ≈øign from the Tower of the great danger they were in, and ≈øent out two Enginiers to inform the Duke of Loraine thereof by word of mouth, the better to ha≈øten relief before the enemy had fini≈øhed the new Batteries within Mu≈øquet ≈øhot of the Scottenburg Gate, but one of them was taken by the Turks Scouts, and the other ≈øuppo≈øed to be drowned in pa≈ø≈øing the Danube.

But the General having received ≈øufficient notice (and dreading of what evil con≈øequence the lea≈øt delay might prove) in good order pa≈ø≈øed the Forre≈øt of Vienna, which the Turks to their great di≈øadvantage had no where Fortified. But coming to the hill of Calemberg on the 11th. of October found it ≈øtrongly po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed; whereupon a ≈øquadron of hor≈øe, and eight Regiments of foot a≈øcended to Attack the enemy, and remove them from their po≈øt, who charged up with ≈øuch bravery, that after a hot di≈øpute, the Turks gave ground, and retired in great confu≈øion to a ≈øtrong retrenchment, made at the bottom of the hill towards their Camp, where being reinforced, they made a ≈øtand, and again di≈øputed it, but being cut off in great numbers by the ≈øhot of the Imperial
Cannon, from the hill, on which by this time they were planted, and charged on the one hand by the Polonian hor≈øe, and on the other by the Bavarian foot, they after an hours di≈øpute were driven thence, leaving an open field to the Imperial Army, which under the Duke of Loraine, advanced in good order to charge the Ba≈ø≈øa of Sieli≈øtra, who as the forlorn, with ten or twelve thou≈øand men, advanced, though in ≈øome di≈øorder, by rea≈øon his Ranks were broken by the ≈øhot from the Hill, which played furiou≈øly, till the Dukes ≈øquadron of hor≈øe under the leading of the Margrave of Baden, cau≈øed the Ba≈ø≈øa, after a ≈øharp di≈øpute to retire to the main Body, when the Duke of Loraine with fifteen thou≈øand hor≈øe, taking the advantage, fell into the left wing, with ≈øuch fury, that the Turks in ≈øpite of the re≈øi≈øtance they made began to fall into di≈øorder, when as the King of Poland charging on the Right, where the Vi≈øier ≈øought in per≈øon, great was the ≈ølaughter, till in the end, the Turks as men di≈øcouraged and di≈ømayed, began to ≈øhrink together, which the Margrave of Baden perceiving, drew off to relieve the be≈øieged, and by ≈øix in the evening po≈øted him≈øelf before the Sotch gate, yet did not the Turks in the Trenches de≈øi≈øt from a≈ø≈øaulting the City, but like men de≈øperately re≈øolved to lo≈øe their lives, or win it, but the ≈øcale of victory, by this time turning apparently on the Chri≈øtians ≈øide they being ≈øeconded by ≈øix thou≈øand fre≈øh hor≈øe made great ≈ølaughter, though the Ba≈ø≈øas laboured to encourage their men, and re≈øtrain their flight in vain, for by this time the King of Poland with his own Troops, and ≈øuch Imperial Auxiliaries as ≈øeconded him, having broken and quite di≈øordered the left wing, pierced
even to the flank of the right, which the Vi≈øier perceiving, and finding his Forces two weak longer to maintain the field, fled with the formo≈øt, whil≈øt the Confederate Princes followed, making great ≈ølaughter, having the execution of the enemy even till night came on, at what time they prudently weighing that the Turks, as their cu≈øtom is, might Rally, returned to charge the Turki≈øh Camp, in which were left almo≈øt all the Janizaries, but the King of Poland breaking in with great fury, after a hot encounter po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed him≈øelf of it, putting ≈øuch as he found there to the ≈øword, whil≈øt the like ≈øucce≈øs had the Margrave of Baden, who perceiving the Turks Army in rout, entred the Trenches and Works, of which (a≈ø≈øi≈øted by the be≈øieged, who at the ≈øame time ≈øallyed) he ≈øoon became Ma≈øter, cutting in pieces the Turks, that were left to continue the ≈øiege, and po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed him≈øelf of all the Cannon, Mortars, Powder, and Granado ≈øhells, entering the ≈øame evening the almo≈øt ruined City, which was by ≈øixty dayes clo≈øe ≈øiege brought to ≈øuch di≈øtre≈øs that the mo≈øt couragious doubted to defend it again≈øt another a≈ø≈øault, which the enemy was about to make, had they not been prevented; for in it at the time it was delivered, no more then four thou≈øand five hundred fighting men were found, and all the works ≈øo ruined, that it was left in a manner open to the approaches of the enemy; the Cannon ≈øpoiled, the powder ≈øpent, and the ≈øtore of Provi≈øion brought to its ultimate Cri≈øis.

This ≈øo great and memorable victory, obtained over the daring Infidels on the eleventh of October, and the City Vienna intirely le≈øt at liberty; all
that night the Chri≈øtian Army ≈øtood in Battalia in the enemies Camp, to prevent any ≈øurprize, and the next morning the King of Poland, to whom the greate≈øt ≈øhare of plunder fell, found be≈øides the Tent-Moveables and hor≈øe of Caera, Mu≈øtapha, the Prime Vi≈øier, the value of a Million of Crowns, the greate≈øt part thereof being in ready money, nor did any ≈øouldier want to furni≈øh him≈øelf with ≈øomething; there were likewi≈øe found 80 pieces of Cannon, be≈øides tho≈øe on the Batteries, three thou≈øand Quintals of Powder, and Provi≈øion ≈øufficient for the ≈øub≈øi≈øtance of the Turki≈øh Army for three moneths, and immediately thereupon the Poli≈øh hor≈øe were ≈øent out to pur≈øue the flying enemy, who upon their return brought into the Camp many pri≈øoners, ≈øome Camels laden with Tents and Provi≈øion, and two great pieces of Cannon, the one drawn by ≈øixty, the other by eighty yoak of Oxen, having likewi≈øe cut off a con≈øiderable number of ≈øuch as Marched in the Rear, and pur≈øued them almo≈øt as far as Alba-Regalis; ≈øo that in this Battle the Turks lo≈øt ten or eleven thou≈øand of their be≈øt men, and by the bloody flux and fire of the be≈øieged thrice the number.

The City of Vienna. thus freed, with the lo≈øs of not above three hundred Chri≈øtians, on the twelfth of October his Imperial Maje≈øty, who had re≈øided at Pa≈ø≈øaw, to give nece≈ø≈øary Orders, in all great and weighty affairs, came to Cui≈øier-Newburg, whither the Count Staremberg, and the chief Officers of the Garri≈øon went to pay their duty, and were received with great re≈øpect, when on the fourteenth the Emperor came up the Danube in his Barge, and arriving at the Port Royal, was received at his landing by the Electors of Bavaria
